product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
In the fragrance section of Macy’s I sprayed this on a test strip. WOW! Loved it. Before leaving I sprayed it on my arm. From opening to the dry down I loved it. Had nothing like it in my collection. Two weeks later I put down $130 to purchase it. A little much but the quality matched the price. My wife was not as excited about it but said it was nice. (She’s rarely excited about me purchasing another bottle of cologne though.)

My first wearing I put too much on. Had to wash it off 1hr later. Wore it a second time the following week. Did not overspray but it was cloying about 90 mins. Knew I had a problem at this point! Did not wear it for 7 months. Did I purchased a cologne different from the one I tested in the store? Put it on today to see if my nose would welcome it again. Nope! Hate from the first spray.

I did it again. Purchased without buying a decant to give it a few wears. This is especially important with strong scents of this sort. A potential love or hate scent. One you can quickly grow tired of.

Unless you KNOW this is a scent DNA you like, sample patiently. Give it a 4, 5, 7 wears. It is a hard reach even if I still liked it. I am feeling guilt and shame and regret over this purchase.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
Guilt is not something that us, perfume afficionados, should deal with in this hobby. We shouldn't feel any form of guilt for liking or not liking a certain fragrance that maybe is highly acclaimed in the community, by friends, family, etc. Tastes differ, and so do preferences. And in regard of Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme, one of my father's favorite fragrances, I hardly feel as impressed by the scent. But I do see why it garnered so much attention.

The opening is properly intoxicating, with an immediate blast of orange blossom floral prowess, with a clear bitter facet and a potent white floral/jasmine sweetness. Warm, spicy, even slightly cinnamon-like nutmeg and pimento aid in keeping that white floral potency in check. But to no avail; the orange blossom eventually wins the round.

At the heart, things turn interesting, but not exactly in a good way. Under the load of orange blossom, a prominent powdery orris appears with a creamy/buttery accent as well. Hints of violet are also detectable. The osmanthus does seem to add some sweet fruitiness to the blend, but it's still unable to dethrone the main protagonist. However, it's at this point that I get a pretty strong hair fixative spray vibe which mildly burns the back of my neck as I breathe in. It's got that sharpness and chemical attributes which instantly reminded me of hair fixative. And while it's not enough to ruin or overpower the whole scent altogether, it's not trying to hide either.

As we reach the base, that hair fixative vibe does diminish, but the orange blossom is still very much present. Some patchouli brings a generous dosage of muskiness, but also sort of a medicinal nudge and a sweet undertone attributed to patchouli. The vanilla and benzoin do not seem as strong, bringing just a mild ambery warmth and powderiness. All things considered, I'm not the biggest fan of the scent structure, but it does gain a few extra points for being more unique on the designer scene than most other modern day entries. The overall blending and quality are nothing extraordinary, derived primarily from that hair fixative vibe that I get, which to my nose, doesn't hint at excellent quality, but rather at intoxicating attention-garnering composition. But then again, maybe my nose is betraying me by being too sensible (skill issue).

Speaking of attention-garnering, you'll be getting plenty of that with Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme, just there's a 50/50 chance that you'll get positive reactions. On my skin, this fume lasted for well over 24 hours. On my second wear, it even surpassed 34 hours. And I see that great longevity is largely the case for most people with Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme. So no worries there - this has plenty of fixatives to offer that performance, which might also be responsible for that chemical hair fixative vibe that I get. In terms of projection, I got a very solid 3+ feet for the first hour, with a very noticeable sillage. It would slowly mellow down to 2 feet across 2-3 hours, and eventually it would settle on less than one foot of projection by hour 6-7, still noticeable if you got close enough, e.g. sitting next to me.

While Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme is definitely guilty of having a load of fixatives for increased performance and intruding people's noses, it's not guilty of being Swiss Army Knife-level versatile. And that's primarily because of that performance. The scent itself is also, as mentioned, a bit more polarizing/intoxicating than your average designer (mostly due to that sharp fixative facet), so it limits the number of sprays. As a leisure wear, for clubbing or for more formal events, this would fit just fine. For office or school, or any context where you don't want (need) to stick out, keep the sprays on the lower side.

Verdict, your honor? Guilty of intoxication through the usage of fixatives. That's largely the only thing I find Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme guilty of. Do I find it guilty of being an irresistible scent? No. Do I find it guilty of being a high-quality creation? No. Do I find it guilty of huge success? Well... yes, it appears so. Amongst designers, Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme does manage to stand out, and I believe its slightly more polarizing (but not challenging) nature, paired with the performance are what drive the sales of this juice (and, well, the brand name too, as always). Do I believe it is a good value fragrance? Not really, but it could've been worse. Do I recommend it? Not really. So, therefore, I sentence Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme to a lifetime in my "decent at best" category. But what say you, people of the jury?

Overall Rating: 6.9/10

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
This fragrance, is simply put, in another league when it comes to the basic designer fragrances. Gucci guilty elixir is to put it lightly the best thing you’ll find in a normal beauty store right now, this does what sauvage elixir should do but doesn’t.

To start, Guilty Elixir is like walking into a dinner party this beautiful orange blossom that you can almost feel the petals of greets you at the door and as you make your way to the dining room, as you sit down you notice the nutmeg and pimento take their seats on either side of you. However they don’t overstay their welcome they simply introduce themselves to you and fade into the background. As their friend calls them to sit farther down the table.

At the heart of this fragrance, they finally have the the majority of guests together and sat down at the table. Just before the food comes out as you’re talking to the osmanthus that had taken the place of nutmeg you feel something tapping on your shoulder, you turn to see who it is and time screeches to a standstill as you come face to face with an orris butter note that almost suffocates you with its presence, however, you don’t mind. This note is far and away the star of the show and the reason the party is so lively. The orris butter stays rest of the time this fragrance is on you, and as the evening progresses you choose to bring your dessert of vanilla and benzoin garnished with a bit of patchouli outside behind the house to deck where you notice a small creature laying on a bed next to a doggy door. It’s a small sort of cat from what you can tell and as you take a seat in one of the chairs it crawls into your lap.

Scent 10/10 - This score is relative to not only what this fragrance has parallels to but also to designer fragrances in general, this is at least “private blend” status and if not better as it not only deviates from the entire line its a flanker of, but its also the best thing outside of any private lines in the world of designer fragrance. Though it isn’t the best fragrance of all time, it is, in my opinion, completely unchallenged when it comes to current designer fragrance.

Versatility 8/10 - comfortably a cold weather fragrance but can easily be pulled off if the wearer is dressed maturely or at least if it’s later in the night.

Sillage 9/10 - No complaints, stronger than is required for a “night out” fragrance.

Performance 10/10 - set and forget. No need to worry about reapplying period, its a night out/date night fragrance and by proxy you don’t need it to last more than 5-7 hours yet it’ll still be comfortably projecting a couple feet around you by the end of those 7 hours.

Value 10/10 - This really should be a designer price but its at an entry level niche price and completely fine being there, not hard to find for around 100-140 but if you can’t find it then its to me worth every penny of retail.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
You know, I almost feel like this fragrance found me not me it. Me and my girlfriend decided, we’ll get each other fragrances as gifts this holiday season. I decided on Elysium, which ive been wanting to get for a very long time, but never did get and she decided on Instant Crush. Than one day we went to the store and I saw this fragrance. I remembered George (YouTuber) talking about it and he said its reminiscent of Reflection man, but smoothened out with vanilla. So i was like ok im gonna spray it on, I did while we where leaving and didn’t smell it right away, because I definitively remember eating a pretzel (lol), when I finally did smell it, I was so surprised this smell I was smelling was coming from a designer house. Spicy, slightly fresh, smooth woods smashed with some of the best smelling vanilla I’ve smelt. I think Gentle Fluidity Gold is also a great vanilla, but this to me in the drydown smells like youre eating an amazing vanilla ice cream on a beach. You’re smelling the trees around you and the summer breeze…Absolutely Outstanding… I was back to the store 4 times to wear this and in the end chose it over Elysium. Now lets compare it to Reflection man. I have tried Reflection before, really wanted to make it my signature, because the iris and overall floral nature of the fragrance really spoke to me. Only problem was, that it went so sharp on my skin it started giving me headaches. This has that same powdery iris, along with the fresh like spices, but it doesn’t go sharp, the vanilla rounds up the whole story, making it so much more enjoyable for me. You might think that the vanilla will take away some of the versatility, … I would disagree. I think this is still perfectly wearable in all seasons. This fragrance man… all im gonna say is that ever since I’ve gotten it my other fragrances, have been getting a lot less wear because I wear it so much. That spicy, yet fresh opening that fades into the vanilla, but still retains the iris… ahh outstanding this to me is a bonafide 10 and my signature scent I’ve been searching for.

10/10

Update: I got my first bottle for Christmas 2023, its now 20th of June 2024 and I just got my 2nd bottle, because i finished the 1st. Lovely scent and extremely versatile, by far my girlfriends favorite scent on me also.
Still a 10/10

Update: the 3rd bottle just came in a few days ago. Still absolutely love it.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
This is a nice fragrance with a great performance: eternal longevity and very good sillage: room filler in the next two hours or so

It smells really like a Quentin Bisch creation with a DNA similar to Le male Elixir but more polished and, refined and mature

The dry down is very pleasant: vanilla dominated: I sprayed it in the morning and I still can smell it 12 hours later: it stays on cloths even longer:

My main issues are:
1- bottle design could have been better, but who cares
2- The price point is a bit high for a designer brand

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
I heard a lot about this fragrance in the community and the fact that it was a departure from conventional men's designer perfumery; I decided to try it out the next time I was in Macy's and boy, did it blow me away.

The first whiff is undoubtedly white floral, with some peppery spices added to make it a bit masculine. This is not a bland clean soapy neroli like in Neroli Portofino EAU DE PARFUM or Myslf. It is dirty, almost animalic, and Floral with a capital F. Then a boozy note kicks in, which I believe is the osmanthus. I think this is one of the most underrated notes in perfumery, and I love almost every fragrance in which it plays a big role. The scent is rounded out by powdery orris butter and a touch of sweet vanilla. What surprised me, and isn't really in the note listing, is a bit of a leathery edge in the base notes which makes this fragrance undeniably masculine, even though the spine of the scent is white floral and sweet. Overall, a complex and immensely enjoyable fragrance from beginning to end. Although it bears a resemblance to Reflection Man, it is more sweet and also has that earthy, leathery edge that Reflection lacks.

Now we come to the pricing. 183 USD for 60ml is practically unheard of in the mainstream designer space, but I think it is well worth it. With Gucci Guilty Elixir de Parfum Pour Homme (an absolutely ridiculous name), you are getting niche-level quality, niche-level longevity, and niche-level complexity. When compared to the Amouages and Xerjoffs of the world, $183 is not a high price.

Lastly, what is with the bottle? Channeling AVGN a bit here, but could they have picked another color than puke green? The questionable marketing and bottle design aside, this is a great release, probably the best designer release of 2023 for me. Definitely not a blind buy.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: Floral & little citrusy opening with a hint of spices and nuts and a soapy undertone. Beautiful dry down with a heavy creamy vanilla note but not in a gourmand way. Insane performance, prominent for well over 8 hours & i can still smell it on my skin over 24 hours later. Also a compliment magnet, almost all my coworkers said it so good. Yes it is overpiced a bit but the quality and performance is there so that at least maked up for that.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
Ever since I've tried Gucci, I was only a fan of certain fragrances they have. "Made to measure" & "Intense Oud" being an example.
.
So I was skeptical about this one & so far I must say, I like it for the most part. It's pretty unique in its own way, the heavy dose of Orange Blossom, nutmeg & Orris butter make it pretty stand alone. It's creamy, it's fresh, spicy & a tad sweet behind it which almost feels green. U get the vanilla'ish kind of base in there pretty quick which I think is the combination of that & Orris butter that's making it so creamy & not so synthetic.
.
When I first sprayed it on, I felt like I was smelling something similar to YSL 'Myslf' & that was because of the Orange Blossom I was getting. But they are quite different. Like this is much more thick, subtly sweet & seems to have a bit of a waxiness to it. As to where, MYSLF is more synthetic, with the Ambroxan base. & also woodier, with the florals.
.
This scent has slight levels to it. & if you think it's too subtle, wear it once without layering it because I feel it has staying power. The longevity must be where the magic happens. I could wear this, day or night but would prefer a slightly moderate night, 45° - maybe around 60° weather. It can work in the cold maybe if you wear more on the cloths where it will probably stick better. This could also be worn at work just not putting on so much because it'll probably annoy ppl in such close range to have to constantly get whiffs of it. But I do think it's a mass appealer so, whatever, experiment, see what works.
.
I think women will think a guy has range when he wears this scent. It shows not everything has to be dark or synthetic like Paco rabanne or constantly worn like Dior Sauvage. Check it out that Gucci bandana
* video review below for your viewing pleasure

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
It's 2024 (this launched in late 2023 but bear with me) and a designer label is releasing a big, dense, soapy and pungent white floral for men with the edges slighty rounded off with touches of vanilla. Is this real life? Here, a dowdy scent profile was given a rejuvenation treatment by one of the current industry's busiest perfumers Quentin Bisch and it did not turn out too shabby. In fact, this is rather good. The skanky aspects are still restrained enough to not completely scare off the target audience (which I assume to be men in the 20's and 30's) but they are noticeable enough to enjoy them and to commend Gucci for going off the beaten track.
The asking price is a bit bold for a 60ml but it's marketed as an "elixir", so they have an excuse at hand already.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
This elixir flanker has gone to a different direction and smells very different from its predecessors just like what Dior did to Sauvage Elixir. Gucci Guilty Elixir is dense, woody, resinous and masculine floral. Think of Amouage Reflection Man with added resins and vanilla. A very complex and unique fragrance. This is what an elixir should be. This is trespassing into niche territory so be sure to sample first.

Projection - Strong
Longevity - 10 hours

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
Very smooth velvet like pistacie and thats all I smell. I could never get my self to buy but ended up collecting 10ml before deciding it was not for me.
The smell is so pleasing when i spray it on my friends and it can change some ones personality.
In the end it proved to feminine and IRL i only smell it on eastern women.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
“Guilty Elixir de Parfum PH” (what a name…) pleasantly surprised me. Not because the “Guilty” label is out of favor with me; there are enough positive outliers in this very broadly defined and colorful “family.” Much more because I am greeted by an enormously potent orange blossom apple, which can best be described as a wonderfully creamy blend of heavyweight fragrances like “Reflection Man,” “Fleur de Male,” and “Gaultier ²” - which should place enough weight on its shoulders, power in its lungs, and pressure in its fragrant argumentation!

At first, I thought this was a hardcore marzipan charmer. Too different, too surprising, too special this elixir seemed at the beginning. My brain was rattling. But then it dawned on me in half-minute intervals that it wasn’t marzipan I was smelling, but unbelievably concentrated orange blossom. Green, zesty, garnished with an even greener apple. A small miracle of technique and a feast for both the mind and the nose. Still clearly detectable the next day. And yes, I shower. Nevertheless, this is a stubborn little beast in gum-green. Buttery iris and vanilla form the backbone and provide enormous smoothness. Upfront, the orange blossom flares and hisses like it’s on steroids, yet still appears soft enough. An extremely floral yet powerful punch that could almost pass as niche and still offers nothing in terms of accessibility for the refined perfumista. Unusual and great to clearly declare it as “Pour Homme.” Rarely have I enjoyed smelling an intense powerhouse so much. Again and again. It could develop into a cult favorite and a secret tip. But today’s man needs to have more delicate eggs to pull it off casually. Nice Hulk with a bouquet of flowers. Kisses poison and gall.

Sillage: subtle is different
Bottle: green and toxic, good and round
Longevity: easily over 10 hours on my wrist and in a cloud around me

Conclusion: interesting Guilty variation with intense radiance and almost entirely new DNA - orange blossom overkill!

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Gucci Götterfunken or House of Gucci flexes, dude!
review_content: Elixirs are like underwear: You can never have enough of them. Jokes aside. Gucci plays the elixir game and wins, I boldly claim. When I sprayed this fragrance on my wrist in winter, I wasn't immediately impressed. However, as I left the store and was at the train station, I felt like the entire station hall was smelling of "Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme | Gucci." And...

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Best Elixir on the Designer Market?
review_content:
In 2023 or 2024, it is trendy to launch an elixir on the market. Dior has set the example with Sauvage, and several designer brands have followed suit. Paco, Gaultier, Boss, here Gucci, and soon YSL Y will also have an elixir. Most of these elixir additions are significantly more expensive and have almost niche prices. Of course, one should be skeptical when planning to acquire such a designer. At least the elixir versions from Dior and Gaultier were, in my opinion, great successes. Gucci has rather taken Sauvage as a model: 60ml for a hefty price of around €160. Unfortunately, this Gucci is currently only available in 60ml, which makes the price quite high compared to a more economical 100ml bottle, which is now also available for the Sauvage Elixir. If you search online, you can already find it for around €100, which is also quite expensive for a designer, especially since there are already quite a few niche fragrances available at good prices.
Designer or not, I think this Gucci is great! I can't really connect with the brand, neither fashion-wise nor with most of the fragrances. After "Guilty Cologne pour Homme | Gucci," this is only my second from this brand in my collection. I found some quite okay, but I never really warmed up to them, especially from the designer line. This Guilty Elixir is by far the best from this brand and also one of the best designer releases in recent years. Of course, also because I am a big fan of Reflection Man and because this one specifically leans towards "Reflection 45 | Amouage." If someone is just looking for a cheaper clone, they won't save that much here, and the fragrance DNA is by no means 1:1, which I also find good. I have both Reflections, and this elixir is a great addition.

The perfumer is once again Bisch, who also created a great elixir for Le Male. I greatly appreciate his works, and here he has once again hit the mark. This time in collaboration with Gracia-Cetto, who is also an experienced and good lady in the business.
The packaging is absolutely unworthy of the price and simply abysmal. Not Gucci-like, and in terms of style, one could have at least taken a cue from Dior. Loveless green cardboard, loveless green bottle, average sprayer. There is nothing luxurious here, but the content counts.

The top note clearly leans towards the 45, but not as opulent and heavy. The fragrance is very easy to wear due to a pleasant freshness that resonates from the start. A nice floral freshness that is not too feminine and also reminds of Amouage's DNA. The slightly powdery freshness from iris is also very present here. Overall, in the first hours, you get a cheerful and stylish fragrance with a lot of orange blossom and a pleasant subtle spiciness that you can actually wear for any occasion. The powdery iris also provides a great clean touch with sensuality. The sweetness from the base sets in a bit earlier and reminds of a touch of Pegasus from Parfums de Marly, though here it is of course not as heavy. But a slightly metallic sweetness is quite sexy and lovely. A pleasant Ambroxan freshness is also very nice and far from being disturbing. Even though there are some similarities to other fragrances, this is, for me, a standalone scent. While it is inspired mainly by Reflection 45, it is a great fragrance that can also be worn without any problems in the height of summer.
The performance is really superb, and this is a prerequisite for this price. The sillage radiates extremely well, and the fragrance should last into double digits.

Overall, for me, it is a great year-round fragrance that can be easily integrated into everyday life and also unfolds its wonderful sensual effect in the evening. A fantastic blend of niche quality and a crowd-pleasing designer. The DNA is definitely very unique for the designer sector and stands out wonderfully for people who do not want to smell like everyone else.
For a blind buy, it is too expensive, as you can already get 100ml Reflection for under €200, and here 60ml even on sale for €100. I think it is worth it, but everyone should decide for themselves.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: At first, I wasn't a fan of it, as it reminded me a bit too much of Reflection Man. However, when you spray it on the skin, a somewhat different picture emerges. A sweet, floral perfume that appears clean and elegant. In the drydown, it becomes softer, gentler, and smells at the travel altitude of the fragrance as if you were coating powdery, white almonds and sweet vanilla with a hint of leather. Here, several drawers open: An idea of almonds like Pegasus or something floral like Reflection Man. The latter, however, goes in a fresh/floral direction. Yes, it is another elixir, but probably perfect for anyone looking for a sweet, clean, and serious date scent that can also be worn on a regular winter day.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: One of the best designer fragrances at the moment! / A lighter alternative to my beloved Reflection Man (also 45)/ CLONE?
review_content:
Hello everyone,

You came out of nowhere, suddenly you were there, and I really didn’t know what to make of it...

What do I mean by that?

I actively follow the releases from the house less and the last few years have mostly been so-so... and the last really GOOD ones are already a few years back, so I didn’t know what to expect... especially since I didn’t even know (I’ll be honest) the fragrance pyramid. So better - in terms of being unbiased, one can hardly be.

A friend from the souk gave me a sample and enthusiastically said to me "BENNY YOU HAVE TO TEST THIS".... and I thought to myself totally (") unenthusiastically, yeah okay...

But I didn’t know what I had in front of me...

A little backstory to what’s coming next. I have a certain history with Le Mâle EAU DE TOILETTE (my entry into the world of fragrances in 1999) and Reflection Man (it was my first niche fragrance in 2012 and my wedding fragrance in 2021) and shortly after came Reflection 45 and I’ve known Darley for over 10 years, just as a side note!

The Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme has something of everything, fougere, floral, clean, pleasant, almost zesty (it feels that way in the top note) only it is much lighter than all 4 (mentioned) and a SHORT SUMMARY of it.

In the upscale designer segment (in a price range with Chanel and possibly Dior), it is, in my opinion, one of the best fragrances you can buy for up to €105! And I say this honestly and with full conviction.

Testing it is truly a must,
especially if you like the direction and the H/S...

Now to the performance:

The current batches of Reflection Man (recommendation until 2021), the current Reflection 45 unfortunately also (recommendation until February 2022, not later), with Darley only until 2020 and the more recent Le Mâle EAU DE TOILETTE is almost a disgrace, is well known, so please only until 2020! And the Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme easily outperforms all of them, with Reflection 45 it is on par, and THAT is more than remarkable!

CLONE?

NO!

But you can tell that the house looked left and right on the market and took inspiration. It’s already their style and not a CLONE!

When + where!

Always!

I say this very rarely, but it applies here. It works always, fits every occasion and season.

And so far (tested for 2 weeks) the feedback has been AMAZING!

A rising star....., I wouldn’t be surprised!

If I really weren’t convinced, I wouldn’t recommend it to you!
(At least for a test)

And now have a nice day/evening or whenever you read this review, best regards, Benny
_______

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Is anyone interested in my collection?
review_content:
Felice, also known as Duftbunker, drew my attention to the Elixir. At first, I thought, what am I supposed to do with a designer fragrance since I've only been into niche scents for years. In the evening, the recommendation popped back into my mind, and I sought out other opinions on Parfumo. You know how it goes. After reading the good reviews, I set out to find the Gucci and wondered why it was so much more expensive compared to other designers. Anyway, today we're in a generous mood, so why not? Other niche fragrances were much more expensive, so into the cart it went, and I paid. P.S. The Rasasi Hawas Black also had to join in.
Today the fragrances arrived, and I eagerly unboxed the Gucci. A couple of sprays on my right arm and a sniff. A smile spread across my face, and I thought, yes, there it is, my typical Gigolo powdery Italian DNA. It becomes a bit creamier over time without losing its DNA. Che Bello.
Damn, does the designer smell good. I found my signature scent after years of searching; this is it. Who needs niche? I don’t want my collection anymore, just this Gucci. In the meantime, I sprayed Black Hawas on my left arm and thanked Felice for the recommendation via WhatsApp. While writing, the best scent I’ve ever smelled came to my nose. I was perplexed and thought, what a combination. I’m not a fan of layering, but this time it had to be done. Gucci meets Black Hawas. The result has been an atomic Italian powder DNA paired with a dirty deep pineapple for hours now. OMG, this is it. I will combine the two bottles, 50ml to 50ml, and that will be my signature. Does anyone want my collection?

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
...of smelling damn good.
For a long time, I have been searching for adequate and truly good substitute perfumes for "Reflection Man | Amouage." I found nothing. Not even in "Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme | Gucci." What I did find, however, is a truly intense and wonderful scent experience revolving around the RM DNA. The Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme is sweeter and spicier, overall louder, more seductive, and thus also more intrusive than the "Reflection Man | Amouage," and it comes closer to "Shiyaaka Silver / شياكة | Khadlaj / خدلج" than to the RM. In doing so, it surpasses the Shiyaaka in all respects, especially because it is significantly sweeter, more embracing, and rounder.

I find the top note to be very, very strong. It reminds me of "1 Million (Eau de Toilette) | Rabanne." Sweet, spicy, somewhat synthetic, but in a very good way. The scent is mature and far from any Talahon tendencies. The opening lasts surprisingly long, and eventually, it becomes creamier, softer, but by no means light. On the contrary, the spiciness and depth remain, just with less Neroli punch, but rather with Neroli background music.

Unfortunately, it is now summer, and the scent does not hold up well in temperatures above 30°. It becomes almost overwhelming, if not for you, then for your environment. Everything below 25° is optimal. The best perception probably occurs at a comfortable room temperature of around 20°.

So, anyone looking for a truly great designer fragrance with excellent longevity and sillage, who tends to be extroverted or even extravagant, will find this scent to be a perfect choice. Just don’t wear it in the office. It’s simply too strong and omnipresent for that. Three sprays are already a statement. In leisure time, when going out, in the evening, or on cooler (summer) days, the scent is a sure bet. And generally, it’s more of a special occasion fragrance than for daily use.

It definitely does not replace "Reflection Man | Amouage." The Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme scent stands on its own. A family member, like the more impulsive Italian cousin, but by no means a brother or even a twin. It has nothing to do with "Le Mâle (Eau de Toilette) | Jean Paul Gaultier," even if they could be roughly placed in the same direction. How do people come up with such comparisons?

I would advise against blind buys here, especially for those looking for an RM substitute. You will be disappointed. In my opinion, there is currently no adequate good substitute or comparison for the RM; even a "Shiyaaka Silver / شياكة | Khadlaj / خدلج" cannot come close.

There has already been enough said about the bottle. The sprayer is good, the bottle is solid, nothing I would place right at the front of my shelf; the juice is what matters most here.

Maybe I will continue searching, maybe not. If such gems emerge during research, the RM will not be replaced but rather complemented by joyful new discoveries.
In the meantime, I will continue to be guilty of smelling damn good.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Versatile All-Rounder in Niche Attire for Special Men
review_content:
My little fragrance wardrobe is to retain the title of Signature, in order to generate the desired aspect of olfactory recognition: I am not a collector, but merely a user! For the current cold days, I have found two outstanding scents that ideally cover the areas of everyday life and special occasions. For the latter, it has become the Tony Iommi Monkey Special by Xerjoff, which has shone brightly during the Advent season, and for daily business, it is the Elixir by Gucci - perhaps the best among the successful Elixir variants from other houses. It has even displaced my Layton Exclusif. The Elixir comes in a niche attire, primarily created by its richness in facets rather than artistic edges! This is worth a review.

The orange blossom is initially very present, but it comes across as significantly sweeter than sharp neroli representatives; the extraction of the same resource is known to differ. The smooth, slightly sweet orange note is therefore never fresh for me and already feels warm and caressing with the spicy, almost nutty component. Here, the exciting advantages become apparent: the masculine base DNA, later complemented by a bright leather twist, is olfactorily formulated with a nearly feminine aspect by the lovely white flowers. Just something for special men. The feminine facet is also underscored by the vanilla in the base, which, in combination with the orange blossom, enhances a sweetness that still beautifully caresses the masculine, nutty spice, bright leather, and dry wood. Highly intriguing!

The mentioned leather twist is a subject of controversial discussion here. I definitely perceive it clearly, and it is certainly produced by the osmanthus flower, which has this characteristic. On the other hand, I hardly smell the iris; at least not in the lipstick style, but at most as a slightly powdery lightening of the composition. The base and the late dry down are already dominated by an ambered vanilla, which somehow still retains the building blocks of the fragrance progression. My other pick for winter is very "patchouli-heavy," so I am sure I am blind to this note here. Speculative.

Overall, this varied composition is also a real powerhouse. I get through the entire day excellently, receive positive feedback, and it gives me a few extra percentages of confidence. I can even smell it on my clothes the following day. I really like the sprayer: nice and crisp, and it doesn’t release a ton of juice. I like that just as much! The bottle, however, doesn’t appeal to me as much. A magnetic cap would also have been nice for the price. Speaking of price: I got it for just under 110.-, which is certainly justified; the retail price is quite steep. I even believe that the ml price of Reflection Man is better, but I don’t feel like doing math right now. It’s the weekend.

Due to the mentioned richness in facets from a positively interesting composition of masculine and feminine notes, the Elixir comes in a niche attire: orangey-floral sweetness combined with nutty spice, a great bright leather twist, and an ambered vanilla in the base. Always in the background, it is also plump + dry instead of juicy + fresh. I’m trying to look a bit beyond the horizon. If there had been one or another barbershop note anchored, I could even imagine it as a successful neo-fougere. In this composition, however, that thought goes too far for me.

The Elixir by Gucci is truly successful and versatile. A great signature for special men. Only in the height of summer and at the gym do I see it as out of place, as it already has a pleasant warmth that is quite powerful. Special men here is meant in a value-free way; it would be better to say, a special type of man. He is not a leather-jacket bad boy, but still fits due to the contrast with a fashionable all-black outfit. Generally, he is better dressed than casual and somewhat more suitable for clubbing, dates, and Netflix & Chill than for the office, where I also find him very suitable. Only sports are out for me, as he is never refreshing. He fits a confident man who is not only interested in fashion but is also eloquent and open-minded. So the label 'special' in the title should rather be interpreted as 'versatile.' The classification by age is more difficult. He does seem very modern, but at the same time has something established: serious and cultivated in the background, but interpreted very playfully.

The statements regarding the classification highlight the numerous controversies, which make me evaluate the Elixir as very exciting, almost insignificant, and certainly not suitable for every man. Nevertheless, it is a compliment-getter, even if I cannot give a buy recommendation here. Still: Definitely test it! I will celebrate it until late spring. Cheers.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: The Gucci Guilty Elixir is a very strong floral, sweet fragrance. In the opener, it immediately starts with its floral notes, and these floral notes remain with us throughout the development of the scent. After a while, the fragrance becomes a bit spicier and sweeter. Thanks to the orange blossom absolute in the top and heart notes, the Gucci Guilty Elixir has this floral touch; the sweetness comes from vanillin, and the spicy notes come from nutmeg. Despite its strength, the Gucci Guilty Elixir smells very pleasant and will not cause headaches for those around you. The longevity is very strong, and even after several hours, the scent is still very noticeable. The sillage is also very good, and one is usually perceived positively. The Gucci Guilty Elixir can be worn in any season, although I would not wear it in the height of summer due to its sweet and spicy notes. The Gucci Guilty Elixir can be worn during the day as well as in the evening. In my opinion, it fits excellently when one is dressed smartly, such as in a shirt or a suit, and then sprays the Gucci Guilty Elixir on themselves. In terms of price, it is quite expensive for a designer fragrance, and currently, it is only available in 60ml. I find 60ml for just under €100 to be quite expensive for a designer fragrance. All in all, a very good release from Gucci, and the Gucci Guilty Elixir has definitely earned the name addition "Elixir."

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: A Touch of Gucci in Trieste, complex, refined scent
review_content:
Although not Florence, but as long as it's Italy.
I tried this Gucci yesterday in Trieste, the brand fitting for my Italian vacation, due to positive feedback here on Parfumo.

One thing upfront: it’s unfortunately not quite my scent, but it really has a lot to offer. Of course, one expects a lot here, as it is positioned a bit higher in the designer fragrance price range.

But let's take it step by step.
First, I sprayed it on cautiously because it projects well, and yes, I can confirm that. Good thing it was very warm outside; I would have stood out immediately indoors. The longevity is also very good; it lasted over 12 hours on me. But that’s to be expected, Elixir de Parfum.

The opening starts sweet-spicy with a lot of nutmeg and a slightly orangey-floral touch. However, the nutmeg is unfortunately too prominent, and my nose immediately has the reflex to turn away when I get too close to the scent.

In my opinion, the top note is not very mass-appealing, but here it shows that Gucci doesn’t really care, as they follow their own, special path. Also, due to the price, it’s not a product for everyone. But that’s completely fine; mass appeal is not necessarily what moves me personally.

On the way from Trieste to Lake Garda, my partner had to endure it for several hours in the passenger seat; it wasn’t really her scent ;)
Don’t get me wrong, it’s really well made.

However, what came after 2-3 hours pleasantly surprised me. The bothersome sweetness loses its intensity, while the slightly orangey-floral remains, and it becomes woodier. The woodiness balances out the remaining floral aspect and brings the scent into better harmony.
It smells much better and more special to me.

Just Gucci quality, for which many are surely willing to pay the asking price.

Towards the end, vanilla and benzoin come into play. I actually like this sweetness; it rounds off the scent well and lingers as a base for a long time.

For me, it would have been worth the money if the top note didn’t linger on my skin for so long. An overall complex scent that, in my perception, has strengths in the heart and base notes & weaknesses in the top note.

I like the bottle; the color scheme fits the scent, and the spray head is fine. The bottle is also elegantly designed; you can see the attention to detail from the house of Gucci. Really well done.

I will test more fragrances from this brand because I was impressed by the fine tuning of the individual scent components.

Hopefully, the next Gucci fragrance will also catch me with all scent stages from start to finish…

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Great scent, but the bottle doesn't fit...
review_content:
Gucci Elixir pour Homme is truly a wonderfully beautiful fragrance. The first impression is fresh and spicy with a slight sharpness - really pleasant and not exaggerated. Then it becomes warmer and aromatic. The base is the highlight: Amber and patchouli give the fragrance a long-lasting, high-quality depth.

The longevity is top-notch - a few sprays easily last all day. The sillage is just right, not too overpowering, but you will definitely be noticed. Suitable for everyday wear or special occasions.

The only point that doesn't quite fit for me is the bottle. It doesn't seem as high-quality as the fragrance itself and doesn't reflect the elegant feel of the elixir. I would have preferred a design that better emphasizes the quality.

Overall, however, it's a really good fragrance that is worth its price. Anyone who enjoys elegant scents should give it a try.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
Fragrance description: In terms of fragrance category, it leans towards Reflection Man, but without being a true clone. The differences in comparison are that Reflection Man smells more natural, floral, and fresher than the Gucci. The Gucci is definitely sweeter and more synthetic. I prefer the Reflection Man in terms of DNA but find the Gucci scent quite nice as well.

Fragrance development: The scent starts fresh, slightly sweet, and somewhat floral. Later, it becomes increasingly sweeter and spicier. The freshness also disappears quite quickly, and the sweet and spicy notes take over accordingly.

Compliments: This is my wife's favorite scent. However, I haven't received any compliments yet. (Excluding family and close friends)

Longevity: The scent lasts about 9 to 10 hours on the skin. On clothing, about 12 hours. I spray this fragrance about 4 to a maximum of 6 times.

Sillage: Unfortunately, I can only smell the fragrance on myself for the first few hours. At some point, I no longer perceive the scent. However, one time I sprayed the fragrance at 6 AM and was back home by 6 PM, my wife asked if I was wearing the Gucci scent. Even though I become olfactorily blind to the fragrance at some point, it is still present for others. It's not beast mode, but it plays at the top.

Versatility: It’s actually suitable for everything except in high summer, as the fragrance lacks the lightness for high temperatures. Otherwise, it's suitable for everything.

Bottle: It's okay but unfortunately nothing special. I really like the green. The cap and the sprayer are also just okay for the price.

Price/Performance: I find the retail price of 164 euros for 60 ml a bit too high for what you get. However, one must not forget that it is a perfume concentration with a higher fragrance oil content.

Overall assessment: I find the fragrance successful. For me, one of the best releases in the designer sector. However, I would only repurchase the fragrance if it’s on sale. When you calculate the retail price for 100 ml, you can already get fragrances from Parfums de Marly or Xerjoff. Nevertheless, it is a successful release, even if I don’t see it as a masterpiece. 8/10 overall from me.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: As I indulged in my hobby at the Galleria Kaufhof department, treating my nose to pretty much every fragrance for enjoyment as well as learning, it eventually got used to so much that it could hardly be surprised anymore. Passing by the Gucci stand, a friendly salesperson drew my attention to a new arrival, which was immediately sprayed on a test strip and held under my nose....

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: For me, one of the best designer releases of recent years. The Guilty Elixir beautifully captures the Reflection Man DNA and adds this lovely spicy twist. A flawless daily wear and the price/quality ratio is impressive. It lasts on my skin for a minimum of 7-8 hours and on clothes, it easily survives the entire workday in the office. Compared to Amouage Reflection Man, the...

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Gucci Guilty Elixir: A fragrance that sends orange blossoms on steroids!
review_content:
A completely different kind of "Elixir" from the scent like Sauvage Elixir, and yet I like it very much, as do the people who have smelled it on me. This one is the best of all the Elixirs that came out after the Sauvage Elixir. A beautiful floral scent, although it doesn't change much during the drydown. Still, it has something ADDICTIVE about it, as I keep catching myself sniffing my arm and can't get enough of it. This Gucci strongly reminds me of the floral fragrances from the 90s and 00s; I don't know why I associate it with that, but it gives me those memories afterwards. The scents/vibes of that time. It would fit well as a going-out fragrance in the nights/clubs of that era (also in today's time). In any case, I somehow connect that with it. This Gucci can be worn year-round and is more suitable for the cooler evenings in summer. The bottle is a bit ugly. But the inner values count, and the JUICE is what matters. I find this addictive sweet floral scent can be worn anytime and fits both for going out at night and during the day in casual clothes. It can be worn by a well-dressed gentleman (NO suit with tie) as well as by a casually dressed contemporary. A versatile fragrance in every direction. The Gucci Guilty Elixir is a scent that takes the senses on a fascinating journey. With its floral-sweet and spicy composition, it creates a perfect balance between elegance and intensity. The top note of orange blossom absolute, nutmeg, and allspice opens the fragrance with a zesty freshness that immediately grabs attention. The heart note of iris butter and osmanthus gives the perfume a buttery smoothness and a subtle floral quality, while the base note of ambrofix, vanillin, and patchouli provides a lasting warmth.

The longevity and sillage of the fragrance are impressive, making it an ideal companion for special occasions.
Gucci Guilty Elixir is a scent suitable for both everyday wear and special moments, always leaving a lasting impression.

The longevity is a 9/10
The sillage is an 8/10 and initially strong, but after some time it diminishes a little and is not as intense as at the beginning, yet still noticeable. An all-around successful fragrance that finds its friends over time and has already found (me among others). Simply a top fragrance.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: Hey everyone, this fragrance review comes after testing Gucci Guilty Elixir. First of all, I don’t own the full bottle, but I can evaluate the scent based on a sample. In my opinion, Gucci Guilty is Gucci's attempt to enter the "Elixir world" or the "Elixir trend." I really had no high expectations and didn’t even look at the fragrance notes before...

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: Hello everyone, today I would like to say a few words about the Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme. The green Power Man from Gucci has an extremely fresh opening and immediately evokes the image of a freshly washed white shirt. The Gucci is slightly floral and the wearer feels clean. I have the urge to put on a high-quality outfit. Over time (about after 1 hour),...

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Reflection so close yet so far away
review_content:
I learned about the Gucci here in the forum and had to test it, as I really like my Reflection 45. So today I quickly went to a perfume store and sprayed it on. At first, it didn’t remind me of RM at all; there was a note that stood out strongly and I didn’t like it at all, which lasted about 1.5-2 hours. After that, finally the Reflection came through and it was quite close to the whole thing, unfortunately sweeter and more synthetic. Now, towards the end, I feel like it’s getting warmer with a vanilla note and slight Reflection vibes; after about 6 hours, it’s quite close to my skin and approaching the end.
I like the candidates from Amouage much better. As a standalone fragrance, it’s really good for a designer and worth buying, but you should definitely smell it beforehand, especially because of the piercing initial note. However, the 60ml for €164 seems a bit expensive to me; around €100 would be justified.

Best regards

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: Your Majesty, You Forgot Your Orange Blossom!
review_content: One of the best scents from Gucci. A fragrance with class and style that radiates something truly noble. The star of this composition is an extremely clean and cheerful orange blossom that reveals its true potential at the heart. Closely woven in a powdery mist of elegance. The opening begins particularly softly with the somewhat dry aroma of nutmeg, which immediately...

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: when I first sprayed the fragrance, it almost bit my nose...kind of like a toilet block...but only for a few seconds...I think that was the nutmeg... after one...two minutes, I perceive a totally fresh orange that has also accompanied me for some time...when patchouli comes in, it becomes summery again... all in all, in my opinion, the price-performance ratio is great...I’m...

review_title: Gucci pour Homme I High School Edition
review_content:
Gucci pour Homme II is a pleasant, “generically” elegant and cozy designer fragrance, undoubtedly a tad inferior to Gucci pour Homme I, which shows a completely different (and superior) class and quality. But still, it’s nice. Number II is soft, easy going and to some extent a bit cheap; but it is also without doubts pleasant to wear, and that is always a plus in my book. It is basically built on some features of Gucci pour Homme I (you can feel the same synthetic cedar-incense accord), but all twisted with the silky powderiness of violet, a sweet-fruity tone, slightly creamy-lactonic too, and overall with a brighter and cleaner atmosphere. The tea note is really nice, and together with violet and tobacco creates a fresh (yet warm too), cozy, gentle feel of peaceful and sweet softness, almost plushy, well contrasted by a hint of leather (modern, finished, “posh”) and woody-peppery notes. Incomparable to the hyper-refined, adult, sharp and shady smoky woodiness of Gucci pour Homme I... but as I said, really pleasant and worth the low price. The combination of sweet-fruity notes and “pencil sharpener” cedar reminded me a bit of Balmain’s Carbone. Discreet, yet long-lasting persistence. Nothing groundbreaking, but solid!

6,5-7/10

Where do I even begin? Gucci Pour Homme II is such a lovely scent, a modish and fashionable breakfast tea. The bergamot and black tea blend remind the well-known Earl Grey, a top-of-the-tier timeless classic. Aromatic bergamot adds a refined tart citrus taste to the dark, full-lead tea with prized tiny silver tips!

I blindly bought a bottle because of the smoky notes. What a pleasant surprise! I would say a pretty linear fragrance, which is built around the preeminent black tea note, not a light white or lemon green tea you get in Bvlgari pour Homme EAU DE TOILETTE, rather a more oxidated and strong oolongs one like a dark English Breakfast tea. That note gives the scent an intense sweet caramel, malt, and mineral stone-like vibe, with oaky undertones. Despite the azure color of the juice, GPH II is not aquatic, not citrus, and not a sports scent.
I got to know of this fragrance when it was first launched back in 2007, but I was so skeptical about that, thinking it was yet another aquatic one in the universe, and despised it for too long. Oh, man, I was so damn wrong! Gucci pour Homme II is seriously so gorgeous and smells so good.

In the open, I get a fresh and clean burst of creamy bergamot blended with green violet leaves, which fades quickly and leaves a dark tea trail, with a tad of spicy cinnamon and a bit of sweet paprika. Well, my gut feeling is that it incorporates one of the best tea notes and blends it correctly with the herbal violet leaf and the sweet-smoky tobacco. That concoction creates a cool-warm effect, soothing, comforting, and slightly sweet.

Ultimately, I get the myrrh and the tobacco notes in the dry down, which accentuates the ruggedly masculine sexiness that I find intriguing. The perfume stays close to the skin, making it ideal for crowded places, but I don't see any issues with longevity. After several hours, if I smell my wrists, the fragrance is still over there.

GPH II is versatile. It works well in spring and fall when the weather is slightly warmer, and the bitter-aromatic myrrh gives its best. Excellent for office and casual day, evening, or a night out. Today was a pleasant cold spring day, and the scent went well with my skin.

To me, GPH II has something in common with Aura for Men, meaning that they are not one another replica, though they share the same vibe, and the blend of tea and tobacco are very similar.

-Elysium

~ If an understated sophisticated style is the image you project without the need to follow trends then this all-season tasteful tea masterpiece could be for you? If ever there was an example of "less being more" or rather just the perfect amount this is it! GPHII is a fresh and slightly aromatic Gent but also has the perfect hint of spice in his personality coming through. While the violet leaf opens the visit with a slightly sweet hello the cinnamon offers just the right amount of interest and softly spoken conversation to be a welcome guest in his subtle sillage. The pleasant stay of sipping tea ends with a hint of tobacco from his pipe and the woody notes waving good-bye leaving the host and all that have made his acquaintance quite satisfied.

Kind Regards, Plat ~

review_title: A true gentleman in the world of perfume
review_content: Gucci Pour Homme II is one of those scents you wear for personal enjoyment and may go unnoticed by anyone else around you. The black tea brings this fragrance to a lovely skin scent and it performs well in most weather situations. I am curious about using the shower gel and deodorant with this fragrance to see what may boost the projection (highly doubtable). It is unfair to compare this to the original Gucci Pour Homme which has be regarded as a much longed for classic thanks to designer Tom Ford's direction for fragrance. GPHII will please the fragrance lover who desires to remain inoffensive as well as achieve satisfaction solely in a skin scent. It will remain in my collection and fill in that spot where I do not care what to wear that day and yet want to remain anonymous by scent.

Wonderful fragrance... i smell mostly black tea, which smells heavenly.

It would be in my top 5 if it had a better lasting power and projection.

Smells very pleasant and unique. If you find it, dont think, just GET IT.

Definetely a must have. After GPH and GPH II there's nothing interesting by Gucci.

Thumbs up for this scent and big thumbs down for Gucci.

Updated January 2014

review_title: Proves Spiced Black Tea And Incense Go Fabulously Together...
review_content:
Gucci pour Homme II opens immediately with a beautiful violet note coupling with mild peppery spice. As the scent moves to the heart phase, the violet remains though in a subdued state with the early pepper spice now swapping places with cinnamon, the spotlight now focused on the scent's real stars, black tea and non-smoky incense. The overall accord turns slightly sweet soon after, as a honey-like accord slowly grows as time passes and remains through the finish. As it enters the dry-down, a very pleasant tobacco leaf and woody tandem emerge from the base as it joins the remnants of the heart accord to send off the scent. Projection is good and longevity is average at 8-10 hours on skin.

Gucci pour Homme II is a very pleasant scent on the whole. It is relatively fresh and slightly sweet, but it really is the black tea and incense that make the scent work. The overall accord just seems so smooth and easy to wear that the scent excels at versatility as very few will find it anywhere near offensive. If I had any gripe with Gucci pour Homme II it would have to be that it lacks in the distinctiveness department to some degree. That is really nit picking a very nice effort by Gucci on this one and should not put anyone off from giving Gucci pour Homme II a try. That said, for a bit more distinctiveness and performance in a somewhat similar vein (sans tea) folks may want to additionally sample LiquidNight by A Lab On Fire that is more accomplished, in my opinion. Inconsequential gripe aside, Gucci pour Homme II smells very good in it own right and earns a well-deserved rating of 3.5 stars out of 5.

review_title: Sensual black tea and spicy tobacco
review_content:
I am really impressed with Gucci's male fragrance range. I have loved each and every one of them, so much so that I've even considered wearing them myself.

Gucci pour Homme II is deliciously spicy, refreshing and sexy. It would make a fantastic all-year round scent, for all seasons and all occasions.

It's masculine yet subtly sweet. It opens with a green yet floral violet leaf note followed by an interestingly citrusy bergamot and spicy cinnamon composition.

Exotic spiciness is what makes this fragrance. The black tea note really brings out an exquisite uniqueness in Gucci pour Homme II.

Fresh yet warm, this fragrance tends to contradict my senses a little. One minute it's a comforting scent, the next minute it is rousingly sexual. The myrrh and the tobacco notes in the drydown really accentuate the ruggedly masculine sexiness that I find so intriguing.

The lasting power is excellent so there is no reason why I should not recommend this fragrance so highly.

Gucci Pour Homme II initiates with a tea and incense medley. Gradually, the pimento emerges but remains well-behaved in the background with the musk. There is a minuscule sweetness that might be coming from the cinnamon, but the overall composition is spicy and smooth. I can see why some are comforted by the scent, as there is a soothing warmth about it.

The floor manager at the local Ulta store has smelled a multitude of perfumes on me, and this one was easily her favourite. "Ooh! What is that?!" was her immediate reaction. She told me it was the best thing I've tested in her store. I had never seen her eyes so wide. :D

As projection is fairly limited on my skin, this seems well-suited for a nice, cool evening in close quarters. It has slowly moved into my favourites, as the soothing scent of Gucci Pour Homme II lasts all day and puts a smile on my face. I might even buy a second bottle while I still can.

Delicious.

wonderful smell of black tea, bergamot and tobacco. this could be my signature fragrance if it can do better on longevity and sillage. beyond these, this perfume's bottle can be used as a cannonball. 5 or 6 shots can tear down a wall.

This was one of my first fragrances, and it's still one of my favorites.

It's got a nice and subtle spice from cardamin, cinnamon, and tobacco, but the base is a slightly sweet black tea.

The bottle is very art deco. It's square, but the inner vessel has a heart like bulbous hollow. The light blue color of the fragrance is bright. The gold square cap tops it all off.

I wish I knew it was going out of production so I could grab an extra bottle.

Such a masterfully composed scent...

Tea, cinnamon, tobacco, woody myrrh, musk and a hint of pepper (maybe the pimento?) all swirling together to form a higher purpose. It's fresh, slightly spicy yet sweet, smooth and classy. Very subtle and calming, but this also makes for an excellent office frag. Also it's rather unique and the closest thing I've smelled must be Lalique's Equus where the woodiness comes from the cedar-like sequioa. Maybe even a tad of Burberry London lurking in the background with the tobaccco/cinnamon combo there.

The only downside of this beatiful scent is the weak projection, really a pity. Definitely sample worthy.

I am a smoker who wants my cigarette smell to blend with my cologne, instead of fighting them. Gucci Pour Homme II with its Tobacco leaf in the base notes had been intriguing for me as a spring/summer fragrance. I ordered a 10mL sample and the juice has this nice soothing babyblue color. The Bergamot is very short lived in my nose and I get the black tea and Cinnamon right away. The tobacco and musk in the base are subtle and excellently mixed. Another reviewer's description as an ambien or valium resonates with me, Gucci pour Homme II is like a chill pill. Performance, longevity and sillage are not the greatest but this is not an extrovert smell but an introverted one that I find soothing. I like it a lot, but I don't know of an occasion to wear it. I encounter the same issue as I do with Acqua Di Gio Profumo: an excellent mature scent but it's a calming downer. I do not find it elating and often don't reach for the bottle: Profumo I still like to wear on hot summer nights when I want to appear somewhat sharp, but with Gucci Pour Homme II I can only imagine wearing it to calm myself down for a nap in Spring/summer time. I can't think of a good (enough) occasion to wear it and I am not planning on getting this discontinued line.

Did I mention that I enjoy drinking tea? Preferably black tea, since childhood? I like it strong and malty, Assam for example, with a bit of cream or milk. For breakfast, for second breakfast, sometimes even after lunch.

And then there is the Earl Grey Special. This delicate, slightly bitter, lightly bergamot-flavored, and, well, tea-like tea from the delicatessen here in the neighborhood, which is always weighed out by hand from huge metal tins and filled into fine red bags by the lovely old ladies who run this shop. The one with those indefinable blue flowers in it, which smell so fine and give it an irresistible aroma. *This* I drink more consciously, a very special pleasure for me, preferably in the afternoon, without milk, with rock sugar or tea sugar, at the best tea hour, and indeed all year round, even on hot summer days. When I drink it, I feel light and warm, my thoughts take beautiful paths...

When I drink this Earl Grey, I think of Gucci pour Homme II. When I wear Gucci pour Homme II, I think of Earl Grey Special.

Gucci starts citrusy-soapy-muted, with a slight spiciness, a bit green. Very soft. The violet leaf sneaks in immediately and will from now on run through the fragrance completely with a very subtle, bright floral note, always supported by a delicate hint of cinnamon. This duo: violet leaf and cinnamon - dominates the character of Gucci pH II and gives it this fine aromatic quality permanently.

Here, L´Artisan's Tea for Two is mentioned as a fragrance brother, which I can personally understand, but Gucci pH II lacks any trace of smoke, which Tea for Two contains abundantly. Gucci remains thoroughly fine-bitter and soft, the latent bitterness is mildly fruity, it is fresh and warm at the same time, it is bright and friendly, not strong, smoky, or dark. It has something loving, gentle, feminine, and yet it is also noticeably masculine.

The floral note is not floral. The softness is not soft-boiled ;-). The feminine is not ladylike. The bitterness is not harsh. The tannins, despite their natural bitterness, are not fuzzy on the tongue (or in the nose). The fragrance has something of lukewarm, soft water, it envelops me with kindness and affection, or so it seems to me.

Towards the base, not much changes. Wood comes in, it is *naturally* a soft, light wood, not sharp, dark, or strong. Everything remains relatively close to the skin, but with appropriate dosing, Gucci pH II is also perceivable to the outside world, yet it never imposes itself; its beauty reveals itself in the moment you approach it lovingly -- its soft, deep beauty, which I like more and more the more often I get to experience it.
Yes, I have to admit: I do not want to do without it anymore, neither now nor later, it is at the top of my wish list. I also have nothing to complain about regarding its longevity - it is significantly better than one would expect given the rather close projection.

When I think about it, those little blue flowers in the Earl Grey Special must be violet flowers. For me, the circle closes consistently here, and Gucci pour Homme II is the true Tea for Two for me -- but that is another story... ;-)

In my mind, I have written this comment several times - now I just need to type it out.

With GPH2, what I have to say is quite short: He is an old companion, bought back in the day, not used up, given away. Silly.
10 years and 5 decants later, I got the double amount in the bottle - completely happy.

To the actual scent: it is linear and ends where it begins. I smell cherries and taste tea with milk. This seemingly simple recipe is very well executed: the composition is moderately complex and therefore remains carefree. Good for summer, good for winter - GPH2 sits on me like a second skin. This is how I want to smell. Definitely.

You have a meeting or are sitting in a lecture, it doesn’t matter. In the room, Aventus, Hermès, YSL, Dior, Guerlain are floating around. The rather attractive blonde woman with a tendency towards an annoying voice and standard chic style becomes quite nervous. She would love to cling to every single neck. She is dazzled by the sillage, just as she is dazzled by many things in life. She can’t take it anymore and asks the first guy for the name of his perfume. At exactly 4:00 PM, however, it’s time to clock out, because Taff starts at 5:00 PM.
The brown-haired sensual woman, with an unusually masculine self-confidence, who is not liked by many women because she has disconnected from the girly world, enters the room. She gets along better with most men than with women. Her presence makes weak men nervous and envious female colleagues jealous. She catches a whiff of your scent as she passes by. Your eyes meet, and for 2 seconds, there is eye contact. She wants to know the name of the perfume only when she sees it in your bathroom.
Understatement. Gucci Pour Homme II.

Ah, Gucci Pour Homme II, even the bottle gave me the feeling right after acquiring it that this bottle belongs firmly in my collection. And indeed, this fragrance quickly turned out to be the cornerstone of my collection, a fallback scent that one can always rely on - just without the aftertaste of a last resort.

For Gucci Pour Homme II makes few mistakes: the scent is distinctive and unique, pleasantly transparent and yet warm-hearted. It conveys unpretentious elegance. It is timeless.

Earl Grey fans will probably love this fragrance, as especially in the opening, the strong tea aroma playfully combines with bergamot. The first seconds are a tea explosion; initially, the tea pulls back a bit, but already provides the solid foundation present throughout the entire fragrance journey, which initially serves the bergamot and the unusually soft violet. One can enjoy this sovereign yet still spectacular opening for a good twenty minutes. It simply smells really good.

As the scent develops, the black tea returns to the forefront, this time in its pure form and not as Earl Grey. At this stage, there is quite a bit of minimalism - only a hint of cinnamon joins the tea. Both remain silent together for a while, but this silence is in a way an eloquent silence, a communal silence and by no means a communicative stiffness. Tea and cinnamon know what they have in each other.

In one point, I must disagree with the prevailing opinion here. It is often mentioned as sweet tea with milk - my nose does not attribute the sweetness to the tea, but I also have no better answer (perhaps still the violet?). The milky note also seems to me to be clearly distinct from the tea; here I confidently point to the musk, which gives Gucci Pour Homme II a pleasant warmth. Nevertheless, this fragrance is primarily clear and transparent for me. This is not a good-night tea.

In the final phase, tobacco makes its appearance, gently softening the sweet side of Gucci Pour Homme II. Here, the fragrance becomes recognizably masculine for the first time, albeit in the softest way imaginable.

Perhaps my fragrance description sounds like a boring perfume - but I want to highlight one aspect separately: Gucci Pour Homme II, despite all its everyday suitability, transparency, flattering warmth, and elegance, is a very sensual fragrance that, in my opinion, works excellently in an erotic context. This sensuality is not pornographic; it does not push, but it does demand attention from time to time. Additionally, I believe Gucci Pour Homme II has a strong unisex tendency.

The longevity and scent cloud volume of this perfume are often criticized, and indeed I had the same experience at first: three or four hours of great joy, then it was already over. At some point, I tried using a bit more (around six sprays), and now I am almost sure that the spray head of this pretty bottle simply releases a bit less than we are used to. At least since then, I have experienced a longevity that often exceeds the eight-hour mark, without having to endure a suffocating scent cloud. This is quite remarkable for such a soft and transparent fragrance.

However, this scent is quite clearly meant for warm days. Cavaradossi mentions in his comment that Gucci Pour Homme II can even develop an unexpected dynamism on hot days - then one should dose a bit more sparingly. In cooler weather, however, this fragrance remains very shy and only comes to life again within four walls.

As I said: this fragrance quickly became a reference point in my collection and also quickly became indispensable. Gucci Pour Homme II belongs to the Gucci generation of Rush, Envy, and of course Gucci Pour Homme (I), all of which are fragrances that Gucci has discontinued. The current line from Gucci is, to put it diplomatically, somewhat more palatable. It is unclear whether GPHII shares the same fate, as it can still be found in many stores (as of May 2012), and even the Gucci website informed about this fragrance during my last visit - although it was obvious that they did not want to give it the place it deserves. Whether my adrenaline spikes at the thought that I only own an additional backup bottle of this fragrance are justified, I do not know.

But it is still available, and that should be taken advantage of at least as a test by fragrance enthusiasts. Tea fans will surely enjoy this fragrance, especially and particularly female tea fans. Otherwise, there is hardly a way around Gucci Pour Homme II if you have a penchant for balanced, high-quality fragrances with a good portion of style and depth.

I can agree with most of my predecessors, it is truly a very beautiful scent.
Upon spraying, the bergamot is immediately noticeable, and when you let the fragrance develop, I find that tobacco leaf, white musk, and myrrh become quite apparent.
What bothers me a lot about this scent is its low longevity. I have the impression that the fragrance nearly completely fades after one to two hours. Inquiries in my circle have confirmed this.
Since I still find the fragrance composition very beautiful, I always carry a small decant with me for reapplication.

Conclusion: A beautiful woody-spicy scent for summer and included in my collection despite its low longevity.

Addition:
As luck would have it, I received a sample of YSL Tuxedo, and I must say, it smells almost identical to PM II, just with much better longevity. So, anyone looking for something stronger should definitely test Tuxedo.

review_title: You don't drink black tea, you wear it today!
review_content:
Black tea as a fragrance? With some scent notes, one might first wonder if such fragrances are suitable for wearing. But when you smell it, you quickly realize that a fragrance can indeed feature different notes and still smell fantastic.

Just like here with Gucci II.
I really enjoy drinking tea, perhaps even more than the English do. Black tea is perhaps the ultimate tea in my culture. No day can start without a cup (or glass) of black tea, and throughout the day, we constantly consume tea. So often that dentists are happy when we finally get our teeth professionally cleaned to remove the deposits, to put it exaggeratively. I think it should be clear now how much I enjoy black tea.

Therefore, I often searched for fragrances with tea notes, and I found one at Gucci.
The beginning is very fresh. Upon first spray, one perceives a citrusy, almost lime-like note coming from the bergamot, which is more noticeable than the violet leaf. But then the tea makes its presence known and becomes increasingly stronger. It is a wonderful scent that indeed smells like a nice cup of tea, but not like the rather watery tasting tea bags, rather like freshly brewed tea.
Later, it becomes sweeter due to the cinnamon, but also slightly spicier, as one begins to smell the pepper (allspice). Although I do not like pepper in perfumes, this note here is very subtle and harmonizes very well with the other notes, especially with the cinnamon. Together they create a great fragrance composition. Generally, I would say that from the heart note onward, both the tea and the cinnamon/pepper scent are perceived equally. Towards the end, all these scents remain more or less intense, with the tea note slightly dominating, but a light, woody aroma also comes into play. However, I could not perceive the tobacco at all.

Of course, there is also a point of criticism. I feel that the sillage is somewhat low. I have tested it several times, but the projection could have been a bit stronger, but oh well, it's not that bad. The longevity, however, is quite good, so you are surrounded by a very pleasant fragrance all day long.
All in all, it is a beautiful, fresh scent with a nice, albeit somewhat unwieldy bottle in larger quantities. But this perfume not only smells fresh, it is also very suitable for a cozy gathering, or just for chilling, as they say.
Not only tea lovers should try this fragrance, and tea lovers should resist the temptation to want to drink the fragrance water.

Unusual - let's get that out of the way right from the start.

"Gucci pour homme II" offers an exceptionally interesting, creative approach from the very beginning.

It opens with a soft freshness reminiscent of a freshly washed duvet, with notes of black tea being very prominent, really finely thematically executed, delicate and friendly, oscillating between tea sweetness and bitterness.

The violet immediately evokes a connection for me as an old "Fahrenheit" admirer, but the concept here is entirely different due to the black tea.

The clove pepper (Piment) quickly gains a recognizable, slightly spicy presence. Perhaps a bit too much - with clove, there is indeed a fine line between "aesthetic" and "festive." Fortunately, the cinnamon in the heart is only used very subtly.

The base comes to the forefront after about half an hour,
with slightly smoky myrrh and fresh, green-tinged tobacco leaf notes taking their position.

Overall, a lot of praise for the extremely distinctive and truly innovative fragrance concept - that one can still experience something like this in the late 00s is noteworthy, especially given the mass of cheap knock-offs, sugary bombshells, and air numbers.

review_title: With Gucci PHII back to "Tea Flavor"!
review_content:
As you can already tell from the title, I am a fan of wordplay.

For a long time, I pondered which fragrance I would dedicate my second comment to in this forum, and there was simply no way around this noble scent.

Thanks to a decant from Parfumos (many thanks again to Phillytilly), I got to experience the "tea flavor" early this year.

I always associate tea with the beginning of my school years, as I was the youngest in my family and always preferred tea over coffee. And when there was tea in the morning, it was black tea with a little sugar. Add a delicious butter and jam sandwich, and the day could begin.

Of course, I had already formed an image of the scent here and in various forums, and it somehow fit my preferences, even though I couldn't imagine how tea would smell in a fragrance at that time.

Then the moment came - the decant was in the house, and right after the first spray, I noticed this particularly naturally smelling tea note (I can't specify the type of black tea chosen by Gucci in this scent - perhaps the more trained noses can help me with that ;)).

I am really not an expert at detecting various fragrance notes (my respect goes to those who can!), but I believe a fragrance must have something special about it.
Whether it's memories of days gone by or simply a kind of feel-good factor that a fragrance can evoke in you right away.

In any case, this fragrance does that particularly well for me, and I perceive it very clearly.
Of course, the projection of this scent is not particularly strong, but in my opinion, that makes it a classy feel-good fragrance.

You can wear the fragrance pretty much all year round, and the versatility is astonishing - aside from sports activities, I can't think of any everyday situation where you couldn't wear this scent. I am wearing it today at the office and must say, the more I wear it, the more I like it.
