I am rarely approached about a fragrance in our office, but with this scent, it doesn't matter because it is a fragrance that I want to smell :)

The bottle is also impressive - classically designed in thick glass with a heavy golden plastic cap. It could easily serve as a doorstop like the Icon Dunhill bottle, but we are all too precious for that.

You can't complain about the price, especially if you use various price comparison platforms, you can always find a good deal.

All in all, I can say that this fragrance from the house of Gucci is a very special scent for me and has little to do with mainstream, as I have not yet discovered another fragrance with such a delicious tea note (Tea for Two is too spicy for me, and in Bvlgari pour Homme, the tea note was too subtle for my nose).

Hats off to the perfumer Karine Dubreuil, who hit the mark with this fragrance right in the (black) tea.

review_title: In the Rapture of Sensual Tea Depths
review_content: The first Gucci perfume that is joining my collection, the rest have miserably failed during testing or have been discontinued, especially PHI, which I would have loved to test or buy, or even Gucci Rush... but it is what it is, time cannot be turned back and I'm not willing to pay a small fortune! What remains is this Gucci representative, and it compensates for its extinct...

review_title: When Miss Clove Weds Mr. Pepper…
review_content: ...olfactorily speaking, the allspice plant clearly takes center stage. This note is already quite rare in the ensemble, but here it even gets the leading role. And how underestimated it has been, one thinks, when seeing it showcased like this. Supported and framed by violet leaf and cinnamon, it can truly radiate. This scent, however, does not evoke the common association...

A few years ago, the Italian luxury brand Gucci still understood how to create "interesting" and "extraordinary" fragrances with recognizability and sex appeal - I am referring here solely to the men's fragrances, but it is likely similar for the women's perfumes as well. Envy For Men, Rush For Men, Pour Homme (from 2003), and of course Pour Homme II are unique scents that...

I dare to try a little experiment. “Music expresses that which cannot be said and on which it is impossible to be silent.” Victor Hugo Since my childhood, I have been familiar with Frederic Chopin. Sometimes, I find it difficult to adequately describe a fragrance with words. Why shouldn't a person be able to describe something they feel with another feeling, another...

I still remember my first time - with this fragrance - very clearly. I think I hadn't read much about it and was hardly aware of the hype (especially on Basenotes). Sprayed in a small-town perfumery while on vacation and zoom! Who expects something like that - at Douglas?
My mother nodded in acknowledgment, yes, this would be something for my brother (yes, I’m sure he would love it). It would also be something for me, I thought secretly. It wouldn't leave my mind, and so I soon ordered a small bottle - unusually spontaneous for my standards (I try to avoid impulse buys). That was a mistake. I should have gone for the big bottle right away. But given the repeated rumors of discontinuation, I have now made up for it. 150 ml should be enough for now.
Enough rambling - onto the scent:

It starts off with plenty of violet leaf and Earl Grey tea. Not too dry, not too sweet, lightly spiced, simply perfect. In the drydown, a slightly dirty note comes in. It could be patchouli. But it strongly reminds me of tobacco, yes, a pronounced tobacco note. And there’s hardly more to say about it. Except that it is incredibly delicious!
Sillage is in the middle range, longevity is okay.
Aside from the fact that the violet leaf note is somewhat masculine (Fahrenheit is probably to blame), I find the fragrance quite unisex. Ladies, don't miss out on this!

After I wanted to explain to a user here how I find Gucci pour Homme II EAU DE TOILETTE compared to Sculpture Homme God's Night in response to his questions, I realized while typing that this turned into a review. So why not share it with all of you? ;P (By the way, a reference to his username is hidden somewhere here chchch :D #easteregg) ---~~~[...

review_title: Of Intimate Shavings and Earl Grey
review_content:
Can anyone still remember the Gucci advertisement from the early 2000s, where they shaved a G into a model's intimate area? For Gucci, this kind of attention-grabbing was revolutionary back then…
A revolution also befell the wonderfully scented Gucci Pour Homme I shortly thereafter. Or should we rather say, a complete transformation. Because Gucci II has absolutely nothing to do with its beloved predecessor. Yet both fragrances convince me in their own unique ways...

Since I have already written a comment about the "scent twin" Fan di Fendi Pour Homme, I would like to use my comment on Gucci II for a comparison as well.

In the top notes, the fragrances differ quite drastically. The mandarin in FdFpH transforms into a distinctly noticeable cucumber in Gucci II. Right from the start, you can already smell the much-mentioned tea note, which will not fade away throughout the entire duration (in the Fendi counterpart, it appears a bit later).

A certain spiciness can be detected in the heart note - according to the fragrance pyramid, it is likely the clove pepper combined with cinnamon (a lovely combination, as the clove pepper already has a cinnamon-like flavor!).
The tobacco in the drydown hides itself quite well to my nose, contrary to some other comments here. Also, the often described sweetness honestly doesn’t strike me as that extreme (especially in comparison to the Fendi). In my opinion, this note arises solely from the tea.

Actually, I associate tea fragrances more with something like the last evening in autumn, sitting humbly by the fireplace in the rain and wind (for example, I immediately think of Fan di Fendi). However, Gucci II is different. It has a considerable elegance that cannot be underestimated; I can definitely imagine it as an office scent as well.

I want to emphasize the cucumber note once again, which unfortunately is mentioned far too rarely but is clearly perceived by me all the way into the heart note.
All in all, Gucci has succeeded in creating a really good "successor" to the first one, even though the term successor is actually not fitting given the incomparability.

Revolutions at Gucci often bring positive surprises.

review_title: Pardon me sir, is that Earl Grey you're wearing?
review_content:
No, dear sir, I am wearing "Gucci pour homme II"
One might think that as a Moroccan I swear by my Moroccan mint tea, but that's wrong; I prefer Earl Grey, that black tea named after British Prime Minister Charles Grey.
Gucci pour homme II is like a good warm cup of Earl Grey.

Already upon spraying, the fine aroma of black tea surrounds you, as if you have your nose over a tea bag tin.
This blends with the sweetness of fine cinnamon and is pleasantly softened by white musk.
A cup of Earl Grey with a little rock sugar and a splash of milk, that's exactly how Gucci pour homme II is.
I love Earl Grey
I love GphII
Tea time!

review_title: A Shisha and a Cay, please!
review_content: A black tea bomb, that's about the only way to describe it. Although I don't like black tea, this one is quite animalistic. It tastes best when hot! PH Two is a sexy, sensual companion for the long haul. Whether at work, in your free time, or if you're meeting up with the girl you like. A suitable but unfortunately also passive all-rounder. The big problem with this...

On a business trip (flight), I discovered a fragrance sample of Gucci pour Homme II in a magazine. Normally, I'm not a fan of such samples, but I was bored anyway, so I opened it and took a sniff.
Not bad, I thought, and put the magazine away.
A few minutes later... I just had to smell it again....
The more I thought about it, the more I liked the scent.
Somehow, it seemed to be exactly what I had been looking for so often:
A fragrance that absolutely fits me, no ifs or buts.
But what does such a sample really say?
So, during my layover, I headed to the local duty-free shop and sprayed myself with Gucci pour Homme II.
Afterwards, I went to the lounge for a small snack and something to drink,
while continuously smelling my forearm...
The more I smelled Homme II, the better it got.
My decision was made: before the next flight, I quickly went back to duty-free to buy the fragrance. Said and done, I've never regretted it - the bottle was used up quite quickly, which is rare for me.
Now, the second bottle.
Still exactly my wavelength, both for the office and for leisure.

Black tea? In a perfume? What is that supposed to smell like? Should I test it? Yes, I'll give it a try :)

And YES, it smells damn good!

Memories come rushing back, about 25 years ago, to my grandparents' home - half German, half English descent, where so much English PG Tips tea was consumed that one could have filled a swimming pool with it in a week ;) Well, I don't want to exaggerate, but we really drank a lot of this tea. Unfortunately, it has been forgotten in our household for years, but I want to change that from now on.

In any case, this perfume reminds me exactly of that wonderful childhood time at my grandparents', when I would already get a cup of PG Tips tea (with a splash of UHT milk) from my grandma in bed in the morning, along with 2 slices of zwieback with butter & honey on top, which I would dip into the tea. Yes, in the end, there were probably more zwieback crumbs in the cup than tea, but it was so delicious.

This amazing perfume brings back that wonderful memory, which I had almost forgotten until now, simply incredible!

Now I realize what scents can evoke in a person - memories, dreams, wishes, all of that through a fragrance.

Thank you for that!

review_title: The Incomprehensible End of a Masterpiece
review_content:
Gucci pour Homme II EAU DE TOILETTE is undoubtedly one of those perfumes that can be called a timeless classic and definitely belongs to a "golden era." Fragrances like "Envy for Men (Eau de Toilette) | Gucci," "By Man | Dolce & Gabbana," "What About Adam (Eau de Toilette) | Joop!," or Antidote EAU DE TOILETTE are perfumes that I will never understand why they were discontinued.

I simply cannot imagine that it was due to poor sales, and the fragrance compositions themselves should still find great appeal today and are in no way outdated... But what's the point of nostalgic lamenting? I think we've all learned by now that it doesn't help :(
Gucci pour Homme II EAU DE TOILETTE is unfortunately the last great creation from Gucci for men's fragrances, in my opinion...

This scent is also one that has accompanied me the longest and would definitely be repurchased regularly if it were still in production.
After Dior Homme Intense (2011) (definitely the old version), I would probably consider this my second signature scent. The unusual combo of violet leaf, black tea, pimento, cinnamon, tobacco, and white musk creates a fantastic warm spiciness, which always carries a certain lightness.
For me, it is actually almost always wearable and nearly impossible to overapply, unless one really tries to ;)
The fact that the longevity is unfortunately a small drawback has already been mentioned here several times... but for me, it still falls within an acceptable range.

As I said, I will sadly never understand why such masterpieces are discontinued only to throw some meaningless stuff on the market that is already available in one form or another... I have unfortunately not found a truly acceptable replacement so far.
The Sculpture Homme God's Night is okay, but in my opinion, it doesn't come close to "Gucci pour Homme II (Eau de Toilette) | Gucci."

For me, definitely an unjustly discontinued masterpiece...

Another blind buy, sparked by the fragrance pyramid and the comments, arrived at my place a few days ago.
After unpacking, there is the first reason for joy. The bottle is a knockout, a noble, high-quality block of solid glass with a metal cap. The light purple fragrance liquid inside adds the finishing touch.

Now to the inner values...

The opening is distinctly characterized by bergamot and violet leaf for my nose. However, very quickly the protagonist, black tea, takes center stage. This scent note is truly excellently realized here; it becomes a bit smoky-bitter and slightly floral, with a pinch of cinnamon dancing around this long-lasting main phase. Over time, this scent note fades, becoming woodier and quieter, and after a few hours, "Gucci pour Homme II" gently fades out without significant further scent changes, only becoming a bit sweeter. Throughout the entire time, the fragrance remains unobtrusive and close to the skin.

I agree with many comments. "Gucci pour Homme II" is an archetype of a relaxed, laid-back scent, which is not only due to the black tea - for me, the epitome of relaxation. However, it is a bit too relaxed for me; I need and want a bit more strictness and less indulgence in my fragrances.

Fortunately, my noble bottle has already found a new, welcome place of use and is not languishing in my closet.

Once again, I have been tempted into a spontaneous purchase through this wonderful site - and I don’t regret it for a second.

I simply did a quick search online to find where I could buy this little water at a good price, and the perfumery around the corner got the nod. I love Gucci pour Homme 2! It’s sensual - this combination of tea with bergamot - basically Earl Grey to spray on - which is also my favorite tea. A truly wonderful combo. My God, I would wish for an intense version of this - because this Gucci is a very, very fleeting little guy. As soon as it’s there - it’s already gone again. I love wearing a LOT of perfume, and I like to smell it even late into the evening. Unfortunately, the scent only lasts 2 hours with me, and that’s really a shame in this case - because it has turned out really wonderful.

Unfortunately, the scent seems to be discontinued. So anyone who wants to enjoy it really has to be quick.

So far, the only Gucci, after Rush for men, that I have liked 100%. Oh yes, definitely spray it on your skin - it doesn’t work at all on paper.

review_title: When I only had ONE fragrance...
review_content: ... that was many years ago. Yes, there were indeed times when I started small. Once every 6 months, I would go to the perfume store, get advice, and take something new home. But then I stumbled upon this designer fragrance. And that’s when it happened. Love at first sight. I felt immediately comfortable with the scent. The GpH II remained my signature fragrance for many...

Is it really appropriate to smoke while enjoying an Earl Grey? At least in this refined establishment where we currently find ourselves, quite a few visitors have taken to tobacco. They are engaged in late afternoon conversation, outraged about colleagues, sharing tales of the shrewd deals of the day. Sitting alone at a corner table, an unknown man hides his three-day beard behind a weekly newspaper, occasionally crossing one leg over the other and revealing the soles of expensive Italian shoes. Time passes not by a glance at the clock, but by the cooling of the tea. And when the unknown man wishes to pay after an hour and the second cup, a nice tip is left behind.
Wearing Gucci II for my nose is synonymous with "waiting and drinking tea." It means embodying the casual connoisseur even in hectic moments and silently knowing one's superiority amidst unnecessary tumult.
It is indeed an original perfumer's achievement that has gifted us with a violet-soft brute of a fragrance. It’s wonderful that such a thing still exists today. This 5 PM after-work feeling for the entire day.

First of all, I would like to - and must - refer to this excellent Parfumo community, without sounding too "syrupy." Thanks to this site and its content, I have come across the most wonderful fragrances in recent weeks and months; and I am not sure if this would have been the case without the helpful, excellent, and very entertaining comments, as I am indeed an olfactory novice. So much for the praise, which I hope remained within reasonable bounds and...
Now to the actual "business": This is my very first comment on a perfume, and I hope it will be pleasing - although I do not claim the literary finesse often seen in this community.
The first comment is right on one of the more "complicated" perfumes I have perceived to date, or so it seems to me. But first, let’s talk about the formalities: the bottle is, quite literally, a sensation!; cubic, bulky, solid, simple yet elegant: Rating: Excellent. However, there is something I find bothersome about handling the fragrance container: the spray nozzle. Perhaps it is also due to my lack of "craftsmanship" or dexterity, but I struggle with the push button - at least not in the way I would prefer. It either dispenses an insufficient amount, or an "inappropriate" amount, or it "spits" - sometimes it even sprays off-target. One really has to practice with it, which is definitely worth it!
Because the fragrance more than makes up for this flaw. In all three phases of the scent development, namely top note, heart note, base note - and I want to emphasize my preference for the cinnamon that comes in later, giving it a mild and delicate sweetness - the scent is extremely pleasant and light. This subtlety, which was criticized in the comments of other "Parfumos" - due to the moderate sillage and longevity - I find very soothing and refreshing. Fresh is also how my nose perceives the opening, which quickly transitions into a slightly bitter tea aroma that is simply harmonious with the fresh/fresher opening. And when after a certain time - I have never timed how long it takes - the aforementioned sweetness comes in, yes, then I would count Gucci Pour Homme II among my favorites. This middle phase is incredibly good; digestible, calming, attractive, and benevolent.
The fading of this fragrance is then one last impulse of an immensely captivating subtlety, which for me is the strength of Gucci Pour Homme II: Because this subtlety is the theme of this fragrance, which I consider to be among the best. Complicated, as mentioned at the beginning, it is in this sense - also due to the spray nozzle - that it is so "pliant" within perception, meaning that it is sometimes there, sometimes not; due to its fleeting nature, it is difficult to identify clearly, perhaps also because it is so harmoniously composed. But this ephemeral quality is sometimes appropriate, and has often been commented on favorably; - perhaps because one does not always have to overwhelm their environment with their scent.
So much for Gucci Pour Homme II, which for me is fragrant art and a small masterpiece.

A gentle scent, so gentle that I almost get too much of it. "For truly lovely gentlemen around forty," I thought in the first few minutes,
but by now I am increasingly aware of its creeping penetrance. I find the interplay of all the notes really beautifully conceived and executed. The composition is stately and complete, that must be said.
Only: It is too embracing for me, too clingy, too flattering. It always wants to press you against its velvet-clad chest. This is how waves of affection must smell. :) Thank you, but it's all a bit too friendly for me.

A true all-rounder.
This fragrance smells very pleasant, relaxing, refreshing, and definitely not overpowering. I have been using this scent for over 12 years and I always remember the beautiful times of my past years. It is my favorite perfume and will always remain so. Unfortunately, the production was discontinued some time ago.

I still remember the day when I was at a very well-known perfume chain, which seems to choose its assortment more based on sales figures than quality characteristics, looking for a specific fragrance. The rather passive saleswoman didn’t really want to address my wishes. However, this turned out to be very positive in hindsight. She said something like: "this here is one...

review_title: Top favorite from the mainstream class!
review_content: ...I'm surprised I haven't commented on this yet, as it is one of my favorite fragrances. All time favorite! From the mainstream class, my absolute favorite scent. It's a shame it's no longer produced. I don't understand that, as I think it was the best men's fragrance from Gucci. I ran around the city like a madman and managed to get three bottles! About the scent. Although...

Here’s a comment on the (for my nose) last good Gucci fragrance: Gucci pour Homme II.

Right after spraying, the scent is quite fresh, with any citrus or other fruit ingredients completely omitted. Nothing special stands out at first. But after a few minutes, it smells like a very fine blend of tobacco, tea, and cinnamon, which comes across as extremely elegant.

The very balanced mixture of individual components creates a relatively unique scent that I simply cannot get enough of for the past few years and that I still find extremely appealing.
You can also wear the fragrance in summer since it is not heavy. My preferred seasons are autumn and winter, as it suits me very well during those times.

The longevity is even above average compared to current fragrances for me. After a visit to a thermal spa with several sauna sessions and swimming, I could still perceive it well on my skin in the evening. It definitely lasts through a day at the office without any issues.

It is neither extremely sweet (like the current perfume zeitgeist of 2014) nor old-school woody/spicy; it can be worn by any age group for any occasion, yet it is still something special and for me one of the top 10 perfumes that have come to market in the last 10 years.

If YSL is too boring, Dior Homme too powdery-sweet, etc.: just give it a try before it gets discontinued (then it will become ENVY-like really expensive!)

This fragrance is a true all-rounder. I think you can definitely wear it all year long. The top note exudes a relaxed atmosphere, and I have often been told that I smell very pleasant when wearing this scent. While it may not have the wow effect of some other fragrances, you also don’t always want to stand out. Sometimes it’s enough to radiate a “pleasant” scent that...

review_title: A Visit to the Tea Room
review_content:
Season:
The scent fits quite well in winter, but it is probably too weak for the cold season. Gucci PH 2 is also quite nice to wear in spring and on mild summer days.

Age:
I think it is suitable for all age groups.

Suitability:
Going out, dates, and romantic occasions, leisure.

Intensity/Projection/Duration:
Varies greatly, everything from 2-24 hours is possible. I believe the scent does not hold up well in cold weather. Overall, I would classify the projection as subtle to moderate.

Scent:
What does Gucci PH 2 smell like?
Answer: Imagine sitting on a warm spring day on the terrace of a café, dressed in a nice old leather jacket, sipping a cup of black tea with lots of milk and cinnamon. On the table lies a freshly opened pack of cigarettes, right next to a small bouquet of flowers.
I don’t notice much bergamot, but a sweet-floral violet note comes through strongly. The tea is clearly perceptible, as is the cinnamon. Hardly anyone mentions it, but I can distinctly smell milk, and I catch a whiff of the most beautiful leather accord I have encountered in a perfume so far. As sweet as it is on paper, GPH2 is not as sweet on the skin; the initial sweetness quickly gives way to leather and is softened at the end by tobacco, leaving a woody warm impression.

Conclusion:
Although it says Pour Homme on the bottle, the scent is clearly unisex for me, and in a very successful way. Many current fragrances have a pronounced feminine side, and even in fashion, the boundaries between the two genders often blur. Well, one can think what one wants about that, but I find that many scents (like Le Male, for example) or clothes (the glitter trash from Ed Hardy) implement this concept in a very clumsy and cheap way. Gucci, on the other hand, does not. The sweetness of the cinnamon and the floral notes (traditionally feminine) are well balanced by leather and tobacco (masculine). Gucci PH2 is one of the few fragrances that do not want to commit to a gender, which I find very well done. Another example would be Dior Homme. I once considered buying it but ultimately decided against it. Reason: the milky notes. They somehow weigh on my stomach over time (a kind of childhood trauma, I had to drink a lot of milk as a little boy, against my will). Maybe it’s not the perfect scent for me, yet I have to give it a top rating. The notes harmonize perfectly, the creation is independent and original, and it is one of the few meaningful fragrances that can cleverly combine masculine and feminine aspects.

It is a scent, like its bottle: angular and sharp. Masculine and herbaceous. Heavy and light. A fragrance as fresh and free as an unobstructed view of the open sea. It doesn't matter whether it's stormy and you feel the spray on your face or the sea sparkles in the sun.

It is the hint of black tea, paired with fresh notes that the wind carries from the bergamot trees over the violet fields to you. You stand there and continue to gaze at the sea. And you want to smell just like this moment.

For me, it is the fragrance that James Bond wears. Not intrusive, but noticeable. Not Roger, not George, not Timothy, not Pierce, and not Daniel either. The scent is worn by the original: Sir Sean Connery.

Yes, even a "cuddle scent" has its justification at times. Yes, even tough guys want to show their soft and sensitive side now and then. Yes, the fragrance is really great and unique, but not very long-lasting... This dominant tea note has not appeared in any other fragrance I've encountered so far. Extremely soft, velvety, powdery, truly a scent that makes you feel like...

What a masculine presence! The beautiful bottle alone is perfectly suited for tactile male hands; bulky, angular, hefty, and so heavy that it could easily make a guest appearance as a murder weapon in an Agatha Christie mystery.

But the contents also make men's hearts race significantly; Gucci pour Homme II is indispensable on the best-seller list while most other Guccis have remained stuck in the swamp of insignificance.

Gucci pour Homme II opens with pale blue, gray notes, and immediately a wonderful, harmonious tea accord emerges, which defines the slightly melancholic overall character.
The immediate surroundings can clearly perceive the aromatic tea note; for it is embedded in a very gentle, pleasant, and unobtrusive sillage.

However, Gucci pour Homme II also has its weaknesses; it lacks a stronger base structure, making it feel quite shallow, and one misses a bit of "depth." This, in turn, leads to some monotony, and I couldn't wear this scent daily for that reason.
The longevity is also a bit weak, so it is advisable to carry a small travel bottle for reapplication.

But all in all, Gucci pour Homme II is a very well-made Eau de Toilette, with weaknesses that one can gladly overlook. It is indeed a pure men's fragrance, but that doesn't mean that established women shouldn't take a chance on it.

After so many great reviews, I just had to try this scent.

It's good that it's available in every well-stocked perfume department, so I didn't have to order a sample.

The bottle: Elegant and heavy. It doesn't convey a cozy warmth, like the Dior Homme Intense bottle does. But it looks straightforward and high-quality.

The scent: Well, how should I describe it? When I took my first deep breath, it reminded me of cucumber salad. Some will now shake their heads in horror and refer to the fragrance pyramid. Yes, I know. But it somehow reminded me of Grandma's delicious cucumber salad, which was served at every celebration.
No question - I enjoy eating it often, but I wouldn't want to smell like it.

In the base note, the black tea clearly comes through. It (the scent) feels different, unusual, and mysterious. However, I still can't warm up to it (even after hours).

Conclusion: Undoubtedly a very well-made, extraordinary fragrance - but not for me.

I took the plunge and bought Gucci Pour Homme II blind, as it is highly rated on Parfumo. My expectations were not disappointed: From the very beginning, I really liked this fragrance. On my skin, this noble tea-cinnamon note comes through so well that I am constantly asked what wonderful scent I am wearing. You can just tell that all the ingredients are perfectly harmonized:...

If the pimento weren't so dominant, it could have become one of my favorite scents, especially because of the tea. It starts off bitterly fresh with the bergamot, and the tea soon comes through. I love tea aromas in perfumes; the cinnamon caresses everything, beautiful and unusual, but gradually the clove aroma of the pimento breaks through, which annoyed me and actually gave me a headache. Instead of enjoying the scent, I was constantly on high alert. The people around me found it very good.

A few weeks ago, I received a larger package of fragrance samples from Mondhexe.
Thank you once again for that.
Included was Gucci pour Homme II.
The fragrance opens with a very nice bergamot note. Soon, a slight hint of pimento joins in, which is increasingly supported by the scent of a good black tea. After about 30 minutes, a slightly smoky, subtly sweet note adds to the tea scent in the heart, which is complemented by a soft musk after about an hour, while the sweet note recedes. This lightly smoky tea fragrance is gently interrupted by a soft spiciness over the next six hours until it finally fades away.
Gucci pH II is a fine, understated fragrance that is likely best worn in spring or autumn. It is not for my watch list, but rather goes on my wish list.

Forgotten for years, now rediscovered!
I wore this wonderful fragrance 15 years ago. Now, while tidying up my collection, I found an unopened, nearly unused bottle in my closet. Rediscovered for me. It was a gift from my parents, and for a long time, it went unnoticed, making me all the happier to enjoy the scent again. For a while, I couldn't "smell" it anymore, which is why it remained neglected for so long. Now that it is no longer available for purchase, I almost regret that I will probably never get my hands on it again. All the more I enjoy every spray now!

It smells like tea, both elegant and masculine. Yet, it is not too overpowering. The scent lasts incredibly long on me, often 6-8 hours. It is suitable for everyday office wear as well as for a nice dinner.

The bottle is heavy, angular, and has a timeless appearance.

It's a shame that the end is in sight...

I was initially captivated by the presentation: The contrast between this chunky cube bottle and the playful, dreamy violet (violet as a top note for a men's perfume is quite bold and unusual!).

It smells simply delicious, you want to keep sniffing it. However, I feel that it is relatively weak. You can handle three decent sprays without smelling like an entire perfume store!

In the top note, alongside the aromas described above, scents of fresh hay and woodruff (coumarin) explode, as well as fruity notes, like apricot and banana, which also carry into the heart note, reminding me of gingerbread and incense.

I don't find it very herb-spicy, rather sweet. As I said, it's a great scent, but I'm not so sure how a man would come across wearing it!?

review_title: Super bottle, like every one from Gucci
review_content:
So I tested the fragrance a few years ago and was about to buy it, but never did.
Right now, I'm looking for something more for leisure, a versatile scent that doesn't annoy my surroundings too much.
Then this Gucci Pour Homme 2 came to mind again, which I had already tested before, and recently again, and I must say, I still really like it. It smells very fresh and the tea scent is very present in my nose.
It is truly an incredible fragrance, as it doesn't follow the common standard but is something different in the perfume world ;) I'm starting to really like it and I'm considering buying it, but after all your comments, I'm afraid that the scent really doesn't last, and I wish for a fragrance that truly lasts longer ;)

Otherwise, the scent is really genius and is truly something special.

I received Gucci pour Homme II through a sharing to try out (Thank you, Eichkater), as a test seems almost mandatory given the previous comments here. Although a decent pinch of pepper initially hits my nose with this fragrance, this blend with black tea and cinnamon and the other ingredients develops into an interesting, light, and refined scent. If a men's fragrance can manage to spread a light cheerfulness and an everything-is-okay vibe, then it must be this one. There is nothing ostentatious, macho, or intrusive here; rather, GPH II is a very fine and subtle feel-good scent. I also appreciate that it comes across as natural to my sense of smell, in contrast to some concoctions on the market that smell too much like artificial lab products.

With its light, spicy-fresh feel-good character, GPH II bears a certain resemblance to my beloved Baldessarini EdC Concentrée. They are certainly not scent twins, but I would describe Baldessarini as an older cousin of Gucci; especially in the drydown, a kinship becomes apparent. In the heart note, GPH II is significantly spicier, so I still prefer the overall rounder and slightly more balanced Baldessarini just a bit more. That's good, as it seems to be worn less frequently.

But do you really want to smell like a glass of lightly sweetened, herb-spicy-cinnamon chai latte and Earl Grey? Yes! Definitely!! Because this one is so delicious, with slightly floral aromas and a bitter tea flavor, that you (at least I) want to keep sniffing myself. A great scent that is anything but ordinary or mainstream. It smells delicious, warm, and spicy, but thanks to bergamot and violet leaf, it is also refreshing, invigorating, and a bit cool. Somehow masculine, but in a reserved, likable way. Not a loudmouth or a dominant male; rather the quieter, sexy type from the second row. Sensual and stylish, but also casual and suitable for leisure.
For me, it’s a wonderful summer scent that I absolutely love and can wear both at the office and in my free time, especially during the day. Somehow, it doesn’t really fit my idea of evening wear. On the other hand: If I feel like it, I’ll wear it then too.
The only downside, in my opinion, is the mediocre longevity. At least on my skin, it fades after about 4-5 hours. On fabric, it lasts significantly longer. Therefore, I usually give an extra spritz on my shirt or T-shirt. Otherwise, there’s only one solution: reapply.
However, I don’t always crave marathon scents that you can still smell after the next shower. So, the moderate staying power on the skin can sometimes be an advantage.

A good scent that, while certainly not on par with my two favorite perfume manufacturers (Tom Ford (Private Blend!!) Creed), still ranks among the best that the mass market has to offer.
I find it has a nice masculine spicy and tobacco-like scent (is that a word?).
It doesn’t develop as wonderfully while wearing as some high-quality Eau de Parfums, but it smells really good right from the start.
I would recommend this scent especially to younger people, around my age (18-20) and students.
Furthermore, since the scent is not overpowering but still lasts long on the skin, you can't go wrong with applying it, and it’s not a fragrance that divides people into two camps but rather a simple good scent that almost everyone likes and doesn't offend anyone.
The price is also reasonable if you order it like I did on eBay (100ml + 200ml shower gel = €50).

GPH II was the first perfume I bought with the criterion "I want to smell something more extraordinary on my skin"... and that's exactly how I ended up with GPH II after quite a bit of testing strips and wrist sniffing.
The characteristically spicy-cinnamon, yet wonderfully warm-soft scent immediately convinced me. Definitely one of my favorite perfumes for the colder season and fancier evening events.
Although I don't receive nearly as many compliments for it as I do with more "everyday suitable" and more widespread fragrances (e.g. Boss Bottled), it is one of the scents that I personally love to smell on myself. And that is, to some extent, what it's all about, I would say :)

review_title: The sun begins to warm, the snow is already gone, and the buds on the trees are already swollen and...
review_content:
Hello everyone!

This perfume was bought a long time ago, to be honest, I don't remember its price,
First of all, I liked the square, clear, glass, and very heavy bottle; it is so heavy that it could really kill.

The cap of the bottle is heavy and made of gold-colored, textured metal.

It is a masculine scent, although I think it would also suit girls, and belongs to the group of woody, spicy fragrances. It was released in 2007.

Top notes: violet leaf and bergamot.

Heart notes: cinnamon, red pepper, and black tea.

Base notes: olive wood, musk, tobacco leaf, and myrrh.

A fragrance for the young, ambitious man. I think spring is the best time for this perfume, when the sun begins to warm, the snow has fallen, and the buds on the trees are already swollen and slowly budding. When nature awakens and the song of the birds echoes through the city. You walk in a light jacket to meet your friend who has just arrived from a faraway country, you are in a good mood and happy.

For me, the first notes of this perfume are green, violet leaf, and olive tree; I don't hear bergamot at all. The initial notes don't last long, then follow notes of myrrh and cherry, which are not mentioned in the fragrance description, and you realize that it is not cherry at all, but pipe tobacco, so warm, masculine, and pleasant, with a slight sweetness. The rest is a subtle scent of olive wood, green and delicate. This is where the scent of this perfume ends. Unfortunately, the longevity is not good for me at all; it lasts only 2-3 hours, sits close to the skin, and leaves almost no trace.

I liked the scent, but unfortunately, it fades very quickly, so I give it a solid 3.

Pros
Springtime
Pleasant
Cons:
Not long-lasting

I have bought this fragrance 3 times already, the intensity could be stronger, but I find it very sexy, although for the average guy it might be too sexy and too bold.... It suits me personally well, it sometimes comes across as very animalistic and provocative on me with undertones of fresh sweat, as I perceive it, also a bit of smoke and leather seem to emerge.... Very successful, and not mainstream at all.....

Do you know this feeling: Sometimes you try a fragrance in a situation that fits the scent so perfectly that you associate the fragrance with that moment? This happened to me when I first sniffed "Gucci pour Homme II." It was a dry, hot, windless summer day in Frankfurt. And in the fragrance, I recognized all the impressions of my surroundings: There was the overheated, bitter spiciness of the scent (pepper and nutmeg), softened by a green note reminiscent of the smell of the gray asphalt, which was not carried away by any breeze and only made bearable by the greenery of the plane trees, the strictly animalistic note that found its counterpart in the sweat of passersby, and there was the cosmopolitan elegance of the metropolis, reflected in the complexity of the fragrance.

I do not consider "Gucci pour Homme II" to be a "completely different" fragrance from the masses - rather, I see it as one with a certain class and urban flair, less catchy than "Gucci pour Homme I," but that doesn't have to be a disadvantage.

review_title: Then I'd rather go for POUR HOMME I...
review_content:
I already had the brilliant GUCCI POUR HOMME and of course wanted to get this nice neighbor as well...

Here I noticed a somewhat special experience and development within myself... At first, I actually found it quite okay, but after wearing it several times, the scent really started to annoy me over time...

I don't know why, but probably the black tea didn't work very well for me, as this note is quite prominent!

I have to give it to him, he is, like his older brother, unique and thus surely a great scent. Moreover, it lasts quite long on me, but unfortunately, it doesn't please my nose very much... :-/

The bottle design is top-notch and looks very elegant!

Just tried it and I get a bunch of frankincense-oud with leather and resins. I think it's really nice and actually prefer it to Versace Oud Noir. I think the Versace is too soapy, and this is a bit darker but not heavy. Initial impression is very good, I could see wearing this often. It is different from most, it has a slight warmth from the resins, and it is well blended. I am getting great sillage, fairly strong at arms length, but just lovely. It has a nice powdery oud, which is smooth and elegant. I am quite pleased with this.

While I appreciate input and opinions, I am very glad I blind bought this, despite suggestions to the contrary. It may not be groundbreaking, but it is pleasant, a bit mysterious, and different. I don't know much about synthetics, but it smells nice, thats all I know, or care about.

Initial impressions

Scent - 9.5
Sillage - 8.5
Longevity- 8.5 (8-12 hours)
Bottle - 9.5 - that doorknocker cap is so damn pleasing

Will fit nicely in my top 3 with Montale Greyland and Bentley Absolute.

A very decent perfume and it attracts attention. The best Gucci since the times of GPH and GPH II (in my opinion), although from the interesting experiences of this stable there is definitely the Gucci Absolute.
The fragrance of Intense Oud is very persistent with good projection, but not much. After comparing similar fragrances (about 12 oud) - on blotters and body - similar notes to Tom Ford (Oud Wood) and Versace (Oud Noir). Quality of ingredients better than Versace and longer design. The smell is nicer to the nose than the typical dark agar smells due to the breakage of the smell of a fresh pear.
So here we have agar and wood notes and incense and leather and this fruity freshness. The scent is therefore not very strong and dark, but smooth and balsamic in reception.
Solid work and very pleasant to receive. I recommend to all who like the fragrances of the above. In my opinion, it is worth interchangeable with, for example, Oud Wood. When it comes to the amount and durability - it's worth it. If someone would like to save a little and do not want to spend money on a whole bottle of Tom Ford or that Gucio - I recommend Versace.

review_title: Arguably one of the best oud perfumes on the market
review_content:
Arguably one of the best oud perfumes on the market. Its dark and mysterious leans more on the mature gentleman side than a unisex fragrance. The oud note in this one is well tamed. A fine fragrance indeed one that turns heads. A germ from Gucci.

Great performance, massive, exclusive, simply charismatic, powerful, compelling and a compliments galore. It smells great and will make you feel like a million bucks.

Really nice fragrance that brings an appealing scent together with dark elements into harmony. That is where niche sometimes goes wrong for me.. They get too dark or it ends up just smelling like burnt ash or camel anus.. This is a good one. Smokey, woody, some light sweetness.. bold and a good performer.

Not a very great oud, but very easy to like. It's very strong tho. So 2 sprays must be enough. This is the typical rose/oud western oud scent. I have tried to love it, but it never got to more than Like. This kind of perfumes is very cloying, and not easy on the nose. I can't imagine how anyone would wear Oud in warm weather. I can see it work well in winter tho. Just not for me

I have mixed thoughts on this one. Intense Oud has a pleasant scent that strikes me as down the middle unisex - not leaning masculine nor feminine. The actual oud note seems to be pretty minimal or subtle, especially after the dry down. It's more of a fruity/floral mix with oud/patchouli. Scent is pretty mild and crowd pleasing.

Previously, I had recommended 1 Million Golden Oud as a mild oud introduction. The oud there starts out stronger than Intense Oud and after dry down has a pretty powerful leather note that continues to push the fragrance along. Intense Oud will be my new mild "introduction to oud" recommendation.

As you can probably guess from these comments, Intense Oud is too mild, subtle, floral and unisex for my taste. I want something that makes a stronger statement.

Intense Oud's performance is quite good however.

Nun gut, wieder eine kleine Anekdote vorab: (gerne meine anderen Reviews ansehen) Ich habe einen Freundeskreis den ich mal als ziemlich Parfum-affin beschreiben würde. So hab ich an einem Abend mit meinem Freundeskreis Gucci Intense Oud drauf und denk mir nichts Böses. Mein Kumpel schnuppert an mir und fragt mich direkt was ich drauf hab und ruft seine Freundin zu uns und...

This perfume is a masterpiece of subtle allure. A harmonious blend of frankincense, rose, oud, wood, saffron, pear, and ambergris creates a scent that whispers rather than shouts. The rose, soft and captivating, is the heart of this fragrance, lingering on the skin like a cherished memory. Wearing it evokes a sense of timeless elegance and quiet charm – unforgettable...

hello, everyone.
the first words that come to my mind when I feel like a masterpiece is just magical!
a dark poetry like a perfume born in another century long time.
a natural West with a terror side.
my best perfume in 30 years now.
just exceptional!
hold,wake, quality of ingredients injected, just perfect composition.
a 10/10 (one without fault)
after all my vials are 2015, after reformulation?? i don't know.

Gucci took the oud to the mass mare with this scent, and did it really decently. Taking the oud to the earthy, herbal direction. it even reminds me to Black Afgano and similar perfumes.

Not my favourite direction for a oud based scent, but that fact does not weaken its artistic effort and brave proposition.

Very suitable if you like perfumes with oud touches (synthetic one in this case, obviously) going in the aromatic/green direction

review_title: Gucci high stepping into the Niche realm.
review_content:
I've had this fragrance for about 2-3 years now & everytime I pull it out for a sniff, I say "why don't I wear this more". The reason being, you don't just wear this fragrance anywhere. It's not an everyday fragrance. This fragrance is classy, masculine & isn't offensive, surprisingly.....
.
When you first spray this you get a nice dose of raspberry, rose & spice from the saffron & it's all within this beautiful cloud of Oud that is just so smooth. I believe it's the combination of the orange blossom that helps keep it at bay & not so aggressive. Because if you know Oud, it can really be an in your face, fragrance. That can come off as dirty, super Smokey & obviously woody. Most frag houses will always combine rose & oud with saffron but with this fragrance that's not all you get here & that's also very nice, & separates this fragrance from like a More Than Words, Join the Club by Xerjoff.
.
This fragrance I feel really is an all year round fragrance. Amazingly it does work in summer, AT NIGHT. I definitely would NEVER wear this in the day time unless to like a wedding in the fall/winter. It's very situational, & rather than wear this to say the store or running errands. This is a fragrance you're wearing to show you have taste/class, so weddings, dinner dates, night outs, etc.
Lasts for hours, probably 8-9 hours, projects for about 2 hours or so & when it turns into a skin scent, still very present. That seems very intentional, considering this fragrance doesn't project very loud in the first place. Probably about a foot or two of projection.
.
It's definitely a masterpiece in its own right, Gucci's masterpiece. Because I dnt consider any of their fragrance nearly as great as this one & for good reason. Gucci isn't very consistent with their fragrances. They're ok, but nothing too crazy, inspiring or worth mentioning in most instances.
It's def more niche than anything else they've done. & it's an easy blind buy, for anyone over the age of 26 going into the 30s. A mature young person may love it but either way, happy hunting!

review_title: Excuse me, sir, what kind of liquid do you have in your e-cigarette?
review_content:
Smoking is not allowed here.

I don't have a comparison to base variant Gucci Oud but in an intense version is opening very, very sweet for me. Main notes that dominate raspberry with also reminds me of a bit of wild cherry, unfortunately, there is not much more behind it - oud, amber is underdeveloped.
With for me make it is as Gucci Oud Intense is missing something, I would like to break it with some woody, smokey notes.

To be honest it reminds me of fruit-flavored liquids that I sense from time to time from people smoking an e-cigarette. Raspberries/Cherries with a hint of tobacco.

For me, it is too linear, too simple and in some way to sweet, even if fruits notes are definitely more on darker/wilder side.

It could be a great accompaniment for a younger audience and can act as a women scent with a few male notes.

The fragrance is intense. Very Intense. Longevity is through the roof so go gentle on the spray. I absolutely love the fact that I put on a fragrance by 06:00 in the morning and by 08:00 PM when I'm ready to take a shower, there it is still going strong as ever. Absolute Beast...

Its one of my favorites so far most underrated fragrance ive smelt u get a hint of oud then the sweet amber smell brings out alot of more complections i find that the oud starts fadin at the 2-4 hour mark but i sprayed some yesterday and i can still smell it so longevity is not a problem neither is projection if you spray 3-5 sprays everyone will be turning heads

I bought this blind based on the reviews and the fact that I love Gucci pour Homme, which is not so long lasting. When I sprayed the Oud Intense I got the full Tom Ford Oud Wood direction. If I would be blindfolded I would probably not know which is which. I am no expert of course, it is only my opinion. I like everything about this perfume and it is a honorable part of my...

review_title: A designer fragrance with niche quality
review_content:
I was passing by one of the Marionnaud Paris branches and decided to try Gucci Oud Intense. I’m not a fan of oud fragrances, but this one shocked me with the quality of the oud and how well it blends with the other notes.
When you first spray it, you get a beautiful burst of cranberry, rose , and saffron spice, all wrapped in a very smooth oud cloud.

I feel this fragrance works well in all seasons, and amazingly, it even performs beautifully in summer but only at night.

I never expected that I could buy a designer fragrance with niche quality, and what’s even crazier is that it costs only $125! It was truly insane. I highly recommend it, and it’s definitely a safe blind buy because everyone will love it.

review_title: Possible the BEST designer oud fragrance at its respective price point
review_content: Before Hudson's Bay closed down, I used to have a plug at the Yorkdale location who'd always put me on to some nice designer frags... This was one of them. She said that they didn't even have to advertise this one, those who knew, knew, and it was almost always sold out! Man is this one dark, mysterious, and expensive smelling... As a young guy I'm not even sure if it matches...

I have had the fragrance described above in my possession for some time now, even though I don't usually care much for heavy oud scents. On the contrary, they usually get on my nerves at some point. And I swear to you: I have tried almost all of them! I've gone through the Atkinsons, the Laytons, the M7, the Creeds, and even the most dreadful one under the sun, Oud Satin Mood (sticky, disgusting, overpowering, like chewing gum). And I thought I would never learn to love an oud fragrance and be able to add one to my collection, until it entered my life: Gucci - Intense Oud. Just by the name, I thought to myself, this can't be good. Intense and oud? Well, I was proven wrong. Due to the many great reviews, I decided to test it. Luckily. Because what I got is, for me, the most wearable oud fragrance I have tested so far. Let me explain:

Oud Intense is intense, but not in terms of the oud. It is rather fresh-spicy-woody, with the spicy notes lingering more in the background. It also has a slightly fruity touch from pear, raspberry, and orange, which I would not describe as particularly strong. The oud is, of course, also well noticeable, but wonderfully smoothed out by patchouli, amber, and musk. So it is nicely restrained. Where this freshness kick comes from, I do not know. Perhaps from the rose? I leave this analysis to the fragrance pyramid professionals. Besides the freshness, I also perceive a slightly pleasantly bitter, minimal graphite-like note.

In summary, this oud fragrance can be described as a young, slightly fresh-bitter oud scent that is very mass-appealing and straightforward in its progression. The wearer does not need to be dressed in a suit. A shirt, a nice sweater, or a polo shirt is sufficient. It is also suitable for those looking for a very strong but not extreme autumn-winter scent. The longevity for me is between 8-10 hours, and it is almost perceivable up to a meter away until the end. The bottle fits as well. It is elegantly crafted and appears valuable. Price-wise, it is my clear favorite. It costs between 75-90 euros for 90ml, and no other house can compete with that. Therefore, for me, it's a clear 10.

It is unsuitable if you expect a complex masterpiece like the Laytons or Atkinsons. It also would not suit you if you need the full oud blast. And unfortunately, I would ultimately stand against the unisex label. For me, it is a 100% men's fragrance.

P.S.: It has proven its mass appeal by being the most positively commented fragrance in my collection. Even strangers have complimented me on it. Some users are indeed interested in such experiences.

Clear test recommendation,
Your Bene :)

Strangely enough, the scent notes on Parfumo have deviated significantly from those once found at the manufacturer for a long time*. A suggestion for change was rejected with reference to a presumed error on the Gucci page and has now been implemented after all. The annoying thing is that both statements seem to have some validity to me, at least in parts. I will therefore...

Early November, 10 degrees, and the days are getting darker. Time to engage with Oud fragrances. I’m sending 3 fragrances into the race, which not only have Oud in their name but mainly also smell of Oud. Or what I consider Oud. ;) Here we have the reformulated classic from YSL, M7 Oud Absolu. The established reference from Nasomatto, Black Afgano. And the challenger,...

So, now I will take a look at this somewhat neglected fragrance. Certainly, Gucci has played with its trust in being perceived as a major label that understands the art of perfume, with numerous rather unremarkable flankers. Many large top notes dissipate, a significant portion of the budget is funneled into advertising, marketing is emphasized, and the quality of the fragrances sometimes suffers. Nevertheless, it is worth delving into this Intense Oud.

It took a long time for the bottle to find its way to the shelf; I finally came across IO at Oberpollinger. The bottle is well-known, designed in simple black in accordance with an Oud Intense, featuring a golden cap. Even though the bottle has already been seen with Made to Measure, pour Homme, and pour Homme Sport, it is still not unattractive.

This Oud, like its predecessor Oud, did not emerge entirely in a vacuum. While Oud points towards Dark Saphir by Agonist and Black Aoud by Montale, here we find influences from Armani's Bois d'Encens and Encens Satin. The incense and leather, which are initially presented in a dusty, dry guise, reveal a certain roughness. However, this quickly shifts towards much softer realms.

A certain Play-Doh note begins to spread, enveloping the leather and the dry wood. Black Cube and Splendid Wood also possess a bit of this unique Play-Doh note; in my opinion, it is a specific one, as both of these fragrances feature incense and oud, just like Gucci's IO. In Black Cube, amber is also part of the mix, just like here. This combination, when the appropriate facets of eagle wood and incense are used, becomes very smooth, which here is made a bit duller, blunter, broader, and softer by the leather. From this point on, one wants to sink into the fragrance and snuggle into its intense yet always soft power. Once the leather has spread in its soft potency, one tends to see the fragrance walking in the footsteps of Stercus.

To perhaps clarify this Play-Doh note further: if one were to express it harshly, it is even somewhat musty, but this note is so dense, deep, dull, and soft that it remains quite independent when considered on its own and makes a great impression.

Hello friends,

some time ago, when I discovered my first Oud fragrance with Santal Royal and was immediately smitten, I let my emotions guide me and shortly after looked for the next treasure that contained this note.

However, I can’t quite remember how I stumbled upon Gucci Intense Oud. It must have been purely by chance here on Parfumo... You know how it is, you inevitably come across fragrances here that you’ve never heard of before... And so it was - I think - with this one as well.
[...]

I hadn’t really been able to connect with Gucci fragrances until now and found all the ones I had tested - to be honest - quite dreadful and sometimes even repulsive. Normally, I associate this Italian fashion house with some adult wannabe millionaires (maybe they are; good for them) or little “rich kids” who try to make the streets unsafe in certain big cities here with - in my opinion - bizarre and horrible clothes, shoes, or accessories from this brand, along with their flashy cars, without realizing how ridiculous these randomly assembled “garments” actually look (Yes, fashion is of course a matter of taste; but in my eyes, these things just look silly!) Sorry, that’s my opinion.
[...]

Anyway, back to the fragrance itself. I looked at the notes, which I found very promising and enticing at first glance.
“Pear and raspberry? Mmm, sounds interesting and delicious,” I thought first.
“Rose and orange blossom? Sounds like floral undertones, should appeal to me,” I was pleased with the heart note.
“Patchouli, amber, musk, and OUD? Oh yes, if that’s not a great base!” I was quite euphoric and taken with it.

However, the fragrance pyramid had a tiny flaw: saffron! Yes, saffron, the supposedly most valuable spice in the world (at least that’s the common opinion among experts). I had never smelled this note in a fragrance before and had no idea how it actually smells. So I started to ponder a bit and had minimal concerns, but I’ll come back to this in a moment...

Additionally, I read some reviews and watched a few YT videos... So I ordered a decant here in the Souk about 1.5 months ago.
[...]

When the decant arrived at home, I was of course very curious and hoped so much not to be disappointed. Because I particularly had the saffron note in mind...
I sprayed my wrists and at first, a bitter, sour, and slightly spicy cloud of fragrance wafted into my nose... “Hmm, is this the saffron note? Probably,” I answered my own question. Because I didn’t perceive the pear and raspberry at first. But my intuition confidently urged me to wait, and I just trusted my gut feeling, which whispered to me: “Give it time, it’s just starting... It will develop...”

As the fragrance progresses, it indeed shows its great class! The somewhat unpleasant saffron for my nose fades after just a few minutes, and the fruity-delicious combination of pear & raspberry joins in. Due to the rose and orange blossom, the fragrance becomes slightly floral-sweet almost in the same breath, which I really like. The woody touch comes from patchouli and amber, but the oud note is prominent here and is, in my opinion, dominant.
[...]

When the temperatures were significantly cooler compared to these days, I often used my decant and subsequently ordered a bottle. Because I just find it very good!
On my skin, it lasts about 6-7 hours, and the sillage is quite enveloping in the first 3 hours. After that, it can still be smelled directly on the skin.

Conclusion:
In my eyes, this Gucci is a really great and wonderful oud fragrance with slightly sweet tendencies in the background. Despite the somewhat sour and bitter saffron at the beginning for my nose, I find it excellent, as it gets better over time due to its dynamic development. In my opinion, it is best suited for the colder seasons (autumn/winter), and I would prefer it in the evening; however, it can certainly also be worn during the day on cold days, which I will do... :)
It comes across, like most oud fragrances, quite “mature” and I think it’s ideal for men who like to dress classically and elegantly.

For me personally, this is the best Gucci fragrance for men! Although it is marketed as unisex, in my opinion, it is not at all; I can only really imagine it on men. But everyone has to find that out for themselves...

So if you are looking for a great oud fragrance for “Western noses,” you should definitely give this one a try (if you haven’t already). The price-performance ratio is excellent and absolutely convincing; I was able to purchase the 90ml bottle at Notino for €54. And according to the information here, it is discontinued; so don’t waste any time and grab a bottle if you like it ;)
[...]

And I thank each and every one of you for reading!

Best regards

Thanks to the souk and the help of many friendly perfume enthusiasts, I had the pleasure of trying some scents that I might never have encountered otherwise.
One of my greatest discoveries is Gucci Intense Oud. For me, it's a masterpiece from the world of designer fragrances.

I have never tried a "real" oud fragrance, as I have reservations about overly animalic/medicinal scent notes.
All the more, I am glad that the name "Intense Oud" did not deter me from sampling it in this case.
Pear, raspberry, saffron, rose, oud: that sounded intriguing.
And so I was eager to test the fragrance based on a sample.

Upon the first sniff, I was immediately captivated. This scent was simply different from all my previous ones: an alluring oriental temptation with a depth that enchanted me.

Gucci Intense Oud is excellent for special occasions or evenings out (on cooler days), but also perfectly suitable for the office or everyday wear.
You don't need to apply much. The longevity is above average.
I personally enjoy this scent on myself and feel enveloped by a mysterious & seductive aura when wearing it.

The price-performance ratio (around €75 for 90 ml) is very good in my opinion: you get an elegantly appealing and high-quality designer fragrance that stands out significantly from many others.

The bottle is also visually appealing and conveys an elegant impression that matches its contents.

Speaking of designer oud: I also tested "Versace pour Homme Oud Noir | Versace." However, this one fell short of my expectations. It unfortunately offers weak performance and pales in comparison to GIO.
I also tried the very popular Oud Wood EAU DE PARFUM: a good scent, but here too, I prefer Gucci.

Conclusion: Gucci Intense Oud is definitely worth a test and a shining example of the magic of fragrances ;)

He entered my life as a sample and stayed.
When I smelled the first spray on my wrist, I was already smitten.
It awakened something in me.
Simply magical. Slightly smoky and sweet but truly magically attractive. It made me so addicted that the sample was empty within 3 days.
I decided to order a 90ml bottle of Gucci Intense Oud.
However, I was sure that there were too many fakes circulating online. I opted for a Gucci store in Munich, where they told me that the fragrance would soon be discontinued and that’s why it had arrived at the outlet. They gave me a number for an outlet in Ingolstadt.
Since I was offered the 90ml bottle for 100 euros instead of the regular 150, I bought 3 bottles right away.

Back to the fragrance.

It is very seductive.
Not too sweet and not too dark (oud)
I would wear it more in autumn/winter for going out.
But you could also wear it on a cool summer evening.
Definitely very elegant and well-suited for entering the oud world.

In my opinion, the fact that the brand Gucci now has a rather negative reputation also affects the fragrances, and I always assumed that the scents would be less individual and more made for the masses.
Through Parfumo, I came across this fragrance, but I couldn't find a perfume store where I could test it.
Due to the good reviews and the notes that appealed to me very much, I decided to make a blind purchase. I was not disappointed.
It does not smell synthetic and has fantastic longevity and sillage.
I personally don't really perceive the scent after 2 or 3 hours, but it has happened several times that I couldn't smell it anymore, yet I was still approached about it, with the words "expensive" and "very individual" often being mentioned.
In this price segment (around €65 on Notino), I believe there is hardly a better fragrance.
A full recommendation to buy!

In short, this scent is amazing.

Floral, it envelops you with a smoky background that makes it so masculine.
Women love the scent because it smells sweet yet assertively masculine. A man exudes a certain dominance or self-confidence. Probably also because it lasts forever. On clothes, you can smell it until the next wash!!!!

Women over 30 can also wear it without hesitation. It is elegant and sweet enough. But thanks to the smoky background, it's not for younger ones.
It suits a darker type better, in my opinion.

I have found an absolute fragrance twin for those who prefer it less smoky and sweeter: Ajmal 10001 Nights. I use the oil for my wrist in combination. I’ve been told that people would like to bite my hand off?

This scent is my absolute favorite.
Whether for a date, club, or dinner, it fits almost every occasion.

However, I will skip it for the office and summer.

When it comes to oud fragrances, I tend to be skeptical to averse; I don't like this often-praised "animalistic" note, and then there's "Intense Oud."

No thanks. Hm, but it comes from Gucci. Of course, Gucci is also known for extravagance, but you can still give it a try; it's not a niche fragrance. They must pay some attention to their customer base.

And that's exactly how it is.

Gucci Internes Oud is anything but what the name suggests. The opening is quite strong, and you do get a certain oud note in your nose, but fortunately, that fades quickly, and in the heart, there is a beautiful, balanced, robust-spicy note with a slight oriental touch. The whole thing feels very elegant and masculine.

The projection is good, but it doesn't fill entire halls, so it's not a "beast mode" or "sillage monster." You are noticed, but I haven't felt that people around me would rather flee or want to open a window.

Here too, Gucci has done everything right.

A really well-made robust-spicy, slightly oriental fragrance that can be worn on many occasions.

Lovers of rosy scents will surely like Gucci Intense Oud. However, I would rather classify the rose as "intense." The rose scent lingers for several hours, which was too much for me. The fragrance reminded me more of my grandmother, who used to wear Bulgarian rose. The raspberry was quite noticeable at the beginning, which I think is not suitable for a "unisex fragrance." However, the oud was always present with the typical chemical scent in the background. I would have liked to smell something more animalistic here; it all felt rather chemically sterile. As a base note, the oud was still clearly noticeable in the end.
Unfortunately, not a fragrance for me.

I have had my eye on this fragrance for a long time and wasn't quite sure if it was worth a blind buy. In the end, I went for it and would like to share my experience:

I am a big Batman (Christopher Nolan) fan and think that the scent perfectly matches Harvey Dent Two Face. Why? It starts off relatively fruity / similar to TF OW and after about 2 hours shifts to the completely opposite extreme of the spectrum to BA. On one side, there is the very friendly and warm aspect, and on the other, this brutal dark facet that this fragrance brings with it.
Unfortunately, I am not a BA fan, as this scent actually makes me feel nauseous, and I find it a shame that it doesn't completely follow this friendly and warm manner.

Worth a blind buy? No, definitely not, please test it beforehand and take your time to experience the entire fragrance journey.

Gucci Intense Oud

In my rather limited bottle "collection," this wonderful fragrance will soon join. Successfully established against Emporio Armani - Stronger With You Oud and the unfortunately fleeting Polo Oud (which will have to join sooner or later :P)
Rose generally gets on my nerves, but here it works and stays more in the background. Overall, it's a rather subtle Oud scent that has definitely caught my attention :)

review_title: First and probably last Oud fragrance
review_content:
I bought Gucci Intense Oud as my first and probably last Oud fragrance. Since I didn't own any Oud fragrance yet, it was a logical step for me to get one. Having read that it is supposed to be discontinued, I took the plunge with a blind buy under the motto "Now or Never!".
Upon the first sniff, I could detect the pear in the top note, along with a very sour note. I didn't quite like it. I had also read that this one is not supposed to smell as medicinal as other Oud fragrances. Although I haven't tested any others, so I can't make a comparison, over time it had a slight medicinal note for me, mixed with something quite animalistic, almost like sweat. I found it terrible. Others have told me that it doesn't smell that bad, but I still felt uncomfortable with it.
I once had a small discussion with a colleague about the smell of a customer after the customer had left the store. I was firmly convinced that the gentleman had a very strong body odor, but my colleague told me it was a fragrance. This scent reminds me exactly of that smell, which is why I now know my colleague was right. I really lack the imagination to find a situation in which this fragrance would be appropriate. Maybe it's just because of my young age (20), perhaps I will come to appreciate such a fragrance later. However, I cannot recommend this scent at the moment, especially not for young people.

I could almost claim that this fragrance is the best designer oud fragrance.
The scent has a very elegant & masculine character.

The saffron and patchouli give it a slightly dirty and distinctive edge. One can easily perceive the fruitiness of the raspberry.
This fragrance is very well imagined in rainy weather, paired with a leather jacket.
For its price, it delivers decent performance.

For me, it also comes across as slightly alcoholic, busy-like.

...the rumor mill says that the fragrance has been discontinued and that there are only remaining bottles on the market. So better be quick ;) Since Gucci Intense Oud was my very first fragrance, I have a very personal connection to it. In my opinion, it is also the "best" or my "all-time favorite" scent. This fragrance is niche for me! With its limited number of...

When it comes to scent, Gucci Intense Oud is a real knockout. From the very first spray, you are enveloped in a divine, unmistakable aura that screams designer quality. This fragrance is based on oud, a rare, intense, and somewhat animalistic wood. Its potency may seem daunting to some, especially to those not accustomed to an atmosphere reminiscent of a barn. But therein lies...

Gucci Intense was a blind buy because I was craving a velvety oud note - Burgundy Oud was just too expensive for me. Well, you know what they say: if you buy cheap, you buy twice. Don't get me wrong: the fragrance is by no means bad, especially the longevity and sillage are impressive. But for me, it simply wasn't a feel-good scent. Right from the first application, I...

review_title: Less known, but great for getting into the topic of Oud
review_content:
Normally, I'm not a big fan of Oud fragrances, as most of them smell just too intense for me. This one is different. The combination with raspberry and orange makes this scent incredibly pleasant. The longevity and sillage are quite good for me, but not as good as indicated in the average rating. My girlfriend also loves this fragrance and is usually upset when I don't wear it in her presence.

Therefore, an absolute recommendation!

Admittedly, I find it difficult to write a detailed review. I am relatively new to the world of fragrances, which might explain my confusion. Perhaps it is simply the scent that leaves my nose puzzled.

I was expecting a relatively sweet, fruity opening: pear, raspberry, saffron... These notes were all familiar to me. Then I took the cap off the tester and I detected the raspberry. A very sour raspberry. Maybe the acidity is also enhanced by the patchouli? Well, in any case, I sprayed the fragrance and...

No sign of raspberry, pear, or saffron.
I rather perceived a peppery note.

In the drydown, it becomes softer and fruitier and slightly floral. The "acidity" remains, but diminishes.

I haven't formed a solid opinion yet, but I will test it a few more times.

2-3 sprays are enough for admiration. A super oriental, sweet, woody fragrance. The scent is definitely very strong. It lingers on clothing for a long time. You could easily smell it on my clothes a week later. Due to its strength, I would prefer to wear this fragrance in autumn or winter.

To be honest, I was torn between Oud Bouquet and Gucci's Oud Intense. I'm glad I chose Gucci. very beautiful.. It smells like raspberry - pear syrup with cinnamon without sugar, with vanilla and amber. Oud and saffron blend together very lightly and it doesn't irritate my nose. Occasionally, I smell roses. It starts off masculine and over time becomes really...

I was not a Gucci fan for a long time. In fact, this is the second fragrance from Gucci in my 28 years, excluding Guilty Absolute.

The bottle of Intense Oud is very elegant and chic. Intense Oud by Gucci is comparatively linear, yet it does not lack a certain complexity. Fruity notes accompany very subtle oud. Noticeable without being obtrusive.

However, this fragrance definitely stands out. It is subtle but not overpowering, yet still easily perceptible. Spicy, slightly smoky, and with that fruity twist, this is true perfumer's art.

H and S seem, I have only had the fragrance since today, to be very good.

For those looking for a mass-appealing oud fragrance with

The first seconds are a bit strong in the nose, but then it becomes beautifully sweet, mixing nicely with the oud, a very lovely rose that strongly reminds me of whiskey with raspberry!
I perceive it for a long time, and it lasts very long on clothing, very unusual for a designer. Definitely an entry-level oud fragrance, whether you like rose or not, you will enjoy it!

Intense Oud is a truly relatively easy-to-like scent that contains Oud. Certainly a purely synthetic Oud, which is completely normal and fine. The raspberry and pear provide a great topping in the top note. Saffron is also noticeable and fits perfectly with the fragrance. The rose beautifully rounds it off, and the patchouli, musk, and amber smooth out the Oud nicely, making...

The fragrance opens in the top note with raspberry, which is very prominent. It starts off fruity-sweet. However, after a few minutes, I find it also slightly alcoholic, as if a few raspberries were freshly pressed and some were already slightly fermented. Longevity is good. It lasts for several hours. The sillage is also strong, but not too intense. In my opinion, it is a...

Definitely one of the better Gucci fragrances. Rosy, berry wood with a slight sweetness from amber. Smells like a serious, refined man.

I would say, those under 30 shouldn't even bother trying it. It requires a certain maturity and is very likely not to appeal to younger individuals.

The longevity is great, it can last a whole day. Sillage is quite decent.

Cool, cloudy evening. Somewhere between church, cemetery & smoking lounge. The moon illuminates the dark streets, wet asphalt. A man walks by. Dressed in dark black from head to toe. The top hat obscures his face. The umbrella tucked under his arm. Mysterious, a strict stride and - a friendly smile? The associations with Black Afgano EXTRAIT DE PARFUM and...

Designer in a niche coat with bombastic longevity and truly decent sillage. The deep sweetness of raspberry is softened by a dark, dry oud. Although Gucci is not my favorite designer house, this creation convinced me immediately. So, without many words: Gucci Intense Oud is a wonderful companion for the colder season!

---------------------
(Disclaimer: Tastes vary - the review contains only my personal opinion)

Wood, oud, leather, and incense give it enough masculinity, while amber and olibanum add even more allure. A true masterpiece, lasting 12 hours. The projection is not huge, but it doesn't quite reach the skin. The ladies are thrilled. There are essentially no similarities with B.Afgano!

Many thanks to Sören for the sample :-) With "Gucci Intense Oud | Gucci," you are dealing with a truly wonderful, wintery, and Christmas fragrance. Strolling through the Christmas market in the evening, sipping a cup of mulled wine or punch, while the snow is falling... and then there's this perfume! Yes, it fits! The longevity is easily 8-10 hours, and after showering, the scent is still recognizable on the skin. The sillage is similarly impressive.

In the top notes, you can catch a whiff of raspberries and pears - but only for a few minutes. Additionally, saffron is clearly present here. The fragrance pyramid mentions floral aromas in the heart note - I can at least identify them in the form of rose water. Here, the scent DNA drifts into the Christmas season. I detect cinnamon, nutmeg, incense, clove, and myrrh. The base remains smoky with opoponax, but also has a beautifully dark, warm, and woody scent of oud. In the background, there are balsamic, earthy, woody, tobacco-like, vanillic, and animalic hints of amber, musk, and a bit of patchouli.

I understand that some people may want to draw a similarity to "Black Afgano (Extrait de Parfum) | Nasomatto." The smoky note may remind one of this Extrait de Parfum, but for me, the rest has its own unique character.

For me, Gucci Intense Oud is a great fragrance to venture into the spicy, oriental direction. The scent is robust, masculine, and has a beautifully deep quality. The sweetness of the pear and raspberry occasionally makes an appearance. Nevertheless, it remains a deeply spicy and slightly "oud" fragrance. Definitely a recommendation if you want to take a look at the...

I bought this perfume a few years ago because of the many good reviews.
