Of all the heavy oriental scents, I like "intense Oud" the least. I have one of the old versions (Batch 5243) and this earlier batch is quite beastly and lasts forever.
However, it doesn't go down as well with others as Jubilation XXV or Carlisle. Instead of compliments, I have been asked by acquaintances not to wear this perfume anymore. And even in the elevator, I occasionally received a nose wrinkle from others. That's why I haven't worn it in a long time and will definitely sell it again.

Scent: Very dark and heavy, but it's just "too intense" for my taste.
And the oud note comes across as a bit too artificial for me. *self-nose-wrinkle*
I assume that there is no real oud in Gucci anyway.
But for those who like beastly-animalic scents, it should definitely be worth trying.

Occasion: I really wouldn't know for what occasion. Maybe if you want people to keep their distance on the train or subway ;-)

Season: Only winter, only outdoors. Definitely not an office scent; Versace Oud Noir would be more suitable for that.

I find this scent beautiful and my wife likes it on me as well. However, I don't think I would repurchase it, as it is just too "bland" compared to my many other fragrances. What I do appreciate is that the Oud used is not animalic at all. I believe everyone would like this scent, so it makes a great gift.

As one of the most popular colognes sold right now (currently #3 on Amazon) I was very surprised that this cologne only received average ratings.

The cologne is one of my personal favorites and works great in almost every situation as a neutral scent. You can wear it day or night and at work or out playing.

One of the best main stream colognes out there in my opinion but I just don't understand why it's ranked so low.

Oh golly, too strong! Way, way too strong.

Can you believe there is now an intense flanker of Gucci Guilty for Men? Well I can't, and I sure hope I don't smell it on any man I date.

Gucci Guilty is a mish-mash of sharp citrusy lemon, powerful lavender, soapy orange blossom and earthy patchouli. The overall blend is quite, well what's the word, sour. The man in the poster may look like he's 'God's gift to women' with the lady below him looking as if she might be thrown into the thralls of passion at any given moment, but I highly doubt her reaction has anything to do with his perfume, if you know what I mean.

At times it feels as if Gucci was aiming for a citrus aquatic, something slightly sporty and fresh, but the peppery and earthy patchouli and woods kind of crushes that idea. God only knows where this perfume is supposed to be worn. Fingers crossed men don't wear this hoping to get lucky in the bedroom. I think you might get a negative response.

Unfortunately I don't find Gucci Guilty for Men all too sweet either. I think I may have liked a little sweetness to balance out the scent. All I can say for this fragrance is that the longevity and sillage are very good, near excellent if I actually liked this God damn fragrance!

The worst masculine from Gucci by far. I am saddened by this because I've been impressed by most of the male fragrances from this brand, namely Envy, Gucci pour Homme (original) and Gucci pour Homme II. In fact, skip this fragrance entirely. Buy the three I mentioned above. Yes, do that.

LOL! Ok Gucci is my favorite designer house. However, they have been such a let down in the fragrance department as of late. This is so not Gucci. It is a mixture of 50 different scents combined, SYNTHETIC @ it's best! Smells like 1 of Joop's creations, reminds me of ahhhh Lanvin Homme YES!!!! BLAH! Last 6 hours or so on me & then it makes it's exit. The dry down is such a let down. I am really fed up with Gucci from a fragrance stand point!

This new crap they develop & put on the market today is very messy indeed. I have not liked anything this house has made after Envy for men. Everything else was a miss or did not last long enough for me to get a bottle. ( GUCCI POUR HOMME 2 )

Guilty should appeal to those who like GUCCI just because that's who made it & to those who may think the bottle is nice which it is, however do not expect to impress anyone with this. You will just be 1 of the many other people in the crowd not standing out, but following the circus.

…as ratings suggest.
I’ve seen this one on the shelf at my friend’s house, and remembered that Zara Silver is presumed to be the dupe of Gucci Guilty.
I have Zara Silver since many years ago, and despite of being a boring mainstream scent, I really liked it. To be honest, when they were released, every second boy had this type of scent, it was somehow like PR 1M and Zara Uomo.
I wondered if they were really similar or not, so we did some business.
Yeah, that’s true. And I like both of them!
As time passed, they became unpopular, and now I decided to give them a chance again.

This sweet/neroli combo reminds me of Joop! Homme, but Gucci is more fresh, I can imagine as Joop’s Summer version.

Clean, sweet, fresh, easy to wear, for any occasion. Just spray on and enjoy.

There's nothing wrong with a perfume being mainstream. This one certainly fits that description. It's easy-going, friendly, versatile and yet not completely without a soul. Citrusy and floral, not so sweet. In the base there is patchouli, which makes it suitable for evening wear. Maybe not clubbing, as it's not heavy on ambrox or tonka.

Performance is just so-so. Two to three hours of decent projection after which it slowly starts to fade. The EDP flanker is similar and lasts longer.

review_title: I guess we can outgrow some perfumes
review_content: I owned two bottles of this nice EDT, the first one was a big surprise back in 2011 when I smelled it and I got a bottle right away. The scent was nice and unique back then, now 9 years later is very mainstream and every cheap drug store sells perfumes at 10% the price of this one smelling the same. The longevity was quite good, I could feel it on the clothes the next days...

Smells much like Allure Homme Sport, so it's a big disappointment for me considering the masterpieces GPH I and GPH II.

Sillage, lasting power and projection are below average. Thumbs down.

Updated January 2014

This is a scent that I wish had just more projection and longevity. It smells amazing, and the pink pepper does not perform like it usually does with a bubblegum scent for me. This is classy and sexy and would be amazing for any formal event/setting, or in an office since it does not project loudly.

I sprayed 6 times, 4 pulse points, 1 on the shirt, one behind the neck, and it just does not speak or last; even on clothing. It has nothing to do with being nose blind, as I have worn the Invictus parfum for hours and it lasted (and stayed pronounced) even after a run and a shower. I know this is an EDT, but I have other EDTs, like JPG Le Beau, that perform so much better. I need to try the parfum of this version to see if it is any better.

The notes start off with a sweet citrus that lingers throughout the evolution, then the scent opens into a hearty floral smell with the base of a light wood. The scent just smells extremely clean and has a spicy, soapy profile, as well. I absolutely love the way this one smells, but for the money and the performance I can't justify buying this again or recommending it.

This one I had only once in my lifetime and I wouldn't like to get again. It doesn't smell synthetic, which is the best thing I can say about this perfume. The smell was just very basic and average, you can buy similar scent perfumes for fracture of this cost. It is extremely overpriced(maybe because they had to pay a lot for commercial and actors for promotion) and doesn't worth it. I got this perfume just because it was very hyped and everyone wanted to have them. Why? I'm still not sure. I really can't understand those reviews with 10/10 scent. So, you're literally saying that's the best smell you've ever had? I'm feeling sad for you then. Don't buy it, save your money.

review_title: Clean Gummy Candy - Shower Gel in Good
review_content:
I like it. Very pleasing. Sexy. Understated. Radiates cleanliness and a sweet fruity (masculine) spicy shower gel freshness. With a slightly metallic aura.

I can't pick out individual notes here. Everything flows together without contours and results in a "cooked down" mass. The orange blossom is the most recognizable - as I knew it - it is restrainedly sweet, with a slight oriental (spicy) effect in its fullness, and like the entire fragrance, it is pleasantly balanced. I always associate the distinct shower gel aspect in such scents with sweet-spicy lavender (from Spain? - I once heard that the further south, the sweeter). From my perspective, this is also responsible for the masculine orientation. Lactonic notes, which are not listed here, create the smooth food gummy impression that can be perceived as metallic and cool. Accompanied by a hinted vanilla feeling. The transparent violet of the liquid fits well with the character of the fragrance, as it has enough (attractive) substance/depth alongside the cool basic freshness.

Overall, I get the impression of a sweet-spicy gummy candy shower gel with a subtly oriental vibe and a clean, slightly metallic basic freshness. An underlying, hinted soapy quality provides a well-groomed and traditional touch. This elevates the fragrance for me - alongside its understatement - above the mass of similarly positioned shower gel scents and keeps it in an interesting tension between popular-modern pleasingness (which predominates) and classically oriented grooming (which rounds it off).

What I find particularly interesting is that it strongly focuses on this smooth gummy candy note. It is very stable and rounded, without scratchiness or fraying throughout. Quality or well-crafted synthetic. I like this thematic simplicity or reduction, and it is the strength of the fragrance for me. It does not pretend to be different and does not "sneak" any shower gel freshness into the composition out of calculation, which usually bothers me in function. Good longevity on my skin rounds off the positive overall impression. Sexy & chewy!

Gucci Guilty, the new heavily advertised mainstream fragrance, launched at a rather strange time: just after the Christmas shopping season; I would love to ask their marketing folks what they were expecting from that... ;-)
As part of the promotion, there was even a special stand at our Müller in the mini city with all the bells and whistles, and I was showered with samples everywhere over the last few months.

About the scent itself:
At first sniff, I quite liked it, and subconsciously, I was already expecting a rating of 70%. But then came the tests, which turned out to be very disappointing.
On the skin, I don't really like it anymore, and by now, I can't stand it on strips either.
What's the reason?! The top note (as far as I can perceive it; if you spray it on the side or have a bad day, these things are gone before you know it or smell) is quite pleasant, a bit of lavender in concentrations that I find acceptable.
And what comes after?
-> the chemical club, a synthetic something and a long-term horror - the notes can be thrown straight into the trash, as an indefinable strange thing comes along that haunts you for hours, hardly changes for me, and penetrates; I could never really smell the base notes (probably the soap was already at work beforehand), and this strange pseudo-heart note has burned itself into my memory, making one wonder what could possibly be understood under orange blossom. An attempt to describe the reality would be: cheap chewing gum with a failed peppermint substitute-something-else and fruit aroma E xyz...

This leaves the question "How did it get the strange title," did the top note tip over in the heat, and is it mentally approaching the lawn mower man from the eponymous film, or what’s going on?! After all, you can't smell anything grassy there...
The answer is very banal: I transferred some sample packets into a travel sprayer, as they are just the good old tubes without anything, and since I want to fill something new in them again, Guilty is annoying me by now, I never want to wear it publicly again and have it around me all day, I decided today to wear it for mowing the lawn and use it up: every 1-3 weeks, I will properly douse myself before heading to grandpa's, where you are then busy for a good hour, sweating decently, chatting a bit with grandpa, and then leaving; sweated out, dry, dusty, and slightly tired, it will soon be time for a shower, where a thorough cleaning takes place...
(also, the clothes go straight to the laundry)
While mowing the lawn, Guilty doesn't annoy me, it's OK - today’s attempt proved this even in the heat (there's nothing left; due to sweating, it was also less intense at some point)

PS: I have nothing against my grandpa and don't want to torture him or use Guilty to make him ask me, the lazy boy, not to mow the lawn so often... ;-)

Haven't bought a fragrance in years. A lot has changed...
...now you can even rate fragrances on the internet.

I was relatively satisfied for some time with two Boss balls and the summer edition from Boss, until it became a bit monotonous towards the end. Additionally, a Gucci fragrance had accompanied me in my subconscious for 15 years. It gave me a warm feeling in combination with the memories associated with it from back then.

So I did some research (googled Gucci) and ordered Guilty.
First impression ''mhhh delicious, this is it...''

Almost like back in the day with that white square (name unknown...guilty), which, although not identical to the currently described Guilty, is similar. This Gucci Guilty is, in my opinion, heavier, meaning in the context of the notes, more woody-smoky.

The ''base line'' (I don't have the politically correct perfume terminology down...guilty) so the ''main scent'' (yes, it's getting worse...guilty) reminds me of an incredibly interesting time and is very close to the fragrance from back then.

The notes are not particularly complex, but they radiate an attractive warmth. No mega sillage (with 2-3 ''sprays'') for oneself, yet the fragrance is still pleasantly noticeable for a long time. For those closer to you, even longer. Rarrrrrrr
For a good duration of 8-9 hours.
So... why not guilty mmmhhh...

review_title: I quite like it, whether the gentlemen will too remains to be seen
review_content:
After the disappointment with the women's fragrance, I was rather skeptical when Guilty pour Homme was announced. And the expectation was indeed justified, as the scent smells exactly as indicated in the pyramid. Not more and not less, and no note stands out particularly. Thus, for me, it is a very pleasant daytime fragrance when I want a scent without a significant message.

But which gentlemen will see it that way? The Boss faction certainly won't, as it's not warm enough for them. The Le Male fans find it too conservative. The One Million guys think it's too boring, the Joop freaks find it not oriental enough, and the "something fresh" customers think it's not sporty enough.

However, I find it very harmonious, and I particularly like the dark, woody base. The fragrance has a fundamental mood that runs throughout its entire progression. It doesn't make leaps, has no surprises, and there's no vanilla or herbal notes sneaking in through the back door.

Now I'm curious to see how the black-silver bottle with the double G will be received by the gentlemen.

I recently got it and find it significantly more tolerable and less synthetic than Dior Sauvage EdT. I don't understand why some reviews are rather negative. The scent is citrusy and fresh, making it well-suited for spring.
I also find the fragrance quite masculine, and my girlfriend likes it a lot.

Fueled by a very pleasant memory of Gucci Guilty Intense, I wanted to try the corresponding counterpart for men as well. To get straight to the point, after an initial euphoria, the result unfortunately turned out to be rather sobering.

Scent:
The scent itself has a lemony, captivating, and velvety top note that clings to the body, slightly sweet, which for me neither smells synthetic nor comes across as too intrusive.
In contrast to the top note, the heart note, where I can only faintly perceive the orange blossom, already seems very restrained. It is a very delicate fragrance, but it is also overshadowed by hints of patchouli and cedarwood, making it difficult to distinguish between the heart and base notes. One could now comfortably describe the scent as a homogeneous blend of all components, which - as many before me have pointed out - leaves a distinctly synthetic impression.
After a few hours, only a certain oriental warmth from the patchouli and cedarwood can be perceived. The scent fades more or less into empty space...

Bottle:
With the Gucci emblem on the front of the bottle, Gucci Guilty pour Homme can easily be classified into the large Gucci family. What I also notice is that the bottles of the Gucci Guilty members are quite similar, with the women's being gold and this one silver. I would also criticize that the cap of the bottle unfortunately cannot be locked, which poses a risk when handling it and can easily slip out of your hand.

Sillage:
Even with the sillage, only the hint of a scent trail can be perceived at the beginning, so that inclined male and female connoisseurs quickly lose interest when trying to turn around on the street.

Conclusion:
Unfortunately, with Gucci Guilty pour Homme, especially in contrast to Gucci Guilty Intense, the initial interest quickly wanes, resulting in only a brief scent liaison. Guilty pour Homme thus joins the ranks of mainstream fragrances and leaves no truly lasting impression.

Here is my latest acquisition. No, not purchased, but received as a Christmas gift from my employer. And I must say, it's a home run.
I had to try it right away, so I sprayed some on my wrist.
The first impression: amazing! A pleasantly citrusy note that thrilled me, but slightly softened by the pepper. After that, it remains fruity, then takes a pleasant turn as the lavender comes to the forefront. This scent is rounded off by an increasingly woody and spicy note, leaving an incredibly masculine impression.
For me, this fragrance is a real surprise; I like it. Longevity and sillage are okay. I would say the bottle is not one that stands out as a highlight.
In any case, it’s one of my new favorite fragrances!

review_title: Lifeless mixed fresh scent at supermarket shelf level
review_content:
I can only say: "Gucci pour homme". "Gucci pour homme II". "Gucci Envy".

THAT was Gucci's heyday in the fragrance world.
Since then?

As far as the nose can reach: insignificant, interchangeable, watery-fresh stuff, for which one shouldn't spend more than 10 euros for 50 ml.

I don't have much to say about "Guilty": fresh 08/15 start, a bit of lemon, homeopathic lavender.

A hint of orange, surrounded by shallow wood, with a trace of soap on top. Doesn't hurt anyone. But nobody needs it!

This could also be produced by "8x4" or "Axe". But at least they are fair with their prices.

Before I go into detail about this fragrance, I must say that I am positively surprised, as the reviews are rather negative and I would consider this men's fragrance to be a unisex perfume.

The top note has a lovely lemon aroma with a pleasant spiciness. The heart note is beautifully floral with a hint of orange blossom. The base offers a combination of a green-earthy patchouli note, but the base also slightly reminds me of that Solero ice cream aroma consisting of orange and vanilla.

The longevity on clothing is quite solid, and on the skin, it can be detected for up to 8 hours. The sillage, on the other hand, could be improved.

When I bought Guilty Intense for myself yesterday, the attentive saleswoman also offered me Guilty pour Homme.
My husband shouldn't go home empty-handed.

I had previously avoided the Guiltys - after all, who wants to smell "guilty"?

But Intense taught me otherwise, and so I let Pour Homme pass through my nose as well.

Here too, I am greeted warmly by lavender and lemon - a slightly nostalgic blend that immediately puts me in a positive mood.
The orange blossom warms the scent into something cozy.
Patchouli gives Guilty depth, and the cedarwood adds a hint of smokiness.
Nevertheless, the scent remains well-balanced - without being lukewarm.
It makes a likable statement that is far removed from "guilty".

I can easily imagine this scent on my friend, who prefers to wear men's fragrances.

review_title: Guilty of being an inconsequential fragrance
review_content:
I find it very sad how poorly and also inconsequentially almost all Gucci fragrances smell.
I unfortunately do not know Gucci pour Homme I, but it is said to have been an excellent fragrance. However, I do know Gucci pour Homme II, which is one of my favorite fragrances because it smells absolutely wonderful, although unfortunately with a slightly stronger pepper note.

Therefore, since I got to know pour Homme II, I have always been curious about how other fragrances from Gucci would smell. And each time I was disappointed, so that I no longer paid attention to most of them. Then I thought that maybe I was just blinded by Pour Homme II and decided to test again.

But no, … it actually seems that Gucci has hardly any good fragrances besides the Pour Hommes,… which makes the disappointment even greater.

The fragrance:
The fragrance starts briefly fresh with a lemon. Then you can smell a bit of lavender.
Especially in the sweet notes, you can recognize the almost dripping synthetic quality.
So, synthetic doesn’t always have to be bad, but here the fragrance almost comes off as a cheap scent that was carelessly created for the mass market.
A little later, light orange blossoms are added, but it remains sweetish.
In the end, the typical woody notes (cedar) form the base and make the fragrance a bit warmer, and that’s about it.

The sillage and longevity:
The sillage is at best above average. The citrus notes are not zesty enough to project well, the fragrance leaves no scent trail and is therefore only slightly perceived nearby.
The longevity is also low, lasting just about four to five hours.

The bottle:
The bottle is quite okay. The lower part is dark gray and not transparent. The upper area is glass and thus visible. The name of the fragrance is on the front, and a metallic Gucci logo has been attached, which upon closer inspection resembles a Batman logo, which I quite like!

I call this a disappointment across the board. Poorly made synthetic sweetness, carelessly mixed and apparently marketed for people who are only after brands and reach for the fragrance based on the actually strong Gucci brand. At least one could think so…

In any case, this fragrance does not have the class and quality of a Pour Homme II (or probably even I). Unfortunately, it is also not good in any other way, but smells at most "nice without anything but nothing more" and is absolutely inconsequential and replaceable by any random fragrance.

On top of that, there are the weak sillage and longevity and … well, I think nothing more needs to be said.

One can do nothing but sit down and wonder how Gucci could even release something as great as the two Pour Hommes (and perhaps a few other) fragrances. I also wonder if the ladies suffer similarly from inconsequential Gucci fragrances,… well, I will find that out eventually.

In any case, I can only hope that someday a Pour Homme III will appear that can reconnect with the wonderful older fragrances. Hopefully, this wish is not very unlikely…

A Gucci like a runaway "Boss", lemon at the top, biochemical formulas at the heart. Sweetly glued pressboard only if you're willing to wait for it. The orange blossom? A chimera!
On the bottle: The Batman emblem in a dive-arrow position. A bolt gun that’s better left alone. Silver flask for bread-and-butter men.
Then let’s rather write in the name that it’s for sinful boys and offer it to them in roulette with 50 derivatives as soon as there’s a need for "something fresh". Making room for up-and-comers who have run out of Axe.
Ah, what am I rambling about here around my verdict. There are more modest tastes than mine. And if I should really meet someone who wears "Guilty" with dignity, I will praise him - because he perfectly underscores his healthy average with this.

When I first saw Guilty by Gucci, I thought: “Hmm … at least a stylish bottle”

But at the same time, I wondered: “Will they manage to create a somewhat decent fragrance this time?”

In my opinion, Gucci hasn't really produced anything useful since Nobile. Perhaps "Rush," which I always associated with the Canadian rock trio of the same name, was relatively acceptable.

So I set my expectations relatively low from the start, so I wouldn't be too disappointed.

And lo and behold - Guilty is just as unexciting as many of its olfactory peers.

Initially, there was a glimmer of hope because the slightly fruity floral lemon lavender top note pleasantly surprised me. But then it quickly became rather agreeable. With patchouli and cedarwood, much better things could be done.

Guilty is a fragrance that perhaps wants to seem seductive, but ultimately exudes the charm of gray bread. Personally, it's too mass-compatible for me, too safe, and thus too ordinary and too boring.

From a marketing perspective, the name is quite cleverly chosen. But what good is that if the content doesn't hold up?

As a newbie in the world of fragrances, I am (still) quite fond of mainstream scents. Just like with this fragrance. Recently, when I made a purchase at Douglas, I received this scent as a sample. Immediately, I checked on Parfumo how this fragrance was rated... Very poorly. Okay, I had no high expectations and applied it in the evening before going to sleep. Just two or three sprays and I noticed that this scent is very weak, so I added three more sprays, following the motto: more is more. Now the scent slowly started to reach me. Orange blossom and lemon came to mind first. Perhaps a bit synthetic, but well done. Alright, off to bed. The scent quickly transferred to the pillow and has something calming and clean about it. It made me forget the stress of everyday life and (took) me to a cloud bed and a beautiful dream world. The next evening, my pillow still held the Guilty scent. Nice for cuddly falling asleep. Some might think: I told you so, the scent is so boring, you can only fall asleep with it. But that’s not what I meant; rather, it’s nice as a sleep scent or for cuddling with a loved one, but I don’t think I will ever buy this fragrance, as it’s just too weak for me. You can only smell it when cuddling closely. To leave a scent trail behind, you would have to bathe in it. It’s a shame that it’s so weak.
I can’t understand the name Guilty, as I would have imagined a darker, evil, 'dirty' scent rather than such a soft, bright, fresh, clean, and rather innocent fragrance. To me, it also comes across as a bit powdery.
As I said, I haven’t come across better fragrances in this direction yet; there may certainly be better ones, but at the moment I really like this scent. It may be that in two years I will think differently about this fragrance, but my current feeling cannot be taken away from me.

review_title: Gucci Guilty? Pack your bags and get out of here!
review_content:
No, no, and no again!
This perfume has nothing to do with Gucci! Absolutely nothing. Not even in the slightest. What a shame, really. - Because what is the advertising doing here?
It presents a man, the seducer of all female creatures, who can engage with almost any woman, even if she makes it difficult for him.

The advertising is nothing new. Like with many men’s perfumes. But here, the reality, I believe, has gone “drinking”..

When sprayed, it reminds me of absolutely nothing. Cedarwood, lemon, etc. where are you? It not only smells boring, it is boring. A hint of orange does eventually come through, but what am I supposed to do with a dull orange? I was visibly relieved when I no longer smelled it. The shower didn’t save it anyway.

The bottle is well made, but the scent is intended but not executed well.
What a shame - Gucci is a very prominent name in the world of perfumes. One application was enough, and that was only because I got it at a bargain price.

Gucci Guilty EdT is a fruity, light fragrance without much complexity. Lemon, orange, and neroli, along with a bit of lavender (fresh, not musty heavy), pepper, and woods. That's it. I like such uncomplicated scents because they are versatile. Therefore, I appreciate them.

The downside is always the performance. The longevity is not really good, about 4 hours. The sillage is also hardly worth mentioning, Guilty is a skin-close scent. Unless you overspray. Even then, you probably won't offend anyone. The bottle is simple and beautiful, and the price is okay if you catch it on sale (I got it for around 40€/50ml). Give it a try, even for a blind buy!

Gucci Guilty is almost the quintessential mainstream commercial product, almost too cliché and almost too easy to see through. The advertising campaign has been taken to the extreme.

First of all, the name Gucci Guilty is very well chosen. An alliteration with the two G's on the heavy beats of the speech rhythm. The two G's can also be found in the logo on the bottle, in the two intertwined G's. Both words are silvery and end with an i-sound. That's something to achieve.

The ad clips were conceived with Frank Miller. It is his comics that were adapted into film under the name Sin City by Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino. The city of Sin City is almost depicted in a cliché manner. Criminal priests, a clergy that controls the street prostitution, sadistic, pedophilic senator's sons, and under recitations of psalms, the death penalty is carried out. Betrayal, greed, drama. Inspired by this spirit, a fragrance collection for women and men is created under the direction of Frida Giannini. The ad clips show the anonymous urban jungle. Opacity and anonymity hang in the air. Almost a numinous atmosphere. To the sounds of Depeche Mode's song "Strangelove," it shows a city loner, who knows no emotional attachment, meeting a woman with whom he spends the evening and then continues on his lonely path. Yet as a symbolic gesture, he takes her bracelet (from the house of Gucci) with him. Heroic, masculine, and daring, isn't it?

This is the stuff that Gucci Guilty is supposed to be made of. Hm, how does one achieve that olfactorily? What is suitable here?

The fragrance pyramid here at parfumo looks a bit different than the one on the Gucci homepage.
There it says: Lemon, mandarin, green leaves (crushed green leaves in English), pink pepper, lavender, coriander, orange blossom, neroli, patchouli, cedarwood, sandalwood, amber.

I can't really smell the mandarin, but the pepper blends well with the orange blossom, patchouli, and amber. Since the scent does not change subtly and everything is quickly in place, I now smell: lemon, pepper, orange blossom, patchouli, cedarwood, and amber. All together makes quite an impression. Disorderly, chaotic, and bold comes out as the effect. The orange blossom is said to have an aphrodisiac effect, or so the rumor goes. Patchouli has the potential to be dirty. Unfortunately, the highest quality raw materials were not used, and thus the execution is not entirely successful. But the scent can do a bit, I won't write it off.
The imperfect is written on its forehead. Beauty flaw? Definitely! The spoiled? Perhaps it is meant to be suggested. Does it concern the wearer? No! Is the scent unrefined? I would say so. A trustworthy, serious scent? Rather secondary. Can it afford to be? It doesn't care. Does it bring him joy? Irrelevant.
If the advertising machinery is so enormously elaborate, one might automatically think of a bad scent that is being pushed to the customer through the advertising. The advertising is so powerful that I believe one quickly suspects compensation for a lousy scent. Yet I enjoy the scent because it is uncomplicated. It smells completely natural. It is not a demanding and meticulous construction, but therein lies the charm, I think.

There are so many things that the scent simply does not care about.

I throw myself, it seems, more often into the fray for much-maligned fragrances. It can't be due to a protective instinct or a tendency towards principled fundamental opposition. Do I perhaps just have bad taste in scents? Or am I a bore? The latter was at least what this psych test in Neon claimed. It reached this conclusion partly because I find Jennifer Aniston more interesting than Angelina Jolie. So please! What kind of question is that???

Back to business. Guilty also disappointed me on the first test - as so often, I only came to appreciate it after several tries. On my skin, it primarily smells of cardamom, and it is quite aquatic with a hint of an indeterminate sour citrus fruit. The image I associate with this scent is glass; rough, small shards of glass in gray and violet. What this image has to do with the scent itself, I can't even say; I just keep seeing it in my mind's eye when I smell Guilty. And it is not negatively charged for me.

Certainly, it is not my favorite fragrance, but I do enjoy using it from time to time - and I find it quite sexy and daring, definitely not boring. The longevity is good, however, the scent shifts on my clothes after about 18 hours into a cliché note of oriental massage oil. That’s not so uplifting anymore, so I have to air out the clothes properly or toss them in the wash. If nothing else, that’s what the stuff is guilty of: I can forgive that.

review_title: Synthetic Power Shower Gel / will please everyone. But I am not everyone.
review_content:
Nice that I just had a second and final test run, which looked like this: In the back of my mind was the information that I had recently tested another Gucci Silverback.

I unscrewed the cap from the sample stick, moved my nose towards the fragrance dispenser - a tiny moisture rim even dripped onto my finger.
Here we go again! That unmistakable mainstream feeling is coming back! Yuck!

A bit of everything: lemon and orange for the bright sharp fruity, patchouli and cedarwood for the dark woody, some fluffiness thrown in, a whole lot of synthetic power shower gel for the average Joe.

Everything in equal parts, nothing can be recognized, it’s just a melange, a fresh-sporty-sticky mush,
It stings, bites, burns, done!
This is just as bland as any deodorant with the label "Sport".

You can't go wrong here!!!!!!!!!! let the marketing department cheer.
Yes, and nothing right either.
The sheer boredom and forced lack of statement annoys me.
All the more so because it’s probably quite long-lasting, it could even be durable.
To save my skin, I washed it off.

Is this a GUCCI?
But not the same. As described below, the marketing strategists of the Kering Group are desecrating its legacy. {Sure, I know Gucci Pour Homme I, and I haven't had the chance to extensively test GPH II yet.}
---
After reviewing my list, I raised it from 10% to 40%.
It’s not as bad as the truly tasteless Made to Measure from Gucci, for which I gave 20%.

At least Gucci Guilty doesn’t make me feel sick and it doesn’t offend the taste buds like, for example, L'Homme Parfum Intense by Yves Saint Laurent (2013) with 10%. These 10% are after accounting for all efforts, such as the dramatic shift in character within the first few minutes.

It’s simply unoriginal, interchangeable, arbitrary. In vocational school, you need 60% to pass with a 4. So 40% is a really fair failing grade for me.

review_title: Fruity-meaty, unspectacular patchouli-melon that is unworthy of the name Gucci!
review_content:
One of the biggest disappointments of recent years and not at all worthy of the great, traditional brand Gucci... only the stylish bottle is still okay, the rest is pretty much trash, not disgustingly bad, but even far from mediocrity.

The few ingredients already suggest above, oh isn't that a bit too little and uninspired... and that's exactly how it is. Sometimes less is more and the simplest things are the tastiest, but that's not the case here. It's so damn boring, outrageously arbitrary, and has been done better a thousand times before. I won't write a long comment either, this shower gel scent that calls itself perfume isn't worth it. Sillage and longevity are just about okay. The scent of fresh lemoniness and patchouli and wood is not an absolute stinker but rather reminds one of a €5 discount fragrance or a €2 shower gel.

Gucci Guilty PH Intense will be tested soon and is said to be significantly better, but that's not really hard to achieve!

review_title: Guilty in the Sense of Good Taste
review_content:
Gucci Guilty is such a "fragrance" that you can't escape. Now, we don't have many perfumeries here, so the scents are offered in stores like Debenhams, Brown Thomas, or Boots, and that very excessively.
I don't know what got into Gucci to launch such a fragrance, because you usually associate the name Gucci with a certain style and not an Ed Hardy knockoff.

In Ireland, this "fragrance" was launched with great advertising effort and is supposedly one of the most popular scents in the 20-30 age group.
I believe that without reservation.

Guilty is an attempt to rescue the powerhouse fragrances of the seventies and eighties into the new millennium, and this attempt has pretty much failed miserably. Guilty smells like a Saturday night in Cork when college graduates rent a stretch limo and exuberantly roam through the clubs.
It's like a mix of Lynx "Dark Temptation" and testosterone.

You hardly perceive any ingredients, just a sweet mix of floral scents. It could just as well say in the fragrance notes "old socks" and "four-week-old underwear," and you wouldn't recognize it.
No, dear people at Gucci, that was probably a grab in the trash, or a desperate attempt to regain a foothold in the fragrance market. However, this attempt has thoroughly failed and at best lures Irish youths with too much testosterone into the stores, so they can indulge extensively at the tester before heading off to their date. The Irish girls are mercilessly knocked out by such a cloud of fragrance.
Really a shame.

When you see the bottle, you get exactly that: A fresh, clean, elegant, and slightly metallic scent! Lightness and freshness dominate the fragrance, and you immediately think of elegance and luxury, but at the same time, the perfume also smells masculine and smooth due to the metallic undertone!
The scent doesn't seem to be very popular or widespread, which I honestly don't understand, especially since the longevity is perfectly fine!
A good alternative and comparable to Prada L'Homme, which is also a soapy, fresh, and elegant perfume - for me, it's clearly suitable for the office, a fancy dinner, or an evening gala, but also not out of place in everyday life!
For me, an underrated fragrance that you can't go wrong with.

Guilty pour Homme EAU DE TOILETTE is a fresh-fruity fragrance for men. In certain aspects, it also seems a bit unisex to me. After the first spray, you get a fruity, mild scent. Over time, this sweetness develops into a woody, slightly spicy direction. Additionally, there is a lasting freshness.

For me, this is a great everyday and office scent that is subtle and not overpowering. It is particularly pleasant to wear on warm spring days. A good, affordable recommendation for me.

So this is how it should smell to be guilty. Fresh, fruity, floral, slightly citrusy, slightly sweet, slightly synthetic, minimally woody in the later stages. Light, harmless, friendly, but not endearingly charming. Okay. Guilty pour Homme EAU DE TOILETTE is not a fragrance that completely convinces me. It's the kind of scent you can always wear and that doesn't...

GG is relatively uncomplicated, citrusy without being sharp, lavender balances the top note quite well, which, however, only lasts relatively short (20 min max). After that, I don't perceive any orange blossom at all, unfortunately. It may also be because it is so artificial that one cannot even recognize it.

For me, it is not well done, similar to JPG Fleur du Male - I think orange only works when it is used in a high-quality way and processed gently (I always say, Grand Bal from Dior Privee :D )

Also well done in Coco by Chanel.

Here, unfortunately, very synthetic, the head and base notes blur together and the development is very marginal. The cedarwood with lingering lemon hits me hard after 30 minutes and I wish something would happen, but nothing happens anymore...for the next 5 hours...then it fades away.

Unfortunately too boring for me, without a highlight - not bad and not offensive, but also not positively outstanding. Sweet lemon in an average scent, which is available at a low price and will certainly be a good alternative for some.

The scent starts off really interesting and is very similar to other Guilty perfumes, including the Love Edition. After much consideration, I ultimately decided not to purchase this fragrance.

I noticed that while this scent develops nicely, it becomes almost undetectable after a few hours. As soon as you spray another perfume, you can hardly smell Guilty at all. That was the point where I found it disappointing. I particularly enjoy the light citrus and heavy notes in this fragrance; it develops quite charmingly. Therefore, I recommend switching to the perfume from Gucci to fully appreciate the experience. It shouldn't come across negatively regarding the scent, as it is truly good.

review_title: Acquittal due to lack of evidence
review_content:
Well, Gucci hasn't released a decent men's fragrance in a while. So for me, Guilty is already a positive signal. Okay, nothing spectacular happens, but the patchouli-cedarwood base is not to be underestimated. Together with a strong orange blossom and a splash of lemon, Guilty is certainly not to blame for smelling bad. Even the quality is somewhat acceptable; sure, there are better ones, but this perfume leaves quite a decent impression.

Sammy :-)

As the title of this review suggests, I cannot remember my first perfume. I’m probably not the first one to think about this and be unable to recall.

The "Guilty pour Homme" by Gucci could possibly ignite my passion for perfumes, something even the saleswoman at the duty-free shop in Cyprus could not have guessed.

But let’s start from the beginning:

It’s summer - I am in my training - the first big vacation is coming up.

After extensive research, I decided on Cyprus as my vacation destination.
However, let’s jump straight to the duty-free shop in Cyprus.

We were greeted warmly, and without much thought, I was determined to buy something there for my mother.

How I ended up at the Gucci testers for my mother after a successful search, I unfortunately no longer remember. There it was - the first contact with Guilty pour Homme by Gucci.
It was indeed "love at first sniff," as they often say.

Now it came to the decision: "EdT" or "EdP"?
As an "inexperienced lad," I didn’t know these terms - I was aware that there are different strengths/durations, but I had never used the technical terms/designations.
It should be noted that Gucci only mentions this on the packaging and possibly hides it at the bottom of the bottle.

After a brief moment of consideration and the presence of the saleswoman, I chose the "EdT" version. The stronger "EdP" simply put me off during testing due to its "sharpness."

Almost 80 € less in my wallet and a newfound passion.

In hindsight, I probably wouldn’t buy the perfume anymore, as I have become accustomed to different sillage/duration and my horizons have significantly broadened.

I was testing all the new arrivals today.

I've been sniffing the patch of skin that was sprayed with Gucci Guilty pour Homme the whole time.

It's really not a bad scent - it reminds me immensely of Kenzo eau bla bla bla (not the original Kenzo). Like a fresh shower, nothing more. Unfortunately, nothing special. What a pity!

I actually like the opening of lavender and lemon, but I doubt whether these essences have ever inhaled sunlight.

After a few minutes, a scent note joins in that personally makes me suspect bitter or blood orange; even at this stage of the fragrance development, the lavender saturates the citrus, and it may be that the first hints of patchouli are already present.

I don't find the scent woody; rather, it is soft and cozy. No trace of Sin-City rawness, as the ad tries in vain to suggest.

Conclusion: More suitable for students and pupils than for Russian oligarchs.

After a long absence, I'm speaking up again :)

Since I don't own many simple citrus-fresh fragrances, I find it hard to categorize this scent.

It starts off very fresh and sharp, which is probably due to the lavender, but this freshness fades away quickly, and I only smell a salty-fruity orange base note, which reminds me of a toned-down top note of the lesser-known Joop Splash, which also came out in 2011.

The heart note that remains for me reminds me of the unfortunately too weak The ONE, just without the smoky sweetness that is sooooo great about The ONE.

The scent is perceived more closely to the body. I would argue that many women will like this fragrance, as it doesn't steal the show from them with its subtlety :)

Basically, this is an acceptable but overpriced mainstream scent that I don't want to speak badly of.

For anyone considering buying this fragrance, I recommend just giving Joop Splash a sniff, as it is significantly cheaper, or you can snag a bottle of Guilty 50 ml for 10 euros :)

review_title: Solid, but by no means exceptionally special
review_content:
This perfume was the first one I owned at a significant age. Back then, as a novice, it completely blew me away; today, I must unfortunately say that it only moderately impresses me. Nevertheless, it receives too much unjustified criticism; while it is neither unique nor polarizing, it is very versatile in its application. The timeless, unobtrusive freshness makes this scent a solid all-rounder, good for school or the office, where most likely the majority wear it. This citrusy freshness fades after a while, at which point the peppery aromas dominate.
As a brief comparison to another "office scent": GG pour homme can certainly hold its own against Prada l'homme; it is fresher and a tad spicier, but not as refined/elegant and powdery, which is due to the absence of iris in GG, which is included in Prada l'homme. Formally speaking, it is a worthy competitor, but it ultimately comes down to personal taste in which direction one wants to go,
In terms of performance and longevity, not much stands out: it's okay, but by no means outstanding. On me, it lasts around &h, after which it really only becomes a body scent. I think that’s acceptable for an EdT, especially a fresh one.

PS: You really have to smell it; it’s not that easy to describe. Many see it as a shower gel scent, but I must say that it doesn’t smell too "shower gel-like" to me, even though it is quite fresh.

AWESOME, testosteronic man juice, very dry, without a hint of sweetness. This scent is to the grape juice/bubble gum boys what garlic is to a vampire. hahaha Main scents I get here after dry down are leather, let me repeat, LEATHER, mineral spirits and subtle smokiness and earthiness. No gasoline or petrol scent (as in Fahrenheit) but mineral spirits. If you've ever cleaned paint brushes in mineral spirits, you'll know what I mean. Overall, this scent reminds me very closely of the scent of oil based Color Putty®, for those of you who have done finish carpentry with stained hardwood trim.

For such a hyper masculine fragrance, muscular performance is expected and Guilty Absolute does not disappoint. Excellent longevity, projection and sillage. Up the sprays and they'll know you walked in the room or maybe you'll knock 'em dead. hahaha And no surprise - another awesome creation by Mr. Morillas. Dude is a genius. Guilty Absolute is in my top 5.

review_title: Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Homme Review
review_content: This is my Gucci Guilty Absolute Review video. Picked up a bottle of Gucci Guilty on the day our San Francisco Gucci boutique started selling it and have been wearing it and enjoying the scent very much. I must say Gucci Guilty Absolute is not an original scent because I’ve actually smelled Gucci Guilty Absolute somewhere in the past. Possibly from a niche perfume release somewhere I'm thinking. I most likely saw Vetiver in the notes and gave it a chance. So I love Vetiver in fragrances but I can’t remember what that fragrance was. Bummer. But for a designer release Gucci Guilty Absolute is a very unique scent and I’m happy Gucci is making a comeback and releasing more bolder fragrances. As mentioned in the video this is my first Gucci fragrance in ages. The last fragrance I bought from Gucci was Gucci Pour Homme 2 GPH2 but I bought GPH2 much after when it was launched and the hype had died down as it is a pretty great release. But the last real Gucci release I bought was Gucci Rush back in 2001/2002 and Guccy Envy back in 1999 and 2000. Everything after that I dismissed until now with Gucci Guilty Absolute. Watch my video to find out more about Gucci Guilty Absolute. Thank you.

review_title: Sometimes The Art Is In The Subtlety
review_content:
I am in the middle of an ancient village, one where you can breathe medieval air. I go down the stairs that lead me into the basement. There is a half-open door. I enter, and I am immediately surrounded by an aseptic air, which smells preservative. I see on the walls a series of shelves filled with dark brown glass bottles, similar to those once used for storing pharmaceutical iodine liquids. Perhaps one of them has recently shattered. The smell of the pharmaceutical-like odour is pungent. A vast, old, damp wooden table is in the centre of the room. On its surface lie stacked several splits of all sorts of animal skins. Raw leather, wet-white or wet-blue, from calf, buffalo and cow. Maybe this place was an old tannery. The atmosphere is dense and crowded but not stuffy or annoying. Indeed, the mixture of medicinal, wood, and leather smells creates a perfume that is anything but obnoxious. These are the sensations that the images take shape in my mind when I smell Guilty Absolute.

I recently came across the Guilty Absolute pour Femme perfume, which pleasantly blew me away. Despite being intended for a female audience, a male audience that does not cease at the initial fruity and floral accords can also wear very well the perfume. And I am talking about berries and dark blooms, and the rose is just a hint. It's not as tough as Guilty Absolute pour Homme, but it manifests those cough syrup undertones that remind me of my beloved Joop! Homme EAU DE TOILETTE, to give you an idea. But, apart from this excursus, my intention here is to tell you something about Absolute, a masterpiece that immediately kidnapped my soul and that was kindly given to me as a birthday present a few years ago. So, Absolute is so dreadful, an explosive bomb full of woody, leathery, animalic, earthy and smoky accords. This scent is dry, with no sweetness. It has the same intensity and opulence as oud-based perfumes, while not containing any trace of oud: could it be the custom-made Woodleather ™, a molecule isolated from the rare and precious Oud oil?
Regarding the scent, Absolute is purposely linear, and its structure doesn't change much with development and tends to stay the same all the time. It's far from common designer trends, and if you smell it knowing nothing, you might think of something niche. It doesn't contain many ingredients but only focuses on the toughest, woody and earthy tones. So, it wouldn't surprise me to read that it's anything but a crowd-pleaser.

Absolute announces itself with a peaty and incisive bouquet, almost phenolic, and at the same time, I perceive its sensuality. It reminds me a lot of those places where the atmosphere is full of medicinal smells, but also that smoky cloud that surrounds you when you smell an excellent peaty whiskey, my favourite kind of scotch whiskey. At first, it can be scary, especially imagining it by reading my impressions. Still, I assure you that it works, and it is this almost aseptic smokiness gives Absolute this semblance of a niche. So, it may sound a little creepy, but it doesn't bother me at all. I guess the smoky, resinous aroma is due to cypress, here in a species called Nootka Tree, which features grapefruit undertones and sour currant smells, woody and resinous, of course, with leathery and amber-rich accents. And the leathery look is already there, lingering in the background.

The initial burst calms down quickly, and a more woody accord continues through the scent development and hints of leather and incense are combined. The leather is quite dark and soft, relatively restrained, and is much less direct and robust than other famous leathery-centred colonies. At this stage, the perfume is very magnetic for me. I find myself sniffing my wrist, or the cork of the bottle if I have it close at hand, repeatedly during this phase.

At the bottom, a characteristic shade of vetiver takes shape, which is salty, smoky and dark that hatches, intensifying the chemical and phenolic atmosphere and increasing the leathery one and projecting an element of warm vegetation, giving relief from the harshness. As Absolute dries, it clears without betraying the overall aroma, becoming more and more transparent until only a shade of peat smoke remains, that smoky veil that eventually remains in the now empty whiskey glass. I get some weaker patchouli in the bottom, but it's not prominent. It gives it a slight earthiness, but it's not spicy, chocolaty or minty, just a little dirty.

Ultimately, regardless of its linear peculiarity, for me, it is a spicy and smooth alcoholic skin that glides into dark smoky vetiver and rests on a dry base of patchouli and wood. Dark, warm, comforting and mysterious. I can't think of any mainstream designer perfume that smells like this. It's not too strong. It sits close to the skin but strong enough to stay with me most of the day. I would recommend wearing it in autumn and winter, discreet enough and suitable for the office. It has a medium yield on my skin, not bestial, lasts a long time but casts weakly.

I base the review on a 50ml bottle I have owned since June 2017.

-Elysium

Gucci Guilty Absolute is a dark, mysterious, and bold fragrance that would be more suited as a niche fragrance rather than a designer release which ultimately ended in discontinuation.

Even if I have more affinity for leather fragrances such as Dior’s Fahrenheit, Tom Ford’s Ombre Leather, and Marc-Antoine Barrois Ganymede, I cannot ignore the fact how original this is, and how it actually smells fantastic.

By wearing it repeatedly more and more, you will realize how strangely addictive it really is, and how much first impression can fool us. A fragrance masterpiece of our time. Get it while you still can.

TOP NOTES
The mixture of old leather jacket aroma, and aromatic natural smelling green cypress is what opens and rushes into your olfactive senses.

The antiseptic, and band-aid-like scent profile is here as well but is better experienced when smelled rather than reading or hearing about it.

This is undoubtedly one of the best leather-based fragrances I have experienced in my life, and this is coming for someone who has tried almost all popular and less popular leather fragrances on the market.

HEART NOTES
As the fragrance slowly transitions into the heart notes, the fragrance starts to get more natural, with touches of sweet accords reminding more of pine and cypress tree sap.

A detectable woodiness from vetiver, patchouli, and goldenwood also keeps the fragrance from going into the all-sweet territory and transports me somewhere in dark forests during the early fall.

BASE NOTES
When the fragrance dries down, Absolute moves into being a woody, earthy, musky, sappy, and even cozy fragrance. The woody characteristics are more intensified, more evident with smoky nuances.

To say that I was surprised by Gucci releasing something like this, and also praise the creative decision to be different in the sea of clones, and similar perfumes.

-----

Read the full review at scentgrail.com

An (in)famously challenging frag by Gucci. All about leather, wood, and vetiver... but it's also like smelling Stop n Grow nail-biting deterrent solution in front of a fireplace. I'm not gonna fake that I can describe it better than that. Weird, but good stuff. Murderous in the heat.

Guilty Absolute PH was doomed from the start. Consumers in retail stores only care for the very first minute of the opening, that's all the window of opportunity a fragrance gets to make them fall in love. Many of us who own a bottle of this had to try it out 2-3-4 times before we realized we even liked it. The challenge is what kept us going back. The average consumer doesn't want a challenge - at all. Side note: Funny that many reviewers call this "niche style" simply because the perfumer tried to do something oustide the norm. Goes to show the sorry-ass state of designer perfumery these days.

Projection is good and it lasts forever and a day.

Masculinity Level: The Road Warrior. To be fair he's more Dior Fahrenheit to me, but I don't own that one because it gives me a headache.

After I've spent some time with it I've decided to share a few words. Gucci Guilty Absolute, a fragrance that still reminds me of how a true gentleman should smell like. Bold, aggresive, smoky, leathery, woody. Yeah, burnt rubber, burnt tar, woody/smoky burnt leather, gasoline kind of smell. Name it however you want. The quality will remain the same to my nose. A mature...

This gives me strong steampunk aesthetic/vibes. It opens medicinal and a little boozy to my nose, but quickly gets to the best part. I can smell greasy, oiled cogs and old machinery, along with brown leather straps in a steampunk workshop. It feels totally unique to me and a work of art, because it created the above image in my head effortlessly at first sniff. I went into this almost blindly expecting mostly leather and I got so much more. I can't stop smelling my arm. It's scent is addictive. If only it would have lasted a bit longer on my skin... But I should not get greedy . It stays for very long on clothes though. For some reason I think I also get something floral which I cannot identify. It projects decently but it's not to be used in high heat. This is going to stay with me for a very long time.

I will get to the heart of the matter.
I will not recommend this perfume to everyone because it is not easy to wear.
That said it suits me very well.
It's nice to see a perfume with such powerful smells, but without being overwhelming for the wearer.
In other words it is a wonderful scent.
I had managed to get a sample in perfumery, and i fell in love...
A beautiful "medicinal" leather scent.
It won't suit many of you who won't consider it a regular scent.
It's very tough, dark, smoky, daring, unconventional fragrance.
Certainly not a sweet scent.
I do not recommend it at all to young people who are new to the world of fragrances.
Top notes mainly include leather.
The heat is made from patchouli and the base captures the goldwood and vetiver.
Created using a particular blend with a structure that remains unchanged since its first application on the skin, the leather accord and the goldwood are mixed with the natural extract of Nootka cypress, specially selected for this Guilty Absolute.
The resulting scent features dry woody notes.
The composition of the fragrance is intensified with three forms of patchouli oil and earthy vetiver.
Exceptional longevity and huge sillage.
In other words, it's heavy !!
It's powerful, it lasts a very long time...
Between 8 and 10 hours on me.
Small advice: Do not have a heavy hand at the risk of seeing those around you suffocate... You have been warned in advance.
To give you an idea of the smell of this Guilty Absolute, it smells like the worker coming home from the factory.
It reminds me of sawdust, grease, machine tools covered with metal shavings, or the auto repair shop.
Buy as many as you can, as it will soon be difficult to get hold of.
Conclusion: A perfume of a great class, powerful, but not for everyone.
Test it before buying it blindly i recommend it.
For me it is a total success, but by no means recommendable to beginners as with sensitive noses.
With this Guilty Absolute it's not very complicated.
You will love it or hate it.
My rating: 9/10

review_title: I'm just here for the leather, the rest I don't care...
review_content:
I as grow older a discovery has revealed itself to me; not to give a shit and it's very liberating. Almost cathartic as when you realise that as a 40 something man you are almost/practicably ‘invisible’ to people younger than you (this is apparently true...they did some kind of study), and if so inclined to foolishly go around either trying to prove your ‘visibility’ to young women or your ‘machismo’ to younger guys; it can be summed up as.

Frivolous, futile and fuckry.

Far happier to just not care. Indulge in your interests and hobbies, like I don’t care about what is happening in any current zeitgeist. I’m not concerned about being on trend, I don’t waste any time wondering if the music I listen to is in any way popular. I don’t care if some 20 something woman finds me attractive or if some 20 something man thinks he ‘could beat the shit’ out of me (probably could but I don’t care, it's an irrelevance). I really wished I had this level of low energy in my teens and early twenties as I could have done so much more with my time.

I realised way too late the true meaning of not really caring, what that actually means; I thought, wrongly, in my late 30s that it meant, just schlubbing around in a t-shirt and a pair of tracksuit bottoms and a battered pair of trainers. Nah that’s ‘giving up’; that’s resignation, never again. I decided that I would live my life how the fuck I wanted and do what I want. I could not waste time worrying about the considerations toward others if it meant that I would be constantly living miserable and hypocritically. I have been teaching my daughter to be singularly and individualistically proud of herself, her drive and desire to pursue her happiness.

As I get older I have realised that you waste so much time contemplating the reactions, and thoughts of others that it becomes restrictive. Your actions, tastes, fashions, politics and council governed by imagined prejudices and tolerances? All of this to end up on a box leaving a trail of sympathy and polite indifference to your death.

But I’m not dead yet. I have been reading up on different schools of thought in philosophy. And I tripped up on ‘Egoism’ - now I could go all in and explain what it is but I’m two Long Island Ice Teas in and well I’m trying to listen to The Pharcyde’s ‘Labcabincalifornia’ and before that the lyrics to Paul Simon’s ‘Call me Al’ started to relate... so the Egoist does not concern themselves with the notions of state, property, religion ‘a good cause, a doctrine, a system, a lofty calling’ nope they just live for themselves and its part of this whole Individualism thing I’m scoping out.

Now how does this parlay with Gucci Guilty Absolute...well it goes like this: I have had my gripes about this sub and one that really annoys me is the trend of people asking others for their opinions on fragrances bought/ordered. Why? My opinion on a fragrance is mine and means nothing to you; this review, long winded and a sprawling of simile and metaphors. Why do these people care? I know some might say ‘Well they might not be confident enough with fragrances...’

SAMPLE THEN!!

Now the other reason; I had been after a leather fragrance for some time and was let down by some of the offerings by some of the big names and the older classics felt a little lacklustre. I kind of stumbled on to Gucci by accident. I was in Boots and I had asked to have a sniff of Gucci Guilty and the disinterested shop assistant handed me Gucci Guilty Absolute...the love was instant, especially as she baulked at the scent. I was in love I didn’t care about her opinion. I wanted it, I didn’t care. I had found my leather scent.

Gucci Guilty Absolute is that type of fragrance – it is leather! Big bastarding leather...it’s very leather. I LOVE IT because it is so ‘fuck off leather’ it does not hide the fact that this is a leather scent in aura of florals, or aldehydes or boozy scents. Nah! This is like those old-style plumber’s tool bags, this is what Lee Marvin’s leather jacket stank like on the set of the ’Wild Ones’. I would like to compare this to Tuscan Leather but I think that would be unfair as I would have a bias and I am not really a fan of Tuscan leather to me it smells like a trussed-up lady’s handbag left to bake on the passenger seat of an old 1985 Austin Maestro. Tuscan leather softened with trances of fruit and saffron, that it gives it a matinee idol aspect, all sucked in cheeks and gut, furrowed brows and pursed lips like Bruce Willis, on screen bravado and swagger.

Gucci Guilty Absolute is nothing like that, it’s the Uncle who turns up to family gatherings with a new “"half his age what’s thinking about” girlfriend; the mothers, wives and aunts are a little intimidated by. Gucci Guilty Absolute is the bassist in the pub rock band who’s sleeping with the lead singer’s girlfriend, the mechanic that works out of a shack/garage with no name but does great work, the chef who works on the line, who can barely spell any of the ingredients has that one knife that looks like it was rescued from the Marie Rose but can cook like an artist. The Cow that inspired the leather not of this scent, fucks, this is the stench of the leather jacket of the kid that bullied the Fonz, this is the scent of Freddie Kruger’s hat... Theophilus P. Wildebeeste’s leather trousers.

I know there’s other notes in this, I don’t care I’m here for the leather. I have decided that it's all I want from this and it delivers. I’m not after compliments, I’m not concerned with what others think I couldn’t care less. I just love being surrounded by this fug.

Before reading this review, I do hope you had the chance to smell this creation ... now we can talk about it.

This one, Tragedy of Lord George, Acqua di GIO EDT .. and many other scents on the market, let us understand the genius of Alberto Morillas, master perfumer.

This scent, the GUCCI one is a very strong, dark, deep OUD like scent without any mention about the expensive oil, but with a natural aspect to it, that makes me even wonder why we do need to kill the Agarwood trees anymore, if such a note can be done without any trace of it in a scent.

Let me tell you about longevity .. guys, this is beyond beast, this is nuclear .. I sprayed twice on the back of my hands yesterday around 14:00 and today at 18:00 it is still quite present as a skin scent, with one shower inbetween.

It smells rich and complex, not for the novice and not initiated in heavy duty scents .. this scent DNA leads me to believe that Alberto Morillas simply created a work without a specific marketing brief from COTY/GUCCI .. he shows us here how parfumery should be done.

This is not what you would call a mass pleaser and surely it did not come from a marketing team or AI like the idiot Phantom from Paco Rabanne.

Mr. Morillas, chapeau!

Leather with cypress smells like a new shoebox, a very masculine linear fragrance. Niche quality designer, commercial failure in its day but a very interesting fragrance... Created by Alberto Morillas for me it is in his top-3.
If you like leather I think it is something that you should have in your collection, it does not project too much but its duration is good around 8-10 hours

To be honest, when I first smelled this, I wasn’t too sure about it. Wow that’s animalic. It reminded me of "Signature Collection - Agar Wood | Dunhill" big time and I don’t really like that one even though I own it.

But having read some reviews on it it’s got me interested and I dared to spray it on. It actually smells really nice and smooth on the skin. Nothing pungent. A bit dirty but that makes you feel great. “You don’t have to like it. I like it.” It’s nothing like the Dunhill frag. That one tries to keep the dirtiness hidden under a layer of sweetness. The Gucci doesn’t hide it at all.

It’s also a comforting scent. I had farmers in the family and I remember going there as a kid. Being grown up in the city, I found all that cow poo stinky. Don’t be ridiculous, my parents would say. That’s nature’s smell. Of course this frag isn’t as stinky as that but I got those flashbacks nonetheless.

So it won’t give you compliments if that’s what you’re after. I wouldn’t necessarily wear it to the office or at parties. It’s more of an in-and-around-the-house kind of thing.

A niche-like fragrance from a designer house? I am loving this!

For the longest time I have been tired of designer perfume houses playing it safe with the same old fresh and bland crap fragrances that they have been inundating consumers with. Gucci's new director is like a breath of fresh air for the designer fragrance industry.

Guilty Absolute is a wonderful and satisfying linear masculine leather fragrance that will last all day on your skin and at least a week on your clothes!

If you like fresh and safe fragrances, go elsewhere. If you like a different or avant garde leather fragrance, this is for you.

A solid 10/10

review_title: Leather intrepid, industrial, flat and robust
review_content:
I can't believe that Alberto Morillas is behind this fragrance and has dared so much to break traditional watery, woody notes. It is difficult to understand this gem, here the leather is the real protagonist, it is rough, raw, not animalic, intrepid, industrial, flat and robust, there are no notes that truly highlight its composition to make it shine and take it to a splendor of mystery, of seduction. This fragrance resembles the solvents used in saddlery for the treatment of leather, if it remains on the clothes gives the feeling of having passed a cloth with liquid varsol giving that feeling of petroleum hydrocarbons, is completely linear and does not present any evolution, I would have liked more prominence of cypress, also vetiver to push towards the herbal or perhaps a citrus note in its top or in its base.
I would have liked a bit more of cypress, also vetiver to push towards the herbal or perhaps a citrus note in the top or in the middle, this would have given it the twist needed to make it more bearable.

So don't expect any compliments because to wear this misunderstood one needs character and to be confident. I gave it a chance but I couldn't, it gave me olfactory fatigue, I'm really sorry don Alberto M, I'll stick with other more wearable and interesting leather fragrances like Tuscan Leather, La Yuquawam Pour Home, Acqua di Parma Leather, Saharian Wind, Aoud Leather Montale.

For collectors buy a bottle because it is on sale and has become difficult to obtain.

Longevity: 8
Projection: 8
Versatility: 2
Feminine Olfactory Perception : 1

I own and love Gucci Guilty Intense which is a very safe and crowd pleasing release but in the opposite side of the spectrum we have Guilty Absolute with even better results.

Guilty Absolute is bold, it doesn't care about trends or what's fashionable, it's by no means a fragrance for the younger folks. Absolute just doesn't care what's hot and what's not in fact it is almost certain to upset a lot of people and that's the beauty of it.

I found it at a local store, for some reason I was drawn to the tester and sampled it and it blew my mind. Such a realistic leather accord masterfully blended with gorgeous Vetiver, Woods and even a touch of Cypress so I took it home but that's not the end of it, next day I tested it again on skin and it is even better! Paper does NO justice what so ever to Absolute!

Scent is great, longevity is off the charts, sillage is moderate (which is fine, you don't want to be loud with this one) so yes, this is a 'Love' for me

What a surreal story.

My first thoughts were:
-rain filled ashtray
-used transmission oil
-a dirty leather jacket

Create a scene in your head by these circumstances. My brain actually blew up.
This one sticks out of Gucci’s crowd so hard, and even unexpected from Morillas, I didn’t know ‘this side’ of him until now. What a positive disappointment.

To be honest, this scent is not for everyone and not for every occasion.
I can’t decide if I am able to wear it. Or better to say will it fit me or not.
Worth a try!
