Bold, manly, agressive, somehow animalic but bloody awesome. That petrol vibe it´s gorgeous. I think that Fahrenheit it´s a better fragrance and it’s an iconic one, but Alberto Morillas almost made an equal masterpiece with...

This is one of the weirdest perfumes that i have un my collection. When i wear It It is like wearing burned oil or gasoline. It reminds me to the car workshop smell. It is true that there similar scents like for example duro by nasomatto or ombre leather by Tom Ford but this is for me one of the best i have tried according Also yo his price. Original and different yo the mass perfumes but no a compliments catcher. Probably oeople even cant realize tht you are wearing a perfume... More to selfenjoy... Longevity is very good... It lasts for days on clothes...

Guilty Absolute Pour Homme isn’t that challenging. It opens a bit medicinal, followed by a realistic leather. It’s not too animalistic. Woody and the vetiver come later. It’s well blended but lacks scent development. 6+ hours longevity, and moderate projection. This scent is bold and perfect to show “who’s the boss here”

I would wear this on formal occasions to give a statement. A solid release from Gucci. Sadly this gem rumored has been discontinued.

This is one of those rare scents that is bold without being loud or brash. I would describe this scent as rather muted, you get a leather-like, hydrocarbon and some green aroma all at once. One of the first images that this great juice brought to mind was the inside of an old pick-up my father owned that held various items such as tools and dirty mechanic's rags. I only...

This is a tough one: I'm dealing with a good, unusually weird, and (drumroll please...) amiable scent.

Brief disclaimer: If you're visiting this page, you are certainly a frag person who's perfectly capable of discerning wearable from unwearable. You may like or not like the scent, but don't dare typing "Invictus people run from this; This is for alphas; Challenging af."

First half an hour is my most uncherished stage from the whole way. All chemicals blazin' in there. Say you may get to feel the cypress, coumarin and whatnot by drawing your nose near enough; but it's all about the synthetic leather. I always get a fresh vibe with synthetics even this was meant as a warm scent. Once that stage's over, nothing remains "on top", and the fragrance becomes all about depth and perseverance. Subtly reminiscent of polished old / vintage seats, still in good condition, matching the brown of its own presentation. And just like that the fragrance dries down with an above-average performance.

All in all, it's perfectly wearable as said, it's a great reminiscent scent, almost photorealistic if you will. It's tremendously linear and plane, but it really doesn't need to stand out in any way, or through any accord.

Thing is, photorealism is not my vibe. Yet, I keep smelling my arm more often than I care to admit, because Gucci Guilty Absolute is a freaking addicting fragrance. However, I've worn it a couple of times, and it doesn't strike me as the fragrance that you want to keep smelling through your journey. In conclusion, it's a fantastic scent that I have to turn down.

review_title: From a cowshed to a leather jacket
review_content:
What can you find in a bottle:

* On a blotter it opens with a civet-like note which is almost shocking. Something rather to expect within a niche range of perfumes than in a mainstream scent. Camels, horses and cowsheds may come into the mind, though oud is not mentioned here. But on the skin it becomes less zoo-like and brings warm and sensual depth into the fragrance.
* An intimate close to skin scent what you might smell under a worn out leather jacket on a bare male skin. The jacket seems to keep the history of its wearer. Just a few nuances like mineral notes of oil and gasoline or residues of modern fougère perfumes and woody scents ingrained into leather.
* A very comforting warm and dry woody base.
* A slightly metallic aromatic vibe recognizable from many modern masculine fougère fragrances.

Some facts:

Woodleather® is a new Firmenich captive with an oud scent profile. Also used in “Original Oud” by Mizensir, the fragrance project by Alberto Morillas.

Goldenwood® is another Firmenich captive. As long as it’s under patent protection (as well as Woodleather®), not much information will be revealed.

Nootka cypress (also known as Alaskan Cedarwood) is a conifer growing in the Northwest Rainforest area. Firmenich describes the smell of Cedarwood Alaska essential oil as “sparkling with a fresh and breezy grapefruit crisp due to its Nootkatene and Nootkatone content (grapefruit odorants)”and “less camhoraceous and smoky, but stronger, longer lasting and more linear than the regular Cedarwood oil”.

This smells like an old car. The leather seats, the smell of engine oil and gasoline, even a subtle rubbery smell. The opening has a refreshing cypress note that I wished stayed longer. After about a half hour on my skin, the scent dries to a aged brown leather smell and the gassy, engine oil notes come out more. It stays just like that to the end of its life.

I wish there were maybe some more floral notes to give it some softness while keeping the dryness. But I think this is a great layering scent since it doesn't change much.

Its output is leather in a strong and naturalistic note, which is credible and understandable, a little later a smoky aroma that smells of fuel is incorporated, creating an atmosphere and environment that provokes curiosity, due to the unusualness of a fragrance, it remains in this development for a long time, and later some woods with Vetiver are also incorporated, which make it elegant as well as interesting, since the initial sensation will not leave us throughout the life and trajectory of the perfume.

Within the Cuero family fragrances, it is one of the most defined, it is not from the Tom Ford lines or others, and I think it has been and is appreciated by perfumery lovers, even those who consume what we call niche today.

But, it is also true that the general public has not embraced it with enthusiasm, and therefore I doubt that its sales have been profitable, it is true that since its launch on the market it has not had expansive marketing, in Department Stores it was as if it were hidden. It has never been sold in famous perfumery chains. Possibly more accessible on the web than in a physical store, where there is no fitting room.

Undoubtedly a very good fragrance, which always arouses curiosity and interest.

I tried this fragrance in the mall at random. It was not in my wish list , neither i knew it. Man… i bought it the same day. This is EXTREMELY loud leather fragrance. Maybe it’s not for everyone, because is very overpowering and strong. You smell rich. Not rich like BMW M5 competition , but more like Bentley Continental GT richness .. it gives this rich grown up old money...

review_title: A weird way to smell good?
review_content: As happens so often, there is so much hype about a fragrance that we fall in it. I fell on this Gucci. From the start it seemed to me like a super aggressive aroma, I never managed to understand it, I couldn't say that it is gross nor nasty , but I couldn't say that it is a pleasure to smell it either. It reminds me of shoe polish, the smell in those leather stores where they sell leather horse riding accessories, boots, bows, etc. Intense, rough, dark dry, striking. I have some perfumes with a leather note, I like it, but not this. After a year without taking it out of the closet, they decided to sell it, and despite it being "a gem", and being discontinued, people did not dare to buy it either. I changed it for a Terre de Hermes pure parfum, for me a deal. There are many who love this perfume, but not me. Separate note, the master Morillas recently designed the Terrae Escense for Bvlgari, it is for me a version of Gucci, with a sweet touch, more present vetiver, and some earthy notes; It's really a lovely scent, much friendlier to my nose and it's truly a pleasure to use. It's going to be my memory of the Guilty.

I have had slight fluctuations over how I have felt about this fragrance in the year or so I have owned it. Finally I have put my thoughts on record and hope you find my review useful. Thank you for watching

Don't let the Gucci brand name fool you. This is a rare, challenging designer scent. It took me a few tests to finally pull the trigger. The scent is a crafty split between a photorealistic leather jacket and a refined medicinal antiseptic. The Dettol like bottle color doesn't exactly discourage that comparison. In spite of that description, there's a surprising calming...

review_title: A scent to loose yourself into the night....
review_content: Leather is my favorite note, together with tobacco and oud. Masculine, dry and dark.... I was looking for that strong alpha male scent for the special night .... With oud I found it, is Ceylan from Xerjoff, very masculine honey/oud combo. After reading the reviews here I was so into it: "testosteronic" "animalic" "infamously challenging" So I open the package...first spray,...

After smelling so many leather based fragrances, I've concluded that this is the best leather fragrance that doesn't have animalic notes. Simple but multi-faceted dry leather. The leather comes off as shoe polish, petrol, antiseptic, medicinal, and or paint. The Nootka cypress also plays a massive role here as well with some smoky vetiver, very small amounts of patchouli.

review_title: Let's finally address the elephant in the room - is GGA the same as Dark Lord?
review_content:
If you check the fragrances Guilty Absolute pour Homme and Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux , you'll see a VERY large amount of votes in the "similar fragrances" section. People love to compare these two, and I totally understand why:

- both fragrances are made by the same perfume, Alberto Morillas
- Guilty Absolute pour Homme came out one year before Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux and Kilian as a brand does have a tendency of getting "inspired"
- both have a very similar leathery vibe (?)

As an absolute (haha) lover of Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux , I am aware that it's expensive - and that's why I rarely wear it. I've been on the hunt for a leather fragrances that captures that unique feeling that I get from Kilian's fragrance... and all paths seem to lead me to Guilty Absolute pour Homme . But are they the same? And is Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux just a "scam"?

After owning both fragrances and testing them back to back, here's my verdict: Nope, they're not the same BUT they have SOME similarities.
Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux is like a black dark leather jacket: it's still a new polished jacket, smells a bit like gasoline but there's a subtle floral touch to it that really gives it some elegance and mystery - it's so intriguing!
Guilty Absolute pour Homme has a leathery vibe that is SUPER close to No Limit$ - they probably use similar leather ingredients because here I really smell a similarity. That leathery vibe is different in Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux - it's more cold. The leather accord of Guilty Absolute pour Homme is warmer! It's much more woody and is rather linear in it's performance: it does one thing well, leather AND woods!
Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux starts more classy masculine: bergamot in the opening, jasmine-esque florals bring some life to the composition and that leather binds everything together!

But here's the kicker: as Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux dries down, it gets closer and closer to Guilty Absolute pour Homme !
Let's finish this off by mentioning that I enjoy both fragrances! Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux has a special place in my heart, as it was my first big niche fragrance that I fell in love with, so at the end of the day, nothing can really compare to that ;)

But Guilty Absolute pour Homme is essentially a "warmer drydown of Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux ", that's what it feels like. Definitely more woody and warmer, it's more cozy in it's take on leather in perfumery - which I find awesome, as a lot of leather perfumes tend to go in that "new polished black leather jacket" vein. And of course, that price difference is immense. Whether it's worth it to you or not, noone can really say. You have to try them for yourself.
My preference is clear, I have a favorite. But if I want to get a similar feeling AND I want it woodier on a particular day, I'd go with Guilty Absolute pour Homme instead.

review_title: Gucci has found its balls again
review_content:
Since Tom Ford's departure, Gucci has mostly been releasing watered-down, design-board fragrances, especially in the Guilty line, and now this... lecko mio! Is this the turnaround? "Gucci Guilty Absolute" is absolutely amazing and the opposite of its siblings. I stink, therefore I live!!!

"Guilty Absolute" is a stinker of the highest order, completely brushed against the mainstream, fresh out of the stable, more Hermes than Gucci, leather to the max - and I totally love it! If you're into leather scents, there's little comparable even in the niche. Top-notch quality, masculine, striking, a huge step out of the comfort zone for Gucci - wonderful! One can only praise it enthusiastically. Already the positive surprise of the year in the designer sector. No one expected this, it hits you right in the face. Towards the end, it becomes more patchouli-like, but for the most part, it's an animalistic leather powerhouse without mercy. Unvarnished, unpolished, unrefined. I can hardly believe it. Here and there, a bit of synthetic notes peek through, but overall, it's a dream scent for me. Played, daring, won! It has nothing to do with the other Guiltys and should carry its own name.

Bottle: simple and high-quality - the exterior has never been the problem...
Sillage: strong as a stud
Longevity: some leather jackets last shorter - 12 hours!

Conclusion: the best and wonderfully grimmest Gucci for men in years. Gucci is back... let's hope it wasn't a fluke!

The New World version of Pegasus, I...

review_title: Only dead fish swim with the current
review_content:
In a world where everyone wears classic “blue” fragrances, which to me smell like any random sports shampoo, I see myself as a stubborn provocateur when it comes to perfumes. After years of trying to follow the mainstream and finding pleasure in those universally popular scents like Sauvage, Armani Code, and all the others that have dominated the TOP20 in every drugstore and contributed to a uniform general smell in discos and clubs for years, I must sadly admit that I simply do not like them and cannot wear them.

This led to a growing desire within me to swim against the current so as not to be one of those dead fish.
Since TF Tobacco Oud has been my signature scent for over a year and the discontinuation of its production has been troubling me for the past two months, I have been intensively searching for an alternative “In your face” scent.
It should be affordable, but different and provocative.

I liked GGA back in 2017, but at that time it was too much for me, and I wanted to please the girls, not scare them away.
This time I dared to test it intensively on my skin.
My God, it smells so good. Provocative, rough, masculine, simply different.

GGA is, for me, the outlaw among perfumes. Extreme niche for little money (I got it on sale for a mere 40 euros for 90ml).
You smell completely different from the mainstream. This scent has nothing sweet, fresh, or citrusy.
Just leather, wood, and a bit of whisky and smoke. A scent that you must wear with a lot of self-confidence.

For me, it is not a scent for a casual leather jacket and biker boots; that would be too much of a cliché.
Like TF TO, this is a scent for a suit, for a shirt, for more elegant outfits. You may stone me, but it works fantastically.

Perhaps it is also because I live in Eastern Europe and here the women seem to be particularly attracted to a lot of masculinity, but the scent brought me, just like TF TO, consistently positive, almost enamored compliments.
For me, it is an absolute aphrodisiac for a man (25+) with a lot of self-confidence and a certain “aura” of an educated alpha male, a lone wolf who has everything under control, always knows the answer, and despite his animalistic demeanor, is a certain gentleman.
This image of a man, tall, masculine, elegantly dressed, who enters a room and silence reigns, admiration and awe fill the air, that’s the kind of scent it is. You are provocatively different, but not in a banal way, rather thoughtfully and elegantly.

A strong gasoline and whisky accord for me in the first 15 minutes, which transitions into a leathery, woody scent and loses the leather over the coming hours, replaced by subtle herbs.

Not a blind buy, not a scent for skinny, short guys with little self-confident aura; this scent would be as out of place on such a man as CK One would be on me.

This is the third time I've mustered the courage to write a review. Actually, I have nothing to add to my predecessors. Twice when I wanted to write something ... wanted to share ... I thought, "Oh no, everything has really been said."
I have tested many of my decants lately. Also yesterday and today, which made me place an order right away.

But at the end of the day, I sit here alone with Guilty.

I got myself a bottle of this fragrance. I immediately decanted some for when I'm working or studying and want to sniff a scent; Guilty is right next to me. Totally happy after my tested perfumes from today, I found myself back at my desk. I see the Guilty decant, I’m pleased about it, I smell it. Mhhhhh. Simply delicious.

My surroundings have already pointed out the scent to me. Why do I smell so strange, it somehow smells like a cow shed or fertilizer.
I sit here, ready to go to sleep, wrapped in Guilty. I don’t smell cow shed or fertilizer.

I smell leather. Leather that might not be associated with black patent leather shoes. But leather, in cognac color, leather that is smooth but matte on the outside. Inside, it has more of a rough texture. Maybe a bit like the old rectangular leather backpacks.

I can't really perceive the patchouli; I can't say anything about all the other notes either, but I believe the main role here is played by the wood leather. The scent is totally linear. When I spray the scent on my hand in the evening, I can still perceive the wood leather in the morning. The scent diminishes, it is noticeable but weak. Mainly, in the morning, I perceive a kind of spiciness that I would describe as peppery.
The scent lasts long, yet I was constantly searching for a fragrance that I was just as addicted to, a scent that remains just as consistently dirty, a scent with perhaps more depth and something more complex and even longer-lasting or with more sillage.
I searched, asked many perfumers who already have many leather scents.

But to be honest, none of them have been it so far. I got to know many leather fragrances (thanks to the perfumers) that are good and that I will also acquire. But none was like Guilty.
In the end, I got to try the similar scent from Kilian - Dark Lord. The opening of both is indeed similar. But only for a minute. While Guilty is totally linear, the Kilian scent is really very complex and changes. After a few minutes, the scents no longer resemble each other for me.
I'm not saying that the Kilian scent is bad because of that, no, not at all. I think it is more socially acceptable. Not a crowd-pleaser, but ... perhaps more pleasant for other noses than Guilty.
I find Guilty really delicious and it has a very unique character compared to what I've smelled so far. It smells delicious; you can't ignore the scent, it is present and shows very confidently that it is there.
Whoever wants authentic leather will be well served here, but should bring a dose of healthy self-confidence.

Just like the motto: If it's too strong, you're too weak.

Good night.

It seems that the responsible parties have finally noticed: Gucci's rather unfortunate "Guilty" line has not stood out for its overwhelming creativity or quality. The now fifth offshoot "Absolute" is trying to strike a completely new tone - moving away from the orange blossom drugstore sugary water nonsense, towards everything that a "real man" is supposedly required to enjoy: dirt, wood, leather, lush vegetation. To what extent this aligns with the existing "Guilty" customer base remains to be seen. Either way, the new Gucci leaves me with a big question mark.

The reason I can't quite warm up to the newcomer is that it doesn't deliver what it wants to sell you as a feeling, but also due to its somewhat unorganic execution. Gucci has, like many other brands, drawn from the aroma cocktail resources of Firmenich and other consorts for "Absolute." Why buy several different raw materials when you can have spicy, woody, and creamy in one fragrance note? These fantasy notes are then called Akigalawood®, or Clearwood®, in this case Goldenwood® and Woodleather®. They already ruin a large part of the Comme des Garcons scents for me, and even with Guilty Absolute, they create a strangely synthetic scent impression: leather, wood, smoke, it’s all there, but in an almost sterile-aseptic execution. I smell not well-worn vintage leather seats, but rather a production-fresh new car with faux leather seats. A bit like the mid-range cars in the Mitsubishi dealership that settled in our street during my childhood. Throughout the scent development, one note or another occasionally wafts to the forefront, until the patchouli-like (?) nuances assert themselves in the base.
For a dark, leathery scent, the physical, human, "dangerous" aspect is completely absent. I have the impression that Gucci didn't want to completely alienate its existing "Guilty" clientele, resulting in a perfume for clean-scent wearers who also want to appear a bit naughty. "Guilty Absolute" recites masculine macho perfume clichés from the powerhouse and Fahrenheit era, yet remains strangely clinical and lifeless.

When wearing it, I envision - and I hope no one feels offended! - that urban male archetype who works in marketing or advertising in the big city during the week and then drives to the pre-Alps on the weekend with a Mitsubishi Pajero® to engage in some "manly activities" in nature. On one hand, for his own compensation and self-affirmation, and on the other hand, because he believes society still expects these old stereotypes. But it could also just be a malicious assumption on my part. ;)

The new Gucci is certainly much better than its botched "Guilty" siblings. But if I want the ultimate Genghis Khan feeling with leather-cedar magic, I'd rather get "Knize Ten" by Knize or "Gomma" by Etro. They embody their masculinity, but in a much more nuanced and heartfelt way.

When looking at the comments and ratings for this fragrance, it becomes clear that there are only extremes. Either the Gucci is mercilessly punished with 1 to 2 points, or it is highly praised. There isn’t much in between. It’s surprising that it still manages to achieve a relatively good average score of 7.5. I find it commendable that Gucci has released such an individual scent. It probably won’t be the biggest commercial success. This piqued my curiosity. So off I went to Kaufhaus Müller (which has kept its perfume department open despite the lockdown). There stood a lonely bottle of Gucci Guilty Absolute and a tester.
I must admit I fell in love with the scent immediately. I haven’t smelled anything like this in designer fragrances for a long time. I immediately bought the 90ml bottle. I have been wearing the fragrance non-stop for 4 days now and I am still thrilled. It’s cold outside and there’s a lot of snow. I’m wearing the warmest and softest leather scent I know. It fits perfectly for winter. The way this fragrance smells, it should smell when you get into your brand-new Rolls Royce. Finest leather and the noblest woods. The dirty and animalistic notes described in some comments are not how I perceive it. I find the scent soft and elegant. In my perception, it is a so-called "skinscent." The projection is already subdued and very discreet after about an hour. The scent lies close to the skin and exudes its warm and soft aura. In the drydown, woody and boozy accents join the leather. But otherwise, I would describe the scent as very linear. There is no pronounced scent development. This fragrance is definitely not worn for others or to gain compliments. This fragrance is worn for oneself. Because it projects only softly, I find it very versatile. I wear it now in the cold days even in the office. Gucci has managed to impress me with Guilty Absolute. For me, it is the winter fragrance of 2020/2021. I would be happy if more unique fragrances like this were released, even if they only appeal to 50% of buyers. We are all looking for something special and individual.

When I withdrew money in the city center today to possibly have change for a private sale of sunglasses, I received a call that the buyer unfortunately couldn't come after all. Well, on one hand, that was annoying, but on the other hand, I could check out the Türkisen again to see if they finally have something new. Unfortunately, I usually stay one step ahead of the stores in Austria and could only find the new Annayake (insignificant) among the untested.
So I walked through the shelves, as I didn't want to go home without a scent on my wrist. Then I spotted Gucci Guilty Absolute and remembered the first time I tested it on a paper strip: Ugh, no, not at all. However, in the meantime, I have also tested other leather fragrances and expanded my fragrance horizon as well as my fragrance tolerance a bit. So off to Test 2 directly on the wrist.
The beginning is as shocking to me as it was the first time. You get the full force of Woodleather *registered trademark symbol* in your face and have to pause for a moment. But since I tested it on a paper strip last time, I let it develop. Gradually, something floral emerges, almost herbal. The extremely scratchy and powerful aspect fades away over time, but the leather scent is definitely still there.
While La Yuqawam pour Homme reminds me of a freshly bought leather jacket worn by a girl with raspberry perfume, Guilty Absolute gives me the already mentioned leather couch flavor. However, this is not a new couch for me, but one that has been well-used. Mixed with the aromas of the living room, the regular use of Febreze that mom uses to cover up her occasional smoking, which never really goes away. Guilty Absolute reminds me of the smell of taxis in Sofia, which roast with leather interiors at 40°C in the sun and later take you from traffic jam to traffic jam to your destination.
With all these memories, it almost surprises me that we are talking about Gucci here. Considering how insignificantly uninteresting the other flankers have been so far. One could almost think that this is a fragrance that Replica would have liked to release.

REPRODUCTION OF FAMILIAR SCENTS AND MOMENTS OF VARYING LOCATIONS AND PERIODS
Originally: Balkan Taxi Drive
Provenance and Period: Sofia, 2007
Fragrance Description: Leather interior and Magic Tree
Style Description: ???

This brings me to my last point, which is wearability. Since I have been with Parfumo for almost a year now, I can appreciate fragrances that I personally do not like. I understand what can be refined about them and what others love about them. I see that here as well. It is a very authentic leather scent. However, I could never imagine wearing it myself. It wouldn't suit any of my acquaintances or relatives either. Maybe one could wear it on Halloween if one wants to dress up as Leatherface. Perhaps it would be advantageous during hide and seek, as you would blend in even less behind the neighbor's leather couch. Otherwise, I probably would never wear it.

At this point, a brief reminder to all those who might feel offended by my comment: This is, as always, just my own opinion and everything is subjective. I'm glad it could bring you joy.

review_title: Like a punch in the face for some, great love for me.
review_content: This fragrance is highly polarizing. Great love or extreme hate with nothing in between, 50/50. Some feel almost offended by it. For me, however, it is the most wonderful, honest, impressive, astonishing leather of all time. Childhood. The original 50s bag from my father's binoculars, which I always played with. An inheritance from his great-uncle. GGA smells like the leather of that bag. Real leather from the 50s. Wonderful. A truly special experience. And it lasts and lasts, and the sillage is fantastic. I have the huge 200ml bottle. :)

I first smelled this fragrance a few years ago in Munich, and I liked it even then. Then our paths parted. The scent lingered on as a figment in my subconscious.

When I saw it again at Duty Free Stuttgart on my way to the flight to Barcelona, my hand instinctively moved towards the brown bottle with the small black cap.
Boom, the fragrance hit me like Muhammad Ali's right hand on Sonny Liston's jaw. A leather club before the Lord… And I love it. Just like I did a few years ago, but also completely different.

Only now, with the necessary background knowledge and significantly more “perfume experience,” did I recognize the full beauty and uniqueness of this scent.

A deep black gasoline note layered with leather. Like a '68 Mustang Fastback.
Brutal. Loud. Old school.
Not Alcantara leather from the new Porsche 911, like in Ombré Leather (2018) EAU DE PARFUM.
Leather more like: the old biker jacket of Uncle Jack, who used to ride with the Hells Angels on his Harley Davidson and drank a bottle of whiskey for breakfast. The jacket has burn holes; Uncle Jack was a cigar aficionado.

This symphony is initially accompanied by a slightly green-fresh cedar note. But then it disappears. The little green cedar sprout slowly grows into a tree after a few minutes, giving the fragrance a dark woody note.
The gasoline association, which I apparently share with other perfume lovers, fades but comes back every now and then.

After about half an hour to an hour, only old, crusty, time-worn but soft leather can be smelled.
CONCLUSION

My second bottle. I don't know anyone in my circle who likes it. I love it for that.

Designer fragrance with niche DNA.
Not a date scent. A scent to exude dominance. Not everyone can wear it. You have to be the type for it.
A leather jacket is almost mandatory.

Top fragrance, also great for layering with good H/S.
As a man with long hair, it often gets caught there; sometimes I still smell it in the shower after two days.
For a while, it was even my signature/daily scent.
“A fragrance for the individualist,” as I read here. Perfectly described.

Gucci Guilty Absolute is one of the most polarizing designer fragrances I know!
Moreover, it is also a strikingly atypical creation by Mr. Morillas, who, besides doing commissioned work for anyone who pays enough and wants to sell a mass-pleaser scent, is known as THE man for freshies and timeless classics like Acqua di Gio, Light Blue pH, and *ahem* Office.

It surprised me even more that such an uncompromising fragrance was created under his guidance. Because GGA is straightforward and direct, no flattering opening that gradually leads you to the harsh leather. Not particularly complex or with great development (which is typical for Morillas), but that’s exactly what makes it so interesting to me. A look at the notes gives a rough idea of where it’s headed. Vetiver, patchouli, cypress, wood leather, and golden wood - So leathery, woody, earthy. Check. This scent is pure and freshly tanned woody leather to spray on. Nothing more, nothing less.

When I smell the fragrance, I inevitably associate it with old leather and wood, strangely not in a bad way like the old wooden box lined with leather in grandma's decaying or dusty attic. Images of a rocker or some other stereotypical bad guy come to mind, who is forced by his wife to maintain his monthly personal hygiene. Sharpening his razor on leather, polishing his shoes on a solid wood table, and drinking Jacky straight from the bottle. This esteemed gentleman probably wears this fragrance, even if he doesn’t smell similar by nature.

For me personally, the scent is mostly unbearable, and I have only received negative comments so far - yet I still quite like it at times, because sometimes, but only sometimes, men like me deserve a bit of leather, uh, gladly… or something?!

This is a good fragrance for men who want to stand out, whether positively or negatively should not matter to them. For men who want to provoke or impregnate their leather jackets. For the men who, after two bottles of Jacky, will box anyone who gives them a hard time through the window. Uncompromising tough guys indeed.

Yesterday, I took Guilty Absolute out of the cabinet again. This fragrance back then launched the rocket with one or two others, taking my designer fragrance experience beyond the well-known standards to the next level. In hindsight, and following the reviews here, it may be a bold choice; Gucci Absolute is not a guarantee of appeal. But why?

But let's start from the beginning: I actually have unintentionally acquired a few Morillas creations in my cabinet and must say: Guilty Absolute is an authentic and crowd-pleasing leather scent for beginners, making it a wonderful achievement by Mr. Morillas. It is linear, becomes slightly more robust, and does not overwhelm anyone. The weak H/S also contributes to this. It quickly becomes intimate and, unfortunately, disappointing if you are used to bathing in Tuscan Leather.

At first, it smells like leather soaked in sweet alcohol. It is charming and never too strong. For me, it is an absolutely polished scent without edges or corners. You feel like you are in a specialty leather goods store. Many attribute such a scent to more robust leather fragrances, but I must disagree. Those fragrances all smell like leather workshops where raw, coarse materials are used. Guilty Absolute is more like the leather of a new belt, a pair of leather shoes, or a leather bag. These are all appealing leather scents; customers do not buy leather that smells like a freshly deceased animal.

For this reason, I cannot share associations like musty, animalistic, and the like. There are quite different candidates for that, and this view can only be due to the fact that one knows little beyond designer fragrances.
There is not much more to say about the scent; it does not have many nuances and is characterized by the authentically scented trademark ingredients. At most, the vetiver as a wingman is recognizable, and the synthetic wood has also been downgraded to a supporter.

Therefore, Guilty Absolute is the entry into the world of leather; if this is too much or too animalistic for you, you are probably even worse off with other leather fragrances. If you like this but find it too smooth, you will move on.

So... I haven't posted anything on parfumo for quite a long time. To be honest, there hasn't really been any new release in the last 2-3 years that prompted me to share my thoughts. But now the time has come. Well, I probably wouldn't write anything about the GGA (=Gucci Guilty Absolute) either, but I received the fragrance as a gift from my brother two days ago. And that by accident.
You see, (there's no umlaut a on my keyboard, so I always write with ae) I actually prefer the original Gucci Guilty compared to most people here. I just like the scent. Just the fragrance and the overall package with the bottle, color, packaging, Chris Evans, hairy chest, etc. I know the advertising achieved what it wanted ;)
Well, my brother went to the perfumery and wanted to buy me the Guilty Intense, but instead, he bought the Absolute, as I said, by accident. He handed me the bag, I took out the box, and lo and behold, it was a brown box instead of black. I knew what that meant because I had already tested the Gucci Absolute. Not even on the paper strip, let alone on my hand, but just sniffed it briefly at the spray head. That was enough for me :)

Boom... like a punch from One Punch Mickey aka Brad Pitt in the film classic "Snatch" by Guy Ritchie. Anyone who knows the film (I hope everyone does, if not, watch it right away, it's a cult) knows what I mean. You have to take a quick breath after the first sniff. The new Gucci (Okay, it's not that new either) knocks you off your feet. I think it’s mainly because nowadays, they don't really make such masculine fragrances anymore, except maybe in the niche market. It has absolutely nothing sweet or fresh about it like 99% of all men's fragrances today. It just smells mercilessly like... MAN. Maybe too much?

Hmm, definitely not for everyone. It smells very strong of leather and is definitely suitable for autumn and winter.
So I didn't even test it on my skin. It was just too off-putting for me.

Well, that's the one I got from my little brother :) He said he no longer had the receipt. So I had no choice but to tear off the outer foil and immediately give a spray on my hand. It turned out shortly after that he actually still had the receipt. What a drama.

I've had the fragrance for 2 days now and I must say... I can't stop smelling my hand.
Oh, and I should mention that the scents smell exactly the same on my skin as they do on a paper strip. So no development or anything. But I must say that this Gucci feels quite good on my skin. It becomes a bit softer. Not as extreme as from the bottle. It becomes a bit tamer. But just a bit. But that’s enough for me. Thus, it is wearable for me. However, the initial impact of the fragrance fades quickly. I would wish for a longer longevity and a bit better sillage.

Nevertheless, I am already looking forward to autumn ;) With a leather jacket and my suede boots, it will fit so well. So more suited to a rougher style of clothing.
I think it would also go very well with a suit and coat. However, I always associate brown leather with the fragrance (brown leather jacket, brown leather boots). It probably has to do with the color of the perfume.
You all know Gaultier's "Ultra Male"... Ultra Male :D ..I have to grin every time at the name because it doesn't match the fragrance at all. Gaultier's "Ultra Male" is quite feminine. The designation "ultra male" really has no place there, but well. Advertising, I guess. What I want to say is, THIS GUCCI HERE deserves that name. I mean come on people, this fragrance from Gucci is testosterone times ten. At 30 years old, I feel 5 years older with this scent. It exudes masculinity and maturity. I'm sure this Gucci evokes just that in most people who then walk behind you on the street.

On the other hand, it divides opinions. Maybe some will even cross to the other side of the street. Such a thing is certainly not liked. Not that it has ever happened to me :D But I can imagine it.

As mentioned, I wasn't initially thrilled with the Guilty Absolute, but it only took 2 days for me to fall in love with it. I should also mention that it smells very high quality. At least to me. I've read the opposite here. However, it feels very natural to me.

Bottle, color of the juice, packaging... for me, everything is a feast for the eyes with this product. And the best part is, it will never be mainstream, I'm quite sure of that.

And lastly... if movies could smell, "Snatch" would definitely smell like Gucci Guilty Absolute, with its plot and all its characters. Above all, One Punch Mickey, Turkish & Frankie "fucking" four fingers.

In the end, it was a positive mistake ;)

I really like leather as a scent, very much so. However, I find it difficult with real leather fragrances. Tom Ford's Tuscan Leather is far too feminine for me because of its jasmine. Le Malé Essence by Gaultier is nice but sometimes too sweet. Royal Leather by Charriol is also nice, but why do I have to smell like dried plums with a leather scent?

Next up is Leather 6 by Schwarzlose. I find it strong, but for me, it already smells like sex in a darkroom, which is cool, but I don't need that every day. Then there were a few more experiences, and in the end, I landed on Acqua di Parma Leather. For me, that's really fine, noble leather. A leather scent that I can be happy with.

Now I have a good friend. Every few weeks, he meets up with some buddies for a kind of group sport. Every time he complained because he stood a meter away from a youth player who was drenched in 1 Million. You have to know, he doesn't like sweet scents at all. But 1 Million is quite intensely sweet, and the cloud always drifted over to him, so he could hardly concentrate on what he was doing. His desperation was so great that he sprayed everything he had on that 18-year-old in the hope of covering up the sweetness. Now he has Gucci Guilty Absolute... and the problem is gone, because against the leathery/woody scent of Gucci, even 1 Million can't compete anymore.

This friend told me about the fragrance, and it made me curious. When I discovered it in the perfumery, I had to try it right away, and upon the first sniff, I was... shocked!!!

Powerful, dominant. Burnt wood, old leather jacket, auto repair shop with a sweaty mechanic. If AcP Leather is the most elegant Italian version of capturing leather in a fragrance, then Gucci is the counterpoint.

I doubted my friend's nose for a week. How on earth could he like this? ... But I found something fascinating about the scent as well. So, for two weeks, I kept going to the perfumery during my lunch break and sprayed it on myself a few times, and lo and behold, a love developed.

This scent oozes self-confidence. It is not refined or elegant, let alone discreet. For me, this is also not a scent I would wear when going to work. But in the evening at the club or for anything that might happen afterward, it fits wonderfully. It is a bit dirty, very masculine, dominant, and sexy. It suits me for all age groups, except maybe for guys under 20, as that doesn't quite fit yet. But now in summer, sneakers, jeans, open shirt, three-day beard, and the style is ready for this scent.

I am grateful to my friend for introducing me to this fragrance. He has also introduced me to Himalaya by Creed and Oud Wood by Tom Ford. While Himalaya is a great scent for the morning, I believe I still couldn't handle Gucci at 9 AM, as I am not a morning person, and Oud Wood remains the king in the collection; it is a noble overall composition. But I have come to love Gucci Guilty Absolute.

For the leather freaks - you have to test this scent..

I love this extreme leather touch that this fragrance has. It reminds me a bit of the smell at a gas station mixed with strong leather. In my opinion, it's an absolute must-have for every man!
The longevity is more than above average for me - the scent lasted up to 2 weeks on my clothes.. and even after the washing machine, faint notes of this fragrance come through

It actually appeals less to women, but more to male colleagues!
Although it must be said here that the scent repels many "non-perfume enthusiasts," and they often perceive the scent as stinky.

In any case, a clear recommendation from me!

"Gucci Absolute pour Homme" reminded me at first sniff of the typical chypre leather fragrances with conifer resins and balsamic notes. The first wave hit the market in the 70s ("Polo", "Halston Z-14", "Yatagan" etc.), and there was a revival in the 80s and 90s ("New West", "Globe", "DKNY Fuel Men", "Harley Davidson" etc.)

The opening is characterized by intensely fragrant Mediterranean herbs (mugwort, thyme) - the scent has, apart from a bit of yuzu, no pronounced freshness component and starts off sweaty. Soon follows a floral-coniferous heart note with iris, jasmine, pine needle, cypress. The distinctly dry base note, devoid of any hint of vanilla or cinnamon sweetness, is dominated by leather, amber, styrax, patchouli, and vetiver.

Those used to today's creamy pudding notes will experience a culture shock with "Gucci Absolute pour Homme." I find it to be a likable retro scent and a real man - and it has a dark, murky note that reminds me alternately of a cemetery or a bedroom. It's exactly the type of character scent that is often missing nowadays. But you have to like it, as it truly has edges and corners. Similarities to "Fahrenheit" are rather limited, as the latter appears cleaner and, despite the leather note, actually has more in common with "Grey Flannel" (violet).

review_title: Must be wearable and above all desired
review_content:
This fragrance is a statement in itself. Of course, it doesn't reach the level of some niche scents in terms of uniqueness, but it is definitely more special than anything else from Douglas and Co.
For me, it has a relatively strong touch of motor oil, diesel, hex keys, and hard work - pure masculinity, in other words.
Whether one likes this DNA or not is up to each individual, personally I would rather keep my distance from this scent - unless you are a passionate biker looking for a suitable perfume for the next Harley meet.
But jokes aside, the fragrance doesn't do anything wrong in my eyes, after all, it is supposed and wants to be extravagant. However, one should be aware of its presence and not expect a "What smells so good here?" but rather a "Did someone have a breakdown here?"

I tested this expecting to find a typical modern generic designer fragrance in front of me. I anticipated a typical somewhat woody Gucci with a bit of leather that would surely please everyone in some way. What I got was a bit of a shock. :D

This scent will definitely not appeal to everyone, and it doesn't suit everyone, especially not for every occasion. The quite strong top note smells to me like gasoline, motor oil, and dirty worn leather. Something about it clearly reminds me of Fahrenheit, less so of the noble clean leather from TF Ombre Leather. Overall, it feels extremely masculine to me. A fragrance that I could see on some of the 'Sons' from the aforementioned series if they were in tattered leather vests working on their Harleys in the workshop. It doesn't come across as perfumey at all. Not much else comes through. The gasoline and oil fade a bit, but the dirty smoky leather remains. And that lingers quite a while.

I find it surprisingly good, but in my opinion, it is only wearable under certain conditions. A leather vest or at least a leather jacket is a must. The occasion should match as well. SAMCRO FOREVER. :D

review_title: This Gucci has gasoline in its blood!
review_content:
Designer mainstream, check.
Synthetic scent materials, check.
On paper: No reason to consider this fragrance further.

But as so often, theory is just theory and reality is reality. Woodleather? Goldenwood? Who cares!

On the nose: Leather, and what a leather it is! Nasty? I wouldn't say so. But dominant. Uncompromising. Hovering above it: Gasoline, equally uncompromising. What a start! Sounds harsh? Maybe. Still, it is much more wearable than it might sound at first. This gasoline note is borderline and ultra-cool at the same time - that's quite an achievement.

Beneath the gasoline-soaked leather lies a foundation of solid wood, which supports it. Whether synthetic or natural doesn't matter here either. It supports. And it does so solidly and enduringly. Patchouli adds a soft, spicy sweetness. Still different. Refreshingly different.

Alberto Morillas, I bow to this Fast-and-Furious Gucci with gasoline in its blood!

The only fragrances I review are those that possess a unique momentum.

This scent has managed to convince me of its nature right away. Deeply leathery and drenched in gasoline. Well, it's understandable that this is a smell not everyone loves - but that's often an inspiration for me. I give you the association; camel saddle.

It showcases the uniqueness of the thing itself. Perfume.

The scent remains constantly consistent in its DNA, long-lasting, yet never mutating into a beast.

For me, it is a classic leather fragrance in a classic form. Because when I personally look for a leather scent, it must first smell strongly of leather and in the next instance radiate something unique. It must have character. And this fragrance definitely has that.

review_title: The Mechatronics Engineer and the Tough Guys...
review_content:
Uihh... Something from Mr. Morillas/Mr. Fresh?! I was so curious about what to expect given the ingredients.

I don't know if any of you are familiar with those leather-scented cardboard pieces that you can mount in your car or under the car seat to imitate the smell of new car leather (it only works if you have leather seats, right). They now have competition. That’s exactly what I thought when the top note burst of leather scent hit my nose. Leather in a new car, standing in the showroom combined with rubber and oil. And it continues like this from the top note to the end, with a little hint of wood (ash) left at the end. However, the fragrance softens a bit over time and moves away from the coarse thick buffalo leather towards finer Nappa;)

A scent for real (leather) guys and perhaps mechatronics engineers who don’t want to hide their profession even after work and when going out nicely. For me, it’s not a scent for a suit or in the office - unless you wear a leather tie with it:))) or are busy at Gucci in the leather goods department...

The whole thing is interesting, very specific, but as a fragrance, it’s not wearable for me due to a lack of imagination and usability for what occasion I would use it. Moreover, the linear scent progression and the overwhelmingly dominant leather note seem a bit monotonous to me, yet it is indeed (and finally again) a striking and masculine fragrance. It will surely find its buyers.

This headline describes the scent best. For me, as a person with ties to automotive mechanics, oil on my hands, lubricants, and the (partially pointless but fun) burning of high-octane fuel on two wheels, this is simply the fragrance for those situations. Leather jacket on, a few sprays of this, and off we go on a wild journey. For me, it is one of the boldest designer scents...

review_title: Grandpa's Leather Jacket Meets Antique Wardrobe
review_content:
The title may initially sound strange or even negative, but it is indeed meant to be fully positive. I will try to explain how this comes about in my little review or rather my personal story about Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Homme.

My relationship with Guilty Absolute starts, as so often, with a sniffing session in the perfume store (guess which one?) where the bottle caught my attention more out of boredom than genuine interest, as the previous fragrances released under the Gucci Guilty label from Italian provenance had rather put me in a state of less pronounced ecstasy, to put it mildly. So I sprayed a bit of the delicious dark brown juice onto a tester and held it to my nose with rather low expectations - and I was completely taken aback!

Where I had expected something between shower gel freshness and synthetic sweetness, suddenly leather hit me! And wood! And something gasoline-petroleum-like! I did not expect that, and I must say that the scent initially overwhelmed me a bit - animalistic, leathery, woody, and bone dry... that is not an easy cocktail that Gucci has pumped into the bottle.

So I looked further, initially categorizing the leather colleague as "a bit much," went home, and that was the end of the story. Or was it? Somehow, I just couldn’t get the scent out of my head, and every time I spotted it on a perfume shelf, I had to smell it again. And again. And again. Until I finally bought it (thanks to its apparently rather low popularity, it is relatively inexpensive to find) and have been wearing it ever since, whenever the weather and mood allow.

Okay, long story, many words, but how does the biker jacket perform on the church bench in practice? In fact, it is less intense than I initially thought. It is certainly recognizable as a leather-wood scent, but it is also pleasantly warm and rounded and above all - and I rarely say this about perfumes - quite sexy. In terms of scent progression, it is relatively linear, which is not meant negatively here. Longevity and sillage are definitely good to very good for me, and the reactions from those around me are also noticeable - all in all, a great scent for anyone who is up for a bit of adventure in their fragrance wardrobe!

Normally, I would take a moment here to say a few words about the opening and the further development of a perfume. However, this is not necessary at all, because as soon as it is sprayed on, this scent, or should we rather say smell, unfolds with a powerful dose of extremely smooth leather, dressed in a dark vetiver note resting on a base of patchouli and a bit of wood. Even...

review_title: What on earth? Does it really say Gucci on it?
review_content:
What on earth? Does it really say Gucci on it?

So, I have to say that aside from my favorite Gucci fragrance, which is pour Homme II, I don't like any other Gucci men's fragrance, at least from those currently available. This doesn't apply to the fragrances released in the past, as I don't know them very well, but I've heard that they were quite good! Hard to believe when you look at the fragrances currently available from Gucci... anyway, I don't really like any of them, or at least they are rather insignificant.

And especially with the Guiltys, I had already given up all hope of getting something good under my nose... but a visit to a fragrance shop was supposed to change my mind...

Saleswoman: Good day, can I help you?
Me: Oh... I just wanted to see what's new!
Saleswoman: How about the new Gucci?
Me: Gucci? Is it Gucci pour Homme III???
Saleswoman: What? No, that doesn't even exist. I meant the new Guilty!
Me: .... Eww.... Guilty....
Saleswoman: Oh come on! Why don't you try it!
Me: ... if it really must be... I could try it on a test st...

Spruuuuuuuh.... Even before I could say "test strip," I got a load sprayed right on my arm... internally, my eggs already hurt because I had already wasted a WHOLE arm... but...

Me: ... hmmm... Tell me, what's the name of the brand again?
Saleswoman: Gucci!
Me: Gucci??
Saleswoman: Gucci!
Me: Gucci Guilty?
Saleswoman: Gucci Guilty!!
Me: ... noooo... it must be something else...!
Saleswoman: ... why do so many people say that???

Yes, it's hard to believe, but what you smell here is actually not bad at all, and for a new Gucci fragrance, it has turned out surprisingly well! The scent structure itself is quite simple:

The scent:
Right at the beginning, you are immediately surrounded by a rather intense, but not unpleasant leather scent, which should please anyone who likes leather quite a bit. Together with the woody notes (I think I smell cypress here), the fragrance smells good and quite masculine. Moreover, this combination has the potential to be easily recognizable.
For a while, the scent remains like this, changing very little later on, except that a patchouli note comes in towards the base, making it a bit earthier. And I had the feeling that the leather becomes a bit softer. Vetiver was the note I couldn't smell at all.
A little later, you can really only smell the leather, which then doesn't smell softer anymore, but rather a bit rougher, which is not bad. As I said, it's not a bad scent, but it's really only suitable for leather fans. I don't like it that much, but in my opinion, this is the right direction for Gucci after all those really insignificant Guiltys...

The sillage and longevity:
The sillage is still quite strong at the beginning, but then it does fade a bit. Overall, the fragrance remains quite intense, so a larger scent cloud is left behind. This means the scent is well noticeable on someone, so you should be careful with the dosage.
The longevity is enormous. The fragrance can easily last more than fourteen or sixteen hours on the skin, if not more with the right dosage!

The bottle:
The bottle, however, remains not so special (well, that's a matter of taste), even if the logo is supposed to resemble the Batman logo :D
It looks like a fashionable flask (transparent) filled with brown fragrance liquid. Batman,... argh, I mean the logo is integrated into the glass, there is no label. The cap is cylindrical, black, and looks a bit too small. Not bad, but also not exceptionally beautiful.

So, as I said, this fragrance from Gucci has really turned out well, so well that I'm totally surprised that it says Gucci as a brand on it! It is still not my fragrance and will never be, but that's only because I don't like strong leather scents in general; however, many should like it quite a bit, provided they are really into leather. Moreover, this fragrance doesn't jump on the oud bandwagon. It may still smell a bit synthetic, but in a way that's not bothersome.

The scent is quite simple, as it only smells of leather and wood, it is quite masculine and could also be suitable for going out. It can be best worn in autumn and winter.

Hmm…
I know I shouldn't get my hopes up, but... I have a dream! To quote Martin Luther King Jr. :DD
.... I still dream of one day seeing a massive, rectangular bottle in a store with Gucci pour Homme III written on it, and neither leather nor coriander will be in it... one day... one... day...

And now that Gucci has once again released a somewhat good fragrance... one can still dream... *sigh* .... Or can’t one? We shall see... oh, I just hope so. Because leather is really not my thing, but everyone else can also "waste" an arm for the fragrance!

Indeed, Guilty Absolute has a certain character. The amusing reference to Gucci's "rediscovered eggs" is not wrong.

Nevertheless, it does not reach the expressive power of the old Gucci heavyweights Gucci pour Homme (first version) and Envy pour Homme - which, however, had a different fragrance direction.

I would primarily classify it as immensely woody. Leather, vetiver traces, etc. as well. In any case, quite synthetic.

In the other comments, there is a "guess what this reminds you of" game, mentioning TdH, Carbonne, even Encre Noir. All associative and not completely wrong, but the hit is likely to be the following:

It reminds me - especially after the top note disappears - strikingly (!) of L'Homme Infini by Divine, which is, however, miles better and also significantly more expensive.

Could, despite its masculine note, also be interesting for women!

review_title: ...Grandma's old leather bag in the bargain bin down the hall next to the front door...
review_content:
Actually, I hardly like any fragrances from Gucci; they are mostly very unbalanced, often too sweet disco-pumper scents (especially the newer ones!). They usually lack any charm or recognizable individuality. That’s what I thought about Gucci until I came across this one through a perfume review. It was touted as a fragrance that supposedly possesses niche quality and stands out in the leather scent segment due to its uniqueness. Those were big words, and since I do appreciate leather scents - just think of the incredible Ombre Leather by Tommy - I thought a blind buy couldn't hurt.

So I did it, Gucci arrived...(at a bargain price during the pre-Christmas shopping season!)

The bottle:
What can I say...miserable, cheap, the cap is hard to remove, the packaging looks like it’s from a drugstore. Overall, it’s a better flask that you’d rather place at the back of the fragrance shelf so that viewers don’t get startled or begin to doubt the collector's competence. Sorry for the harsh words, but the exterior seems to play a role in perfume :P

The test:
Wow! After the first spray, it was already more than clear that this is a leather scent. And what a scent it is, not a clean-cool biker like Tom Ford's, not an elegant rocker and seducer, no, this is a dirty, rugged guy. What you get under your nose is old, ancient leather that has been well-worn over the years. And for a long time, that’s all you smell. Leather, leather, and more leather. My mother aptly remarked: "It smells like my mother's old green leather handbag that’s in our bargain bin!" And I have to say: she’s right. It does have a slightly "grandma-grandpa" vibe, if you know what I mean? But it’s also exaggeratedly masculine at the same time. Consequently, it has a distinct uniqueness in the leather fragrance market that one must appreciate. This slight "mustiness" of the old leather does fade over time, and what remains is a beautiful, soft leather accord underlined by subtle (really very subtle!) woods. For me, it’s almost not a leathery-woody scent, but just a leather scent. It could also be a leather goods spray on the market or in a department store. Oh, and the good thing doesn’t change much.

Longevity and sillage:
Good! It’s a real powerhouse that projects for about 3-4 hours at a good arm's length before it pulls back. On the skin, it lasts a good 8 hours. So you get your money's worth.

Who wears something like this?
Well, you do, if you’re into real, dirty-old leather and want a leather scent that is truly authentic down to the last detail. It’s also for you if you enjoy fragrances that manage to awaken memories of days gone by. Think of scents like Timbuktu or the wonderful Burberry Touch. Moreover, it pairs perfectly with a leather jacket and wears excellently in autumn or winter. However, I find that it’s more of a scent for those over 30. Below that, it might come off wrong. Also, one must accept as a wearer that some may not perceive it as a scent at all because it’s so natural that, when paired with a leather jacket, it will likely lead to compliments about the nicely smelling jacket :D Overall, I would recommend testing this fragrance beforehand, as it is quite specific! After all, it’s available everywhere.

CONCLUSION: Gucci offers a premium leather scent with high niche quality in a dreadful guise!

I was very curious about the new Gucci fragrance. After milestones like Gucci I, Envy, or Rush, this house unfortunately hasn't managed to produce anything noteworthy. The last creations, Made to Measure or the Guilty offshoots, were "absolutely" underground - and even that is flattering. All the more pleasing that Gucci has returned to its old virtues and can still create...

Do you know that feeling? Fragrances that you would never buy just by smelling them in the store. But when someone close to you wears a scent and you get to know it through them, you start to learn to appreciate perfumes?

That's how it was for me with Guilty Absolute. My best friend always used this fragrance; I didn't know the perfume before. At some point, I bought the perfume for myself.

For me, Guilty Absolute was by no means a scent I liked right away. I had to learn to like it. This smoky, almost burnt-smelling perfume was not something I immediately enjoyed. But that will come.

Longevity and sillage are absolutely top-notch. It’s in the upper mid-range. The stuff lasts long on the skin, and you will be noticed for hours. But what exactly does it smell like?

Spiciness and bitter notes. Smokiness joins in, and I get a hint of burnt notes in my nose. Burnt, but not necessarily in a negative way. Rather, it’s striking. Unique.

And that is this scent. Unique. Not like any other fragrance. Not overly polished, not extremely complex. Simple, high-quality, and yet striking. A scent that definitely stays in your memory. But don’t we all want that? To emphasize our individuality? Guilty Absolute does this very well.

++ Little Disclaimer ++

I have come to love this perfume, but in this review, I cannot avoid addressing the ingredients. BHT and some colorants that have a questionable reputation; there may well be allergenic and harmful substances present here. For the sake of completeness.

review_title: Instead of Probation: Gucci Goes for “Bauhaus”
review_content:
And when I write “Bauhaus,” I don’t mean the great and groundbreaking art school from Weimar, but the DIY store chain from Mannheim.

In the early 70s, there was such a Bauhaus store near my parents' apartment, quite centrally located and occasionally a stop when I needed some crafting supplies for elementary school or similar. Two things have stuck in my memory like Pattex: on one hand, the subtle easy-listening light music that played on repeat there. On the other hand, the smell mix in the store of cut wooden planks and particle board, as well as wallpaper paint and industrial glue.

And somehow, that’s not so far removed from what Gucci wants to serve us with its latest Guilty version.
I actually thought, based on the initial positive feedback, that Gucci was on the verge of acquittal or at least on probation with this Guilty flanker. Alberto Morillas would have fit well as a probation officer, even if he occasionally made a few olfactory missteps.

Here, anyway, he has mixed up a hefty chemical cocktail that doesn’t even pretend to contain natural ingredients - that should at least be acknowledged. The artificial leather-wood blend is only pleasant for the first few seconds; after that, it quickly becomes annoying, especially since the whole thing takes on a strong resemblance to damp gray clay as modeling material. You can of course also purchase that at Bauhaus.
Patchouli and vetiver can only be found in theory; in the scent itself, you hardly perceive any of it ... as if someone had withheld it.

A bit more exciting than the conventional Guilty along with all its flankers is the Absolute pour Homme, but only because one tends to get more worked up about it.

I’m still not at peace with Gucci’s new releases, although I briefly thought that Coty had finally heard the call. If you like it, may it bring you bliss. For me, the entire Guilty series, including this offshoot, is a hopeless case of a virtually incorrigible repeat offender - despite deceptive camouflage.

review_title: While Cleaning Out the Horse Stable...
review_content:
He is a fierce leather scent, this fragrance. Massive leather, and almost nothing else. There is fine, soft leather and firm, durable leather. I suspect this scent belongs to the latter category due to its intensity. This type of leather comes with scars, cracks, creaks, and pops. However, this fragrance shows none of those characteristics. No natural surface marked by the roughness of nature is visible. Still, "Guilty Absolute" is the complete contrast to the usual Gucci waters.

I like leather, but whether it has to be in this intense, smoothed-out superficiality is debatable. Other leather fragrances come across much more distinctly. However, it could potentially be suitable for certain outings and bar visits. Or, indeed, for cleaning out the stable. For everything else, one should exercise caution. You could quickly be relegated to the "stinky corner" with subsequent recommendations for washing, showering, or bathing :))

For me, leather scent means dark, smoky, disreputable, daring, and a healthy, balanced portion of self-confidently selfish, even slightly arrogant, demanding stubbornness. This fragrance completely lacks all of that. It comes across, with consistent penetrance, as quite sterile. A clumsy, bumbling wannabe macho. There is no attraction emanating from it. Nuances, spirit, and charm are missing, which make a desirable macho.

Compared to this, Terre d'Hermes is almost a gentle breeze.
It should really just be called *Leather Extreme*! Caution is advised when it comes to dosing. Longevity for me was easily 15 hours. Top quality, but Mr. Morillas unfortunately
leaves little room for anything other than the leather perception. Other notes are hardly recognizable.
Some women (or men) will surely love it, but for others it might be a bit overwhelming.
Nevertheless, a completely independent, high-quality fragrance.

review_title: Take a good whiff of this one, my friend
review_content:
Guilty Absolute pour Homme is certainly not among the fabric softeners or pale scents. Leather is truly special and richly present, but very well embedded in a pleasantly cheeky spiciness, wood, smoke, and a light oriental sweetness. In this case, the sweet touch does not ruin anything (I’m not a fan of sweetness), but rather rounds it off and enhances the sillage. This combination thus appears animalistic and seductive, possessing a certain dominance. If GA weren't a bit sweet, it would probably be quite intense and borderline. Comparable in effect to N°. XXII - Black Afghan.

If I were an animal, I would probably have marked my territory with this and staked my claim. The sillage is powerful and signals to other males that an alpha male is on the way. In the realm of humans, this creation might also rub some people the wrong way, or one might just fall in love with it. With a smirk, I’ll lean out the window and claim that one submits to it. Well, those are just my feelings and associations.

By the way, I could also occasionally imagine this scent on an alpha female, but I would not issue it the label "unisex" at all. Statements like "grandma's old leather bag," "50s handbag," or "plaster leather" fit well and resonate clearly. A unique feature in the leather domain and an animalistic dominance would be my summary of an exotic men's fragrance.

This scent smells of adventure, of dusty stables, fine saddle leather, and the hint of wildness that lingers in the air when you ride out at dawn.

From the very first moment, this fragrance reminds you of the rich, dark smell of a freshly oiled saddle, whose leather only becomes more beautiful over the years. It is not a soft, sweet leather, but a powerful, almost rugged aroma - as if you were rubbing saddle care products between your fingers while the warm skin of the horse still radiates the heat of a long ride.

You lean against a pasture fence and let your gaze glide over the wide fields and hills, while your horse snorts beside you.

This scent is as timeless as cowboys in their flannel shirts, worn with ease but with a presence that immediately stands out. It speaks of confidence, of people who don’t need to be loud to make an impression.

We have strong, beautiful leather that lasts for hours, and when the fragrance settles, a hint of vetiver and warm woods remains.
Just this.

A feeling of coming home after a long ride and letting the day wind down in an armchair with a glass of whisky.

I smell only and exclusively leather. I cannot perceive any other components.

At first, I have the impression of a clear, fresh leather. The scent feels almost transparent, see-through. In Dior Fahrenheit, the leather is embedded in a bouquet of accompanying notes. Gucci Guilty is a fragrance experience that is straightforward and minimalist, direct, and unembellished. Therefore, I consider it more suitable for the bright season, although not exactly for the hottest summer days.

However, after three to four hours, a vinegar-like sour note creeps in. In this respect, I can partially understand the dismissive comments of my predecessors.

Sillage is average, longevity is good.

Leather lovers can certainly consider Gucci Guilty as a serious option without having to feel "guilty" about a misstep. I generally don't like leather scents that much. However, that must be set aside here. All in all, I would say it's a decent scent, but not one that causes enthusiasm.

Guilty is most likely wearable in casual settings. It evokes associations of jeans, motorcycles, and of course, leather jackets.

Dear friends of fine fragrance, I recently ordered Guilty Absolute pour Homme as a blind buy. Good choice! There are fragrances that you give away, others you are glad to finish, and then there are those: I will buy this again when the bottle is empty. I find myself in the latter case. Sure, it will never become my signature scent, but I am fascinated by it: Positive: - It...

There he stands. Weighing around two hundred pounds, scars on his face, muscular, with a sword in hand. Brutal, wild, determined, rugged. The beard speaks of determination, the gaze of a fighting spirit. But not of blind, senseless brawls in drunken nights at the club. No. From the absolute will to protect his people and family. Tempered and driven. Strong, but not immortal. The fight is his life. But only when he must. Then he has "Killing in the Name of" by RATM in his blood.

To sit by the fire on summer evenings with his loved ones. With his little ones in his arms. Completely calm. Like "Nothing else matters" by Metallica. That is his life too. Warm, heartfelt, loving, bear-like.

Not everyone likes him, but everyone respects him. Not everyone can handle alpha males who know the way, who show a clear edge (and can hurt because of it), clearly. Some are frightened. He is not a smiling guy that everyone likes.
But the boss. Because he has substance in what he does. Because he can make unpopular decisions, which does not mean he lacks backbone. Certainly not.

Women with ego find him hot, while cowards think it's too wild, hard, brutal.

I actually received this scent as a gift in the summer.
At that time it was new, and I had no idea what kind of fragrance it was at all.
I opened the packaging and saw Gucci Guilty Absolute, thinking to myself,
what has Gucci done this time, a version of the boring Guilty in brown?
I opened the bottle and sprayed it on my arm and asked my girlfriend what she thought of it?
Her reaction was iiiiiiiii it smells like an old leather sofa,
my thought was, it must smell amazing..
Next, it was my turn to smell..
I sniffed and suddenly had a vivid imagination, an unkempt guy (with good taste) with a three-day beard,
a smoking cigarette at the corner of his mouth, dressed in black leather, and riding a Harley, it all just fits this scent.
Later, the woods also come through, and it becomes a mild leather scent.
This fragrance is not for the faint-hearted.
You have to be the right person for this scent,
so that you wear the fragrance and not the other way around!
Mass appeal is another matter.
It certainly won't appeal to many people who are into mainstream fragrances.
Longevity & sillage are brutally good.
The bottle, well... we've already discussed that.
My tip is, I spray this scent on the leather seats of my car, and they smell like good, high-quality leather again.

review_title: Little experimentation, but plenty of cojones
review_content:
Guilty Absolute is by far the best in this line for me. The leather is as intense as one would hardly expect from Gucci. Once sprayed on the skin, you walk around for 2 days with an olfactory leather jacket.

If you want to smell pure leather, you are in the right place. However, that’s about all there is to it. As the name suggests, the scent is Absolute. But if you are looking for a complex interplay of various notes, you are definitely in the wrong place. Little experimentation, but plenty of cojones.

I can imagine that it can be too dominant on hot days. So I would categorize it as a masculine scent for cold days.

The scent has a full blast of leather with a hint of wood. For the cold winter months, it is a very, very good companion. The performance surprised me positively. However, it is not made for every nose, so I recommend testing it first or ordering a small sample. I will definitely reorder.

I place this scent somewhere between Givenchy Gentleman (without the civet) and a flat-cut Eau du Fier (which has unfortunately long been taken off the market) without its jus de veau - or smoked ham - aspect and campfire realism, to which a wound plaster note was added - an interesting statement that obviously winks towards Tom Ford's golden design era and aims to pay homage to the Texan grandmaster of porn chic, confidently elevating the now tacky image of the house to make it appealing to a new and young generation. Unfortunately, the perfume lacks a bit of juice and 'grime' to make it feel more three-dimensional and natural...
Still: hats off to a scent that finally dares to do without sugar!
p.s.
Could work wonderfully as a base under other leather and patchouli perfumes.

The bottle resembles a flask, and the liquid looks like a long-aged cognac. But that’s where the positives end.

The scent starts off indefinably fresh + sparkling, but immediately transforms into a biting smoky note that, despite its intensity, fades quite quickly. My first association was lighter fuel.

Since Gucci has moved to Coty/ P&G, many beloved fragrances have been removed from the lineup or significantly reduced + reformulated, and what has been newly released for both women and men is a complete disaster.
Generic fragrance garbage, regardless of whether it says Gucci, Boss, Jil Sander, Escada, or D&G on the label.

review_title: IS this supposed to be a designer?
review_content: Sam and Dean Winchester are stranded with their Impala at a lonely gas station in the middle of a remote forest area. "Why don't you have a spare gas can in the trunk?" grumbles Sam. "Shut up!" Dean snaps and gets out. "There are leather jackets and sawdust all over the place, look at this!" Excitedly, he grabs one of the jackets and takes a deep breath of the thick cowhide....

Super masculine, rugged leather, absolute manly men, You will grow a beard and moustache using this, Hunter born .A nice dark, deep leathery bomb with a slight airy aromatic vibe and a moist woody base, it gets to the point quickly. Definitely has a niche quality coming from Gucci and the smell matches the color of the juice. Strong and masculine and great for cold winter days but I admit I love it in the summer too. Im also getting a sweet cherry fruity feel which I love. Reminds me of bandages in a good way as I also get the medicinal and gasoline vibes as well. Great performance and a gem that I would recommend just for its simplicity but great scent.

review_title: I've been wishing for a long time…
review_content: … for a 1967 Ford Mustang. An acquaintance has a workshop and sells classic cars and called me to come by because he had a bargain for me. So I put on my jeans, a white shirt, sneakers, and my leather jacket. In the workshop stands a fire-red Mustang coupe with cream-colored leather seats. The car has just under 15,000 km on it and is in impeccable condition. The smell of...

review_title: The Adventurer with a Broken Motorcycle and Oil on His Fingers
review_content: Surprisingly masculine and leathery for a Gucci Guilty variation. More of an outdoor scent that radiates movement, a thirst for adventure, and masculinity. This fragrance is definitely leathery and also "dirty." At this point, one does not imagine a freshly showered delicate gentleman ready to throw on his suit. Rather, it evokes the image of a worker, a mechanic, the bearded guy who is about to roar through the mud on his Café Racer. More like the man who, in a white undershirt, is about to dump the next load of gravel onto the trailer. The longevity is quite good, the projection as well. For the now fairly affordable price, it's not a bad choice at all, as long as you know what to expect. I would recommend it more for ages 30 and up.

Where do I start :) I first smelled Gucci Absolute in 2017 when it was released, and I still remember it clearly.

The first thing I smelled back then was dry, very dry leather. I found it incredible, but I didn't know how, when, and where I should wear it.

I often caught myself smelling it again and again on a yearly basis, and the fragrance kept changing for me.

About half a year ago, I bought it, and what can I say? It will definitely remain a staple in my collection.
