This leather has a dry yet slightly zesty sweetness. A faint undertone of oil occasionally comes through, and I don't want to miss this scent.

It is generally ranked for autumn and winter here, but I think it works anytime as long as you don't overdo it. I really enjoy wearing it in summer, and it works great in the evenings too.

In my opinion, it's a must for every leather fragrance fan.

Men's wearable leather perfume. At first, it's loud leather, but that fades quickly. Next, a blend of wood accord with herbs takes over, and you start to fall in love with the fragrance. I have the feeling that there are citrus notes in it, even though it's not mentioned in the pyramid.

If this hadn't come out right before the pandemic, I think it would've been way more popular. It would've drawn in the clean girl crowd, the unisex scent crowd, and of course the Harry Stiles fans, among others. It has a nice balance of clean and herbal without smelling like hand soap or cleaning products, and it is very soothing. The bottle is gorgeous and sleek, and unlike most of what is being churned out by mainstream brands at the moment. It plays nicely with other scents to layer, and you can amp up the floral-ness or even add a bit of fruitness if you so desire. I feel like this was barely a blip on the radar, which is a shame, because it is really good. It is a little more powerful than other skin scents, but it doesn't dominate when worn either. I call it a skin-plus scent, because it is there and it is lovely, but it doesn't draw attention like a magnet. Rather, it is subtly charismatic. I do think it is truly unisex as well, as the chamomile doesn't give "flower," it gives "outside in the early morning sunlight."

review_title: A Sort Of Amulet Against Evil
review_content:
Gucci Mémoire d'une Odeur has always fascinated me ever since they first released it. That hay and sweet herb-like nuance immediately caught my attention, the intense and familiar aroma of chamomile, bitter honey, and green apple. Chamomile, a small daisy-like flower, does not smell but more than one because different varieties offer different shades to a perfumer. The wild one, for example, is herbaceous, green, and fresh, more reminiscent of the herbal tea we drink to calm us down or invite us to sleep. The German one, on the other hand, is sweeter but smoky, with hints of apple. Finally, Roman chamomile or Anthemis nobilis is sweet, delicately spiced, and intoxicating, with an apple blossom flavor. The latter was chosen as the top note for Mémoire d'une Odeur. So, close your eyes for a moment and imagine you are lying on a lawn. Next to you is an old wicker basket where you have placed a few handfuls of chamomile flowers. They look like a polka dot extravaganza, and the sun-intensified scent is unexpectedly lush. All this is Gucci's perfume, even if it's not the first with chamomile flowers, there are masterpieces like Youth-Dew by Estée Lauder, Gucci by Gucci, or my beloved Clinique's Aromatics Elixir, and so on. it'sIt's the way that wildflower blends with the other ingredients that makes this scent original and intriguing.

The perfume belongs to a new mineral and aromatic family and opens with an explosion of watery notes, where for a moment, the partnership with Kenzo Pour Homme is inevitable. I feel the same vibes in it, that underlying aroma so characteristic of the blue bottle in the shape of a bamboo cane, and I honestly can't tell which note or blend reproduces that beautiful watery accord. After a few minutes, I get a bitter almond-like puff, just a glance, followed by a herbaceous facet coming to life. I perceive the aroma of chamomile petals with light shades of petroleum and leather aspects, the same smell that comes out of a teabag when pressed between the fingers. There is no doubt that this flower so rarely used in perfumery makes itself felt, and I love it. From the very first notes, Mémoire d'une Odeur is not an intense, opaque, heavy perfume. Instead, it is just like the chamomile flower, relaxing, soothing, graceful, fresh. The initial aroma fades into the foreground but never completely disappears from the composition.

Slowly the opening retracts to make room for a floral heart. Jasmine, present here in a particular species known as Indian Coral, announces itself with nuances reminiscent of acacia honey and something that comes from orange, flowers probably but also a touch of sweet zest. The honey note is delicious, with a pleasant bitterness, and the orange remains relatively shy. As for jasmine, it can quickly smother a perfume due to its volume, but it is worked with a lot of subtlety here. You will easily guess its presence, sure, but it never goes so far as to steal its sovereignty with chamomile. It's a fancy heart, not sweet or overbearing. However, it also has delightful flaps of talc, still supported by the accord of water and a prominent dose of mineral musk that brings a familiar warmth and connects all the other olfactory elements with pure softness.

The woody trail features notes of dry cedar and creamy sandalwood. Vanilla enhances the creaminess of the latter. However, it does not stand out on my skin nor takes a gourmand vibe. The woodiness comes to calm the greedy side of the trio: honey, orange, vanilla. At this point, the scent no longer changes and is all one with the skin. The whole elixir is so well blended that none of the notes goes out of the chors.

I can't help but think that Mémoire d'une Odeur is a contemporary version of those aquatic aromas that defined perfume in the 90s, Kenzo Pour Homme, as already mentioned. I like most about this perfume because its unique blend of notes smell unlike any fragrance I've experienced; there is no Ambroxan, Iso-E Super, or trendy note in here. An excellent perfume for spring and summer, beautiful in the morning as soon as you wake up, you can wear it every day, in the office and on a date, with your most casual attire and when you are dressed to impress, but also if you go out to do a walk or jog. As for performance, well, both sillage and longevity are minor than moderate on my skin, settling close to the skin after nearly an hour. Strictly speaking, I did not expect that from an EDP concentration, the trail would remain discrete. We are talking about an intimate fragrance rather than a juice that will turn heads as you pass. Overall I like it, and a lot.

I based this review on a 100ml bottle I have owned since April 2021.

-Elysium

Now this fragrance is unique, not a crowd pleaser. People will either love or hate it. Personally, I like how Gucci is positioning itself in the designer perfume market with relatively non-mainstream fragrances.

The first spray is a herbal tea slap in the face. Then a floral chamomile comes through, which is truely pleasant. I get instant flashbacks to the happier days of summer vacation; sunny, innocent and nothing but positivity. After a while the freshness makes place for a heavier floral with a serious retro vibe. In the end I get a lovely drydown; soapy florals with jasmin.

I liked that i tried it out. It's fascinating, completely different from any scent I have ever bought or tried before. I finished my 2ml sample, so now I'm at the point to ask myself "Do I want to continue wearing it?" Well.. Yeah I do! And that stylish bottle is also a great plus. So, most likely when I run into a good deal, I'll end up buying it.

review_title: Fresh Swamp, in a good way
review_content: Aesthetic: late 19th/early 20th century impressionism paintings of garden ponds with lily pads. This is a murky yet green scent, almost aquatic to me, but not quite. I attribute that to the chamomile. The murk is probably from musk. I've only ever lived on the coastal Atlantic of the US so I think of swamps when I smell "wet + green." Minus the salt, which would make this STINK but it does not. It's subtle. There is no ocean invoked in this, the water is strictly fresh.

Found a lost and forgotten bottle (40ml) at the departement store, was on sale, and i did what i never do, blind bought it.
I love aromatics and herbal scents, and this one doesn't disappoint. But once the herbal notes fly away i'm let with nothing. I knew this juice was fleeting, but yeah i confirm it.
This is a personnal scent, except your lover, or someone who hugs you, no one will perceive it in my opinion. However this is a good evening/bed scent.
Conclusion : good experience, I don't regret the blindbuy, i wanted to try it.

review_title: A melancholy elegy for the whimsy of childhood
review_content: Herbal, dusty bittersweet, dreamlike and shivery green musk. The sorrows of strange lullabies lilted in gentle whispers, fairytales of snow-blooming trees, borne from bones. A fragile, longing, shimmering bell. A fleeting dew, a pale mist drifting low in a meadow, vanishing into an empty sky. A melancholy elegy for the whimsy of childhood. A deathbed poem at dawn.

They say to never blind buy, and I believe this fragrance helped me understand that quite well. I picked this up as I found a bottle at a very steep discount and figured it to be worth it. While it's a very well crafted scent, and one that smells decently good, it's not something I will personally wear very often. The opening is quite harsh, which I feel might be from the...

The initial spray is sour, floral, and powdery. It's strong for a total of two minutes and then fades into nothing. If you sniff really hard, the chamomile note calms down from sour to mildly honeyed. This fragrance is overall clean and powdery. It's nothing special. I don't like how it smells initially, but a bad fragrance is more exciting than a nonexistent drydown.

Opens up with a medicinal chamomile smell, not tea, more of like a cabinet with medicine and that pack of loose-leaf chamomile tea you drink only when you are sick, cause you really don't drink tea that much. Quite weird and unexpected from Gucci but quite wearable, I just don't like it on myself, I hope Odeur 53 does not smell like this...

review_title: Oh how I wish I liked it...
review_content: Mémoire d'Une Odeur has been my Achilles heel in regards to reason. I have swarmed around this fragrance like a bee to a pollen-filled flower. The bottle is so insanely captivating, but the juice always made my nose scrunch up. I was so lucky to have been gifted this beauty and finally had the chance to give it a proper go. I know I have been gone for too long yet again, but...

review_title: Too weak to be called an EDP
review_content:
I find this EDP too weak to be called a perfume. Poor sillage, projection and longevity. I could douse myself with this so called EDP before bed, to find very little of it on my body or my clothes next morning.

The top notes (chamomile and bitter almond) open a bit too synthetic for my taste. The overall scent is OK after the top notes have dissipated. It was a blind buy, seduced by the Gucci brand name. I would happily give it away if some friend or family member takes a shine for it.

this is definitely not what chamomile smells like, so if you're looking for a photorealistic smell of the flower or the tea, you won't find it here.
nonetheless, it's a pretty fragrance - clean, fresh, comforting and soft. like white linen handwashed in simple soap and rinsed in cold water with herbal essential oils. a little sweetness in the background, a touch of sandalwood to round down all the sharp aromatic edges. +50 to calming aura
definitely a skin-scent, doesn't radiate, but catching wafts of it during the day is pleasant.

Oh, Gucci Memoire, my beloved. The longevity is as fleeting and light as the scent itself (at least on me - I've never been able to keep florals on my skin). Very little projection, so it's a nice every day perfume. Reminds me of something a fairy would wear, or a foggy spring morning. Soft floral/herbal without being too sweet or girly. It's mature but not in an old-lady way. I love the scent, just wish it lasted longer.

Mémoire d'une Odeur seems to be perceived very differently when looking at today's statements.

Contra: There are mentions of glue with 3 letters that should go back in the tube, burnt plastic, moldy wood... and then treated with wood varnish.

Pro: beautiful bottle, romance, nostalgia, sensuality, chamomile-veneer-woody, very light and different.
This is also reflected in the ratings from 0 - 10.0... everything is included. I haven't experienced anything like this here for a long time.

Recently, the perfumer of this fragrance - Alberto Morillas - has often received poor ratings for his scents as soon as his name came up.

However, if you take the effort to look at his oeuvre

- 371 fragrances with an average rating of 7.3 for renowned brands like Armani, Bulgari, Carolina Herrera, YSL, and many others -

you'll find that some very well-known and successful fragrances were developed by him (sometimes in collaboration with others). Most are mainstreamers that need to generate profit through sales in the mass market. As is generally known, these come with a fixed cost framework for fragrance, bottle, packaging, and especially for marketing. It’s safer to stay on the commercially secure side, and often there’s a lack of courage for extraordinary fragrances.

And as MitParfumo Stulle aptly noted on this topic: Mr. M. is just an artist who also likes to make money - that’s not dishonorable (even artists like to eat warm!).

However, he also has some exciting fragrances, especially where he was surely given some freedom. I think of Kilian, the expensive Bulgari series, Chopard, and also my favorite from him, Opus VII/Amouage.

The latest Gucci Guilty releases for men by Alberto Morillas have softened my previously rather negative opinion. I find them bold and also successful, particularly Gucci Guilty Absolute and Gucci Guilty Cologne pour Homme.
The new fragrance - Mémoire d'une Odeur - is also part of this. Accompanied by a promotional film featuring a lot of strange people jumping around a beautifully stunning castle, making fires, and doing other odd things... the message is, of course, hard to grasp: In my opinion, it’s about an 80s/90s revival fragrance, and the first test immediately reminded me of 'Bitter Sweet Symphony' by The Verve

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1lyu1KKwC74

or the film Call Me By Your Name - Elio

This fragrance also somehow has something very life-like and vibrant about it: sad and happy, soft and hard, bitter and sweet.

The pyramid provided here seems incomplete to my nose. Mémoire d'une Odeur starts with a herb-bitter chamomile note that is quickly underlaid by honey-toned coral jasmine flowers (mourning tree), and there’s probably a bit of lavender in there too. Its lightness and clarity come from the generous use of slightly soapy musk, while the base consists of creamy sandalwood and fresh cedar wood, with an almost unsweet vanilla providing the counterpoint.

Mémoire d'une Odeur lies somewhere between Comme des Garçons Parfum, Гоша Рубчинский Gosha Rubchinskiy, and Fougère Royale Houbigant (2010)... this as a rough guideline. The fragrance is very idiosyncratic, and I can't quite put it into the right words. But I think some of the male Parfumos should know these fragrances; for the ladies, if they are not familiar with the scents, a heroic self-test is the only option since I don't (well) know (comparable) women's fragrances. Sorry!

For me, the composition of Mémoire d'une Odeur - like that of the two other mentioned Gucci fragrances - is a bold step away from the usual mainstream monotony despite the surely stringent guidelines here as well.

Longevity and sillage: 5 - 6 hours and medium
Edit: Corrected downwards, the fragrance had better H/S from the tester than from my bottle (2 test runs)

Genre: Like 'Comme des Garçons' Odeurs (play on words!)

For whom: Men and women who enjoy unusual fragrances

When: Actually always - but from 25° upwards it becomes smoother, and the longevity and sillage improve significantly!

Alternatives: None available ;-)

Addendum:
At the Fragrance Foundation, it was awarded Fragrance of the Year in the Universal Prestige category in 2020

Gucci Mémoire d’une Odeur Eau de Parfum
COTY
Firmenich
Perfumer: Alberto Morillas

https://fragrance.org/awards/

A strange summer is passing by. The pandemic and climate change have made traveling an increasingly ambivalent experience, with the ever-raised finger of grandchildren urging restraint. And damn it - they are right.

My biographical CO2 footprint is embarrassing.

Then came the water. Yes, I live in a flood zone, and I could hardly have emptied the flooded basement on my own. Thanks to the young helpers.

I cannot move on to everyday life, even though I have personally come through relatively unscathed. Relatives, friends, neighbors, and acquaintances are often more severely affected. Some who were privileged just yesterday now live in a friend's guest room. At over 70, the thought of a fresh start is not easy. And yet many - including my generation - feel the need for a break.

The car was washed away, so I won't be getting a new one at all.
I never intended to end up as one of those retirees who mistakenly think they can turn the local marketplace into a drive-in while in reverse gear.

And only in the moment of destruction do I realize that I have been blind for too long to the lush beauty of my homeland. What wonderful corners and treasures are there here?
Memories of wonderful and memorable moments of my life...

Now, this is not a seniors' forum, but a perfume forum, and the present Gucci fragrance is aptly not called Memory of the Prom, but Mémoire d'une Odeur.
It is no less capable.

It reminds me of how, as a little rascal in short pants, I roamed the woods of my homeland with my friends. Always in search of adventures or materials for dam building. The wet leaves, the soft ground, rain, moss, a snail, a earthworm, a brook gently winding down a slope, sunbeams peeking through the trees, the rust on an old metal barrel - even the inorganic felt organic in such an environment.

The nettles stung, because that is the job of a nettle, the sweater itched, and a splinter occasionally found its way into a finger. And I was bursting with life that surrounded me.
I smell more here than just a dull bagged tea; rather, I perceive the chamomiles as wildflowers at the edge of the field, along with the earth surrounding them.

This Eau de Parfum is the antithesis to the Instagram age. Not loud, colorful, and flashy.
Instead, it is herbaceous yet familiar. No synthetic gourmand trying to please everyone with sticky sweetness. And that is precisely what makes it so authentic.
Its fragrance notes represent the nuances and facets of life far more accurately than those terrible cinnamon pudding bombs. Honestly, I would hardly have expected such an anti-mainstream statement from Gucci.

By the way, Mémoire d'une Odeur features, at least for me personally, the most aesthetically pleasing bottle in my collection. A fragrance can hardly be dressed more elegantly.
I can hardly wait for the start of autumn. I want to slip into my shoes and jump in puddles. I want to hear the dirt splattered on my pants. I want to bend down and admire an ant at its diligent work for minutes on end.

All the good was so close all along.
Thank you, Señor Morillas, for reminding me of that...

On October 3rd, I boarded a truck ferry heading to the Baltic Sea to relax for a few days on the Curonian Spit. To reach the passenger deck of the massive ship, foot passengers were guided immediately after boarding through a narrow corridor that seamlessly transitioned into an apparently endless escalator. Up we went, and a slight unease set in. A few bars of "Stairway to Heaven" came to mind. Suddenly, there it was, a poster. Alone in the wide expanse. Beautiful people in soft light. Bohemia, I hear you rustling! A sign, fate, divine providence! A new Gucci fragrance - and the escalator leads me straight into the heavenly realm of the onboard shop. (It should be noted that my collection at the beginning of October still consisted of Gucci Rush and Gucci Rush - my scent since 1999.) So I quickly checked in, had a cozy beer for my husband's sake, and disappeared into the (12 square meter) onboard shop. Chic bottle. Fits those beautiful people who seem to have something Bacchanalian on their minds in the soft backlight. My insides are already reveling in seductive, soft scent spheres. I spray on the paper. Full of anticipation, I inhale the fragrance. Peuhaoioioi! I am outraged. I almost topple over backwards. What on earth is this, what is it supposed to be, and who the hell wants to smell like this? Alcohol on foot tincture with straw and moss under decayed birch. I expected a perfume that should smell like what my average nose knows and can categorize. This is definitely not "Memoire d'une odeur." I was somehow disturbed and trudged back disappointed to my husband, who secretly rejoiced at having saved a lot of money.
A month later, I am at the turquoise shop and get to choose a birthday fragrance. The saleswoman is wonderful. She scans me, knows me. The first fragrance presented is mine and is purchased. However, I am a bit disappointed as I would have liked to try more. "Oh, that reminds me of an experience with the new Gucci, I would like to test that one again." The wonderful one confidently reaches for "Ambrosia di fiori" and holds the paper under my nose. "No, this one isn't for me either, but I mean the green one, the intense one." "The green one, seriously the green one?" The turquoise lady is noticeably shaken. "Yes, I want to give it another chance. Maybe it will develop and become beautiful." "No, nothing will become beautiful anymore!" Have I mentioned how incredibly likable this saleswoman was? Nothing beats disarming honesty. So we both don't find the fragrance that great.
Third attempt, end of November. There it is again. The green anti-floral water is smiling at me, I reach for it and become daring. I spray the fragrance on my wrist. It is no longer as harsh as during our first encounter on the stormy Baltic Sea. Once the alcohol veil has faded, it takes on a sober note. It is clear. It has nothing playful about it. It doesn't want to be erotic, not feminine, not wicked. I like the chamomile, which calms me. It has something strict about it, it sets the direction while remaining clear and noble. The woods come in, giving the chamomile fullness. I perceive the musk only minimally. At the very end, I can sense the vanilla, very delicately, now only in connection with the chamomile, which is now just a fine veil.
Early December: What’s the point of being stingy? I bought the bottle. What has moved me for so long and repeatedly is meant to belong to me. I also have an explanation: Since our first encounter, I have sniffed through the entire turquoise standard range and realized that I find flowers terribly off-putting. Especially lily of the valley. Fruits are somewhat better. I have also understood that my fragrances must be at least unisex. I find many men's fragrances more wearable on me than, for example, a SI or LVEB. That a pure women's fragrance can trigger a buying impulse in me is extremely rare. I am now happy when a fragrance smells different, when it can stand out from the fruity-floral pleasantries.
And "Memoire d'une odeur" can do that all too well. It is not a girl’s fragrance. At least not for those who want to be sweet and sexy, rush to the nail salon, and stick on fake lashes.
It reminds me with its slight hay note of my horses and already evokes a sense of well-being in me for that reason alone. I spray it on my pillow before sleeping and sleep deeply and soundly. It is so light and clear that I would even wear it in the stable. I would never even think of doing that with another fragrance. And I believe my horses would like it too.
Tomorrow I will wear it to school, and I am curious to see what it will evoke there. It remains a polarizing fragrance, but it is worth giving it 7-364 chances. All fragrance conventions on "reset," and "Memoire" has the potential to create a new scent memory.

A few days ago, I entered the local beauty store because I saw this fragrance in the window...

The young saleswoman was already grinning at me, certain that I wouldn't like it...

My first reaction, "Wow, this is different... I'LL TAKE IT," caused uproarious laughter. You couldn't say it better.

The scent reminds me of the chamomile version of A Song for the Rose. Strong, herbal, floral, and somewhat woody.

The progression goes from aggressively herbal to beautifully tea-like towards the end.

Truly a very unique designer...

The longevity is good, but likely very variable depending on skin and weather.

Sillage is good, but not overwhelming. Very airy yet still dominant.

I already love it.

review_title: ...of Hay and Herbs and Nervous Children.....
review_content:
I am actually quite lazy when it comes to writing and prefer to give a short statement about a fragrance. But Memoire d‘une odeur is so wonderfully different. Just the name suggests something good.
For me, the Roman Chamomile is definitely dominant in this fragrance. It should not be confused with the scent of chamomile tea, as some have indicated here. Anyone who knows the pure essential oil of Roman Chamomile knows that chamomile tea smells completely different.
In aromatherapy, Roman Chamomile is primarily used for restless toddlers. It has a harmonizing effect on body and mind.
With the oil of Roman Chamomile, it was love at first sniff for me. I liked it from the very first try.
I often used it in the fragrance lamp for my children.

I took the test strip of Memoire d‘une Odeur home and held it under my children's noses. The test result was very positive. My son said: it smells good, like hay and herbs. Whether the judgment was so favorable because they have been exposed to the scent from a young age is hard to say....
But there really isn't much more to say about it. I feel the same way.
Green, herbal with a hint of woody powder in the base. With recognizability without being vintage-heavy in any way.

Definitely not for gourmand lovers, but certainly unisex.

Today I finally discovered Memoire, the new Gucci, which I had been eagerly awaiting.

However, the opening is somewhat sour, and I disappointedly set the beautiful bottle aside.

I'd rather go for the "floating" crane from Berdoues, which I've also had on my radar for a long time.

But already in the car, a calm yet full aroma surrounds me, emanating from my wrist.
Memoire pleasantly reminds me of itself.

This transformation is not Kafkaesque, but very accommodating.

The chamomile brings tranquility and nestles against the soft woods.
A cozy feeling arises - emphasized by the warm vanilla.

This scent reminds me of sociable yet quiet evenings in the hunting lodge, where we casually chatted over a cup of tea, and the branches of the trees gently tapped against the windows.
The stove crackled comfortably, and nature surrounded us - so close you could reach out and touch it.

Yes, that is the "Odeur" that Memoire gently reminds me of.

review_title: Zooming Past the Mainstream at 180 km/h
review_content:
How do you incorporate chamomile, hay, and herbs into a fragrance that is still pleasing? Gucci has managed it - although the scent almost defeated me at first. I couldn't really make anything of it. I didn't find it bad, but somehow it was also not a fragrance experience, neither in a positive nor in a negative sense. At least there was nothing that repelled me, unlike some other testers here. At first sniff, I imagined I smelled a strange rubber note that I associate with myrrh (are you sure there's none in there?!) and that wasn't a turn-on, but it did make me curious. So I wore it for a day and that was... okay. Nothing more.

The next test went completely differently - the scent is simply beautiful. Just beautiful. Fresh, clean, calming, unusual, and with a high recognition value while still being pleasing. Yes, "pleasing" is a nasty word. No one wants to smell "pleasing," I just mean: This fragrance, despite its very specific aura, doesn't hurt anyone and delights all those who appreciate it. I've found that among the people who actively test it, opinions are usually very divided, but among those who perceive the scent on others - for example, on me - the unanimous opinion is that Memoire d’une Odeur is very pleasant and far from being generic. What more could you want? For me, this is a perfume that is better not "tested," but simply worn, without expecting anything (you know how some perfumes fail when you "sniff closely," but are great when they waft into your nose by chance?).

For me, Memoire d’une Odeur is a successful blend of retro and modern, of a scent that doesn't want to be one and a perfume that has everything that makes a truly good perfume. Although it is completely clear: This scent cannot please anyone who isn't fond of chamomile. The most beautiful woods and the finest musk cannot overshadow that, and even the vanilla won't save it (by the way: chamomile and vanilla? I never thought that would work!).

What else is there to say? In my opinion, this is not a unisex scent, but suits the ladies better (really, Harry Styles as a face for this?!). The sillage is not overwhelming, but noticeable, and the longevity is good, though not outstanding. A "hippie scent," as the advertising wants us to believe? Nope, but similarly free-spirited, quirky, and connected to nature.

A warm embrace from the past. That's how I would describe it best. Growing up in a village with horse domes and wildflower meadows, I can somewhat relate to the advertising and the name...
But one thing at a time. The fragrance was released in 2019, and I wanted to test it immediately. The bottle is beautifully vintage, and the name sounded promising. I went to the perfume store. Sprayed it on my wrist and "Bah!". Here I can agree with my predecessors that the initial impression smells rather medicinal. As often happens, we simply don't give things the time to develop when the first impression is already bad. Chamomile is also very special and unusual in the mainstream fragrance segment. You also associate chamomile more with childhood, when you were sick and had to choke down the tea...
Two years later, during the pandemic, I moved back from the big city to my roots, went for a walk, and once again noticed the herbal scents that I loved as a child. Memories came flooding back, and as luck would have it, I saw Gucci Memoire d'une Odeur at Müller and tested it again. Love, sentimentality, and memories. I think the current mental state and circumstances play a role in how one initially perceives a fragrance. Today, I discover the depth of the scent. Somehow it makes sense today.
The composition starts with spicy-floral chamomile. Warm, vibrant. Minutes later, woody notes weave in. Sandalwood, and later a cedar note. The chamomile is a throbbing heart from top to base. Wrapped in fine woods, until in the end, the warm vanilla transforms the chamomile into a skin-friendly scent.
It smells to me like the bottle looks - vintage. It is unisex without a doubt, but I see people in their mid-20s and older wearing this fragrance. It seems mature, unpretentious, thoughtful, and personal. Personal in the sense of: I am completely myself and don't want to be in the spotlight. People notice me, respect me, but everyone realizes that my presence is enough without many words.
The sillage is moderate (spring 12-20°C). At work, I was sniffed out. Opinions are divided, but no one found it unpleasant.
This fragrance is worn for oneself and not for others. I find it subtle and somehow comforting in the time of the pandemic, where we often live in isolation...
I am a big fan of the sprayer, and this one gives a great and even mist!
In summary: Give this fragrance a chance. Try it out from time to time, preferably in different seasons.
I got a good deal on Notino, check it out.
Best regards.

Mémoire d’une Odeur is like flipping through an old photo album.
Images of a Sunday walk in a spa park or castle garden - it smells herb-floral, very fresh. The flowers are planted and cared for with great precision, a beautiful weeping willow by a pond. Everyone is wearing their "good" Sunday clothes, the little girl with knee socks... an ice cream cone in her hand. She stands in a trellis and daydreams. The Sunday dress is a bit uncomfortable. Older ladies are feeding ducks.

Then comes chamomile tea in kindergarten. Comforting, protective, a break.
And an old pharmacy after a visit to the pediatrician. The light gently refracts in the old glass bottles on the shelves, their wooden scent forming a sweet-warm contrast to the medicinal. Trust.

The herbaceous opening of Mémoire d’une Odeur surprises me greatly... it scratches... and is at the same time as retro as those faded photos from the zeitgeist books of my hometown... Like a Super-8 film from childhood... that’s how it smells... The theme is extremely well captured... it awakens many memories, still images, film sequences. At some point, the chamomile comes - but not sweet, rather "pharmaceutical"...
The impression of a Polaroid-distorted 70s atmosphere pushes itself forward and sends images. Overexposed. But beautiful.

In between, I also get the association that this is how a "good" bar of soap might smell in the modest quarters of a servant in Downton Abbey. Not opulent, rather modest. Actually, such a soap doesn’t quite fit me - but it smells so cozy-arrived. Maybe for the laundry drawer?
-------------------------------
Mémoire d‘une Odeur is truly a scent far removed from the "mainstream." At least, when one associates terms like "crowd-pleasing" or "performance" with perfumes. In fact, it is much more complex than the fragrance description suggests. The herbaceous opening seems to emanate from the weeping willow - very fresh, floral-herbaceous and initially very unsweet. The chamomile reveals itself to me only later, but when it does, it is very clear, albeit gently and thoughtfully. One should therefore be fundamentally fond of this note. I found this phase in the scent's progression to be very pleasant, calming, almost comforting. With the woods, the scent then becomes very intimate and a "memory of a scent." I join the other reviews that describe the fragrance as quiet yet profound.
It can be suitable for everyday wear - perhaps as a comforter in these stressful times - but I believe it would distract me due to the memories it evokes... clearly it is also unisex, but in my opinion, it leans more towards the feminine.
I just looked at the photos from the advertising campaign because I didn’t know who Harry Styles is, and I was quite surprised. Dancing with cheerful, flawless millennials in "boho" style in front of a castle ruin, I would not have associated the scent with that at all...
I find the bottle very fitting, nostalgic - really very, very beautiful!

Regarding longevity: not perceivable on the skin the next morning, unfortunately a chamomile echo in hairspray on the test strip.

(Addendum: no joke. The test strip just fell into my coffee cup... doesn’t smell bad at all... but unfortunately, the hairspray note also comes through here).

For me, Mémoire d’une Odeur is a beautiful time-travel scent that reminds me of Ninfeo Mio by Goutal from the composition (I’ll get to that another time), and I would tend to place it in spring and late summer. Whether I will get it, I’m not sure yet, as both the very herbaceous opening and the hairspray touch at the end do not immediately harmonize with my skin chemistry. But I will definitely continue to test it.
----------------------------------
With heartfelt thanks to Sweetyy for the decant.

There it stood, in the men's section, between the Sauvages and Codes of this world. I had expected the new Gucci to be more in the women's category, despite its unisex character, but it doesn't really matter where I find it. The main thing is that I could finally smell it, as chamomile scents are rare. And let's just say: now I know (again) why...

I believe that in my Müller, it will hardly find any friends among men. Too specific, too strange, too androgynous, too tea-like it seems at first. It doesn't fit between "Invictus" and "Cool Water." And yet, it is one of the cleverest and boldest new releases of the fragrance year. It starts with a shimmering-synthetic chamomile. This creates confusion somewhere between grandma and chemistry lab. But it invites you to sniff and awakens my curiosity. Not that I particularly like it, but it was a new scent experience somewhere between Hermes and Bulgari. And new olfactory experiences are something even a seasoned veteran enjoys (also/especially?). And in the new (designer) releases at the end of the 2010s, deviations from norms and trends must also be sought with a magnifying glass and thus welcomed.

This "memory of a scent" transitions from the aggressive chamomile to herbal flowers, all underpinned by a honeyed musk, more bitter and special than sweet. Very anti-mass taste, very classic and refined. A bit dusty and far too quickly gone, but the underlying idea is daring and great. But when should one wear it? Probably either all the time or never. A very eccentric interpretation of chamomile. Romance turned up to 11. And yet, it’s over the hill in no time. Strange. Confusing. Disturbingly calming. Takes some getting used to. Inaccessible. Thick eggs with a quiet flap. Do you have to be a chamomile fan for this? Or can those who are not appreciate this quirky interpretation?! Morillas on a confrontational course. Not natural. If you look closely, but somehow timeless and certainly not boring. You just have to concentrate and hurry, because it quickly becomes, fittingly, just a memory...

Bottle: elegant, classic, good in hand
Sillage: quiet, quite quiet. Luckily, because as I said, it irritates some. I chamomile, I do not chill.
Longevity: 5 hours after applying it, hardly a trace remains

Conclusion: far from the idea that tea pleases everyone and never causes offense... this piercing, polarizing chamomile bomb can definitely come across as stubborn and repulsive to some. Others will fall in love. I have not yet decided, seeing both pros and cons. Not one for the top or flop year lists, but a genuine, timeless divider that shows courage and is worth exploring further. Better than a slick, please-everyone type. Morillas unleashed.

No, I certainly won't write a factual treatise.

No dissecting tables to uncover secrets, rather a little rendezvous, an encounter between two unexpected ones.
Already impressed by Bloom and lured by this wonderfully green bottle,
I tried the new fragrance from Gucci shortly after its release.
It was pure disappointment.
A delicate nothing that led me, in my disbelief, to spray a few decent bursts on skin and clothing. In the hope that, far from dominant foreign scents, its soul would reveal itself, Mémoire remained silent, as if refusing me conversation.
Consequently, I refrained from purchasing it, but something about this perfume had triggered a desire in me to seek its presence again and again.
Today I believe I know that it was the initial chamomile. As a cushion-forming perennial, I had planted it years ago between old natural stone slabs, and typical for herbs, it released a wonderfully aromatic scent with the slightest touch. A bit like in the old pharmacies with their dark wooden counters and stone mortars, where many healing substances were ground.

Fate gifted me with a few samples, and I decided to give Mémoire the undivided time and attention necessary to get to know each other.
This new way of encountering allowed me to not truly perceive the composition in its details, but to gradually understand it as a whole construct.
Slowly, a deeper meaning emerged, even if with secrets still unrevealed.

This perfume is truly not for the impatient, not a party pleaser, not neat and tidy for the office every day, not a fresh kick on hot days.
This scent demands an appointment, long walks with the fascinating unknown, and not measuring time with the clock.

Like a soul, it will never be fully grasped.
How wonderful.

Wow, what a successful new fragrance! The house of Gucci continues its unconventional path and presents us with an unusual mild-spicy scent that pleasantly stands out from the overly sweet gourmand mainstream of today. The mild chamomile note is at the forefront throughout the entire fragrance journey and becomes spicier in the base with musk and woods. Not for everyone’s nose, but "Memoire d'une odeur" will surely find its admirers. Has classic and vintage potential.

What a beautiful scent! I admit that I was initially attracted by the bottle - I had almost forgotten that I usually get along quite well with Gucci fragrances.

I had the Mémoire d'une Odeur in a package with several samples and, to be honest, I feared it might be too funky grassy based on the reviews. Good in theory, but probably not for me. Not at all. I first sprayed it on paper, was immediately thrilled, and then it was the first one I applied to my skin.

A truly unusual fragrance. A very very herbal-metallic opening, then woods, green, and of course chamomile. Contrary to many other opinions, I find the chamomile to be very subtle. After 10 minutes, a certain floral herbal+pudry sweetness develops, which later transitions into a chamomile-woody-grassy-vanilla scent. But everything is incredibly transparent and light. For me: Beautiful, ethereal, and natural. Picking chamomile bouquets that wither immediately, but your fingers still smell of them all evening. Late summer meadows with a low sun, lightness and carefreeness, ripe fields standing so splendidly that they already announce thunderstorms and a change in temperature... Perhaps it takes certain memories to appreciate the scent. And yet, yes, this is how I want to smell! The name is programmatic, it evokes memories and transports me to a time when I was happy.

However, it is really, really subtle. I can imagine two types of opponents for this fragrance. Those who simply cannot relate to the scent profile and those who like it but find it too weak. I also have to keep smelling my wrist to perceive it and have thought to myself that it could be more intense... But - then it wouldn't have the same character.
So definitely not a scent that others immediately notice when you enter a room; it stays with you. An intimate fragrance. Longevity is there, but it quickly transitions into a body scent where it is almost hardly perceptible. I hardly believe it is a fragrance that one gets complimented on; one is rather perceived as pleasantly scented, but not perfumed.

For me, someone who does not care much for expansive fragrances with heavy sillage and who prefers green-grassy-herb-floral-powdery scents, I am already a big advocate of this fragrance. Very unique and quirky, definitely not to everyone's taste. Despite the pretty and decorative bottle, definitely do not order blind; I believe you either love or hate the Mémoire d'une Odeur. For me, however, it is almost a poetic fragrance.

review_title: It starts with a cup of chamomile tea with honey.
review_content:
Finally, I made it to our provincial capital Münster today. There is not only one of the turquoise branches there. I also wanted to test this highly debated little fragrance.

So I headed straight for the Gucci shelf. The beautiful packaging was already smiling at me. This lovely shade of green with the golden stars looks very vintage. It feels like the 50s. But the tester was missing. The very nice saleswoman seemed to have not only professional competence but also quickly found the object of desire again. A beautiful classic bottle that also reminds more of the 50s than the hippie era.

Then I sprayed it on the test strip and on my skin. The fragrance opens with a cup of lukewarm chamomile tea with honey. I remember that scent from my childhood. The home remedy for a bad cold. The top note lasts about half an hour. Then the heart note appears and strongly reminds me of damp new paper. I believe that Mr. Morillas has borrowed a bit from Mr. Frédéric Malle and the "Une Fleur de Cassie" that was released there. In this high-end fragrance, you also find a bit of that mustiness, which then dissolves into deep melancholy. For the base note, Mr. Morillas referenced another creation from the Malle edition, namely "Geranium pour Monsieur." Both base notes are strikingly similar.

The fragrance is something different. I'm already pleased about that. The longevity of the base is quite good. It lasts over 6 hours on me. The sillage, however, is terrible. The scent stays very close to the skin.

Conclusion! For a label like Gucci, which has often been noted for mediocre mainstream products lately, this fragrance composition is very daring. You can see it in the very controversial discussions and the very different comments and statements. But finally, something is being dared again. Of course, one can also stumble in the process, but just the same synthetic fragrance goo or the overly sweet slightly floral generic scent have been enough to annoy me in recent years. Let’s commend those responsible at Gucci for perhaps not so easy decision to launch this fragrance. It doesn't happen so often in the perfume market anymore. In the end, the product is supposed to make money. The great times of fashion designers selling us a luxurious dream are unfortunately over.

To name a perfume "Mémoire"/"Memory" is actually quite presumptuous. (Scent) memories are not predetermined; they arise organically in each individual life, and certainly not according to plan. "Mémoire d'une Odeur" also does not coincidentally smell like anything concrete that I personally associate with special moments. But still. "Memory" captures it quite accurately....

Heart: Come, let's go on a trip // Head: Oh yes, gladly (excited) where to? // Heart: To a time long past. You surely remember, it smelled so beautiful everywhere. So fresh, so green and cozy. // Head: Yes, wait... I think I remember... I have a memory of a scent. I see green meadows, snow-covered mountains, blooming fields of chamomile, fresh hay, and oh the beautiful trees. The wood, it caresses my nose. // "Come," said the heart to the head, "let yourself go, switch off and dream a little..."

That was roughly the communication in my inner self when I sprayed this fragrance. It is so completely different from the candy scents of today. Therefore, it also leads to a "uurgh, what is that" upon first spray. But, you have to take your time with this scent. It is advisable to read the ingredients first and then spray. Sniff without expectation.

The bottle: Super. Absolutely in theme with the scent. Vintage par excellence. No retro gimmicks, like "this is how it used to be." No! It is like it used to be.

The scent: Wonderful harmony of chamomile, woods, and meadows. Featherlight. A bit of vanilla brings the harmony. A sunny day on a freshly mown mountain meadow in the Dolomites. Absolutely unisex.

Sillage: Initially quite strong, also bitter, but it weakens relatively quickly. After about 45 minutes, it develops into a skin-close scent without fading. It distributes a pleasant hint to its surroundings with every movement.

Longevity: I would say it could be a bit longer. If you prefer it more intense, the tendency is to re-spray after about 1 hour. The sprayer mists the perfume pleasantly fine, so reapplying is not an overwhelming issue.

Conclusion: A candidate for purchase. Stands out from the crowd. Individual. A successful year-round fragrance. Yes, it is the memory of a scent that everyone carries within themselves.

I liked the packaging of Memoire d'une Odeur: a rich warm green with golden stars. The pink interior matches perfectly. I find it very feminine but not unisex. The light green glass bottle looks classic and resembles an antique column.
The scent is delicate, enchantingly light. Primarily chamomile. The vanilla adds a slightly sweet touch to the chamomile. A harmonious fragrance combination. The flower head of the Roman chamomile is innocent white. The flower interior is yellow-green and resembles the daisy. A playful flower, just like the scent. Cedarwood mixes with sandalwood and noble woods. Everything is just very light and weightless. The chamomile-vanilla blend is always in the foreground. The mourning tree, a type of cypress, grows in mild southern climates. Does it provide the spice?
In my opinion, Memoire d'une Odeur does not have sillage. I can smell it at most for 3 hours on my wrist. A wonderful spring-summer fragrance that seemingly only I perceive on myself.

Herb and heavy, the chamomile blossoms open up. The unfurled jasmine and chamomile flowers are ethereal and move more lightly, but never lose their grip thanks to the dry woods in the base. There is a touch of sensuality in the scent due to the musk.
A wonderful cool, herbaceous floral fragrance that touches me deeply in the soul and embodies both a beautiful melancholy and a restrained joy at the same time. It is always a lovely surprise when you awaken from a dream and still perceive this scent upon waking.

It is probably my favorite perfume, at least my most personal perfume, which I wear rather rarely because I don't quite feel ready for it yet. Many associate memories from the past with the fragrance, which the name is also meant to imply, but for me, it represents the future. In the perfume, I recognize the person I would like to be, the person I could be, but am not yet, which is why I don't always feel quite ready to wear it more often, as I have not yet lived up to my own expectations. At the moment, the perfume is also an expression of my emotional vulnerability, just as this review fundamentally shows the tenderness of a person.
So I look forward to the day when I can do justice to the scent as a person and wear it more freely.

In the end, hopefully, all that remains to say is Days of Future Passed.

review_title: The Horse Girl and the Diaper Cream
review_content:
A quick note: I am not a typical horse girl (anymore). My time of riding is long gone. Sometimes I look back with a tear in my eye, but my sporting interests have changed, and that’s okay.

Nevertheless, I can still vividly remember the beautiful summer evenings I spent at the stable. After a long ride, cleaning the horse and bringing it to the pasture. To finish off, sitting on a hay bale with my best friend, watching the sunset and chatting about everyday life. The scent of dry grass mixed with the smell of hay & straw in my nose and the warm evening sun on my skin.

Once home, I would first rinse off the horse smell in the shower and quickly apply cream - with diaper cream. I love the scent of baby products. Shampoo, bath foam, body cream - all found in my bathroom.

But now to Mémoire d'une Odeur:
Just like my described typical day at the stable, I perceive this fragrance - in the same progression.
It starts off hay-like/strawy through the chamomile, but after a short time, it develops into a powdery direction. The musk makes it clean and cozy. It smells exactly like diaper cream to me. All of this happens on my skin within two hours. Unfortunately, I can hardly perceive it afterwards, which sadly does not make it a candidate for purchase for me.

Nevertheless, it serves as a small reminder of the beautiful summer evenings at the stable, and when I want to be reminded of it again, I will rummage through my drawer for the little sample, spray it on, and indulge in memories.

Sometimes you smell a perfume and immediately fall in love with the scent. Mémoire d’une Odeur, however, was love at second sight. At first, I couldn't connect with it, but now I can't imagine my life without it. When I first smelled this fragrance, I wasn't really convinced. The chamomile instantly took me back to the cold season of my childhood, when I lay sick in bed...

review_title: Melancholy and Joy are Probably Sisters (Erich Kästner)
review_content:
I spray the fragrance for the first time just before going to bed. What I perceive is slightly medicinal, almost biting. But this only lasts a few moments and then there it is - the chamomile. I see in my mind's eye hot summer days when my sister and I played on the lawn behind our house as children. Not a lush green lawn, as the heat has turned it dusty yellow. There are no flowers, just these chamomiles without petals that smell in the sun like the tea that Mom always brews when we are sick. A bit like baby bath additive too. And Mémoire d'une Odeur smells exactly like that - soft and warm, like a hug from Mom or Grandma. I consciously do not mention Dad or Grandpa, as the scent radiates something very feminine and comforting for me. Just like the mother who holds you in her arms when you have fallen and strokes your hair. If I had to name a fragrance that stands for "security," it would undoubtedly be this one.

But even the coziest hug eventually comes to an end, and this happens quite quickly here. I perceive Mémoire d'une Odeur on my skin for about two hours; it lasts a bit longer on clothing. But that doesn’t bother me, quite the opposite: a "fantastic longevity" or "monster sillage" would not suit this fragrance. It is quiet and delicate and doesn’t want to be anything else. The scent progression is very linear (though I have no idea how a weeping tree smells - does anyone know...?). I sense a minimal hint of musk more than I actually perceive it. Mémoire d'une Odeur is not a fragrance I will wear in everyday life. Not because I don’t like it. It makes me happy, almost brings me to tears at the same time. Because it was so beautiful back then. Because it will never be like that again. The memory - that remains.

I find it difficult to find the right words here. Simply because this fragrance is so beautiful: It radiates calm, warmth, and security. Nothing that hits hard or has a killer sillage/projection. But I don't want that at all with this scent. I find it too "intimate" to share it with others. I want to wear it for myself. Wear it when the soul needs a little break... Whether from pain, stress, sorrow... Or even from too much euphoria. This fragrance brings me back to myself, calms me, comforts me, but also uplifts me. I've never experienced anything comparable with a fragrance before.

Normally, I don't have high expectations when it comes to duty-free shops. One could also say it's a snobbish attitude. However, since the current Guccis all have such pretty packaging and I'm not only snobbish but also superficial *gg*, I decided to give them a try. The result pleasantly surprised me. Various Blooms turned out to be delightful, and Mémoire d'une Odeur was...

I immediately noticed the stylish retro bottle, and the scent itself is said to be something special as well. It is not feminine or fruity-floral, but calm, sleepy, and green - sounds lovely!

When freshly applied, the top note reminds me a bit of a Russian children's cream with chamomile and fresh hay. I enjoy this herbal-dry aroma because it reminds me of the fields near our former house in late summer.
Unfortunately, after about ten minutes, there is not much chamomile left; instead, a bitter woodiness takes over and does not feel warm and spicy. I suspect the Prijat ("mourning tree") is to blame.
The scent has now become much more of a bland... Well, muffin, and I feel like I am wearing an old piece of clothing that has finally seen the light of day after sitting in the closet for a long time. What a shame.

Perhaps it is because I am sweating a lot in this weather, and the scent cannot unfold much potential on such damp skin, but the fabulous 8+ ratings here almost shock me.

review_title: Unfortunately, really just the memory of a scent
review_content:
I was mainly captivated by the top note of this perfume, as it really excited me and I was a bit careless. I still like the scent; it's actually quite a nice fragrance. With one huge drawback: as soon as you've had it on your skin for a few minutes, you feel like you only imagined having applied it. If you then bring your nose to the spot where you sprayed it, you can perceive it easily and it's not that weak. But the nose should really touch the skin. It creates a whole new dimension and definition of the term "close to the skin."
However, I must make one significant concession: the scent lives up to its name; it's just the memory of a scent.
Still, I'm not selling or giving away the bottle just yet - I think it looks great on the shelf, it really does look fantastic.

The first time I smelled the fragrance was after I bought a new mascara and a sample ended up in my bag.

At home - it was a pleasantly warm early summer day and I was out cycling - a few spritzes landed on my wrist.

I was quite astonished, as I had never smelled anything like this in a perfume before.
I like chamomile.
The yellow-white spots on green meadows lift my spirits.
I drink it as tea when I want to feel secure.

The musk is very gentle and provides a soft bed for the chamomile.

And then the cedarwood comes in and embraces it all.

I purchased the beautiful flacon a few weeks later.

Its greatest use so far has been on a hot summer day in Venice, starting in the morning on the Vaporetto on the Canal Grande and ending in a fine little ristorante at the far end of Cannaregio. I wore a light silk dress that day, and memoire carried me through the day and the heat with graceful calm, with a refreshment in the early afternoon, in this wonderful city.

Give the fragrance a chance on the skin so it can develop. It needs a bit of air and warmth.

Chamomile bath, chamomile tea, chamomile drops,… chamomile, chamomile, chamomile, Roman chamomile! That’s what I expected, but it wasn’t my first impression. Instead, I have the scent of hay in my nose, damp-warm and steaming. A rather peculiar start, but somehow appealing. I almost want to say that the chamomile isn’t present at all, and suddenly, a few moments...

This beautiful memory scent makes me sad.....

But let's start from the beginning.
I tested it in the perfume shop and gave it some time. It needs that. It has to "settle." The scent is simply different. After half an hour, I was sure I absolutely had to have it. I quickly dashed back to the perfume shop, sprayed it on again, and enchanted as I was, immediately packed the largest size. No one has ever captivated me like that. Wonderfully beautiful.
It actually starts with a mild chamomile, then becomes cozy woody, vanilla, just so homey and comforting. I am completely blown away.
That’s about it for the scent progression. But I don’t find that bad at all. I love this feel-good factor it brings. It really touched me, as KVolteer mentioned in the comment before me.

BUT: it doesn’t last. It’s gone again immediately. Occasionally a hint comes by and lets me take a deep breath and dream. But that’s too little for me. I want to smell LIKE THIS. But for real. ;) I am deeply "in love." Why is it so short-lived? That’s so, so sad.

review_title: From Afar, Closeness Beckons!! - or is it the other way around??
review_content:
I don't know if I can fully trust my nose with this mysterious scent. Because - it presents me with quite a few puzzles. This happens to me extremely rarely; I can't quite remember when and with which perfume this "phenomenon" has occurred before.
With these "memories of a pleasant scent," I am dealing on one hand with a "quiet presence," but on the other with a "deeply engaging" odor.
At times, it powerfully seeks the proximity of my nose, while at other times, it seems to wave goodbye from afar. When it comes closer again, it is not exactly as before; similar, yes, but with different accents. This interplay lasts for several hours.
It has something of an herb meadow in early autumn, also something subtly "medicinal," which probably stems from the quite prominent "Roman Chamomile."
Deeper within, one can perceive forest-like chords that seem quite woody, but also remind one of freshly fallen, damp leaves. One term that comes to mind is slightly yellowed old books that smell faintly of "lignin." In a library whose large windows overlook a somewhat overgrown garden.
Herb-sweet - with a tendency towards bitter - the secret cannot be fully unraveled. And it doesn't have to be. Yet it keeps prompting me to sniff again, leaving a little question mark behind. Magical? -- But of course!!

Many reviewers describe a feeling of security that they associate with this fragrance. I can only agree!
It captured my heart the moment I was finally able to smell it for the first time. My first and so far only blind buy. I have not regretted it. So what do I perceive when I wear it... First, an almost lemony note that I search for in the fragrance pyramid in vain, but it is there, followed by the scent of freshly cut grass that has been lying in the summer sun for a while... Then there is the chamomile, not at all bitter as initially suspected, but warm and sweet. I am reminded of a hug from my grandmother, who never wore perfume, who simply smelled clean and of plain chamomile hand cream. It is a small trip back to long-gone childhood days...
Certainly not a scent that impresses the opposite sex, but I believe that is not its intention. I am still relatively at the beginning of my fragrance journey, and one reason I started it was that I was looking for scents that would put me in certain moods... Just six months ago, I owned only one perfume, and I hardly ever wore it. Then I began to remember which fragrances I liked and owned in the past - 20 years ago. Some were still available, so I repurchased them. Pleasures by Estee Lauder, ardenbeauty by Elizabeth Arden, and L'eau d'issey by Issey Miyake. Now I continue to see what encounters me and enchants me, testing through decants and discovering a whole new world... Memoir d'une Odeur is a memory, as the name suggests, that is very precious to me.

review_title: Like a Novel, Patience is Rewarded
review_content:
For a long, long time, I circled around this fragrance. The bottle is so beautiful, yet the many negative voices about the disturbing chamomile made me hesitate. Then I managed to get a miniature, and patiently I waited, and both for me and my partner, the controversial scent struck immediately - so the bottle was allowed to move in!

The opening is green, herbal, yes, but in a very interesting way that I surprisingly do not find disturbing. This may be due to the vanilla, which adds a warmth that makes me want to be patient. I don’t have to wait long until the chamomile is hardly noticeable - the musk with the wood-vanilla mix surrounds me like a walk on a mild spring/summer evening. A certain creaminess makes me think of high-quality (sun) cream (never, ever forget SPF!), which even brings a hint of vacation feelings. But not in a sentimental wanderlust sense, rather: I have done my day's work and enjoy the season!

A subtle fragrance that can create memories as a special feature, while also elegantly highlighting everyday life to cradle in memories that could have been sketched from novels: It takes time to fully absorb this scent!

When I wear this fragrance, I think of all the hot summers in my homeland. My mother would lay dried chamomile flowers on the porch. Whenever it was siesta time and a breeze blew, I would wrinkle my nose because it reminded me of past colds. And now? When I smell the chamomile, I see white bed sheets fluttering in the wind, the golden fields outside our village, the swing on which I carefree swayed back and forth. Now I feel secure, grounded, at home with this aroma.

I appreciate that Mémoire d'une Odeur has neither incredible longevity nor sillage. Because this fragrance, this memory, is meant to be just for me.

Hello everyone :)

I was totally hyped about this perfume, I read from many that it was something special, especially I was keen on the bottle (I am also a packaging collector), but as the saying goes, you smell with your nose and not with your eyes.

Today I was at Karstadt and sniffed this scent both on the test strip and on my skin (with the Absolu it was criticized that I should test things on my skin in the future, so I did :) ) ... At first, it smells very citrusy to me, which I found very pleasant, but in the dry down, it smells quite musty, I can't quite describe which spice that should be, but musty indeed, so my pure joy for this perfume was quickly dampened and I am now considering switching to another one, although the prices are quite steep.

40ML 67 €
60ML 82 € (could also be 80)
100ML 114 € (uhm yeah ^^)

The bottle is a true feast for the eyes, resembling an ancient Roman column with a gold-colored cap and a turquoise blue fragrance liquid, featuring a very elegant inscription and a golden border, a real eye-catcher, but as mentioned above, you pay for the scent and not for the bottle.

I hope I could help you a bit with your purchasing decision, have a nice weekend :)

I have heard a lot about this fragrance composition, mostly very positive... I got it for myself without testing it beforehand and was surprised. A quiet scent that lingers in my hair and accompanies me throughout the day. Yes, it is quiet. Yes, it is not a scent for going out... very introverted, exactly what I wished for during my time working from home. It calms me,...

No, because I am definitely not pregnant. Then it can only be Mémoire d'une Odeur!!!

I recently wrote a statement about how good it smells on my husband. I couldn't describe it, because none of the listed notes stood out. He just smelled great with it. I also have the feeling that unisex fragrances with a slightly rugged touch simply suit him better and last longer, because his skin just absorbs every scent immediately ;)

Recently, my package from Flaconi arrived. And what was included as a sample? Yes, this fragrance. I considered giving it to my boyfriend, as I didn't want to smell it on myself (yes, the comments are not the best). But I was brave and sprayed it on my wrist.

Alberto, what is this????

I mean, yes, the scent is unusual, I have to give it that. I think that's good. But sorry, I felt sick right away! And I am actually not sensitive (Is that how you spell it? haha).

I close my eyes and imagine someone holding an old, already cold chamomile tea bag under my nose. I'm not a fan of chamomile, but now and then I drink chamomile tea. There are worse smells, like caraway (ugh), but this really exceeds everything. This is not a pleasant chamomile, really not..

Furthermore, there are woody notes present, which I don't really pick up. It just "smells" musty, old, and really - as already mentioned here - slightly like rubber. *shudder*.

Positive: It doesn't really last long. (for me, however, too long) After an hour, it was gone, thank God.
No trace of vanilla and sandalwood, it just remains musty.

I have removed the good rating I gave it. Because now I have tested it. One gets the sample, because I want to get rid of it as quickly as possible!!

I have to admit that I really struggled with the choice of perfume for my first review. Should I pick a scent that everyone loves? Or something more well-known? In the end, I chose one that I felt I needed to protect. Just like it is there for me.
I watched some YouTubers who had extremely controversial opinions about Mémoire d'une Odeur. I just had to test this "Chamomile Hammer."
I ordered the 7.4 ml with this rollerball applicator - no big loss if I don't like it after all.
I found the small green sliding cardboard box decorated with stars to be quite charmingly romantic.
About the scent:
You immediately smell the chamomile, very herbal, almost like those chamomile steam baths I was put in as a child whenever I was sick. There's also a bit of country road with hay bales in there. At first, I didn't like the scent at all... too harsh, too green... just not my thing. I also have to say that I'm not a fan of chamomile tea; the association with being sick is just too present. But I learned from a YouTuber that the best scents need time to develop. So I kept my arm away from my nose for a couple of hours. I still perceive the chamomile cloud around me, but it becomes softer, warmer, creamier... when I finally dared to take a sniff, there it was - vanilla! I love vanilla scents. Especially green, herbal vanilla. It shouldn't be too sweet. I think that's what makes the scent so unisex, that it doesn't become overly sweet.
When my husband came home, he immediately said: "Oh, you smell really nice." I then reapplied it fresh to show him the top note. He couldn't believe it was the same scent. He even wrinkled his nose.
By now, I even love the opening, and how could it be otherwise - the 100 ml bottle (this beautiful turquoise vintage bottle with the golden cap) adorns my shelf.
I want to protect this scent, by which I mean I want to speak a good word for it, because I often hear how terrible it smells, while I find it so wonderful, comforting, and embracing. For a designer scent, it's very bold and special, but it has opened a big door for me on my journey into the niche world. I no longer let top notes blind me.
I wore it in spring and summer - you can't really overdo it. However, I can't say anything yet about its suitability for wool sweaters.

review_title: The Needle in the Haystack Found
review_content:
I first smelled this fragrance in 2019 on a person I find very fascinating. She works in the arts and has a very special aesthetic. At that time, I didn’t have the courage to approach her to ask about the scent.
The scent lingered in my nose for quite a while.

About a year later, I was in a perfume shop looking for another fragrance. That’s when I noticed the beautiful green bottle. It seemed to me like it had been magically transported from the 70s to the shelf.

When a spray landed on my wrist, I almost flipped out: IT IS THE FRAGRANCE.

I am delighted every time I use it and associate it with a cozy, high-quality, warm feeling.

The translation "Memory of a Fragrance" fits sooooo well in this case :)

After what felt like the 5th time testing, I just couldn't warm up to this scent! :( I repeatedly tested it in the perfumery, but my nose just couldn't get along with this fragrance! Again, you can tell it's either a hate or, as some might say, a big love scent... For me, definitely a hate! I have to give this fragrance some credit; it is definitely something special but also new, something I haven't smelled anywhere else until now! Anyway, every time I sprayed the scent on the test strip, I got a strange kind of goosebumps... Not because it blew me away!

Upon spraying, I could smell a very sharp + penetrating pistachio note... (Am I the only one who could smell pistachios?) ... shortly after, the chamomile became very noticeable... But I must admit, I'm not a big fan of this note. The chamomile note is very, very bitter on my skin but also extremely piercing :((( Musk gave me the final blow! It wasn't that fresh + pleasant musk, but rather a very unpleasant, artificial, and overly powdery musk note... The woody notes came through occasionally during the scent development; they were very subtle, which I personally found quite disappointing! Since I really like beautiful and noble woody notes in fragrances. The only note I couldn't smell at all was unfortunately the vanilla... It stayed in the background :(

Many are probably thinking that I'm condemning this perfume... No, I'm definitely not! I just didn't like this perfume; it's not really a fragrance direction I prefer! But still, I wanted to give the scent a chance! Despite testing it multiple times, I just didn't like this fragrance!

review_title: Poetry for the End of the Year or Papillon
review_content:
Poetry for the End of the Year or Papillon

A butterfly lands on my hand.
I want to catch it,
but it flies away!

Yes, autumn is progressing and soon winter will arrive again. It still buzzes sporadically in the garden and now and then I even see a butterfly flutter by.

A subtly bitter chamomile starts immediately, then it is enveloped by delicate green woods. What does a weeping tree smell like? I don't know. Probably very inconspicuous. But it beautifully connects with the chamomile. Then a hint of musk comes in, making the chamomile softer - almost creamy.

I am still waiting for the dry-down. It is slowly becoming more and more delicate. Just a light breeze of transparent little wings. The wood is only barely perceptible and the vanilla is very hidden as well. I continue to sniff at my hand and catch a remnant of the sandalwood-vanilla finish.

And quickly it is just a lovely memory.

I find it difficult to find beautiful green fragrances. But I like this one very much, even though it appears so delicate and fragile. Therefore, it is best to spray it at home for cuddling and linger with a cup of tea in hand, reminiscing about the beautiful memories of spring and summer.

I don't understand the bad reviews. The sillage and longevity are very low, but the scent is beautiful.

review_title: Girl I really wanna believe y
review_content:
I’m being honest, I only bought it because of the bottle lol,
Just kidding, no I found it quite okay on the first test. Even though the scent tends to be torn apart online, my memory of the fragrance was positive. It would have been different if Tom Ford had released it in the Private Blend in a completely emerald green bottle; I would have been curious if it might have been received better.
In the style of Rose Prick.

Today at 32 degrees and with a planned trip to the lake, I thought it was a good day for this scent. I already figured it might need more warmth.
Since I always remembered the fragrance as a delicate floral water, I thought
5, 6 sprays are easy and off we go.

And boom, hello? Who are you? With each spray, I instantly noticed how it became sweeter. My memory of this scent was already different.
At 32 degrees, the floral notes suddenly became completely alive, as if you were riding a bike along a gravel path by the stream, the smell of a warm road, warm skin, and the bushes and flowers along the stream.
Fresh wind in my face,
so loud that you can hardly hear anything else.
That’s how the memory of this scent suddenly smelled, and I was very happy with my choice for the day.
It needs heat. I had such an extreme scent bubble around me for 3 hours. And my date said I smelled great like sunscreen.
I thought, well, 2 sprays would have done it too, but I didn’t expect it to suddenly come to life in the heat.
I find the scent smells mega authentic, without synthetics, and I suddenly like it a lot, precisely because it is so “different.”

Matching song:
Cabin fever - Jaden @0.41 seconds

I see the scent in the late summer afternoon evening at sunset

review_title: From Kamistad Gel to Mémoire d' une Odeur
review_content: I first tested this fragrance on paper.. Big mistake, as it was very alcoholic. It immediately reminded me of the medicinal smell of Kamistad Gel (for inflammation in the oral cavity). But somehow it didn't let me go. So I tested it again on my skin and waited 5 minutes. And now I found it fantastic. Gentle chamomile, soft wood, fresh green, and a hint of powder. I find it very special and extraordinary, something you rarely smell. Mémoire d' une Odeur is also magnificent layered over Molecule 04.

review_title: Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir? - Möchtest Du heute Nacht mit mir schlafen?
review_content:
The first impression -
The first impression.

Your appearance caught my attention and I thought, I definitely want to get to know you.
Mémoire, I believe this is the beginning of a wonderful friendship. At least that was my first thought after I applied you for the first time, because you enchanted me with your peculiar charm.

Formidable! You envelop me with a pleasant scent of chamomile with woody-green notes and round off your presence with a vanilla accent. Wonderful! You are very subtle and have a calming effect on me. This is incredibly pleasant, as life is usually already too loud and too fast.

Un ami est long à trouver et prompt à perdre -
A friend is hard to find and easy to lose.

Unfortunately, I had to realize after a relatively short time that it is always the dearest ones who disappoint you the most. Just like you! Where have you gone? Everything was so extraordinarily pleasant... Now you are gone and it’s loud around me again. Great. This makes me a bit sad, because everything started so promisingly.

Chaque chose en son temps -
Everything in its time.

Indeed, you have truly touched me and left such impressive traces that I often think of you. I won’t let you go, and I already have an idea...

Voulez-vous coucher avec moi ce soir? -
Möchtest Du heute Nacht mit mir schlafen?

You are enough for my bed!
What I had planned with you was different, but this compromising relationship seems to be a very good solution nonetheless.
Just give me that soothing feeling at night, as it allows me to fall asleep with a smile on my lips.
Yes, now you love me - and even if you leave me again soon and I have to wake up without you... it remains "Mémoire d'une Odeur"

Phew, I’m not quite sure what to make of this scent. Lured by the appealing bottle, I sprayed it in the store. Shortly after applying it, I unfortunately found it really terrible. On me, it smells somehow fermented, glue-like, and almost like expired medicine? It’s hard to describe. Since I tested it directly on my skin and not on a paper strip, I had to endure the scent for the rest of the day, and I must say that in the end, I was positively surprised. After a while, the fragrance developed into an extremely pleasant, fresh-woody direction. But not this “freshly washed laundry lemon-fresh,” rather this “fresh forest air-fresh.” The smell of this perfume reminds me of a beautiful girl running through a fairytale forest in a loose dress. I couldn’t stop sniffing my hand. Nevertheless, I ultimately didn’t buy this scent, simply because that sharp medicinal smell bothered me so much at the beginning, and unfortunately, it lingers for quite some time. Such a shame, because the scent is so pleasant in the end, and the bottle looks wonderful too...

review_title: For me, simply the perfect spring
review_content:
Mémoire d'une Odeur was on sale and according to the description of the content, I thought to myself you can't go wrong. So I quickly ordered it.

When the bottle arrived, I was really impressed with the flacon. Somehow timeless and yet a homage to the old times!
I found the flacon simply brilliant and I liked it a lot. The first impression was already successful.
While testing, I found the scent to be “okay”
It was fresh and smelled pleasant, and especially the chamomile stood out beautifully, yet this scent did not blow me away and I did not feel the urge to wear it, so it ended up in a drawer!

Last weekend, I had an appointment and was pondering what would fit today, opened the drawer and thought to myself “why not”! You really can't go wrong with this scent.
Moreover, it is not too intrusive, and I remember that this scent smelled quite fresh.
So the decision was made: This is the one!
At first, I didn't really notice the scent, but over time and especially with the spring-like weather, this scent really got to me and I felt that feeling of spring! It highlighted the sunshine and the green that was slowly sprouting everywhere perfectly!
The chamomile and the freshness just fit perfectly with spring.
