It's like listening to a song that is “okay,” but when you hear the song in a certain situation/mood, it fits and completely captures you!
That's how it is with this scent in spring!
For me, this scent best describes what I perceive in spring and what spring evokes in me. Joy, enjoyment, freshness, being free, and yet a certain lightness!
And the more I wear it on such days, especially now, the more I fall in love with it!

It is not dominant or intrusive, but it flatters you and envelops you with the emotions of spring!

I still haven't figured out what this fragrance reminds me of... - ...but the name says it all!
I can safely say that this is the first women's fragrance from Gucci that I like and that I will definitely buy sooner or later.
The delicate Roman chamomile accompanies the entire "fragrance program," and all other components remain consistently mild to gentle, never intrusive or overpowering.
All in all, a surprising scent that one enjoys remembering and that even reminds me of something I will certainly explore further...

The opening is a distinctly noticeable green chamomile that then becomes softer and more enveloping through the vanilla.

In my mind, this scent creates a picture.
I see a Victorian greenhouse in late spring, when it is pleasantly warm in the morning, but the midday heat has not yet arrived, more of a between time than a before or after.
The plants inside grow wildly intertwined, all in various shades of green, with the occasional blossom peeking through the leaves, in white, yellow, or other cheerful colors.
The first rays of sunshine filter through the slightly dusty windows and brighten the room. Hopeful, they warm it against the cold that was for what is to come. A nostalgic coziness, a memory (of a scent), from another time...

I don't think everyone will like this somewhat special smell, but some may find a long-lost feeling or a memory within it.
It is definitely worth a try.

The scent brings me to a vision where an older man falls for a young lady who wears this fragrance... He takes the perfume from her bag, smells it, and absolutely wants to buy her the scent again. He hides his feelings and thinks about this woman every night before sleeping. She is so special, but so young and forbidden. What should he do? Sandalwood and vanilla...

The nose behind it is Alberto Morillas. According to Gucci, this is the brand's first unisex fragrance, with Harry Styles as the face of the campaign, which was shot in the fields in front of Montecalvello Castle in Italy. They wanted to convey the free spirit authentically. Free from space and time, hence modern yet nostalgic. The scent is herbal, rough, and bitter. If there...

This fragrance feels like a warm hug while sitting wrapped in a blanket by the fireplace. It radiates absolute well-being for me. That's why I also like to wear it in the evenings; I would prefer to bathe in it. It is a very rounded scent without edges or corners, yet something quite special, far from the mainstream. My first scent association was "oily." The feeling of...

It’s probably due to my skin chemistry, but despite my sensitive sense of smell, I only detect a subtle chamomile tea. The other notes don’t come through for me, and unfortunately, the fragrance is just a mild breeze. I feel like I’m in the fairy tale "The Emperor's New Clothes." It’s a pity because I enjoy discovering unusual perfumes.

review_title: Unisex?! Maybe when men go extinct
review_content:
Basically, I am a big fan of unisex fragrances. After all, they are not bound to appeal to a specific gender, but can move between gender boundaries, allowing for more creativity. But how does Gucci fare with its first unisex fragrance?

"With the new fragrance direction 'mineral-aromatic', which arises from the combination of Roman chamomile and Indian coral jasmine, Gucci Mémoire d'Une Odeur cannot be assigned to either gender or time of day." - Of course, the classification into more masculine or feminine is a matter of opinion, and some men may enjoy this scent, but if you ask me, this is a purely women's perfume. Therefore, it doesn't surprise me that of the 454 users who own this fragrance on Parfumo, 73 percent are women. Before I ordered the 7.4ml version, I was also a bit confused, as the scent seemed rather feminine.

Translated, the name of the perfume means "Memory of a Scent," and as absurd as it sounds, this fragrance reminds me of my mother's hairspray, which she used 20 years ago. Of course, it's nice when scents evoke memories, but I don't necessarily need my mother's hairspray on my neck.
The fragrance is quite linear and doesn't change much. You can definitely smell the chamomile, but it's somehow difficult to describe. I can't clearly identify and describe the other notes. I actually believe that I've never had such a hard time describing the scent of a perfume as I do in this case.

The perfume is very unobtrusive, which is probably also due to its poor performance. Since I usually use four sprays on my neck, it was difficult to create the same conditions this time, as the 7.4ml version is delivered as a roll-on. But even when applied generously, the scent barely lasted two hours in my self-perception.

The packaging and bottle are simple, but somehow fit the fragrance quite well. I find 100ml for about 74 euros a bit much, considering the poor performance.

Let's hypothetically assume that I had a girlfriend and she wore this fragrance; my nose would probably have no objections even if it doesn't blow me away, BUT on my neck, it is completely out of place.

The scent starts on my skin with a herbal, slightly spicy explosion, which becomes weaker and softer after a few minutes. In the drydown, a pleasant chamomile note quickly joins in and takes the lead, while the herbal aspect remains present in the background.
The fragrance becomes very close to my skin quickly, but I can perceive it like a gentle breeze for several hours. I don't smell the woody notes and the vanilla (my skin generally absorbs a lot of vanilla).

I find the scent very interesting; the opening is not quite to my taste, but I really like the chamomile in the drydown.
I don't think a full bottle will be in my future.

Many scents are associated with experienced moments, with beautiful times or with special people who have crossed our paths in life. Some even evoke a déjà vu.
This Gucci understands that masterfully!
Who hasn’t had to drink chamomile tea in childhood when plagued by a nasty stomach upset? Memories of caring parents or grandparents come rushing back. No matter how bad the chamomile tea may have tasted, the comforting feeling of security and being cared for remains through the scent of the brewing tea.
Who doesn’t remember the chamomile-lined edges of golden grain fields and green pastures during long walks? The relaxation that set in?
The nostalgically beautiful green bottle fits very well with the overall impression that the perfume conveys. The scent starts with chamomile, unusual and more niche than designer. The chamomile remains from start to finish. Initially strong and almost alone, the other notes gradually join in: The powdery chamomile supported by musk followed by a soft creamy chamomile through woods and sandalwood. In the end, beautifully nestled in vanilla.
It is exactly this scent progression, with the retention of the chamomile odor, that creates the memory that makes this fragrance so unique for me. I never thought I would like the perfume so much.
For me, it is not a perfume for going out but rather for home and everyday wear, providing a sense of well-being as soon as one of the chamomile clouds reaches the nose.

review_title: In Search of the Lost Chamomile
review_content: After a long consideration, I made a blind buy. I was looking forward to a herbal chamomile scent. I was excited about the much-mentioned green and even musty notes. However, what I found inside is a surprisingly floral fragrance. A perfumey scent. Not very special. In fact, I can hardly smell any chamomile at all. I'm disappointed; the scent is nice. Nothing more. It becomes extremely close to the skin after just 15 minutes. It feels more like a body spray. Hmm. The best thing about this fragrance is the bottle.

A very interesting scent, in my opinion. What I always wonder is whether it is really unisex. I mainly smell the chamomile, musk, and vanilla. I think the bottle fits the DNA of the fragrance perfectly. Definitely a green scent. However, since there is always a rather feminine floral accord present, I am really not sure if I would classify Mémoire d'une Odeur as unisex. For spring, though, it is truly a dream. Unfortunately, there is a bit of synthetics involved, which, given this price, shouldn't be too heavily criticized in my estimation. The longevity is good, not outstanding but definitely acceptable. The sillage unfortunately leaves something to be desired, but it is not extremely poor either. All in all, a very nice fragrance, but men should definitely test whether it is not too feminine for them.

The name is incredibly fitting; it is not a perfume but a wonderful memory of scent, fleeting, hard to grasp, yet so soothing, friendly, and beautiful.

I am surprised that none of the reviews mention Donna Tartt and "the secret history"
but I can’t imagine anything more fitting than the beautiful and light moments of the book, where the initially carefree friendship and moments of enjoyment are described.
I don’t know if anyone can agree with me, but for me, this scent is exactly how I would imagine the fragrance of the twins Camilla and Charles side by side on an early spring evening.
So beautiful, yet elusive, and with a palpable sad longing for something that can never be brought back.

I am a true fan of this scent and perceive it as a true masterpiece of olfactory art.

However, I find that Gucci has made a mistake by marketing it as a perfume. In my eyes, it is closer to a self-care product, and even if it may be decadent, it is really not something one buys for others or to please, but as a token of love for oneself.

It is like a new category for me, something I had not known before.

My favorite way to use it is after a hot bath or shower, to wrap myself in it, mix myself a Baptiste (cognac, maple, cider), read a little, and then use memoire for what it does best: to enchant my pillow before going to sleep and carry me away.
For some, it is a perfume; for me, the most beautiful pillow spray one can imagine.

review_title: The Smell Of The Backyard At Night
review_content:
I would like to have an infinite number of perfumes, one for each moment of the day. I want to wake up in the morning and sprinkle myself with what I think may represent my mood, more, and I wish that others around, smelling my perfume, could somehow imagine how I feel, could have an image of me, feel mine sensations. Am I asking too much? Maybe yes, but that’s what I want from perfume, and that’s why I never have just one. And even on the same day, the scent I put on in the morning, probably in the evening, no longer suits me. This morning, a lazy, foggy Sunday in April, I woke up to the addition of tuberose. And Gucci Bloom worked my desire perfectly.

I admit, my fault; I only recently discovered the fascination of the tuberose flower since I started ignoring the genus. As an ignorant man, I have always dedicated myself to perfumes intended for a male audience who, for some unknown reason, does not include this beautiful flower in their blend. There are perfumes like Bvlgari Man in Black that contain it, but they don’t give it the proper emphasis as in fragrances intended for a female audience. An exception is Zara’s recent releases, Bois Soleil Men, where the sensual flower plays an important role.

Bloom is a floral bomb but not a complex fragrance. It is a melange of flowers to create a bohemian bouquet that treads the razor’s edge between vintage and modern, the smell of the backyard at night. Bloom has a unique packaging that immediately captured me, a linear bottle with a lacquered surface and the pale pink color of porcelain. It’s like a box of face powder. Brilliant, delicate, but so wonderfully magical. And Bloom’s powdery note was an emotion, a velvety but not crushed sensation, immersed in the enveloping tuberose and jasmine that makes everything fresh and tender. It is the perfume that is revealed little by little after the first most powerful note. Bloom is therefore not an immediate perfume but one that reveals itself with grace, caution, and freshness. And it puts the spotlight on tuberose, enriching it with jasmine and honeysuckle. Everything is fresh, with the right amount of “sweet,” the right amount of “green.”

The scent unfolds directly with a dry and flowery bouquet. It’s purely a white floral blend, but rather than edgy or jarring, it’s delicately understated and sweet. There are no notes of Hesperides or aldehydes. The first notes are divine: pure white flowers, no fruit, no citrus, no sweet notes—just like diving into a flower bush. And this sets this fragrance apart from the multitude of floral scents currently on the shelves. The creamy tuberose hit with all its splendor explodes. It is a diva, rich, sour, bitter, a touch of waxy, camphor, simply delicious. A touch of bitterness makes me think of lily-of-the-valley.

The heart is and remains a floral mix; soon, the dewy white jasmine blooms. Rich, the bud is in the background, and there is something greenish, a green element of foliage with even a hint of undergrowth. The more it grows, the greener it becomes. Jasmine peeps out from time to time but remains docile and is not indolic. Sweet but not sickly, just like pouring a drop of honey on the bud, sharp but not annoying, noisy but not disturbing. Presumably, it’s because of the tuberose, but I seem to get a gardenia-like shade. It reminds me of walking in a garden of white jasmine, gardenias, and tuberoses that bloom right after the rain, with the warm breeze hitting my face. There is a light powder that could be an iris or a soft orris mixed with something like violet leaves, but it’s probably just one aspect of the Chinese honeysuckle.

The last stage adds a honeysuckle-like aroma, which is probably the added element of the Rangoon Creeper. I love the scent of honeysuckle, mine is the common white and yellow one, and every time it blooms on my terrace, I feel happy, so maybe that’s another reason why I love Bloom. It is the sweetest component in the development of this floral cluster, but it is a civil and lovable sweetness, which is never unpleasant, intrusive, or cloying. The base is a little powdery and balsamic, with a musky undertone but still rich in tuberose. There is a soapy atmosphere, not a classic soap scent, somewhat the characteristic fragrance of Marseille soap.

It is fresh and gentle with a dreamy and diaphanous sillage and scents like a bouquet of white petals through and through but has a persistent and ubiquitous creamy undertone that never allows it to be too floral or too sweet. Indeed, linear, while the subtle undertones change over time, but the scent doesn’t need to change much when it’s interesting enough to begin with. Like a memorable painted portrait, it has a face that you can perceive again and again and see it a little differently every time. To some, it will seem too linear and without notes, but in reality, on the skin, it has enough facets not to be boring, and at the same time, it is straightforward to overlap with other perfumes. It is a clean floral scent, slightly soapy, not too sweet, relatively modest. It is an elegant floral. Brunch with friends, spring office work, a date for a summer dinner - the scent is versatile and will blend well for many occasions. Bloom falls firmly into the non-indolic realm. You’ll never find that buttery fatness that is off-putting at times.

I based the review on a 100 ml bottle I own since January 2021.

-Elysium

Beside Rush, I am not an owner of a Gucci perfume. None of them suits me. I am sorry I had no chance to smell Envy because I heard it was a beautiful creation.
Now, let’s talk about Bloom. Tuberose is a nice flower but it can be very heavy. 2017 seems to be a tuberose year: Twilly, Gabrielle and now Gucci Bloom. I bet that by the end of the year there will be more perfumes that have tuberose as a starting point.
The fragrance opens with a sweet tuberose. The sweetness comes from honeysuckle, a flower from heaven with a gorgeous smell. So, I get a sweet, wonderful tuberose because it is the diva in this composition.
The perfume is linear with a tuberose which dominates the other notes. Sweet but not sickly, sharp but not annoying, loud but not disturbing. A classic composition made for all those who love white flowers.
The dry-down is a little powdery and balsamic maybe due to orris root, but still full of tuberose.
Projection and longevity are very good.
Gucci Bloom is a very nice fragrance where the tuberose is very well represented. It is different from others perfumes and bold in its own way. A good floral for the floral lovers.

review_title: In your face floral in the best possible way
review_content: A contemporary, buoyant floral, with a hidden green note, perhaps from the tuberose. Longevity is considerable for a white floral, and the dry down remains fresh without a sweet or powdery finish. Highly recommended for lovers of simple floral bouquets. Excellent for Spring and Summer daytime wearing and for warm spring and summer nights. But I wear Bloom anytime I need a lift. This is a bold floral that does not go by halves.

review_title: Sweet, Clean Floral -- budget version of Diptyque's Do Son
review_content:
The opening is a sweet, clean, and heady Jasmine. The scent doesn't really change in the drydown, and remains a very sweet floral. I don't pick up anything powdery or green, to my nose it's a pleasant, smooth sweetness throughout.
On me, across many wears on skin and clothing, the lasting power is a very poor 2 hour maximum unfortunately.
I've tested wearing Gucci Bloom and Diptyque's Do Son at the same time, and their dry downs are indiscernible to me; additionally they have the same lasting power on me. Do Son has a creamier, more delicate opening but Bloom is much cheaper.

It’s 2005. I’m 6 years old. I’m hanging out with my then-25-year-old aunt in her bedroom. Gwen Stefani ‘Hollaback Girl’ is playing. This perfume smells like that moment for me. I think this is what her laundry detergent smelled like at the time. Victoria’s Secret, maybe? I wish I could offer an unbiased opinion of this because I’m sure this perfume smells great to someone who isn’t instantly transported back to their aunt’s satin sheets from 2005.

Very similar to Do Son by Diptque. There's pros and cons to both. Do Son has a slight biscuityness (think digestive biscuit) that I find distracting, but it's also somehow "brighter" than Bloom. This is a pleasant and light jasmine/tuberose. It's ever so slightly powdery as it dries down but in a way that is still very realisitic floral. I veer towards saying it's not exactly...

This is a floral scent, that can be a bit overwhelming. Even to someone who is a huge fan of jasmine and tuberose. I have a theory that because this is a simple scent, only 4 notes, I notice the notes more than I would in a more complex scent. In a more complex scent my nose and my brain will be busy trying to disassemble the fragrance. In this scent there is very little for...

review_title: A soft petal bed for a sleepy honey bee
review_content:
Heavy white florals. The initial cloud smells like those flowering bushes that are pretty tame and unassuming during the day, but suddenly become super fragrant on summer evenings. I can never remember their name. But they're beautiful. Humid, honeyed, warm.

I'm usually not a big fan of heavy floral scents, but I have to admit – I found myself enjoying this one quite a lot. It became sweeter as it settled on my skin and jasmine came to the forefront. I didn't feel any powderiness. On the contrary, it was very clean and easy to breathe in. Unexpectedly good, realistic flowers on a gentle creamy backdrop.

For a brief moment I thought I was falling in love. Something about this composition was very comforting. Delicate, honeyed floral sweetness. Airy warmth. It felt... safe. Like I was a little bee cradled for the night in the petals.

But then in a blink of an eye it was gone. It lasted barely longer than an hour in total, but near the end it suddenly fizzled away to a weird greenish base. ~20 more minutes and it was completely gone.

Left an overall pleasant impression except for the abrupt ending. But while I think back on it and do want more of that cozy feeling, I'd rather search for it elsewhere than fly back to the same flower I've painfully fallen out of before.

Got in a tester kit from Sephora (I really like buying these and playing with them), sprayed on my wrist, and immediately did a 180° turn to go scrub it off (micellar water will do the trick!). I do get a blooming sensation when I sniff which is really cool but this smells like what an old lady would wear to church. Reminds me a lot of whatever Estee Lauder (either that or something like Elizabeth Arden) my mean 5th grade teacher wore.

This is definitely a fragrance that evolves after wearing it. Sniffing the bottle leaves something to be desired. It’s heavily floral. I didn’t think it was exciting. However, I accidentally sprayed it on my fingers as I was spraying it on a test strip. I grew on me as the scent sat and blended with my chemistry. The dry down is a sweet, floral, creamy scent. It’s not bad at all. Just not necessarily amazing.

Gucci's Bloom is the modern designer floral par excellence. Fresh, green-tinged, and youthful, it has become somewhat of an instant classic. Indeed, it is sometimes hard to believe its distinctive floral-patterned box and pink rectangular flacon only hit the shelves eight years ago.

Bloom's fresh white floral opening delights with its dominant tuberose and crisp green facets, like crushed young stems. The waxy petals and green stems of jasmine soon become apparent, and are superbly blended with the tuberose. Both flowers are neither carnal nor indolic at arm's length; they are softly creamy and very fresh, with a splash of naturalistic sweetness. It's only up close that they have a bit more indolic bite, but you'd have to be very initimate for someone else to detect it.

Bloom becomes creamier and less sharp in the dry down, while remaining clean and bright. The shift is subtle, and overall the scent is fairly linear.

The comparisons to Diptyque's much pricier Do Son EAU DE TOILETTE are apt, but Bloom is arguably a better fragrance; more coherent, simpler, more persistent, and certainly more affordable. It may be more synthetic, but you couldn't tell due to its clever composition.

In fact, from among the wave of minimalist designer florals that descended on the market in 2017, Bloom is by far the most naturalistic, despite being predominately composed of synthetics. It is lighter and more cheerful than Twilly d'Hermès EAU DE PARFUM, which has a heavy-handed dose of musk in the base, and more distinctive than Gabrielle Chanel EAU DE PARFUM, which timidly mimicked the citrus and floral accord of Jour d'Hermès EAU DE PARFUM, released four year's earlier. Alberto Morillas really does know how to compose a blockbuster to a budget without sacrificing artistry, and Bloom is among his finest examples.

I received Gucci Bloom as a Christmas gift in 2017 from my dear daughter.
I am actually always on the lookout for vintage fragrances, but I can't expect my family to gift me such scents. You have to know a bit about them, and they don't.
So, before Christmas, I always make a little list of fragrances, new releases, or classics that could be gifted to me.
And Bloom was certainly a good choice.
I perceive Bloom as a modern, soft, pleasant floral fragrance. It is modern in that the floral notes appear delicate and balanced. The flowers are present but not overwhelming.
In the past, it was different; floral scents often made you feel like you had your nose buried in a whole lush bouquet.
Here, you can certainly recognize the tuberose, which is soft and not too intense, and a bit of jasmine is balanced in its dosage.
I am not familiar with Rangoon Creeper, so I don't know how it smells and cannot judge how strongly it influences the scent. I had to Google it first.
It is also called "Chinese honeysuckle" and is a tropical climbing plant found in South and Southeast Asia.
Of course, it cannot be compared to the floral bombs from the eighties and nineties, but that's okay.
I think it is a beautiful, modern, delicate, contemporary floral fragrance. It could last a bit longer, but I am also too influenced by the eighties, where a fragrance easily lasted 10 hours without becoming too close to the skin. But nowadays, you have to be glad if a fragrance lasts 4 hours.
A good gift and one of the better new releases in recent years.

that this fragrance is now one of my absolute favorites.

It all started about a year ago. I was newly pregnant and had received a sample.
“Brrrr, this is terrible, cloying, and just nooo,” was my first thought.
Time and again, that one spray would hit my nose, and I can tell you, I have never experienced a fragrance that made me feel genuinely sick. I mean really. Sure, there are many that aren't my style, but I never actually felt nauseous.

Well, as I said, I was in a different condition, and then the worst nausea really hit.

Mon Guerlain and this one managed to catapult my scent receptors straight out of the game. I knew Guerlain before my pregnancy and I really liked it, so much for that.

Unfortunately, I was constantly confronted with Gucci in the family, even if it was just subtly, it was dreadful, but the others can't help it :)

So, the pregnancy was over, and I started to get Bloom under my nose more often, and suddenly I was so in love. It was like a lightning bolt hit me, and I couldn't believe that I suddenly liked it so much. It now reminds me of my beloved Oilily that I owned in the 90s.

So I tried it again and walked through the city.
Yes, it's great, has enormous longevity, and a beautiful floral sillage.

To me, it simply smells creamy and beautifully floral. Additionally, very, very elegant. I don't find it powdery. Like a body lotion mixed with flowers and a bit grassy.
Here, it’s enough to spray 1-2 times; otherwise, it’s really too much. But that’s definitely sufficient.

Well, today I can hardly believe that this wonderful fragrance once made me feel so overwhelmed and what hormones can do to you :)

By the way, I still can't stand Mon Guerlain anymore, not at all; that love is definitely over :)

Today my eyes were caught by a charming floral carton that one must stop for as a packaging victim.
Oh Gucci Bloom.

At the sight of the flowers, I thought of the folk song: We weave you the virgin's wreath - but the scent does not come across as innocent - virginal at all.

It is fresh green, as if just picked - but not girlishly playful.
But also not ladylike elegant.

It makes its own interesting statement, which is a bit untamed and pleasantly natural.
The enchanting chaos of a wildflower meadow, where everything still fits together.

The jasmine shines bright and clear, and the tuberose is intense - but not breathtaking.
A soft bitterness is added by the iris.

All the ingredients are dew-fresh - and still rooted in the earth.

Bloom has also taken root on my skin - and it lands without a doubt on the wish list.

Gucci BLOOM is by far one of the best women's fragrances that hit the market in 2017. It reflects what Gucci stands for: luxury, elegance, and confidence, as this scent has, in contrast to appearances like BAMBOO, a wonderful quality.

Scent: Anyone who hates tuberose shouldn't even bother looking at it. Because it is very, very tuberose-heavy. But in addition to the wonderful composition of the flowers, the fragrance has a very creamy note. I can't quite describe it, but it's definitely not sweet. BLOOM smells, to put it briefly, of bright flowers, with a generous splash of tuberose surrounded by cream.

Longevity/Sillage: There's no comparison to lukewarm waters like BAMBOO. Finally, Gucci has raised the quality level. BLOOM lasts a good 9+ hours on the skin, and on clothing, probably for several days. The sillage is very noticeable, but one should definitely pay attention to the dosage as the environment may perceive the already pronounced tuberose scent as overwhelming.

Bottle: Extremely simple, which is not necessarily what one would expect from Gucci. Square shape in a soft, washed-out pink. The name of the house and the fragrance are affixed. The bottle also has a nice weight to it.

Braided hair, softly flowing dresses, barefoot walking in lightness through a garden full of white flowers… yes, there are worse things in this world. As long as one is not averse to tuberose and does not disdain jasmine, one can share a joyful connection with this perfume. I must admit that I am not indifferent to some of Morillas' creations, and Bloom is no exception.
The division into top, heart, and base notes is unnecessary, as the perfume immediately unfolds completely with all its components. It opens with a fresh floral-creamy bouquet of tuberose and jasmine paired with Rangoon creeper; a color changer throughout its existence, as it initially blooms white and then gradually blushes from pink to dark red. According to Gucci's fragrance description, this Rangoon creeper is said to possess a slightly powdery and feminine scent note, adding richness to the creation. Due to my lack of a pure olfactory reference for this climbing plant, I would say this component supports the perfume as a whole and adds a touch of exclusivity due to its unusualness. The iris mentioned here is not perceptible to me, but rather a hint of musk in the background. Throughout the day, Bloom remains floral-creamy, but becomes more delicate and gently fades out after a long-lasting wear.
In summary, a lush blooming imaginary garden for the skin… simple and lush at the same time. Fine!

review_title: Between too much and too little
review_content:
Summer in April - already in the first spring months, we were sweating at 30 degrees. And I chose Bloom as my first summer fragrance this year. Was this decision wise? No idea - but now at the end of June, it’s empty, and I want to write a few lines about it.

Actually, Bloom is not a prototypical candidate for summer; it’s far too heavy for that - autumn would suit it much better. The scent has a tropical-floral quality to it; the description says "creamy," but I would not agree with that at all. The floral aspect is not fresh or classically refined in any way, but rather very muggy - wearing it feels a bit like being in a palm garden or greenhouse. That's almost too much in hot temperatures.

The bottle also appears very modern and, with its peachy pink, seems pastel-light - but that’s not Bloom at all. The bottle could have been much kitschier according to the scent it contains, something more 90s-style - but not so straightforward and clean. One associates the color with a fruity scent, which you certainly do not find in the bottle.

Right after spraying, Bloom is very strong, and you expect an impressive sillage and longevity - but in my opinion, there is too little of that. It smells briefly and intensely of the specified floral potpourri, but then dissipates within a few hours and is no longer perceptible in the evening. On the skin, it has completely vanished; on clothing, you might still catch a hint of it. That, in turn, is too weak for a designer fragrance.

Speaking of potpourri - do you know those dried plant parts that have been coated with a fragrance oil to scent the room...? Bloom reminds me of that. For me, this perfume is not a candidate for repurchase; its floral heaviness and green notes were just too much for me. I prefer flowers interpreted as fresh or sweet, perhaps with accents of vanilla or soft woods. This one simply has too much flower embedded in too little.

First off: I love this scent. Even though various people (men) can't make me dislike it, as some of my buddies think it smells like grandma. Yet it is such a beautiful, purist floral masterpiece: Tuberose dominates and jasmine softens it into a floral-powdery-soft fragrance. I can't say much about the longevity, but I can say a lot about the effect:

This scent envelops you in a floral cloud that surrounds you all day long - without smelling outdated. You have to be careful with the dosage, because if you apply too much, you smell like a greenhouse.
The jasmine is not that harsh, hyper-dominant jasmine of an alien, but a softer, subtler one.

This makes this fragrance so unique, as it has an incredibly beautiful floral essence without becoming an overpowering bouquet. Bloom is puristic, modern, and at the same time has a lot of classic floral scents that stand out and perform really well, without reminding one of the bouquets from the fifties.

Gucci Bloom is something for individualists, as both wallflowers and women from the "I’ll blow you away with my scent" category will find it somewhat semi-appealing, since for some it is too dominant and for others too pure. I believe none of the fragrances in my collection is perceived as controversially by my surroundings. My colleagues find it quite cool, while others think it’s rather old-fashioned. I really like this controversy, because despite its enormous floral character, it is straightforward and not overly whimsical.

Dakota Johnson and the lush floral splendor on the poster surely contributed to my decision to purchase this fragrance. However, even after multiple applications, I am not sure what to make of it. Bloom, however, has less to do with the scent, rather it resembles a heavy bouquet used to spray dried flower arrangements.
Tuberose as a hint, but not in its pure, unadulterated form, rather distorted by overly soapy jasmine, which overshadows the perfume and makes the scent too heterogeneous to be well described. Humid and too heavy, with one particular note that bothers me reminding me of DIOR J'adore. Too inconsistent, too indecisive.

What makes a great perfume? First and foremost, it’s the fact that it is a great perfume for me personally and perhaps for some or many other people as well. Taste is primarily an individual matter. Aside from the fact that a perfume deserving the adjective "great" must appeal to me extremely well in all its notes and their progression, it needs that moment when the...

review_title: In the Tropical Greenhouse in Sicily
review_content: Today I want to write about Gucci Bloom, as I had the pleasure of receiving a sample through an online purchase. I didn't really like the flanker Gucci Bloom Nettare di Fiori; somehow it was too stuffy and too heavy for me. With Gucci Bloom, it's different. I feel immediately transported to a tropical greenhouse. There is jasmine in its purest form, there is tuberose, but it doesn't smell like Hypnotic Poison, rather creamy-soft, and there is something exotic that I can't quite place. Like exotic tropical flowers. The sun is shining. Insects are wandering. In the jungle, all sorts of strange plants are thriving that no human has ever seen before. In the shade lies a lethargic leopard, exuding majesty. This scent is creamy, floral, not too light, not too heavy, and feels very elegant. I imagine the wearer like this: no grass skirt, no coconut bikini top to further weave the tropical-exotic image from above, no. A dark-haired lady with an elegant chignon, wearing a white silk blouse and large white pearl earrings like the girl with the pearl earring by Vermeer. She sits on a terrace overlooking the sea in front of Sicily, sipping an espresso. This perfume definitely evokes associations of the (sub)tropics for me. Yet it is unmistakably European. (Some may disagree with me.) The sillage is strong. Gucci Bloom is definitely something for a lady, and I like it! I think it's a versatile perfume, suitable for a business meeting just as much as for dinner or the theater. Who would have thought that I would ever like a Gucci fragrance! Gucci Rush - too sweet, Gucci Bamboo - too boring, Envy Me - too unremarkable, and as I said, Gucci Bloom Nettare di Fiori - too heavy. And now this! I give Gucci Bloom a score of 7.5 points, as I am not a huge fan of tuberose.

When you wear this fragrance, you truly smell like real flowers. It feels as if you are stepping into a flower shop that exclusively sells white flowers. An absolute must for spring. Also very suitable for everyday wear, e.g. at university or at work, as it does not hit you aggressively but rather has a fresh, beautiful note.

I have really tested many fragrances in my life, but none have smelled as good as this one so far. It really lasts on my skin for several days sometimes! I'm a big fan of this balance between floral and powdery. I have truly received compliments from several people that this fragrance smells so good on me, which is really flattering.
Gucci Bloom - for me, an absolutely perfect fragrance!

I used the sample that I was allowed to test back then simply as an air freshener in the bathroom. It didn't work as a perfume, something bothered me about it, even though the pyramid is exactly my style. I love jasmine, love tuberose, love musk, and here it didn't even come across as "warm" and sexy to me, but just flower, short and sweet. And I usually like flowers

After it was applied, I really missed the scent. It didn't even annoy me, like some of my fragrances that I prefer to smell.
At some point, a bigger AF will move in with me, I need to dissect this again to understand what ultimately won my heart.

The perfume is unique and easily recognizable, everywhere. It would definitely work as a signature scent. If someone can wear it, great, I would love to smell it, just not on me.

review_title: How floral do you want to smell? - Yes!
review_content:
That I would ever write a review about this fragrance, I never thought I would in ten years. I have tested the scent countless times due to its beautiful packaging. Something about it bothers me extremely, so it wasn't worth another thought.

Until yesterday...

My colleague was standing next to me at the computer and showed me something, and suddenly this extremely delicious-smelling cloud of fragrance came towards me, it smelled like a fresh flower meadow. In spring, the birds are chirping, the first flowers are blooming, the grass is still slightly damp. The sun is shining.
Wow! I took another deep breath, is this a perfume? Is this a fabric softener? Or is this a hand cream? Should I ask her? Normally, I can recognize (almost) any perfume blindfolded...

When another cloud of fragrance hit my nose, I just had to ask her.

Before she pronounced the name, Gucci Bloom immediately came to my mind. But since when does it smell this incredibly good?

And of course, it was Gucci Bloom!

In our office, the whole hallway, everywhere she walked, it smelled wonderfully for hours afterwards. I don't mean in a cloying way like perfume. Not at all.
It just smelled really clean, well-groomed, anything but like perfume and cloying.
And that's why I suddenly love this scent so much; I can't stand fragrances that leave an extremely overpowering scent note throughout the house.

But back to the fragrance, how did I perceive it?
First of all, totally well-groomed, not intrusive at all. But somehow fresh, clean, spring-like.
The scent is very floral; to me, it smells somewhat cool and floral.
It definitely smells floral; anyone who can't handle that should definitely stay away from this fragrance.

It is also relatively monotonous; I find the progression quite boring, but that’s exactly what makes the scent somehow special.

This may not be the highlight of my fragrance collection, but I can already see myself strolling through the city in spring wearing a delicate summer dress with this scent.

My new clean girl scent!

Ladies and Gentlemen, today I would like to share my opinion on a women's fragrance, namely Bloom by Gucci. How did I come to test a perfume for women? On one hand, I know several scents by Alberto Morillas that I generally like, and on the other hand, I was looking for a Christmas gift for my mother. It was only natural for me to give it a try, and now you will find out my...

review_title: Unfortunately, it didn't blow me away
review_content:
A few days ago, my dear colleague provided me with a whole little bag of perfume samples - for "sniffing." With a thorough warning that most of them weren't for her. Apparently, among her personal shelf warmers is also "Gucci Bloom," which I daringly tested last weekend.

I had to hold on tightly to my makeup table - it nearly knocked me over. This perfume combines quite a bit that I don't like in a fragrance. Tuberose simply reminds me too much (and unpleasantly) of the Canasta afternoons in my great-aunt's living room, when I, as a young girl, was allowed to watch the sprightly ladies play cards.

So internally, I truly feel crushed on the floor, but in practice, I stand there with a juicy spritz of "Gucci Bloom" - and it refuses to leave me. The longevity was - to my dismay - really lasting.

I just can't get anything out of this scent; the musk in the base completely takes my breath away.

So today, I told my colleague about my fragrance clash with "Gucci Bloom" - she just laughed gleefully, as she had warned me...

My second review... wow, I'm already at this point, moving on to another Gucci fragrance, my beloved GUCCI BLOOM.
Alberto Morillas has done EVERYTHING RIGHT with the Bloom line, specifically in my opinion with Gucci Bloom including Gucci Bloom Acqua di Fiori.

Floral, jasmine, white musk... everything comes to the forefront. The cologne-like super pleasant after smell is simply wonderful and gives the whole thing such a luxurious kick. It reminds me a bit of Chanel Mademoiselle _

I don't even want to talk about the longevity... the more positive version of a super clingy dude who doesn't care about anything ;)

--- This cheeky Bella has stolen the doll again! Like stung by a tarantula, Else dashes after the dog, across the gallery and down the stairs. The beech wood of the venerable staircase creaks in protest at each jump over such outrageous behavior. The dining room and the salon had just moments ago fallen into a contemplative midday slumber, allowing the spring sun to shine...

review_title: The Bloom That Slept Through Summer and Awoke in Autumn
review_content: Warm, soft, floral, slightly powdery. Too serious for spring, too fresh for autumn. In the context of climate change, the perfect scent for a mild autumn :)

review_title: Beautiful with the right skin chemistry
review_content:
This is so gorgeous straight out of the bottle - like a milky gardenia combined with a sugary amber musk.

Unfortunately on my skin, the pear blossom sticks out like a sore thumb and turns a bit salty (I have pretty acidic skin pH so I guess I'm not surprised by this) - which causes the fragrance to topple out of balance.

Try this - it's not boring like some have said; to me it's understated, classy, and beautiful if you have the right skin chemistry!

Not the worst out of the Floras, but only because it's faceless. Smells sugary-sweet with an indistinct synthetic undertone. I didn't get much berries, and wasn't able to recognize any particular flowers. Everything except sugar was vague, more of a formality than anything else.

Fabric softener kind of smell, except fabric softener usually lingers longer. It took less than an hour for everything but the base to evaporate, and by the end of the second hour the base was gone as well.

For the money that it costs, this whole collection feels like one big scam to me tbh.

I agree with everyone who thinks this smells pretty close to Viva La Juicy. Especially in the opening and heart phase, it's uncanny. Lively, fresh berries with a spritz of mandarin, clean gardenia, glossy light caramel (which is listed as brown sugar here, but smells more like a caramel hard candy). Very girly and easygoing. Ironically I find the original VLJ a bit more floral, but many of the flankers lean more into warmer gourmand territories, and Flora does, too.

At least for a while. In the drydown I can suddenly smell the Patchouli and jasmine, and together with the citrus sparkle of the top notes that still hang on, they remind me of a softer, sweeter Coco Mademoiselle. What a surprise! I like that this perfume is not quite as predictable as I thought, even though I seem to be the only one who gets this aspect of the scent.

In my opinion this would make a good everyday scent or even a gift for someone who likes perfumes, but isn't deep into the hobby. And of course also for someone who is and really likes fruity florals, or sometimes needs a break from the niche-y stuff. Just a pleasant, feminine scent, maybe a bit generic, but nicely done.

Kind of off-topic, but I have to get this off my chest: I really didn't like the frilly-frumpy-flowery aesthetic of Gucci under Alessandro Michele. Always a ruffle too much. It took me years to get used to the "new" Flora bottles and I still hope they will get another makeover.

Non-specific fruit and floral float casually on a solid jasmin and sugar base. It certainly does not impress but it is pretty and playful, and there are days I wake up eager to put this on.
It definitely leans youthful but the jasmin really anchors this down in a way to avoid being "juvenile", even though the sugar really does push it this way.
It's very much a mini floral dress sort of perfume. It is fine enough. I also want to add that this has the best atomizer in my entire collection and allows me to spray exactly how little I want to spray.

review_title: Nice floral perfume, but I don't get gardenia
review_content:
This is a nice, mostly inoffensive perfume. Despite the name, I really don't get much gardenia.

I get an initial note of purply, berry, sweet tart like candy. Then it moves to a general floral. It's here that I'm surprised to not get gardenia. Or at least what I normally think of as gardenia. I don't know? Maybe I don't actually know what gardenia smells like? I get more of a violet, freesia like floral. Then it sort of melts into a caramely/amber/skin like scent.

Very mid in terms of how long it lasts. For me it doesn't seem to project very much, but I think of that as a good thing. It feels like it lasts for a decent amount of time but it only hangs in a fairly small bubble around me. For me, it's a safe for work perfume. I'd say it's a fairly safe blind buy - as long as you are generally ok with florals.

This isn't one that I'm going to buy a full bottle of or constantly reach for but it's nice. No complaints. I'll happily use up the sample size I have. There's just nothing super unique or interesting about it.

If you want to smell like that classic smell of ,,grandmas home'', go for it. I personally didn't really like it because it was just a bit to flourish and old smelling. It's a great mix of notes and definitely stays interesting, but honestly there's better alternatives for that. You will smell like a crazy garden for about 10 minutes, after that it's just granny coming out.

I have to admit, Gucci fragrances have never convinced me before. I am 25 years old and always found the scents to be more suited for "mature" women. I became aware of this perfume because of the incredibly beautiful bottle. My thought was, however, "Oh, this probably won't be for me again." Today I went to the perfume store and saw the bottle standing there. Pink, gold,...

Hooked by the appealing advertising and the beautiful bottle, I set out to find a sample of this fragrance and soon succeeded. Right from the first spray, I noticed that Gucci Flora GG is also a victim of what I have dubbed the "Müller phenomenon." The first spray smells like the perfume department at Müller: alcoholic, piercing, floral-powdery, and undefined. Unfortunately, this happens to me with many designer fragrances. But it's not too bad, as this impression fades after a short time. However, unfortunately, this fragrance did not convince me further along. The name Flora is absolutely fitting; the scent is floral-sweet. It is also quite pleasant to wear. Unfortunately, I could hardly perceive any development of the fragrance. I could detect various notes (mandarin, jasmine, hardenberg, sugar), but that was about it. For me, Flora GG feels flat and does not differ from other standard floral fragrances. However, anyone looking for a pleasant, subtle sweet-floral scent won't go wrong.

I must solemnly declare at this point that for the first time in my life, a perfume nearly knocked me out. And I mean that literally. Within seconds of applying it, I felt so nauseous that I thought I would faint immediately. Yes, I fled the perfume store to get some fresh air. As I sat on the train on my way home, the cloyingly sweet, berry-biting scent from my wrist wafted into my nose, and my head was buzzing. Yes, I got a headache like I had only ever experienced from one fragrance before: Burberry Her.
What a shame, because I really like the classic Gucci Flora and Gucci Bloom, but this one is concentrated cotton candy, ultra-sweet poison. Maybe it’s too strong, or maybe I’m just too weak...?

I really like the original EDT of Gorgeous Gardenia (GG) and since I can't get to the city at the moment, it had to be a blind purchase..... daring, but I often take such risks and it works out 95% of the time :-), here is my review:

The bottle: the 30ml bottle fits very well in the hand and has a certain weight (still okay for a handbag), it looks quite high-quality despite the sticker. The spray is great, it really sprays very fine, no dripping or running of the liquid. The bottle has a very nice vintage feel due to its design and fits the fragrance very well. A downside is that you can only guess the fill level by shaking it.

The scent: it reminds me of the GG EDT but is, in my opinion, greener and airier and less sweet. Based on the comments for the EDP, I would have expected a sugar bomb, but that is not the case at all. At times, it resembles the Gucci Bloom line more, but is less overpowering. The scent starts off fruity-herb-fresh for me, after about 5 minutes, slightly creamy flowers come through, while this heart note remains subtly underlaid by a delicate green "cut flower note" for a long time. Only in the base, after about 1.5-2 hours, a soft floral sweetness comes into play, but everything is very moderate and pleasant, the green note remains just a whisper. The scent never becomes stuffy, too sweet, or cloying. The GG EDP feels modern, fresh, cheerful, and has a vintage vibe without being "old."

The sillage and longevity: as beautiful as the scent is, it could use more sillage and also more longevity. Maybe it's also due to the current temperatures and it will come out stronger in spring/summer? I will know in a few months.

The price-performance ratio: it doesn't quite fit for me, meaning it's too expensive for the rather low sillage and longevity, good that there are offers .-)

The campaign: at first, I wondered why Miley Cyrus, I would rather see her with Libre, BO, or something similar, but somehow she fits... I recently read that she embodies self-expression, authenticity, and optimism, being a free spirit of her generation, and that is what the fragrance is supposed to convey. Well, I would expect a scent with more edge or punch from free spirits, but when viewed from the vintage side, it somehow fits. Unfortunately, I can't find the right words to really describe what I mean (if I do, I will edit my contribution). By the way, the older "free spirits" (and also "non-free spirits") can definitely wear the scent just as well ;-)

My conclusion: I find GG EDP to be a great fragrance for all ages, but it unfortunately lacks a bit in sillage and longevity. It definitely brings a bit of optimism and "free spirit" into the currently rather difficult and serious times.

Rarely have I encountered a scent that is too sweet; most of them make the alcohol bite your nose first. Here, however, there’s a hit from the sugar claw right away. Do you know that feeling when you want to adjust the colors on your TV screen and suddenly the colors are so garish, as if you’ve bitten into the wrong mushroom? That’s how Gucci Flora smells... completely overdriven. Floral is only in the name here. Olfactorily, it reminds me of an overly sweet cocktail that has been sweetened not with sugar but with stevia and corn syrup.

On the second sniff, we notice two scent twins: https://www.parfumo.de/Parfums/Hunkemoeller/Noir The teen perfume from the grab-and-go shelf and https://www.parfumo.de/Parfums/American_Eagle/Vintage_for_Her_Eau_De_Toilette from the fashion label in the USA - both fit in well there. For a premium luxury brand like Gucci, however, this is an absolute failure.

After I sprayed Gorgeous Jasmine yesterday, I had to realize that its scent fullness was not suitable for the heat.
However, I like to wear it in moderate temperatures.
So today I cautiously approached Gorgeous Gardenia.
The scent fullness is also present here, but the gardenia is gentler than the jasmine.
It is also not a directly subtle fragrance, but it feels lighter than the jasmine.
The aquatic mandarin keeps the scent flowing, so the flowers seem to flow past like on a clear stream.
Jasmine is also present - but here the more subtle gardenia takes center stage.
One spray is enough even in these hot temperatures.
It's also a beautiful floral scent, which will probably only come into its own in the fall.
I have also moved my jasmine into the fall lineup.

review_title: You can't go wrong with this scent!
review_content:
A review from a man's perspective :D

I bought Flora Gucci as a gift after a long consideration and some testing in the store, and since it was still new.
The bottle is beautiful, presented in floral pink and gold with lovely edges, really well done.
When sprayed, lovely floral accents emerge that become even sweeter, as if you were standing in a field. I characterize a self-confident woman with this perfume, and it is very pleasant to my nose. It is not bitter, it is not too sweet, and it is not overly extravagant but rather remains subtle yet beautifully floral.

I find Flora Gorgeous Gardenia absolutely great; I can only recommend it to anyone looking for a gift, as you really can't go wrong. The joy was also quite large, and as I said, a very pleasant scent.

I fell in love with this perfume immediately. I first received it as a sample and tested it right away. The scent is very unusual, floral-citrusy, very fresh and invigorating, but also slightly sweet and light. Later, before I bought it, I wanted to test it again in the store and it was a WOW effect! You can definitely wear this perfume in summer and also in early autumn....

This fragrance has such a lightness! This freshness, these subtle floral notes, and this slight sweetness are simply beautiful. I find that it also has a very light fruity aspect, but only minimal. No matter where you go, you won't bother anyone. I don't know anyone who doesn't like the scent. I often wore it in the summer at the office. Yes, the longevity unfortunately...

I own the pink Flora Gorgeous Gardenia EAU DE PARFUM along with the yellow and purple ones.
I treated myself to the first scent because I really liked the packaging and the campaign.
Those expecting pure flowers from Flora will be disappointed, as there are additional notes at play, specifically fruity ones like Andean berries and mandarins that can be detected in the top notes.
In the base, brown sugar and patchouli come into play; I find the sugar interesting as it refines the scent with a sweetness.
Overall, the pink Gucci Flora is an average scent that is well-suited for spring, but personally, it doesn't blow me away, as I have many fragrances and have been able to test quite a few.
However, everyone has their own taste; unfortunately, I find the longevity of the Flora scents to be rather underwhelming, which is a shame because for the price, one could expect more.
Nevertheless, I am happy to have it in my collection, although it is not worn often.

It smells like a synthetic old flower shop. Slightly headache-inducing upon application, but not noticeable throughout the day. It is definitely not a striking perfume or a compliment magnet. It works well for spring or autumn. It is light, but the synthetic note makes it feel a bit heavier, so it's rather not suitable for summer.

Incredibly charming composition that reminds one of sweet sparkling pear. Ripe pear and whipped cream sprinkled with brown sugar. It reminds me of apples, cherries, plums. It feels as if the perfume swirls in the wind like rose petals. This fragrance is for true ladies. Aristocratic, intelligent, and graceful. Moreover, the bottle is a real eye-catcher. Beautiful, colorful,...

review_title: I found my love in Portofino
review_content:
My very first review (don't judge) after it was recommended to me by a loyal user who I consider a perfume expert, has to go to Gucci Flora.
A very beautiful spring scent aside from the gorgeous design. Floral... garden-like jasmine... somewhere a few berries pop out, so a bit fruity, but the floral notes dominate!
During the day, the floral scent can fade a bit and the sweetness stands out.

It's not the longest-lasting fragrance of all time, but it fits perfectly because I find it sufficient for use on important occasions outdoors on a beautiful sunny day, but watch the dosage (aside from the price if you are not completely independent yet ahaha;) )! It could make you feel a bit nauseous without joking, but that's the typical Gucci strength, so it hits ahahha.

It reminds me of Portofino... even though I've never been there, that's why I wear it rarely or not at all... so I don't fall too much into my Italy dreams...

#gucciflora #sendmetoitaly

Thinking of a pure floral scent, Flora Gorgeous Gardenia EAU DE PARFUM delights me with a very tasty fruit opening. The berries are not well defined, but their character is noticeable and pleasing. After a few minutes, the fragrance becomes floral-fruity and is very sweet. And from here, it starts to become increasingly ordinary.

As it develops further, floral and fruity notes blend together, forming a relatively sweet homogeneous mixture that is widespread in women's fragrances. Good for everyday wear and leisure, certainly not a bad date scent in sunny weather. But it's a bit frustrating considering it promised so much more in its first hour.
Nevertheless, it's a fragrance that, thanks to its lightness, exudes a lovely, youthful carefreeness that brings a bit of joy.
It also has a good sillage that lasts a nice 3 hours. Surprisingly, it only takes another hour for the scent to shrink down to skin level. For that, I find the price too high.

What I really can't stand is the kitschy bottle.

On the bottle, for me, a beautiful, intense summer fragrance, full of colorful flowers and joy of life. I couldn't help but spray it on, but it took less than a minute for the colorful flower meadow to vanish and be covered by a huge cotton candy cloud. Where did the flowers go all of a sudden? Where was summer? All this thinking gave me a headache, and I desperately tried to wash the scent off my skin.

....phew, where do I start...it smells to me like the time when I used to vacation in those all-inclusive resorts and the maid, oh no, I mean room service, had just been there. The floors are freshly mopped, the beds newly made, a flower arrangement on the bed. Well, a clean scent in the sense that I wanted to make the room romantic for the couple and sprayed a bit (generously) floral room fragrance note Flowerpower Bubblegum Strawberry. Well, you breathe in, you breathe out, it’s annoying and personally takes away a bit of my air...similar to Prada Paradoxe intense. The bottles are really nice to look at, I only own the yellow flanker from this line...I believe it was Gorgeous Orchid...yes, if I take another deep breath before going to sleep, it has a bit of fabric softener jasmine for me...

Not without reason have I used this fragrance up twice already. It is so beautifully fruity sweet and not at all intrusive. A very elegant sweetness from flowers, slightly powdery and absolutely perfect for every day. When I had the tester in my hand, it was already over for me. I can only recommend it to anyone who prefers sweet but not overpowering scents.

I am hopelessly in lust with Gucci Rush. It really stands apart from other fragrances. It is not trying to be something else.
The sweet, fruity candy powder and flowers melt together, and pack the first punch. Then they effortlessly give way to the hazy patchouli to create a sugary, spicy drydown.
It is totally carnal and provocative - no soft innocence here. Spicy, sensual, hot and ready, daring, unique, in-your-face, unapologetic.
You will either be completely, utterly taken...or not. It is worth finding out!

review_title: Meandering anthropomorphizing of a perfume. Great perfume, though.
review_content:
There’s nothing I can add to the comments I’ve read about how this smells. Hairspray, lactones, patchouli, non-existent flowers, bubblegum, poppers. All true.

It’s the feeling, though. There’s not even an attempt to tether this thing to anything actually botanical. Natural and chemical are words I tend not to use, because what do they mean? Nature, as we use it discussing the environment, has no meaning whatsoever when you look at it. And what matter isn’t chemical? That said, Rush’s value is that it is unnatural and chemical. And altogether unapologetic. And all the better for it.

If this is a signature scent, I pity the people close to the wearer. This is definitively an occasional scent. It is loud, cruisy, intolerant and laughs incessantly. This is the Dionysus of perfume. It’s also monotonous, not in the sense of humdrum, but of hitting one note, and one note only, endlessly. There is very little evolution in time with this one, but why should it be otherwise? Who wants a party to end? All credit to Tania Sanchez for describing this as both large-scale outdoor art and intended for a night out. That’s the best characterization I can imagine for this baby. Ultimately, though, the night-on–the-town analogy gives with one hand and takes with the other. Yes, Rush is the life of the party. Absolutely. We’re all drawn to her when she arrives. But she’s also the sitter. The last one at the party, dancing drink-in-hand by herself while everyone else has left.

Wonderful.

review_title: Way too much in just the right amount
review_content:
First encounter: my nose was blown to pieces, not knowing what was up, down or day of the week. A screaming freesia and peach combo smashed into my face and for a few minutes I was unable to smell anything else. But the bulldozer patchouli made me smell again - only just patchouli. A very close friend had given me this as a gift, no specific occasion, and I sprayed it to show that I appreciated the thought. There was no way I could regret it. I had to wear it off. I smiled and said thanks.
For a long time it stood in the closet. Occasionally, I grabbed it to make sure that it was the same experience, and for a long time it was. But then something changed…
One summer day I sat next to a friend and noticed a lovely smell. I had to ask and she told me it was Gucci Rush. I was confused. What was happening? Later when I came back home I tried it again. And it was great. Still overwhelming and hefty but also nice and romantic (?)
I do not know what has happened but today I like Rush, even though I do not wear it often. I will describe the scent as ‘fun’. And it is great to have fun sometimes.
95/365

The first time I smelled this was at an Osmothèque conference on 100 years of chypre. Rush was chosen and presented by Christophe Laudamiel as one of the iconic chypres. At the time I hated it. What the hell is this weird plastic thing?
Now I understand it. If Mitsouko is Ingres’ Grande Odalisque, then Rush is Martial Raysse’s Made in Japan version of it. It's deliberately kitsch, blatantly synthetic, plasticky, shouty, industrial. Just as Martial Raysse said, beauty is bad taste, and bad taste is the dream of an over-desired beauty. Seen in this way, Gucci Rush fits perfectly into the pop art aesthetic. No need to be so serious all the time. Sometimes we just need a bit cheap trashy fun.

Certain perfumes bring a mental image to mind. The image Rush brings to my mind: a pale 20-ish woman with greasy dark hair curled away from her face (Farrah Fawcett-style), smelling of cigarette smoke and vomited fruity drinks, wearing jeans she has to lie down to zip, talking too loudly in the parking lot of a dance club because she's drunk and can't tell how loud she is. If I had to work next to someone who wore this, I'd consider paying them to wear something else. When I have a sample of a fragrance, I always try it at least twice on different days, but I couldn't bear a second try on this one. (050609)

I owned Rush more than 20 years ago, but it was too much for my young nose, so, while I knew it was special, I never fully embraced it. I blamed it on the patchouli, and actually decided that I hated patchouli in general. A year or so ago, a relative showed me her bottle of Rush that she got as a gift, and a single whiff took me on a journey back to early 2000. It suddenly...

review_title: Alien rush at the end of the Century
review_content: Texture plays a role in this, which is good - because the theme is simple and doesn't change much. Fizzy, milky, powdery-woody and plastic, there is plenty for the nose to latch on to, as well as coriander, white flowers and patchouli. I say milky 'texture' but it’s better to call it milky hued; pale and lactonic. Rush has an alien feel, like Feu d’Issey (1998), and -...

When I first whiffed this stuff I hated it. But then.. I kept coming back. There was something so in your face about it that turned me off initially. Then I realized where Gucci Rush fits in to the scheme of the world and its beauty became shiningly apparent. Can we talk about the bottle design for a minute? It looks like a VHS tape. That's perfect because this smells like the late 80s. It's hairspray and shoulder pads, acrylic hot pink nails and blue eyeshadow. This is how porn stars smell when they get all glammed up for a big shoot. Notes wise, it has all kinds of things going on at once. High volume florals, sweet vanilla, earthy patchouli, fruity peach. It's a hot mess but it somehow works! It is certainly meant only for wear at night, in a busy club or smoky bar. The synthetic smell is unnoticeable in these environments. I might sound like I dislike it, but it's quite the opposite. I LOVE THIS. It's a stand up and take notice smell. Big and loud with huge hoop earrings this scent is. She is a fashionista and her friends copy her style. Everything about this says big hair and gooey lipstick. But the world needs that! How can we appreciate that which is simple and refined if we do not occasionally experience a crude excess? Gucci Rush is the olfactory illustration of this concept.
It has a presence around the shops at this time of year; Mother's Day next weekend. On me it smells like unwrapping an Apple Computer, niche cellophane. Sorry, no love towards it.

The smell of a baby doll toy would be how i describe the scent in modern times. Sweet floral - would be my answer 20 years ago.

Gucci Rush is a millennial mother who gave birth to gen Z Amouage Guidance daughter.

I thought it was long discontinued, but after learning it was still produced, I had to re-purchased it for the nostalgia sake, after, what, 20 years? I didn't even test it at the store, just decided to go off the memories of the scent.

The scent brings a picture of a black winter leather jacket with fox fur trimmed sleeves and hood. The kind i couldn't afford at the time, but all the it girls seem to have. Just clarifying, it's not the description of the notes, its the memory that is revived by this perfume.

Can we please talk about the bottle design? I would really like to hear the story behind it. What motivated this unique, kitschy style? The funny thing about it is, I remember 20 years ago, it didn't strike me as something weird and original. I just took it for what it is, and if i remember correctly, it felt quite normal. How different it's perceived today in 2025!

The first time I met Gucci Rush was in my last year at university. I remember the girls wearing it, Friday nights at the mirror in the shared bathroom doing their make-up, and the last part of this ritual was imbibing their white bodysuits with Gucci Rush. I've always been attracted to its synthetic sweetness, but somehow, in those days, I wasn't the mini-skirt + high-heels type of girl.

The Rush reincarnation that I own now isn't the same scent-bomb like the Rush of those days. The newest version has been domesticated, but it still lasts and projects decently. It's a classic and modern perfume at the same time. The peach seems to have been made from plastic, and this is how I imagine those robots from Westworld smell: strange yet familiar, odd and attractive. It's a pretty interesting and nostalgic scent.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Prima data cand am făcut cunoștința lui Gucci Rush a fost chiar in ultimul an de facultate. Tin minte fetele care il purtau, vineri seara, in baia comuna de la cămin, toate se machiau la oglinda si povesteau, iar ultima parte din ritual era îmbibarea maieurilor albe, mulate pe corp cu acest parfum. Întotdeauna am fost atrasa de dulceața lui artificiala si fireasca in același timp, dar cumva, pe vremurile acelea eram prea sfioasa ca sa mi-l cumpăr. Cumva nu eram eu tipa aceea cu fuste mini si tocuri si atitudine: nu ne prea potriveam.

Reincarnarea care o port acum nu mai e aceeași bomba îndrăcită ca Rush-ul de atunci. Versiunea recenta a fost îmblânzită, dar totuși are o persistenta si siaj destul de decente. Este un parfum clasic si modern in același timp. Piersica parca e făcută din plastic, ca si cum robotii din Westworld, pielea lor artificiala, ar mirosi așa: străin si familiar, straniu si atractiv deodată. Este unul dintre cele mai interesante parfumuri pe care le-am încercat si nimic nu se compara.

review_title: As tacky as the bottle it comes in
review_content:
Bizarre is the first word that comes to mind when describing Gucci Rush.

I'm actually quite familiar with this fragrance, my childhood dance teacher used to wear it as her signature. To me, Rush conjures up memories from the past. It's the smell of lipstick, hairspray, various cosmetics and hair curlers.

Gucci Rush does however smells wonderful on smokers. The smokey tobacco tends to blend wonderfully with the plasticky, peachiness that is Gucci Rush.

However, without the tobacco, this fragrance is a nightmare. Oddly enough I find that if I continue to smell Rush I start liking it as my nose becomes accustomed to its unique smell, however if I leave it for 30 minutes and then go back to it, I'm back to disliking the scent.

It's either a love it or hate it. I personally dislike the tackyness of the packaging and the cheapness of the fragrance itself. I'm usually pretty open-minded with unique fragrances, but in this particular case I am not.

This is what I'd describe as being the smell of melted lipstick meets tomato sauce. Odd, loud and nauseating, it seems to last a lifetime on my skin. Even harsh scrubbing can't kill this fragrance or help regain my sense of smell.

My initial impression of Gucci RUSH was of an oriental vanilla perfume. Completely innocuous and likeable. The patchouli creeps in slowly and does not seem too loud at all to me (as some reviewers have complained...). But perhaps my patchouli receptors were permanently paralyzed during my testing of ANGEL. In any case, I am surprised by the polarized reviews of this...

Gucci Rush is a perfume with great staying power and sillage, not for the faint-hearted!

It smells mainly of wood, flowers, peach and especially coriander which makes it spicy and gives it a "sparkling" and "punchy" effect.

I find it quite sexy, and even after all those years, I still like it. A perfume that doesn't leave indifferent.

This smells like Fun Dip or PixiStix.
This is a cool powder being both sweet AND tart at the same time.
It is fairly linear and reminds me of My Insolence.
It's a manic depressive frag and I would like to eventually buy a small bottle

review_title: First perfume to make me chuckle out of complete awe
review_content: Wow, seriously, where do I even begin? What a journey this fragrance is, immediately! No need to let the notes settle down at all, you're immediately led into a smoke-filled basement club rave with cigarettes, perfumes, ecstasy, alcohol-breath and happy, flirty party people. Wow, this truly is the 90s in a bottle that I remember, right before cigarettes were banned in public and authentic smartphone-free 90s techno raves became nothing but a blast from the past.

I was delighted to find out that Rush is back in the market as I thought it was discontinued and I couldn’t find it anywhere few years ago.

This is truly the scent of early 00’s but a really good one. It is quite chemical but at the same time very addictive, it’s something you have never smelled before and never will again.

For me it still smells the same as 25 years ago, maybe it’s nostalgia or maybe it’s just that it is a good perfume. I only wish Rush 2 would come back to market as well, as I thoroughly enjoyed it and it was my signature scent alongside of Envy Me, from early twenties to mid thirties. I would still purchase both of them if they were available.

review_title: a smooth mix of floral notes
review_content:
I’m am doing a review of the classic formula of Rush. I haven’t tried the newer bottles, but it may have been reformulated. I’m not sure, but just a head’s up if you’re considering this scent.

The opening of Gucci Rush is a smooth mix of floral notes and what smells like peach (though, I’m not sure this is even an ingredient since I cannot find it listed). I would say the floral aspect at the start is more dominated by the rose note and the gardenia.

Add to that is the familiar scent of patchouli, which is well blended in Rush, and never goes overboard in my mind.

Most of what you’re going to get from this one will from the peach, patchouli, and gardenia. It’s floral/fruity with a bit of a dirty side to it.

This scent just sort of grabs your attention from the get go and feels so perfectly smooth as a floral based scent and not overly ‘green’ or like you’re walking through a garden.

It has a certain energy and seductive quality to it, which I suppose is where the Rush moniker came from.

At it’s heart, Rush is a sweet perfume but once again it stays grounded by the vetiver and patchouli notes which give it an earthy/woodsy quality. Some spicy kick floating in the background, but nothing too intense.

review_title: Come on Barbie let’s go party!
review_content:
I used to love going to Bootie Mashup parties. Following the motto "We ruin your favorite songs," the big names in the scene like Dj Lobsterdust, TitusJones, and many others mercilessly mix EVERYTHING that the world of music has to offer. Pirate-pop icons like "Knock out Eileen" are still a favorite of mine to sneak into every playlist, and I would still roll up in the company parking lot with PartyBen's "Galvanize the Empire" if I hadn't gone independent years ago.
Sure, the results are musically convincing sometimes more and sometimes less, but the parties are a blast and the music is very danceable. Where so many rhythms collide, your own wiggling has to fit in somewhere.

Just like a really well-made bootleg, Gucci Rush mixes elements from well-known fragrances without regard for losses: there's the peach from Mitsouko - hardly recognizable under the thumping bass -, the smoky purring vetiver-vanilla from Habanita, and the patchouli-hedione backbone of Diorella. All of this has been shaken up with an overdose of milky-fruity lactones in a joyfully bubbling chemical cocktail, where probably no one can say anymore what originally belonged where. What emerges is a completely far-out, but extremely cheerful neo-chypre, and I strongly doubt that any of the ingredients ever grew on a plant. To me, the result smells more like a random byproduct from Walter White's trailer.
However, Rush doesn't get you high, but it does make you happy. At least me.

Spinning around on the vibrating dance floor, I sing along to snippets of songs I didn't even know I knew. Neon colors glow in the black light, swirling with me, faster and faster. Accidentally, I bump into another dancer while giggling and disappear to the bar before he can misunderstand my attack. Instead of the requested gin and tonic, the bartender sets down a glass with a bluish fluorescent liquid in front of me, grinning devilishly. I don't care! Boldly, I take a sip - and lo and behold, it tastes delicious. Just the right thing at this moment.
At some point, I find myself barefoot outside the club. I disposed of my trampled shoes in the trash can around the corner. The music pulses in my blood and the bass still thunders in my ears. The cold night air prickles on my skin as I wait for my taxi.
Tomorrow, I will be a sensible and responsible adult again. Then I'll wear Chanel or Guerlain, because I really have enough scents for the library, the theater, or a nice dinner in my perfume cabinet. Rush is certainly not the prettiest or smartest of my olfactory friends, but she's the one I love to dance with the most. She has a big mouth, but her heart is in the right place, and I don't know anyone who can laugh so heartily at herself as she can.
I don't really believe that my little (ugly!) red plastic bottle will ever be empty. But you never know...

review_title: The Red Lego Brick of the Child Woman
review_content:
I got to know Rush through the comments here and got myself a leftover bottle (as so often..).
That was about three years ago now. I often take a long time to get to know a fragrance before I write a comment.
Rush is still in my collection, still the same bottle.
The bottle itself is bright red and rather ugly, but very handy, fitting even in the tightest, overcrowded perfume cabinet and definitely has recognition value.
It also creates a certain contrast - the hard, unplayful bottle to the feminine scent.

Rush is, as mentioned, a very feminine fragrance. A bright floral scent with a bit of fruit, but never too sweet.
This femininity corresponds more to that of a young woman, lolita-like, doe-eyed, delicate. A woman, delicate with an innocent gaze, who attracts men with her big eyes and apparent fragility, awakening their protective instinct. It would have suited Kate Moss in the nineties perfectly.

Rush has a bright, floral scent character, innocent yet erotic.
I perceive the top notes most strongly with the bright freesia, gardenia, and a hint of peach. Following that, a bit of jasmine can be recognized along with a touch of fresh rose and a slight apple note behind it. Overall, it never becomes too sweet or too fruity.
