I can't directly identify coriander here; it may provide a slight, gentle spiciness, just a breeze.

Rush should not be over-applied, as it can easily come off as artificial. When applied subtly, it feels really nice on me. All in all, Rush is a well-crafted fragrance that older women can wear too - you don't have to be a Lolita to enjoy it! I'm considering getting another bottle of it.

review_title: Dirty Talk or just Gucci Rush after all...
review_content: For a long time, I resisted buying this fragrance. I know it from the past and I really don’t like the smell. Too spicy, too harsh, not sweet enough. About 2 years ago, I finally dared to order the fragrance "blind." Why? Simply in the hope that I would like the scent better at a slightly more mature age. I have always been a bit disappointed with the bottle. Okay, it is special and unique. But too angular, too plastic-like, and too synthetic for my taste. Still, it is different from other bottles. And so is the scent; different from other fragrances. When I wear Gucci Rush, my friends immediately assume that I am "on the hunt." We once had fun "studying" the effects of Gucci Rush. When I spray Gucci Rush, this scent clings to me like a magnet. Men (and some women too) hang around and often whisper some indecent things in my ear. When I wear a different fragrance, I do get approached, but usually less indecently. I asked my friends if I had "write me!" somewhere when wearing Gucci Rush. That is not the case! It seems that for some men, certain synapses are indeed activated... Synapses that lead to Dirty Talk. I mean, I have nothing against dirty thoughts, but I don’t want every third person whispering all their fantasies in my ear. I’m not a therapist for "horniness" ;). I still love the scent. Of course, also to play a little, but mainly because I simply love the fragrance. When sprayed, Gucci Rush starts off very floral and I perceive peach. Sweet, delicious peach. After a while, coriander clearly comes into play, making the scent very spicy. But I totally love this composition. Hated in the past, loved today. Over time, patchouli and vanilla join in. The scent is still sweet, but also fruity and spicy. And from this point on, the synapses are engaged. An irresistible fragrance that makes some people turn around and ask questions. The sillage is perfect. A bit intense, but bearable. Not overwhelmingly filling the room, which is totally positive. The scent lasts easily over 8 hours. It also survives hot nights and keeps the synapses busy. You can still smell the fragrance on clothes after wearing it, which I love. And all of this from an Eau de Toilette! Someone should try to replicate that. Gucci Rush will not leave my collection!

There are few fragrances that are as unmistakable, sexy, and at the same time somewhat strange to me. Rush is not one of those generic scents that get lost in the sea of successful fragrances. It is simply distinctive. I love how it envelops me and how it radiates. It is sweet, animalistic, fresh, while also being synthetic, and one should be careful not to overdo it. It definitely packs a punch. When I smell it, night falls. I see the lights of the big city. I taste beer, Vodka Red Bull, strawberry liqueur. I hear live music; rockabilly, punk rock, stoner rock, and I see hardcore shows (that’s music too ;-)). I think of the Röhren in Stuttgart, of the Submission with several floors. I set my alarm for 10 PM to get ready for the party. I remember pre-gaming with girlfriends and the hope of meeting certain guys at concerts or parties. I recall loud, wild driving music, incredibly good and terribly bad bands, sweaty crowds, sticky concert and club floors from beer, and foggy, smoky concert halls.
Furthermore, I remember the annoying birds that wouldn’t let me sleep in the early morning hours. And the Sunday morning that didn’t start until 2 PM - at the earliest. Rush accompanied me until that point and only disappeared after showering, when the hair lost the smell of smoke from washing and the remaining makeup was rinsed away. Yes, and today I sit on Sunday at 9 AM, well-rested after breakfast, still with a cup of coffee at the table, writing this and reminiscing about old times. Thanks to a spritz of Gucci Rush on my wrist. And I look forward to the next night out with a concert and girlfriends next weekend. Less wild, less long but still nice and surely accompanied by 3 spritzes of Gucci Rush.

review_title: Vladislav Balovackij. The Attempt to Land a Number-Two Hit.
review_content: *Heaven is white, because it's snowing stones again* *Ferrari or Lambo - I want both!* - thought 15-year-old Vladislav Balovackij. Eleven years and 22 number-one hits later, Vladislav sits in the basement of the villa he gifted to his mother, trying unsuccessfully to land a number-two hit. *Tell me, what should I write in my lyrics? What else should I entice you...

I have a nostalgic story connected to Gucci Rush. Let me take you back to San Diego in 1999. I had had enough of the dreary life in Switzerland and decided to travel to California for six months. So I did. Besides unforgettable experiences with a Chevy convertible on California's famous highways and wild city trips to Las Vegas and Los Angeles, I also attended a language school in downtown San Diego. The body culture had me firmly in its grip, so in addition to romantic beach volleyball sessions at the beach, I even toiled away at the gym during the day. While intensely chatting with my charming Frenchman from Paris on the cross-trainer, I flipped through Vogue magazine and discovered a fragrance sample of Gucci Rush. Once I smelled it, I was done for. I had fallen head over heels in love with the peach-freesia bouquet topped with coriander-vanilla. At the next Macy's, I quickly treated myself to the simple red plastic bottle, which was far too expensive for my standards at the time. To this day, I still don't know whether it was the influence of the coriander or the Frenchman that drove me nearly out of my mind. Regardless, this bottle has since become an essential part of my perfume collection. After all, no one wants to miss out on California feelings and French kisses from 1999. Especially not when the Backstreet Boys are crooning their hit "I Want It That Way" from their album Millennium...

Through all the comments, Gucci Rush piqued my interest. I knew this perfume, but I had never tested it. On one hand because of the ugly bottle, on the other hand because I'm not a fan of Gucci fragrances..

Today was the day. I wanted to test it.

I have to agree with the others. Yes, it is really special and I think that's a good thing!

Gucci Rush starts off directly floral sweet. I can't recognize the peach as such, just a pleasantly fruity sweetness mixed with the floral freshness of the freesia.
Jasmine follows right after and lingers relatively long. This makes the scent lightly honey-sweet and exotic. The coriander is also exotic. To be honest, that was what I feared the most. Coriander in a perfume? No, I associate coriander with Asian cuisine (not negatively, I like coriander). But I have to say, yes, that might make the scent so special and gives it this incomparable spiciness.
In combination, the fragrance is really great. Despite being an Eau de Toilette, the sillage is simply insane. The scent has been clinging to my wrist for 9 hours and keeps coming back to my nose...

One thing I must criticize though.. Unfortunately, Gucci Rush doesn't smell as great on me towards the end as it does in the heart note. Unfortunately, no vanilla and patchouli in sight (maybe it’s also due to my skin). Towards the end, it has a slight "cleaning note." It smells like a perfumed bathroom cleaner or something similar. I can't describe it well... But this smell then dampened my enthusiasm and kept me from purchasing it. Because if it weren't for this peculiar note, I would have definitely bought it. I have enough fragrances, but this one is quite special and so beautiful and timeless at the beginning..

Maybe it’s better this way, because I actually have enough perfumes and my boyfriend (whom I never listen to regarding fragrances) said that the bottle looks like a cassette recorder ;D

To all lovers: It's on sale in turquoise, so grab it ;) I wouldn't be surprised if it gets discontinued soon :(

review_title: this should appeal to the XTC generation
review_content:
Also such a strange thing. When I have Rush, it feels different....
It is based on a patchouli/vanillin/undecalactone accord. But once this combo of patchouli/lactone has gripped the brain like an old rag, it’s unfortunately over. A fitting description I once read is also: "smells like teenage bad breath"....

Gucci Rush is one of the few mainstream fragrances that has remained consistent in both the scent itself and in my appreciation from day one.
Late nineties: Gucci completely changes the image of the noble but trend-wise outdated Italian leather and fashion manufacturer and reinvents itself with the help of Tom Ford. The relaunch hits like a bomb, and Gucci Rush surpasses the label's first fragrance "Envy" by far in sales and success. The bottle of both fragrances comes from Tom Ford, and while Envy was still understated-elegant in appearance and feel, he created with Rush a bottle that truly polarized. It repelled me, as I was a fan of the old school when it came to bottles, and thus very fond of Shalimar and L'air du temps.
But the scent!
It was often mentioned in the same breath as cocaine, and the parallels are easy to recognize:
Hot and cold, exciting, a high indeed. RUSH as in Gold Rush, not Rush hour.
A sparkling sweetness runs through the scent profile, which has an inexplicable freshness despite the floral heaviness. I also notice a champagne mood that arises when I use Rush. And last but not least, it arouses a desire for sex, something I don't experience with any other fragrance.
The sillage is and was brilliant; you are noticed and you notice yourself.
Now a classic, groundbreaking, often copied, but never matched (Clive Christian has, in my humble opinion, also borrowed, but at what cost....)

review_title: Men's Magnet, Flower Sex or the Ultimate Experience?
review_content:
Totally hooked by several comments here, I just had to test Gucci's Rush. I already knew the summer version Rush 2 from before, but I didn't find it that special either. So, I marched into the perfume store and tested the red plastic bottle that is referred to as a men's magnet.
It was a warm day, and I found the scent to be simply "Wow" ... probably also influenced by the many comments I had read here beforehand.
The bottle was on sale, so it came home with me... I was totally happy and euphoric, and the air conditioning blew the scent around me the entire way home. What a hit :) Provocative!
That evening, I went out to see the reactions. Nothing happened... no one said you smell good... or what a sexy scent. No, I had to hear from male friends that the scent doesn't suit me at all... etc. A big disappointment on my part :(
Now finally to the scent:
Rush starts with a loud peach-flower note that smells really delicious. But then something comes in that I must have totally overlooked in my euphoria. A lot of coriander... and the annoying thing is... the cooler the temperatures, the stronger this note becomes... I can't sniff it... it causes nausea, it comes out really bitter on my skin. I don't smell jasmine or rose at all.
Bitter-sweet, smelling like a mushy peach, it remains until Rush becomes bearable again.
When patchouli, vanilla, and vetiver unite, it becomes quite nice in the base. I find that enchanting... but the scent is already quite faint on me, so in this case, it might just be enough for flower sex :)
The longevity is about 8 hours, and the sillage is very loud at first... but it becomes quite quiet over time.
The red plastic bottle is quite nice and, above all, shatterproof.
Conclusion:
Overripe coriander-peach with a still beautiful drydown. Unfortunately, there's nothing magnetic about it for me ;)
I also apologize for my statement that was written in extreme euphoria after I got home from my perfume purchase.
To all those for whom the scent has the said effect... I'm really happy for you if it is the ultimate experience for you. My bottle can move out again... the coriander ruins the scent for me too much, and with nausea, not even a flower sex mood can arise ;)

When it comes to fragrance purchases, I am truly not a penny pincher - my dear husband can sing a song about it - but Rush is still not in my collection.

However, I don't find the scent bad at all - upon closer inspection, it's even distinctive.
I think the unwieldy brick bottle has dampened my desire to buy, because the eye eats - or rather, smells with.

But if I set aside the exterior, I encounter a meaningful fragrance.
Moreover, it is not "in a rush" - rather, it takes its time.

Floral freesia and juicy peach are well balanced, and receive a spicy twist from coriander.
Jasmine and rose gently but clearly join in, gaining stability from sweet vetiver and soft vanilla.
Patchouli adds a certain depth.

Not an everyday scent, as I unfairly assumed at first - due to its plastic block appearance.
Here, once again, the inner values count.

I notice that it is often gentlemen who take it to the checkout - either they wear it themselves or gift it to their girlfriend.
Both are possible.

For me, a scent with a delayed Aha effect - overwhelmingly.

The scent is quickly dealt with: For people who like fragrances with development, it can be interesting. KN has a certain freshness that gradually transitions into a powdery-solid base. No killer sillage, longevity is okay, overall it comes across as rather subtle-clean. It’s doable.

Let’s talk about the elephant in the room.
Imagine you are a perfumer. Gucci hires you: Create a scent for us. You say: Okay.
Instruction: It should result in a "It’s doable" scent. You think, weigh options, try one direction, attempt another, sniff, discard, redo, change things up, revisit something, time passes, final touches, scent finished. You know you haven’t created a unique masterpiece, but a fragrance with a decent 7.4 on Parfumo and it has been produced for over a quarter of a century - your effort, your expertise, and your result can’t be that bad.

And then they bottle your scent in a brick???????????
That’s how you go from perfumer to bullying victim. Or was a bet simply lost?

Mjaaa, I suppose, one could argue that it has a certain uniqueness. Unlike the similarly flat Idole bottles, it doesn’t fall over with every gust of air because it’s sensibly placed on the longer side. It takes a real gust of wind to knock it over.

I’ll accept uniqueness (if one is not familiar with the Idole bottles), but I’m not willing to attest originality to it. It is far from the elegant simplicity that a Chanel No. 5 bottle radiates.
They could have salvaged the thing if they had used somewhat higher quality materials. However, when I held the bottle in my hand yesterday, I was appalled by this cheap, lightweight plastic. Folks, that’s outright refusal to work. If I were teaching product design at a vocational college, the student who seriously handed me something like this should be careful that I don’t (**********); it would be more honest to just not submit anything at all.

What I give the bottle credit for: It negates aesthetics and value, but at least it doesn’t negate 200 years of emancipation, unlike those failed caricatures of Good Girl. Those things have nothing to do with shoes or bottles. My opinion.
That’s why it gets 1 point. On one hand, you can’t give 0.5 for bottles, and on the other hand, 0 is too little because the scent is delivered in a spray container, and at least you don’t have to carry the fragrance home in your bare hands.

I have owned Gucci Rush for a while now and can only describe it properly over time, as it develops differently depending on the outside temperature. At the Christmas market, it is a lovely floral companion, but it only unfolds its full potential for me at warmer temperatures. At the temperatures prevailing today (summery, but still bearable, at least in the apartment), it comes quite close to its name "Rush," which translates to "intoxication," among other things. The intoxication is hidden in a red Lego block, and the commercial for it is musically underlaid with beats: fast, electric, synthetic.

A synthetic touch seems to be present in Gucci's Rush as well. The scent is fruity-floral-spicy-powdery-milky. I find it difficult to pick out individual scent components; they are very closely intertwined. I also think I can recognize pineapple, yes, pineapple, and milk. Somehow, I even have to think of banana split. On one hand, it is sweet, but on the other hand, it rises up against the lovely sweetness and excessive pleasantness with an inherent roughness. Coriander could be responsible for this, as it creates an idiosyncratic connection with fruit and flower, and patchouli also comes into play. This roughness has something very intimate about it, somehow heading towards sweat. If there were more of it in the scent, I wouldn't dare to wear it. Over time, the intoxication becomes darker, deeper, more harmonious, and the roughness diminishes.

In midsummer - and I know this from personal experience - at around 36 degrees Celsius outside, it is an imposition for the environment, although it might also have been due to excessive dosing. I have no idea how much one has to pour over oneself to overwhelm the environment with it, but the mother of my former roommate managed to do that in our home. I’ll just say: super summer, very hot, you can't open the windows during the day because of the heat, and then Gucci Rush overwhelming in the apartment. I was done.

Gucci's Rush wants to play: with me, with my environment. Therefore, I wouldn't wear it to a business meeting. However, for a date, if I already know the man or can at least assess him. If I know that there is a certain harmony or attraction between us. Because I do not perceive Gucci's Rush as harmonizing precisely because of its rough component. It can intensify an existing attraction, but it only becomes calming and balancing later, when the aforementioned component recedes into the background.

The intoxicating scent lasts long on me, and I find the sillage bearable and definitely not overwhelming. However, a hallucinogenic effect has not occurred for me - even after multiple uses and different dosages. But that is not the purpose of this intoxication anyway.

The bottle is so off-putting, but it is also a testament to the fact that appearances can be deceiving. This ugly case (which unfortunately can never be completely emptied) has enchanted me and continues to do so even after 20 years.
I have never been so inspired by patchouli with vanilla and jasmine.
I couldn’t care less if it has become mainstream… I’ve been using it from the very beginning and it always awakens my inner goddess.
I would love more of this… but I would greatly appreciate a prettier bottle!

Does this community really need the 598th comment on this fragrance? Some will say: no, I already know it, I've had it, or I don't like it. Others may have only noticed the red block on the table with the offers and not paid further attention. However, since "need" plays only a minor role in this forum, regarding perfume in general and collections beyond, let's say, one to three bottles, I have decided to share a few words about Rush. Because this fragrance deserves it!

When it was released, Rush was a hit! The unusual bottle, fire red and made of plastic, was something completely different and fit well with the times. I didn't find the design beautiful back then. I prefer glass bottles, heavy and straightforward, or even opulent and sparkling, but in any case, with a pleasant feel. This flashy Lego brick is none of those. The handling is anything but nice. Awkward and annoying, until the spray finally lands where I want it, always at risk of needing to see a chiropractor afterward, with a dislocated wrist. With 5 sprays of Rush on, a joy for any therapist.

This scent blows me away; it is still sensational. When it came out, many had it, which is always the case with new releases, and there were other beauties at the time that were not to be underestimated. I liked it a lot, but after one bottle, it was over between us. Until I reclaimed it now. And it has reclaimed me!

A floral scent, indeed, and these are generally not my thing. But here, it lacks that cuteness, playfulness, that daisy and ruffle attitude that the Chloes, for example, are supposed to convey. This flower here is different. Sexy, self-assured, provocative. Feminine, but not girlish. And certainly not matronly. Longevity and sillage are top-notch. For me, Rush is a puregoing-out scent. To all the women on the prowl who enjoy flirting: spray on Rush, slip into jeans, leather jacket, and dive into the nightlife!

Anyone who knows the film Sin City surely still has the city amazons in mind and Goldie, who drove Marv crazy with her scent. It could have been Rush.

review_title: And here's to you, Mrs. Robinson, Jesus loves you more than you will know.....
review_content:
...God bless you, please Mrs. Robinson.
Heaven holds a place for those who pray,
Hey, hey, hey
Hey, hey, hey

"Do you want to pick up a young guy??"

That's what a friend asked me recently when we went out one evening and I was wearing this scent!
"The smell is kind of porn!!" she said.

I was initially shocked.

Although I also found the scent really great, "porn"
- that association didn't come to my mind at all.
However, this was to change over the course of the evening, as quite a few guys approached me.
And NO: I didn't have a plunging neckline, no high heels, and no "I'm-me" look.
I wasn't even particularly styled.

"Wow - you smell really great"
"Awesome perfume"
"You smell amazing"

Yes, I heard such lyrical comments :-)

The red something seems to be a true magnet for men.
This also fits with the countless descriptions from previous commentators.
I didn't know it before.
This red VHS tape look always put me off.
But I really have to say that the blind purchase was worth it after I became aware of the scent here in the forum.

As for the scent itself, I must first highlight the great longevity and, as mentioned above, the insane sillage.
With my hat, the top note somehow completely disappears.
Immediately, jasmine and rose spread out, which generally always come out very strong for me.
It seems to be a dark rose with many dangerous thorns.
From the base, a very sultry patchouli stands out, which makes the scent truly refined, mysterious, and absolutely sexy.
I have the image of sitting in a leather armchair.
Dark corset, red lipstick.
Some cigarette holder, whiskey - like Stifler's mom.
And yes, I like this image.
Young guys around offering me snacks and gazing at me.
I mean hey, if men pick up young girls, why shouldn't I do the same.
There are plenty of ladies who, even if only occasionally, appreciate a young guy.
Basically the opposite of a Lolita scent :-)

It's remarkable how scents like this can really give you confidence.
Confidence and strength.
They encourage me to be a little unreasonable for an evening.
Life is so short, and one should occasionally break the rules.

Be crazy once and escape all constraints.
Don't think about tomorrow.
Be a vamp.

You can do that in RUSH with the greatest pleasure.

However, you shouldn't spray too much.
Otherwise, you might come off as the Dangerous Woman, like a "she-wants-to-know" type.
And that doesn't have to be the case.

And even NON LETHAL WEAPONS can be very dangerous if used improperly and in excessive amounts!

So ladies, when you apply the scent:

Fill out the weapon permit, straighten your crown, and then:
ENJOY!!!!!!

Well, I've never come across anything like this! So cheeky! So frivolous! So red! So plastic and so unwieldy! And yes...so mmmh!
The list of "so's" could go on indefinitely and perhaps change a little every day. Because the scent is not always the same, just like the mood of the wearer isn't. Sometimes it seems cheerier to me, sometimes more subdued, sometimes cheeky, and then again more melancholic. One thing, however, is always true: it's unusual!
The ignition of this red fragrance powerhouse happens with a twist of Freesia and Gardenia, which really kick things into high gear. If you press the peach pedal right after, the engine practically roars. If you give it enough room with the right dash of coriander, the roaring turns into a loud and dangerous hissing! Then the fun begins! The red speedster revs its molecules until they smoke and finally launches from its starting point. You really have to keep a concentrated eye on it, or else it's out of sight. It has already left other drivers behind. The high-gloss body reflects sunlight briefly like a flash, then the "sled" takes the first curve and leaves behind a scent trail like no other. Jasmine and rose wear off quite quickly. Instead, patchouli is ignited, and not sparingly. As it approaches the next bend, vetiver intervenes and manages to contribute something hearty and fresh before the powerhouse starts to overtake the other cars. Relentlessly, it zips past them like a red arrow, some look downright left behind when it leaves them in its wake again. The class difference is clearly visible and leaves no questions unanswered. This red lacquered chassis has the devil in the gearbox, and it's letting loose passionately!
Gucci Rush is fast and sleek, curvy and alluring, feminine and energetic, unabashed and loud. You need a bit of courage or the right mood for such a race. And this car doesn't let just anyone take the wheel. You have to be enough of a woman to be allowed to get in, otherwise the scent strengths will overwhelm you, and instead of on the podium, you’ll end up in the piled-up tires at the side of the track or in the ditch.
It has to fit; otherwise, everything feels out of place. And I find the plastic container somewhat out of place for such a powerful and untamed scent. If it were any stronger, it would blow its unstable casing apart. What belongs here is a proper, heavy, deep red, straightforward bottle made of solid glass that keeps the inner demons in check until their release.
You wouldn't pack pearls in a jute bag or diamonds in a paper cup!

Rush is for me the hippie among my fragrances, even though it doesn't actually come from that era and I didn't experience that time myself. Yes, I have to think of the hippie movement of the 60s/70s with its search for new ideals, escape from societal constraints, Woodstock, the music of Jimi Hendrix, San Francisco, Johnny Depp in Blow. Feelings come from within us, from the gut, from the heart, and they don't need long justification.

At a first encounter with Rush, it is immediately clear - repulsive or extremely attractive. It's not a fragrance that a woman (man?) has to think long about. Upon first spraying, Rush hits the nose immediately and explosively. The description of the cute top note actually contradicts my perception. However, since coriander follows relatively quickly and then this absolutely g e n i u s connection with patchouli and vetiver takes place, the top note quickly becomes history. A strong preference for patchouli should be present.

The floral (the classic part) component (rose, magnolia, jasmine) has been well integrated, bringing together with patchouli and coriander sex and strong attraction, soft elements into play, a hint of vanilla. I don't even have to think of a dominatrix whip with this scent, nor do I want to.

I see this fragrance on quirky young women who stand out from the Heidi Klum breeding selection and have their own head and style, and definitely late hippies and all those who simply find Rush genius, like I do. Rush is close to the skin, deep and warm, yet not overly sweet, a truly successful oriental.

In this sense, friends, PEACE and be humane to one another!

review_title: No Overachiever - Still a Very Good Performance
review_content:
Here, I am oddly struck by a sense of nostalgia for high school.
To put it bluntly.
I was glad to have outgrown school, and my time there was, like for everyone, sometimes more and sometimes less amusing.
I experienced my first parties with Gucci Rush.

Memories of hedonistic pleasures and indulging in nihilistic thoughts, curious searching, finding, and discarding concepts come alive.

Personalities that would suit the perfume, in my opinion, would be Kate Moss or Amy Winehouse. Rush is not for the very well-behaved.
Spicy coriander meets floral notes and a synthetic peach. A matter of taste. Polarizing.

It doesn't quite fit me anymore, but I wouldn't want to miss it. I feel the same way about my white Fender Stratocaster, equipped with a temperamental tremolo that makes tuning it difficult.

I actually like the bottle, contrary to many opinions; the design has remained somewhat dry or plain in its statement, but the boxy shape reminds me of Lenovo ThinkPads and thus at least doesn't evoke any bad associations.

review_title: If only the coriander weren't there...
review_content:
Oh, Gucci. Why, why only?... Why are most of your fragrances so disappointing or at least just plain banal? I had fallen in love with Gucci pour Homme II (I unfortunately don't know the first Homme...) and then tested various other men's fragrances from Gucci. And although I don't know all the other fragrances yet, all those I tested were quite boring, unremarkable, and scents that you could actually forget after testing. And finding that out even hurt, after I had given GpH II a full 10 points!

I don't know yet if it's the same with the women's fragrances. At least, I've heard that Rush is supposed to be one of the better scents, according to a good friend. So now I'm excited to apply this fragrance and hope to smell a good Gucci scent again, even if it should (once again) be for you ladies.

Okay, I'm starting now... but I can already see that coriander is listed in the fragrance pyramid... it stands out to me!...

The scent:
The scent starts with freesias that smell slightly stuffy and floral. Along with that, you can smell a nice peach that gives the fragrance a fruity note. So far, so good, and everything is okay!
And then it’s there,… the coriander. Unmistakably malicious, it wreaks havoc in the otherwise nice fragrance and makes my mouth corners turn down, but I’ll hold off for now and hope that everything turns for the better…
The jasmine gives the fragrance a sweet note and also somewhat covers the coriander. But I still don’t find the scent that appealing, as it… well… doesn’t smell that great.
A light rose, slightly synthetic smelling, comes through and blends well with the jasmine, which by now also smells slightly powdery.
Well, after a while, the coriander recedes a bit and the floral notes lose some of their stuffiness. Now, slowly moving towards the base, patchouli and vanilla join in, although the vanilla is somewhat weak. The scent remains with a light peach note, a sweet jasmine-rose mix, and slightly powdery vanilla. The coriander, which has mostly faded, still lingers in the background and, in my opinion, gives the fragrance a disturbing and unpleasant note that brings the entire scent down a bit :(

The sillage and longevity:
The sillage is okay, the scent will be somewhat pleasant to smell, but I still find the ratings here on Parfumo a bit too high; however, it could also be that the fragrance may have been reformulated since 1999 and thus lost some strength. The longevity is okay at about eight hours.

The bottle:
The bottle is rectangular, slim, and made of plastic. It has a red color and the name of the fragrance is written on the side. The spray head is integrated in the middle, which you just have to press down. Interesting in itself, but it looks like it’s more from the 80s or early 90s.
And strictly speaking, one could even consider it as a somewhat oversized sweetener dispenser. Nevertheless, I find the bottle quite okay, as it is something different.

Well, what can I say. Rush has not turned out to be a standout, which is just my opinion, as I don’t like coriander and this fragrance especially radiates a bit too much of it in the initial phase and, of course, the heart note before it fades a bit in the base, but is still detectable. Without it, the fragrance would have actually been much better and would have received a significantly higher rating from me.
Well, Rush has the potential to be better. I wonder if Rush 2 is better... I’ll have to test it sometime!

Because especially in summer, coriander can be very piercing, while all the other fragrance notes are rather tuned for summer or warm days, as the scent is sweet but not overwhelmingly sweet. It’s suitable for many situations, maybe even for going out, although it could have a stronger sillage for that (which would probably also have intensified the coriander… a vicious circle!).

So, for those who are not very bothered by coriander (as it is weaker in the base), you get an above-average good fragrance from Gucci. It is definitely worth testing, but whether you will smell nice with it… well, you’ll have to try that for yourself; I think probably not :D

Rush starts off sweet-sour fruity and with a tingling sensation in the nose. Others mention pepper, but the scent reminded me more of an overripe peach that is slowly fermenting and taking on a slightly alcoholic, sparkling note.

What bothers me is this cheesy note that develops very close to the skin with the first spray. I read online that certain citrus fruits as well as certain wines (the fermenting peach?) can produce this cheesy scent character. There is also a cheesy character in the malt absolute used in Thierry Mugler's "Human Scent." Perhaps the cheesiness is the scent note that Murcie perceives in her great comment as "animal presence that almost brushes against the obscene." After all, it should also imitate the human scent in TM.

I became aware of Rush through Murcie's comment, and she was so kind to send me a sample (thank you, Murcie!). But personally, I find Rush too sweet and nice due to its fruitiness. I don't find anything obscene here. No dominatrix. But also no gray mouse. It should be a middle ground. Mistress Lillifee, indeed.

And her accessories would look like THIS:
http://www.worleygig.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/12/pink-sadomaso.jpg
;-)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I perceive Rush as very close to the skin with little sillage, and the top and heart notes are very rush past.
What remains is a powdery, sweet vanilla scent. But it lasts quite a while. I could still smell it the next morning.
Patchouli hardly comes through on my skin, but it is very present (and delicious!) on the test strip. I can also find the coriander there.

As I wrote elsewhere virtually: Gucci Rush is "Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!" in a bottle! The name says it all, this stuff has real speed!

The cherry-red plastic bottle, resembling my son's Lego bricks, prepares you for this unusual fragrance that doesn't rely on top, heart, and base notes.

Rush's fragrance components, including magnolia, freesia, patchouli, rose, and hmmmm, vanilla, join hands to slyly and cheerfully outpace one another. When the losing accord catches up with the others, it does so not to merge with them into a harmonious blend that relaxes on the wearer's skin, no! Like a spiral, it outshines the others, who fall behind and slightly stumble, only to charge ahead again shortly after.

Impetuous, yet perfectly balanced, this floral-milky-fruity-vanilla whirlwind dances on the skin. Sometimes it smells predominantly floral with a fruity accent that somehow reminds me of apples. Just as I come to this conclusion and inhale another whiff of Rush, I catch a hint of patchouli, slightly spicy components, and vanilla, which have stepped forward in a flattering and irresistible manner, promising me, like sirens, that the next adventure is surely coming. And one thing is clear, no adventure, no "Faster Pussycat!" without Rush, this crazy, irrationally unforgettable (neo-)chypre.

Just the thought that this "substance" might be discontinued triggers acute withdrawal symptoms in me...

Unconventional, gentle and bitter, spicy and sweet, strong and mild, subtle and striking,
multidimensional and a harmonious whole.

I find it special, I think it's great.

review_title: A Mix of Man Magnet and Diva
review_content: I must admit, I have quite an ambivalent attitude towards this fragrance. On one hand, I find it rather unpleasant when I inhale it directly; on the other hand, it captivates me when I apply it sparingly or sniff it from a distance. My boyfriend feels similarly - at first, he found it off-putting when he smelled it directly on my wrist, but later he had to admit that "Rush" is...

Rush is a very complex fragrance with inner contradictions. Once the top notes faded, it felt to me as if two scents were separately perceivable side by side: on one hand, a distinctly sweet, sultry-fruity scent (I can really relate to the comparison with Lolita's eraser), but alongside it, there is also a peppery-smoky, dark, and almost dangerous note (the comparison with...

Since the TV commercial is very erotic and Gucci is all about sex sells, and this fragrance is said to be very sexy according to comments, I thought (as a little addict of erotic scents that make every man instantly frisky) that I absolutely have to test Gucci Rush! Even though the bottle looks like it’s from Mattel... When I sprayed it, I immediately thought: This...

Do you remember those fragrant erasers and colorful pens and ballpoints that you found on every Diddl-Shop counter in the 80s, and how the checkout line always got longer and angrier because the pubescent kids had to sniff through all the stuff, from keychains to scented stickers?

Yes, okay, I'm talking about myself, and I hereby apologize to the annoyed cashiers, to whom I certainly didn't make life easier even at a young age with my 50 pfennig budget.

In any case, RUSH original smells as red as depicted, and the bottle looks just like a sugary peach-strawberry(!)-vanilla Ratzefummel!

Yes, yes, Rush is a fragrance that polarizes.
I came across this scent four years ago when a colleague wore it. I liked it immediately (on her), and thus I was tempted into a spontaneous blind buy. Well, you all know how it goes. The initial euphoria quickly turned into a gag reflex when I sprayed it for the first time.

I only smelled pepper (of the worst kind) that went straight through my nose and flooded every single brain wave.
Panic set in.
This must be how an attacker feels when they get a face full of pepper spray from their victim!

This cannot possibly be THE scent I smelled on my colleague.
It was quickly scrubbed off and banished to the very back of my bathroom cabinet, never to return.

As it goes - after some time, I gave the fragrance a second chance.
This time, very, very sparingly dosed, I didn't have that "shotgun pepper blast" feeling as intensely.
I remained persistent and brave and wore the scent all day.

And suddenly - whoosh - after the initial pepper disaster, the fragrance began to unfold beautifully. I smelled like a wonderful bouquet: gardenia (very strong), freesia, and definitely peach.

Fantastic - THAT was what I smelled on my colleague.

The scent is very intense and lasts fantastically long on me. When I wear it all day, I smell the lovely vanilla by evening.

Conclusion: If you heroically survive the pepper spray blast, something wonderful unfolds that lasts immensely long.

review_title: They probably wanted to go all in on Sex Sells in their ad
review_content:
The big marketing creative directors at Gucci should know better and, at the latest since Lindstrom, that sex only advertises itself.
In the end, the ad is anyway inappropriate for the fragrance, which initially smells overly loaded and unpleasantly of freesias and gardenias, and later transforms into a very sweet and actually quite delicious scent of artificial roses and vanillas. Patchouli acts as a big plus in the background, but overall it remains a teen fragrance for me, no longer suitable for anyone over 15. Other associations are images of innocent underwear printed with strawberries.

~ Inspiration ~
I once tested Rush II and found it quite good, as it reminded me of sunscreen. Recently, I happened to receive a sample of Rush.

~ Bottle ~
Cumbersome, but extraordinary.
The square, narrow shape and especially the striking color draw attention. The name means something like "hurry" or "rush" and conveys a fast and hectic impression to me, which, however, does not match the scent.

~ Fragrance ~
The top note impresses with peach, but the freesia keeps it from being too sweet. In the heart note, rose and jasmine come to the forefront, blending with the peach. Coriander adds a slightly spicy undertone. It is rounded off in the base note by patchouli, vanilla, and vetiver. I perceive it as fruity-floral-creamy-spicy.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 7-8 hours (a bit longer on clothing and hair). 2 sprays are sufficient, as it might become too intense and sweet.

~ Occasion ~
I find that it suits work well in spring or summer, but also for leisure activities. For evenings or going out, it is too boring for me.

~ Conclusion ~
There is a certain similarity to AN'NA by Annayake and Bruno Banani Woman. Those who like these fragrances will also find Rush great. Unfortunately, there are too many notes in this perfume that I do not like as much (peach, rose, and vetiver).

I bought this fragrance for the first time 10 years ago and I keep coming back to it every now and then. It's a lovely oriental with a lot of patchouli, which prevents it from being too sweet. The red bottle also complements the perfume very nicely.

I have never experienced such a contradictory fragrance..... It comes out completely differently on each person, in my opinion, with massive fluctuations....

My thoughts on women who wear this scent are as follows:

Young woman, I want to approach you IMMEDIATELY BECAUSE you are wearing Gucci Rush!

Or:

Young woman, forgive me, but please keep at least 5 meters away - BECAUSE you are wearing Gucci Rush.....

I personally am male and wear this fragrance.... On people for whom it works well, it smells very sexual and sensual, and one should be aware of that.

It is rather less suitable for the office, although sometimes I wear it during the day out of longing for this scent........

review_title: The bottle kept me from trying it for ages...
review_content: I found the bottle - this square plastic box! - so awful that I didn't try the fragrance for a long time. However, when I finally did, it convinced me. Unfortunately, at some point I developed a rash from the scent, which is why I no longer use it.

review_title: Lay back and remember to the 90s
review_content: Wonderful or not for other generations... I have a well-known fondness for discontinued fragrances and rarities, so I was all the happier to be able to call a very generous decant of this retro candidate my own, thanks to a dear friend from the perfume community. The old-timers will remember this beautiful scent, which starts off cocktail-like with a peach. I immediately think of Grandma's peach punch, clean freesia, which we know from Chloe Signature, and gardenia, which always brings that green blooming garden feeling for me. Spicy coriander, but beware, definitely not soapy here! Yes, those were the days when the heart, top, and base notes together had at least 12 components. In conclusion, still no olfactory rush hour. Spring in a bottle! Clean, fruity, and green-floral, essentially a freshie from the 90s. The only downside is the shabby bottle, which has always kept me from adding it to my collection.

This is definitely something to my taste. Spicy, floral - but not too much - and my beloved patchouli gives it a smoky touch. Not always for me, but every now and then.
The only downside: the bottle looks great, but it's a bit awkward for not-so-large hands. Design takes precedence over user-friendliness here. But it's a fragrance, not a dish brush!

I know, I have it myself too, for whatever reason, but I've only used it once since then, before that just tested it repeatedly in the perfumery.
It smells unpleasant to me, it reminds me of something I don't like. Patchouli is too little for me here. One scent note bothers me immensely, maybe the coriander? It smells spicy and sweet and warm and heavy. I think of older ladies and the faux leather of the old "DDR" trains. The bottle is really ugly too. I first thought there was a camera lying around.

Well, soon I will probably be lighter by one perfume again.

review_title: Not for me - or maybe it is?
review_content:
Well, in that sense, it is mine. I once received it as a gift and sprayed it two or three times to try it out, but I never went out with it. It smells terrible on me. Synthetic, it stings the nose. This doesn’t get any better even after wearing it for a longer time. On others, however, I like the way it smells; it has a high recognition value. No, it’s not for me.

Addendum, 24.11.2010:
I just checked on eBay what prices one can achieve for a 75ml bottle that has been sprayed three to four times. It could be worth it... After that, I thought I might give it another try - and lo and behold, is it fear of loss or has my taste or sense of smell changed in such a short time? In any case, I suddenly don’t find it so terrible anymore. Still sweet-spicy (yes, I find it sweet), still a bit synthetic, but somehow... better. I will test it throughout the day tomorrow (for which occasion which perfume is for, work or leisure or anything else, usually doesn’t matter to me; I just go by the season and my mood) and then possibly revise my previous judgment.
Result: No. It just doesn’t fit. I will not keep it.

I had almost given up on Gucci fragrances. I had disliked all the female scents, (with the exception of Envy Me 2) and had little enthusiasm when I came around to trying their male scents.

What can I say? I like all that I have tried so far. Gucci pour Homme is to die for.

This fragrance is spicy, woodsy and masculine; all that a man should be. With such complexity within this composition one might expect a disaster, but have no fear, Gucci pour Homme is so well blended.

The opening is extremely powerful. One should wait until the fragrance has settled and dried on the skin before inhaling this wonderous scent. The top notes are mostly intense spices with a smokiness that resembles the scent of a smouldering cigar. The whole experience is almost aromatic.

Towards the drydown, incense, papyrus, leather, musk, vetiver, vanilla, patchouli and oakmoss become more prominent, creating an earthy and dry finish that is rather sensual, warm and mysterious. The sillage and lasting strength is better than good. It is truly amazing.

I haven't come across anything that smells this good on a man yet. I do more than recommend this fragrance, I urge all men to go out and buy it.

I had never smelled this perfume until this year, I am a young person. I blind bought it because of the hype this one has in the market.
What I have learned about vintage and discontinued fragrance is that yes, they are good, but people say wonderful things about them because they are perfumes that accompanied them for years in their lives, with which they created memories, with which they grew up.

When you smell a perfume that you had a long time ago, it creates a knot in your stomach that makes you relive everything you lived when you applied it and it is wonderful, but when a person has never smelled that perfume before, he/she has a completely different vision.
Gucci I is a good perfume, vintage-like. Men's perfumery in these years has taken another direction, so it doesn't say anything to me.
It's a good perfume, no doubt about it, but not for me. I would not recommend this perfume to someone who has never had it or smelled it, and even less at the current prices.

In my opinion it's the best designer's woody/incense fragrance that i have and tried. Extremely masculine and sexy.

Some herbs and spices in the opening. In the middle phase i can smell a pimento note and some pepper but soon the woody notes joins and then it develops to a rather dark/heavy woody fragrance with incense.

Excellent sillage, lasting power and projection. Smells more mature. Definitely worth it.

Updated January 2014

I've never worn a Gucci fragrance before. There I said it. So please forgive a non-haute-fashion perspective on this fragrance, but I'll cut to the chase if this is already offending your fashion sense: I was unimpressed.

Yes, the orange color was interesting, but the fact that my sample came in a orange translucent pouch was not (at least the color avoided the condom implications of Porsche Design's The Essence).

What I got out of this was a full-scale, Defcon 5, round-up-everyone-for-military-service-including-70-year-old-men-who-can-barely-walk PEPPER ATTACK! This lasts for six hours and is so intense that I sneezed a few times. Not fun. Eventually it moderates somewhat and introduces a slight smoke accord, followed much later by some aromatic non-cedar woods. The fragrance structure would suggest base notes here, but the only woods that fit the description are top notes. Oh, and of course there's the annoying vanilla note somewhere between the beginning and the end, but it's mercifully short.

So Gucci, you haven't won me over. Plenty of scents use pepper without burying me in it (Herrera and Memoir Man, for instance). I realize that my skin amps pepper quite a bit, but this was just short of Yatagan-induced nausea for me.

A little spice, a little smoke, a HECK OF A LOT OF CEDAR! My wife brought this home for me from a closeout at a grocery store or something saying she smelled it in the store an liked it (maybe $30 USD at the time). I sprayed it on a was instantly in love and we went back to see if they had anymore. Unfortunately they did not. Well I used the bottle up until it was bone dry thinking I would find another somewhere and by the time I did it was already going for over $100. Now it is astronomical if you can find it. Was it a great cedar? Yes, one of the best I have smelt. Is it worth hundreds of dollars? Nope, not to me. Enjoyed, loved, remembered, but there are to many great scents to try and replace it with another bottle.

review_title: This was my all times favorite scent, sadly discontinued
review_content: Sadly discontinued many years ago, this perfume was a bomb of cedar wood, incense and spices. A scent made for a mature refined gentleman, self-confident, well-dressed and elegant. I spent years trying to find a scent with the same dna as Gucci pour Homme. The one which comes closer will be Bentley Absolute, the difference is, that the Bentley have oud and the Gucci have...

review_title: Gucci Pour Homme 1. We got that wood
review_content:
Gucci Pour Homme 1 is definitely an experience and I'm very lucky to be able to smell it and have a bottle myself. I've heard this stuff has become discontinued and very hard to find. I have almost a full bottle and I'm going to be using it sparingly. GPH1 is one of the few designer fragrances that helped build up my collection. GPH1, TDH, and Polo Blue were my trifecta. I will eventually have reviews out for all of those so I hope you enjoy them. I went into GPH1 blind so here's what I got from the rocky beginning to the much calmer review.

The Smell: GPH1 Is a beautiful scent that leans on the masculine side. Women can pull it off too. If you're a fan of the woods, cedar, with a hint of pepper and that legendary drydown, this is for you. There are a ton of notes listed in the breakdown regardless where you go. I've learned early that the breakdown isn't accurate. Feel it out yourself. It's heavy on the cedar and pepper on my skin. I've read where people compare it to pencil shavings and, while they're entitled to that opinion, I disagree. If I had pencil shavings that smelled this good, I would've had it made in high school. It pretty much stays with the cedar and the pepper throughout the life of the fragrance on me with the amber showing up late to the party per usual. As far as designer scents go, not many do woods like this one. This one can put many niche scents to shame also so that should tell you it's a competitor.
Rating: 8/10

Projection: Pretty good. Usually wood scents will dial it up on the projection especially because they typically have amazing heart and bottom notes. It's no difference with GPH1. It starts out strong and keeps going for about the first 4-5 hours and then it dissipates to somewhat of a skin scent on me for the remainder. Going by my usual process, 4-5 hours would be an automatic 5 or lower (other intangibles to consider). 4-5 hours of solid projection plus the fact that it hangs around after that and people can still smell it on me while about 4-6 feet away is still great. If you're looking for the "loud and proud" scent on this one, go back to the Invictus/Sauvage counter because that's more up your alley. This isn't that, nor does it try to be. It's great how it is.
Rating: 7/10

Price Point: Here's where it gets tough. You have to dig to find this thing. It's been discontinued so you'll be paying anywhere from $95-$450 USD (eBay). It's crazy. You just better hope you get the cheaper end. I, personally, don't believe that GPH1 is worth $450 so the minute you get to the $200 range, I'd be backing off on the gas.
Rating: 5/10, possbility 8/10 if you can get it for cheaper

Versatility: GPH1 is amazing. I've worn it to every scenario I could think of and it seemed to do well in each one. Work? Great. Date? Amazing. Class? Good. I will say it performs best in the cooler months (Fall, Winter, & possibly the cooler parts of Spring). I learned the hard way that people don't like it when you wear a strong woody fragrance around them in the dead of summer. Pay attention to your situation and it'll do just fine.
Rating: 8/10

Final Verdict: 7/10 by the numbers. I ranked it around an 8-8.5 mark. I really love this stuff which kinda sucks at the same time because unless they bring it back, getting my hands on another bottle will be very painful. Therefore, I'm gonna use it sparingly. Special occasions only! I recommend if you can pick up a bottle and you love woody scents, this is a must have. Doesn't matter if it's a designer scent or not. It does things that the niche side still struggles with!

review_title: How does a myth come into being?
review_content:
Why is it that we often only come to appreciate many things (and unfortunately also people) when they are no longer around, when they are no longer there?

Loss awakens desires through reflection and memories of what once was. Clearly an old principle of humanity.

People like Marilyn Monroe, James Dean, Gianni Versace, J.F. Kennedy, or Lady Di were already shining figures during their lifetimes, favorites of the masses and the press alike. With the tragic death of each individual, these people became posthumous myths. If they had not died young and tragically, but had aged normally, perhaps today no one would be as interested in them.

Perhaps similar thoughts were considered at Gucci or LVMH? How does one make a fragrance immortal? One lets it die young.

I still vividly remember my first encounters with "Gucci pour Homme." How this fragrance swept me away and captivated me at the time. My absolute signature winter scent. Back then, I didn’t think about fragrance pyramids, top, heart, and base notes. The main thing was that the fragrance smelled good and was housed in a presentable bottle. It could be that simple!

Today, this fragrance still excites me, or rather, it excites me again. I have only now truly understood what a masterpiece Michel Almairac has created here.

Yes, this fragrance is essentially just made of incense. Incense in excess and me? That usually doesn’t work, but in this case, it does, because "Gucci pour Homme" is not a church incense scent, but a luxurious interpretation of this fragrance component:

Top note: Incense with a fresh kick from basil, tarragon, and lemon

Heart note: Incense spiced with pepper and patchouli

Base note: Incense with softeners like amber, tonka, vanilla

Top note to base note: Incense on various woods

Boring? Definitely not. I perceive "Gucci pour Homme" as a very noble, luxurious, warm, cosmopolitan, and elegant fragrance. From my perspective, it is not a scent for "youngsters," but requires life experience and first "life scars" to truly unfold. First wrinkles and other signs of time go perfectly with this fragrance.

Moreover, the bottle is magnificent. This heavy glass cube with the seemingly floating fragrance inside, reminiscent of the color of cognac. For tactile people like me, a dream!

For me personally, "Gucci pour Homme" is THE fragrance from Gucci; nothing that followed could come close to it. Neither in terms of quality nor regarding longevity and projection.

Dear people at Gucci / LVMH: You have done everything right with this fragrance. Christmas is coming soon, in Italy and France just as in Germany. I wish for an unchanged comeback of this class fragrance. Is there anything that can be done?

When a fragrance reaches a certain age, or has been discontinued, and 21 (detailed) comments have already been written about it, it’s no longer about dissecting it, describing it, and breaking it down into top, heart, and base notes, but about something else.

I was sitting on a couch back then when a buddy held a nearly empty bottle under my nose. Quite curious, I stole a spritz for my wrist, and it was all over for me; no two days later, this heavy, dark glass monster was in my cabinet. And since then, I’ve been hooked on it. It accompanied me daily to my training, to every party, every birthday, every shopping trip, to university, to every country, every date, and every bed. Sometimes it felt as if I could skip reapplying, as the scent was always perceptible around me. I was simply Gucci. My closest friend once said during a club visit: “...no matter where you’re hanging out, if I want to drive and can’t find you, I just follow my nose, and I’ll find you.” Well... she always found me.

My fascination for this fragrance stems from the fact that, in my eyes, there has never been anything that could suit me better. Of course, that’s complete nonsense, but it felt as if Almairac had created this scent just for me. Plus, I was still very young (18?), I had acquired a Gucci fragrance that was, for my standards, very expensive, and I sprayed it, more than lavishly, all over my body, my (faux) leather jacket, my ripped jeans, and white t-shirts. It’s about more than that; it’s about a feeling, a way of life, about disrespect for overpriced consumer goods, to which one seems to be addicted, while actually hating capitalism and wanting to abolish it. When I eventually learned that it had been discontinued, I thought it was a bad joke. Well... I still think it’s a bad joke. That dark smoke, the sweet incense, and the dry, creaky wood. I miss you dearly. So the search began; I lost myself in forums and comparisons, I must find a substitute for it somewhere.
Countless test runs later, the bitter realization: No. There is no substitute. No matter how close they come, they cannot replace it.

I used the last milliliters about a year ago, unknowingly, on a very special evening -> “Oh, how beautiful love must be; when I grow up, I want to love too,” I don’t want to provide more information on that. The bottles are slowly losing their remaining scent, my clothes have long been washed, and Gucci pour Homme belongs to the past. If I could now finally quit smoking, I’m really trying hard, that would be the end of an era. My era.

But since I’m a good junkie, today 15ml were filled and left in my mailbox. I will cherish them and can now, whenever I feel like it, indulge in memories of the past. So there’s only one thing left to say:

Fuck you, Gucci!

Gucci. With the fragrance Gucci pour Homme II, Gucci completely convinced me back then. A totally wonderful scent, slightly sweet, slightly peppery, and of course with its fantastic black tea note, I was smitten from the very first whiff, and it was clear that this fragrance had to be part of my collection.

To be honest, this was also my first encounter with a Gucci fragrance. At that time, I thought I had discovered a new amazing brand for myself and eagerly set out to try all the other Gucci fragrances. And after testing a few, I eventually ended up in tears, but not from joy, no, but from pure disappointment. None, absolutely none of the other Gucci fragrances came close to GpH II, making this wonderful scent feel like a lucky find, as if Gucci had created such a fantastic fragrance purely by chance and luck... the predecessor, this scent here, GpH I, was already sold out back then, so I couldn't test whether this fragrance was indeed as great as well.

Well, I finally got my hands on a sample of GpH I... oh, if you only knew how much anticipation I had when the sample finally arrived. And I can tell you one thing: The wait for this sample was worth it!

The scent:
The scent starts off both spicy and woody. The citrus notes are more in the background; you can smell the basil more, and as mentioned, the wood is very prominent. Since papyrus wood is mentioned, with a little imagination, the scent can indeed feel like flipping through an (older) book (but in a nice way; it’s not the musty cellar scent that clings to books after long storage in a cellar :D). Besides the basil, I also perceive a strong but not piercing pimento.
A little later, the woody notes become even stronger (but no wonder, I’m currently reading in the fragrance pyramid about more woody notes), while the spices recede, including the pimento (so those who don’t usually like peppery scents can still take a look here).
The scent is rather unsweetened, as there is only a slight sweetness in the background. Additionally, there is a very light, earthy patchouli that fits well with the woody scent and the now emerging resinous and smoky notes.
Towards the base, the scent becomes a bit milder, which may be due to notes like vanilla, tonka bean, amber, and musk. These are only very faintly present, but you can still clearly notice how they change the scent progression and soften both the spices and the strong woody notes, while the woodiness still plays the main role (with cedar being the strongest among the woody notes). The amber can, however, be smelled quite well a bit later :D

The sillage and longevity:
The scent starts off quite strong but then diminishes a bit in the next 15-20 minutes. It is therefore above average in strength and will still be well perceived by others. I think GpH I is a bit stronger than GpH II.
The same goes for longevity, as the scent easily lasts eight hours and a bit more.

The bottle:
The bottle is rectangular with a very thick glass bottom and is filled with brownish fragrance liquid. The front simply displays the name of the fragrance. The bottom of the bottle is dotted or ribbed, giving it a great look and a nice tactile feel. The cap is large, solid, and black. A very beautiful and high-quality bottle.

What has happened to Gucci...? Why do their fragrances, especially the men’s fragrances, no longer have the class and the pleasantly convincing scent of the past, long discontinued fragrances?
Why is there “something” like Guilty pour Homme, which smells absolutely bland and totally banal and boring, and the only good thing about it is the Gucci logo because it reminds me, as a freak, of the Batman logo??

* sigh *

Gucci pour Homme I is almost completely different from Gucci pour Homme II, except that both contain some spicy pimento and use the same bottle. But Gucci pour Homme I has also become an excellent men’s fragrance that is totally convincing due to its above-average sillage and longevity. There is also a difference in usability, as I find that Homme I is more of an autumn and winter scent while Homme II could actually be worn at any time.

But wow, what a great scent!
I prefer Gucci pour Homme II because of its tea note, but this predecessor here has also become an excellent fragrance, making one really regret that it is no longer available. I think I will eventually buy a bunker bottle of Gucci II for safety, before this scent is discontinued as well...

Well,... it’s not really my style to talk like this, but I have to say that Gucci is really messing things up right now, at least when it comes to most men’s fragrances. Since today, by chance, I saw the collectible magazines of Star Wars helmets in a magazine shop and immediately bought the issue with the Darth Vader helmet (and yes, I am a damn freak, damn it!...),... I’ll make the following comparison: While Gucci pour Homme I and II are as great as Star Wars Episodes 4-6 (as well as the new and great Rogue One), most other Gucci men’s fragrances are about as good as Star Wars Episode I (though among them, there might still be one or two scents that are at least as good as Episodes II or III :DD)
* sigh * * sigh *

I really hope that one day Gucci pour Homme III will come, but to be honest, I don’t really believe that…

And if you ever get your hands on this fragrance, don’t miss the chance to at least test it once!

review_title: "Ambre Orients" older brother - please, Gucci, let it (come) back to life!
review_content:
Man, oh man, another fragrance that drives me to despair just thinking about what must be going through the minds of decision-makers at a perfume house to discontinue such a fine scent without any apparent reason.

Instead, these people "delight" us with soulless and artistically worthless junk like "Guilty" and "Made to measure".

One of my first thoughts upon re-testing after almost 10 years: Armani must have taken his inspiration for "Ambre Orient" from here.

"Gucci pour homme" is an extraordinarily beautiful, smooth oriental fragrance, warm, sensual, slightly sweet-resinous-smoky.

The opening is more inviting and harmonious than in "Ambre Orient", which hits quite hard on the curry note.

Sure, the ingredients of the two differ noticeably, but the fundamental character of both is very similar.

Gucci starts off with a spicy-oriental vibe, tarragon, petitgrain, and incense create a slightly sweet, woody-dried-fruity, sacred impression, seductive, well-composed.

A good dose of delicate pepper enhances the whole thing in a nicely piquant way, patchouli complements the sacred incense in the heart phase and shifts the aroma field towards resinous-woody smoke, very soft and balsamic through prominent amber notes.

It gets a bit more vanillic in the base, where the fundamental, mild incense provides the framework and spicy essences like sage and clove exude a masculine effect.

Overall, one of the most beautiful (affordable) orientals I have encountered so far, alongside "M7 Oud Absolu" or "Jubilation XXV".

Gucci, how about it? Do the fragrance world this great favor! You hold the resurrection in your hands!

review_title: The best scent on this earth
review_content:
For me, the best scent that has ever existed.
It is a feast for the eyes, truly a simple and elegant bottle design. The fragrance is incomparable and long-lasting. It's hard to describe, as I'm not yet well-versed in the notes, but I would say the wood note is prominent and the bergamot is in the foreground.

The day it was discontinued is one of the darkest in perfume history for me.
Take my firstborn if it is brought back! ;-)

For me, yes.
When you delve into the scent, it is for many something like a myth... a legend. Perhaps also because it was discontinued so quickly and at its peak.
It represents a very specific class of men.
And so I felt a bit frozen and special when my bottle, which I snagged on eBay, arrived yesterday.
I applied it and it made an "instant" click.
I immediately understood what it means - for whom it stands and what story it has.
Maybe I'm just blinded.
But I just feel something.
Something that touches me - and that's what life is about... right?

And I must say... it is also a truly outstanding scent! New school, fresh... paired with old school vanilla, amber, incense!
Plus, this incredible genius bottle. It looks like the whiskey glass for the perfumes of this world.
Feel like Gentlemen?
YES, I LIKE!

Once again, a phantom that the community mourns. Another discontinued fragrance a’la Relax by Davidoff, overrated to the max, or rather a milestone that was discontinued too early a’la Patou Pour Homme. I find it difficult to categorize this fragrance.

Let’s talk about the scent. The opening is dominated by incense, just like the heart and base notes! To be honest, the incense is so strong that I can hardly smell any other ingredient! Vanilla, basil, tarragon - not a chance. Vetiver and musk, definitely!
It doesn’t really matter as long as you like the scent. I like it, but compared to Pour Homme 2, it falls short.
A noble fragrance for the evening and for the colder seasons. Longevity is very good, lasting about 8 hours.

If I had to categorize it, I would place it in the category "It would be nice if it came back, but I wouldn’t mind if it stayed gone."

One thing I can tell you, I would not trade with a demon of crossroads and sell my soul for this fragrance, certainly not.

review_title: Priest, oh Priest you horny pig
review_content:
This is the most beautiful incense scent I have ever tested. I am not baptized, have no strong connections to Christianity... and yet I always associate the smell of incense with something "church-like." The opening of Gucci pH also begins slightly sacred. For me, it is almost pure incense, even though it is only listed in the base. However, this fades quite quickly and the whole thing becomes calmer, warmer, and somehow "different." A note joins in that reminds me of the medicinal oud note in Duro by Nasomatto or in Cuirs by Carner Barcelona. In fact, it is quite clear.
Maybe my nose is going a bit crazy after testing 5 fragrances today... but for me, this scent is warm incense, a subtle sweetness, and a medicinal oud note, even though there is no oud present... I am sure that this impression comes from the incense combined with other notes.
In any case, this makes the scent erotic, sexy... masculine, dominant.

Yes... it is like the priest who is actually a corrupt womanizer under his robe.

One of the most beautiful scents I have had the pleasure of smelling in a long time.

How could Gucci let something so beautiful die... terrible

review_title: I’m silly, wrote a comment, dreamed of the fragrance in excitement, and deleted the comment...
review_content:
What I wanted to say is:
I will not give up hope that no one will look at me funny when I wear this scent as a woman.
I am so enthusiastic about the fragrance, my absolute favorite! Woody, spicy, warm, delicious, serious, and so perfect that everything fits together, nothing is missing, and nothing stands out. Like a forty-year-old, successful man who doesn’t like haste in his life, a stable job for years, house, dog, classic car, children, a wife - first love and forever. A dream man..... Well.... When I feel like something is missing, I don’t cheat, I take this perfume from my husband’s closet (by the way, my gift)!!!
I lack nothing from my husband, but from myself. And with this scent, I feel anti-childish, anti-pink, anti-ordinary woman.
It goes perfectly with my shirts, black high heels, tight jeans,
Then I am - I myself, just as I am and still a woman.
Unfortunately, I can’t sniff out so many ingredients because I’m already looking forward to the base note. It’s damn woody! Old, sun-dried wood. Amber, tonka bean, musk, incense dominate powerfully! I can still smell a hint of beeswax... with a bit of honey....
The scent is warm, woody, cozy, smoky! Amber...
As a woman, I can say that I feel very secure and well taken care of when I’m next to a man who wears this scent.

Somewhere a long time ago, I heard the following:
“What one sinned with on earth in life, one will suffer with in hell!”
My poor sense of smell............

Today tested in a wonderful private perfumery in Düsseldorf, but unfortunately it wasn't available for purchase there anymore. I would have paid up to €100 for it, but even though I personally find the eBay prices too high, it would probably still be worth it. Because Gucci PHI is probably Gucci's best perfume and the masterstroke. Gucci PHII is also great and I haven't tested Rush yet, but it hardly gets better for winter and somehow this scent was also a trendsetter for newcomers like Potion, which I also like, but it is not nearly as masterful. Why does Gucci discontinue such things and focus on Guilty? Well, I don't think I need to say anything about that, it's a shame.

The bottle is heavy and one of the most timeless and stylish. The sillage is strong and spicy-masculine. Whether at the Christmas market or at winter festivities or even Christmas - this scent would not wither in my collection. And maybe it will still be in my collection someday, that would be a dream. There is one downside, which was the longevity today. I wouldn't have thought it would give up after just 7 hours. But it might also have been due to the age of the tester or the day's condition. And one more personal note. The personal note is that I tested a few of the most expensive and high-quality niche perfumes in the luxury boutiques today. Because of this, I probably need to make my entire rating system a bit stricter so that not too many score 100%. Because there are even better scents than this one. But in the mainstream area, this quality is a rarity! Also, I usually don't go for spicy scents, but this one is too good not to love!

I smell spices, incense, a bit of pepper & cinnamon, tiny citrus splashes, and also a bit of wood. It almost reads like a cake recipe, and if it were one, it would be worthy of a wedding cake.

If I could bring 3 dead scents back to life, Gucci PHI would definitely be one of them, and it was a great loss for the men's fragrance world! But legends are not stopped by an early death.

ADDENDUM (04.14.'13): I was finally able to get it, I'm super happy to have it in my collection, even if it's just the 50 ml and I can only wear the scent again in 6 months when the weather is right :) A very special fragrance experience, thanks to my colleague ;-) !

In 2004, I found myself at Douglas with a tight budget, faced with a choice: Gucci Homme or Eau d'Issey. In the end, I chose the latter. The story of Issey doesn't belong here; it unfolded very amicably, that much can be revealed. I only came across the Gucci again when the discontinuation of Gucci II sparked a double lament. I had tested Gucci II during a sale and found it just okay. Curiosity then led me to a vintage bottle of the number 1, and lo and behold: regret set in. It is so exciting, and I actually remember well how I felt in 2004; I thought the same back then, but I didn't have the courage to go for it.
Now, what excites me about it: It is simply different yet incredibly balanced. Incense-woody-spicy, slightly sweet, but not too much, a bit floral and citrusy, but far from a cologne.
It gives the fantastic feeling of growing a few centimeters, steps feel lighter, and one is more present. It would be interesting to know one's own biography counterfactually as a what-if. If life (which I have no complaints about!) had unfolded differently, would I have chosen it?
Well: Woulda-coulda-....

Preferences:
change, views and comments sometimes too

Characteristics:
dust-dry woods, spices, and incense. Woody-spicy, masculine.

Occasions:
few, not a scent for everyday use

Sillage: strong, room-filling
Longevity: long-lasting

Wearer, Age:
a mature man in middle age, black suit, slicked-back hair, cigar in mouth, luxury limousine, educated with good manners, in the evening a glass of cognac or whiskey in front of the wooden fireplace
on his old estate in the countryside

Legend:
so it is said in the tale,
in modern times after the millennium,
I’m not so sure

Sorrow, Nostalgia: no

Vintage:
from the modern era after 2000, not comparable to the vintage fragrance classics of the 80s or 90s

Fragrance Twin: none
Unique in its kind: yes

Reevaluation: yes

Into the personal collection:
only out of nostalgia, small remaining amount, not a full bottle

Odes: none (anymore)

Prices:
up to max. 200 euros / 100ml, no more

Own olfactory interests further development: yes

A block of glass. Heavy, solid, and with a gold-brown core of liquid aphrodisiac.

I still remember how I once welcomed you into my small collection during my wild phase of growing up. We met in an orange drugstore chain. You were sitting there quite inconspicuously, yet powerfully on your shelf, about the third or fourth row, looking at me as if you were the only one of your kind destined to find a new owner today. Yes, I had already sampled a few of your friends, but none convinced me right away. You, in your inconspicuous yet striking attire, were desperate to be noticed. And then you overwhelmed me in a cloud of pure muscle power. The lady who sprayed you recommended you as a companion. Admittedly, she did that for all the others too, but she was right about you. And from then on, I carried you through my life for 2 years. Together, we met the first important woman and the first true love of my life, fought for months over her until the grand finale on a Spanish island, which we initially lost. The month after the finale opened new possibilities for us, and after drifting through Tokyo, we found ourselves on the home stretch. We triumphed as we leisurely drove through a desert with mountains full of eyes in a camper van, ultimately landing in a hostel... after which we accompanied the lady for 7 years until everything became incredibly complicated. You were not to blame - for the last 5 years, you just stood on the shelf watching everything go downhill. Since then, you have remained a third full, just as you have been since 2008, because I can only smell you every few months. And I don’t even need to press your cap. You may no longer accompany me, but you will always be by my side.

This fragrance overwhelms and completely engulfs everything around it. It casts all others into the shadows. It’s hard to believe that it’s supposed to be an EDT. I like to compare it to a scent from Christian D., also "pour Homme Parfum" (not Intense), which is no longer available and stands barely filled in my collection. However, there are differences in the base note, which for me can almost only be expressed by the term "heaviness." Gucci pour Homme is a bit heavier, albeit just slightly. Only very few, if any, oud fragrances can compete with it.

review_title: But surely there can be more incense, right?
review_content:
This must have been said multiple times by the marketing executives at Gucci to the poor perfumer; otherwise, I can't explain this scent...

I can already smell this ostentatiously oriental incense note in the top note, and then in the heart and base notes, I smell nothing else. Goodness, what was Gucci thinking? And - why is this scent so high up in the local charts?
