The fragrance has illustrious "relatives"; "Gucci PH II"; yes, the "tea scent," sensually subtle, it has real class, even if its longevity is pathetic. And yes - "Gucci PH (1976)," refined and unobtrusive. So why this incense monster?

For me, it is extremely "unsubtle," intrusive, and completely dispensable; this exaggerated orientalism can be done better by Amouage, as they are more consistent.

The longevity, however, is epic, and the bottle is, of course, sensational, but that is by no means enough to compensate for my olfactory disappointment here.

I certainly do not want to intentionally "diss" or devalue a fragrance here, but rather warn members who might have considered a blind purchase and may want to rethink it now...

Those who enjoy incense in extreme doses may feel free to go for it; "class" and "refinement" look quite different...

review_title: Warmer incense - where can you still find it?
review_content:
I have no emotional attachment to GPH.
I find the scent very pleasant, but I have only worn it a few times.
Especially outstanding for me is the wonderfully warm incense.
This incense is the defining element throughout the entire development,
so that I can hardly decipher all the other components of the pyramid. And yet it is so
perfectly integrated that it never stands alone, never dominates.
Feels good, and yet never ordinary.
It's a shame that it is no longer available.

So I started (like so many before me) to compare it with the
"similarly scented perfumes." I would like to briefly outline my experiences here:

Potion:
During the first testing, it actually reminded me strongly of GPH, quite intuitively.
In direct comparison, however, you notice that it comes across as much sweeter and spicier,
more like Bentley for Men Intense. Less mature. Patchouli also cannot replace the incense.

Greyland:
The resinous note of cedarwood does indeed bring it close to GPH. However, it is too spicy and herbal, more fresh than warm.

Bentley for Men Absolute:
So far, it has the greatest similarity for me. The resin is more intense. When I first smell Bentley and then GPH, I can hardly perceive the latter anymore. Nevertheless, the similarity is astonishing.

ToDo:
CdGp2M, Dirty English

review_title: And is this supposed to be oriental?
review_content:
What was the artist trying to tell us? I don't know. It's somehow sour-woody-sweet with an Evernyl base note drowned in Ethylhexylmethoxycinnamate and a bit of vanillin, which doesn't really come through.

Well, I only bought it because I think the predecessor (Envy) is so great and the bottle is quite decorative.

review_title: Elegance in a Dark Tobacco Costume
review_content: As is well known, the company "Gucci" was founded in 1921 by master saddler Guccio Gucci as a small workshop for leather goods and luggage in Florence. The initial production of leather goods, suitcases, and bags led the company to success. Fashion was introduced relatively late, and only in 1981 was a women's collection presented. With Tom Ford at the design helm in the...

review_title: Sauna, Cinnamon, everything is steaming! Also for Her.
review_content:
The perfume made me steam and I in turn made the perfume steam, and it builds up and everything is steaming and sweating. Delicious.

I liked and still like the perfume very much, but it was too extreme for me. Sauna and cinnamon. In my opinion, it is also too sexually suggestive without actually being sexual.

I eventually used up my last bit and bought a bottle for a friend when it was still affordable. For a strong, fierce woman.

Definitely a sculpture. Unexplainable that it is gone. It should be reissued unchanged. Amen.

...whoever has ever smelled these clove cigarettes from Indonesia will either love or hate them - and will always recognize them! Gucci pour Homme is not quite as extreme, but it always reminds me of the scent of these cigarettes.
In general, it is a true spice scent - mainly Christmas spices (including Apicius' list) with a broad woody base and a very light sweetness, which makes the fragrance particularly suited for the current Christmas season and thus for Christmas markets. The only downside is the longevity: especially outdoors, the scent dissipates very quickly, so I have even found myself reapplying it in various perfumeries.

I cannot understand the discussion about the target audience. Of course, it is not a perfume for teens, but from the mid-20s onward, Gucci pour Homme is definitely wearable. It is more about the season - I generally only wear it in the cold months, preferably in November/December.

This scent simply gives me a warm, cozy feeling, and even while I am writing these lines, I catch myself sniffing it again and again. Strict or sacred darkness does not come to my mind at all - rather this image: Christmas Eve gathered with family around the Christmas tree. The fireplace provides comforting warmth, the candles are glowing, and the whole house smells of Christmas. Wishing you all a lovely pre-Christmas season!

Gucci Pour Homme was already a small masterpiece that had a lot to offer and thus met all the demands one could have for a complete men's fragrance.

However, contrary to my expectations, there is no relation between the two Pour Homme (I and II); both fragrances go in completely different directions.
Gucci Pour Homme reminds me more of the legendary Santal Noble by Maître Parfumer et Gantier, which could ultimately be a sensible alternative, but unfortunately is quite hard to find and expensive.

I was all the more pleased about the rare opportunity to test this fragrance, as the fact that it was discontinued for inexplicable reasons must have disappointed most Gucci fans.

The opening of Gucci Pour Homme is alcoholic, sharp, and distinctly medicinal in nature, but only for the very first moments.
Actually, that's already a good sign, after all, not a few classic men's fragrances start in this tried-and-true, albeit seemingly unconventional way.
Anyone who looks a little closer at the listed ingredients can unmistakably sense that this must be an extremely spicy fragrance, but Gucci Pour is even more than that; it is more of a pure "spice bomb"! Of course, one has to like that.

In this fragrance, all the aromatic substances have been so harmoniously integrated that it is difficult to break it down, and therefore it makes more sense to gain overall impressions.
Overall, Gucci Pour Homme is quite robust and spirited, coming across as significantly more masculine than its popular and worthy successor, Gucci Pour Homme II.
Associations with a subtle aroma reminiscent of almost Christmas-like fragrance oils cannot be entirely dismissed, but to categorize it solely in that time is unjustified, as it would also maintain its magnificent, long-lasting, and effective presence throughout the year.
However, considering the continuously declining quality of today's Gucci range, the discontinuation of Gucci Pour Homme is all the more incomprehensible.

A big Mille Grazie to ScentLover for the sample.

It's sitting around here and was more of a bad purchase.

Actually, it's a great spice scent for winter: clove, cinnamon, allspice, nutmeg or something like that. I do like that, but the top note is quite strange. Pretty dark - herbal. I don't like it at all. I can't really say that anything about this perfume is bad, but I just don't like how it smells on me.

The almost identical scent without the irritating top note can be found in Héros by Uomo Parfums - Didier Calvo. But I believe it's no longer in production.

review_title: The scent that won't let you go, the toilet is simply everywhere.
review_content:
One day my friend came home with this scent after receiving several perfumes from a friend. Even as a gift, I wouldn't have wanted this scent. After the first spray, it smelled to me only like a toilet! This scent is biting, penetrating. The sillage is very good; once
sprayed, you are haunted by this scent, it feels like everything just smells like it. In our case, the scent was only used to cover up a business in the bathroom, the scent simply overpowers everything.

Unexpected in the Gucci line - and perhaps already extinct because of that - is this representative of the artfully captured incense. At first, it extends a delicately shaped, elegantly balanced head from the bottle with strange features of bergamot, lemon, and lavender. But it quickly swells powerfully, the spirit, filling the room and settling on a darkly glowing cloud of...

This scent does not just smell woody, but like an entire forest. Not green at all, rather more like a deforested woodland. I would say it smells more like fir wood, maybe spruce or something like that. One should choose the occasion carefully, as Gucci Pour Homme is not a fragrance you wear just for fun. Not because it is so serious, no, it comes across as very, very strict,...

review_title: Unfortunately, I don't have a photo for you today...
review_content:
Oh, I wish so much that I could smell the fragrance facets described here. Unfortunately, I had significant difficulties from the very beginning and didn't dare to talk to anyone about it at first... At first, I thought of GPH as a strange isolated case that I couldn't explain. Then, gradually, I had opportunities to test various samples extensively and also "fragrance twins" like CDG 2 MAN or Potion.

Now, however, it becomes clear to me that my impression is not just an exception, as I experienced the same with all the mentioned samples: I can hardly perceive any fragrance notes at all, except for a piercing, biting chemical... I think of toxic gases, lighter fluid on steroids, something whose marketing is punishable under some EWG regulations. Do you remember from childhood when (*ahem* some people?!) found the smell of gasoline both repulsive and fascinating? It feels somewhat similar to me, except that the fascination isn't quite as strong, because the chemically-synthetic - pardon - smell takes center stage!

To all GPH fans and to all friends of qualified comments (I am one myself!!): Please excuse my statement, but perhaps we can agree on the added value of the comment in that it might be at least chemically interesting that this entire fragrance family behaves so extremely with me. The development of the fragrance essentially does not change either. Yes, it becomes a bit milder in between, and I can somewhat imagine what is meant here with jasmine and tonka (unfortunately, more is not possible), but then in the absolute drydown, the smell described above always remains, which is, by the way, perceptible for exactly 48 hours.

Can someone explain to me what is going on? Do I need to see a dermatologist? Otherwise, I really have the luck that perfumes last quite a long time on me, come across well, and I don't have any intolerances or allergies or anything... Is anyone else experiencing something similar??

Gucci pour Homme was the first perfume I acquired from the spicy-scented range. During the first testing, until then I only knew aquatic or citrus notes in the top notes, I actually had a wow effect. Perhaps that’s why it has remained one of my favorites.
In the meantime, I clearly prefer this fragrance direction (one does get older), but I still enjoy returning to Gucci Pour Homme within this group. For example, in direct comparison with The One by D&G, I find it not as unnecessarily sweet as the D&G product.
So: Not daily, not necessarily in the height of summer, but always very, very gladly.

... and yet easy to wear - these are the qualities that characterize "Gucci Pour Homme," the Latin Lover among men's fragrances. With its powdery-chocolate tobacco-cedar-amber note, it shows clear similarities to "Lagerfeld," but on one hand has a "pomade-like" note and on the other hand, in my opinion, is still a bit more refined.

Although I hate to say it, I find this fragrance one of the most overrated and over-promoted perfume releases of this year. To be honest, not many of Gucci's female fragrances have managed to impress me, (with Envy Me 2 being the only exception). I had some hope for Guilty, however I find it very bland.

I have no doubt that it will sell well, especially over this Christmas period, but it doesn't strike me as something that those 'naughty girls' or those particularly daring would choose to wear.

To my nose it's mostly sparkling fruits with a touch of spicy pink pepper. It has a pineapple juice quality in the opening, however it's not nearly as acidic as other pineapple based scents.

It's pleasant enough, yet incredibly boring, leaving me longing for something with much more depth. Where is that beautiful, earthy and green patchouli note that I so constantly crave in scents these days? There is so much missing from Guilty's composition.

It took me a while to be able to smell this fragrance seeing that it opens so subtly on the skin. It doesn't have much in the way of sillage I'm afraid, nor is the lasting power that of an impressive nature.

The name and the shiny gold bottle just doesn't seem befitting of this fragrance. It's misleading in the way it has been marketed as something elegant and formal, when it is in fact rather casual. It reminds me a little of Chanel's Coco Mademoiselle EDT.

There's not much else I can possibly add to this review. I'm disappointed and truly underwhelmed. It's predictable, but pleasant nonetheless.

Written: Oct 31, 2010.

I really like the smell.. opens with a blast of strong pink pepper which quickly goes away, then I get peach, lilac and amber. This is a sweet warm fruity floral oriental on me. However it quickly becomes a mild skin scent and is totally gone by 3 hours so although I will enjoy my mini of it, I will not repurchase because of the low throw and short life. The bottle is interesting but the scent is nice but not exciting and there is no quilty feeling wearing this. Another misnomer, innocent would be more like it.

GUILTY? How about BORING? Having sprayed myself with my entire sample vial, I feel prepared to assert that the only thing Gucci is guilty of in this case is massive dilution. This liquid is so flimsy, vague, and insubstantial that it smells like a hundred other recent light floriental launches. All that glitters is not gold, and all that is "gold" does not glitter.

For a lilac perfume with something to say, I recommend Ineke AFTER MY OWN HEART.

At first sniff, all I could smell was lilac. It took several minutes to develop into something a little more complex. That being said, I think this is a pretty scent, but it doesn't really stand out as unique. It is a little sexy, or, perhaps sensual. There's honestly not much more to say about it - it's a little underwhelming for me.

review_title: boquet of flowers under a musk blanket
review_content:
lilac+geranium= ick
If you do not like musk, you WILL NOT like this fragrance!
I can discern the notes though

How they came up with the name 'Guilty' for this scent is a mystery to me. I've never smelled something as innocent as this.
It is a pleasent smell, one you would choose when not knowing what to wear or as a safe office scent. Sillage is low and longevity seems even worse. I can't say anything about the notes listed, which is it's quality maybe because the blend is subtle and seamless. This could be a lovely scent if it would perform, but is hardly does. Maybe it is called 'Guilty' because it's hiding :-)?
I got is as free sample along with my shampoo, won't buy a full bottle.

review_title: This perfume is a sad stressed person with a touch of arrogance trying so hard to be elegant...
review_content:
For me, it is one of those perfumes when you smell them, you realize you have been smelling it from women older than you all your life.

It is not a bad thing per se, now in my 30s I wouldnt mind wearing something like this and I don't think I am old or anything like that, but we all know how smells work in our brain and I cant avoid to make the asociation with older women in a way it makes me imagine a single mother who didnt want to be a mother but she is following the expectations of their burgoise boring and autoritative family, for once tyring to be sexy again wearing a dress for a party after a long time of having an stressful life, I don't know how to describe it. Damn, I hate the description I have made but this is the image it evoques in me T.T

Lilac is the colour I see the most here, but diluted into a lot of hair spry. It is heavy and airy at the same time.

It is a very elegant perfume, but also very serious and a little boring. I don't know why but also the fragrance it is pleasant and on paper felt special, on my skin it didnt make me feel anything beautiful or pleasant. It is so serious and with a touch of arrogance that is a sad perfume trying to be elegant so hard that fails to me

At first, Guilty comes across as a simple, powdery floral - almost too basic. There's nothing extraordinary about it, just a fragrance that stays in the safe, familiar zone.

But as it develops, a fruity note starts to emerge. Unfortunately, this fruitiness doesn’t turn out to be the juicy, refreshing kind; instead, it takes on a harsh, almost overripe quality, like a fruit that’s stayed too long in the sun. It seems like the peach is to blame for this misstep.

In the end, it didn’t win me over. Gucci Guilty aspires to be elegant and refined, but it feels stuck somewhere between trying to be sophisticated and coming off as a little forced. A nice try, but not quite a success.

It smells like someone mixed Curve and J'Ador. This is sweet fruity, floral. I see lilac listed as the main note but I'm not really smelling it at all. The patchouli and amber take a while to appear but they're soft and nicely done. Sometimes I feel like they can be overpowering.

The branding makes it sound like it's sultry and sexy, but is the standard HS locker room post-gym class smell from 1995-2010, just with a Gucci price tag.

Before I begin, I'd like to state that I am 29...and refuse to smell like a granny, so I'm very selective with the scent I choose for my skin. I received this perfume through a monthly subscription perfume company. I had it in my queue and was SO excited to wear something well...Gucci. At first I was not a fan. It was VERY lilac...and way too powdery for me. BUT as the day went on, and the perfume began mixing with my hormones an ph, I began to pick up the black current, vanilla, pink pepper, and patchouli notes, and WOW did they mix harmoniously with me skin! This scent smells like rich b
*!!! I had my friend smell it (she is also a perfume "snob") and she said the same thing. You must give it a bit to allow the lilac to settle out of it's powdery form to pick up the beautiful blend of sweet peach and raspberry, with the warmth of vanilla, and the guilt of patchouli, black current and pink pepper. This has definitely become a go to of mine when I want to smell like success and portray a sexy goddess. You will not overpower the room, but people will smell you...experience you....remember you. You will feel guilty because the men will go to bed thinking of you.

The confession:
I don't actually own this fragrance myself - but my dear mom does. Every time I stand in her bathroom, I eye her collection: Chanel Eau de Parfum - a timeless classic, J'adore by Dior - wonderfully elegant, and of course Guilty by Gucci (these are just a few, after all, I inherited my love for perfumes from her). So I sprayed the fragrance on myself and was more than surprised.

The description of the culprit:
As some have already reported, this perfume smells anything but "guilty." I expected everything, just not this soft, light lilac cloud that now surrounds me. As Mahatma1951 described so well in her great comment - who would consider someone who smells like this to be guilty? Because the fragrance has no edges, nothing wicked, and nothing polarizing (I can imagine that it is perceived as pleasant by many noses). The perfume itself is beautifully composed and truly smells very harmonious, well-groomed, and incredibly feminine. The aforementioned lilac undoubtedly dominates here and envelops you for several hours in a warm and soft, but rather intimate sillage. For this reason, I find it absolutely suitable for the office and everyday wear, as it has nothing intrusive in my nose. It would also work for dates, but only if you have arranged a puzzle night (;

Final plea:
One must not take the name at face value and buy it blindly if one expects a scent worthy of a sexy femme fatale on the stand. Because it is the exact opposite: agreeable, unobtrusive, soft, sweet, and cuddly - just like a little innocent lamb.

Ladies, let's stick to the topic! This endless nitpicking about the perfume name. I hereby declare you guilty of hair-splitting! Whether you are naughty or not really doesn't depend on the scent. We all know by now that it's not about what it says on the label, but what's inside. Now to the point: Gucci Guilty is an all-rounder. There is practically no phase in which the...

Guilty EAU DE TOILETTE is accused of being trivial and of misleading with false pretenses.
Objection!!!!
Guilty has indeed committed a crime, yes!! Absolutely....
Guilty of causing confusion with its name,
guilty of being pleasing,
guilty of being arbitrary,
guilty of being beautiful,
guilty of being wonderful,
guilty of being the perfect office scent.

One cannot accuse it of triviality; that can undoubtedly be refuted.

It relies solely on its charm to captivate as many people as possible. For this, it brings nothing but its lovely tones into play and shows no sophistication, which it doesn't even need.
A hint of fruitiness paired with sweet lilac nuances defines its character, only interrupted by soft creamy amber tones and a minimal pepper note, with underlying patchouli streaks. It comes across as floral-fruity, buoyant, bright, friendly, and always well-groomed.

Anyone with so much charm doesn't need to resort to tricks.
To accuse it of triviality is simply wrong.

So what can be held against it?
Only its longevity and sillage. They are simply too low.

Guilty EAU DE TOILETTE is thus to be acquitted of its charges.

review_title: Outside Ivana Trump, inside insurance clerk
review_content:
I swear by the perfume god that I tested Gucci "Guilty" for the first time BEFORE reading the comments below. My impressions of this piece of work are therefore unbiased.

The scent is nice. Not at all Gucci-Pucci. No ostentatious sweetness, nothing baroque, nothing screaming. No, a very pleasant representative of the "light" kind: Radiant, clean, friendly. Sparkling mandarin, floral white-fleshed peach on harmless patchouli. Quite sexy in a clean way.

Okay: My must-have-it-now center doesn’t kick in. I’m not burning with hot love, I’m not racing with tunnel vision to the next fragrance temple. However, if someone were to casually throw it at me, I would wear it gratefully and happily.

But wait a minute. My stomach is raising alarms. A dull feeling of disharmony grips my insides and disturbs my peace of mind. What’s wrong? Everything seems pretty nice, doesn’t it?
_______________________________________________________________________________
_______________________________________________________________________________

Suddenly, I see her in my mind’s eye. The pretty classmate, fellow student, or colleague, of which there are thousands everywhere. Clothing style: Esprit basics without any missteps. Jewelry: Minimalist-modern, also Esprit. Make-up: None. Consistently and demonstratively none. Body language reduced, speech style inconspicuous, special identifying features non-existent.

And then comes the day of the prom, the campus party, or the company Christmas party. And suddenly she’s there. All dressed up, puffed up, with naive painting on her face. Really going for the queen of the night look. Clunky high heels strapped to her feet, a black mini dress on legs that haven’t seen daylight in years.

You can’t help it. You feel painfully embarrassed.

_______________________________________________________________________________
_______________________________________________________________________________

Yes, that’s it. THAT is what’s wrong with Gucci "Guilty". It is v-e-r-k-l-e-i-d-e-t!!!

... when it comes to choosing inappropriate names for their fragrances. I recall a subtly floral daytime scent named "Premiere." I wouldn't have necessarily imagined such a sugary sweet squeaky concoction under "Rush" (sorry to all who like that fragrance). And the generic scent "Made to Measure" for men... But who knows, maybe they do this on purpose and the inappropriate...

Yesterday, I finally tried the fragrance with the cheeky name "Guilty" amidst the hustle and bustle of the city.
I braced myself for something "daring" - but what was that?

A lovely scent jumps out at me - with the playfulness of an innocent Easter lamb.
The fragrance is soft and cuddly like its curly little fleece.

The pink pepper is gentle and lively, sparking a desire for outings in the greenery, where fragrant lilac trees sway in the wind.
Amber rounds out the scent, making it shiny, like the mild April sun that illuminates this spring idyll.
Depth and a hint of earthiness are brought to the pleasant fragrance by the patchouli.

Guilty is beautifully balanced and harmonious - except for the misleading name - the only thing that bothers me about this charming scent.

It has made it onto my wish list.

The scent pretends to be something it is not. With this name, I expect something wicked, alluring, seductive. A perfume that should evoke sinful thoughts but is structured quite differently. If this is what sin smells like, then it’s utterly boring, and we certainly won’t be tempted by anything at all. Meanwhile, disappointment hides behind a beautiful bottle, which I really like, feels pleasant in the hand, and deserves a better content.

The cute mandarin top note flashes briefly, and the pepper has probably been forgotten in some spice rack for years. No trace of aroma left. Then it gets a bit floral-powdery, and the uninspired base note announces itself, which doesn’t impress but at least stays on the skin for a while. However, nothing else happens, so waiting is pointless.

With Guilty, one only feels guilty for having spent unnecessary money on boredom in gold.

"Guilty" by Gucci, accused of boredom, mediocrity, pretentiousness, and low longevity, is hereby officially defended by me with this comment.

The accused is by no means as bad as its reputation, quite the opposite. The following points speak in favor of the fragrance:

The top note impresses with gourmand freshness, mandarin and pepper add a kick.

Lilac is rarely found so well and harmoniously embedded in a fragrance (without coming across as soliflore), especially since a great effect is achieved with delicate peach.

The accusers from the Parfumo community have fallen for the saying that not all that glitters is gold. This is certainly true, but in this case, it is hard to accuse the defendant of not looking attractive. Just because it has a striking appearance does not mean it lacks inner values.

The longevity is only as good as the user is able to handle the fragrance. That means spraying generously in hair and on clothing or moisturizing the skin beforehand - this way the scent also delivers what it promises. In any case, Guilty!

I therefore request that the innocent Gucci fragrance be acquitted of all charges and that the verdict be reconsidered. Thank you for your attention ;-)

That is the question here. Clearly: Totally innocent. Totally virginal, flat, and by no means interesting! I admit, I once had this fragrance. As far as I remember, I had just turned 20 and had it gifted to me because I was also drawn in by the advertising. Promisingly, I sprayed it on and thought it was okay, but it had nothing to do with bad girls who...

the 12 jurors are fidgeting, impatient, wanting to go home for lunch - Another
convict to convict or acquit. Restlessness is palpable....

There ... the convict, her hands behind her back, bound with hard handcuffs. Her hair shiny and long down to her waist. - She is still young and looks so innocent...(the jurors fall silent, embarrassed).

Quickly looking at the files, what she is accused of. Ah heroin smuggling! How much! 2 kilos!
Hmmm. The court ritual unfolds...

Then a wonderful delicate lilac scent permeates the dry courtroom - delicious and fine, as if an angel is floating through the room...

Not guilty, was the 11-0 verdict of the jurors. Only the 12th said nothing more - he has fallen into a trance....
PS. Rarely have I experienced such a wonderful unity, yes, a union of all ingredients - as with this Guilty
nothing pushes forward here, no sharp pink pepper, no lonely or overpowering patchouli, no bitter
amber, no wilting lilac - NO
everything blends harmoniously on my skin -

I have awakened this scent, which has been ridiculed here in the reviews as a frog, into a prince....

review_title: It might actually be the exact opposite. And suddenly the scent makes sense.
review_content: I think a new level of marketing has been reached in the conception of the Guilty fragrances. But I believe it goes even further than just bringing the scent to people with an exaggerated advertising machinery. The film Sin City serves as inspiration for the Guilty fragrances. The commercial is produced in this comic style, just like the entire Sin City film. Frank Miller...

review_title: We all just want one thing...
review_content:
... and Gucci is certainly aware of this. Who doesn't want to be beautiful, desirable, and sexy? "Sex sells" seems to be the motto guiding the advertising campaign here, trying to lure us in. The advertisement suggests that with this scent, one transforms into an irresistible, passionate Femme Fatale. And then it’s even called "Guilty." With low expectations, I delve into it.

After a moderately strong smell of alcohol dissipates, the scent starts off rather dull. A lonely slice of mandarin, which seems somewhat synthetic, carelessly garnished with a few peppercorns. The fragrance is fruity here, unfortunately unnatural and sweet. There’s only a minimal hint of pepper, too little to attribute it with the descriptor spicy. After a few minutes, patchouli begins to shimmer through the previously inconsequential fragrance mix, cautiously steering towards an oriental direction. Already better, yet not guilty. Lilac adds pleasant powdery and creamy accents, contributing a soft, cuddly, feminine note. It’s becoming increasingly floral, as another bloom seems to be joining in. However, it is too vague for me to name it specifically. The peach surprises me positively, completely velvety and warm, with no trace of scratchy fruit sweetness. Well, it is sweet in a positive sense. It’s supposed to symbolize a forbidden fruit. The femininity here is more flirtatious than wicked, very cuddly and playful. Amber creates a rich, soft bed on which the notes roll around gracefully. Nothing with complete loss of control and overwhelming sensuality. After about five to six hours, I find only a spicy hint of patchouli on my skin, paired with a delicate lilac and peach note.

All in all, I find Guilty not bad. Over time, I like it more and more and it gives me a comforting feeling. It envelops me in a creamy, powdery, fruity, and floral scent cloud with a touch of oriental. Nicely done, but why this name? With Guilty, I don’t strut around swinging my hips, tossing my hair provocatively over my shoulder with the absolute certainty that my eyes resemble green laser cannons, instantly captivating my willing prey. And he would do nothing more than be my captive for a night. Okay, that was exaggerated :-D

If the longevity and sillage were better, I would even consider a purchase. Aside from sports and in great heat, one could wear the scent for many occasions. I like the floral-fruity-powdery creaminess. And a woman who feels good in her skin and is aware of her positive aura should never be underestimated.

Many thanks to Ti for the sample ;-)

~ Inspiration ~ I was very drawn to this gold-glossy bottle, and since I have had good experiences with Gucci so far, a small bottle (30 ml) was allowed to join my collection. ~ Bottle ~ Square, with rounded edges. It looks a bit like a flat cube. The golden color conveys luxury and wealth. The mirrored GG for "Gucci Guilty" is the real eye-catcher, through which you can...

I was able to test Guilty in advance at Drogerie Müller.
My verdict is: "Not guilty"
The advertisement promises something sinful, erotic, which the name also suggests. But unfortunately, only the price is a sin.
The scent is lilac and a few other minor notes, not worth mentioning. Now I've been wearing it for almost 4 hours, and if you get your nose really close, you can still smell a tiny bit of it.
At least the bottle is beautifully designed.
If I had tested it blind, I would have guessed it was a fragrance from the drugstore. Not really bad, but interchangeable.

"Laaaaangweilig!"
My predecessors have already said it all. Still, I want to add my two cents.

Guilty is harmless and nice, it doesn't hurt anyone. It is unobtrusive and well-behaved, so you can wear it daily when nothing better comes to mind. It's not bad, but it's miles away from making a big impression on me. You're right if you think it fits better in a drugstore.
The pepper is cowardly, hiding behind the mandarin. Peach, lilac, yes, present. Everything feels a bit artificial, but okay. In the base, Guilty becomes creamy, soft with amber. Patchouli joins in hesitantly.
The bottle looks like it could appeal to teenagers who want something from Gucci.
There are a few southern girls living near me who always wear thick makeup, their eyes painted black. They wear fake designer clothes and try to make everything look expensive. Guilty fits in well there.

Oh yes, the girls work for a cleaning company.

I plead "not guilty" in many respects except for one point: the name of the perfume is truly an unfortunate choice. Who would voluntarily want to be associated with the adjective "guilty".......Nevertheless, the perfume is on my wish list!!! I find the scent exceptional for two reasons: a) finally a perfume that does without rose b) and the eternal vanilla doesn't have to...

review_title: A Floral-Oriental Dream with a Hint of Pepper
review_content:
At the beginning, Guilty reveals the peppery side of the fragrance. This is accompanied by a light sweetness. Once the top note has slightly faded, the lilac of the heart note breaks through. Thus, the fragrance takes on its floral characteristics. Although I usually don't like lilac that much, I find it very fitting in Guilty. In the end, amber and patchouli are added, which steer the fragrance in an oriental direction.

A great scent that is sexy, elegant, interesting, warm, and sensual. I really enjoy wearing this fragrance and feel very comfortable with it. The longevity is also very good. Whenever I think the scent has completely faded, the next time I "sniff," one or another note reappears.

With the word "heartfelt" one could describe the scent quite well, I think. You can hardly smell the mandarin; instead, the lilac quickly and intensely comes to the forefront. The peach also comes through nicely and adds a pleasant sweetness that makes the perfume so romantic and soft.
A slight woody note keeps "Guilty" from drifting into the cheesy or boring. Rather, it is a very elegant scent that I find extremely successful.
Two male friends (20) of mine also liked it, as they found it unobtrusive and pleasant.

I must confess, I love this perfume; I can't quite say why, I just feel incredibly comfortable when I wear it.
It surrounds me all day, like a veil it wraps around my skin, very delicate yet present..
The chemistry between us is just right, as I often get compliments on this scent..
As boring as many find it, it can't be that dull :)
On me, it smells stunning, elegant, sensual, delicate.
Unfortunately, this wonderful feeling doesn't last long, as it fades after 5 hours.

I sniffed a sample abroad and was torn. Buy it or not?! Back here in Germany, I really kicked myself because it hadn't been released yet.
A month later, I called it mine: a lush fragrance, I like to wear it in winter or in the evening, it's too much for summer.
It's not wild and "roar," but it wears nicely and lingers in the nose with a high recognition value.
I really like it!

I really like the bottle, it looks elegant and expensive.
But the scent itself is... well... sweet, floral, and a bit herbally oriental...
I actually like patchouli, but here it's just not blended that well... it also smells kind of oddly powdery somehow... I can't really describe it ;)
I don't find Guilty particularly terrible, but it's not outstanding either... just so-so... it also depends on my mood, sometimes I even think Guilty is quite nice ;)
But in general, this scent is probably not a hit. It smells nice and is generally okay, but nothing special...

review_title: Oh my God - the name! Uhhh - cough - oh my God, the scent!
review_content:
Guilty - guilty - great name, so wicked, so seductive, so forbidden.
All really great characteristics (well, sometimes ;-))
And I thought to myself: Please, please, smell only half as good as your name says you do!
Bääängggggg! - Giant frying pan on my head when I first had the scent in my nose! Dream shattered.
Yaaa... now I need to collect myself and report on how it smells: Honestly, I can't say - I can't really pick out any of the notes mentioned above. Sweet, yes, and a bit oriental. But not successfully oriental... and also not successfully sweet.

I find it terrible, intrusive, and very ordinary. In no way convincing.

I can't understand how it could rise so high on the popularity scale???!

NEXT!

Well, when you see the bottle, you would expect a bit more.
The scent is so familiar and interchangeable that it’s almost impossible to elevate it further. You would expect something like this from inexpensive drugstore fragrances.

Fortunately, this time there is not as much patchouli used as in Rush.
Unfortunately, there isn't much special about Guilty either... But we shouldn't punish this mainstream scent.
Top notes of grapefruit, red mandarin, and bergamot?, a hint of cassis and juicy peach, with pineapple? In terms of floral notes, I believe in jasmine or tiaré (lilac? mmm but which color, not the white?). Possibly alongside the red pepper, a bit of ginger? Wood?: patchouli with cedarwood and a lot of sweet amber musk.
We perfume enthusiasts are the scent freaks, and Guilty is therefore too nice...

Gucci Guilty is not a bad scent. I own it myself and am quite satisfied with it. Nevertheless, for me, it is a very simple sweet, slightly oriental everyday fragrance for the colder seasons. In the advertising, this scent is portrayed as "wild." In reality, it smells rather tame. I wouldn't describe it as boring, but it lacks that certain something. The longevity is good. All in all, I can really recommend the fragrance. Not as an incredibly wicked evening scent, but as an everyday fragrance for the cooler months. Those who enjoy something a bit sweeter and warmer will surely find joy in this little gem.

First of all: I am referring to the version in the 'old' bottle that was released in 2010. And I do not understand the average rating at all.

I still remember very well the purchase of my first 'real' perfume: Gucci Guilty!
I associate very beautiful days with this scent. Back then, I was a fresh high school graduate. As a gift, I got to spend 3 weeks abroad in the Emirates with my uncle. With a bit of pocket money, one day I went shopping, and I bought this wonderful fragrance.
It was around springtime and already very hot in the Emirates. My daily routine consisted of: exercising, sunbathing, showering, and then: applying this fragrance.
Even after my time with my uncle, this scent accompanied me for a long time and brought me many compliments; it seemed to harmonize very well with my own chemistry. Since then, I have been searching for a comparable fragrance that brings about the same effect and I also mourn the old formulation of Gucci Guilty... the original version has unfortunately been discontinued.

For me, this scent is a go-to. On hot days, I am enveloped in a cloud of lilac, patchouli, pink pepper, and amber. The patchouli and amber, as well as the rose, give the fragrance the oriental notes that make it wearable even in winter. The pepper and mandarin add a slight spiciness and freshness.

This fragrance has given me many beautiful moments, and I cherish my last 'original' bottle.

(Fyi: the Intense version still has the old bottle, but I find the edt version better in terms of scent. Unfortunately, I do not like the scent in the 'new' bottle at all...)

....yawn, let's see if I stay awake while I comment.....
What more do we have to endure? Isn't it enough already with the mediocrity, lack of creativity, greed? YES!
Not only does the bottle remind me so strikingly of the ...something-Me line from Escada, but the scent is just as boring in the base.
More than what Omara says about it, I can't really think of anything else. The fragrances I'm criticizing here are all not bad. But interchangeable. And definitely too expensive. For the price of an MB, you only get a Smart.
No, I'd rather stick with my Custom-Rods.

For a long time, this fragrance passed me by, but eventually, I stopped and gave it a chance. Before, I resisted because it seemed too mainstream to me. But I understand why it is so popular! If I have to choose a fragrance for an elegant evening, this is my choice! So special, soft, and warm, it carries me through beautiful times.

review_title: What or who is supposed to be guilty here?!?
review_content: Oh dear... another one! How many more times? And yet another fragrance that the world doesn't need. No marketing concept can help - all that sexy, sultry nonsense... It's just a dull mixture without heart and soul. And the longevity is terrible too! After an hour, all that was left of Guilty was hot air. If you need a run-of-the-mill fragrance for all occasions, you might be...

Many years ago it happened - a moment so magical and unique that it changed my heart forever. I fell in love. For fourteen years now, our love has stood the test of all the ups and downs of life, unwavering and full of devotion. It is that rare, almost fairy-tale love that the most beautiful novels speak of - a love that does not fade with time, but only grows deeper and more intense.

And just as our love blossoms in all its facets, this fragrance unfolds as well - a delicate melody of flowers and longing. A hint of lilac and rose wafts through the air, gentle yet full of passion, as if petals were dancing on a warm summer breeze. No trace of pepper - just a fine, sweet freshness that reminds one of the innocence of days gone by. Like the sparkling sweetness of a children's lemonade in an old film, warm and full of comfort. The violet finally rises with lovely elegance, rounding off the fragrance experience into a gentle, almost dreamlike harmony.

It is not just a fragrance - it is a memory, a feeling, a love letter to time, to the past, and to all that is yet to come.

review_title: Looks great on the outside, but what's inside?
review_content:
The bottle looks really cool, at least in the picture. I haven't seen it in real life yet.
I'm finding it hard to rate. The sample is almost empty, so I guess I didn't find it that bad. It's relatively sweet, which isn't really my thing. I think it leans a bit towards an oriental gourmand direction. For a sweet scent, it doesn't annoy me that much. I can imagine it well for going out and that it would appeal to the male gender. I would see it more on younger ladies and during club visits rather than on a settled woman or at the opera. The younger crowd might find it sexy, but in my opinion, it's not elegant.
It's not for me, but I don't think it's that bad.

review_title: Envious that this is not marketed to women
review_content:
I bought this fragrance just the other day when I was out shopping for a cologne for my boyfriend. I had tested many male scents that day, however this one stood out amongst the rest.

To be completely honest, I think I liked this fragrance because I could see myself wearing it. It had this alluring, dark and spicy sweetness that captivated me almost immediately.

The sales assistant actually agreed with me that this fragrance could easily be unisex on the right woman. I believe that I am the woman that can succeed in wearing Envy.

Envy for Men opens with peppery orange, lavendar and rich mahogany. The top notes also have a slight menthol smell which is possibly brought to mind due to the intense green colour of the juice itself. The ginger is really lovely in this fragrance as in most cases ginger can make or break a scent.

In the heart the sweetness becomes more apparent with the carnation, jasmine and rose hinting that this fragrance is suitable for women as well.

The drydown is amazing. Vanilla, incense, patchouli, amber and tobacco creating a smokey and almost exotic scent. It is a delight to snuggle up to someone wearing this fragrance as it is both soothing and arousing.

I had every intention of giving this fragrance to my boyfriend for his birthday, however now I seem to be changing my mind. I am almost decided on keeping this fragrance for myself and finding him something else to wear or suggesting to him that we could possibly share.

I've dogged Tom Ford's perfumes. I'm not a great fan of his eponymous perfume line, but on smelling Gucci Envy for Men, something clicked.  The Gucci perfumes of the Ford era were a first rate line of designer perfumes and are a testament to the value of art direction.

Gucci Rush is a pitch-perfect modern example of the pursuit of beauty in classical perfumery. It's gorgeous, it stops you in your tracks, it makes you think.  

I have a love-hate relationship with Gucci Envy, but then again I hold ambiguity in very high regard. A perfume that polarizes opinions points to a strong artistic voice. One that splits an individual’s own opinions is ingenious.  

Gucci pour Homme I (Michel Almairac, 2003) was a thoughtful, beautiful perfume released at a time of big perfume ad campaigns followed by even bigger yawns. I doubt that a Gucci perfume was launched without a high degree of gloss, but in this case the proof was in the pudding. In fact, whether GpH I started the trend of beautiful woody incense perfumes for men, it certainly became the leader of the trend mainstream market.

Gucci Eau de Parfum and Gucci Eau de Parfum II reflect a brilliant strategy of letting the blandness of the market serve as a backdrop. Seen against a group-think market of women’s perfumes in the 1990s, they stand out both for ingenuity and for their beauty.

Gucci Eau de Parfum is a strikingly simple floral Oriental writ large that rose above the monochromatic mob of syrupy gourmands. It offered an old-school animalic quality to women who had been lead to believe that the height of beauty was to smell like a cupcake, sprinkles and all.

Gucci Eau de Parfum II was a subversive little beauty that infiltrated the fruity-floral genre, skipping the spoonful of sugar in favor of a tart woodiness. Gucci edp II has none of the frivolity and triteness typically associated with the genre. Its pokerface and assuredness give it a character more like a classic woody such as Jean Patou 1000.

Envy for Men didn't bust down any walls, and unless quality comes as a surprise to you, it doesn't shock. It's the spicy, woody, resinous perfume equivalent of a Russian male choir. A large range is covered, but the rumbling bass is what I remember. A lot has been made of its nutmeg and ginger notes being its defining attributes, but like Givenchy Insénsé, whose floral notes have been touted as the reason for the perfume's failure to breech the men's market, the note isn't the coup de grace. Beauty is.

Many men fear unadulterated, or better, unmodulated beauty, and despite its nominal set of 'masculine' notes (lavender, cedar, incense, amber...) Envy for Men is luxuriously beautiful. It's like many of the Amouage masculines such as Gold Man (1983) and Dia pour Homme (2002) where the goal is explicitly for a man to smell beautiful. The litany of questions that often curtail men actually wearing a perfume are irrelevant. (Is it an 'office scent'? Does it broadcast easy identification with your cohort? Could it be perceived as feminine?). If you look closely, Envy for Men easily passes masculine muster, and should assuage the fear behind these questions. It should simply have been seen as a handsome, distinctive entry into the market. But men's deep-seated fear of appearing beautiful trumps the rest, and, despite something of a cult following, Envy for men has gone the way of much of the other Ford era Guccis. It's been discontinued.

Perfume fans follow the work of individual perfumers. Why not branch out a bit and follow the work of the art director? If the perfumer can be likened to the director in film, the art director is somewhere between the film producer (eg. Serge Lutens) and the art curator (eg. Frédéric Malle.) Larger-scale commercial perfumery relies on a consensus model that defines creativity very narrowly.

The Gucci line of the Ford era is similar to the Estée Lauder perfumes made during Lauder’s time. The ridiculous lie of the Lauder line during Estee Lauder's lifetime was that she made each of her perfumes herself. Lauder was known for producing a spectacular line that didn’t shy away from polarizing opinion. Azurée, Knowing, Aliage, Estée. And her perfumes for men, principally in the Aramis line, are still the best compilation of masculine fragrances from a large commercial cosmetic/perfume producer. If she had openly proclaimed herself as an art director of the line, she'd have beaten Lutens and Malle to the punch by decades.

If you're interested in looking at perfume from the perspective of the art director instead of the perfumer or an entire line, take a look at the Gucci perfumes by Tom Ford. Some are discontinued, and some are still in production, but they're all fairly easy to find.

I love Envy, actually it was my signature fragrance when it was released. I had 2 bottles, the yellowish green and the reformulated electric green juice. First formulation was better.

But even with all the nostalgia I will not re-buy this fragrance. It's hard to get and the prices are just ridiculous.

If you're not an Arab prince don't bother seeking this fragrance out, you can get so many better colognes at a fair price right now. One example will be Bentley Intense.

Performances are just average and the compliment factor is pretty low, to be honest. The vintage snobs will say this is a holly grail, just because they have it and you don't.

So don't believe the hype, and just forget about Envy.
RIP

review_title: Back when they knew how to do it
review_content: This is the epitome when it comes Down to, how to make a good fragrance overall, not just a designer. Because this one was the spark for a lot of these Niche fragrances we see today, and we know that, if this was just filled from its bottle into an expensive niche today, it would sell like cold lemonade on a hot summer Day. This was/is perfect still. Just stunning. . And performance is outstanding. Happy to own a 2005 bottle.

review_title: A discontinued emerald green jewel of a fragrance...
review_content:
What a fantastic fragrance this was! A spicy oriental full of ginger, incense, cedarwood and sandalwood... and a gorgeous smell to match! The very definition of an oriental with woods!

Stylish bottle, classic green juice... a prominent incense vibe. In my mind this is like standing in the middle of a Chinese Temple... sandalwood and jasmine incense burning, an almost menthol-like aroma of Chinese herbs and spices. Envy for Men opened up with incense and sandalwood, followed by lavender, ginger, pepper, cardamom and coriander seed. With a sweet & spicy amber and vanilla drydown in the base. What wasn't there to like? It had everything you could want from an oriental for men! Class, sophistication, a faint aura of mystery & seduction... this is more than most fragrances can offer thesedays!

It really is a shame that Gucci discontinued all the outstanding and daring work Tom Ford produced whilst he had full creative control of the company. He built Gucci up like a Phoenix from it's ashes, and now it has lost what set it apart from other designer brands. It lost it's bold creativity and most of all, it's uniqueness in terms of fragrances.

This is a gem of a fragrance, and I will cherish what little I have left of this juice in memory of this once great brand. R.I.P. Envy... you sexy green devil!

I don't often get a chance to review discontinued scents that have such a storied reputation as this one. Luckily people's generosity knows no bounds and i could get my nose on this one. Hope you enjoy the review and find it helpful.

review_title: It broke my heart, and my wallet
review_content: I adore this stuff, I really do. To the point where I splurged and bought about 5 or 6 50ml bottles of it. Now, I didn’t pay the ridiculous eBay prices for it, but it was still a kick in the wallet. Why did I spend all that money on a 10+ year old eau de toilette? Well, that’s a long story. I’m of the mind that this is perhaps one of the greatest male fragrances ever...

I originally shunned this when I tried it a decade ago... That was a big mistake, as it actually is a great spicy oriental with ginger as a primary note. I may prefer Floris Eau de Santal and Eau de Santal Extreme that have a similar dry-down, but Gucci was first and deserves credit for paving the way... Oh, and it smells great in its own right. Those who enjoy ginger based spicy orientals can stop here after trying this one. 3.5 to 4 stars out of 5.

review_title: Love this so sad its discontinued
review_content: I really used to love this as a young man it was a fragrance that reminded me of some great times and it truly sad that its been discontinued. It just oozed the moment for me, it really represented my ambition and what I wanted to achieve in life. It just captured a feeling. I've bought it on ebay a few times now as its hard to get now its not produced. really really a fave of mine.

review_title: Gingery incense with cedar and nutmeg...
review_content:
Really nice and enjoyable, but IMO not the holy grail that everyone keeps saying. Longevity is great. Warm, woody and musky.

That being said, it's rather formal and not something you'd wear to work or at the movies. Be warned though, not much development going on here, rather linear fragrance. Really good stuff, but try it before you waste insane amounts on a bottle from the Bay, which seems to be one of the last places to get your hands on this discontinued pleaser. At the original price of 40$ this was decently priced, but now...

If you're looking for something with a similar vibe, I'd recommend Prada Amber Pour Homme Intense.

A discontinued masterpiece! Fresh, summery! Reminds me of a pine forest! The longevity of this perfume is about 8 hours. It starts with an exceptional combination of lavender, cardamom and ginger! After about 1 hour you will start to notice sandalwood, cedar and jasmine. Its weak point is that it is discontinued and because of that the prices are sky high! If you want to have a piece of history in your hands, as well as around your neck, be prepared to spend some money! If you know the right people, it can be done cheaper!

One of the seven deadly sins.
To pale with envy, to be consumed by envy, or to turn green with envy.
Envy, also known as jealousy, is a sin that drags many others along with it.
Typically, anger, resentment, and bitterness soon follow. In the worst stage, acedia follows,
also known as sloth,...the soul begins to dissolve.
The seven deadly sins slumber in all of us; I have personally become well acquainted with some of them and have gladly allowed them in,...I confess!
But since I have been living according to the rules of Buddhism for a long time, they are well under control.

Envy,..Envy was the first fragrance from the house of Gucci launched under the new leadership of Tom Ford. Under the new direction of head designer Tom Ford, Gucci was propelled to unprecedented heights, awakening from its dusty and deep slumber.
Although Daniela Andrier was responsible for Envy, Tom Ford was significantly involved in its development,..which is inevitably recognizable.
Envy was extremely masculine, sexy, and very lascivious,..the envy was, in the truest sense,..green!
When it was released, it sold out in no time; now it lived up to its name, as people were envious of those who managed to get a bottle.
Wearing Envy, one was inevitably approached about it,..a true Tom Ford!

Envy opens the sin with mandarin and pepper, initially slightly spicy-fruity with faint hints of cardamom and anise.
After half an hour, Envy begins to change, and you can feel how the sin slowly rises within you.
Clove spreads out, and nuances of musk, opoponax, and jasmine surround you, alternately vying for dominance.
Envy surrenders to the full sin in the final accord.
Vanilla, amber, and soft suede with a small sin of vetiver make Envy uniquely striking and sexy.

Envy has a very good longevity of 12 hours even with the smallest dosage. The sin does not fade away quickly.
Its sillage is strong, but not loud, and is above average.
Envy is often quite obvious.

Conclusion
A fragrance that created the atmosphere of a humid, steamy, and mossy jungle floor in
me and lets its surroundings partake in it.
Very masculine and seductive for both genders, with a distinctly Tom Ford note even at that time.
One of the milestones of the house of Gucci and still contemporary and extremely attractive today.

Since I have been free from envy and jealousy my whole life, this sin could never harm me, but there were plenty of other deadly sins that had far more chances with me... anger, for example, but with a few prayers, that one passes quickly too.
Pssst: But it doesn't always help!

A business fragrance as it should be! Gucci Envy for men is a blockbuster, this scent is synonymous with all the translations of a single English keyword: SOPHISTICATED!

Here, wonderfully spicy, peppery, and zesty notes are combined with a beautifully oriental fragrance accord without becoming even remotely loud. At the beginning, pepper and ginger dominate, presenting a very potent yet unobtrusive play of freshness, a non-sweet mandarin can be sensed, a soft, warm hint of anise and cardamom envelops the overall picture, and vanilla is already gently pushing to the surface in soft intervals after a very short time.

There is a very warm freshness, a refined interplay of zesty summer scent and oriental feel-good atmosphere - an extraordinary semi-gourmand companion that whispers softly: "Here I am!" Gucci Envy for men inevitably stands out from the crowd with its sophisticated and cosmopolitan aura, doing so with great subtlety and unmistakable elegance. A wonderful, high-class fragrance for the cultivated man.

The green potion in its distinctive, masculine bottle is the perfect companion for meetings & co in business attire and a very good friend for the hours afterward in the hotel lounge. It makes itself comfortable on a dark leather couch in dim light, enjoying tobacco and cognac, and lets the evening end stylishly and relaxed.

Gucci Envy for men certainly hasn't reinvented the wheel, it doesn't belong in the niche fragrance category, yet it is still different from all its brothers and sisters. This scent surprises without overwhelming!

The longevity is very good, but one should be sparing with the dosage and proceed with caution. A downside is the enormous dependence on individual skin chemistry, where surprises can often end negatively. Gucci Envy for men, like many other fragrance jewels, has unfortunately been taken off the market despite good sales figures and without understandable reasons. I have not found a scent even remotely comparable to it to this day. Here, too, a great master of perfumery, Maurice Roucel, had his hands involved (despite the lack of mention).

CONCLUSION: Those who enjoy gourmand notes that do not overwhelm should test Gucci Envy for men; those who count long-lasting and differentiated perfumes among their preferences will feel at home here, and those looking for a demanding, refined fragrance for serious occasions should secure an artifact of the green envy water, because (to quote Cornelius Nepos): "Envy is the companion of fame."

review_title: Gucci's male milestone - Coriander-spiced mandarin and leathery, vanilla wood in pure harmony
review_content:
It has always been on my watchlist. It’s been 14 years since I acquired a (then quite generously sized) 4.5 ml sample by purchasing Fahrenheit or something similar, shortly after the release of "Envy".

I have never owned more than this sample - but it was my choice on my very first date back then. And that date also led to my first girlfriend in my teenage years..

I was already aware that the scent radiates something special - but I never thought of buying more than the 4.5 ml. And today, having acquired a decant again and tested it after 12 years, I kick myself for not having fully enjoyed the real existence of "Envy".

In short: For me, Gucci's absolute best! I also like "Gucci I" and "Gucci II", no question - but what the brand has achieved with this men's fragrance in the black-dark green monolithic bottle surpasses all the others noticeably.

A dark fruity, coriander-spiced mandarin dominates the start - the complexity is already evident in the fragrance pyramid, which positions a true orchestra in the top notes - fine, powdery pepper alongside unusually early hints of soft, spicy rosewood nuances round off the start in a complex manner.

Everything is already underlaid with a soft, masculine woodiness that has an extremely strong presence. The more autumnally green flowers of the heart phase sensualize the spicy opening and evoke associations with a brighter, greener "Antaeus".

The base then transitions into a still softly woody, slightly vanilla leather that exudes an incredible masculine calm and comfort.

A truly great, artistic, incredibly charismatic fragrance milestone.

If Gucci were to (please, please!) reissue it - I would probably stock up on it until I’m 80 years old...

Right off the bat: If I were to wear a fragrance for the rest of my days, it would be Envy for Men. I have never encountered a scent with which I felt more in harmony. You don't have to understand it, but that's how it is. If I remember correctly, the first version was more yellow, then came a pale green, and finally a strong green. According to my fragrance memory, the ginger in the top note and the sandalwood in the drydown were much more dominant in the first version than in its successors. If I had known back then how much I would miss Envy for Men today, I would have acted like Helmut Schmidt, who allegedly hoarded Reyno menthol cigarettes in his cellar before they were banned. Be that as it may, missed opportunity. Today, I only own a quarter-full bottle of the second generation, and I guard it like my own eye, because I won't participate in the bidding madness for remaining stocks. By the way, my first Envy for Men bottle was a gift and initially caused me to shake my head: "I’m not going to walk around with a fragrance that I constantly have to think about being called 'envy'." However, after the first spray, that intention went out the window. By the way: In search of a fragrance twin to Envy for Men, I briefly landed on the recommendation of Floris Santal and Carven Homme. Unfortunately, both are at best distant relatives, but definitely not twins for me. So I continue to sniff my way through the fragrance landscape in search of the holy grail that Envy for Men was for me.

review_title: Egg swings whenever & wherever you want - or: Style only looks like arrogance from below
review_content:
I have been hunting for this one for a long time - and now I've found it through a nice perfume from Italy. Of course, it is more expensive than it was 4 years ago in stores, but still affordable, and who could have guessed back then that soon moon prices would be demanded on eBay. Now I no longer have to look at owners and fans with envy; I also have a 100 ml bottle and can join the conversation. It is definitely worth its 100€ (1€ per ml), back then for half the price it was one of the best deals on the market.

The scent has everything that most new releases lack: eggs, courage, charisma, punch, a recognizable style, and purpose. Much of this we owe once again to Tom Ford, who had a hand in this. I would even go so far as to place it on the same level as today's bestsellers and recognized top perfumes from his line - like Sahara Noir, Black Orchid, or Extreme. Tabacco Vanille might be a bit of a stretch, but that's also a different weight/price class, and the leap isn't that far either. In my opinion, the Private Line contains more super noble scents for special occasions. In contrast, Envy Men can be worn anytime and anywhere (as long as it’s not too hot) and can become the go-to scent. You just need a bit thicker eggs than the average, meaning self-confidence - but that can partly be trained.

Envy Men most reminds me of the very good Michael Kors Michael For Men, just greener and a bit more old-school. But it is clear that this old-school barbershop feeling is intentional and more of a modern homage and interpretation - like so much with Mr. Ford, in memory of the good old days.

Envy starts with a smoky-green masculinity chaos. Shaving meets vanilla, retro meets future, incense meets Green Berlin. A real scent for the boss - not the little boss. The scent is also spicy and gentle. Lavender brings a calming effect and makes the scent come across as laid-back and egg-swinging - without truly appearing arrogant. Just determined and cool - I'm sexy & I know it! A slightly leathery undertone also contributes to this sexy attitude. Simply super versatile and super popular - in the worst case, it comes off okay, never bad. But you have to be prepared for the scent to be potent and thick, so you should apply it sparingly, and at over 15 degrees, you might want to reach for a lighter scent. Green, leathery, spicy, heavy, oriental - a real wonder package. It's a shame that not more people get to test it.

Bottle: classic, masculine, bulky - but Gucci still does that well today. But as everyone knows, the scents have degraded much more significantly.
Sillage: strong, thick, confident, knows what it can do and wants.
Longevity: easily lasts the whole egg-swinging day.

A great scent, far above designer average, unjustly in the shadow of its 2 brothers (Gucci PH I+II), and a shame that it has been discontinued. Anyone who thinks the new Gucci scents aren't as bad as everyone says: please test Envy, and Guilty and Co's eggs will shrink to raisins.

I stumbled upon Gucci Envy one morning in the lost time between two seminars. I actually just wanted to kill some time in the perfume shop; in the end, I walked out with a broad grin, trailing a green perfume cloud behind me through the pedestrian zone. After another unsuccessful attempt to find something positive in the male Chanel -Egoiste and Allure-, the toxic green bottle from Gucci caught my eye in the perfume shop. A spray on the blotter: Envy is outrageous. At its core, a wild mix of cheap herbal drugstore perfume, vanilla sauce, and sprinkled ginger dust, the result is somehow so wonderfully extravagant that the top notes completely blow me away. A sweet mixture of spices that I can't quite identify, very nicely done, but certainly not for everyone. Unfortunately, the drydown is rather disappointing, an old-fashioned green perfume with vanilla - this could have been done better and more high-quality. While the beginning is still youthful, the base tends strongly towards the over-50 direction.
Envy is not a subtle perfume; rather, it’s a spicy-green raucous “Hey, here I come” in sweet vanilla sauce. You certainly won't find any understatement here. Envy wants to be loud, intrusive, and distinctive. The longevity on my skin is, by the way, fantastic, like with most Guccis. 8 hours is no problem at all; you can still smell it the next day.
Who is Envy suitable for? Probably for no one and everyone, I can hardly pinpoint a specific type or occasion. Maybe best suited for over-50, somewhat rough-around-the-edges, self-important lawyers like Rolf Bossi. But basically, one must say: whoever wants to smell like this just wants to smell like this - it won’t really fit anywhere.
After I had also applied Envy to my skin, I had to endure the university day in my perfume cloud - because I felt a bit embarrassed, I settled down far away from any human company in the next seminar. I assumed that Envy was once again one of those perfumes that I like - while the rest of my age group finds it a terrible imposition. When a very nice fellow student (whom I otherwise had nothing to do with) sat down next to me, she moved closer instead of away from me - physically close. Whether she really liked the scent of Envy or just had her cozy day - no idea. In any case, she wasn’t driven away by Envy as I had expected.
After a second test, I treated myself to 50ml of the stuff. The bottle has been sitting here for almost a year now, but I still can’t decide whether I find the toxic green spray terrible or fantastic. Even though I rarely wear it, I haven’t been able to bring myself to sell it. If I ever want to smell like an extroverted retiree in ginger-vanilla soup, I know exactly where to reach.

review_title: "the feeling of being a man and being desired - it practically screams sex!"
review_content: said Tom Ford about this fragrance. Young and wild, but with feeling and intellect, a bit aggressive, yet sensual and above all SEXY!!! Gucci perfectly captured the lifestyle and spirit of the new, hip generation of the late 1990s. With Tom Ford at the helm and the consistent modernization of the company, a dusty brand was revitalized. With glamorous outfits, modern...

review_title: Hyped Mainstream Designer at Moon Prices
review_content:
In my 2 years of activity on parfumo, I have learned quite a bit about fragrances and tested many.

At first, one thinks this scent is the holy grail. Everyone wants it, it is coveted and expensive.
That's what I thought at first too.

Ultimately, it’s not about having something in your collection for others,
but about finding your own style and showing individuality.
After all, you don’t have to chase every trend, not even in fragrances.

Here, an attempt was made to create a green spicy fragrance from the late 90s with modern elements for the new millennium.
These elements are flowers and leather.

If you have sniffed a bit into the real vintage classics of the 80s, then this Envy seems relatively normal.
It’s okay, but not the biggest fragrance hit.

For me, unfortunately, its composition doesn’t work:

The flowers, especially the rose, mixed with leather set off alarms in my nose.
Somehow, I don’t tolerate the green Envy well; it has a somewhat bitter sweet sourness that doesn’t harmonize very well with or precisely because of the green spice components.

It is slightly sweet, but above all strongly floral-leathery. That doesn’t fit well together in my nose. Vanilla is very, very subtle in the background. A very mature, strong, loud scent for men aged 40-50+ one might think. A slight old-fashionedness is undeniable.
“Grandpa” fragrances send their regards.

Wearing this scent at 20 to 30 years old would seem ridiculous and inappropriate to me, just to follow a trend.

In conclusion, it must be said that it is definitely not worth 400€ / 100ml.

Harsh words for the Envy disciples,
but that’s how I perceive it.

review_title: 400 € for a 100ml bottle - that says a lot
review_content:
After reading all the comments here, I wanted to join the disciples.
It’s a shame that Envy is no longer in production. Rumor has it that Tom Ford parted ways with the Gucci main brand and took his formula with him. This doesn’t quite align with his shares in the company, but given that he now has his own perfume brand, I suspect the formula was torn apart during the split by both parties, or aliens stole it.
No matter what speculations are circulating here - the fact is: this perfume deserves to be placed on a pedestal.
Here is my story:
Towards the end of its production, Envy was still available at Douglas. I, who had enjoyed wearing Dior Addict and Gucci Rush, went to Douglas once again to give myself hope for a new fragrance. At the end of my round, I made a detour and walked past the men’s fragrances, and there it caught my eye with its unusual color and bottle shape at that time, with that hefty cap. I thought: what on earth is that??? So I went over, drawn in like by magic, and tried it out. The saleswoman looked at me in surprise, but the moment the scent traveled through my nose into the farthest recesses, I forgot everything around me. I grabbed the packaged bottle and went to the checkout.
From that moment on, it became my perfume. My number 1, followed by Dior Addict, which I hardly wear anymore.
The truly amazing thing about this scent is that it adapts to the wearer. I gave it to some of my male friends to test. For them, it turned into a zesty woody tiger from the jungle - typically masculine. For me, however, this scent transforms into sandalwood, candy aisle, and lemon. And it lasts, it lasts longer and better than many high-priced neighbors and even longer than my recently acquired "Noir" by Tom Ford. Once a month, I spray 2-3 sprays on my coat, and that’s enough.
Normally, I like spicy, woody vanilla scents with a hint of mandarin, but not too much. This one is the big exception.
To return to the description "Not of this world":
Gym, summer, heat, sweat - reactivate this scent when applied to the décolletage, and it blends with everything your body emits - and it smells even better. (Think of the old advertisement for this scent)

It’s a pity that Envy is no longer produced. Unfortunately, there is nothing comparable.
Even its dupe from Larise smells too masculine and musky for me.

For those who have the money to invest 400 € in this perfume, congratulations on your purchase, use it sparingly, the unicorn.

No more shaking and no more wringing helps. This morning, I sprayed the last drops of “Envy for Men.” This fragrance was one of the last remnants from the beginning of my passion for perfume in my early twenties. And back then, among all the “boy scents,” it was the only truly adult one. It survived, deep in the closet, my years of fragrance abstinence and waited for its revival, which happened a little over a year ago. It has always been a scent for special moments for me...

“Envy for Men” starts off herb-spicy. Pepper and coriander are extremely present, but are quickly tamed by the mandarin, without being flattened. The citrus fruit caresses the two spices and complements them perfectly.
The subsequent phase is still quite spicy, but it becomes green-woody with slight floral influences. Rose, jasmine, and clove join in, but not just the blossoms, no, the whole plant, with stem and stalk, with leaves, flowers, and roots. Masculine green-herb and slightly floral, but not in excess. With the slowly fading coriander and pepper, a fantastic combination is achieved here! One of my favorite fragrance components, fine sandalwood, perfectly rounds off this phase.
The fragrance is already perfect at this point. The base is the crowning conclusion. The combination of leather and patchouli is generally my personal favorite, here supported by a subtle, natural vanilla pod. Vanilla is also the last note that gently leaves my skin after an astonishingly long time.

Together with Givenchy's “Gentleman” and Guerlain's “Héritage,” “Envy for Men” is so far the only male fragrance candidate to receive 100% from me. For reasons I mentioned in my comment on “Gentleman,” I do not do that.

As the last fragrance molecules decompose this evening, an era comes to an end for me. “Envy for Men” is a milestone; it is Gucci's best fragrance for me.
Although I have found my exit fragrance and own some other olfactory delights, I will miss it. It's a shame that it has been discontinued.
Fragrances like this are needed in the (men's) world now more than ever!

Farewell. It was nice with you; I will keep you in my best memories.

review_title: You shouldn't try to change men!
review_content:
What have I nagged and tried to change about my beloved! I called him a fragrance philistine, Prince Valium, olfactory deep sleep. I slipped him samples, gave him perfumes and fragrance vouchers for his birthday, Christmas, and Easter.

And what did HE do? He placed the new fragrances decoratively on the shelf and used the vouchers to buy perfume for me. He did everything to avoid giving up his "Sculpture" by Nikos, which he has been using for what feels like decades and which suits him brilliantly, but -- at some point, as a woman, you want to bury your nose in something else.

Apparently, I complained one time too many, because at some point he came around the corner, beaming from ear to ear and proud as a peacock, with a turquoise shopping bag. From his victorious smile, I could tell that this time there would be no fragrance for me. I was right! What emerged was "Gucci Envy For Men."

Aha.

Well, how should I put it? It's certainly something completely different from "Sculpture." And it's beautifully green, which my nose quite likes. But the mix of spicy-green and floral-sweet doesn't entirely appeal to me. The hint of coriander causes me intense nausea. And all in all, the entire composition makes me think of mosquito spray.

HE thinks he has hit the olfactory jackpot, I have stomach cramps.

If darling now sticks to "Gucci Envy" for the next few years, just as he did with "Sculpture" by Nikos, then I have a serious problem. The only solution: blackmail! "If you wear Gucci Envy, I'll drown myself in Chloé" (darling's quote about Chloé: laundromat).

Oh yes. Problems upon problems. But -- I guess I deserve it. You shouldn't try to change men.

...had already been reached for some time and there should be just over 3 hours of flight time left to Frankfurt am Main. It was one of those wonderful days in midsummer. Cavok! No turbulence, monotonous straight flying, boredom! But then the moment of relief. I flipped through the in-flight magazine of the former Hamburg International to the next page and saw this image! GUCCI ENVY. Several stacked bottles pointing in different directions with oversized caps in jet black and green contents. I was thrilled by the presentation of the advertisement and admired the designer-specific competence of Gucci's marketing department. Rarely have I seen a perfume advertisement that was so appealingly designed.
I was never a fan of green fragrances. Not even back in my early 20s. Nevertheless, Gucci's marketing back then, which was impeccable, somehow convinced me. Upon arriving in Frankfurt, I decided to quickly search for this scent in duty-free despite being completely exhausted.
