I held the bottle in my hand, which was covered in fingerprints and, in reality, was not quite as beautiful as I had expected. Never mind, I took the first spray on the cardboard strip! I was like petrified, and contrary to all expectations, the colorants of the fragrance immediately contradicted my expectations! Not a green scent! Luckily. I dared to test it on my forearm and left the perfume department to head home.

The fragrance initially impressed with a very fruity top note of syrupy sweet citrus fruits infused with cinnamon and coriander. It was one of the first fragrances with a real progression and complexity that I encountered. It delivered an outstanding sillage for hours, and throughout its superior longevity for an EDT, new scent peaks of ambered leather, spices, and a hint of powderiness unfolded. It was difficult to distinctly separate the top, heart, and base notes over time. Even after hours and upon my arrival home, I could still perceive the sweetness of the almost candied citrus fruits on vanillin. I usually don't like vanilla. However, in this fragrance, it was wonderfully harmonious even on my rather demanding skin.

The fragrance ranks among the best releases ever on the market beyond the "real" niche.
If I had to smell this today blindfolded and guess the perfumer, I would immediately guess Gualtieri!
I might claim that it would give the impression that he was even inspired by this fragrance back then. If I meet him, I will certainly want to discuss this fragrance with him. This scent offers so much material for conversation and was surely a tremendous challenge for Daniela Andrier. I have really tried almost all of her fragrances and must say that this one is certainly among her best. If not the best.

For all those who did not get to experience it. You definitely missed something. And I say this reluctantly. Even in this case, I have not found a worthy successor or a dupe to this day.

In my subjective feeling, it can be described as a cross between Blamage, Chinawhite, and Prada Amber pour Homme.
That may exceed the imagination of most; to make the description even simpler, imagine Blamage with reduced intensity, with mandarin instead of peach and a vanilla addition.

In the end, the question remains why such a cultural asset is lost. It is a mystery to me. I cannot explain the demise of this magnificent fragrance.

review_title: You smell so good ... being jealous is allowed!
review_content:
So, now I'm daring to say something! :-) I am giving (I believe for the first time) 10 points for a fragrance! What a shame that this is hardly available for purchase anymore. I was lucky with a pretty good eBay deal ... the rest is a love story, even though it only started a few days ago!

"Envy" really has the potential to become my signature scent. I took it to the cinema over the weekend and immediately received a compliment ("What are you wearing that smells so nice?") and during the film, I was bathing in my own sillage. I didn't care at all that I might have applied it a bit too generously. I just thought to myself (the movie was quite dull): "Man, you smell good!"

What usually puts me off a fragrance is leather. However, I don't consciously perceive that here, so everything is (more than) fine. The rest is a combination that I consider unique and I have never smelled anything like it before: masculine, seductive, spicy, woody, paired with a gentle sharpness and a balsamic base. I don't want to go into too much detail: I can hardly imagine a more beautiful scent for the moment!

The result: I am really happy! :-) I still have a sample box with 15 fragrances that just arrived today, and I don't even want to try any further. For the moment, of course, but that has already lasted four days. From now on, every new fragrance will have an extremely hard time competing with "Envy." Let's see what the previously unknown Daniela Andrier has conjured up ...

review_title: My Déjà-vu of Green Spiciness par excellence
review_content:
I am sitting in front of a Gucci Envy Men perfume miniature that I originally ordered to
join the conversation after the many comments on eBay.
And what can I say, even though I have never owned this scent before, I am experiencing a rather positive déjà-vu.
It feels so familiar to me... as if I had used it for years...!??
Yet I have never had it...
What could possibly be so similar? D & G The One Gentleman - no, not really! - maybe in terms of spices, but that one is aquatic and does not smell green. Moreover, Envy is far superior to Gentleman (although I don't necessarily find that one bad). Davidoff Classic? No! Too harsh... Davidoff Relax... I don't know... too long ago... So the déjà-vu remains... ...whatever, this perfume saw the light of the perfume world during a time when a perfume was more of a pure utility for me and did not represent a direct area of interest... whatever...!

This scent is one of the best I have smelled in a long time.
It starts very fresh, green, spicy.
The pepper is absolutely present but not sharply pungent, rather in a unique softness and yet powerful
(if it were a wine, one would probably speak of silky tannins). This character carries through the entire fragrance from the top note to the base note.
A mandarin underlines the overall work, which also comes across as rather green instead of classically mandarin. But it exudes a wonderfully pleasant freshness.

In the heart note, various floral scents come through that I cannot exactly categorize, as well as woods that are powdery / velvety.

In the base note, there are then 3 true classics for an attractive men's perfume:
Leather, patchouli, vanilla.

What hasn’t been said about this scent already... now I can somewhat understand it... Tom Ford: It practically screams sex! Oh wow! What a slogan!
Whether I would want to equate Gucci Envy Men with an aphrodisiac, I don't know, but I would say it is definitely an erotic scent!

I also don't think it requires much courage to wear this scent - because I find it, at best, incredibly pleasing - without being proper.
It is designed so well and harmoniously that one almost has to like it, unless one has a problem with some ingredient or simply does not like the green or spicy fragrance direction.

But one can truly say that nothing was done wrong with this scent in its genre!
It is spicy-sweet without ever being greasy, sticky, or even hinting at any lack of masculinity, cheapness, or a candy store vibe.

It is green/fresh/woody without ever spreading even the slightest bitterness or herbaceousness.

It is sexy without ever being socially unacceptable or vulgar.

And then this smooth, powerful softness! Actually, things that should exclude each other.

One of the few fragrances in this world for which there can only be 100%.
Fragrances where everything was done right!
Here:
Green Spiciness par excellence

A day without Envy is a lost day.
This perfume is more than the sum of its parts.
It is an event.
End of statement.
""The following errors occurred: Please enter a more detailed text (min. 200 characters) or write a statement.""
No! Everything has been said.

The first fragrance that made me angry because the bottle was empty.

For more than 12 years, I have mourned this scent; there has honestly never been a fragrance that embodied me more than Gucci Envi.

A resonance so positive, so attractive like it, it’s rare for a woman to give me such a compliment, solely because of the fragrance.

It is masculine enough that you don’t have to be over 40 to wear it. It is elegant without having to wear a suit. It is as sporty as each one of us, without being a tennis sock wearer, and so fresh that you can easily forgo cool fresh deodorant sprays.

The woody notes accompanied me with every step; Jasmine said hello, Patchouli joined in, and the sweet vanilla nodded along. That’s how I liked to smell.

The fragrance: my first true love in perfume.

The longevity: I remember a long-lasting scent.

The sillage: Wonderful.

The bottle: Masculine, classic.

review_title: ENVY seems to be very sought after...
review_content:
I bought a bottle around 2003. I thought the scent was great, but I used it very rarely. About ten years later, I casually threw away the cube along with a few other old fragrances. It was sitting untouched in the cupboard and taking up storage space. What do you want with a perfume that you don't use? Sell it? I didn't want to bother for 5,- €.
I really didn't know anything...!
That's how it is. Personal appreciation related to a subject increases, passion is ignited, you become interested and learn more, and suddenly a product is mystified. Now everything is beautifully collected.

Coriander? YES! And how. Soapiness after spraying. That's special, but really good. It's quickly clear after spraying that Envy is something very special and independent!

The scent is somehow soapy. As mentioned at the beginning. And due to components like rose, jasmine, patchouli, among others, the scent is also quite classic. At the time when the fragrance was released, many perfumes were aquatic, fresh, "blue," sweet - this one is not at all and is certainly not a "child of its time." At the same time, it also reminds me a bit of the fragrances that followed later. Those that had a spice or a woodiness. I find it a bit like a form of crossover, if I may be symbolic here.

The scent has a bit of 80s soapiness, with patchouli and classic rose or carnation. But it is also soft, like, for example, an Egoiste, which is definitely 90s and also uses sandalwood, which we have here as well.
But there is also leather, vanilla, and jasmine, which already leans a bit into trends that, in my view, were a bit ahead of the fragrance. This leads into the 2000s.

If we look a few years ahead at Gucci, we will see that with Gucci Pour Homme (2003) they were also very far ahead of their time.

The scent is - what I really like - unique. You know it once you've smelled it. That, for me, is what defines a brilliant fragrance that represents a kind of signature. Even in its development, it is special; it is spicy, I don't really perceive it as leathery. It's soapiness, spice, it's a bit herby. That's great. The fragrance has a special note that I recognize immediately, but I can't explicitly trace it back to a specific ingredient. Above all, it is "green." Today, green is back in trend, but you, Envy, are unfortunately no longer available.

Lost in the jumble of the overwhelming supply of weekly new releases in countless variations, soulless and characterless. More is more, and the market for exclusive niches is no longer exclusive, but every niche manufacturer subtly wishes that every second person walks around with their scent. Back then, there were designers who brought something to the market. It was almost an event in the perfumery of a small town.

Nostalgic? Yes. But, who cares!

Why they would also discontinue it, I have no idea. But I know that it could still easily stand its ground today and would even fit into the current trend. What a shame. So I am left with the memory and a few drops.

review_title: Fragrance Hieroglyphs and the Glorious Three
review_content:
Next to Background by Jil Sander, Envy For Men by Gucci is the fragrance that perhaps influenced me the most before I began to delve a little deeper into the subject of perfume. And like Background, Envy For Men has also disappeared from the market. EFM is a wonderful Eau de Toilette that is not easy to describe. I wore this fragrance at a time when I might have used three perfumes regularly. I didn't miss anything back then. The access to a perfume at that time - and I don't mean this judgmentally - was direct, unfiltered, simply naive.

In such cases, there is always the danger of romanticizing a fragrance retrospectively. Therefore, I tried to approach this scent critically once again and took my time in assessing it. Green is Envy for Men not only in color. The fragrance is spicy, with a slight sharpness that could stem from coriander present at the beginning. What I also recognize is a sour freshness. I really like that, as it makes EFM not sluggish but rather agile. Woody notes quickly come into play, making this perfume more masculine. A bit of everything? What kind of fragrance is this?

In the dry down, there is a beautiful and subtle sweetness, in my opinion. For my taste, the vanilla is not too present. I have a kind of long drink association. EFM is not boozy, but it does remind me of an alcoholic beverage. At the same time, Envy exudes something cool. I cannot identify the mandarin, but a pleasant fruity nuance plays in the background. It is not a true oriental. Nor is it a pure wood scent. So what is Gucci Envy For Men then?

For me, it is wearable in all four seasons and various occasions, although one must admit that the fragrance is not subtle. However, I do not find it vulgar or loud. For me, it is the perfect holiday scent, whether skiing or at the beach. I do not understand the leathery component in this fragrance; it does not reveal itself to me. I would not have thought that leather could be included here. By the way, this strongly reminds me of Relax by Davidoff. Indeed, what a fabulous thing the return of the glorious three would be! Background by Jil Sander, Relax by Davidoff, and Envy For Men by Gucci. I would probably acquire all three fragrances immediately, although I still consider Background to be the undisputed number one.

In my eyes, EFM is an independent and multifaceted fragrance; there is simply a lot to sniff out. I try to decipher fragrance hieroglyphs. However, when it comes to longevity and sillage, I am quite sure: both are in the upper good range. A mysterious scent, not truly eerie (in the sense of frightening), but somehow puzzling.

(Thank you very much for the sample, Yatagan.)

If a fragrance has taught me not to believe in love at first sniff, it was Envy for Men.

The new scent came fresh out of the box onto the shelves, the perfumery owner hadn't even priced the goods yet and was looking for a list, when I already had the tester in hand. A great bottle, nicely angular, a massive black cap that covers two-thirds of the glass, a light green color that promised a lot.

The first spray on the card immediately dispersed into the air, the first whiff promised true joy. Further sniffing at the card over the next few minutes only got better. I sniffed other new arrivals, but they all went straight into the trash can that day. After a few minutes, I was sure I wanted to test this scent on my skin as well. A few sprays on my wrists and "Aaaaaaaaahhhh!" Delight! A lovely fragrance! So off I went back onto the street, did a little shopping, had a small lunch at my favorite bistro, and then straight back to the perfumery. The scent kept getting better. By then, Mrs. Schnurer also knew the price, quickly the discounts for the first sale of this new fragrance were negotiated, and the largest size EdT came home with me in a bag. I smelled good, my girlfriend could smell me well, I was happy!

The next morning, I applied this wonderful new scent again, and just after a good quarter of an hour, the hammer fell! First came the tart citrus freshness of the mandarin, then soon followed spicy pepper notes paired with floral accords like jasmine and rose, and then ... parsley! And with a vehemence I had never smelled before. The scent of this lovely garden herb covered everything, lasting the entire day. I could smell nothing else. My surroundings were consulted, but no, they smelled all sorts of things, just not parsley! In the following days, I repeatedly applied the fragrance in different concentrations and always got the same result: parsley!

Two weeks later, I went back to the perfumery. Suddenly, their tester smelled like parsley to me too. On site, they said they couldn't understand this association, but that perhaps I had "wired" either the garden carnation or the vetiver incorrectly. However, I have never had this connection in my nose with any vetiver scent before or since. And you don't find garden carnation too often in fragrances either.

I was disappointed, and in the following weeks, I tested the scent in all sorts of situations and seasons, but the parsley wouldn't budge. I really like parsley as a spice in food, but on the skin, it just doesn't work.

Since then, I only buy fragrances after I have thoroughly tested them with a small tester over a few days. This was my very first overwhelming fragrance mispurchase, and it still lingers intensely in my nose!

review_title: My Big Brother, Gucci Envy Men "the fragrant bond"
review_content:
Gucci Envy Men will always remind me of my big brother.
I was just 14 years old at the time, and I smelled this fragrance in our house.
But what was it?
Something sweet?
Something fresh?
Something classic?
Or was it spicy?
I didn't know, but one thing I knew:
I had never smelled anything like it before, and my nose liked it.
Following my nose, down the hallway through the open door,
I ended up two doors down in my brother's room.

He was standing there,
in front of his mirror,
his last glance,
his last spray,
like every weekend "picobello" to go out, but this time with this new masculine scent.

He was now complete.
He was my role model.
My feelings at that moment were:
I wanted to grow up quickly,
to have his clothes,
to keep his style,
and last but not least, to wear this fragrance.
I wanted to become a man, no
a gentleman.

From that day on, this fragrance became "the fragrant bond" between me and my brother.
It never left my nose,
not my mind
and to this day, not my heart.

Unfortunately, this perfume is no longer produced.
Nevertheless, I found a 100 ml bottle of EDT online
and gifted it to him for his birthday this year after 11 years.
He was very happy about it, but he doesn't know what joy he has given me.

Gucci Envy Men, my big brother.

Envy is one of the few perfumes that I can tolerate on myself. It is just sweet enough that the woody note becomes pleasant and creates a very subtle masculine aura without a cologne scent.
It clings almost a bit too long for my taste - one spray is enough to last until the next wash (thanks to Tonalid). I always apply perfume to my clothes and never on my skin, due to allergies. This does not hinder its development. When applied a second time, the dry down accumulates, which does not contribute to an improvement.....
Unfortunately, it is no longer available.

review_title: Now comes the hobby-professional analysis, my friends, buckle up
review_content: Strong ginger meets a strangely orange-like citrus fruit, crossed with a bit of anise and herbs. Something like that. A good, interesting opening, where sometimes a hint of mint and a bit of medicinal balm comes through. I can't quite place it. A beautiful, chaotic jumble. Then it becomes woody, earthier, and the "orange" turns into a leathery lemon. The vanilla comes...

This is my first comment here on this forum, after having read along for months. I felt compelled to share my opinion as well. Is it necessary? Probably not, but I’ll do it anyway. Please forgive me :)
Why this fragrance in particular? Because it is, to this day, a MILESTONE in the history of perfume for me!
When it was released in 1998, I tried it right away and it was love at first sight. Since then, this fragrance treasure has accompanied me everywhere. I wore it at work, in the disco, on a first rendezvous. Although I was too young for this scent back then, I loved it fiercely and still do. No one my age liked it at the time. But I have never received as many compliments for a fragrance as I have for this one. It’s also a sign that a perfume really suits you. The opening of coriander, mandarin, pepper, and rosewood is very noticeable, and then there’s the leather, vanilla, and patchouli. For me, a hint of marzipan develops at the very end-divine! Very harmonious and also very charismatic! Now you have left us! I only have about 80ml of this green gold left. I hope it lasts a long time.... I pray to the gods that there will be a reissue someday...

review_title: Good, but it lacks the final kick
review_content:
So, after I managed to snag a bottle of Envy for Men at a great price here in the forum (thanks to Schnuffos), I guess it's time for a comment.

Envy was a blind buy, as I couldn't get a sample from my trusted fragrance dealer. However, due to the fragrance notes and comments, I really wanted to test this scent.

The top note is truly successful. As a fan of Fahrenheit Absolute, I love spicy perfumes, wonderfully peppery and spicy! The top note could definitely last a bit longer, as it is the highlight of the fragrance for me.

Longevity is indeed a strong suit of EfM (I can only agree with my predecessor MaxFavier: You can still smell it the next day!), but it is quite limited to sweetened patchouli.

I would also agree on the character of EfM. This is more of a scent from the category: Here I am! What’s the world worth!
Subtle is probably the wrong word (sorry Hoto74666), as an office scent it is rather unsuitable.

Long story short: Great scent, but to get 100% from me, the spicy component would need to last significantly longer. For me, Fahrenheit Absolute is still the benchmark for spicy fragrances, and EfM doesn't quite reach that.
In comparison, it's quite an average scent. I'm curious to see how long it will still be produced.

review_title: I am at a ball in...
review_content: ... a costume as Il Buffone. To this, I wear this fragrance that stands out from the crowd and perfectly matches the edges and corners of this costume. Upon applying this fragrance, the first thing that hits the nose is a woody citrus spicy peppery scent. Quickly, woody and floral accords blend in. A hint of leather with vanilla becomes noticeable. The patchouli makes this...

Jasmine and white floral dominant fragrances are often hard for me. They can be fine as supporting notes but when they are front and center many of them to turn very dirty smelling on my skin or just become too screechy and headache inducing for me. However Gorgeous Jasmine does none of those things and the only real way to describe this scent is pretty. It probably won't blow anyone's mind for uniqueness but it is still a lovely, feminine floral fragrance.

I am a big believer that softer and easy reach scents very much have a place in a perfume collection and not everything needs to be some great masterpiece. I can respect a fragrance that sets out to be good at what it says on the tin. Gorgeous Jasmine is precisely that. The jasmine here is not a dirty white floral, rather it is fresh and green. The rose very much takes a back seat and lets the jasmine sparkle. I said this also in my review of Gorgeous Magnolia but I really like the way Gucci does patchouli in this line. Patchouli is such a hit or miss note but here it is, not a dirty patchouli but simply a very light earthiness. When combined with the creaminess of the sandalwood, magnolia and benozoin and the greeness of the jasmine, the entire effect is realistic jasmine and fresh, clean feeling.

Very pretty, easy reach daily scent that feels appropriate for any situation and probably could be worn year round if you're fine with skin scents. My husband seems to like this one too because he is not someone who comments regularly on my perfume, but every time I wear this he tells me I smell nice.

Absolutely love the packaging and atomizer of this line. The scent is like a 7.5-8 but these bottles and atomizers are 10/10 for me. I own a 50 ml bottle and could see myself repurchasing.

Eta: this has become one of the most worn perfumes in my collection. So easy to wear, appropriate any time and anywhere. This is now one of my favorite clean white florals.

review_title: Delicate flower on a green branch
review_content:
That’s exactly what is says – Gorgeous Jasmine. I received a tester as a gift with my other purchase, and I must say I didn’t expect much because I am not very into realistic jasmine or hard-core white florals, but this is so beautiful! At first blast, it’s fresh and floral – just what you’d expect. Then, an hour or so later, jasmine blooms into more intense, soapier self that I would whole-heartedly recommend to all white-flower fans. Then rose joins it producing warmer, sunnier impression, and jasmine begins to remind me mock-orange flowers, which I adore, with slight accents of solar notes and green leaves. Then I begin noticing magnolia coupled with benzoin, reminding me a bit of Zara Violet blossom or even Mugler’s Alien. Then sandalwood adds substance and creaminess, making it warmer.

Also, ever-so-delicate patchouli keeping it mysterious with a cool waft here and there! The tester leaflet didn’t list patchouli note and I thought I was imagining it half of the day, until I looked GFGJ up here and was reassured that I’m not hallucinating.

This is the best jasmine that I ever tried – not too intense, but not obscured by other ingredients, rather, tenderly supported by them, like a flower floating in sweet nectar. Other jasmine scents often peddle jasmine so much that you would be better off just using essential oil instead. Yet Gucci Flora creates an impression of a fresh delicate flower on a green branch, and it’s lovely. It makes you feel lovely too. Very inspiring perfume.

If I had to ascribe a personality to it, I would say it’s a young girl walking in the morning to her first office job, full of hopes and ambition, willing to impress, but also daydreaming about love. She wears white blouse, minimalistic sparkles of jewelry, and wind is playing with her shiny loose hair.

I perceive it as a perfect day or even morning scent, lovely for spring, cooler summer days, and early autumn. It has the freshness and the warmth enough to cover most of the year except the dramatic extremes. I am so amazed by it that I must post it right away, so no comment on longevity yet, but I plan to update.

Bad news is that upper notes smell like citrus flavored dishwash. Good news is that they disappear pretty much immediately. But where's the jasmine? I tested it on both myself and my partner, and on neither of our bodies was there any jasmine. Just rose and magnolia on a super sweet balsamic backdrop.

I don't know, perhaps it's my own fault for expecting a fresh jasmine scent from a perfume called "Gorgeous Jasmine"? Or for expecting anything at all for that matter. Whatever flowers were there – withered away into incomprehensible sweet mush after the first hour. By the end of the second hour it was completely gone from my skin.

An utter waste of money, but hey, at least it didn't waste much of my time.

I am pleasantly surprised. I wasn't expecting much since I'm not that much of a floral fragrance type of girl, but I WILL be moving on to a 10ml travel size once I'm through with the sampler vial.

So, everything starts off with a fresh zing of juicy and tangy citrus. After a few minutes, the jasmine unfurls its creamy, white floral scent and it is a beauty, let me tell you! I could now sense the black pepper giving the juice a very uplifting vibe. It's giving me vintage, but at the same time, modern esthetic. Beautiful and well blended together, I instantly fell in love. It's soft, feminine, lovely and just so nice! The roses blended themselves very well to tone down the indolic aspect of the jasmine. After a while there is this woody but creamy aspect that's coming through thanks to the sandalwood, but the jasmine does remain the star all throughout. I usually don't like patchouli, but this time I barely smelled it since the jasmine was in the spotlight. All in all it's a beautiful fragrance if you're searching for a perfume where jasmine is the main character. It's pretty, smells great and is a great crowd-pleaser!

Despite not liking the fragrances from Gucci I have tried as of yet, I have always been circling around Gucci Flora Gorgeous Gardenia. Something about it spoke to me, but I only tried it quickly and with a small spray on the wrist. It was nice, but I wasn't enamored. Then, suddenly, Gorgeous Jasmine was launched and something about the two bottles called my name, so I tried it on a paper strip and I just had to try it properly!
Initially quite sweet and of course, floral. Somewhat soapy, which I didn't expect when trying it on a paper strip.
I would have loved the juicy fruitiness of mandarin, which is listed in the composition, but it is nowhere to be found.

After dry down, Gorgeous Jasmine becomes quite powdery.
And alas, it is boring. Absolutely boring, like any other Gucci fragrance I have tried...
It's been a while since I've reviewed a fragrance based on the scent on a paper strip, hasn't it?
So, because of the difference, I've sprayed generously on a paper strip and let me tell you, the mandarin is detectable even from afar!
I sprayed the test strip and layed it to evaporate the alcohol, just in arms reach, I could smell the fruity mandarin. After dry down, it is much milder and up close, Gorgeous Jasmine is a fruity and juicy floral! This is what made me so intrigued in the first place, the charming fruitiness with the mild floral in the back. On skin, however, Gorgeous Jasmine is nothing gorgeous, just a floral simpleton.
So simple and generic that I'm struggling to describe it, whereas on paper many words come to mind; fruity, fresh, feminine, delicate, perfect for summer, and even spring, a little peachy, reminding me of The Scent by Boss, I could go on.

Once again, I must admit that designer fragrances aren't for me.

Received my first bottle as a birthday gift from a friend, immediately hooked after the first use and finished the whole bottle since then. First impression: what caught my attention and liking was the Jasmine note being very much evident and fresh. I'm now on my second bottle, but for some odd reason, it now smells like the bathrooms on an airplane. I don't know if im insane...

Gucci's Flora Gorgeous Jasmine is a fun and fresh fruity-floral that doesn't take itself too seriously. On the flipside, it can come across as too sharp, sweet and synthetic. It's not necessarily a bad perfume, but you can tell Alberto Morillas was composing to a strict budget here.

Flora Gorgeous Jasmine opens to a salvo of bright clean bergamot with a hint of orange blossom. The jasmine is present from the start, and is equal parts sweet and green. It's a clean jasmine, without a hint of indoles, and is ever so slightly soapy thanks to the orange blossom, and a nice (if noticeably synthetic) watery rose note. The overall effect is similar to a fruity-floral shampoo.

In the dry down, there are wafts of amber and scratchy patchouli, but the fragrance stays fairly light and clean, thanks to the persistent bergamot and jasmine. I suspect the bergamot's persistence is due to the citrus-floral aromachemical dihydromyrcenol - an ingredient commonly used in men's fragrances and cleaning products, which can smell harsh and chemical in certain contexts. This is, unfortunately, one of those contexts. It doesn't outright ruin the fragrance, but it does detract from an otherwise well-balanced composition.

While Flora Gorgeous Jasmine is overall a playful, uplifting fragrance, it can't match the elegant ease of Gucci's Bloom EAU DE PARFUM. It may share Bloom's touch of greenness, but it also lacks Bloom's creaminess and smoothness. It's just too sharp, too unrefined, and ultimately pretty ineffectual.

review_title: Good clean, fresh floral for leaving a good impression or smelling good in summer, not for special events.
review_content: I also tried Gucci Bloom and among the 2, this one, the Flora, is more youthful. It is of the little perfumes of Jasmine that do not smell to lady, but more fresh and young. Gucci Bloom on the other hand is a 100% floral perfume that smells very elegant and fresh, but maybe not very suitable for young or casual environments, it gives that impression of seriousness. Perfect if...

All I smell is bath and body works gardenia from the 90s. Did not expect that at all. I mean it’s fresh and clean, very white floral, but yeah…I can see why ET Gardenia is often mentioned as a dupe. Very linear, it just stays gardenia all the way through for me. …This really makes me curious about Gucci’s actual Flora Gardenia fragrance.

Sillage is medium the first hour and then it shrinks down pretty close to skin, longevity is maybe three hours.

I am pretty bummed out about this one…It’s a cold and wet November day so maybe that has something to do with it. Putting my bottle away until I can try again in the spring.

Edit to add: Spring came around and as the weather warmed up this fragrance really started to bloom. The jasmine started to shine and the performance is much better in a mild, warm atmosphere

I am still quite new to the world of perfume; my entry into this new "obsession" began a few weeks ago. For the first time in ages, I was in the perfume department to test a few classics among women's perfumes and to get an overview. But even before I could test the first perfume on my list, this bottle caught my eye. Among all the extravagant and elegantly designed glass bottles, it stood out - a turquoise bottle, my favorite color, with a floral vintage print on the label, subtle yet elegant, exactly in the style I love so much. Of course, I HAD to test it first. And I was shockingly in love. The slightly fruity mandarin blossom note in the opening, the sweet and gentle jasmine scent, even the soapy note in the drydown that reminds me of laundry detergent, but in a good way... I can certainly understand that it won't be everyone's favorite. But for me, it is simply a feel-good fragrance through and through.

I tested several other perfumes, some of which I liked very much, but this fragrance was still my favorite. After 2-3 more sniffing tours through various perfumeries, I finally got it for myself. And everyone around me loves the scent on me, also because it fits me perfectly. It's as if it was developed for me, including the bottle design.

I intentionally waited to write the review until now because I wanted to make sure that my initial enthusiasm wouldn't fade once I got to know more fragrances. In the meantime - that is, at this moment while I am writing this text - I have sniffed a lot of fragrances and expanded my collection with some other favorites. And yet, Flora Gorgeous Jasmine remains my absolute favorite. Gentle, elegant, fresh jasmine with a slight sweetness cuddles up to my skin and caresses me without being intrusive. For the people around me, the scent seems to be something very special; I have been asked several times which perfume I am wearing because it smells so "fine and elegant." On my skin, it lasts a good 6 hours before it becomes intimate; for the first 3-4 hours, I still enjoy the scent myself, but after that, I no longer perceive it, although my surroundings do for a bit longer.

My associations with the fragrance:
At the beginning: A walk in spring, just before the start of summer. A light, refreshing breeze blows over the skin, gentle sun rays provide warmth, and the long-missed, sweet-smelling flowers adorn nature.

Drydown: A hug from mom (I could swear she always used a laundry detergent that smells similar), before you fall into the freshly made, cool, soft bed after a long day, freshly showered.

For me, this is still the fragrance that suits me best, that brings me joy every time I smell it - and it appeared just in time at the beginning of my journey into the world of perfumes.

My new favorite. Contemporary AND classic. If you don't have a grand Southern wardrobe at hand or would attract too much attention with a crinoline, but still want to feel superelegant - then you can wear whatever you like and still irritate your surroundings olfactorily with a grand entrance. I have a great fondness for a polished lady atmosphere with a discreet costume in pastel tones, silk blouse, fluttering scarf, wagon wheel hat, and matching gloves - all silky soft and flowing. Snug and slightly floral, sweet but not too sweet, and a little blurred - a daguerreotype with faded colors and hair blown by the wind. There must be some counterpoint. This jasmine-supported favorite perfume has such a grandeur, as the citrusy freshness of the mandarin blossom prevents the elegant jasmine from drifting off into the musty bayou. And it also serves as an opening for the ladylike magnolia - I don't mean that in a derogatory way, quite the opposite. It becomes creamy and skinny butter-soft over time, as the hesperidic note recedes. Then the sillage also diminishes. Longevity is good. The high-quality bottle is a decoration for any vanity or bathroom shelf. - It can be enjoyed entirely for oneself, but also brings joy to others. More suitable for ladies over 30 - for those who prefer a slightly fruitier and cheekier scent and enjoy similarly playful ingredients, I recommend the equally new delightful flanker from My Way Floral. I like that one too and it feels like Flora's younger cousin ;-)

I admit that I immediately reflected on the commercial with the white poodle in the flower meadow - because poodles and flowers are my thing.
I had to test this promising fragrance.
Especially since the beautiful poodle was cast as the protagonist of this scent.
Even my poodle-loving husband enjoys the spot - and he has no objections to driving to the perfume store with me.
And the trip was worth it.
The jasmine is radiant white and lush - and is delicately accompanied by magnolia.
Roses mix in with a velvety touch, making the fragrance soft and cuddly.
The patchouli frames the pleasant scent composition - and adds a touch of elegance.
A casually elegant fragrance that leans towards the romantic side.
I find it irresistible - and we reach for the bottle in harmony.

How I love the early summer time when jasmine spreads its rich, sometimes intoxicating aromas in generous waves of fragrance.
These golden faces with their radiant white petal crowns on the dark green foliage, which, due to its dullness, forms the most beautiful backdrop for their radiance, the decorative feathery “umbels” of summer jasmine, the delicate star jasmine, and all its many varieties that have one thing in common: their unmistakable scent!
Sometimes fresh and just gently unfolding, a moment of virginity, yearning towards the sunset as the right time for white flowers begins; or the already practiced, sensual blooming beauties in their full ripeness, not to forget the slightly overripe and therefore somewhat carrion-like fragrant "little stinkers," which so wonderfully serve as softly glowing light reflections to help the heavy oud compositions achieve their warm, erotic-floral radiance.
It’s no wonder that jasmine must not be missing in almost any of the classic floral fragrance creations and often spreads great fragrance joy as a soloist.

And who would be surprised that I quickly positioned my little, so curious nose for “Flora Gorgeous Jasmine” by Gucci after my Belgian fragrance friend Jessica was so enthusiastic and urged me to try this fragrance composition: "You must try it, Dear: It's really gorgeous!"
I could have held back due to previous Gucci fragrance experiences:
Oh, if only I had!
But I sprayed myself, albeit not too generously, only to be immediately taken captive by a true wave of jasmine fragrance with a slightly unpleasant metallic-iridescent streak.
Almost unleashed, as I already wrote in the statement, jasmine squadrons invade me and my senses, which are so trustingly wide open and receptive.
But where is the sensual allure, its ripe eroticism, the fine, sometimes softly purring feline animality of my beloved jasmine?
A tsunami-like wave of white flowers overwhelms me dominantly, leaving me no time to enjoy the different aromas of the beloved floral splendor.
So dominant that the fresh and simultaneously delicate citrus fragrance entrée with the tingling note of black pepper only briefly appears like a quick flicker, acting almost as a door opener for “His Highness Jasmine” and must immediately step aside.
Magnolia in spring's gentle delicacy gets startled and unfortunately flees too quickly, only the fragrant splendor of the Damask roses, which have been too proud for generations to yield the field to this abundance of foreign aromas, stands almost defiantly against it.
Even here, this jasmine does not allow for any dissent; its importance must come first!
I miss the usually harmonious interplay of the fragrance notes: What a pity!
The beautiful base of aromatic and resinous-smoky fragrance notes, which can be traced back to sandalwood and benzoin, and which should provide a familiar and skillful final highlight with rich golden-brown and earthy patchouli accords, almost gets lost on me.
Up to this point, this unusual jasmine weight, with its actually very sympathetic entourage in tow, has already overwhelmed me (and thus made me scent-deaf to everything else?).

I am exhausted and slowly feel bothered.
So the not too pronounced longevity is quite welcome; my skin doesn’t seem to agree either.
My beloved jasmine magic has probably been bound here in richly flowered branches to a witch's broom, with which my devotion to it - at least here in this creation - is to be driven away.
It worked: I capitulate to the fragrance fullness of Gucci's "Flora Gorgeous Jasmine"
And so I am glad when the overly loud proclamation: “Jasmine to power!” slowly fades away, along with the consequences of a fragrance explosion, which I did not expect at all.
Only now, as I resign, do pleasantly creamy, soapy fragrance nuances emerge from my skin, reminiscent of “Jasmine at its best!”, which finally reconcile me a bit, so that we do not part in complete discord.

I admit, I struggle to come to terms with Gucci's “Flora” creations; we do not like each other, despite the tempting fragrance pyramids that always try to persuade me and the dear fragrance friends who enthusiastically recommend them to me.
This time I was ready to try - "Jasmine" was the enchanting magic word that lured me in, but I emerged from this adventure quite disheveled.

As soon as I got home after testing it on the back of my hand at the perfumery, I was greeted with a "wow you smell so nice, so clean!" I had to order it right after because it impressed me as well. For me, this is a great fresh and slightly sweet scent that reminds me of freshly washed laundry. In the drydown, I pick up a note of tuberose (which isn’t actually in it), which slightly reminds me of L'Interdit (My Way as well!). Beautiful fragrance, not surprising, after all it was created by Alberto Morillas!

review_title: Jasmine of creamy tea and fresh flowers - Patchouli almost none
review_content: This is my absolute favorite jasmine accord, the most beautiful celebration of jasmine. Both are present here: the herbaceous-green jasmine tea with creamy milk, but also the fresh jasmine flower from the garden. They sound wonderfully noble and mature together. Someone has created a monument to jasmine here, a tribute, an ode. I love it. You feel fresh and grown-up and botanical and connected to the world. Mega. Patchouli is almost undetectable here, so there’s no comparison with Scandal by Gaultier or Black Opium or La vie est belle - I can hardly sense it, and that says something - at least a factor of 10 less than in the aforementioned.

The scent is a dream.
It is very present. Right from the opening, there is a very prominent, authentic, soft, yet loud! jasmine note followed by a sweet freshness. The fragrance has a long-lasting durability and a great sillage. I think the scent is fantastic. I give it a 9.5 and a clear buying decision.

Anyone who likes jasmine will find joy in this.

At first, there is a lot of lemon enveloped by jasmine. You feel like you are in a jasmine field with lemon trees standing at the edge.

Over time, it becomes a bit sweeter, but the lemony note remains present in the background.

A very floral scent that, in my opinion, can also be worn in winter.

Unfortunately, it doesn't last long on my skin. After 3 hours, it was only faintly noticeable, and after 4-5 hours, it was completely gone. It is only still detectable on clothing afterwards.

Jasmine can be green, herbaceous, and a bit bittersweet, reminiscent of tea; it can smell creamy like a milky tea; or floral like a white sweet jasmine flower. I can sense all these aspects of jasmine here. It is an ode to the different sides of jasmine. Patchouli, which usually tends to dominate a fragrance for me and can even ruin it, is here only very quietly in the...

The bergamot notes remind me of L'interdit, but this perfume is lighter, more floral, and more liberated. After 2-3 hours, it reminds me of the Schauma herbal shampoo from around 2010, which was always at my grandma's... a cozy, nostalgic scent for me. But even without this association, I would embrace this fragrance; it is simply a comforting scent.
Unfortunately, the fragrance fades after just a few hours.

I find the advertising spot wonderfully fitting... I came into contact with the fragrance through my sister, and I wouldn't have thought before that jasmine would appeal to me so much.. To me, it smells like a wonderful bouquet of flowers with jasmine, but without the heaviness or very strong sweetness of typical jasmine (I know jasmine flowers from my mother's garden), as this often reminds me more of a scent from my grandmother.. Overall, for me, it is a very fresh and floral fragrance with a slightly citrusy note.

This one gets much hate, undeservedly so, in my opinion. I feel the mistake many make is to use the same measuring stick to judge all fragrances. Not every scent should be noticed from across the room, or be expected to last over 8 hours- Subtlety is sexier than being overt and in your face. That being said, I think this performs fine, on par with most fragrances. If you look on the other site, there are many unsolicited reviews from women also for this, so I feel this needs more accurate representation on this site also. Yes, the one review here is from a woman, and she is entitled to her opinion, but I would like to share the fact that others do indeed enjoy this Gucci. In fact, most of them say it is indeed sexy and mysterious, check for yourself.

So, anyway, this is a nice tobacco-violet based scent with the cypress providing the interesting nose tickle in the similar vein as aquatics do. It isn't the most favorite in my collection, but puts a smile on my face whenever I sniff it, and I think more folks should give it a try. Also, the bottle itself is handsome, a timeless classic in its shape and feel.

review_title: The best Gucci classic collection for me
review_content:
bought in the summer of 2011, I tested it in perfumery in 2009, I found it fantastic.

it is a perfume that I appreciate wearing on summer evenings for its refreshing and elegant side.

It's really hard to describe, one has the impression that this perfume was made for an elite, I can easily imagine a cosa nostra sponsor wearing this type of perfume, for an occasional dinner.

a perfume of seducer which it seems to me is no longer marketed in stores in France.

if you have the opportunity to test it do not hesitate I find it underrated.

Gucci by Gucci pour Homme is certainly nice, but a little too safe in my opinion.

A sales assistant described this fragrance as being sweet, however I do not agree. I'm also not very convinced that this is a woody chypre.

I'd say that this fragrance is more of a woody aromatic. The scent is refreshing, masculine, yet bland. A little like Only The Brave by Diesel.

The cypress and bergamot opening, while somewhat unique, needs more strength. I appreciate that Gucci wanted to produce something modern and stylish, however they failed, creating something rather generic.

Gucci by Gucci pour Homme "is not meant to be vibrant, virile, sexy, attractive to women, refreshing or fancy." However from a female's perspective, women like their men to wear a fragrance that is memorable, something that they may smell elsewhere yet connect to you with fondness. This fragrance just doesn't seem to have that ability.

The scent dries down to something rather musky and subtle. Unfortunately the unique notes like elemi resin and olibanum aren't standouts here.

The lasting strength is very poor, terrible in fact, which is very disappointing. I do still recommend this fragrance, however not with upmost enthusiasm.

review_title: Victim of much confusion (and possibly reformulation)
review_content:
It seems like Gucci by Gucci pour Homme is the victim of many misconceptions. Reviewers seem to confuse it with a multitude of other scents, it gets heavily criticised for its performance, and Parfumo has the wrong perfumer (I would fix it but if Aurélien Guichard can’t be bothered to claim it, then I won’t force it upon him).

My batch must be 2013; I purchased it after a girl I knew chased a man down the street to ask what he was wearing, and then she insisted on my buying it. The girl didn’t work out, but I continued to wear it for many years in the winter months. I never really had any issues with longevity - it doesn’t last a whole day at work, but it’ll get you 3/4 of the way there.

As to the smell, without breaking it down to notes, it’s a spicy, green and slightly woody fragrance. I’m not sure if my tastes have changed and I used to like it more, or if 12 years of improper storage have ended it, or simply smelling other top-quality fragrances have moved this down in the pecking order.

It’s still pleasant but inoffensive, a good office scent, and the Parfumo score of 6.9 is very harsh (it may have been reformulated and be worth such a score), but I have to admit that it’s not worth seeking out or buying.

review_title: Quite good, but not a smash
review_content: Tobacco, powdery and synthetic sweet. Average woman-friendly, but not able to go them crazy. It's like a "good, ok..." but not "Wow, amazing". Good for cold days and evenings, business, but in my opinion not for daily use. I had travel bottle, simply gorgeous!

For me, Gucci by Gucci is somewhat underrated here. First of all, the bottle is really top-notch and looks unique! I find the scent just as unique! Something between tobacco and amber and freshness. I know nothing comparable! A great men's fragrance - for everyday use - for the office and certainly unique enough to stand out in all that uniformity! Except the sillage is really...

Gucci by Gucci pour Homme - not to be confused with Gucci pour Homme - is another easily available and mid-priced fragrance from this brand.

Right upon spraying, you notice: This is nothing special. What I primarily smell here is - average. After about a minute, a scent begins to develop: it is somewhat soapy, a bit vaguely floral, slightly aldehydic fresh, but also sweet, voluminous, and broad. A type of amber is probably responsible for this. Additionally, there seems to be a kind of musk involved. The florals are the most pleasant aspect of the fragrance, but you can find better ones elsewhere.

The notes read interestingly, but the execution does not match. I bet cheap synthetic fragrance materials have been used here. In a blind test, I would have considered this scent more of a representative of the cheap segment. A truly off-putting example of a designer fragrance. What a quality difference between this perfume and the spicy Gucci pour Homme!

My recommendation: Stay away!

Season:
actually year-round, but in winter the scent has no chance of survival

Age:
25 and up

Suitability:
good for the office; I wear it for going out and for special occasions

Intensity:
varies: In winter, the scent fades within a maximum of 2 hours, even if you spray 12 times (!). Now in spring, it looks better. I use it together with the ASB, still have to spray a lot, but it lasts between 6 and 12 hours. I myself perceive it only very faintly, but I have been approached about it several times, so the projection is fine. GbG is more of a subtle scent

Fragrance:
At the start, the scent comes across as very cool and fresh, I even perceive slight aquatic notes, in the heart note, jasmine clearly emerges and makes the scent a bit more lovable. Additionally, I also detect a leather accord, on some days it reminds me of synthetic leather, which I don't mind at all. Amber and tobacco in the base give the scent warmth, not necessarily sweetness, but prevent it from becoming too bitter.

Conclusion:
I love this scent! I have searched for something like this for a long time and have finally found it. GbG is very balanced: fresh without being citrusy or significantly aquatic, and warm without being sweet or overly woody. The scent is very modern, yet somehow also comes across as classic; it doesn’t drift into the unisex category, but it’s also not overly masculine. The Gucci fragrances (my favorite label, by the way) are all very natural, but this one is the most synthetic among them, yet it’s not a chemical bomb. I also find it to be the least spectacular, but I like it the most and it’s the easiest for me to wear. GbG comes almost 100% close to my ideal concept of a (men's) fragrance and leaves me with hardly any wishes unfulfilled. This is how I want to smell.
GbG has faced a lot of criticism: too tobacco-heavy, too synthetic, not a real chypre scent, etc. I think it is good just the way it is and currently my favorite scent alongside Mania. On the other hand, I can certainly understand that many people, including myself, find this scent boring or even bland. It is certainly not a masterpiece, but it smells as if it were made just for me, so to speak, by request.

P.S.: Before buying, definitely test it on the skin multiple times. Many people, including myself, have significant issues with its longevity.

review_title: Hardly there, and it's already gone.
review_content:
Something about this fragrance has captivated me. I love this composition. "Fresh-Spicy" really hits the mark here, especially an incredible lightness of being that I can sense. And the interplay of freshness with the tobacco and floral notes is truly wonderful. It suits every season and every situation, doesn't bother anyone, delights everyone, brings joy and good mood. I want to smell like this all day, every day!

Unfortunately, this is exactly the central problem. The whole day only becomes enjoyable with intense and frequent reapplication. The longevity is really incredibly poor; after two hours, the fun is over for me. Even with my nose right at the spray point, I can no longer catch a whiff of that wonderful scent. For that, the little potion - even with Gucci on it - is definitely too expensive for me.

In summary, I can only give a good rating for the fragrance and the massive bottle; unfortunately, the other criteria really fall through the cracks. What a shame!

Mamma mia, what a flop, almost a farewell to the great Gucci times. The brand Gucci really shoots itself in the foot with such extreme disappointments like Guilty or By Gucci - not absolute stinkers, but so insignificant that the fragrances would probably smell worse than most drugstore scents at the bottom shelf and would fade away without a sound.

I like the first 10 minutes, the top note. There’s a slight hint of Gucci feeling - but then it’s gone for the next 7 hours. I was just shaking my head while testing it on my wrist. They take such highly regarded classics like PHI off the market and come out with something so banal. Luckily, my PH II on the shelf still reminds me of the glorious times of the brand. But something needs to change in the coming years to avoid being completely out of favor with perfume fans, at least the gentlemen.

The bottle is great, solid and heavy, the spray head is also of high quality. The sillage is hardly present and the longevity is in the gray average of 6-8 hours.

But the scent itself is partly unbearable; I wouldn’t want to smell like this at work, in my free time, let alone at fancier events. Not even while exercising. The short initial minutes are intense and thick, like a better version of Guilty, fresh yet spicy and a bit gourmand. But then it’s just a light freshness, nothing behind it. As if they had cooked this scent on low heat, a bit too much synthetic notes come through, smelling somewhat like fresh experiments in a chemistry lab or a sewage explosion near heavy industry.

How can Gucci invest so little in a new men’s fragrance!
Keep your hands off and raise your fist for a boycott!

I can't evaluate this perfume because I suspect it is somehow psychologically linked to a negative experience for me. At least no other perfume has ever caused such a strong feeling of disgust.

This initially exaggerated freshness combined with a chemical "BASF note" and a third citrus note (like Mr. Clean) is totally shocking. I've tested the scent several times now to perhaps find out what disgusts me about it. In any case, I could hardly wait to wash this smell off again.

But it lasts a very long time; you can even smell it the next day.

I think as a teenager I wouldn't view this scent so critically; it somehow reminds me of pubescent youths in the village disco. To my nose, it smells extremely cheap. If I didn't know it wasn't a cheap knockoff, I would guess it came from a discount store and was marketed under the name "Chipper Propper Citrus."

This is the first perfume I've tested where I can't give a rating on the scent because it disgusts me so terribly. Even if a sexy woman in stockings were to wear it, I would run away in disgust. Sorry for my directness; I don't mean to speak poorly of it, but apparently my brain has a negative association (or whatever it's called) when I smell this fragrance.

review_title: Money doesn't stink! - or how I opened an account at the Gucci Bank
review_content:
Gucci by Gucci pour Homme smells to me like an exclusive bank. One imagines the scent of old banknotes, futuristic designer steel furniture, noble tropical wood veneer, and sinfully expensive designer suits and costumes made of silk, cashmere, and virgin wool. Unfinished granite and marble flooring also come to mind.

I enter and am greeted warmly but reservedly. Opening an account goes smoothly, but it is not exactly cheap. Everything feels very trustworthy and conveys a sense of being "well taken care of."

When I briefly leave the bank and take another look at the cool steel-blue shimmering glass facade of the bank, it becomes clear to me that the only thing I will ever have at this bank called Gucci is a regular checking account. Nothing more, but also nothing less. But at least the interest rates are moderate. And in today's times, that's already worth something.

That Gucci still has it, even if not like in the eighties, has been proven with Gucci pour Homme.
It has not become a loud fragrance experience, but rather a refined scent that fits well in a Victorian-style office, and thanks to 800 years of English architecture, we have quite a few of those to offer.

The bottle is, in my opinion, very understated and serves excellently as a projectile if one is attacked. When you hold it in your hand, it feels very high-quality and heavy.

However, since it is more about the content, it is rather a very pleasant scent that is somewhat underestimated. Not a masterpiece, but certainly appropriate for the office. Stylishly Italian, with English restraint.
When I sprayed it, the first thing that came to mind was amber and leather, reminiscent of an old Italian villa, not musty, but elegantly furnished, and the owner is by no means someone who wants to show off what he has.
A count in Friuli would probably wear this scent, paired with tweed, corduroy pants, and a shirt. Someone who has survived from the old times when people did not flaunt but were aware of their status and wealth. Not a scent for the wannabe rich of this world, for whom Guilty is the perfect accessory.

So Gucci still has it, albeit with little refined sophistication, but good enough not to offend. Basically, an everybody's darling and all-round scent for the office.

review_title: "Modesty is the worst form of vanity."
review_content:
This quote by François de La Rochefoucauld summarizes the main character trait of Gucci by Gucci Pour Homme quite well. The fragrance is, as has been frequently mentioned, a quiet connoisseur. It remains very reserved on the body and does not feel the need to push itself to the forefront. It also quickly becomes rare and fades away.

I find the scent starts off quite multidimensional. It combines freshness, spiciness, and sweetness. However, none of these three facets dominate the others. Everything is present; the fragrance has so much potential and means, but it doesn't want to reveal everything. Primarily, it shows what it can do.

There is also a certain tension because you don't know which aspect will prevail. After a few hours, it is the freshness that lasts the longest. However, its sharp contours from the beginning have softened. The scent feels a bit unstable and doesn't quite know where it wants to go. It may start to drift because the sweetness and spiciness are still there, but not everything is in its firm place as it was at the start. The sweetness is the amber, I assume. Initially appealing, it loses its strength towards the end. The floral component of jasmine also becomes somewhat disruptive in the potpourri after a while. The spiciness is the tobacco. I find it very stylish and well integrated into the overall composition.

Overall, I find the fragrance to be beautifully multifaceted and noble; I would want to say that, so as not to give the impression that I dislike the scent. However, compared to others in this price category, it falls short because Gucci's price expectation is really steep. I also don't understand why the largest size is 90 ml and the 100 ml is withheld. For that price, one could at least expect 100 ml.

Conclusion: A well-structured and built fragrance at the beginning, which wobbles over time, becomes unhinged, and allows swimming and chaos to break out, failing to maintain its level over the full distance.

I recently came across this scent with an acquaintance. We quickly met for a beer at the bar after work, and then I suddenly smelled this fragrance. For me, it was a “WOW” moment. “Is that your scent?” “Yes, at least what's left from this morning,...”. I really liked this light touch of “business scent,” and it just suited a great suit, a nice shirt, and stylish shoes! I appreciated that it wasn't overpowering but fit perfectly into the overall picture. For me, a very successful business fragrance or something subtle for evening events.

review_title: Right from the start, the actually interesting scent runs out of steam
review_content:
Wow, what a bottle! It shouldn't fall off the shelf in the bathroom... the tiles would have a hard time coming out unscathed with that massive glass.
The scent has already been thoroughly analyzed here, for me it is a really very interesting nose-pleaser without any adventurous qualities. Fresh and classic, it comes across and doesn't really clash with anyone. I find it wearable for late spring and also for summer, even now at temperatures around 25 to 30 °C.
After long comparisons, I feel there are certain parallels to Lacoste Red, although the crocodile definitely lingers longer and more aggressively. This brings us to the biggest drawback of Gucci.
Right out of the starting blocks and even before the finish line, it runs out of steam. So it is absolutely impossible to truly savor the scent or perceive any development over a longer period. I would have to keep the bottle with me at all times and at the latest after 1 hour administer several powerful sprays to present the scent to my environment and myself throughout the day.
What a shame, it unfortunately does not fulfill a good price-performance ratio. For the weak intensity and longevity, it is unfortunately way too expensive!

I gifted myself this fragrance for Christmas. As mentioned by others in the community, the scent is relatively ordinary at first. However, it develops and reveals a warm base. I have worn it to public events where I don't want to stand out because of my fragrance, but rather through my appearance and what I have to share. ;) The longevity is really mediocre, if not barely...

Anyone who has ever been in office life or is still in it, possibly even in a higher position, will know that in some companies, at certain events, for certain hours, it seems appropriate not to appear too conspicuous. The shirt must not shimmer too pink, the tie should be subtly coordinated (light pink on ordinary pink has nothing to do with taste), the shoes preferably...

I wore the fragrance again today, as it had been sitting uselessly on my shelf for a long time (it was a gift).

Well, I unpacked it (I keep all my fragrances in their original packaging) and sprayed it on, not expecting too much, as I didn't remember it very well.
But then it happened - the scent overwhelmed me; it was fresh at first and developed throughout the day into a well-balanced blend of freshness, warmth, and bitterness.
I really liked it from the very beginning of wearing it; maybe I only like it because many others don’t, but that doesn’t matter - I like it, and that’s why I give it 91% (or my mouse gives it 92% :-)).
It may not be the best fragrance in my collection, but after wearing it for a day, I am really excited about it and find it misrepresented by both of you in some way.
However, this is my personal taste, and it doesn’t have to mean that just because I like it, everyone else will too.

Münchner

Having tried many Guilty fragrances, I was very interested in this perfume. The bottle is heavy, typically Gucci, and looks very masculine. With the first spray, a citrus-woody but also very masculine note immediately comes out. After that, it smells a bit like Gucci Guilty, and the heavy woody notes emerge. In the end, it's a combination of fresh, woody, and a little floral notes, which all create a nice freshness.
I don't really perceive patchouli and amber, and since it's an EDT, it actually lasts quite well.
Conclusion: A stylish, elegant perfume with a summery freshness.
Fades away very quickly, the scent has nothing extraordinary. For the money, there are better options. Weak

I had the fragrance in 2009 and I can positively remember the SCENT.
It was and still is very pleasant!

Unfortunately, the scent alone does not determine an assessment in this case.
Because the longevity is simply not good, as well as the sillage which also decreases rapidly once you have used the fragrance.
I only know worse from HB Bottled!

The longevity; on me it was about 4-5 hours.
The sillage; was gone after about 1 1/2 hours.
The fragrance; is TOP and I liked it very much 10/10 points...
The price, simply outrageous so I haven't bought it since then.

I have often sprayed this fragrance in the store and could hardly perceive anything. Now I ordered a sample from Douglas because there were hardly any better alternatives and my 10% voucher was about to expire. I have already commented on the Sport version, although I only have that soaked piece of fabric. Still, I recognize a clear similarity between the two. Despite the...

Not too sweet, the tobacco is not bad.
I would describe the scent as very classic, perhaps something for the businessman. You could use the bottle to knock someone out.
They didn't skimp on the glass!

review_title: Very special, but unfortunately also very weak...
review_content:
I recently treated myself to this fragrance, as I already own the sport version of it and I really liked that one...

First, the bottle: It looks really great! (100%) I generally like Gucci bottles a lot! Timelessly classic yet very special!

The scent: At first, I always perceive a "minty taste," whether that's just my nose or if it's actually like that?!? After that, the scent changes into a herbal mix and here comes the only major criticism, the longevity!

I don't know how others have experienced this scent, but I can spray it on 5 times and after 3 hours, you already have to search for Gucci by Gucci on me... For a fragrance in this price range, that's quite disappointing, as I would like to enjoy its scent and not just wear it like a disinfectant...

Many describe it as a business scent. I can agree with that as well. If you want something more understated and discreet, you really can't go wrong here.

First of all, many thanks to Awin4me for the sample:-)

My husband applied the fragrance and I could see it on his face. As I got closer, I knew right away. This is once again a scent that says nothing to you. Boring, subtle, almost a hint of "nothing." The longevity is mediocre and the fragrance stays very much in the background. I can only fully agree with my predecessors. As a target group, I only see business people who do not want to stand out at all. For us, it had nothing special...

review_title: For the adapted office drones among us...
review_content:
Pleasant without being intrusive and therefore more than suitable as a business scent, as has already been described by me. However, if you want to let the office rebel or even the office stud shine through, then this is certainly not the first choice.
But sometimes you have days when you just don’t want to stand out and prefer to blend in with the crowd of drones. So, if you want to fly under the radar of the boss, feel free to indulge here...

I experience Gucci by Gucci as 95 percent well-groomed boredom. Normally, our paths would have parted ways by now - if the remaining five percent didn’t create a somewhat interesting blend in connection with the unremarkable lion’s share.
It may be jasmine, but the main note throughout the entire scent development reminds me more of - a rather synthetic - lily of the valley. It drifts along on an aquatic accord and is cushioned at the back by musk (even though it doesn't appear in the fragrance pyramid here). The sillage is okay, and the longevity on my skin is very good - in the evening, what I sprayed on in the morning is still clearly noticeable.

In some comments here, GbG is characterized as an office scent. I agree, and I find that this type of EdT is quite pleasant for me in the office on some days - even though I generally prefer fragrances that are less inconspicuous. However, the synthetic lily of the valley does push GbG a bit out of the Boss blandness bubble; a tiny trace of extravagance in the adjusted comfort zone.

To me, Gucci by Gucci Homme feels like a 1:1 copy of Hugo Boss HUGO, which I used to wear for a long time. Floral-sweet.

Unfortunately, it doesn't last very long either - by the next morning, I could no longer perceive anything.

Although this scent has some mainstream characteristics that some of us seem allergic to, it is not at all bland. Personally, I enjoy the occasional freshy. And this one in particular because it doesn't go sweet or vanilla. There is rose indeed and it has a bit of saltiness for a fun twist. Easy-going and friendly smell with decent longevity.

I'm happy with my free sample and when I see a good discount on this I'll grab a full bottle.

I think about this one a lot. After testing more than 400 frags, nothing smells like Gucci Guilty EDP. It's fresh, but dirty. Beautiful rose forward fougere, with salt and pepper notes, drying down to a chocolatey patchouli. It's almost a niche style Eros Flame.

Super versatile. Casual or dressed-up, go anywhere type of scent. Works especially well in the transitional months, as well as nighttime year round.

I find it performs very adequately.

Best from the line for me. Designer unique-ness done right.

I always loved gucci as a brand, but in terms of fragrances I was dissapointed. Guilty Edt was synthetic and so weak, guilty elixir was also synthetic and so sweet, but it was strong. Guilty parfum was AMAZING in terms of smell but again, it was so weak, Guilty absolute was really good, but it was right opposite of the “Mass Appealing” and was just too dark for me to wear. The only gucci left was the edp, so I am here to tell you about my experience with it. Opening is… different. Chili, rose, salt and balsamic vinegar opening is something you would not easily see in a fragrance, especially if that fragrance is a designer. I was suprised at first, then i fell in love with it. Opening is the most controversial and imo the best part of the fragrance. In middle, we see orange blossom and lavender which gives a clean and floral smell and at the base Patchouli and Cedar will give a woody scent. The scent remains dark, woody, mysterious and unique while also staying floral and clean for the mass appeal. Performance is just average. You can expect somewhere 5-8 hours depending on your skin type and you will get about a foot of projection for maybe first hour and it will become a skin scent. Lasts a decent time but it doesn’t projects good. Season-wise it is not fresh enough for summer in my opinion and lacks the strength of sweet notes for the winter, so it will be best for fall and spring, but if you decide to use it in winter or summer, I don’t think people will complain. Price is kind of expensive so definitely buy it on a discount. The biggest pro and con on this fragrance is actually the same: So unique. I definitely like it but I don’t know about the others, I got a few compliments but also some of my friends didn’t like it at all because of the vinegar note. Definitely sample before a full purchase, not suitable for a blind buy.

It is one of those perfumes that I had to buy because I had tried it, a practice that every perfume enthusiast enacts but few follow through on. This creation offers something that could be classified as unique, in light of the fact that it is difficult to try to associate it with something you have known or smelled before. In my opinion, it is an absolutely unisex perfume. The rose is the protagonist from the start, where the chili pepper shines only a little and then the white flowers appear, mainly orange blossom and almost no neroli, and some woods in the background. I cannot feel the lavender and patchouli, which would give it a rougher and more masculine character. It is not a very evolutionary perfume, offering practically the same from beginning to end. It is fine, creamy, bright, and feels more comfortable in warm temperatures and during the day. It is really charming and distinguished, elegant and quite unique. The negative part is its performance, irradiating moderately around the hour and falling quickly on the skin to die before 5 hours. It is well worth compulsively pressing the spray, and if necessary reapplying, because you enjoy it.

Opens on a strong white whine vinegar and salt, which is interesting and works well for warmer weather. Dries down to a nice spicy rose with a creamy orange note.

Not great longevity or sillage on my skin, the opening notes are there for a very short while before the rose takes center stage (not a bad thing necessarily). After that it becomes closer to a skin scent, that disappears after 4-5 hours. After a couple of hours the rose still remains but the orange blossom is replaced by a weak note of dry cedarwood.

Regardless of what the bottle says this leans heavily unisex with the fresh opening and the later spicy rose offering a sort of sensual discovery closer to the skin, which I would appreciate on both men and women.

Overall a nice and unique warm weather fragrance without aquatic or citrusy notes, which although they're obviously appreciated, can feel rather outplayed by the end of the warmer season. My daily for spring.

Books I associate with this fragrance:
Slow-burning romance. Creeping ever closer until the discovery of the sensuality and warmth buried close to the skin. Alternatively a shorter, romantic story (perhaps reflecting the shorter life of the perfume)
1984- George Orwell
City of My Dreams- Per Anders Fogelström
White Nights- Dostoyevsky

I have the og EDT, it was always good, citrus, smooth aromatic. The edP is a huge improvement, honestly. For how safe it is, I don't know how it's so sexy. Compliments galore on the edT, I just recieved the edP. It's an improvement for sure. Overpriced? A bit. 90$ for 50 ml, but it does the damn job! Good release, even if it's 3 years too late

Finally, there is the GpH with the corresponding "bang". A pleasant scent for the whole year with the appropriate longevity of an EdP. If you're looking for something extraordinary, you're in the wrong place; if you simply want to smell nice and good, you've hit the jackpot. I received compliments right after the first application ;-). Of course, this is a mainstream...

Quite bold of my wife to gift me a fragrance that neither she nor I knew, especially since my collection has grown quite large. This year, I have made many perfume purchases, mostly inspired by reviews here in the forum. Unfortunately, I have often been disappointed, and I vowed not to make any blind buys for the foreseeable future.
And there it was under the tree, this Gucci. I had zero expectations for this scent, knowing that Gucci is recommended by pretty much no one. I was pleasantly surprised. Right after spraying it, I knew I liked it. A fresh and masculine scent. It immediately reminded me of Aqua di Gio Profumo. I kept smelling my wrist all evening. A sign that I like a fragrance.
The best part is that I had no high expectations and was truly positively surprised. Often in the past, it has been the opposite. Huge expectations, constantly fueled by "hype." Bought the fragrance and then thought, "okay, so this is it!?"
Conclusion: I am very satisfied with this Gucci and happy to have been positively surprised again.
Merry Christmas

In my opinion, this perfume is a must-have for anyone who wants to smell good. You can't go wrong with this fragrance.

My first encounter with the Guilty line was with the 30ml EdT, which I received as a Christmas gift. This was about seven years ago, and I got the scent because the person immediately thought of me during the first test of the perfume. I quickly used it up and completely forgot about it after a while. When I rediscovered the empty bottle and managed to get a few more sprays out, I realized that I didn't want to miss this perfume in my collection. Unfortunately, I find that the EdT doesn't smell the same as it used to, so I came across the EdP. After the first test, I immediately noticed that I had found what I was looking for.

The perfume has a pleasant spicy character and develops a nice, fresh floral character after a short time. The fragrance is best suited for colder months, and I prefer to wear it when I am dressed entirely in black (like the bottle haha).

review_title: Not standing out, but smelling good
review_content: With this fragrance, you won't stand out from the crowd or receive endless compliments. In my opinion, it doesn't come close to the EDT. It's just too inconspicuous for that. However, it's not that bad after all. The opening is quite fruity and sweet. It retains a spicy note, and after a while, the DNA of the EDT comes through. A fine woody note now makes it a delight for the nose. For me, it's a definitely wearable fragrance!

Back then, I entered a perfume store unaware, with no inkling about perfume, and just randomly "tested" a few scents. In the process, I discovered this gem. Without knowing which fragrance notes I like or am familiar with, I fell in love with this scent.
