It's nothing "super special," perhaps even a bit "flat" and not incredibly complex, but it is different from the rest, and that's what gives it its charm. The rose, lavender, and pepper offer a fragrance combination that is rarely found in the designer segment. In my opinion, it is quite mass-appealing yet still not very well-known and not worn much. I was often approached and asked what I was wearing.

In short:
The scent is not characterized by incredible craftsmanship or complexity, but by simplicity and passion. For me, it is a very special fragrance that marks the beginning of my scent journey. I would buy it again anytime!

In 2020, I stumbled upon this fragrance quite by chance. I had actually bought a different perfume, and in the packaging was a sample of this perfume. Without any great expectations, I sprayed it on; to be honest, I had never really engaged with fragrances until then. But at the moment I caught the first whiff, it was clear to me: “I need a bottle of this.”

The scent exudes pure authenticity and confidence, without being too intrusive or too feminine. The rose is perfectly integrated here - it adds character without tipping the whole thing into softness. On the contrary, to me, the fragrance feels strong, self-assured, and elegant at the same time.

Even today, years later, I still consider it one of the best designer fragrances I have ever owned. It has that certain something that is hard to describe. Something that clearly sets it apart from the crowd in its price range. A perfume that you don’t just wear, but that accompanies you and stays in your memory.

review_title: For me, it should rain red roses
review_content:
I sometimes struggle a bit with roses. Sometimes too dominant, sometimes too piercing…
Here, nestled between lavender and orange blossoms, they come softly and show themselves at their best.
And if it weren't for a subtle hint of wood and neroli in the background, the scent could easily be classified as "pour femme."
But as always, the rule applies: Don't let the label drive you crazy.

The fragrance is fresh right upon spraying, then immediately floral, slightly sweet, a bit salty, and only in the drydown does it become slightly woody. Above all, it consistently smells good. I am truly smitten. Equally modern and timeless.
This extremely harmonious mixture of fragrance notes makes it wearable year-round and for all occasions. For any gender, for any age. I really can't think of a situation where it would be inappropriate.
The bottle is perfectly fine, the sillage is understated but definitely present. The longevity also gives no reason to complain. Only after 6 hours does it become close to the skin for me, which I can live with perfectly.
Last but not least, it can be purchased very cheaply if you just look around a bit. All of this makes it the perfect daily scent for me. And if it weren't for its big brother "Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme | Gucci," it could have even become my signature scent.

There’s just one question left at the end, since it is Gucci:

Does it squeak?

Yes, but really only at the immediate moment of spraying. After that, it comes across very mature.
As long as the scent and I exist, I will keep repurchasing it.

... Canale Grande in Venice. Sitting in the gondola with me is my beloved in my arms. In her hand, she holds the rose I bought her earlier. We dock at St. Mark's Square and walk arm in arm across it, looking for a small café where we can have a cappuccino. We gaze dreamily into each other's eyes.

Upon applying this fragrance, the first thing that hits the nose is a slightly sharp rose scent. This is accompanied by a slightly sour salty note. Floral and woody accords mix with these. The patchouli adds a dark note.

The longevity and sillage are good.

This is again a fragrance for men from around 25 years old. It can be worn all year round, both during the day in the office or gym as well as in the evening at a club or for dinner.

Those who enjoy a floral woody slightly sharp fragrance will find themselves well accommodated here.

I think Gucci Guilty is a top fragrance for spring. Since everything starts to bloom and smell nice again in spring, Guilty always reminds me of fresh flowers. With its floral scent, it is very subtle but still has good longevity. I like to wear it to not stand out too much but still smell good. The price-performance ratio is also fine.

review_title: Regrets, with a ghost of musky honeysuckle.
review_content:
I regret this perfume. I tested it before I bought it, but I had tested many that day, and I believe nose confusion led to this purchase.

It feels murky, like watery leftover perfume notes muddled together. Not stinky, not memorable, and no solid personality of it's own. The one thing that saves it is that it has a little depth and not being overly bright. It does feel somewhat anchored, but unfortunately it's anchored to nothing. Though the scent is listed above as "flowery fresh," I think it's flowery, but not fresh.

It's floral but foggy. If this smell were a color it would be smog gray. Floral notes are easily discerned, and I do get a whiff of the bergamot (although this isn't a citrusy perfume). And I realize this isn't a musk, but it reminds me of one. Likewise, there is no honeysuckle note, but the blend of florals creates a reminder of honeysuckle.

This contains vanilla, but I do not smell it at all. And there's literally nothing sweet about this.

I don't hate it, but I regret it. Trying to use it up, but I won't repurchase. I'm never excited to wear it.

Gucci Bamboo is currently my absolute favorite perfume. It is also the only one for which I receive compliments when I wear it. I simply love its fresh scent, and it lasts easily from 7 in the morning until late at night. However, it does not smell like bamboo, as the name and the closure of the bottle would suggest.

I also do not perceive the bergamot as indicated in the heart note. Rather, I notice the trio of lily, orange blossom, and ylang-ylang. I also detect this in the base, along with a hint of sandalwood. Amber and vanilla, on the other hand, are not noticeable to me; the scent feels more aquatic.

Oh yes, and I have one warning: Do not spray the perfume on light-colored clothing, as I suddenly had purple stains that, however, came out with intense washing.

- screams Bamboo rather hysterically into the crowd.

The newcomer among mainstream fragrances. Gucci presents a rather heavy bottle with unfortunately mediocre content. I didn't have much expectation for it, and accordingly, I wasn't particularly disappointed when I tested it. A rather floral scent that initially packs a punch but quickly proves to be extremely short-lived. Typical Gucci. It has been a long time since anything has hit the market that showcases uniqueness or even quality.

The scent starts off quite floral, with a dense cloud of something cardboard-like. Chemistry kit ahoy! Furthermore, it has a slightly piercing, hissing note that quickly spreads thickly on the skin. Bergamot? Where? It starts off very dominant. The flowers are quite entrenched in the fragrance pyramid. Ylang Ylang is particularly stubborn here and puts all other components into a coma. Subtly, there is a bit of orange blossom, but it completely withers under the power of the Ylang Ylang.

After this opening, the scent then becomes distinctly sweet, fruitily tinged. Again, this strange cardboard thing. What could that possibly be? The vanilla comes in lightly, but unfortunately in such a disastrous state that it almost makes me shudder. Bamboo doesn't make great leaps; it becomes slightly woody in the dry down, but this unpleasant cardboard quality remains until the end. Ylang Ylang is strongly present throughout the entire fragrance journey, but for my taste, it's far too much of a good thing. Everything is overshadowed by this ingredient.

Bamboo hysterically screams that it is here and that it is oh-so-elegant and feminine. It hisses petulantly at the beginning, letting out all its strength and intensity. Strong, yes. At first. Intense too. Intensely chemical. Nothing feels natural, just overloaded with Ylang Ylang. After not even a short time, the scent then dissipates into nothing. It only smells floral, with slightly different, tipsy ingredients that somehow want everything but can do nothing.

The bottle is heavy, fits well in the hand. It is of good quality, in contrast to the content. The longevity is actually a joke at this price and presentation. Sillage is not even worth mentioning.

Gucci sends a real stallion into the race when you think of the advertising, and what happens then? The stallion quickly runs out of steam.

Seduction? Desire? Feminine, perfected elegance? Not a chance.

There is a real deception here. Bamboo seems really intense, noble, and extremely strong in its presentation at first sniff. But all of this is misleading. Many, especially people outside our circles, buy perfumes if they like the sprayer right away.

Gucci is slowly going down the drain. With this fragrance, they haven't done themselves any favors. It is nothing new, not horrendously bad either, but any low-cost discount fragrance can claim that. And for 5-10 times less euros.

~ Inspiration ~
I became aware of "Bamboo" here and it landed on my watchlist until I received a sample to test during a swap.

~ Bottle ~
The thick glass bottle contains a delicate pink liquid. In keeping with the name, the cap looks like a bamboo stalk.

~ Fragrance ~
Bergamot provides a citrus-fresh opening, while Casablanca lilies give it a green-floral character. I perceive ylang-ylang only in the background with a handful of orange blossoms. In the base, it finishes lightly creamy with sandalwood and vanilla.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 5-6 hours. A few sprays are enough, as it becomes too piercingly synthetic for me otherwise.

~ Occasion ~
It fits into the mild days of spring, summer, and autumn (also suitable as an office fragrance).

~ Conclusion ~
It is too unsweet/synthetic for me, and the piercing green lily bothers me. More for fans of Asian-aquatic scents.

My mom has rented the Gucci fragrances for herself.

Not that I don’t like them - I get along well with Guilty Intense - but otherwise, the Guccis just suit my mom better.

Therefore, I don’t want to stick my neck out too far with the assessment of Bamboo, as I haven’t smelled it on her yet.

On me, however, Bamboo comes across as quite unharmonious - almost shrill.
The bergamot speaks up loudly, and it is not calmed by the lily and the orange blossom.
The opening feels intense and agitated.
Ylang Ylang stands separately beside it and doesn’t blend in.
Neither the sandalwood nor the vanilla really smooth the restless scent.
I also can’t find the expected bamboo.

A fragrance that leaves me perplexed and nervous.

But, as I said, the final word has not yet been spoken, as I haven’t smelled Bamboo on my mom yet.
Maybe it will surprise me with its good sides on her.
I am curious about this test.

Gucci Bamboo is a subtle, nice scent. However, that is exactly why it is one of my favorites, because I don't always have to leave the house with a sillage bomb. The opening is beautifully citrusy, followed by a light lily and ylang-ylang. The base rounds it off very nicely. Sillage, as mentioned, is not the best, but that is exactly what I find great about this fragrance. My...

At Müller, the friendly saleswoman treated me to two fragrance samples, and so I tested Bamboo today.
I found the beginning absolutely wonderful - like whispering bamboo in the wind on a cool, dry summer morning. Will this be my new scent?
But after a few minutes, I smelled mandarin, nothing but mandarin. Everything else remained blurred in the background. Only after 10 hours did the desolation fade, and after 12 hours, I liked Bamboo again.
Beautiful scent but not on my skin.

A clearing opens up to me in a mix of dark and light green tones. White sunbeams touch large waxy leaves in a vine-draped, impenetrable jungle. The air is fresh like the morning and yet strangely warming. Pale wisps of fog lazily swirl between the bright, smooth trunks of nameless, branchless trees, shimmering in the light bluish yellow like wet opals. Sparkling droplets run down the leaf veins and collect in deep green funnels at the heart of tropical plants.

A hint of sweet-sour fruits wafts in on a gentle breeze, unripe apples and figs, juicy bergamot take their time to unfold, only to then blend into one another.

As unadorned as a sample bottle may be, this fragrance requires no grand embellishments. Gucci Bamboo accompanies the sophisticated woman of the world on a snow-white yacht in the harbor of a glamorous city. It joins her for a fruity-sparkling cocktail on a rooftop terrace, so high up that the street noise no longer reaches her. It is with her at the important meeting in the office, where she must be particularly eloquent and confident. Because it decides her career.

Afterwards, she throws her cotton-white blazer over her shoulder and treats herself to a new pair of sandals. The expensive ones. For success.
She knows what she wants. She is completely in her element and simply magnificent.
She is a better version of herself.

It's a pity that the scent dissipates as quickly as a soap bubble bursts. A fleeting accessory for the moment, not for eternity. Not for me.

Gucci ...
... luxury, glamour, exclusivity ... that’s what I associate with the name Gucci

This fragrance does not quite match these associations.
The bottle is a noble eye-catcher, no question about it.
But the scent has nothing noble for me. It rather impresses with its everyday suitability.
It starts very fresh and citrusy with its bergamot top note, and the sandalwood from the base notes joins in early. These two ingredients accompany you throughout the entire experience. I cannot separate the floral ingredients of the heart note individually, but they are clearly arranged as a floral bouquet for me. However, it feels like too much of a garden show and somewhat intrusive.
Vanilla? Yes, it was indeed listed on the "recipe," but it seems to have been forgotten in my bottle. But my olfactory cells are more trained hobby sniffers than fragrance professionals.
Overall, I would rate this fragrance as sporty fresh and suitable for the office.

Bamboo ... wash, spray and go ...

Terribly chemical opening, I can detect a few good undertones, but they get lost in the unbearable main scent for me (it reminds me of something disgusting, but I can't quite recall what it is).

After a short while, it becomes somewhat more bearable, but still not good for my nose. I need to wash it off quickly... Bamboo and I will surely not become friends.

I wear the scent for all sorts of occasions and also daily at work, very fresh and gentle, yet still distinctive. I really like it and could buy it again anytime, if there weren't so many other bottles on the shelf ;) Fortunately, I don't notice any bergamot, which is not one of my favorite ingredients. But ylang-ylang and vanilla along with sandalwood is a wonderful...

review_title: Should've Name it Guilty Green or Guilty Sport ...
review_content:
I sampled Gucci Guilty Black recently at Sephora on the Upper West Side in New York City. I liked the smell enough on my skin to buy it despite the mediocre rating on Parfumo.

However, there is a good reason for the run-of-the-mill ratings it has.

----

Guilty Black opens with a combination of lavender and light powdery/floral smell that makes it lean hard on the fresh side, with a light touch of sweetness.

The smell transitions to a mixture of woods and a minuscule touch of leather in the heart and base note, which plays nicely in an easy transition from the fresh notes, while maintaining a soft masculine scent profile.

It is a solid overall fragrance that is complex and easy enough to use (more on that later). However, the fresh/woods combination profile is ubiquitous with men’s fragrances in the current era due to how well it works. Guilty Black will disappoint someone looking for a unique scent profile, as it's present in many sports-like fragrances.

That disappointment is exponentially higher with people who knew Gucci’s creativity with fragrances in the past, and the lack of creativity in recent times. Effectively, Guilty Black is Guilty Intense, minus the lemon note and switching Amber with Leather.

----

A standard 100 ml bottle of Guilty Black is solid. Functionally, like any bottle in the Guilty line, it is slim and easily fits in one’s hand like a smaller smartphone, making it easy to spray and carry around in a pocket or bag.

I also like the green and black combination that Guilty Black has going on, giving it an attractive designer style. However, the bottle is not an artistic masterpiece by any stretch of the imagination.

----

In terms of performance, Guilty Black may not be up to everyone’s expectations.

For longevity, Guilty Black lasts for about four hours. That period can work for a date or a short meeting. However, it is nowhere close to lasting for an entire workday without a respray. (Good thing the bottle is easy to carry.)

In terms of sillage and projection, the fragrance does not project far from the skin, and the scent trail it leaves is faint. Do not expect Guilty Black to announce your presence as you enter a room, or even when you walk by a person. However, someone close to you would almost certainly appreciate the scent, as it will not overwhelm them.

----

Guilty Black is a versatile fragrance. However, it shines brighter in some scenarios, and weaker in others.

For example, in terms of season or climate, it works best in the milder temperatures of Spring or Autumn, or if someone is in a mild climate like San Francisco or London. The fresh aspects of the scent should make it workable in the summer months without cloying or nauseating anyone. While detectable, it does not perform as well in the Winter, which is unusual for a fragrance with Black/Noir/Night/Nuit in the name.

For social situations, Guilty Black is too weak to use in an outdoor event, or a party at a large venue, as the scent fades into the background.

However, it works in every other situation. It can work great as an intimate date night fragrance, especially if one is shifting away from the modern trend of primarily sweet scents.

Guilty Black can also work as a leisurely fragrance, or as a scent after a workout in the gym, because of the fresh and woody aspects at the forefront of the fragrance.

With that said, Guilty Black excels the most as an office fragrance, as it is a fresh scent that does not have the sillage to bother people beyond a personal space bubble.

----

Gucci Guilty Black is a solid fragrance option, but there are many reasons for disappointment. Admittedly, if Gucci called the fragrance Guilty Sport or Guilty Green, the reception is probably better.

However, Guilty Black is the name of the fragrance.

Anyone looking for a winter fragrance that excels at large parties or outdoor events would be disappointed, as most expect that out of Black/Noir fragrances.

Anyone looking for projection or longevity in fragrances will become more disappointed, especially at the price point offered, and knowing that Black/Noir fragrances typically last longer.

The same level of disappointment applies to someone seeking a unique fragrance—especially if Gucci’s current offerings do not impress them.

However, putting aside the negativity, and the silliness of labeling a sport/green scent black, if someone treats Guilty Black like the fresh fragrance it is, they will find a solid daily scent to freshen up at a point in the day in the office, or a potential date night fragrance that is outside the trend.

----
Edit on Sept. 30, 2024 -- Apparently, Gucci renamed the fragrance Guilty Essence. This is a much better name.

There’s not much to say about Gucci Guilty Black that hasn’t already been said here. It opens with a touch of spice and settles quickly into a familiar green, shower-gel freshness. Clean and smells like you just stepped out of the shower. It’s not mind-blowing, but it smells good in an approachable way.

Calling it disappointing wouldn’t be fair. I’ve come to realize in this hobby that not every scent has to reinvent the wheel. This is the type of scent a guy who doesn’t really care about fragrance picks up at Macy’s just to say he has something on the shelf. And there’s nothing wrong with that.

This isn’t a release made for the serious fraghead or snob. Whether you’re into high-end perfumery or just picking up designers, odds are you’re going to smell pretty damn good either way.

It’s not a standout, but it’s an easy wear and a solid beginner fragrance. It's something to reach for when fragrance isn’t the focus.

review_title: Gucci now stands for the highest resistance to learning
review_content:
Doesn't Gucci read all the devastating reviews, both from experts and newcomers about Guilty and Guilty Intense?
Are the 2 predecessors really selling so well that another attempt at resuscitation is necessary?
Where have the old great perfumers gone who created Gucci PHI and II?

All of this and many more are questions that go through my mind after today's test of the new Gucci release. If one can even call it new, because there is nothing new, great, or improved here. It smells very much like the other 2 Guiltys, and that should not be taken as a compliment. My and many other comments on the 2 say it all.

Guilty Black also has the typical note that swings creepily between gourmand sweetness and watery freshness and light fruit, which does not appeal to me at all. It starts with a greener note than the predecessors, which already indicates the scent color. Lavender is also slightly present at the beginning. Then at some point leather and a bit of patchouli and wood come in, as if the heart note has been skipped.

The bottle also follows the Guilty style, everything remains the same in all respects. Only the longevity has been slightly increased, now at 8 hours. Sillage remains in the gray middle ground, the scent itself has nothing to look for even there after the 3rd attempt. For me, the name Guilty is lost and dead and stands for pure boredom.

Really weak presentation that doesn't need a long comment!

review_title: Mainstream Sex can also go horribly wrong
review_content:
as Guilty Black also proves..

First of all, I have to say that I am quite disappointed with this scent. One can hardly call it a scent anymore. More like a composite chemical cardboard, where a lab rat somehow made itself comfortable. My daughter said it was like those world-view-shattering rats, Pinky and the Brain. I burst into loud laughter.. Yes, that must have been them ;)

No. Joking aside.

Gucci conveys here, as it could be otherwise, sex appeal with lots of naughty, sweat-driven men who shine and attract all female gazes. The only gaze from women will probably fall on the very uncreative bottle, which is not really enchanting or appealing.
The scent itself is nothing special. You can smell it in every drugstore. So one shouldn't throw money out the window for this one. Better to spend a bit more and get another perfume that is worth its price.

The opening is as prudish as my grandfather and just as bored as he was. I had to chuckle when I think of him pushing his walker back and forth. Cursing and really disinterested. Yes, that's Gucci at the beginning too. Want to soak it up? Not a chance! The lavender is a bit overdone. It reminds me of lavender that stood on the kitchen table for days.. No - I really don't want to imagine that. It's somewhat dull and spicy at first, but it rushes down into the cellar as quickly as my mood after application. A woody touch emerges and everything sinks into a jumble of various ingredients. Sometimes leather comes to the fore, sometimes patchouli, etc. One variation follows another, but the scent doesn't come together.

I have to say, I expected much more from Gucci. Making beautiful eyes at the customers is one thing, but at least 50% should be delivered. Here, it's not even half. We all want sex, and being guilty now and then too. But then the minds behind the perfume should sit down together and rethink things clearly. So I won't get all excited and eager to plunge into the night with Grandma's lavender scent and a carousel of ingredients that don't even want to harmonize.

The bottle is just as uninspired as the scent itself. I give the longevity a bit more than 50%, because once it's been on for a while, it becomes almost undefinable.

Yes Gucci - we wanted fun and mood - you gave us frustration and disinterest.
Mainstream sex is desired, but not always achieved. The only ones who might be reached are boys who are still in the developmental phase.

My conclusion is that the scent is not successful. Unfortunately. Gucci has had some great horses in the stable, but this one is clearly the pony.
The advertising is not bad in itself, but for heaven's sake, create something that screams of touch and fusion if you embody that too. Some might certainly feel taken for a ride.

More than 20 percent is not possible. I don't want to offend anyone who likes this scent, but for me, it is one of the worst men's fragrances in a long time.

I have already judged the conventional Gucci Guilty in my comment. But now Gucci dares to push another fragrance onto the market with the flanker Guilty Black, a scent that the world does not need, to bore us to death.

What may be touted here and there as fresh and fruity turns out once again to be a synthetically smelling mixture aimed at profit maximization and not a nose-pleasing delight for fragrance connoisseurs.

Yes, with a bit of imagination, I can detect some orange blossom molecules from the test tube. Otherwise, Guilty Black quickly falls back into its musty components. And unfortunately, the shelves of perfumeries are already overcrowded with this kind.

This might only appeal to someone who cares much more about external superficialities and less about inner values.
Because one must admit - the bottle looks absolutely appealing again here. But after the fragrance designer, together with the marketing department, probably blew the entire budget, everything had to be saved on the ingredients.

Therefore: nothing learned and thus guilty as a repeat offender!

Hello, this is my first comment here in the community. My first encounter with GGB was in a huge department store in Amsterdam. All the major perfumers were represented here, such as Dior, Chanel, Versace, Armani, Givenchy, etc. In any case, it was a paradise for perfume enthusiasts. I tested Tom Ford's Noir and Spicebomb by Viktor & Rolf. Since I was in quite an intoxicated...

review_title: What devil is at work here?..
review_content:
..When comparing today's Gucci range with its earlier perfumes, this is a perfectly legitimate question.
Gucci, alongside Prada and D&G, is probably Italy's largest fashion house, and in 2013 it simply has no decent fragrances to show anymore; even worse - they are getting worse with each passing release.

In Guilty Black pour Homme, I see the sad and absolute low point of this brand, and even if I wanted to, I couldn't find anything positive about it in the slightest.
Qualitatively, this creation is at a point where only BOSS and co. would be comparable, as there are now quite a few fragrances that could easily surpass Guilty Black.

Guilty Black starts with a dark spiciness and initially presents a lavender accord. As the fragrance develops, it becomes woodier and so dry that it scratches, and eventually this scent becomes completely indefinable.

The worst part is not even that this was essentially just a polite description of a pure synthetic concoction, but that this fragrance has neither significance nor character; it's really hard to say when I last encountered something more trivial!

To describe Gucci Guilty Black properly, one would almost have to resort to vulgar language, but that doesn't belong here.

The bar couldn't be set any lower. It's just sad that this comes from Gucci.

I find the bottle quite appealing, I like it a lot. The scent is a bit overpowering at first when you apply it fresh, which is why I didn't want to take it and left the store. A little later, I smelled the fragrance sample again and I liked it quite a bit. It didn't blow me away, but it was pleasant. I find the orange blossom quite pronounced.
What I also found noticeable was the duration of the scent. Even after hours, I could still perceive the smell.

review_title: Guilty, innocent, or just grossly negligent?
review_content:
In Gucci fragrances, I no longer seek what I once found and cherished a few years ago. But everyone deserves a second or even third chance.

Especially when the bottle shines in such a beautiful green. I have no idea, green currently exerts a magical attraction on me. But maybe it’s just that botched Batman emblem that stands out even more in this black-green color combination than in the predecessors of the Guilty series, which Black shares the bottle with. Not really innovative, but other fragrance houses are even more extravagant in recycling well-known bottles.

The scent starts off quite nicely with fresh green accents, lavender stands out pleasantly. Then there’s a brief and weak hint of something bitter-citrusy, which research suggests should be neroli and orange blossom - but even with this knowledge, I can’t recognize them. What follows is the often-smelled synthetic mush of leather, wood, and patchouli. The lavender quits its service after just an hour and leaves the nose to a sweetish haze.

But how does the scent affect my environment? I had to face the question of whether I was even wearing a fragrance. A somewhat clear differentiation of the components is only possible for about half an hour, after which everything disappears. I am happy to discuss the high pH level of my skin, which has successfully neutralized certain components in several primarily synthetic fragrances, but I have never experienced anything like this. Even one and a half testers in a row dissolve into nothingness in no time.

I am at a loss as to how to rate such a fragrance that disqualifies itself from the race. And unfortunately, the little I can smell is not even in any way great, extraordinary, innovative, or inspiring, but just well-known and ordinary. And that is still one of the best things I can say about this fragrance.

review_title: Nothing special but not bad either
review_content: Gucci Guilty Black and Gucci fragrances in general have totally flown under my radar until now. I smelled this one out of curiosity and without high expectations at a Douglas store and quickly sprayed it on my arm. At first, I was not very impressed and had already written off the scent. A slightly green freshness greeted me. Not exactly exciting, special, or complex to my nose. After leaving the store, I sat down outside in a café. I gave the fragrance another chance and smelled it again. Now it was different. The green note had disappeared. Instead, a slight sweetness had joined the freshness, which was by no means intrusive or anything like that. The cedarwood was already shining through a bit, making the scent feel very rounded and truly pleasant. I found this fragrance to be super calming, unexciting but still somewhat mysterious. At no point does it clash. And that’s probably where we get to the reason why the reviews for Gucci Guilty Black are so poor. With its scent profile, it is nothing groundbreaking or extraordinary. Primarily, it is a mass pleaser that knows how to convince the broad audience with a fragrance DNA that almost no one can hate. Among perfume connoisseurs, such a scent profile is quickly labeled as generic and boring. No question, there are 100 times more exciting and unique fragrances than this one. Nevertheless, Gucci Guilty Black works as a perfume. If you are just looking for compliments, you should definitely take a closer look at this scent. Because if one thing is clear to me, it’s that especially women love this fragrance. It simply works. However, one should not be too stingy with the spraying, as longevity and sillage are rather average.

I was looking for a new interesting fragrance. I had the saleswoman show me various products. Most of them left me cold.

With this one, I unfortunately let myself be deceived by the first impression. At first, it smells quite pleasantly aromatic and slightly fruity, but then I perceive - I can hardly describe it otherwise - a scent similar to that found in an African shop. The worst part is: Even if you handle the relatively expensive bottle quite generously and spray yourself properly, you already have the feeling after a short time that there is hardly anything noticeable left on your skin or clothes. You can wait in vain for compliments because the fragrance seems to lose its effect far too quickly.

The bottle shown here looks rather boring, but the one I got looks like this http://www.douglas.de/douglas/D%25C3%25BCfte-Herrend%25C3%25BCfte-D%25C3%25BCfte-Gucci-Gucci-Guilty-Black-pour-Homme_product_723394.html and it definitely has something to it.

Otherwise, I am rather disappointed. Especially for the price, one could have expected more than this interchangeable scent, which could probably be matched by most perfume bottles from the drugstore market.

One of my absolute favorite perfumes. The blend of floral and fruity notes is simply beautiful. It has this unique balance between sensuality and elegance. Every time I wear it, I feel confident and glamorous. It was also one of my first perfumes, so it holds a very special meaning for me; moreover, it is truly underrated and deserves more recognition!

Gucci Guilty was my first real fragrance. I wasn't disappointed, but I wasn't extremely impressed either. Not a bad scent, but there are definitely better options.
Only suitable for spring and summer. Do not wear it in winter. The fragrance is not very aggressive, making it suitable for a calm day.

i got a decant tester of this a few months ago and after the first wear i knew i needed a bottle of this. i can't stop smelling myself when i wear this. it's soooo addicting to me and i can't wait to wear it all summer. gorgeous orchid is pure delicious ozonic vanilla orchid, and it wasn't until i read other reviews that i could smell banana. there's definitely banana laffy taffy in the background somehow but despite hating actual bananas i love banana laffy taffy so it doesn't bother me at all lmao. it's a very yummy scent!

I didn’t expect to love Flora Gorgeous Orchid - in fact, when I smelled it in store first I was unimpressed and even disliked it, so I wrote it off. Then I tried "Atheeri / أثيري | Lattafa / لطافة" and fell head over heels for the scent DNA, so revisited Flora Gorgeous Orchid expecting to not need it since I had Atheeri. Gorgeous Orchid has a banana note at the opening that I can’t get enough of, and to my nose it’s much fruitier and bubblier than Atheeri. I own and love both, and I’m so glad I revisited Gorgeous Orchid.

This Flora Gorgeous Orchid feels like vanilla under the sun.

One could swear they catch a hint of green banana - not quite ripe - that might have slipped into a basket of exotic orchids. There's also a suggestion of ylang-ylang, calling to mind a faraway island sunscreen - chic rather than loud.

The vanilla reveals itself slowly: neither dessert-like nor oriental, but soft and enveloping. The whole thing has the feel of a holiday.

Flora Gorgeous Orchid may not be groundbreaking, but it has the charm of being simply pleasant. A joyful, well-crafted little sensory escape.

The initial cloud was floral and creamy, like an overly sweet custard. Less powdery than I feared. Not great, not terrible. Ozonic notes were pretty pronounced and made the whole thing almost palatable. At that point I was even kind of hopeful about it. There was potential that once the initial cloud subsides and the fragrance properly opens up, I might actually enjoy it!

Well, that never happened. The ozone was a delight and this perfume's only saving grace for me personally, but it wasn't enough to offset the sweetness. The initial aggressive cloud took about 40 minutes to mellow out (or maybe my nose just gave up by then?), but even past that point nothing really ever changed. There was the basic vanilla, there was the orchid, they were both so sweet that my teeth hurt. If one could get diabetes from smell alone, this thing would probably already be outlawed in a few European countries.

It's hard to put this feeling into words, but I felt like it never became a proper sum of its parts. Like each of the three simple notes were there on their own, never really mixing together into a proper composition. Battling for my attention and overloading my senses in the process instead of working together to create something worthwhile.

It never evolved or changed in a meaningful way, just slowly got less and less obnoxious until it disappeared from my skin completely in about 3 hours. Far from the worst fragrance I came across thus far, but for that price tag I found the execution too cheap and uninspired.

Pretext: I have tried this scent multiple times at multiple stores over a span of a few months before I finally brought myself a travel size bottle. The scent really grew on me because the first times were just like "Hm, it's nice but nothing to write home about (and certainly not worth the price tag)".

It's a lovely take on a floral vanilla that could work well in an office setting as well (as long as you don't overspray like hell). There's some freshness at the start, which might be the base notes (as weird as it is), but I couldn't give you an exact note. It vanishes relatively quickly and becomes a floral vanilla. It isn't the most unique scent but it's a lovely scent that is a nice bridge between more vanilla-forward scents and pure florals. It's sweet, it's floral, it's slightly fresh.

The longevity is not the greatest. It's good on clothes (you can even smell the scent on them after 6-8 hours) but it vanishes very quickly on my skin. I can only get a wiff of it when I really sniff my wrist. Sillage is okay; someone close to you will notice the scent but it isn't one of those scents where a room can smell you before you enter the room. Makes it office-friendly, imo.

I have only beef with the travel size bottle. It looks cheap because it's just yellow glass with a yellow plastic cap (the yellow is a different hue than the glass) and a tiny print of the brand & scent name. The full size looks pretty with the print and I would have expected something alike on the travel size. I think I'm spoiled from 7 Virtues' travel size bottles, which look similar to their regular sizes.

This is one I’d never have thought to try until someone told me it has a banana note - and it does! Lots of banana in the initial spray, which then fades into a sweet, floral vanilla with (you guessed it!) beautifully fresh, clean orchid notes. As it settles it becomes ozonic, which is another thing I love in a perfume and see all too rarely. Not a complicated scent by any...

This came as a tester when I got Pure Poison, and wow, yes, mango lassi--that's it. I was wondering what was so dripping with syrup. I love the taste of mango lassi. This feels like I spilled it all over my clothes.

The 'ozonic' notes keep it from being too buttery, but it's not enough to hold back the ripe, even overripe fruit. When the vanilla breaks through later, it's almost a relief. Reminds me of the orange Flowerbomb because of the excessive mango, though without any of that one's brisk sharpness.

It's fine if you like fruity and very very (did I say very) sweet. It lasts for ages, you can't scrub off that one little spritz, it's that strong, and there's a very hot pulsing vanilla at the heart of it waiting for you at the end of the day. But I find i cannot stand mango as a scent. Not by Body Shop, not by Gucci. It's me, not you: so, pass.

I`ve been giving wide berth to Gucci perfumes, especially this Flora collection. Something about the bottle design didn`t appeal to me, I imagined the scents inside to be boring, average, I don`t know why exactly I never felt too keen to try them. So imagine my surprise meeting this cute mango lassi with banana in Flora Gorgeous Orchid. I don`t pick up much vanilla, just a mash-up of the mango beverage plus that L`Oreal Gentle Kids` Shampoo Banana Flavored, the one in small bottles shaped like colorful yellow fish. It was such a pleasant discovery, a lot of memories, breakfasts in Hyderabad and washing my baby brother`s hair with his favorite American shampoo when he was a toddler. A fun, friendly summer fragrance that I would consider purchasing when I manage to finish something in my collection.

I smelled this when it first came out but wasn't wowed. But I'm trying to use up all my little samples I've collected over the years, and I reached for this today. Wow. This is not a gourmand vanilla. This is a gorgeous, feminine, ozonic vanilla that is so elevated and elegant. The ozonic notes make it fresh and absolutely perfect for summer and hot weather. This is a clean girl vanilla. I absolutely would buy this when summer comes around again!

If I think about bananas and look at the yellow bottle, I vaguely smell banana taffy. But no, this is not a banana scent. It is a creamy vanilla orchid. I typically don’t like orchid but in this it keeps the vanilla from going gourmand while keeping a clean sweetness. My husband thinks it smells like sugar cookies when smelled from the nozzle, but I feel it is much more complex when sprayed.

I was looking for a clean scent that didn’t lean aquatic or citrus for Fall and this smells nice on crisp mornings. I think it will be better for spring though as it is more floral verses cozy.

Longevity is surprising for how soft it is. I can smell it on me for easy six hours, but I like to carry a decant and respray at four hours. There is not a huge sillage, the scent bubble is intimate yet persistent.

A solid okay in my book.

Oddly enough I would describe this as a “fresh vanilla”. This vanilla is in no way edible or gourmand but nevertheless it’s a vanilla, just one with a lot of floral properties. This is a very “pretty” and romantic scent like a young woman who has her shit together and is happily floating through life. It’s ever so slightly powdery but by no means a truly powdery scent, rather it’s a bit creamy. This one works all year round, from the heat of summer to a cold winter day. Very suitable as signature scent.

I really enjoyed this fragrance more in the beginning. It smelled like a citrus somewhat vanilla candy, though i did get told it smelled like a citrus cleaner (yikes lol).
Fresh and sweet, really pretty! Then it was more of a sweet (not sugary or gourmand) creamy white floral scent, still nice but not the biggest fan of florals so i wasnt vibing with it as much anymore.
Then after while that sweetness left and all im left with is that creamy white floral but now with a “freshness” to it. Think of the scent of a watermelon rind, that’s the scent that was there mixed with that floral. Not a fan anymore after that

This scent contains just basically orchid and vanilla tones. Thats why it smells very soft creamy and trully elegant. Apart from this statement there are nothing to define about it.

It can be used in daily life or in the evening in every season. Besides it is ideal for the women liking to smell orchid tones inside floral fragrance.

My favorite Gucci Flower, I also own the pink and Lianen. However, the yellow one is by far the best, which has pleasantly surprised me, as the other two did not blow me away. I am a big gourmand vanilla fan, which is why Gucci Flower Orchid fits perfectly into my scheme. The sweet vanilla is dominant and comes through very well, kissed by vanilla orchid. Simply wonderful and unique, sweet, creamy yet floral and fresh. The vanilla is not too sweet and blends beautifully with the floral scent. The fragrance is suitable for everyday wear and creamy, I like it very much.

review_title: Incredibly exciting and a bit disappointing
review_content:
I at Douglas: spray on my hand: go outside so I can perceive the scent without influence and I smell: super fresh watermelon and cucumber.

At home: read the notes and almost fall off my chair: so few notes in it and yet it smells relatively complex. However, 0 vanilla!
Quickly looked up "ozonic notes" and those must be the "watermelon/cucumber" that I perceive. But how can it be that I smell them first, even though they are in the base notes? Very exciting.

After half an hour, very slightly vanilla scents come through, still combined with the fresh character, very interesting.

And then: the more time passes, the more delicious and very realistically smelling vanilla is added, yet until the end with a green note, which unfortunately sometimes almost turns it a bit towards cleaning product for me.

I myself am a big vanilla fan and would have expected a lot from the notes had I read them beforehand. However, I would have been disappointed as well, since it smells too little of vanilla for me, or the combination with the freshness creates something different than I had hoped for. Still exciting and something different, I think.

I know the title is not particularly creative, but I can't describe the scent any other way.. I'm not a big fan of floral-fresh fragrances, and accordingly, I haven't thought much of the entire Gucci Flora line. Especially because they simply don't last on me. However, when I tested the new Gorgeous Orchid, I was definitely positively surprised. The scent is simply...

review_title: Vanilla, sweet, warm without feeling cheap
review_content:
Considering that I don't like vanilla scents at all, this one has captivated me. It envelops you and accompanies you throughout the day, the warm and sweet vanilla orchid, without being too overpowering. However, one should use it sparingly, as it is very intense, like all Gucci perfumes, and can easily come across as overwhelming.

In my opinion, the scent is suitable for any season, but one should keep in mind that it is warm and rich, not fresh.

I don't know how I could fall in love so spontaneously again. I have generally kept a wide distance from Gucci, the perfumes, those who love Gucci, please forgive me...especially the Flora line was, until the orchid appeared, a horror for me. But...you always have new experiences. In one of my various orders, the sample with the typical pattern was included in the box as a little extra....Please no, I thought, I'll give it to someone else. But it's yellow???? Okay, tonight I'm on fire and in testing fever. What can I say, only three notes listed, that's something for me. I smell a powdery, wonderful vanilla. My heart is already beating faster
..No frills, this powdery scent actually reminds me of "Vanilla Powder | Matière Première," just a bit more floral. ...otherwise it wouldn't be a sprout from the Flora line. Simple vanilla meets vanilla orchid. The oceanic notes are still a puzzle to me...please don't think of something fresh, clean, for that the scent is too linear. Compared to "Vanilla Powder | Matière Première," which has a bit of woodiness, I classify this scent as a cozy, comforting candidate for the cool season; this fragrance is direct. It takes no detours, does not change. Suitable for any season...I better stop writing, otherwise I'll end up buying it.

I received a sample and it was love at first sniff. It reminded me a bit of the scent -Fame (Perfume)- by Rabanne. Even though the fragrance pyramid doesn't match at all. There’s something they have in common and I love both. I adore the slightly salty note mixed with flowers. I would wear this one more in summer or late summer, and Rabanne would be the brother for the...

I'm not a fan of the pink Gucci Flora at all. This scent surprised and convinced me all the more. I find it very good, not too sweet, and it smells wonderfully fresh with a hint of vanilla. The longevity is long, and despite the floral note, it doesn't come across as overwhelming or unpleasant.

The comments here made me curious.

Personally, I can't relate to the entire range.

I think it could be for men. It has such a masculine note. Probably the aquatic one.
Actually, the vanilla orchid is quite nice. Neither artificial nor too sweet.
But it's just not feminine enough for me.

For anyone looking for a truly great, spicy, and deep vanilla orchid note, I recommend "Black Opium Le Parfum | Yves Saint Laurent." Only Classique EAU DE PARFUM was comparably vanilla-like. It's a shame it was reformulated.

The longevity is very poor for me. For the price, it's also outrageous.
Maybe it really smells better on men.

It started on a prominent coconut note and something else vaguely fruity. I would never have guessed what kind of berry it is if it wasn't written on the package. No orange at all. Reminded me of those children's fruit flavored markers that give you a headache 30 minutes into the drawing.

Thankfully, the upper notes mellowed out before my headache kicked in. Musk very quickly started peeking through from beneath, giving the composition a pleasantly creamy quality. It basically smelled like those feminine "berry smoothie" flavored shower gels (and lasted on my skin just as long). After the first hour most of the top/middle notes were already gone. I was left with just musk and a wee bit of patchouli.

The base notes clung to me for a few more hours, and admittedly I did enjoy that, but if my intention was to just smell musky – there are so many great musk-forward perfumes on the market, many of them with way more interesting compositions and better longevity (and at times for a fraction of the price of this one).

Best one out of the Flora collection, but still meh. Waste of a cute bottle.

I went in Ulta and decided I wanted to test one of the Flora Gorgeous scents after work today so I sprayed this on as out of the four this smelled the most appealing to me out of the bottle. It smells good but it's nothing remarkable or super memorable. It's also didn't find it to be incredibly strong either. I like this but not enough to buy.

I did not like the original Gucci Flora or Gorgeous Gardenia, but I do like Gorgeous Jasmine. I've also been on a hunt to find magnolia focused fragrances that work for me, so while I admittedly did not need another coconut fragrance, I ultimately couldn't resist trying this and purchased a 30 ml bottle after testing it a few times in store. It's a newer addition (a month or so) in my collection so these are really all first impressions:

1. Unique? No. But it is however good at what it sets out to be and I don't believe every perfume has to be some olfactory masterpiece. Easy, pretty, light, feminine. Great daily scent for places like work, bed or even just to feel clean.
2. The longevity is good and I get about 5 hours of wear but I find this is a very intimate fragrance that sits very close to the skin. I'm also fine with this because I'm not someone who thinks every perfume has to be in beast mode.
3. This is a very creamy almost waxy smell. I wouldn't say it quite crosses the line into wax soap territory but there is a hint towards it in the notes. This makes sense given it's a Magnolia centered fragrance. Even with the berry and coconut, I personally do not think it leans particularly tropical and the magnolia is still the primary center focus of this fragrance.
4. Because it is so light, it struggles a bit more in the cool mornings so I think this may be one that comes more to life much more in the spring and summer but it could still totally be worn year round if you just want a skin scent.
5. I really like the way Gucci does patchouli. It's not a dirty patchouli at all and in this blend really helps ground the fragrance in a pleasant way.
6. I know it is the juice that matters most, but I really love this bottle and the atomizer on this line. Gucci did a stellar job on the packaging.

Good scent and excited to really see how this performs in warmer months. If I continue to like my small bottle this much, it may be worth investing in a larger bottle when I run out.

Eta: Updating my rating as this perfume has been absolutely beautiful the past few spring months. I stand by it being a good easy reach, daily scent but I've come to really love it. Wearing it alongside the blooming magnolias in my city has been truly a delight.

review_title: Another designer perfume in an oversaturated market
review_content:
Received this as a sampler with a Sephora purchase way back before it was annonced, forgot about it for awhile and now here I am ready, to test it!

I'm going to say it: it smells like baby powder. Floral, slightly fruity, yes, but baby powder above all else. And it's not something I want to wear during the day. I'm already not a great fan of powdery perfumes, so this was already a no to me, but my colleagues told me it had a baby powder scent and that was an even more immediate turn-off. There's clearly a Gorgeous DNA going on here (I smelled Gorgeous Jasmine before and I was reminded a bit of it in this scent). Blackberry was the strongest contender in the top notes with its fruity and tart accord. Flowers sort of blended in a non-descript way, giving everything a powdery accord that ended up overwhelming everything. There's also an adjacent plasticky, almost Play-Doh scent that came up when I pulled my nose right up to my skin, but it's not detectable when I'm at a reasonable distance. Everything ends up drying down to this earthy, warm scent, a welcome contribution from the three bottom notes. I feel like this perfume could've been better blended as the notes and accords do seem to clash a bit during its time on my skin, but I can't clearly pinpoint what should've been done differently.

Overall the perfume isn't bad, it might even be good for those who love floral, powdery scents, but to my nose it isn't amazing enough to add to my collection. I also have the feeling I have already smelled something similar before and I can't seem to put my finger on the name of the perfume. Anyways, I'm just saying that if you do have a floral powdery perfume in your arsenal, you don't really need this one, except if you really love the Gucci Gorgeous line. It's a fine feminine-leaning perfume, but nothing amazing or unique.

I've spent far longer on this review than it really merits, because I keep trying to figure out what my problem with this scent is. The thing is, I feel a bit cynical about the whole Flora Gorgeous line, and I'm really not sure why. It's not like I need fragrances to be high-concept or anything— some of my favorite perfumes are of the unfocused, as-long-as-it-smells-good variety, and the names promise white florals, which are an easy way into my heart. Just something about these fragrances in particular seems directionless, like they came up with the (admittedly, beautiful) bottle first and then cast about desperately for something to fill it with. Magnolia in particular feels very perfunctory. Fruit, check, florals, check, pick a color for the bottle and call it a day.

Maybe I'm not being fair. This is not a bad scent. It doesn't smell bad. But to me at least, it fails to cohere. The fruity top notes seem stapled-on, like they have nothing to do with the florals they're supposed to prelude. The florals themselves feel thin and textureless. The most interesting thing about this is the patchouli, which, placed in this particular context, does genuinely conjure up for me the scent-memory of a magnolia leaf— grassy, sort of spicy. In a better world, this could be the core that the rest of the fragrance was built around. But this feels like an outfit comprised of individually beautiful pieces, put together by someone with no sense of style.

white florals with a bit of fruit, particularly coconut, and a bit of patchouli. it does give off an older lady vibe because of the floralchouli combination. i actually think that the other releases in this collection are better. someone mentioned it smelling of dirty berries, which i can pick up on as well.

review_title: It smells like freshly washed laundry with fragrant flowers among it
review_content: It smells like freshly washed laundry with fragrant flowers in it. I feel it as floral, sweet, fruity. I don't smell the coconut at all. I was surprised when I saw it listed among the notes. Anyway, I don't necessarily want to smell coconut. I recommend you at least test it! It's worth smelling at least once. At the moment, it hasn't convinced me to buy it in a larger...

I annihilate perfume and for some reason this bottle just will not empty. I simply hate opaque bottles where I can’t see exactly how much fragrance is left. Even though, yeah, they protect the juice better. Bah.

Anyway, this reminds me so much of CH Good Girl. This Magnolia has that same warm, hazy, vanilla/coconut/powder vibe. It’s nice and cozy. I like to wear it after a long day and a shower, before bed. When I try to wear this during the day it fades incredibly quick. Being outside kills it within minutes. Gentle sillage but moderately decent longevity on clothes. Simply doesn’t exist on my skin.

It’s pretty and soft and enjoyable, especially for having a strong patchouli base. Clean, floral, cozy. I have found I really like it in the fall.

review_title: If only it weren't for the Ylang...
review_content:
Hello you fanatic scent sniffers! Here I am again, with a new fragrance on the scene! This time a scent from Gucci… namely Flora Gorgeous Magnolia. So, you can imagine that I have no idea what magnolias are and especially how they look, let alone smell… but being the clever person I am, I first took a look at the label of the bottle, because sometimes it shows what the scent is supposed to smell like. Good, right? NOT AT ALL!

Because next to the fragrance were other scents from Gucci, namely Flora Gorgeous Gardenia and Flora Gorgeous Jasmine… and do you know what? All three fragrances have exactly the same label!!! Only the name is different (and the bottle color), but otherwise?…. Great! Gorgeous Gardenia… what are gardenias now? Can I hang them on my windows or am I confusing them with curtains? AAAAAAAAARGHRGHGRHG!!!

So I quickly looked it up on the internet and yes, those pink flowers that take up a large part of the label are indeed magnolias! But why are they also shown on the other fragrances? Shouldn't the other flowers have been in the foreground? Like jasmine? Or those curtains?… I meant gardenias of course… :D

Anyway, the bottles look quite nice in their pastel colors and the labels, so I grabbed one of them and sprayed it on. Soo,… and thus follows my fragrance report!

The Scent:
The scent starts off quite sweet and fruity. The beginning reminds me of something, but I just can't put my finger on it. It could also be that it reminds me of some kind of candy :)
In any case, it smells nice, you can definitely smell the berries, the coconut is a bit more in the background.
A little later, you can perceive the jasmine with its nice, floral sweetness. This initially makes the scent even sweeter. But just a little later, the fragrance radiates a note that I haven't had under my nose for a long time, but I can never forget it because I absolutely can't stand it: Ylang-Ylang.
Wow, Ylang-Ylang has a very distinctive and intense scent that comes across as opulent and, for me, also stuffy, and I actually want to run away, which unfortunately isn't possible since the scent is on my arm. And on the ENTIRE arm, so I can describe it as accurately as possible, uffffff!
If there are "somewhere" in the scent supposed to be magnolias (as I said, I have no idea how these flowers smell), then they probably get a bit overshadowed since Ylang-Ylang is the main note for me here and overshadows all the other scents, which I personally find very unfortunate because it kind of ruins the scent for me.
In the base, you still smell the strongly radiating Ylang-Yangs, and there’s always a rather opulent sweetness coming through. A bit of patchouli enhances the opulent impression of the scent a little and makes it a bit more robust. Musk and those light woods, well, I don't think I would have guessed if it weren't listed here in the fragrance notes.
Only in the later base does the strong Ylang-Ylang scent finally weaken, so that now many other notes, mainly sweet scents, become more noticeable again. Thus, the late base is much nicer again, especially when the scent becomes slightly powdery and eventually the lovely musk can be smelled. All in all, a scent that is quite okay, but I don't like it that much because of the Ylang-Ylang.

The Sillage and Longevity:
The sillage is strong, not overwhelming, but if sprayed generously, you will definitely be noticeable for several hours. The longevity is also very good at over 10 hours!

The Bottle:
The bottle is rectangular and narrows towards the neck, where the cylindrical gold cap sits. The pastel violet tone looks nice and fits the theme of the fragrance. The label features a drawing of various plants, with the magnolias standing out, and it is all very nicely done. All in all, a very beautiful bottle.

Conclusion:
So, first of all, I should make one thing clear: namely that my fragrance report, like every other test of mine, is purely subjective. And because I really can't stand Ylang-Ylang, I personally don't like the scent that much overall.

However, I believe that most of you ladies might actually like it. Because it is not trivial or 0815-floral and has many beautiful, sweet notes to offer, although some might find it a bit too sweet.
It also radiates well, lasts long, and you don't smell much synthetic in it.
Fragrance-wise, it is almost an all-rounder, but on very hot days, I wouldn't use it, as it could really come across as suffocating and oppressive.

You could use it well in your leisure time, maybe even for going out, just don't come too close to me with it, he he :D

Well, that’s it from me again. Hm,… I still don't know how magnolias smell, but whatever, by the next time I will surely have forgotten how they even looked!
I wish you all a lovely evening, until next time then :)

review_title: Floral fragrance that doesn't last long
review_content:
I treated myself to the Flora Gorgeous Magnolia alongside 2 other fragrances from the FLORA GUCCI line.
I found the packaging and the overall marketing well done. I chose the purple flanker because of the great top notes and the musk.
At first, a berry scent emerges with subtle coconut notes, and quite quickly, the floral fragrance nuances develop after spraying, dominating the scent profile, which is why we have a more floral than fruity fragrance here. The ylang-ylang notes are very strong, in my opinion.
The musk gives Flora Gorgeous Magnolia a nice warm warmth.
The fragrance is okay for me personally, but nothing I would wear often or that would blow me away; everyone's taste is different.
Unfortunately, the longevity of all 3 FLORA GUCCI fragrances is below average, which I find very disappointing. Overall, it's a nice scent, but nothing more.

I have tested the Gucci Flora Gorgeous Gardenia twice already, and both times I wasn't really impressed. But the bottles are so beautiful! This time I was in a store where all varieties of the line were available for testing. Since I was already carrying 5 or 6 test strips with me at that point, I had to choose one - it was the Magnolia, I love the purple of the bottle!

Right after spraying it on, I got a good mood boost. The fruity notes came through very strongly, especially the blackberry and the orange, and in a high-quality way, not cheap or smelling like a teen perfume. At the same time, the sweet flowers were already very prominent, making it truly wearable for adults.

Sillage and longevity are in the good middle range. For the price, it's okay, but there's some room for improvement.

After a while, the base gradually comes through, and I finally think I can smell the coconut note. The (or is it one of the sweet flowers) is a tiny little nuisance for me, so I currently tend not to add it to my wish list. But it is a lovely scent.

review_title: Fresh Magnolia Scent Fills the Air
review_content:
Let's first take a look at the bottle. The design is simple yet elegantly executed: a pastel lilac glass bottle adorned with a golden cap. On it, a textured flower meadow sticker adds to the tactile experience. When we remove the cap and take a spritz, we first encounter a very mild, floral scent that fills the room. Once sprayed on the skin, it warms up, and the initially very mild floral fragrance becomes rounded and refined. For up to four hours, it projects strongly on the skin without fading. After that, it softens, becomes more skin-like, and lasts a total of up to 8 hours, until it is barely perceptible.
At a price of €80 (I purchased it online; higher prices tend to appear in stores), I believe it is a beautiful and gentle scent that holds very well on my skin and has a lovely projection. I mostly wear the fragrance in the office, where every time someone enters the room, compliments are given. The sillage is strong and enveloping, without being unpleasant or even overpowering.
Thus, I recommend it to anyone looking for a spring-like, floral scent that can be worn confidently in close contact with others while leaving an impression.

It is not for everyone, but I adore this perfume. It is unique, earthy, sexy and beautiful. This scent unleashes inner tigress in me. It feels ancient and mysterious – like walking through the ruins of a forgotten, ancient temple and feeling connection to dark mysteries of ancient times.

The composition is sultry and spicy. The opening is a bit sharp with orange blossom and heliotrope, but it goes into middle notes pretty quick and they are so divine. I normally do not like caraway seed in perfumes. But this one proved me wrong. The combination is so harmonious and beautiful. It wraps around me like a second skin and makes me feel so divine. It is strong, dark but silky at the same time. The scent has wonderful complexity towards the dry down where the leather, incense, woods, musk and just a touch of vanilla are in perfect harmony.

Gucci EDP has been my favorite for many years. It has strong and unique character, but that’s why I love it so much. I crave its dark beauty, especially when the autumn rolls in. It is sad that this scent is discontinued now.

review_title: An Ode to the Caraway Seed
review_content:
As odd as this may sound, GUCCI EAU DE PARFUM is a lovely little ode to the caraway seed. I didn't know this until I saw the notes, but I was certainly pleased by the woody nuttiness which I was unable to identify, and there it was: a double dose of caraway seed!

In its warmth and woodiness, GUCCI compares favorably with DOLCE VITA, but GUCCI has its own distinct flavor--figuratively and literally.

Let us now lament the sad plight of the forlorn caraway seed, so long relegated and promiscuously applied to rye bread, while at the same time scorned from a distance, mistaken far too often by those of feeble sight for a weevil or an insect egg.

The caraway seed, GUCCI has admirably affirmed, has an honorable, independent existence worthy enough to play a central role in a high-quality perfume.

GUCCI evolves very quickly to a subtle, slightly sweet, nutty-woody scent, and its lingering caraway aura would be very difficult for the untutored (suitably apprised) nose to tease out of the other fine spice and chypre elements, in addition to a few flowers and a touch of incense. (This is NOTHING like Serge Lutens CHYPRE ROUGE, which is more like a caraway seed monster to my nose!) Together, the flowers and oriental components combine GUCCI edp to create a sly perfume which draws attention to itself only through its subtlety.

GUCCI keeps her clothes on, but her blouse is made of very sheer silk.

Gucci eau de Parfume is like a elegant Tweed jacket dry and musty it brings
an Androgynous chicness in modern perfumery The opening of Heliotrope with
it's vanilla with almond nuance opens the
top note, in a few minutes dry Caraway
makes it's presence known Iris adds to the
powdery feel it has an strawberry middle
drydown Leather is subtle and it's not
overwhelming Incense adds to the dark mystery
of the scent with an reserved
reputare aloof and not showing her true
nature i love the dark musky drydown
and vanilla sweetens the base.

Gucci eau de Parfume has no categorized
identity genderless it's neither Male
nor Female it brings androgamy to the
wearer it's unisex to me, these are one
of the scents that thinks outside the box
like CK One that does not follow
conventional rules on female perfumery
it avoids trendy girlish watery floral
fruity scents that is all the rage and
beats to it's own drum, this scent is for a
woman who wants to break convention.

review_title: Nothing for everybody but still mine
review_content:
I have used him for years and this has been a long time.

I have found a rest test and rediscovered him newly by chance now.
The beginning is very tastily, sharply and at the same time soft. Caraway and thyme duel gently with Heliotrope.
I find the interplay of seasoning and lighten sweet ones wonderfully. Whoever doesn't like orange flowers should keep away from it. The Orient fans perhaps should glance at it.

Vanilla opens the base; it then will show itself woody musk and incense. It gets dark and mystical like the color of the smell.

A serious smell is passionate, calming infinitely. I have found a new/old winter partner.
Spicy,warm,mysterious fragrance with great sillage. On my skin, main notes are incense, leather, cedar,heliotrope.Yes, it is dark , but dark is sometimes very enjoyable

Like leather seats in a room full of spices and incense. This is a very dry fragrance, but quite mysterious as well. Has an almost resinous like quality to it. Spicy caraway with deep vanilla. Dry orange blossom in the opening. The "cherry" aspect of the heliotrope with the dry leather and incense make it very unique. Can be a little dry, and almost tangy with the spicy-sweet dry-down, but I like it. This is amazing for a female EDP from Gucci. There is nothing quite like this out there these days, and it also develops into an incredibly sexy dark, spicy leather scent on a man. Brilliant!

i really wanted to like this! it is certainly a well constructed, and very respectable perfume, in terms of both formula and quality. but, as i was afraid, the iris and heliatrope ran right out of the gate with loads of sweet incense, which on me is the instant, and terrible powder bomb! the resinous woods underneath are rich, and fine, the vanilla seductive and slightly boozy, the leather note smooth, and not overdone, and the nutty undertone gives it a buttery, almost "oily" cast. there was a light herbal note that dissapeared, and i can detect some flowers drowned in the sweet, srupy juice, but i cannot distinguish, or rescue them. sadly, i cannot get it off my hand. sungular. one drop. so, if you love it, please apply carefully (this test was an old formula) it is a powerhouse!

review_title: Didn't live up to the expectations
review_content:
The bottle itself and the darkness of the liquid inside, was certainly intriguing to say the least. Gucci eau de Parfum was one spicy fragrance that I was dying to try.

The opening was good, spicy yet smooth and I saw that this fragrance had potential, however what followed was rather strange. The scent just vanished, it was barely detectable, a wimpering hint of spice the only thing left on my skin.

Where were those enticing flowers, the double dose of caraway seed and herbaceous thyme? I began frantically sniffing coffee beans, almost shoving them up my nose in order to smell a faint hint of something, but to no avail.

It was only about 5 hours later when the drydown began to immerge that Gucci eau de Parfum reminded me of its existance. I can see where the comparison to Dior's Hypnotic Poison comes in. The base is very vanilla with a musky and nutty feel to it. The incense and leather notes are only very faint.

Overall, from what I can gather, Gucci eau de Parfum is intentionally a soft and intimate fragrance, not so heavy with the spices as some may think and quite feminine rather than being unisex or masculine.

What I expected and what I experienced were two different things entirely.

I don't think this perfume is made any longer, but I have a pile of carded samples that I bought years ago for $.25 apiece at some old perfume shop. I always liked it in that dirty pleasure sort of way, relishing that cheap thrill of mild sleaziness of enjoying a cheap perfume. 

Trying this perfume again after a few years I realize my mistake. I found these samples at some mistakenly low-price and the made amateurish mistakes of equating cheap with Cheap.   This is a beautiful, simple floriental, one that eschews the genre’s typical diva-ish complexity in favor of simple, well-chosen broad strokes. I smell it as if it is under an olfactory magnifying glass. It's laid out like paint-by-numbers canvas that only has the colors orange flower, cumin and amber filled in. The artist stepped back, realized less might be more and left if in its simple state of beauty.  Perhaps more mainstream perfumers should try this pre-editing, because Gucci EDP smell a little rough at the edges and just right.

This simple structure makes a tightly knit perfume that remains coherent through drydown.  Smelling it years later, it seems like a fragrance that could be released today as a masculine woody floral.

This fragrance is one of my favorites. It's spicy and warm. Makes you want to kuddle up under a blanket while drinking cinnamon tea. At the same time it makes you want to explore mysteries or go on an adventure. It incapsulates the feminine secrets and essence. It's a statement fragrance, but at the same time so very private.

If there was room for 21 fragrances in a top 20, this would be in mine. GEdP always fascinates me when I spray it. It has a unique, warm and spicy smell that I just dive into. Lovely flowers, spices and woods make a whole, that wraps around you, comforting and soothing. Like wearing your favourite winter coat. Or like a dear friend giving you a hug. I met this one in 2003. I...

A few days ago, a dear friend came to visit. Although she originally comes from Bavaria, she looks more like a Scandinavian (blonde, fair-skinned, blue eyes) and is quite sporty. Fragrance-wise, she tends to be "fresh," so we have little in common in that area.

However, this time I noticed right away during the hug of greeting that she smelled quite "different" than usual. No trace of freshness, but a hefty dose of patchouli or rather a "lipstick accord" wafted around her, delicious enough to bite into. My first thought was "Ombre Mercure" by Terry de Gunzburg.

Of course, I had to investigate. It can't be that she just changes her fragrance habits like that ;-)

The solution to the mystery is actually quite simple: The fragrance is Gucci's "Eau de Parfum," and it comes from the collection of her recently deceased mother-in-law. Since she found the bottle "stylish" and the scent "something completely different," she gave it a new home.

Since we know each other really well and she probably guessed that I would be drawn to the scent, she kindly brought me a mini. Such friends are priceless ;-))

From the very first moment, I perceive this wonderful lipstick accord, which stems from the glorious iris. Carried by (lush) heliotrope and (moderate) orange blossom (which doesn't push itself to the forefront for me) and slightly softened with thyme, a wonderful scent picture emerges that you can almost grasp.

And although no patchouli is listed, I still imagine smelling it, as this "lipstick-patchouli accord" is exactly what reminded me so strongly of "Ombre Mercure" by Terry de Gunzburg from the start. A scent that I still really like, but due to its insane density, I can no longer wear and enjoy.

In Gucci's "Eau de Parfum," this accord is not quite as dense and long-lasting, as it is broken and grounded by (finest) sandalwood, (dark) vanilla, (non-sacred) incense, (light wild) leather, and cedar.

All in all, a well-rounded affair, a real "wow scent"!

Anyone wearing Gucci's "Eau de Parfum" should be aware that it is a striking fragrance with absolute presence. However, it is by no means loud or cheap in its effects, but rather mature, noble, effortlessly elegant, exciting, yet unexcitable.

Even though the chosen name expresses more of an understatement, the fragrance has a lot to offer and demands a confident presence. Gucci's "Eau de Parfum" is a loud scent, but one with style, charm, and a wink.

A fragrance for a grand entrance in formal evening wear, but just as exciting when paired with jeans and a white shirt/white blouse. For my part, I will certainly wear it just like that (jeans, white shirt, suede shoes) in my free time, because for "good" (i.e., evenings) I have my pathetic remnant of "Gucci pour Homme."

The sillage can indeed be overwhelming and expansive. As always with such fragrances, the dose makes the poison.

The fragrance color (amber or cognac-colored depending on the light) and the design of the (massive) bottle, with the scent seemingly floating inside, clearly indicate that Gucci's "Eau de Parfum" (2002) and "Gucci pour Homme" (2003) are scent siblings:

- Both are surrounded by this special scent aura that displays a certain arrogance.
- Both cling very, very well.
- Both show their noble origin.
- Both are of very high quality.

Both.....are unfortunately no longer produced for reasons I cannot understand!

And as I already expressed in my comment on "Gucci pour Homme," I can only reiterate my incomprehension about this. In my view, after these two fragrances, Gucci has not brought anything comparable to the market (except for "Gucci by Gucci" for women).

Gucci, back to the roots, please!

The perhaps most important thing first: A woman wearing "Gucci Eau de Parfum" should already possess a certain maturity, that calmness that comes from experience and self-confidence, which cannot be learned but can only be acquired over many years.
Only then - I assert - does a harmonious overall picture arise between woman and fragrance, a symbiosis that goes beyond pure harmony, which I could not imagine to be more perfect.
And definitely not on a young woman, perhaps not even on a woman in her thirties - although or precisely because I was 34 years old when this fragrance captured my heart in the year of its release.

I almost overlooked it when it appeared on the shelf of my then-favorite perfumery.
The Gucci brand was not among my preferred fragrance houses; I found no connection to their creations.
So I initially thought it was a joke when the owner introduced "Gucci Eau de Parfum" to me with the words: "I know it's still too early, but the time for you two will come!"
Given the dark liquid in the bottle, I could not imagine it for the life of me, as it reminded me of "Youth Dew" and "Cinnabar," undoubtedly wonderful fragrance creations, but for me still unbearable to this day.
