However, the aforementioned owner was also a good friend who knew me and my passion for fragrances very well and had already pointed out numerous fragrance jewels to me that I would certainly have overlooked otherwise - and I have always avoided being rude without necessity...

So I resigned myself to my fate and let Simone take the spraying action - only to walk away highly satisfied with my new treasure five minutes later.
With the clear awareness that I was actually still too young for it - significant age differences have never bothered me in choosing partners, but with fragrances, I paid a bit more attention to compatibility with my reflection.
Our time would come...

"Gucci Eau de Parfum" was a revelation for me from the very first moment, a spicy-warm creaminess.
Nothing crashed, nothing exploded - the feared olfactory thunderstorm might have played out elsewhere, but not on my skin, which I had bravely held out instead of the paper strip.
Clearly feminine, gentle and very determined, warm and soft, highly elegant and yet strangely warm-hearted, a fragrance spread that conjured the image of a very calm, very confident, very friendly and approachable woman before my inner eye, a woman from whom I was still separated by at least a decade and just as much character growth.
A woman who prefers cream white over night black, for whom long red claws and stilettos are neither a synonym for femininity nor elegance, whose aura places her at the center of any society and for whom personal development is more important than the latest gossip.
A woman whose scent of light leather and noble body cream blends with the aromas of her garden and whose smile always reaches the eyes.
I have no idea if I will one day encounter this woman in my mirror - but it would be a beautiful goal.

It is a full, rounded perfume that was launched in 2002 and smells as if it comes from another era (thankfully!). A slightly sweet, plum-like accord combined with a lot of vanilla, heliotropin, and especially cumin create this fragrance, which also has a light orange blossom note. Very "retro," reminiscent of "Femme" by Rochas, but spicier due to the cumin. Hardly available anymore. What a pity! Much better than all the other Gucci fragrances that followed after 2002.

The "Devil" and his minions are driven away by sage smoke and thyme. And it attracts the "good spirits."
This scent makes no compromises here, just like Van Helsing with Count Dracula.
And like the "Gucci EdP," it "packs a punch." Not even the cape remains, just a cloud of fine dust that the wind blows away.
The opening with heliotrope and orange blossom hints at the unusual combination of thyme and cumin, dusted with iris.
Very strong in longevity and projection, you should apply this fragrance sparingly to enjoy its true soul.
And when after hours the warm, soft base of cedar, sandalwood, vanilla, and incense reveals itself, no evil demon stands a chance of surviving. So "heavenly" is the slightly smoky-vanilla-spicy scent accord that you feel safe and secure.
"Gucci Eau de Parfum" is a composition of aromas that is so unique that it resembles no other perfume I know.
That the scent is "heavy" is true. But sweet? Not at all!! Nor is it "cloying." Certainly not "dirty."
Rather, it is simply enveloping, good-natured, and unusual.
By the way: Not just for ladies.

...that I was a blind purchase.
...but the best one ever made by my owner.

And here is our story of getting to know each other:

I lay bored in a box filled to the brim with other contenders.
There were flowers, waters, heavyweights, and all were just waiting to be taken home.
And then I saw her, my new mistress, who would free me from this uniformity, who would grant me freedom and let me be known. For that, I will reward her accordingly. I promised. And then, as if she could hear me, she reached into the box and had eyes only for me. The others were not even given a glance.

I am the chosen one, and so it was. We went home together, and I rewarded her curiosity.
With wide eyes, she undressed me and revealed my dark brown soul. She trusted me right from the start.
I could tell because she, without hesitation, introduced me to her nearly most intimate places...
And I recognized from her moans that she liked me, no, that she had been captivated by me from the very beginning.

I enveloped her like a balm with my elegant tendrils in the form of orange blossom and iris.
I also showed her my distinctive and spicy side, which would protect her like a man. Here, my spices like thyme and cumin helped, which she already knows from the kitchen and enjoys using.
With my musk accord and cedarwood, I ensured that she would stretch and snuggle against me. I seduced her.
Since then, she has guarded me like a precious treasure, as I am the last of my kind.
But I will give her everything until the last drop!

Why this fragrance has been discontinued and is now very rarely available or completely out of stock is a mystery to me. Fortunately, I still have a few remaining bottles, and until three years ago, you could still get original packaged 30ml flacons from the States for about U$ 60, which I treasure like a gem.
Gucci classic is sensual and very balanced; there is no cloying sweetness, neither caraway nor leather, musk or sandalwood spoil the feminine character; it is not intrusive without being shy and certainly not discreet. You enter the room, and everyone, regardless of gender or age, joyfully and admiringly sniffs in my direction. I hardly perceive orange blossoms; iris, heliotrope, vanilla, and incense can be sensed, but the interplay of all the ingredients is as perfect as in a star orchestra: no one stands out, is unpleasantly noticeable, and together they form an ideal conglomerate.
In our best perfumery in Vienna, I wanted to find a twin, together with three super noses who really made an effort. They agreed on Lalique Le Parfum, which might seem similar at first, but after just 5 minutes, it fails miserably. What a pity, such a pity.

Last night I was a bit bored and rummaged through my perfume cabinet.
By chance, I stumbled upon this gem. Since I really couldn't remember how this treasure smelled, I quickly sprayed a bit on my wrist. And? What can I say? I immediately took it back to the bathroom because something this fine should never languish in the back corner.
Okay, the opening is a bit strange; you don't quite know where the scent journey is headed, but the base is simply stunning. Not because it hits you hard in the nose, but because this fragrance radiates warmth, elegance, and softness.
The leather note is perfectly balanced and develops a certain "rrrrr" effect with vanilla and incense-if you know what I mean. ;)
Buy it, folks!

review_title: A Blanket That Wraps Me Up
review_content:
This fragrance has something mystical about it.

The top note is quite intense. It opens up fruity-spicy, with a slight "bubblegum" aroma teasing my olfactory senses.

In the heart note, the fragrance throws around spice bombs, and you can't shield yourself from it... Dry iris flees from cumin and thyme, heavily breathing and fascinated by such boldness, I must engage in this game... I must go through...

Once I have mastered this hurdle of olfactory bombardment, I am rewarded with a gradually emerging creaminess, spicy-leathery, just like a velvety brown blanket that offers me its cozy warmth and security.

My skin chemistry masterfully presents this fragrance to me, leather notes and slightly nutty accords appear. Frankincense ensures that Gucci 1 doesn't become too smooth and soft in the dry down, it brings this mystical "touch".

Candles, incense, and chill Oriental lounge sounds --- outside a winter night at icy minus 15 degrees and inside cozy warmth for two... this fragrance fits perfectly...

review_title: A special scent that unfortunately does not agree with me!
review_content:
Gucci EDP is unfortunately not a perfume for me, not at all. This scent makes me feel sick, especially the thyme, which is quite prominent here! But I will still give it a try.
What I find positive about Gucci is that the entire fragrance bouquet has a certain recognizability, a rather special note!
I have to admit that, even though I can't stand it....
I will try to describe it as objectively as possible;)

The perfume is rather fresh for a few seconds after application, then the clove, very intensely fragrant thyme, and also caraway become noticeable.
In the base note, the scent of thyme and clove is still quite present, quickly merging here with some incense, a hint of vanilla, a bit of leather, and cedar. This perfume overwhelms my stomach, sorry!

...to get through the cold months. Gucci Guilty Intense is a love for me! I don't do signature scents because I don't want to limit myself but this one comes very close! Light sweetness in a bottle with some nicely blended flowers and some pepper and patchouli in the background.

Yes, this is a floral scent, but it's not what I'd usually expect from a floral perfume. I've been a little apprehensive of florals, mostly because a lot of them contain heavy white flowers or a rose note that dominates everything. No, this is definitely not your stereotypical flower powerhouse. Nor is it heavy or suffocating. The geranium and lilac work really well together and don't take center stage.

Guitly Intense is rather fresh and 'sparkly' smelling, almost like a glass of champagne with some fruit added. I also get a whiff of honey whenever I put this on, even though it's not listed as a note. Delicious!
I don't find it especially sexy (I've owned sexier scents!), I just wear it because I like it. It's appropriate for leisure or daily wear during winter as well! Don't turn this beauty down simply because it used to be a popular clubbing perfume!

I've received a couple of compliments when wearing this, mostly from my friends whenever I hug them. Like I said earlier, this is no powerhouse with beast sillage and presence. It's a bit light and I usually spray around 5 times so that other people can smell it on me as well. Longevity could be better, however the real problem with this scent is that it becomes a skin scent rather quickly. After about 4 to 5 hours it just becomes a skin scent that you can barely pick up anymore. It lasts longer on clothes so I just spray some on my scarf. I will probably have to repurchase this one when I run out.

I don't know whether an intense version of this fragrance was entirely necessary. To be fair, the original Guilty was fairly short-lived, and while Guilty Intense is an improvement in terms of projection and longevity, it leaves much to be desired.

Gucci Guilty Intense is a pleasant fragrance, easy to wear and a sure crowd-pleaser. It shows a somewhat interesting contrast between peppery florals and earthy patchouli.

Since this fragrance has been 'amped up' to an EDP, what was considered pleasant in the original fragrance, now smells sharp and at times, a little screechy. The pink pepper accord is unfortunately overwhelmingly strong on my skin, smothering the feminine lilac and heliotrope blend.

I personally like to wear scents that make me stand out from the crowd and feel exceptional. Once again, (similar to my reaction to the original Guilty), this flanker comes across as bland and overrated. The high price tag leads you to expect so much more.

Gucci Guilty Intense is much warmer and more elegant than its predecessor, making it a good choice for Autumn and Winter. Fans of the original fragrance that had issues with its lasting strength, will most likely enjoy this intense EDP flanker.

Original review written: October 2012.

review_title: oriental lovers only. fruity florals beware
review_content: Well, all those people on the right have it, so it must appeal to some. On me, it was stomach turning. I heroically stuck it out for an hour but, in the end, had to scrub. Rotting lilac and pest control chemical.Very strong and thick oriental. I have a hard time with amber and patch.

After Guilty had hopped towards me, charming and lively like a little lamb, and had fortunately rendered the title "Guilty" absurd, I positively approached trying Guilty Intense.

Although the Intense appears fuller and darker, I cannot assign any "guilt" to it either.
This fragrance is also soft and seductively cuddly - and in no way wicked or even offensive.
It may be the black sheep in the herd, but it is also tame and cozy.

The pepper is mild-spicy and the lilac enchanting, yet unobtrusive.
Amber adds a gentle glow to the fragrance, and patchouli is responsible for the dark fleece of the sheep.

A scent that, although a favorite, stands out from the crowd.

I don't know which marketing genius named this incredibly attractive fragrance "Guilty," because the wearer really shouldn't feel guilty at all.

On the contrary - my fellow humans find the scent very warm and inviting - just like I do.

Back when I was in the early stages of my youth, my peers wrapped themselves in stuffy floral-sweet drugstore perfume clouds, and that was all I knew. There was no talk of more expensive perfumes or brands like Gucci. At that time, my mother bought Gucci Guilty for herself. I then tested the perfume... and oh my God!!! It was as if I could literally smell gold. I immediately fell in love with this scent and claimed it for myself. Guilty became my first real perfume. After that, I was done with stuffy floral-sweet drugstore perfumes ^^^^

I associate the scent with cool, clear starry nights in late summer-autumn when you go out and are dressed more elegantly. Actually, Guilty is wearable in any season and even during the day.
How does one feel when wearing the scent?
Not like an ordinary woman out of the ordinary; but also not like a little princess in the spotlight - rather like a true Queen. A Queen who is very low-key (as the scent is perceived more subconsciously and intimately),
more calm and reserved with her elegant demeanor (due to the weak H+S) and has a mischievous smile with a seductive, almost enchanting aura.

Gucci Guilty is simply a fragrance that radiates a "golden" charm. Without vanilla, without spice, without gourmand, without stuffy sweet something. Identifying and describing the scent notes themselves is relatively difficult; I would vaguely estimate floral-synthetic-soapy-dry-woody. The delicate floral lilac note proves the "Guilty" rather the opposite. So as seductive and guilty as the low-key Queen may initially seem, she is also quite innocent :)
The only flaw of the perfume is its longevity + sillage.

Guilty was my first love in the world of perfume, everyone liked it when I wore it, as it is not a scent that one (at least on others) can dislike, and it remains my all-time favorite.

I am a big fan of Gucci Guilty Intense! It is indeed a heavy fragrance, which is actually more suited for the cooler seasons, but still perfect for summer party nights. A seductive, short dress, long flowing hair, high heels, smoky eyes, sex appeal... and then the erotic scent of Gucci Guilty Intense... This could almost turn into a fairy tale... In fact, I find the TV...

Today I received this beautiful fragrance. My first thought was, here I have a wonderful heliotrope scent, paired with lilac. The lilac is dominant here. I have never sniffed such a fine lilac scent before. Ideal for lilac lovers, very elegant and delicate yet still sexy (in my opinion). I don't really perceive the mandarin and pink pepper on the first sniff at all. The...

This EdP is neither "guilty" nor "intense." But really good. Classically good. The top note of (clearly recognizable) mandarin and pink pepper (however that smells) is beyond any initial suspicion. Lilac, heliotrope, and violet (heliotrope clearly dominates) are certainly no angels, but must be acquitted due to lack of evidence. Regarding the suspects amber and patchouli, the investigation was closed due to lack of particular public interest.

So in short: if you just want to smell pleasant, without sticking your neck out too far or smelling cheap, and also don’t want to be tied to a specific occasion, then you’ve come to the right place. I can't think of much more. The scent is coherent without edges and corners - but in a very engaging way. Perhaps a tiny bit uninteresting - but not really meaningless. It radiates warmth - I would associate it with the color orange. Definitely a more youthful scent, so not necessarily for the distinguished lady over 50.

One drawback: the longevity leaves much to be desired for an EdP that also claims the addition "intense."

review_title: the violet is guilty!! Intense? Yes, very guilty..
review_content:
Given the name Guilty and the design of the gaudy bottle, I would have spontaneously associated it with a very intrusive, provocative scent, but as so often in life, one must admit that one is on the wrong track with stereotypical thinking and prejudices.. because Guilty opens as a delicate, sensual, velvety delight.. why delight, you ask? I immediately have an association.. I feel my saliva increasing and I have an uncontrollable craving for finely whipped, unsweetened cream..
I suspect that the combination of lilac and patchouli is responsible for my cream dreams..
Mandarin and pepper are not perceivable from the start, and after just a few minutes, a very persistent violet makes itself known.. hmmm, while this is not bad, it is definitely the reason why it cannot become my scent..
The longevity of the fragrance is very good, so anyone deciding to purchase should not be stingy and prefer the EdP over the Edt.. (there's only a 2€ difference)

My conclusion: if one had forgotten the violet in the top note, then... oh, I don’t even know what then:-)

I have a kind of love-hate relationship with some Gucci fragrances. Starting with Rush, which I have owned three times and still don't know if I like it or not.
Gucci Première was already a bit further up on my scale, a beautiful but unfortunately rare classic.
Where was I? Oh yes, Guilty. The bottle is an absolute no-go that initially kept me from testing it. Then I made a quick stop at my trusted perfumery and snagged a sample of it. Since then, it has been gathering dust in my treasure chest.
And then, on a whim, I cautiously dabbed it on, with zero expectations.

Sniff...sniff - ah - sniff.... - mmmhh - sniff not so bad at all.

In fact, I associate this scent with a large beige cashmere scarf that is beautifully warm or an elegant brown-golden cognac. The fragrance is warm, wonderfully laid-back, and very classic.
As a signature scent, I think it would be quite suitable. The fruits stay in the background, but the pepper is present, and the patchouli is very subtle.

Okay, now I have finally made myself guilty by waiting so long to test it, and I actually need more of it now....

review_title: Expectation not met... But still beautiful
review_content: To be honest, I expected something different from the name. Especially with "intense," I thought there would be power behind it. The scent is still beautiful. You get a lightly powdered lilac, accompanied by a bit of fruit. The patchouli grounds it with a hint of green. The fragrance has a pleasant sweetness and is an elegant and well-groomed scent. It can be worn in any season and for any occasion. Unfortunately, the longevity and sillage are only mediocre.

Back in the day, I used to "blind buy" fragrances all the time. Many a time, I was left unimpressed and disappointed in the purchase. I believe it was due to my impulsiveness and inexperience. When I was just learning about fragrances, I wasn't sure what all the notes smelled like from the description so I was more willing to throw caution to the wind when making a purchase. Fast forward 10 years. I know what I like and what I don't like now. I know what notes I'm drawn to and which ones I'm not. I now have an instinct that is much more hoaned, when making a blind buy. I am happy to report that I am very rarely let down from blind buy purchases I make nowadays.
Working in a store that carries fragrances is both exciting and daunting. So many fragrances to research! Haha
I take my time and I look at every one and then I google the ones that I am most interested in to read about the notes, the prices, the availability and finally, the reviews. I take all of that information into account before I jump at a blind buy now.
When the feeling of confidence kicks in, I go for it! Or, if I'm feeling really unsure, I take a pass. Sometimes I'll research a scent for hours before making my mind up but in the end, all the digging around is worth it.
I finished work on Thursday and decided to take a look at the fragrance section before leaving for home. (Believe it or not, I do not do this every day! Haha)
I knew that we had just received a large shipment in of fragrance in that day and was eager to see what we had. I picked up two for men (Versace Oud Noir and Gucci Made to Measure) and three for woman (Gucci by Gucci, Versace Vanitas and Dolce and Gabbana Light Blue.)
I stood there with my phone and looked up all of them. No to the Oud, too manly. No to Made to Measure, too boring. No to Vanitas, too similar to Chloe, which I despise. No to Light Blue, has been reformulated and is now screechy.
Hmmmmm.........Gucci by Gucci. Ding, ding, ding..........we have a winner!!!
59.99 for a 50 ml. bottle plus my employee discount, not bad!
Unboxed it when I arrived home and smelled the nozzle. I knew instantly that I was going to love it. I wore it the following day and had that huge sigh of relief, knowing that I had made the right decision.
When I first sprayed it on (I always do 2 or 3 sprays on my chest/tummy area) I noticed a "stinky" note but it didn't scare me, I knew it would settle down and it did. I'm hit or miss with patchouli but it's smooth in here. The musk is light and also smooth. The honey brings a sweetness but it's also smooth and gentle. Overall, it's smooth and well blended and to me, it's a confident, sexy, "power" scent. It's not in-your-face or aggressive. It sneaks up on you, gives you a warm hug and steals a kiss! Alluring!
I've read other reviews stating that they wished it was spicier but I think we have enough spicy scents out there already. I think that this one is perfect just as it is. Absolutely stunning for cooler seasons.
Lasts all day on me and I continually get wiffs of it whenever I heat up and am moving around.
The bottle itself is also drop-dead gorgeous!
It's sad that it's been discontinued but I'll certainly enjoy it to the very last drop!

i smell patchouli and honey, equally.

oh yeah and its a darkly light scent, it really is! i know that doesn't make much sense but its winter-y and spicy but only a whisper on my skin. even when i first spray it, it fades to a beautiful sweet honey dusted kiss. a light, sheer, warm hug. in fact, its so light that i had to re-spritz before i left work. 3 hours later and its still wafting gently to my nostrils, hahahaa. (sorry that sentence sounded ridiculous and made me laugh.)

review_title: A Woody Floral with No Wood
review_content:
I don't understand the patchouli note in this scent. I don't smell it – at least not in the traditional hippy way. Nor am I getting it in an earthy way, as is in Prada Amber. Nor is it green. What I am getting is a gorgeous, satiny wood. I am really amazed by that considering there is no wood listed in the notes for this fragrance. If I were to visualize this fragrance it would be glossy, like a sleek, smooth, polished piece of ebony wood. The fact that this has no wood sent me on a search to find out more about the Patchouli plant itself. I was able to find out that there are several varieties that are shrubby, and the sap is often extracted from their woody stems and put to various uses. The most widely used this way is Java Patchouli, which is prized for its sleek wood notes. If this is the type of patchouli used here that could explain the beautiful wood notes I'm smelling.

When taken as a whole, this composition is very rich. The fruit, honey and spice notes are very light, seemingly only there to accentuate the beautiful patchouli. I'm not getting Tiare outright but there is a creamy, buttery richness to this composition that could only be attributed to that. But make no mistake, Patchouli is the star here and in its present form is extremely seductive, sexy, and glamorous.

I'm still finding it hard to believe that a note I normally dislike so much can be so beautiful; but from first spray to the silky end this was a head over heels love for me. I am so sad this gorgeous scent was discontinued. I am actually baffled by that.

This Bottle says Sex to the T and with
the Gold Charm Glamour. I Love the Dark Opaque Brown Quarz Sqaure bottle.
like an exclusive V.I.P darky lit Quarz
and black leather Furnished Discotque.
with Tall slinder Bronzed women wearing skintight golden and bronzed short Dresses and Plugeing neckline Sexy male G.Q. Models With black Fendi Sunglasses
with dim golden strobe light pulsating
over the room. A disco in a Bottle.

But the notes are to light and fruity
for this bottle.
get rid of the Tiare flower Pear And honey and replace it with Incense Cardamom sandalwood woodsey notes
vetiver Jasmine Benzoin Oppoponox & Myrrh. if i was a Perfumer it'll be a more darker more Woodsy oriental Scent.
I Love the bottle but vamp up the Perfume to it's look and name.

This perfume isn't as bad as people make out, however it is slightly boring and unoriginal.

I expected this fragrance to be intense, warm and truly seductive, however what I get is a light, musky, almost masculine scent. Not bad, it is definitely wearable, but not as outstanding as I would've liked it to be.

There are slight hints of woodsy notes throughout this fragrance, yet there are no woods listed in this scent. The guava and pear notes confuse me greatly as I cannot smell them at all. Gucci opens with floral notes and stays like that until the scent fades away.

Another disappointing aspect to this scent is its lack of lasting power, which surprised me seeing that you pay a considerable amount to own this fragrance. In my opinion you aren't getting what you paid for.

I can't help feeling like there's something missing in this fragrance. It definitely lacks character and appeal for me.

I was given Gucci by Gucci as a Christmas present back in 2010. At that time I loved fruity florals and especially those with a citric vibe such as Armani Diamonds. Watching me spraying GbG that evening must have been such fun - except for my husband, who had bought it. He did not understand my interest for perfumes and often told me that it was a crazy hobby, so it was sweet...

In the year 2007, I was looking for a fragrance with lots of patchouli. As a budding goth, that's just part of the essentials. The friendly saleswoman at Müller immediately recommended this EDP to me. I thought it was great too, but Gucci??? The epitome of tackiness would almost be a betrayal of my dark persona. So I preferred something else xd Today, thankfully, I don't see...

The bottle already caught my attention: beautiful shape and warm, noble colors.

The bottle incorporates the design elements from the past of the Gucci house:
In the center is the Horsebit. In the 1950s, it adorned handbags made of heavy brown leather, which was quilted similarly to a saddle.
The idea for the web stripe comes from the stable. The saddle is secured with the stripe of linen fabric on the horse's back. The lettering is based on the original signature of Guccio Gucci and is stitched into leather products.

The first fragrance creation by Frida Giannini is a modern chypre scent that I really like. It is quite soft and warm, sensual and elegant, like the coat of a horse.

I can easily detect a slight fruitiness that gives the fragrance its modernity. For me, this scent is consistently sensual, warm, and softly composed. A light sweetness (from the honey) is also noticeable.
For me, it is a noble fragrance that is not too overpowering and lasts for many hours!

review_title: Exotic Tiaré Honey, should I wear it out?
review_content: When a label suddenly decides to discontinue a fragrance, I can accept it if better scents come into production. Gucci by Gucci could not replace my dearly loved Gucci Eau de Parfum I. However, it is still a very delicious, fruity scent. At first, I wasn't quite sure if the slightly biting honey-tiare-musk combination was really bearable, but ultimately, it is exactly what makes this perfume unique and exceptional. The explosion of guavas and pears upon spraying is really wonderful and very fruity. At the same time, I smell the Tiaré flower and musk, which run through the entire scent progression. The honey is noticeable but not dominant. I perceive the patchouli at most as a base carrier, but also not prominent. It is a very nice fragrance, perhaps a bit of an acquired taste, because the Tiaré has a special scent that one must like and which does not play a major role in the perfume industry, but that is what makes this perfume extraordinary and special. As a going-out scent? For me, it is more suited for a professional workday; for going out, it is neither elegant nor sexy enough. In my opinion, it does not have the erotic and aphrodisiac touch. But as I said, I like it very much...and the bottle is also fitting.

My mom has claimed the Guccis for herself - rightly so, as they suit her excellently.

I gladly take note of her elegant scent trail - but I always kept a respectful distance from fragrances like Premier, as they seemed too ladylike for me.

Even when I am beautifully washed and combed, I am nowhere near as naturally ladylike as my mother.

But a spray of her Gucci by Gucci, which she encouraged me to try, surprisingly clings to me like a second skin.

Who would have thought - for this scent is exquisite and elegant as well.

Its softness and flexibility make it quite wearable for me.
It still exudes an alluring preciousness that surprisingly fits with my casual outfit.

Pear and guava are smoothly fruity, and the Tiare is elegantly floral.
The honey note reminds me of French nougat, which melts sweetly in the nose.
The patchouli is soft and warm.

Gucci conveys closeness and security - it is elegant, but in no way distant.
For a cuddle cat like me, it is very fitting.

I thank my mom for the good advice and for always sharing everything with me.

I don't want to tear apart a scent in the air, but for my nose, it is definitely not suitable, and my dislike is my personal opinion. "Gucci by Gucci" definitely starts off fruity-sweet, almost overpowering for me. This remains the case for quite a while until a kind of citrusy and slightly green-bitter note takes over. This is paired with a honey note (similar to English Honey Drops). Later, scents of patchouli and musk can be detected, which are very active and pleasant to sniff, but these fragrance components are constantly "overflown" by this fruit and honey note, making "Gucci by Gucci" personally just too sweet and too heavy for me. Dear Gucci friends, please don't be mad at me, as I am just a lover of chypre and spicy orientals.

What I like about Gucci is that the fragrances I own are beautifully quirky and unconventional! However, since Flora, I have become a bit more cautious, as it is not my scent.

Gucci by GUCCI EDP is the idea of dusting off the Chypre fragrance category and creating a renewed interest in this scent direction today. I find the basic cleaning successful, at least for me. I have smelled classics in this category and found myself too weak for them. They were, of course, interesting and an experience in connection with their history, but not wearable for me. All critics of the fragrance will find thousands of reasons why Gucci by GUCCI is not a successful retro Chypre or does not deserve the name Chypre. However, I am a lover of this scent and can only report good things.

Gucci by GUCCI is more precisely described as chypre-fruity, but it would be an outrageous cheekiness (this phrase comes from Cinderella in the film "Three Hazelnuts for Cinderella," I don't know why it just came to mind??? Well, 3HFA fans recognized???) to make a comparison to Mitsouko by Guerlain, so I won't do it, couldn't do it, and somehow I have done it anyway, but Mitsouko is also classified in this subcategory of Chypres.

Gucci by GUCCI EDP is my fragrance; rarely does a scent from this family capture my heart, but this one has succeeded. Fruity in the top note and already in the first whiffs unusual. A tart fruitiness, zesty and very, very fleeting, which is a shame because this top note is brilliant. The heart with Tiaré, and I already sense patchouli here, is complex and holds up very well into the base. An extremely successful move is to add a honey note to this floral heart, this wonderful Tiaré, and the marvelous patchouli, perfect and not sweet! Even though the honey does not flow forever, which is not necessarily a disadvantage, a wonderful base remains, and the typical scent character of Gucci by GUCCI, while weaker, remains soft.

The bottle is definitely successful, as elegant and unobtrusive as the scent itself. Gucci has packaged a retro idea in a great commercial, and I have once again dug out Blondie with the incomparable Debbie Harry and can almost see the Gucci girls dancing to Heart of Glass.

A lot has already been said about the scent of this perfume, but due to the rather different perceptions, I would like to share my opinion as well.

In my opinion, the scent is intended for an elegant, self-confident lady and is suitable for both evening wear and business life. It pairs well with a classic appearance in a suit or pantsuit.

For me, it starts with a very fruity, but not sweet presence, but soon becomes warm, elegant, slightly bitter, yet subtly a bit sweet, creating a discreet but well-perceived feminine overall impression.

Gucci seems to develop very individually on the skin and is perceived differently by those around, but generally never negatively or unpleasantly. In my opinion, it does not have a very high recognition factor. But isn’t it actually nicer if not everyone, especially in the professional world, immediately knows which fragrance you are wearing and you are not pigeonholed with associations?
A good perfume should give the wearer a personal touch, and Gucci by Gucci fulfills this requirement.

The longevity of the scent for me (EDP) is medium to good. However, I no longer perceive the scent throughout the entire day. If I spray it in the morning, I feel the need to reapply in the afternoon. The heavy, bulky bottle is anything but suitable for handbags, so it’s better to decant a little or refrain from reapplying altogether.

On the vanity, the bottle looks very nice, and I personally like its appearance, but this is probably more a matter of taste than with many other perfume bottles. It certainly appeals more to the classic, mature woman than to the young romantic girl, but that is intended here and fits the content.

I also find the brown tint of the bottle positive, so you can leave it out without having to hide it in a cupboard or box to protect the scent from light. Nevertheless, the bottle is translucent, and you can see how much is left. My bottle is now running low, and as a critique, I doubt whether the bottle can be completely emptied due to the wide, flat base, and the spray tube is positioned in the center, making tilting ineffective.

It remains a surprise how often I can still use the scent, as I will not be repurchasing it despite my overall positive impression - at least for now - because the competition in fragrances is simply too great.

As I read the other comments and incorporate my own opinion, I think that despite the name, the scent will have a hard time being accepted into the league of great classics in the long term, but it is definitely worth testing it extensively.

review_title: Narciso Rodriguez For Her (Eau de Parfum), is it you?
review_content:
In a sniffing mood, I reached for Gucci by GUCCI. An acquaintance of mine wore it, and I thought it was really great.
From memory, I expected this very scent and found something different:
Narciso Rodriguez For Her (Eau de Parfum)!
I looked again at my hand to see if I was actually holding the right bottle. Yes, it was GbG.

The first three hours, the two are quite similar. NRFH is a bit spicier and less floral-sweet, but the similarity still caused confusion.
After three or four hours, it takes a different direction. Strangely, I can now smell the pear that is supposed to be in the top note. Patchouli and honey make GbG sweeter and more pleasant than NRFH. Pleasant, as I quickly get a headache from the scent twin.
It is bitter, but the floral and fruity notes make it feminine and elegant.
Some time later, it becomes increasingly powdery, less fruity, and even a bit smoky. Here, the patchouli note slightly reminds me of Dark Amber & Ginger Lily by Jo Malone.

Now I really like it, and my memory of the woman comes back - But do I want to wait five hours every time for the scent to develop the way I like it?

The longevity and sillage are okay. However, one should not spray it too generously, as one can be overwhelmed by the oriental spiciness.
GbG is best suited for autumn and winter evenings, but can also be worn during the day with just one spray.

In my opinion, it is a sensual scent for women who like it spicy, bitter, and feminine.

I will not buy it, as I don’t want to wait that long for the base. But I’m happy to recommend it.

Addendum: 08.02.2015 23:39
Even after about 17 hours, I could still perceive a slight hint. Super longevity!

... "wow!"
One should give the scent a moment to settle.

After the first spray, I immediately thought: "Oh man, this smells cheap!" Not "tacky-cheap," which might have been somewhat nice, but "drugstore scent-cheap." A mishmash of whatever, a bit overpowering, indefinable, simply not good. Especially for this price. A no-go!

If you give the perfume a little time, it changes relatively quickly and turns very positive. The scent won't reinvent the wheel, but it becomes an interesting perfume that can adapt to any situation (with the right wearer, which I'll get to).

Regarding the scent notes:

Not fruity.
Not sweet (that's how I perceive it, even if others smell it differently).
Not delicate.

For me, "Gucci by Gucci" is a scent with edges and corners. Not a girly scent for teenagers. The fragrance is very mature, and for me, it's of the somewhat rougher kind. The scent seems a bit uneven to me. It's a little "fidgety" and might come across as extremely overpowering to some, especially at first. That is, until you can really clearly sense the base note. Then it starts to show, for the very first time, a bit of its softer side. But that's really just the faint trace of the scent that remains on the skin at the end.

You really need to pay attention to where you wear it.

By the way, this is the Midnight Poison phenomenon. It also seems extremely intrusive to me. Until the base comes to the forefront. That can be pleasant if you like it - then it can also be pleasant from the start - but otherwise, it should really be approached with caution.

For me, Gucci by Gucci is not an all-rounder. I'm not the right person for that, simply because of the initial strong presence of the scent. But in the evening, when it's cold or when going out... those would be the Gucci moments. People who really like this perfume - more than I do - and stand by it, will find that the scent suits them in EVERY situation.

Unfortunately, I have to say that the price-performance ratio here won't be to everyone's taste. The scent is really not that "special."

P.S.: I find the bottle very pretty.

As angular as the bottle, so profound is the inner essence. Warm, feminine, cultivated, subtly erotic, but never pretentious or vulgar. All the notes blend harmoniously for me, without being boring on one hand or jagged on the other. The scent is, for me, the liquefied embodiment of elegance and style with a twist, of serious, practiced calm, upright understatement with an incredibly feminine glow beneath it, which the wearer knows how to handle and lets loose in selected moments. No squeaky citrus, no sticky peach, no sweet fruit sorbet that would disturb this tasteful nobility. The pear nestles with a flutter of the eyelashes against the warm honey and gently leads to the velvety musk-patchouli finish.

Fantastic. I consider the scent to be grandly underrated and suitable for both daytime and evening wear.

If only the bottle were a little less ostentatious - we really don’t need that.

I find the bottle completely unappealing. Strained to look elegant, and what’s with this silly, jingling stirrup in plastic gold? Because I found Rush by Gucci quite impressive, I decided to try Gucci by Gucci despite the silly bottle, and the scent pleasantly surprised me. The top note briefly raises fears of the currently popular fruity-floral-sweet mush. But then it develops a nice balance of fruity, subtly sweet, and bitter notes. An interesting tension. Overall, it has an oriental feel, but is hardly floral, not spicy, and only slightly sweet. I could get used to that and would even tolerate the bottle. However, it’s more suited for the cold season.

~ Inspiration ~
So far, I have had quite good experiences with Gucci fragrances and wanted to test this one after Guilty and Flora.

~ Bottle ~
Classic and elegant.
The warm brown tones look luxurious, especially together with the golden cap. A small golden stirrup serves as an eye-catcher on the closure. Overall, it evokes an association for me with brown, stately horses, their wealthy owners, and the accompanying equestrian tournaments.

~ Scent ~
It starts fruity-herb with pear and guava.
This top note gradually fades and reveals the harmonious heart note of white Tiare flower and light lily of the valley. The whole is rounded off by a combination of honey, musk, and patchouli. A warm, sensually feminine scent develops that is not too sweet but rather floral-woody.

~ Longevity ~
I can perceive it on my skin for about 4-5 hours (on clothing and hair even longer). However, a sparing application is advisable, as it can otherwise become too biting and intrusive.

~ Occasion ~
It suits stylish, self-confident women who know what they want best.
I see it as an evening fragrance and for special occasions in the colder season; I can also imagine it well on successful businesswomen.

~ Conclusion ~
Actually, I am not very fond of herb-woody perfumes, but I find this one quite pleasant to wear due to its blend with slightly sweet floral accords.

wow, a real fruit bomb :) I am very surprised!
I like the scent, it would be worth considering as a gift... ;-)

The scent is very nice right after spraying. Unlike most perfumes, I really like the first whiff of this one. Unfortunately, unfortunately, unfortunately, after just two hours, only a very ordinary scent remains that smells like an older lady. Not bad, but just more than 0815.

Gucci by Gucci is a good all-rounder for me.

I always use it when I'm not quite sure which perfume I'm in the mood for today.

At first, it’s quite fruity due to the pear, sweet, but not overly sweet. Overall, this scent is not intrusive and stays quite close to the body for me.
In the end, honey/patchouli lingers very softly on the skin.

It lasts about 4-5 hours on me, which I find quite short.
I won't be repurchasing it also for that reason, but also because it’s just an all-rounder for me. It can be replaced by one of the many other scents that are out there.

Thanks to this site, I have at least 50 other fragrances in mind!

What a shame: The bottle looks so elegant and beautiful, and then this: Unremarkably fruity (pear), it reminds me of fine drops in nut (Williams-Christ pear) or whatever those pralines are called ... No, it’s nothing!

I love this fragrance, fruity yet tangy, you have to
let it develop, and it lasts super long on me.

I saw it, sprayed it, sniffed it, and instantly fell in love with this wonderful scent in its delightfully kitschy bottle.
The top notes of guava and pear completely convinced me of this wonderfully fruity, yet not overpowering fragrance.
I hope to welcome it into my collection soon.

Today I tested Gucci by Gucci and I must say... not a scent for me! I expected a slightly sweeter gourmand fragrance based on the listed base notes! Wrong! Fruity, too fruity/floral for me! I think it's the pear that bothers me immensely! All in all, not a special fragrance where you could say "WOW" what a scent experience! Gucci by Gucci is not bad, but it has no...

review_title: as a weapon of anesthesia maybe....
review_content: seems to smell not bad, but the whole fragrance is so penetrating that it directly numbs my nasal mucous membranes, rises to my head, and dries my throat. so strong and intrusive, it smells like him everywhere right now. he really doesn't need to put himself sooooo in the foreground? less is often more.

GUCCI RUSH 2 is nearly the strict antithesis of GUCCI RUSH. RUSH 2 is cool, slightly soapy, lightly floral, not at all sweet, and rather shortlived in the edt.

The somewhat dark, lingering oriental thickness of RUSH (imparted by mingling patchouli and vanilla) is not present in RUSH 2 at all. Rather, RUSH 2 is a tiny bunch of little white flowers on a cool morning with dew still clinging to kelly green blades of grass.

It's almost as though the Gucci people self-consciously sought to produce a fragrance which would appeal to all those who disliked RUSH. A better name for RUSH 2 might be:

~(GUCCI RUSH)!

review_title: A soapier and much more pleasant flanker of Rush
review_content:
Rush 2 is hardly related to Rush at all. This is an entirely different composition altogether.

Upon first application, I could barely smell it. The opening notes are extremely subtle and intimate. I would describe the rose, freesia and lily of the valley as having a soapy and fresh-like quality.

With the emergence of the heart, Rush 2 develops character. The scent strengthens considerably and shows elements of originality. The soapiness is still present, however I detect a subtle greeness, like a tropical, damp garden smell.

Rush 2 concludes with a simplistic black currant and musk blend, with this being the only fruity kick you will experience during the development of Rush 2, right at the very end.

I vividly remember a man that owned a perfume store where I used to live, raving on about Rush 2. He had me try it several times but I had to go back to this fragrance 3 years on because the scent hadn't stuck in my memory. Because of that I don't think this fragrance is very memorable, certainly not signature material in my humble opinion.

I used to be part of the crowd who thought Rush 2 bore no resemblance whatsoever to the original Gucci Rush. But now that I have worn both within a few days of each other, I have changed my mind. They ARE sisters! First of all, they have the same father, Michel Almairac. They were born a mere two years apart from each other and therefore part of the same "perfume trend generation". Like sisters who are close to one another, they are able to play together and layer well with each other. While original Gucci Rush is the louder, bossier, dominant older sister, Rush 2 tries to emulate her in certain ways.

In Rush 2, the fruity aspect of Rush's peach is replaced by a sweet juicy black currant note. The original had a strong gardenia note, while Rush 2 has gardenia but it rests shyly in the background, preferring to let cleaner flowers like freesia and lily of the valley do the talking. The original is the bad ass of the clan, sneaking out late to party while Rush 2 stays home and studies but lets the original sneak back in through her window because after all, they are close and she likes to live vicariously through the stories Rush brings home. Rush 2 is the daughter grandma likes better but original Rush is the one who will go on to be famous.

I emptied at least two bottles of this fragrance in my younger years. A scent I always liked, but then somehow lost sight of-or rather, lost track of.

When I read that this fragrance was no longer being produced, the familiar hoarding instinct kicked in, and I quickly purchased another bottle. The word "discontinued" always triggers strange behaviors in me... Now, many fragrances that I liked very much back then no longer seem to suit me today. But I thought, at least I have Rush 2 for nostalgic sniffing.

However, the first spray surprised me: I still really like the scent! It is still absolutely wearable today. Fresh, floral, a bit fruity, without the otherwise indispensable sweetness that is so common today, yet not bitter, no scratching, stinging, or biting-just nice, fresh, feminine, compatible with others, and very pleasant to wear.

And they are discontinuing this? WHY? Gucci Rush 2 (which, by the way, has absolutely nothing to do with the classic Rush!) is not a scent that will take your breath away or one that you will never forget, but as I said, it is office-appropriate and will make a pleasant impression. Or you might not stand out at all, depending on the situation. Very few will feel disturbed by this fragrance; many will find this adult fruity-floral pleasantly appealing.

The only downside: The bottle (is that supposed to represent a cassette case? Who even remembers cassettes??). I remember that you could only get the rest of the fragrance out by digging the corners of this plastic thing deep into your palms. But that won't stop me from wearing this lovely scent until it's empty.

After I had forgiven Rush for its "boxy appearance," I boldly reached for Rush 2.

This scent greets me more lovingly than the original version.

Rush 2 has, unlike its bottle, no corners or edges - instead, it welcomes me gently and friendly.
Even the blackberries are not square, but full and round - and roll towards me pleasantly aromatic.
Freesia and Narcissus spread floral brightness, with a hint of soft rose.
The palm wood is also cuddly - and the lily leans towards elegance.

An attractively floral-fruity daytime scent that, contrary to its name, knows no rush.
Rather a fragrance to lean back - and relax.

Indeed - haste makes waste.

Yes, in the early 2000s, alongside "Mädchen" and "Girl," there was also "Sugar." And in this - undoubtedly the best and unfortunately eventually discontinued girly magazine - there was a beauty interview with Holly Valance in one issue. She was the one with the not-so-great one-hit-wonder "Kiss Kiss," but at the time, she was an icon for all of us 13-year-olds, at least for...

The scent of Gucci Rush 2 is unmistakable, super sweet fruity and yet has a touch of freshness somewhere.
If anyone is wondering where I get the freshness from, well, it simply smells like you just stepped out of the shower after using a berry shower gel or shampoo, or maybe even both. The hint of musk, which is unusual in shower gels and such, does suggest that it must be a perfume.

Unfortunately, I am quite divided on the longevity of the scent; on skin and hair, I can't perceive the fragrance for long, and the sillage has never been as noteworthy as with other fragrances where people turn around and say "Wow, what smells so wonderful?". It's a pity because Gucci Rush 2 really has the potential to appeal to more people. On textiles, however, jackets and scarves, I can still perceive the scent for a long time, which makes me happy, but spending money on a "bed spray" is rather disappointing.

The bottle could have offered more; it looks modern and does justice to its plastic predecessor Gucci Rush, but a glass design might have made the concept much more appealing.
Pink plastic. The pink is great, no question - but a plastic bottle... well, the attempt to stand out from other bottles has, in my eyes, backfired.

It's a shame about Gucci Rush 2, which I really enjoy wearing, but the overall concept unfortunately does not do justice to the fragrance.

For over 15 years, this has been my recurring fragrance that manages to excite me every single time.
Back at the beginning of the new millennium when it had just been released, I tested it once and without hesitation had to have it immediately.
I must admit that it develops fantastically on me. Fresh yet somehow silky and powdery at the same time.
A colleague visited me today, and when I asked her (out of pure curiosity...not because it smelled so amazing) which fragrance she was wearing, she pulled out a bottle of Rush2 from her handbag.
I could hardly grasp it...very fruity and sweet, without any recognizability, it wafted from her to my nose.
Even when I applied it again on my wrist, that incredibly fine, noble aura was back, almost too beautiful to be true.

It's a shame that production is being discontinued.

In my opinion, this creation is a subtle and elegant product: the scent is discreet, almost subliminally present, but it does not stand out "just passing by."
The other side of "rush 2" is the gentle playfulness, almost a sense of risk, that the numerous floral-sweet fragrance components contribute. But now to the components...

Roses and daffodils are often mentioned in the same breath, occasionally combined. This is probably what they thought at Gucci: who doesn't love that delicate rose scent, which always feels spring-fresh and sweetly invigorating? Of course, that alone would be too little for a top-class fragrance like this: the daffodil flower catches the rather light and superficial rose scent as it falls and gives it a subtle but solid base: the creation now has a gentle, yet necessary weight.
To perfect the base, they also chose the musk component, which, when applied correctly, can elevate a fragrance to the ultimate aphrodisiac. Personally, I often find that this effect fails due to overly generous application, for example with some (male) Lacoste creations, but Gucci has done everything right in this case. The scent now has a perfectly rounded base thanks to components like musk, light exotic woods (palm), and a touch of forest moss, which work hand-in-hand, making it playful yet somewhat warm-hearted and serious at the same time...
With many fragrances, quickly fleeting - as is the case here - however, never to be underestimated is a good and well-defined top note - after all, it makes the first impression!
Especially the delicate, floral-sweet freesia component and the softly subtle lily of the valley send a playful and open-hearted message ahead...

In my view, the scent gives a woman a certain elegant, fresh, and cheerful touch in a way that is suitable for both everyday life and special occasions. Therefore, I would not give an explicit recommendation of "only for the evening" or "only for parties" - "rush 2" actually fits anytime.
However, I would limit the fragrance's capabilities during long evenings in clubs or similar places, as it tends to dissipate after a few hours in smoke and constant warmth...
Seasonally, "rush 2" does not need to be restricted, but the skin should always be freshly washed when applying the fragrance.

Gucci's "rush 2" is always gently perceptible - except under extreme conditions like smoke or sweat - yet I would recommend a moderate to generous application: about 2-3 sprays for the neck and/or ear areas. This way, the scent floats playfully and gracefully with every head movement and does not dissipate too quickly.

With Gucci's "rush 2," a woman buys an invigorating, elegant, and pleasantly sweet all-time fragrance.
Almost suitable for every type of woman, this creation delights both attentive male and female noses ;-)

I assume that Rush sold satisfactorily, and that’s why Gucci came up with the idea to build on the success of Rush by launching a fragrance called Rush 2. The similarity to Rush is limited, which makes me wonder what the point is. In the top notes, I can still recognize a certain kinship, but then Rush 2 develops quite differently. It is lighter and much more streamlined than Rush, floral but not sweet. The quirky and threatening bass notes that Rush has are missing here; Rush 2 is more like a well-behaved recorder. The most striking thing about Rush 2 for me is a pronounced Nivea cream note.

I don’t find it unpleasant, but it’s also not a fragrance I would need. I probably would have described it more favorably if it had a different name. However, anyone named Rush 2 will be measured against the big sister Rush, and that’s a high bar to reach.

Gucci Rush 2 has been with me for more than 15 years. First as a signature scent in my early 20s, and now I still reach for it often. It simply goes with everything, fresh, uncomplicated, and in my opinion so feminine. It's also the only fragrance that I have repurchased multiple times. It's a shame that it is no longer being produced.

review_title: Hopeful Start with a Sweet Finish
review_content: A new perfume is a must, urgently and immediately! So I have become a regular visitor to the local perfumery in search of it. The ladies see me almost daily at the moment. After testing Elie Saab and then Rush 2 yesterday morning, it quickly became clear that Elie Saab does not fit my preferences, so I dove into Rush 2. Since the opening was okay, almost delicate and not disturbing by my standards, I dared to spray myself quite heavily and then wait for my beloved oak moss in the base. Initially, everything was nice, perhaps a bit lacking in wood in the heart note for my taste, but I decided to wait. I did that - with high expectations for the base. Unfortunately, those were not met. Over time, a scent developed on my skin that constantly lingered unpleasantly in my nose and made me long enormously for a shower. I think it was the blackberry that developed very strongly and sweetly on me, leaving hardly any room for oak moss and musk, and this perfume has been kicked off my list.

I don't know how it happened to an old sniffer like me, but I only discovered this fragrance last year and was immediately smitten.
Finally, a floral scent that doesn't smell soapy and stands out from the crowd.
The bottle is certainly very quirky, but since I love pink, I could warm up to it as well.
This fragrance will surely accompany me for a long time!

For lovers of perfumes that have a slightly more robust note, this fragrance is perfect. There is no risk of headaches from an overly sweet scent, yet it is still intense. A quick spray once on each side of the neck is enough to fully enjoy the fragrance. At first, one perceives the rather floral note, especially the lily of the valley and the rose, which are very well...

review_title: Loyal Companion Since My Youth - with a Feel-Good Factor
review_content: Gucci Rush 2 works for me absolutely all the time! Floral, fresh, and also aquatic, which I really like. It always reminds me anew of my prom and generally of my last school year. Unfortunately, I can only perceive it briefly on myself - but my surroundings apparently notice it for longer. When I apply it to a scarf, it lasts significantly longer, and I enjoy sniffing it and...

At first, Gucci Rush emits a strong, sweet scent, but over time it becomes more robust while still remaining sweet. I find the fragrance to be both floral and powerful at the same time. It lasts a long time and is present with every movement, without being intrusive or heavy. Still, it is not a subtle scent; it's hard to describe, as it is indeed a unique blend of floral and...

Matched my pink wave that I had at the time.
Exceptional scent with a high recognition value, somehow reminds me of cream or sunscreen :-)
Very innovative stylish bottle.

I love the scent of this perfume! It is citrus-delicious!
It really lasts easily, is light and perfect for summer!

Looking at the notes I should love Gucci Flora, but something in the opening makes my nose twitch. As in allergy oh no I'm going to sneeze twitch. So it's not love I'm feeling as my sinuses fill up. Is peony the culprit? Or maybe the osmanthus? I think it's the osmanthus. The osmanthus note here is very similar to the one found in those eponymous perfumes that come out of China, more green and cloying than honeyed. And sorry to say I find this particular rendition of osmanthus, which blooms heady early on and lasts for hours on me, headache-inducing in a way I do not find in Keiko Mercheri's Osmanthus, for example, which I adore. It quite spoils my enjoyment of the powdery rose-patchouli combination that emerges in the middle stages as Lola observes. I have to thank the lovely rubyred for the sample but all this is to say that surprisingly Gucci Flora is not for me.

I tested Gucci FLORA edp some time ago and found it not very exciting and somewhat homogenized, but I've decided to give this fragrance another sniff since I was recently sent a fresh sample of the edt.

Although it has become a common practice to change the formula of a perfume launched under the same name but in edt and edp concentrations, FLORA does not represent such a case, it seems. The notes are the same, so it should come as no surprise that the edt is simply a more dilute solution of the edp. I should say, however, that I have quite a bit more experience with osmanthus than I had the last time I tried FLORA.

Osmanthus is sort of a ready-made fruity-floral flower. It is light with a very subtle peachy quality. This is why compositions featuring osmanthus are almost by definition office-ready inoffensive fruity-floral frags (ORIFFF). If that's what you're looking for, then FLORA may work for you.

Flora opens up to me with orange green yellow citruses then dries to an airy and sweet note of peonies i do detect a bit of peach that is soft and not evasive the middle dries to an delicate and Intoxicating note of Osmanthus that spreads it's gentile aroma over the summer sky and very faint and diluted
note of sandalwood rose and patchouli
are the shy evasive notes that hides
behind dark crevasses in rocks or behind
leafy roofs of foliage. Flora has a girlish innocence inside a chic high end
veneer, the scent brings what it delivers airy and not overly sweet that shows modernity in a bottle.

Nice, is a good word to describe Flora by Gucci. It's pleasant and clean, but rather boring and safe.

While obviously aimed at the younger market, Gucci chose to use a simplistic floral composition of citrus, peony, rose, osmanthus, patchouli and sandalwood. Not what I would call a daring combination.

At the time of this fragrance's release, most of the world was heading into the warmer months, however Australia was going into Winter. Because Flora is so light, fresh and powdery, I don't expect that this fragrance will be a best seller this month.

I would have liked to have seen some stronger floral notes such as; jasmine or orchid added to this fragrance to give it more of a kick. The scent as it is now is far too common for it to be outstanding.

I'm disappointed that this fragrance turned out to be so mainstream. With a name like Gucci, they could have easily gotten away with experimenting with new and unique floral combinations. Here's hoping that their next release, which is also rumoured to be aimed at the younger crowd, is much more daring.

This never became my scent. Why?
It is floral, but too floral.
It is sweet, but too sweet.
It is fruity, but too fruity.
10 years ago every teenage girl smelled of it, and It became too much for me. The fragrance started to annoy me, whenever I met it. And that was often and everywhere.
I got a half used bottle from a friend. I could not bear to tell her that I regarded Flora as an annoying scent so it was adopted. And just stood there on the shelf. Finally I sold it.
The bottle is lovely. But it is not a reasonable for keeping it, now I have decided to downsize my collection. My future fragrances will have to be top scent-top bottle.
Farewell Flora…
Year 2, 25/365

Oh, what’s that floating there? A small, lonely little flower in a puddle of sugar water. How on earth did it get there? And who’s going to get it out? What kind of flower is it anyway? A little rose? A peony. No, wait. It’s not a flower at all: It’s a floating scented candle for 0.79 EUR (recommended retail price). Honestly: What does Gucci think they’re doing?? A...

I had bought Flora blind - the beautiful bottle had captivated me.
But with the first spray, I was irritated - I had expected something distinctly floral.
Instead, I was enveloped by fine, small flowers. Perhaps daisies?
That was my first association with the mild scent.
Actually very lovely.
The peony modestly makes its appearance, and the citrus notes are also finely balanced.
The rose remains discreetly in the background, but osmanthus elevates the whole delicate fragrance weave.
Above all, there is a hint of sandalwood.
Not a prominent, outstanding scent, but one that certainly has its place.
Especially in hot headache-inducing temperatures, it is very appropriate.
You smell subtly, without disturbing yourself or others.
Today, in this heat, it was a pleasant companion - and even my husband's sensitive nose was fond of it.
A quiet, reserved scent - for, let’s not forget: Modesty is an adornment.

Wake me up when it gets exciting...

My predecessors have already said it all: sweet, floral, fruity, artificial - boring.

Great bottle, great name, great advertising. And yet just mediocre. The scent-turned-mainstream. I'm seriously pondering the question of when and why one would want to smell like this. Just perfumed, without edges, without depth, without development. No standout, not even pleasing. But I can't find a satisfying answer.

Gucci produces such fantastic fragrances! L'Arte di Gucci, THE oriental chypre sensation par excellence. My companion for half of the 90s. Or later Gucci Envy. A bold green herbal scent composition. Then Rush. Wow. A sexy rrrr-scent, not shy at all. And also Gucci II. Sparkling berry fizz, fun-delicious-lovely. Even the new Gucci by Gucci still has something special.

And now Flora. Yawn. I'm turning over again...

Flora by Gucci has often been described here as a mild floral fragrance that doesn't have much to offer. I would like to defend the scent here - even if it's just a little.

I bought it some time ago out of pure boredom while browsing, and because I couldn't find anything that truly excited me, I bought it almost blindly, meaning I just sprayed it in the store, found it quite pleasant, and took it home. Today, I'm wearing it...

This morning, right upon spraying, I found Flora to be quite unremarkable, a floral scent that I couldn't clearly define, with a very faint citrus note. The next hour remained similar, but with a strange scratchy undertone that I could only smell close to my skin; if I waved my arm a bit further away, the scent aura was actually quite pleasant. After another hour, I reached the base, the scratchiness was gone (which I'm glad about!), and what remains is a soft, almost vanilla-like sandalwood scent, and I perceive a slight anise note, even though the fragrance contains nothing of the sort. For this base, I can rate it at 70%, otherwise it would be significantly lower.

So, in conclusion, I can say: the scent is pleasant, indeed nothing particularly outstanding, but a delicate companion for the day. I quite like wearing it in the office; it surrounds me with a gentle scent veil, but is at best only marginally noticed by colleagues. More is really not needed in a professional environment.

The longevity is average (it lasts about 4 hours on me), and the sillage is rather below average.

When the fragrance was released and the advertisement was running on television, I couldn't help but keep looking. I imagined being overwhelmed by a sea of flowers with this scent - it could be a fragrance I would like again. However, that was before my time here at Parfumo, and I was completely unaffected by negative opinions. Still, I didn't buy it, not even tested it, and I...

Even though there are many dissatisfied people, this scent feels like it was made for me!
I apply this fragrance and feel as if I am lying in flower petals.
Everyone in my circle immediately asks me what fragrance I am wearing.
I consistently receive compliments.
One shouldn't expect a "wow effect" after just one spray of this scent, but once you find the perfect dosage, it lasts on me almost the entire day!

Gucci's Eau de Toilette Flora doesn't get going. Citrus notes are not recognizable, and something vaguely reminiscent of rose petals might be there. The mention of osmanthus blossoms in the heart note doesn't help much. In the base, patchouli can still be suspected, but sandalwood fails to provide any new impulses to the overall scent progression, which is very modest. What I also think I can smell (although it's not listed) is something like delicate peach skin. A small glimmer of hope?

The bottle is nice, no question about it. When it comes to longevity and sillage, one must conclude: weak. Furthermore, the EdT is not exactly inexpensive compared to other perfumes. What is surprising in the base is a musty powderiness; it simply lacks liveliness and freshness.

Flora has no distinct character, no unique typicity. I can most easily imagine this scent, aside from the price, as a starter fragrance for teenagers. It is not particularly intense and lacks depth, avoiding all edges and corners. The fragrance components feel domesticated and muted, so you constantly have the feeling of driving up a hill in a small car with the handbrake on. And that’s just not fun.

I bought Gucci Flora because I like floral scents.
Unfortunately, I think the recognizability is quite low. It's not that special. There is rose in the top note and heart note... somehow too much rose... I don't know, something just doesn't fit...
My boyfriend also found it totally awful... headache alert :D I can't wear it anymore.

I was somehow drawn to this name "Flora" and the bottle in the shape of a hexagon. Now I have learned that stop signs do not always have to be octagonal, because in the case of Flora, six corners are completely sufficient. I smell no rose, no sandalwood - nothing that inspires me or that I could elaborate on.
I am surrounded by a stuffy sweetness reminiscent of a Walt Disney little girl fragrance. In the Gucci online shop, the same scent notes are listed for both the EdT and the EdP. So there should also be mandarin, pepper, and other flowers playing a role here. To be honest, I really don't know what Flora is supposed to smell like - it certainly isn't flowers, unless we are talking about artificially scented, Chinese plastic rose imports. At best, I still perceive a Haribo Tropi Frutti scent of mandarin fruit - and that's it!
Either this is a really mediocre fragrance with way too high ambitions, or my nose is incapable of perceiving the notes. In dubio pro reo - so I gladly take the blame and declare my capitulation.

Really a shame, because with this bottle design and perfume name, one could have expected something great. Is this not one of this year's Fifi finalists? Well, I would gladly take any bet that it will not make it.

P.S.: This bottle and my fragrance sample (thanks to Elchen) is the EdT.

review_title: When Nothing Better Comes to Mind
review_content:
Ok, I received the bottle as a gift, and as they say, you don't look a gift horse in the mouth.
The scent is a bit too sweet and floral for me, something for days when I'm in a good mood or in the mood for a sweet fragrance.
Unfortunately, it doesn't last very long, or maybe that's a good thing....

~ Inspiration ~
I was drawn to the special hexagonal shape of the bottle, but I'm still a bit confused about how many "Flora" variants there are...
The commercial honestly scares me a little :/

~ Bottle ~
A real gem! The shape stands out from other bottles and, with the thin black ribbon and the curved script, it looks elegant and feminine.

~ Fragrance ~
Upon spraying, I perceive a very light citrus and mandarin note, which, however, fades after a few seconds, making way for a lush bouquet of peonies and roses. It exudes a sweet-floral and slightly powdery scent. With osmanthus flowers, a hint of pink pepper, patchouli, and sandalwood, it softly concludes in the base.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 5 hours (not much longer on clothing and hair). If I spray too much, it becomes too dry, synthetic, and scratchy in my throat.

~ Occasion ~
It fits well into the mild days of spring, summer, and autumn. Also suitable as a subtle office scent.

~ Conclusion ~
The slightly earthy-spicy osmanthus note bothers me, making it too unsweet for my taste.

I can’t enter a department store without visiting the perfume section. I’m probably not alone in this forum ... So, yesterday it was that time again, I specifically set out to try “Flora” by Gucci.
Upon spraying, the very lemony top note stands out, soon to be accompanied by a floral-woody note - no, not replaced, but rather complemented. The scent remains consistent throughout. DeGe53 was looking for the sandalwood, and I’ve found it ;-) I think the sandalwood is very present from the heart note onwards. At the very end, and only on the sidelines, the patchouli tries to make its presence known.
Overall, I don’t dislike “Flora,” but it won’t make it into my collection. Too bad, the bottle is exceptionally pretty.

I received the fragrance as a gift, was excited and sprayed and sprayed - but I can't smell anything, almost nothing. When I press my nose to the spot where I sprayed, I can smell a tiny bit, but that has never happened to me with a perfume before. In the end, I gave the bottle to my mother, who thought it was great, well, if she thinks so. I can't even describe this scent because I really smell hardly anything; what I do smell is a little floral, but that fades away after a few seconds.

smells old and musty somehow.
you can clearly smell citrus and patchouli.
and well...I think this scent is okay for older people...

When I smelled the fragrance about 4 months ago, I thought it was amazing.
Now, after the birth of my daughter, I just wonder what I was thinking. The scent is certainly not bad. But I can no longer perceive it after 1 hour of spraying. The fragrance reminds me a lot of Kiton Donna. It is much sweeter and doesn't last as long.

but for Gucci, a scent that is far too weak. You have to hurry to catch a whiff of the pleasant floral fragrance or quickly reapply.
oh, it's just a shame about the beautiful patchouli and peony

The scent was sprayed on me today at Karstadt!!! (Permission granted) The opening is very nice, fresh, light, powdery-floral. But that’s about it. It doesn’t last, has no depth. Not even sufficient for summer. I’m a bit disappointed, not even my beloved sandalwood comes through.

The title here is that which instantly springeth to mind @ first intraspiration: it's like when one is out on a country walk, & there's just been rain; and the path has become overgrown, so one flails @ the obstructing herbeage with one's walking-stick (the law proscribes the carrying of machètée in England!). Sometimes when one does this, the blast of broken-stem aroma is overwhelming; & this 'fume is a bit like that. It does settle down though, with the ancilliary muskinesses & ambrinesses phasing in really quite seamlessly - by which I mean, not merely displacing the intense fougère-ity, but kind of softening & blunting the °thorns° in suchwise as that they do not °tear° @ one so much.

After a stuffy hot day, I now throw open all the windows and doors at night - boldly even the front door.

I need the cool night air - no matter who now strolls in unhindered.

I enjoy the draft that sweeps through all the rooms, blowing away the fatigue of the day.
Why am I not as awake in the morning as I am at night?

And Bloom Acqua di Fiori helps me with my wakefulness.

This fragrance greets me with a fresh green, like my garden after the long-awaited downpour.
The lawn now lies lush and gleaming in the moonlight, having soaked up the rain.
Light spots from my lanterns dance over it, seeming to move the flowers and bushes.
Jasmine and tuberose breathe a sigh of relief, for the day was hot.
They also welcome the damp coolness.
Sandalwood embraces the vegetation against my skin, and the moonlight gives it an emerald tone.

I have hope for a good new day.

review_title: What one has too much of, the other has too little
review_content: Gucci Bloom caught my eye when I was looking for a feminine-floral-not-sweet-adult fragrance: Because of its beautiful packaging! Unfortunately, the tuberose also caught me - in the nose - and thus the scent was immediately off my list. I was eagerly awaiting Bloom Acqua di Fiori - the fragrance pyramid promised something like a Bloom light. And this promise is indeed kept by the scent. Jasmine and tuberose are still in the lead role, but softened by a little fruit, a little resin, a little wood. And therein lies my problem: Yes, I know, you will say that you really can't please everyone, and that might be true. But Acqua di Fiori just feels a bit arbitrary. I still find the scent pleasant, but I seriously doubt that I would recognize it if a lady in my vicinity were wearing it. Additionally, the top note smells a bit synthetic to my nose. However, I can very well imagine that Bloom Acqua di Fiori will find a fan base - perhaps also among younger ladies and girls - especially in summer. I will certainly enjoy using the sample during my summer vacation, but the scent will not make it onto my wish list. Have fun testing it yourself!

When Gucci Bloom came out and I sniffed it, I found it quite nice, but since I don't wear such heavily floral and powdery scents at all, I didn't know what to expect from this one.
But to my surprise, this one was so completely different.
It was as if I were smelling the stems of the flowers from Bloom.
Then I had an idea:
I sprayed the Aqua on and followed it with a regular Bloom. The result was very interesting.
That's when I started experimenting.
Since my nose likes citrus scents, I added some D&G Light Blue to the Gucci fragrance. A very cool variation. I was often told that I smelled very summery and fresh without being too overpowering. Which is really cool with the lemon from DG, to tone it down a bit.
I really enjoy experimenting, this way I also finish a few perfumes faster :P

Conclusion about the scent:
Doesn't last forever. I wouldn't wear it alone. In combination, very nice!

Bloom Acqua di Fiori is somehow "scratchy"-floral for me, while being airy and also a bit soapy. I couldn't really name a single fragrance note. The sillage is in the lower mid-range. This makes the scent suitable for everyday wear, fitting for any occasion in spring and summer. After about three and a half hours, the base notes slowly start to come into play, making the fragrance a bit rounder, softer, but the scratchiness of the opening doesn't completely fade away. And that's what ultimately makes me dislike the fragrance overall. After about 7 ½ hours, "Bloom Acqua di Fiori" then fades away for me.

I thank Skripka22 for the opportunity to test this.

Another one of those Gucci fragrances that could split opinions. Gucci Bloom and its fragrance offspring live up to their name and were all too floral, too sweet, or both for me - well made, but just not quite my style. Acqua di Fiori, however, is a bit different and just my thing. The opening begins with stepping into a flower shop. If I'm not mistaken, someone has already...
