Floral, green, almost not powdery and absolutely no sweetness: The scent has unexpected unisex qualities, for me it is a solid everyday companion. For the man who likes to smell freshly showered. It can also be layered very well with simple citrus perfumes, smells great with Eau de Gaga (unfortunately hardly available on the market anymore).

For me, the most beautiful from the entire Gucci Bloom range.
Every year, when spring arrives, I am always on the lookout in my collection for a really beautiful spring fragrance that is light, floral, but not too sweet. Every year I ponder which scent I could choose and whether I need a new one now. And every year I rediscover it among the many perfumes and think: oh no. I had you last year. And every year, after the first spray, I realize again: no, you stay with me. You are my spring messenger.

The scent is floral, fresh, and a little powdery, but not sweet at all. Just as one imagines the delicate scents in March and April. Before the concentrated sweetness hits you in May.

This fruity floral (more floral than fruity) is in my opinion just as classy and chic smelling as the bottle looks.

Juicy, creamy osmanthus infused with soft citric's, a strong peony note, a rose with a whiff of vanilla leading to a drydown with a hint of sandalwood to give the florals a well chosen 'earthy' vibe. This is how this elegant scent unfolds on my skin.

An all-rounder that behaves at all occasions, I can't see you going wrong wearing this. It's like a little black dress among florals, it is versatile and classy. A well blended and timeless perfume. I daresay that people who normally wouldn't like florals might find this beauty appealing.

Silage is: "a classy and beautiful floral aura with fruity moments and an apparition of sandalwood that enhances its beauty." -- Longevity is very different from person to person. On me it's a satisfying 5+ hours if applied on clothes too.

Not the cheapest scent and notoriously moody depending on chemistry, so sample on skin before purchase to avoid buying a pretty yet fleeting disappointment. Good luck! : )

Flora by Gucci has recently entered my collection. Overall, I absolutely adore it and it is definitely going to be one of my favorites. It’s probably pretty underrated and I am not sure why because to me it’s just gorgeous from the packaging to the juice inside the hexagon shaped bottle with the black bow on top. The box has stunning artwork of beautiful floral designs. I usually put the boxes away but I kept this one on my dresser. It’s joyful playful and gives me free spirited boho vibes. I do believe it’s more of a summer or spring fragrance as the projection is not very strong even for edp. I originally thought it might be more of a winter perfume, but it’s just not that heavy. It’s more of a citrusy osmanthus and I do not detect much Rose or patchouli in this. It’s a very well blended citrusy almost fruity floral, so it’s difficult to see if any notes really stand out. It’s just a very pleasant charming scent that you can hardly go wrong with purchasing blindly unless you really dislike citrusy notes that are not very strong at all. It makes me think of sun, summer and strolling somewhere in the Mediterranean. Somehow I think of my recent trip to Portugal. I love the ad, I love the bottle I love the perfume. I am charmed. It is adorable.

review_title: Not much more exciting than the EDT
review_content:
I gave Flora by Gucci a fair enough chance. I tried both the EDT and EDP versions on the skin and on a card, and yet neither excites me.

Flora EDP is just too much of something. Perhaps it's too sweet, too creamy or just too floral. Something about this composition unnerves me.

When settled on the skin, Flora EDP smells like a bar of soap. Clean and pleasant but nothing that could cause any heads to turn in your direction. Perhaps it is that inoffensive, quiet feeling that has so many people loving this fragrance.

I hate to say it, but Flora comes across as rather synthetic to my nose. If it smelt like a natural bouquet of flowers I probably wouldn't dislike this fragrance so much. That odd creaminess makes me prefer an unscented lotion over and above this fragrance, both of them creating the same feeling.

Flora is restricted to the floral category, even though it attempts to become earthy with the patchouli in the base. I managed to wear this fragrance for the duration that it lasted, which was an impressive seven or so hours. Flora EDP was unfortunately so very linear over this time, that it showed barely signs of depth or complexity.

This fragrance is very flowery, like the name already indicates. It is verg recognizable and very feminine. Loved it! It also stayed on for a long time. With only two sprays, people would still compliment my parfume at the end of the day.

review_title: Jeune fille en fleur (girl in bloom)
review_content:
This scent is a hymn to feminity : floral, fresh, but also warm and sensual.
At the opening I smell mainly the peony notes with a very light citric touch, not at all sour, then The floery heart arrives to my nose revealing the osmanthus, warm, not too intoxicating but well balanced. It could be weird but on my skin I didn't smell the rose I see in the pyramid.
The base notes, which last on my skin for a few hours, are warm and sweet (not sweetish): a not earty patchouli and a very light and pleasant sandalwood. The sillage is quite good, although I was expecting more from an eau de parfum. Anyway, a very feminin and pleasant fragrance contained in a simple but elegant bottle. The price is quite high, but I recommend it to the "girls in bloom " of all ages, expecially in springtime-summer.

"Flora" I still hear my ballet teacher saying to me. A lady with a mane of red hair, of Bulgarian origin. She gave me this nickname, and so it echoed - whenever she corrected me - "Flora" through the hall, which I really liked. About half a year later, I was watching TV with my roommate when suddenly a short film in the form of an advertisement appeared, sweeping me away into...

You spend forever thinking about which fragrance is the one, the absolute must-have that you need to buy, and then treasures like this one go completely unnoticed. And this despite the fact that Flora is one of the perfumes I have repurchased for the 3rd or 4th time and comes into play absolutely reliably every spring/summer. I thought I wasn't really into flowers, but the composition of Flora is special! An absolutely refined and addictive scent.

My husband was sniffing at my neck the whole time while shopping yesterday! ;-)

Flora is actually a calm yet unusual companion for the day. You spray sunshine directly from the bottle! I do smell flowers in the top note, but I can't name them individually, and I would have never guessed rose was behind it.

I think it's the osmanthus that captivates and takes me in, giving Flora that exotic kick! I found osmanthus extremely sexy in Paco Rabanne's Ultraviolette... with Flora, I also smell vanilla... no idea why? Maybe it's the mix of flowers, osmanthus, and the woody notes that makes it seem so seductive and vanilla-like?! Regardless, what a beautiful companion! The bottle is a feast for the eyes, a bit playful, but Flora is a little like that too... the longevity is fantastic... I could smell it on me from 7 AM until late in the evening! Unfortunately, I can't say the same about many other scents currently on the market! The sillage is in the medium range, but I don't need more; I want to enjoy the scent experience myself without annoying other people with it.

If you're looking for a new fragrance, definitely try Flora, the sunny flower goddess!

review_title: Warm Late Summer Days on a Golden Meadow
review_content:
Flora is, for me, a perfect perfume for mild summer evenings. If a sunset on a hot late summer day had a scent, it would definitely be Flora. Warm and sensual are the two adjectives that come to mind first when I spray Flora.
At first, the scent is very intense and too sweet. Fortunately, this sweetness dissipates quickly and transforms into a creamy, warm, floral fragrance. When I wear Flora, I often get told that I smell very good, which unfortunately is not the case with other fragrances I have, as they are not as long-lasting. Flora remains perceptible for 12 hours without any problems. Of course, towards the end, it becomes just a very close-to-skin scent. Only on clothing does the fragrance actually last until the next wash. Due to its long-lasting nature and the intense, yet not overpowering scent, Flora is truly perfect for going out in the summer.
Since the eye always "smells along," I want to mention the bottle, which really looks extremely decorative on the shelf.

It’s (not just) the same story with Gucci every time. A fragrance is launched, powered by advertising, sales are quite alright, and six months later, another concentration pushes its way onto the shelf. Instead of giving the fragrance time to establish itself, it is already overshadowed by the next one (Guilty) and hardly has the chance to be repurchased.

Now, I am biased in truly evaluating Flora, as I don’t like sweet fruity-floral scents. And you can’t really talk about longevity. But it was well received. Especially among young, very fashionable ladies, it found a following. The packaging, which is said to be inspired by the 2009 fashion collection, also looks appealing.

But as I said, hardly can the child walk somewhat, the sibling comes along and takes all the attention away. What a shame.....

review_title: A fragrance that deserves much more attention
review_content:
I still see my former best friend, her mother always stored her expensive perfumes in her room back then. And I see how my friend wrapped it in a thick scarf and wore it in winter. She was the goddess.

I absolutely do not like floral fragrances, but I love this one. To this day, I hardly know anyone who wears it, UNFORTUNATELY. It is so soft, so cuddly, and yet so present. An absolute feel-good fragrance for me, which carries many powdery elements.

You really have to try it, especially the ladies who are not into floral scents.

Oh Flora - you and me - that's probably not going to happen. It all started so beautifully. I still remember standing with my friends in front of the perfume shelf. It was supposed to be a new scent. Actually, everyone was just annoyed and wanted me to decide quickly. They only came out of politeness or boredom, as I was already the one with the "perfume obsession" and spent every day hanging out in perfume shops. So I had to decide quickly.

Chloé was heavily advertised, which was also quite new on the market at the time, and you. Both sprayed, both heavenly. Damn. Somehow, I found you both quite similar with my untrained nose back then, probably the rose. I deemed Chloé a tad better and quickly chose it, but you, Flora, never left my mind!

And you've been holding on for 13 years now. There are perfumes that don't last this long on the market. Unfortunately, you were never a real hit, even though you are so beautiful. Floral describes you perfectly, a bit velvety, and the sillage is fantastic. Every time I spray you in the perfume shop, I smell you on my wrist all day long. You are fresh, yet not too much, fruity, but not overwhelming. I don't perceive patchouli in you, but various flowers that I can't quite identify in their abundance. You are actually perfect.

But then came my first own apartment, and there was never enough money anyway, then other scents entered my life and well, you’re probably rolling your eyes, we all know the excuses. In 2018, I almost bought you spontaneously, but once again, I put you back on the shelf and chose another.

Now you seem to be slowly disappearing from all the stores, and you have namesakes on the market. I don't even want to call them daughters, as they have nothing in common with you. If I don't get extremely lucky and happen to grab you somewhere very spontaneously, it seems like it won't happen between us. Which is a real shame! Adieu and perhaps farewell - dear Flora.

It smells floral, as one might expect from the name.
But it doesn't smell girlishly innocent floral; rather, it has a ladylike quality.
This fragrance smells warm, elegant, and slightly sweet. A sort of adult version of the many floral scents available on the market. I own it and like it very much. It is not an everyday scent for me, as I feel it doesn’t quite emphasize ME. This fragrance is, for me personally, something for special occasions. I enjoy wearing it and feel more grown-up with it. In my eyes, it even radiates a bit of arrogance. The longevity of the scent is good. It lasts well through a workday or otherwise. I would recommend it for women who appreciate elegant fashion and prefer a classic style.

I really love this perfume. When I first smelled it, I had a very specific image in my mind:

It was a very hot summer day. At some point between the afternoon and the evening sun, there was a heavy downpour with thunder and a stormy wind. The hot weather had to release itself. After the weather calmed down, the goddess emerges. The last yellow, neon-orange, pink, violet, and bright red sunrays penetrate through the gray ceiling facade made of clouds. The air is still a bit fresh after the rain, but the sunrays of the beautiful evening sun bring back some warmth.
The air reminds one of the sea. You feel as if you are in a Mediterranean setting, where history, aesthetics, and elegance meet nature. A beautiful combination, just like the flora: warm, divine, feminine, precious, natural, but also artistic, elegant, beautiful, powerful, and yet tender, simply WOW.

Once again, I really love this perfume. I prefer to wear it during an evening stroll or dinner by the lake after it has rained. I don’t know, but in that moment, I have such a beautiful feeling, a feeling that I would love to have forever.

is the goddess of bloom, youth, and joyful enjoyment of life in Roman mythology. In allegorical representations of the four seasons, she embodies spring.

Flora by Gucci starts off fruity-sweet. Very sweet. I distinctly perceive freshly peeled mandarin, very ripe, very delicious, but after just a few minutes, the fruity aroma is overshadowed by a musty, piercing scent that reminds me of mandarin peels forgotten in a plastic bag for hours.
This note accompanies the transition to floral notes, which now begins with the heavy sweetness of osmanthus. I must admit, I have never smelled osmanthus flowers, but I associate this somewhat stuffy sweetness with them, as I know rose and peony, yet cannot perceive either of those here.
For several hours, the scent lingers, remaining sweet and cloying on my skin, still underlined by something musty-fruity.
Only in the base - I have waited a long time for this - does the sandalwood lighten the sweetness. And now, finally, the rose can contribute its fine, herb-sweet powderiness to the scent's conclusion in a soothing manner.

On my skin, the longevity is (too) good; perhaps it only seems that way because there are several aspects that bother me. The one-dimensionality in the scent development may be the reason for the somewhat synthetic impression that "Flora" leaves on me. Overall, I would wish for more genuine floral notes in a "goddess-of-flowers fragrance."

This perfume was a gift from a good friend. Flora and I have not become friends. Fortunately, the good friend is still one!

Floral, yet not too sweet.
Mature, but playful.
Seductive, without being overtly sexy.

A fragrance that is clearly a beloved all-rounder for me and, despite this quality, is eye-catching. And it’s also a compliment magnet.

review_title: not bad at all even without floral love
review_content:
I confess I am more against than for floral scents, so why am I sniffing Flora? Good question? The hype, the advertising? (which I even liked) I think it's both :D

The first time I sniffed this fragrance, I was so little put off that I had to go back to the tester shortly after :)

This floral note is at least not as intrusive and headache-inducing as so many other floral scents; perhaps it’s the pleasantly noticeable warmth of sandalwood that makes the fragrance enjoyable for me..

I wouldn’t buy it, but if someone in my environment wore the scent, it wouldn’t bother me.

Those were still bouquets from the house of Gucci, not to be compared with the "new" floral line. The nicely designed bottles don't help, even if it's a matter of taste. In the Flora Gucci 2009 bottle, I most distinctly perceive the roses in the opening, no harsh patch and a stronger honey note (Osmanthus? Actually a red flag candidate for me), which becomes subtler in the heart. DD pleasantly woody spice. 6 candidates that create a beautiful fragrance pyramid, a classic that is timelessly created.

Why is this called Envy? Should it inspire envy? Symbolize envy? Should I value envy? Sounds much more like a Calvin Klein fragrance wanna-be name, but I bought it, so who’s to say the marketing didn’t work? No. 19 is a sharp green floral, PR Metal is a flinty green floral, Alliage is a cool green floral. Envy is a sour green floral. Bitter works wonderfully in perfume, hence all the great leathers and chypres. Sour is another story entirely. Sour, as in acidic, can add balance to food, but doesn’t really have a comparable place in fragrance. It’s sort of like coffee in that respect. Bitter coffee is an ideal, sour coffee is a shame.

But the sourness here adds a bit of fruit that ties together the green and white florals and makes the whole thing soapy, if a bit cold. I wear it occasionally, and, interestingly, this is one of the few fragrances that people smell on me (a man) and comment positively on. I think sour reads to some people as a sibling tone to the popular “fresh” and “sport.”

I come back to this one occasionally, but I’ve never really grown fond of it. It is an insecticide-like floral, with references to floral notes but not the feel of bloom to it. I think it is the soapiness that makes me not write it off, but I can’t say it is an enjoyable fragrance.

Gucci ENVY edt opens propitiously with patches of lily of the valley peppering pastures of springtime grass gently swaying in the breeze. Fresh and clean, green without the mean. If I could call a halt to the trajectory of this fragrance at about the thirty-minute mark, we would be best friends.

Unfortunately, what ensues is a metamorphosis into a synthetic-smelling drydown, as though the flowers became frozen in motion through a process of plastification, and the grass suddenly hardened to artificial turf. These disturbingly sturdy components may well last for eternity--or until the wearer decides to take a vigorous bath, whichever comes first!

With such a splendid array of notes, I had high hopes for ENVY, especially when I found out that it was a floral green which I had somehow neglected for so many years. Now it becomes clear, however, that it wasn't meant to be. The reason is as plain as can be: ENVY does not like my skin or me!

I don't usually like fresh, green scents, however in this situation I really enjoyed wearing Envy.

Upon first application, Envy is very green and quite refreshing. The fruits balance themselves out nicely along with the magnolia and freesia. Thankfully pineapple is a subtle note here, because with most perfumes pineapple likes to rear its ugly head and cause me to dislike a scent.

As the fragrance settles on the skin it becomes increasingly grassy, but not sharp like Chanel No.19. Envy is tame and polite, it doesn't like to make a loud, obtrusive statement.

Envy feels very modern for its time. Its slight metallic-like quality captivates me. Although Envy is something that I probably wouldn't wear, I am very intrigued by it. Envy fascinated me from the very beginning to the very end.

The lasting strength is average, if not a little better than average. Like I mentioned before this isn't a particularly strong scent, so I'd say it is fairly intimate. A green floral that I do surprisingly recommend.

When this was released I remember falling in love immediately. Envy is fresh, floral and totally irresistible. It is the smell of summer.
The beginning is sharp. Fresh. Fruity. Lovely. Modern. It lasts for more than ten hours and I often wear it at work. It is however a scent that is not wearable by all. A dear friend of mine smells like rotten fruit and dirty clothes. She loves the fragrance, but she turns to Chanel no. 19 or Gres Cabotine instead. I have not been able to work out which note it is that conflicts with her skin but maybe I will one day.
Well done, Tom Ford, designing the bottle.
247/365

An old magazine article that I still have about the launch of Gucci Envy in 1997 mentions that Gucci Envy is "inspired by the fresh delicate scent of the wine flower never before used for a perfume". Wine flower... Maybe they mean grape flower?... Maybe they mean grape blossom?... Maybe we will never know...

“Hey Envy, old buddy! How happy I am to see you again! It's been a long time...” “Is this some kind of '20 years later' reunion or what? Over there, I see - that's the old 'Sculpture'? Hey, Sculpture! How's it going?” “Sorry, she can't hear you.” “What happened?” “She lost her head. Tipped over. I pulled her out of the bay. She wasn't as lucky as you. You...

review_title: Envy, come back soon, back home soon
review_content: Envy, never go out again, never again. I worry, worry about you. Think of tomorrow, think of me too. Envy, come back soon, back home soon. Envy, never go out again, never again. Unfortunately, Gucci has put an end to you. Wherever the sea voyage took me in life, I still remember today what I wrote to Gucci. In every port, a letter went overboard, and I always wrote:...

Thanks to the many great comments here, Envy has been positively brought back to my memory.
I owned this wonderful fragrance in the late 90s along with many other perfumes like Loulou, Joop Femme, Escada by Escada, Jádore, Poison, and also Sun was very present.
Admittedly, I can't imagine any of these scents in my collection today, and that's why I hesitated a bit about whether I would still like Envy today? because my fragrance preferences have changed significantly over time. But Envy holds special value for me, as it was my first Mother's Day gift from my now 16-year-old daughter. We mothers know what a sensitive time we go through at first... first Christmas, first Easter, and also the first Mother's Day, sigh, it's been a long time! Sorry, I'm digressing, now to the scent:
Bold, ordered, and arrived yesterday! (Allegedly the first women's fragrance from Gucci). Envy is a green floral scent, very sensual and feminine with a touch of freshness and by no means sweet. Although it is categorized here more as a spring-summer fragrance, I find it very suitable for a rainy day like today, enveloped with the first signs of spring;) There’s also nothing to complain about in terms of longevity, it lasts for hours on me.
The top notes are said to include bergamot, pineapple, as well as freesia and peach, which my nose cannot confirm. The lily of the valley dominates from beginning to end, beautifully merging in the base with moss and woody notes.
As Joe already mentioned, it also reminds me a bit of Diorissimo.
In summary: Envy, I still like you, and I am glad to have you back in my possession!

I would like to dedicate my first comment to one of my favorite fragrances that is no longer available. An old saying goes that envy makes one ugly. This is not true - at least not when one wears Envy, because this creation by Gucci comes from a time when this house stood for style and elegance with Italian flair and not for status symbols for Mr. and Mrs. Nouveau Riche.
Envy opens with a rather strong floral cloud. However, it is rather cool and bright, exuding the bouquet of hyacinths, violets, and early lily of the valley, interspersed with bitter, leafy nuances and a hint of freesias. Very soon after, the fragrance becomes softer and rounder, evolving into a green-woody veil that beautifully counteracts the scent of the lily of the valley and prevents it from becoming too sweet.
A brilliant fragrance that can be worn around the clock thanks to its subtle sillage. Compared to the discreet scents of more recent times, it still knows little restraint. In this sense, it is truly an olfactory child of the nineties.

Wearing Envy is like:

a wonderful early summer day, I am already awake quite early, everyone is still sleeping, it is completely quiet.
I roll up my pant legs and walk barefoot into the garden, running over the dew-soaked grass.
Wonderful, my toes tingle, it is sooo nice to feel the soft, cool grass.
I close my eyes and smell the leaves of the trees, absorbing their scent, the air is clear and fresh.
The sun rises, gradually the birds awaken first and then the people, it gets noisy, but that doesn’t bother me, because “my” garden is like a little oasis in the busyness that is now spreading.
I feel good, am relaxed, and look forward to breakfast and the first cup of tea with my loved ones in the house.

I have known Envy for a long time, it is a cheerful yet elegant fragrance.
I perceive the top note as citrusy, fresh, I wouldn’t associate it with magnolia.
It fades quite quickly and green notes emerge, there is also a bit of light wood in it. Overall very pleasant, subtly intertwined. The flowers are more in the background.
I find the base to be slightly powdery, warm, very subtle.
I don’t find Envy sweet overall.
A fragrance that fits well into the warm months of the year, but I wear it all year round when I crave “tingly feet”.
The longevity is good, the sillage is pleasant.

"I have always admired your style, I wanted to be as elegant as you"
"I would love to recommend my tailor to you, but unfortunately, he is dead"
Dialogue of a typical gold chain gangsta with an Italian mafioso from an action blockbuster.

I discovered Envy post mortem, the elegant Italian fashion designer Envy is unfortunately dead.
The color green fits the name more in my opinion than the scent. I absolutely do not find it green-fresh. It is somewhat soapy, but still elegant. I have never smelled such stylishly packaged lily of the valley. It is a uniquely beautiful companion and I believe many will mourn the scent.

I love this scent! It's somehow fresh, yet warm and floral!
I won it blind on eBay back then!
I thought to myself, Gucci must be good :) yep, hit!
For me, it's a classic!
At first glance, the bottle looked masculine to me and not very appealing...the yellow color of the fragrance is also not that interesting! Then I sprayed it on my skin! At first, it smelled like alcohol and somewhat fresh...and like moss... :/ well, not so thrilling...but then suddenly the flowers joined in! And bam, it was feminine! And so sexy! It smells to me like sex on a flower meadow :)
Or at least a hot date at a picnic :) where you feed each other grapes and have lily of the valley in your hair!
At least on me, it smells stunning :) I know, self-praise stinks, but in this case, it smells hot :D It's such a special scent that develops differently! It's not overly sweet and therefore a real change from my other fragrances! I think that's why it's so interesting! Many smell like synthetic plastic flowers, but real flowers???? I find it smells really natural! Just like how lily of the valley can only smell in moss! Plus, the musk makes it warm and adds the love in! A truly rounded overall package!
Unfortunately, production has been discontinued...for whatever reason?!
Luckily, I still have one in reserve :D

I don't know what that creepy advertising image with the creepy girl is supposed to mean! But the other sexy pictures capture it well! It's definitely not creepy :)))))

So for me personally, it belongs to my absolute favorite perfumes! Unfortunately, I'm afraid to use it because it's no longer being produced :-( whhhyyyyyy only

Envy was the first fragrance I fell in love with, and it introduced me to the world of perfumes a few years later - so beware, this review is full of nostalgia.

Not your typical choice for a teenager, right? Well, I received it as a gift from my mother, who actually hates it, and it immediately became my favorite scent, pushing all the woody and vanilla fragrances aside on my shelf. Ah, those high school days when Envy harmonized so well with cigarette smoke and wild trips! It is crisp, strict, and so chic that it reminds me of Kate Moss from the 90s.

For me, it is truly a masterpiece, a penetrating blend of oak moss and lily of the valley. It's a shame that it is no longer produced; I wish they would create such green floral scents again. I only have 15 ml left and can't bring myself to wear it, as I guard it like a dragon. I bought CdG Celluloid Galbanum in the hope of rediscovering the familiar scent, but it's not the same; it is green, yes, but simpler and bolder.

Today, Gucci essentially offers a profile-less uniform scent. Envy was different, unremarkable yet still special. A composition of various essences, each of which could have easily become intrusive and unpleasant, so perfectly balanced that it is a true pleasure to sniff. For me, Envy is like the dress for the best friend's wedding; you don't want to steal the spotlight, but...
I love this scent and have been searching for a worthy successor for years. Who can help me?????

...that I am writing here for the first time and specifically about Envy has no particular reason, it just brings back some not-so-nice memories for me.

I had this fragrance many years ago (in my -young-and-stupid-time - how could I have back then?) and I still remember well, it evokes a feeling in me like a lemon that you just look at and everything tightens up.
This green is simply too much for me.
Even though I haven't sniffed it in years, it is still in my nose.
Although, one should never say never, maybe I should give it another try?

when I feel like a green scent, Gucci Envy is the first one that comes to mind.
I find the top note has something of green apples, but not so dominant; there are also other green fragrance notes that I can't quite place. (Maybe fresh leaves??)

In any case, very delicious and fresh, and perfectly suitable for spring/summer.

I also prefer to spray it on my hair or clothes, as the top note lasts longer that way.

The base then goes in the direction of woods/musk; I find the longevity very good, even though it is a very light scent.

a long time ago, it was in the nineties. My colleague wore this scent, she was always perfectly styled, only designer clothes on her body. Quite cool and arrogant, the only thing I liked about her was ENVY.
At some point, long after that, I discovered Gucci Envy while browsing the internet and bought it on a whim. And there it was again, the memory of that unsympathetic colleague.

But the scent is still something very special today.... even on me. Like a warm summer meadow that you take to bed, because the longevity is insane.
I love this perfume ️

I had wanted to experience this discontinued fragrance again for so long, and thanks to a dear Parfumo, this became possible.
Finally, the moment arrived, and I applied Envy to my left wrist. Let's see, I closed my eyes in curiosity and waited to see what would happen. Would the scent be as I remembered it? Would it transport me back to the time when it was my signature scent?
I enjoyed the moment as I perceived lily of the valley, violet, and then cedar. A broad grin spread across my face as I opened my eyes. Yes, just as I remembered it!!! And then came the sobering realization… it didn't take me back in time. Strange, for so many years, this bottle was everything to me, yet it brought back no experiences.
Today, when I choose my perfumes based on mood, occasion, feelings, season, etc., it's completely different… every moment with a fragrance is a memory.
But as a very dear Parfumo said, "On your fragrance journey, you've probably passed by so many wonderful perfumes…" Yes, he is right, and that's a good thing…
It was lovely to test Envy again, but now I know that for me, I don't need a signature scent, but rather a fragrance journey filled with many wonderful memories.

I associate Gucci Envy with the image of an elegant spring pattern in pastel shades, inspired by harmonious scent notes, it feels like a gust of wind bringing spring, a green floral accord characterized by lily of the valley and hyacinth, and has a metallic quality.
This unique fragrance was released in 1997, and the gifted perfumer is Maurice Roucel. He created Envy in a way that gives me vibes of modern architecture while avoiding floral ornaments and simplifying the form, which is also reflected in the sleek chic bottle. Roucel's composition starts with the transparency of green flowers and a high green note, accentuated by the saltiness of metal. The composition is radiantly clean, clear, elegant, and confidently feminine with a high recognition factor! Oh yes, Gucci Envy is practically always on my wish list; of course, I am aware that production has unfortunately been discontinued. I have been wondering for years why this successful and sought-after formula hasn’t simply been revived… Maybe someone among you knows the background to this… Envy remains one of the best compositions for me in the 'green floral freshie' category!

review_title: I like it terribly, but unfortunately it gives me headaches :o(
review_content:
I really like this Gucci Envy, even though I'm not much of a citrus fan when it comes to perfume. Unfortunately, it always gives me terrible headaches. I have no idea why. So far (thankfully) this is the only EDT perfume that has done this to me. It's a great scent, and I can't wear it... I bought it many years ago and have tried it again and again, but unfortunately, it's always the same. That's why I sold my opened old version of 100 ml on eBay. But I still have two smaller versions of 30 ml that are not quite as old. I don't know if Gucci Envy has changed anything about it at some point, but I'm not brave enough to open one of them yet. The two will definitely stay stored safely in the cupboard for now... Maybe the headache will go away someday?

If it weren't for that, this EDT is simply brilliant. But something in it just doesn't work for me, which I deeply regret...

Otherwise, it's a super beautiful, fresh, and pleasant scent; it has also lasted a very long time on me.
What wasn't so good for me at the end of the day...
But I haven't given up hope of possibly being able to use it one day...

I cannot agree that it qualifies as a unisex fragrance.
I would describe it as a subtle, pleasant, and unobtrusive scent.
Ideal for everyday use, I think!

super perfume that you can wear every day!
it is very fresh, clean but still interesting enough.
i think it could even pass as a unisex scent.

review_title: You're not really to blame, but that's okay
review_content:
In 1980, Barbara Streisand and Barry Gibb breathed into each other on disco music... somehow this scent reminds me a lot of that duet... Nice, catchy, and yet somehow mainstream - but with a certain old-fashioned basic trash factor.

With that name, you expect a knockout, but instead, a nice breeze comes along. Besides the massive misnaming, I find it okay. I smell bergamot stronger than pink pepper - I don't know mandora - in the top notes. According to my research, mandora is a rum - which fits, as it has a slightly alcoholic opening. Then in the heart notes, an illustrious round of popular floral notes comes around the corner. This time it's the powdery violet-pink floral gang that can cause headaches for some. I like the notes because they are harmless. Amber and patchouli finish it off. This makes it a bit creamier.

The scent is a solid everyday fragrance on me. Okay, nice, but nothing that hits you over the head with a fragrance club. But that's okay, as it falls into my range of "I work here" scents. A solid fragrance for people who don't want to exude great dominance and want something different from white flowers. Because I think that has its charm too - a bit old-fashioned, but quite charming. Somehow like Lana del Rey in a velvet jumpsuit with a Marge Simpson hairstyle. I like that because it's somehow not very sexy, a bit old-fashioned, and yet somehow original. Just like the girls in class who didn't belong to the clean girls' gang and never wanted to make a career. And that's what I like about this fragrance - because somehow this whole anti-pure and at the same time completely banal in its modernity makes the scent cool: Just like listening to old Bee Gees records, teasing your hair, and wearing velvet clothes.

A friend of mine wore the original Gucci Guilty while we were on vacation together in 2014. Pleasant scent, at least that’s what I remember, nothing special, fresh, designer fragrance, beautiful bottle.

In April of this year, I received a sample of "Guilty pour Femme" and was quite taken with it.
At that time, I wore it for several days at home and felt completely comfortable with it.
I can’t remember the details of the original, but this one felt floral, fresh, old-school, feminine.
At first slightly sharp and cloying, it develops into a true all-rounder. Not a really old-fashioned, "madam-like" perfume but very floral-sweet in a powdery direction. Very nice to wear for women 30 and older.

Last week, I came across the sample of "Guilty pour Femme" again and wore it for a few days at work and over the weekend at the hairdresser’s. Compliments were pouring in.
And what could be better with a fragrance?
I own many perfumes that I love to wear - and yet I never get a reaction from those around me about the scent. No "What are you wearing?" or "That smells so good...."
"Guilty pour Femme" has elicited true praise in no time at all. Colleagues, hairdresser, hairdresser clients.
I had applied the fragrance heavily - 4/5 sprays.

"Guilty pour Femme" definitely makes it onto my wish list; soon, around late summer/fall, the lavish golden bottle will be sitting on my dresser.
My summer perfumes this year were "Jardin sur le Nil" (super fresh-green) and my summer favorite "Narciso Rodriguez - NARCISO Ambrée" (warm, sensual, late summer). Both are great perfumes. But it’s slowly time for a little change.
And "Guilty pour Femme" is perfectly suited for that, a solid, classic-feminine scent.
Universally applicable. Now in summer and also in cooler temperatures.

When it comes to compliments, there is definitely no acquittal.

I wish you a lovely transition from summer to fall, stay healthy and optimistic!

Complete coincidence that this one got to move in with me - I had already tested the EdT back then and, due to the penetrating vanilla in the base (I hate vanilla), it was banished to the NoNo list. Well, then I got a sample as a bonus and since everything deserves a second chance, the perfume was applied - Surprise! Another one of those candidates where the EdP and EdT noticeably differ, and one should definitely try both. Nomade EAU DE TOILETTE was also such a case (here, however, the EdT is more my style than the perfume).

I tend to find that fragrances become very sweet on my skin (so vanilla on top is a no-go), but at the same time, I really like these white/pink, powdery, slightly floral scents that remind me of luxurious body lotions. It's always a balancing act, as you don't want to smell like grandma's powder box. The balance is found here; at my delicate 40 years, I find it "age appropriate" - for a 20-year-old, I would probably find it a bit outdated.
Lana del Rey (quickly googled, born in '85, okay fits my 30+ assessment) as the face of the campaign is a good choice, feminine, a bit retro, sexy without being cheap - I just say eyeliner and an updo. I also somehow think of the series Mad Men.

Aside from that, whoever came up with this incredibly STUPID name - the bottle is chic and fits the fragrance direction. Guilty... why guilty? Why? For smelling good?

Speaking of smelling, the citrus top note is non-existent for me; if anything, there's a hint of pepper that adds a bit of spice to the following floral potpourri. The flowers, especially lilac/rose, remain softly creamy, no sweet scent bombs. I would have blindly guessed musk in the base, but officially, there isn't any, oh well. Altogether, very harmonious and elegant.
For the office, for me (!) it's almost a touch too sexy/feminine, as I'm not really that type, but in the evening/date, it's an ideal candidate.

Longevity is very good; regarding sillage, I'm still cautious, as I always use such creamy scents very sparingly at first, so they don't annoy me. I would rate it at least normal to initially strong. In high summer temperatures, it would definitely be too much for me, but below 20°C, it works great.

I have been using Gucci Guilty for a while and I am somewhat torn. I perceive it as a kind of fresh but also powdery scent. Somehow old but still new.. A fragrance that I don't smell often, which I really like. I can remember the original version, it was a bomb. This one is a bit lighter and more modern, but you can still clearly recognize the original version in the scent. The fragrance stands out but not negatively. I have actually been asked what I am wearing and I often receive compliments for my scent. What could be nicer than that with a fragrance ;)

I belong to the people who rarely buy a perfume more than once. Simply because I hardly ever finish my bottles. Usually, the next scent is already waiting, and the old one fades into the background...
I have repurchased Gucci Guilty EdP. More than once.

It is the scent I keep coming back to. There is nothing about this fragrance that bothers me; it is floral-creamy, and I always associate it with a confident, modern, and well-groomed woman. It is neither gourmand nor "foodie" or overly sweet. Perhaps that is why it is currently not in trend. For me, that’s an advantage, as I don’t smell it on every street corner. :)

Guilty EdP smells "grown-up" but not outdated. And it lasts FOREVER. In my hair and on clothing, I can still smell the fragrance clearly after 12 hours.

review_title: Is Pour Femme As Good as Pour Homme? Watch My Review
review_content: I was very excited to learn of this Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Femme launch and to learn it was created by the same team of Alessandro Michele and Alberto Morillas for Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Homme. Sure enough, it doesn't disappoint. Is it as good as Gucci Guilty Pour Homme? Please watch my youtube review to find out. Thank you in advance.

After the men's version of "Guilty Absolute" positively surprised and even dazzled me with its dirtiness and uniqueness, I always kept this dark pink women's version in the back of my mind. I was too curious whether it would work just as well for me (or the lady by my side). This week, the raspberry projectile was then on the testing ground, meaning: on my body, and I can finally share my impressions here.

"Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Femme" (the perfume names keep getting longer) reminds me of a slightly shadowy and more voluminous version of one of my favorite women's fragrances: Lalique's "Amethyst." And that is basically the answer to the question I posed to myself above: yes, the women's version is also really good. Even if it might not immediately find its way into my collection, I can only give it a thumbs up, recommend it (at least as a test), and praise it. Its appearance matches the scent; woody, strong, almost slightly earthy berries are rather rare in women's fragrances, and with this perfume, a woman (or perhaps even a man) can only shine and stand out. The roses may come from the lab, but they are just as juicy and sultry as the forest berries, synthetic done right, everything feels really rounded and mature. As if the current women's mainstream taste has been stripped of most of its sweetness and turned through the chypre wolf. Magnificent! If only Gucci could always operate at this level. This is great women's tennis. Nuff said.

Bottle: I really, really, really like the matching color.
Sillage: measured over the entire duration, not overwhelming or potent at all. Very wearable, as long as you don't get stuck with your finger on the sprayer.
Longevity: lasts and lasts and lasts... 9 hours at the worst.

Conclusion: for me, almost as good as the masculine version. Berry-blooming bosom friend. La Bomba with taste.

This is how (and will likely be) the beloved partner would like to smell.
I have really spent a long time sniffing through numerous women's fragrances, and aside from L'Instant Magic, there hasn't been much that truly blew me away.
This fragrance, however, was a complete surprise. The contrasts in scents have already been clearly demonstrated to us by Aventus. What was once the smoky birch in contrast to the fruity pineapple in the black rider - emphasis on was - is now the blackberry that increasingly gets "wrapped" by the rose and patchouli. Unlike many designers, there is a noticeable scent progression, just as one would wish.
Give this fragrance a chance; no man can stand those countless sweet-floral women’s perfumes anymore. With this scent DNA, you also have a unique selling point.

Beautiful, enchanting blackberry scent, with a lot of juicy-fruity, dominant, unsweet blackberry, a bit of rose, needle-like woods, and earthy, bitter patchouli.
It actually reminds me a little bit of the old Gucci No 3 in the dry down, probably due to the needle-woody, coniferous aspect with the patch.
This one is quite special. You have to love blackberries, as they are extremely present the whole time, and despite the fruit, it is not a sweet scent, despite the amber, but rather fruity-bitter.
It also slightly reminds me of the N. Rodriguez EdT.
I now have a Gucci in the house again after 20 years.

Well, I quite like this unsweetened chypre fruit. The blackberry sets the tone at first, shining in full glory without a trace of sweetness. I really like that, as I generally enjoy berry notes, but many fragrances with berry notes are too sweet for me.
Guilty Absolute does it differently.
To be honest, I can hardly perceive the rose. When it is present, it is really only very subtle, with the blackberry supporting it, not dominating.
I did not expect the drydown at all at first: it becomes woody, bitter, very mature. "Monarda" as a note unfortunately means nothing to me, so I can't identify it. Sometimes when I sniff, I also catch a bit of "mossy" in my nose, almost like oak moss. It smells fine, and I got used to it quickly. Patchouli and amber do not stand out much, rather patchouli.

An interesting unsweetened, mature, bitter, "cold" scent that I can well imagine for autumn.
Definitely worth a test and a nice change from otherwise warm, sweet fragrances.

By the way, I do not find Guilty Absolute comparable to Lalique Amethyst at all.
The Amethyst remains very flat on my skin, smelling only of sour berries the whole time and really does not develop at all.
I find the Gucci much more successful and interesting.

Yesterday there was a large crowd at the Ruhrpark shopping center. I am generally averse to crowds - especially now with the masked individuals. Somehow the ubiquitous masks create a sense of uniformity - and you can't catch a soothing smile as you pass by. So I took refuge in the Douglas store and reached for the blackberry-colored bottle. And lo and behold - I am...

Some of you might be surprised now: powdery? Yes, exactly. And even creamy. I find that strange too. And when I read the previous short reviews here: my scent perception on my skin hardly matches - not sharp, not overly fruity, or anything like that. I sprayed it on and later, while looking at parfumo, I wondered: If this is really the one I have on, then it is delicious and...

review_title: Designer perfume that smells like niche
review_content:
Love it! Totally unisex (my boyfriend wears it also). Realistic smell of blackberries and cypress. Good especially for summer and spring but interesting to wear around the winter holidays, since it has something reminiscent of Christmas.
Very different from the rest of designer perfumes.

I had to test this fragrance several times before I could categorize it for myself.
What I found unpleasant and almost overwhelming the first two times, the powerful strong blackberry, developed into a more pleasant scent journey from test to test.
The fragrance is dominated the whole time by a slightly scratchy, dry blackberry, without any sweetness. Quite soon, I can perceive the Bulgarian rose, which remains subtle in the background and softens the dry, hefty berry a bit.
Gradually, earthy and warm tones develop. I also sense a slightly resinous, smoky note.
They add more depth.
Amber and patchouli take a bit longer to make their presence known. They are never intrusive here and make the overall impression warmer.
This fragrance really needs to grow. Just like the scratchy tendrils of the blackberry in the garden that wrap around everything, this fragrance also wants to grow on its wearer.
Applied in the morning, I can still perceive Guilty Absolute intensely in the evening.

review_title: Giulty Absolute pour femme, frugal comment
review_content:
I was very curious about this fragrance
last night I was at Douglas and sprayed it on my forearm;
it felt immediately familiar, but I couldn't quite place it,
I sprayed again and kept sniffing, over and over
I don't perceive the scent, or rather the top note, as very sweet, a bit sweet
once the sweetness faded, I realized it strongly reminds me of Aventus for her.

review_title: I Collect Berries in the Conifer Forest
review_content: Guilty Absolute really surprised me, and in a positive way. Dark red, tart berries paired with a slight floral note, the ethereal scent of cypress needles, and subtle earthiness - that's how I would describe the fragrance. Initially, it reminds me a bit of Amethyst by Lalique, which I also like very much. Guilty Absolute is rather unsweetened, which I find totally great. Nothing against sweet fragrances, but they are often too overpowering and quickly become too much for me. GA stands out from the mainstream designer fragrance monotony, if I may say so. In terms of scent character, I believe it could also pass as a niche fragrance. It also undergoes a beautiful development. I always enjoy fragrances that I can connect with nature. And scents that remind me of the forest have always captivated me. They just shouldn't be too earthy, and this one isn't. The dark berry notes remain well perceivable until the end and are enveloped by the fragrant base notes. Neither the patchouli nor the amber accord are dominant or annoying. All the fragrance notes are harmoniously coordinated for my nose. Guilty Absolute has a rather cool, damp character for me. When I imagine "my" forest with this fragrance, it is an autumn forest in the early morning, where the botany is covered with hoarfrost and a light mist hangs in the air. I wouldn't exactly describe GA as particularly pleasing or mass-appealing. It has a distinct character. So if you're considering a purchase, definitely test it first.

Red fruits, mixed with beautiful rose and patchouli.
I notice a pepper note that runs through all the layers.

I like it. Guilty Absolute feels well thought out and has depth. It brings both pleasant weight and warmth.
Perfect for autumn and winter.

The fragrance has good longevity and the sillage is strong. It's too special and too loud for daily wear, but I enjoy wearing it for dinner or special occasions.

I can't describe it any other way. It has a distinctly medicinal smell mixed with an artificial cherry/berry note. Unfortunately, for me, it was a blind buy gone wrong. On my skin, not much changes; the cough syrup scent remains. Unfortunately, it doesn't suit my skin.

review_title: Blackberry with the Gucci Guilty DNA
review_content: Smells very earthy at first, takes some time to develop, no love at first sniff, but once it settles, the earthy note disappears and the classic Guilty DNA emerges paired with a heavy fruit. Sillage and longevity are very good for me. More of an evening scent for autumn/winter.

review_title: Terrible... Unfortunately, I can't think of another word...
review_content:
I tested this perfume and it literally made me feel nauseous...

What I associate with this scent is a fine whiff of alcohol... Not just any alcohol, but exactly how it smells in a bedroom where someone has slept off their drunken night... Uff, I've rarely smelled something so bad...

...I really wanted to like this fragrance... The notes sounded very interesting on paper: blackberry, rose, warm woods... but on my skin, it unfolded completely differently than expected. Instead of fruity freshness and floral elegance and depth, I mainly perceive a very woody, dull note that strikes me as unpleasantly musty and reminds me of a damp room. The promised blackberries or floral component are hardly recognizable. Everything gets lost in this dark, almost dusty accord. I miss the lightness; instead, I perceive a heavy, oppressive scent profile that I personally find unpleasant. Of course, it's a matter of chemistry and taste. I can understand that some find this fragrance exciting and interesting. However, I prefer to keep my distance from it....

Aaaaw, this is so awfully cheap and uncreative. Calone notes, melonal (the fruity stuff) on a plummy-milky ketones accord, a polished citral note, spices (notably cinnamon) and a sad, thin, dry, rubbery leathery note. I did the effort of picking up some notes but basically it’s just a metallic, plain and dull fragrance which smells of pure office-safe “nothingness”. Exuding bespoke elegance like a pair or supermarket socks. Bring bang Tom Ford!

4/10

My wife recently said that now that I'm approaching my mid-40s, I can no longer walk around like a slob. So, I moved the suits I had previously called my "sacks" into (temporary - who knows how my figure will develop...) retirement in the attic and bought myself two new suits. It was an unexpected experience: a sale at the outlet of a high-end Italian manufacturer. Row upon row of suits hang on the rack. I try one on, and everything fits like it was tailor-made. The price: still in sight of the 08/15 men's outfitter's house brand, including the alterations that are undoubtedly required there.

And the moral of the story? "Made to Measure" is not for me!

I hope my little story could give some encouragement to those struggling with suits and perhaps even entertain a bit. I can hardly contribute more at this point. A longer comment doesn't really fit with the scent development, which is practically over after two hours. The only thing to add is that I also perceive something peppery in the opening. Furthermore, the description of the top note is missing "absolute from a fallen asleep foot".

Speaking of "Made to Measure" vs. "off the rack": Gucci shouldn't give up hope just yet. Somewhere out there, there might be the guy for whom MtM fits like a glove. In the meantime, I'm doing the same. Fitting, I mean.

So, that's enough for now. Wishing everyone a lovely evening!

I really don't understand why this fragrance is received so poorly here while it is referred to as a "hidden gem" in the English-speaking world.
And I also think that Made to Measure is a little hidden gem. It smells very understated and modern, yet sweet and seductive in its heart note, which is probably due to the berry and plum notes.
The opening is somewhat peppery and fresh at the same time. The performance is also not nearly as bad as everyone claims. Here, they talk about a maximum of 1-2 hours, while the fragrance lasts around 6 hours on me.
So, anyone looking for an elegant, fresh-sweet fragrance that is very understated yet still very present has a true hidden gem with Gucci Made to Measure. Since the price has also dropped significantly, it makes this fragrance even more attractive.

I don't even know where to start!
Yes, on one hand, I had a tiny bit of hope for the latest fragrance from Gucci. It can't be that they only bottle and sell junk now.

Yes, the new bottle really looks elegant and sets high expectations. Moreover, Gucci positions "Made to Measure" as oriental spicy, which sounds absolutely promising.

But what is boldly marketed as a custom creation turns out to be nothing but absolutely cheap junk off the rack. Well, the first few seconds you could still tolerate it as somewhat fruity fresh. At least it smells a bit like lemon and mandarin along with some slightly sour notes.
But hardly has it been sprayed on the skin when the whole halfway decent impression vanishes like a suit made of tissue paper in a rainstorm. Even if you were to stand there naked afterward, it would still be better and more stylish than smelling like this synthetic sweaty sludge, even though it's so weak that you wonder why you would even bother to perfume yourself for so much money?
The drydown, if one can even speak of that, turns out to be dull and sour, and upon closer inspection, it reminds me of kidneys with sauce that my mother used to cook. On the plate, quite tasty; on the wrist, definitely strange.

For me, Gucci has reached the low point of a low point with this thin little water. "Made to Measure" is actually a case for consumer protection, as the overpromised bottle misleads buyers, and I can imagine that this patched-up synthetic material is only purchased by insecure gift buyers or pain-free fashion victims or blinded Gucci fetishists. Anyone who wants to be fooled by a misguided corporation can go ahead and buy it. For everyone else, I can only hope that they can distinguish a good tailor from a rip-off money-making scheme.

So, I'll kick things off with Gucci's new release Made to Measure. Right off the bat: the term NEW release doesn’t quite fit, but more on that later. I was as excited as a kid in a candy store for the new Gucci fragrance. I quite like Gucci's current "contemporary" philosophy, which is why I don't find the newer scents as bad as many others do, although it must be said that they certainly don't come close to the old heavyweights. But I think Frida Giannini is a really cool, laid-back chief designer, or as we say nowadays, "Creative Director".

So, let's get started. Let's begin with what we’ve known for a little while now, the bottle. The image of the vessel with the measuring water has been admired on Parfumo for a few months. Admittedly, it is absolutely presentable, but upon closer inspection, it is cobbled together from old Gucci components. The bottle itself is the same as the one used for Gucci by Gucci Pour Homme and the Sport version. The sprayer is just as tiny and powerless. You really have to press down with your finger until you realize you've sprayed something. The color is from Gucci Pour Homme II and is not necessarily ugly; on the contrary: I think it would beautifully adorn my fragrance shelf, but whether it will actually do so in reality is still questionable, as I need to convince my nose, which has already given its OK with its eyes. The lettering is from the women's fragrance Première. This thin, jagged Gucci lettering is not entirely original here either. So, visually, they've almost rummaged through the entire bottle world of Gucci, but the result is convincing. I think Gucci bottles are among the most beautiful out there.

Made to Measure comes from Gucci's fashion past, just like Première. Both are fashion lines, and both fragrances are meant to form a pair together, not in the sense that one says Pour Homme and the other Pour Femme, but rather in a more subtle way, through the fashion lines. (I don't know if it's Prèt-à-porter or Haute-Couture.)

So, what does the nose say about the whole affair? Essentially, the olfactory experience continues where the visual one left off. Even in the scent, you can identify some references to the familiar, partly genuinely Gucci, partly borrowed from elsewhere. The fragrance starts off citrusy. That’s the entrance, and what safe stepping stone has been chosen? Right, the top note of Guilty. Not quite 1 to 1, but a bit brighter, because in Guilty, the top, heart, and base notes are quickly shoved together, and I identify the amber as a scent note, adhering to Gucci's own fragrance pyramid and not the one from Parfumo here. Well, so bergamot, orange blossom, lavender. Lavender is just not really dominant here, rather, unfortunately, it’s the not scratchy (in a positive sense) rough bergamot and the orange blossom. The top note lasts longer than in Guilty, but then the amber occasionally makes an appearance. The scent development here is more prolonged than in Guilty, where it’s immediately overwhelming. Even though the amber is in the base note here, it’s the amber that brings the first light nuances. So we are currently at bergamot, orange blossom, and amber. I couldn't detect the water lily, sorry, my nose really gave it its all, but when it comes to the water lily, it was also at a loss and let its (nose) wings droop. The juniper berry, or something herbal, is not really differentiated; the juniper berry isn’t offered that distinctly, but it replaces the bergamot so that the whole affair doesn’t drift off and remains stable. Additionally, there’s nutmeg, and suddenly my Richer got totally excited. Here, MRE (in my Richer's opinion) was borrowed from some Boss ball. Immediately, my Richer drags me to the nearest Karstadt and sniffs at the gray-orange Boss Motion. And lo and behold, cinnamon and nutmeg are also in play here. The spicy-fruity aspect could come from Boss Motion. It seems to me that there’s a trend of reviving old classics that aren’t worn as often anymore, and you don’t really know what they were, to be reused as something that is incorporated into something new yet doesn’t appear entirely unfamiliar. This is also the case with Armani Code Ultimate. Armani Code + Armani Mania (I’m not straying from this theory of mine :)
In the base, there’s not really much going on anymore. Upon arriving at Boss, the fragrance slowly fades. It has become a bit heavier, which is a plus, although truly weighty is something else. So can we sniff out leather? Well, maybe just a hint, very subtle. Gucci Première? Luckily, I know patchouli differently; essentially, it just continues spicy-herbally, becoming less differentiated and less definable, and then it’s over. Longevity of the whole thing? On the skin, maybe 5-6 hours; the scent strip holds up well for me, but in the end, only something undifferentiated can be perceived.

So longevity is maybe 5 out of 10 points (Okay, with a bit of goodwill)
and projection is unfortunately only about 3 out of 10 points, truly not a sillage monster, and all of this with maybe 15 sprays.
The price is still cheeky; I believe they wanted 49 euros for the 30 ml travel spray. Well, if you have it, I’d rather save up for my Keiko Mecheri.

My theory is that this is meant to be the men's Christmas motor fragrance for Gucci; I can imagine it as an autumn scent and as a Christmas gift for hobby noses, it’s definitely okay.

All in all: A fragrance that wants to make something new from the old, without reinventing the wheel but merely shifting familiar parameters around.

review_title: Not love at first sight, but surprisingly good!
review_content: I might be the first and only one here who ultimately bought the fragrance after multiple tests and actually likes it. But if that's the case, then so be it. Here’s my short review: Made to Measure is a fragrance that, despite a certain complexity, really has no major rough edges. Compared to my other preferred scents, it is much softer and somewhat sweet, as the...

Should I start with the good old days when I was olfactorily shaped and could still blindly reach for any new Gucci fragrance, confident that I would like it, that it would suit me, and that it would, to a certain extent, set a trend and be recognizable? No, better not ... Instead, I’d rather tell you about my two pairs of shoes that I had made for myself by an old...

review_title: At Tom Ford, toenails curl up...
review_content:
... when he sees how Gucci continues to drive itself into the abyss while cheerfully smiling and thinking they are doing many things right. They should just take a look on the internet and realize that their recent men's fragrances have been absolutely meager and at times pathetic. Made to Measure crowns it all, in my opinion. Here we are left with a lukewarm all-rounder with a fancy bottle. Not even lukewarm, this scent has nothing at all that could justify a purchase or convince testers. I hope this thing stays like lead on the shelves!

It starts citrusy and grayer than the famous mouse. Bergamot and maybe a bit of lavender. But more like an indefinable brew. Where the ingredients come from is a joke and I don't care. Your brew is lousy, Gucci. It doesn't matter whether you compare it to Axe deodorants or Creed perfumes. With a slightly cinnamon fruity touch and ending in the cheapest, light leather with an amber accompaniment. So incredibly pale, as if the perfume had a disease and was inhibited. Have I already mentioned that all of this is indefinable and mushy slush that has been smelled a thousand times cheaper in some form or another?

The bottle is great and sturdy and elegant. But unfortunately cobbled together. The sillage is that of a 3-year-old couch set and longevity under 5 hours. Do I need to say more?

I would trade 1 ml of PH or, for example, also from Envy or Rush for 100 ml of this watery stuff at any time. If given to me... I would directly re-gift it or sell it. Gucci - WAKE UP!

I cannot understand the very weak reviews of this fragrance.
It presents itself surprisingly well to me.
It opens with a sweet, but not overwhelming, bergamot-orange bouquet, then transitions to nutmeg, stirred with a broken juniper twig and oriental plum(!) in cinnamon, and closes hours later as a comforting scent with patchouli, amber, and labdanum. I also know the latter Chypre-honey note from the wonderful Eau de Guerlain.
Well, Gucci Made to Measure is not loud and intrusive, but neither am I.
It is a reserved charming gentleman, without ever appearing boring.
And I don’t find any cheap mainstream aqua notes in this fragrance, especially since I hate those.
The shower gel and the cream aftershave are also very pleasant and help me start the day well.

…and we are supposed to be dazzled by it - by the name Gucci, the elegant bottle, and even the packaging is extraordinarily beautiful. However, the blend grenades are slowly losing their spark. Everything reads wonderfully, the appearance is maintained, but in reality, the essence leaves much to be desired.

Bergamot from Calabria, the oranges were specially flown in from Tunisia, French lavender graces the composition, the heart note is supposed to enchant with the help of Sri Lankan nutmeg and the tried-and-true plum-cinnamon combo, and the base of labdanum, patchouli, leather, and amber additionally tempts one to have positive expectations. One could at least expect a fresh, fruity, spicy leather standard. Unfortunately, it seems that some chemistry from Syria has also been mixed in, which was apparently quite cheap back then due to an oversupply - times change.

Unfortunately, it smells overly synthetic, no matter how lively the fragrance still is. In the drydown, you can already sense what has been flowery described on paper, but a hint of olfactory poison gas unfortunately lingers constantly in the background. This is not only terrible but also a cheek. No one expects high-quality synthetic fragrance materials in a cheap drugstore scent, but if you are charging a decent amount for the name Gucci, you cannot sell the same content just to be at least 400 percent more expensive.

"Made to Measure" is an economic maximum principle, according to which one wants to achieve the greatest benefit from the name Gucci with one's own limited resources, and that is disgusting. This fragrance crime is primarily a custom-made product for personal profit, but without a fair measure and goal, because if the only quality of a perfume lies in the bottle and the packaging, something is seriously wrong, and one should be strong and resist the optical temptations.

I had a sample of this fragrance sent along with a perfume order to be able to join the conversation, to judge whether it really is that bad, and possibly to write a truly awful review that I had been somewhat in the mood for...

And lo and behold, all my wishes were granted! Yes, this thing is really that bad. Incredible what a brand allows itself here, which has produced an absolute classic with "Nobile" and then still a very good fragrance with "Gucci PH II."

Synthetic. Sweet. Period. 13 ingredients are supposed to be in there? LOL! She gives this fragrance to him for Christmas because the saleswoman talked her into it, so that when he gets the inevitable question in the office about what he is wearing, he doesn’t have to say Mexx, s.oliver, or Tom Tailor, but can say "Gucci."

This fragrance is, however, not a bit better than the scents from the aforementioned manufacturers, but three times as expensive. Unjust, divisive perhaps, but that’s how the perfume life in the mainstream has become. As long as it’s called Boss, Lacoste, Gucci, etc., even the worst and most unimaginative synthetic sludge is bought.

Women who give such things as gifts, or even men who voluntarily buy such things for themselves: MASCULINE is different, very different. You don’t even have to go into the expensive niche area. You won’t lure any dog out from behind, in front of, above, or out of the oven with that. Very dreadful, but indicative of this era regarding the perception of fragrances...

review_title: Quality bottle / scent? Inversely proportional - Shallow aquatic air number
review_content:
Again, such a flashy scent from the 2010s.
"Custom-made"?! Is THAT what Gucci understands by it today?

Ha! I have to think back a long way to find a truly creative, distinctive Gucci men's fragrance: "Envy for men" was one of those. Or the early "Gucci pour homme" line.

Here, it feels more like a large department store - nothing is custom-made, rather copied and thoughtlessly thrown together.

The first 3 minutes - as usual with today's mass fragrances - packed with stacked aromatic density, a lot of fruit, including orange and berries, behind it some artificial-aquatic tones.

After not even 5 minutes, the scent package noticeably weakens, anise, water lily, and a hint of plum shimmer through. All framed by a shallow, synthetic lab note, perhaps artificially created wannabe Asian musk?

Then it quickly goes downhill, the drydown sets in after just 20 minutes, you can sense some amber in the base, but there’s no trace of leather to be found.

Overall, very flat aromatics, not a total disaster, but also nothing to remember, let alone buy for way too much money.

Instead of designing such a flashy, massive bottle, they should have invested 100,000 euros more in a better perfumer. Here, they are very much dazzled!

One doesn't even know where to start, because the scent can actually be described in one word: dishwater, although dish soap would probably smell better.

The entire fragrance is unfortunately a complete outrage, it is sticky and clings to the skin and is so fresh that you can hardly perceive it, on top of that there is this overwhelming "scent" of soap and an old moth bag.

The bottle unfortunately also looks rather unloved, although it is still the best part of the whole thing. The packaging is unfortunately just as cheap and comes across as gaudy.

After about 10 minutes, the scent has almost completely vanished, and this is from Gucci and at this price.

With my last order from the Central Drugstore, I received a sample of Gucci Made to Measure among other things. The bottle and packaging looked very high-quality already... and in a life before Parfumo, I used to like Gucci Guilty... does that mean I'm going to hell?;-) But after an Our Father, I should be forgiven...

In the wine world, according to Stuart Pigott, there are so-called "Coca-Cola wines"... these are industrial products that are "manufactured" in tanks in large quantities... which have nothing in common with a valuable natural product and the beautiful romance of wine... they taste the same everywhere... not bad... but regardless of whether it rained, hailed, or even snowed that year, whether in Greenland or South Australia... they always taste the same... just like Coca Cola tastes the same everywhere in the world (has to taste).

Just like that, Made to Measure is a loveless and uninspired fragrance... not bad in the sense of stinky sludge, but arbitrary, interchangeable... it could be a global brand or a discount store product... that already gives a devastating verdict for any Parfumo. What could be worse for a fragrance than being described as "generic" and interchangeable??! I can't identify any individual notes... just something slightly sharp, herbal, and reminiscent of men's aftershave pokes my nose and smells like something I've definitely smelled a thousand times before. It's unbeatable in its boredom... it could easily start a boring club with Ultrasense and Invictus... while Invictus here almost smells like a second Jubilation in comparison. Because Invictus doesn't even try to smell like an adult and valuable perfume but shamelessly shows that it is "full of emptiness" and makes 16-year-olds happy.

Here, they try to appear elegant on the outside... and Made to Measure never succeeds in that. No wonder no perfumer is mentioned above... maybe there wasn't one...;-) or it's just self-protection. Anyway, for those who aren't really into perfumes, and whose mommy still lays out their clothes for vocational school or the first year of apprenticeship in the morning, they can safely buy Made to Measure, then they get a solid, below-average perfume (also suitable for the office) and it looks a bit cooler than the Axe spray on the bathroom shelf if a woman should happen to wander into the apartment... just make sure to take off the Uli Stein or Walt Disney socks and the Christmas-themed tie first... and clear away the Diddl mugs from the night before... then maybe it will work out with the neighbor;-).

So, if you like a mega discreet bore, want to avoid any fragrance compliments (from women) at all costs... and are sitting in a single office anyway, you should buy Made to Measure... although 60 euros for something like this... hahahaha... add another 20 euros and the (good) world of perfume opens up to you...

When I received Gucci Made to Measure as a gift from a good friend over 10 years ago, I never thought this fragrance would remain my absolute favorite for so long. It has accompanied me through many years and countless memories, always with its unmistakable charm.

Gucci Made to Measure is a versatile fragrance that can be worn year-round. Whether it's summer or winter, it always fits and adds a pleasant, fresh note. The scent opens with an interesting combination of bergamot, lavender, and anise, rounded off by spicy notes of cinnamon and nutmeg. The heart of the fragrance, dominated by plum and water lily, gives it a floral and slightly sweet nuance, while the base notes of leather, amber, and patchouli add a warm, masculine depth.

Unfortunately, I must admit that the longevity of Made to Measure is not the best. After about 6-7 hours, the scent noticeably fades, especially if one does not spray generously. Yet, despite this small weakness, the fragrance has always been well-received. Friends and colleagues have often commented on it and given compliments, which has confirmed my choice.

Even though Made to Measure receives rather average ratings here on Parfumo, it has been and remains a special fragrance for me. It is not the loudest or most striking scent, but that is exactly what makes it so pleasant and versatile for everyday use.

Just another generic floriental in a posh, golden bottle.
Honestly, I find it more and more difficult to tell these fragrances apart.
Is it Guess? Or Armani? Lady One Million Eau de toilette or Eau de Parfum? Or the latest Gucci like in this case? This said, it is a totally average, fairly unobtrusive scent - nothing to here to justify the name "PREMIERE". It is neither sexy nor vuluptous. I can't find any leather in it and the woody base is totally unpleasant and synthetic in a bad way. Judging from the poor quality of the ingredients used, this one should be avoided, you could be wearing something much more original for the same price.

review_title: Sweet raspberry jam instead of champagne with white flowers and leather
review_content: I'd say - try it on your skin before you buy and don't let the advertising to tempt you. To my nose it doesn't smell anything what is claimed. No champagne, no white flowers, no leather. At least not as I know them through my own experience. I smell a very big purple raspberry "fruit" cooked into a jam with a lot of sweet white musk (somehow the image similar to what I get from The Body Shop Raspberry line). It's very dense and sticky and suffocating to me. But definitely give it a try it if you like the modern fruity-musky tendency (I smell it a lot in Celebrity scents). In that genre it's pretty good - rounded, has a good volume and free from unpleasant aberrations. But only if you like fruity jams.

As far a cry (or should I say sob) from Gucci No. 1 as a perfume can get. This gasp-inducing, misery smells nothing like it's warm-sounding notes. Bergamot and Orange blossom? No way. Woods, Leather? Nope. More like sweetish berries in cream of gasoline.

review_title: Break on Through to the Other Side
review_content:
I have been revisiting many fragrances recently that I have neglected for a long time. I am finding the exercise wonderfully successful - more so than I dared hope! I think I have been ^very^ constructively coached in the meantime. And with this particular one it is not even a case of finding much new in it, but more of ^refinding^ what I perceived in the first place.

I found something a little curious about this when I first tried it. I noticed that the reviews here are not very favourable to it. But I like the °tune° that this fragrance playeth! I'm not sure that I can argue that it is a ^great^ composition, but it ^does^ have a tune that I happen to like rather a lot.

I find the fruity sweetness of it buffered - which is to say, held back from becoming cloying - by a very subtle tobaccoleafy sort of note. And certainly °sort of°, as I find that I ^begin^ to perceive a tobaccoleafy note - but then it is not ^quite^ that, but something really quite unique to this fragrance, and that teases me a great deal, and in a very pleasant way, with my wondering how to define it!

Perhaps it is the note that is listed here as 'woods', or the 'leather' one. Or maybe this rather curious note÷accord÷quality has been °rendered° into notes-list-speak by these idiomata as mere conveniences, as I agree with a previous reviewer that it does not have anything that shows ^patently^ as wood or leather; but it ^does^ have that curious quasi-tobaccoleaf °quality° that I have been here describing.

... a few hours later ...
To be perfectly honest, I am sympathising more with the reviewers who are somewhat scathing of this, on the basis of having actually been wearing it all this time since I last put anything here.
