I mean ... it's a bit sort of, well, dead! It really isn't a very °sanguine° perfume, this one. It's, sort of, a bit of a °flat beer° sort of thing, IYKWIM. Feel like saying to to it "come on! get up! ^do^ something!". I think the people who have been scathing of it probably well-know what I am talking about. Yet, at the same time, I'm not retracting what I said in favour of it. I don't know whether it ^could have^ been made better in the respect just cited without compromising the interesting & positively distinguishing qualities described above: maybe it ^has to be^ a bit °unsanguine° in order to have those qualities - I don't know. But it has it's uses. I can quite easily forsee occasions when I'll use it quite happily.

#######

In connection with what I said about having rehabilitated or reinstated fragrances I have long-neglected, I would like to raise the following point - not so much to sidetrack duscussion about fragrances into discussion about mysticism, but to get worked-out between us what can be done when we find that we have fragrances that we now despise and scourge ourselves for having °wasted° minlet on.

There's an item of ancient wisdom that can be found in various places - ancient Chinese, Freemasonic, all kinds of mysticism - to the effect that when you learn ^anything^ - anything ^at all^ - you go through essentially three phases: first the initial joy & enthusiasm; then the grind, as the disciplines become irksome; then the consolidation of those disciplines, and a return to the original joy - but a joy this time °exalted° by the change in oneself imparted by the installation of a body of learning in oneself. 'Breaking through to the other side', I think one could call it. And I think it is so, whether it's a skill one has learned, appreciation of an artform (including a perfume) or whatever.

When I first started using fragrances I was wowed by all fragrances; then I learned to become critical, and had crisis after crisis as I °learned° disappointment; now, I think I am °breaking through to the other side°, and I am getting back to something like being wowed by all of them - something like, but actually better!

The name of the new Gucci perfume doesn't really show much imagination. I'm curious to see if Chanel will just accept this.

So here it is, the scent that Gucci hopes will boost their Christmas sales this year. The pyramid reads quite modestly, and since Gucci fragrances have never really excited me, at least the newer ones, my expectations weren't too high.

I was pleasantly surprised by the top note - which seems to develop in the wrong order, because the first thing I notice with astonishment is the leather. A fine wild leather note that made me curious for more. But - no such luck - the leather note fades away within a few minutes, leaving behind a generic and interchangeable scent from the remaining notes that we know all too well. The orange blossom holds back more graciously than, for example, in Elie Saab or Burberry Body, and since there are no fruity notes to further emphasize the mediocrity, a very delicate, floral-woody perfume remains, which is discreet in both sillage and longevity. That's a pity, because I actually quite like the base, where the fine leathery note reappears.

The bottle with the stirrup is already familiar to us from Gucci fragrances, and the golden, or rather gilded, presentation suggests something precious. Now, Gucci Premiere will surely play its role in the Christmas business, but I would doubt whether Gucci really needed this scent. In any case, Gucci Premiere is not extraordinary.

Yesterday, I made my obligatory Sunday trip to my fragrance dealer, equipped with requests from my girlfriend and my cousin. Well, my girlfriend and cousin knew exactly what they wanted, but I wanted to choose a little something for my mom. It was supposed to be a surprise! I tried this and that, but time and again my hand wandered to the beautiful golden Gucci Premiere EDP...

review_title: Frustration purchase that was worth it.
review_content: Gucci Première was an unexpected frustration purchase. I just had to have something, and so it became Gucci Première. However, I do not regret this at all, as the frustration purchase was worth it for me. Gucci Première is a great, sensual scent. At the beginning, it is fruity-sweet, with a hint of citrus notes, and it is already quite heavy on me from the start. The...

I must admit that I have a bit of a contentious relationship with Gucci. I have 6 fragrances from this house at home, and they all impress with their very short longevity. However, this could be due to my skin chemistry, as the scent holds up perfectly on clothing.

Now to Premiere... I agree with the majority of my predecessors. A premiere is not something you experience every day, so a fragrance with the same name should be something special. Something opulent for the evening. Something that stands out and takes people's breath away (in a positive sense). So, anything but this Gucci scent.

It starts off quite sweetly with bergamot and orange blossom. But much lighter than, for example, Code Femme by Armani. (There, the orange blossom is more present and heavier). After about 20 minutes, it becomes increasingly floral. Not bad, but relatively unspectacular. What bothers me, however, is this leather/musk note. I can't help but feel that it clashes with the floral abundance. It feels a bit like wearing two perfumes at the same time that don't really go together. Really a shame, because you can already tell that it is something high-quality. No disturbing alcoholic or cheap synthetic undertone. Just... as if someone had mixed the fragrance essences and didn't come up with anything decent. Really a shame for a rather high-priced brand like Gucci.

If you still like the scent, it is more suitable for everyday wear. Wearable at any time of day, from young to old. It simply lacks any profile, any recognizability (aside from the leather scent that bothers me here). Really a shame and truly unworthy of a luxury brand like Gucci.

review_title: Finally, I have found my fragrance!
review_content: For a long time, I had been searching for the perfect perfume for me. The search proved to be extremely difficult. Just when I was about to give up, I stumbled upon this perfume. I had tested it some time ago but dismissed it as unremarkable. However, recently I received a sample of the turquoise one in my bag. When I tried it again, I was captivated. First of all, I find the...

Well, I have now tested several perfumes from Gucci, own some, and have had a few. This scent here definitely does not carry the "signature" of some Gucci classics like Gucci Rush, Gucci Accenti, Gucci Eau de Parfum, Gucci Envy. I find Premiere lacks anything special, no recognizability like the aforementioned classics. It's a shame that Accenti is no longer available.. These perfumes had something special, a note/aura that bears no resemblance to other perfumes. But that is just my feeling. I would describe Premiere as an average scent, where one would not guess that it is a Gucci perfume!. The entire fragrance bouquet feels familiar to me, like I’ve smelled it somewhere before. The top note is still quite pleasant, bergamot and orange blossom are rather fresh-floral here, but after a short time, it takes on a rather harsh musk touch, and I also perceive something fruity. Here, the AHA-WOW effect is completely absent for me. Sorry if I put it this way. This scent can be worn well in the evening, as it becomes a bit heavier in the base note, and in the cold season! The positive aspect here is at least the longevity.

I have to agree with Turandot - exciting is something else! This scent is simply one thing: "nice". You can hardly say more about it. I can't really detect a great development in the fragrance here; rather, "Premiere" is for me a rather appetizing orange cuddle musk mix. It reminds me, as the title suggests, very much of Narciso Rodriguez edT, just in the well-behaved variant. This is a decent clean musk, creamy and somehow "motherly". It simply smells like a well-groomed mommy after showering. But do I want to smell like that? Please, no.
As I said, this is not a bad fragrance. I find the orange-musk combo balanced and lovely, but a bit more wood and leather would have been nice. Unfortunately, the whole thing smells quite trivial, and the longevity doesn't convince me, just like with many other Guccis.

This scent simply reminds me of Italy. Not only because I wore this perfume on a trip to Venice, Verona, and Lake Garda, but also because this fragrance radiates the elegance and femininity that I associate with an Italian woman.

I love that the leather note is so prominent in this fragrance, as it harmonizes very well with the floral notes of the white flowers. However, I also detect quite dominant pepper notes, and I am really surprised that pink pepper is not listed here. In terms of intensity, I find the perfume quite good; there are days when I feel the need to reapply during the day, but there are also days when the strength is completely sufficient for me. Overall, I would describe the scent as delicate yet present. In my opinion, it is not a “quiet mouse,” but it is also not a show-off.

I think it’s great for days when you are dressing elegantly, as I envision a lightly tanned woman in a white shirt, dark-wash jeans, light brown ballerinas, and a matching handbag with simple gold jewelry. But in my opinion, it can just as well be worn on days when you are casually heading to the city for coffee in a dress.

~ Inspiration ~
I became aware of the perfume through the advertisement featuring Blake Lively. She embodies the epitome of a young, beautiful, successful woman in Hollywood.

~ Bottle ~
Like with "Gucci," the square shape has been retained. Also, as a small accessory, there is the medal with stirrup. The shiny gold color stands out here, which is meant to evoke film premieres and the associated Oscar ceremonies.

~ Scent ~
The top note starts with bergamot and sweet orange blossoms. White flowers and a hint of musk join in. The warm base is formed by various woods and leather, which can be perceived well from the beginning.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 5 hours (on clothing and hair a bit longer). 1-2 sprays are sufficient, as the scent is intense but not overpowering.

~ Occasion ~
I find it most suitable in autumn/winter or on cooler days in spring. Whether for successful businesswomen in the office or for an evening out - it leaves an elegant, self-assured impression.

~ Conclusion ~
Like its predecessor "Gucci," it is quite well done, but I can't (yet) fully identify with it.

To describe this fragrance, one word is enough: Boring.

Smelled a thousand times, nothing new, no innovation.
What a shame, the bottle looks beautiful.
Gucci no longer convinces me with its new fragrances (-> Flora Garden Collection *yawn*)...

I hope they come up with something new soon, because the old fragrances were great (Rush, Gucci1&2, Gucci by Gucci,...).

As my predecessor already mentioned, the scent remains the same until the end, nothing changes at all and the longevity can also be rated as weak.

Actually, there isn't much to say about this little water beyond the title. A nice citrus top note, but the heart and base do nothing for you, nor do they do anything against you. It's all been smelled a thousand times over or something similar - boredom is the name of the game.

review_title: Not a going-out scent, but quite good for everyday use
review_content: Premiere was a gift I received. After about 8 weeks, I had used it up (50 ml) because I found it quite good for work, unobtrusive yet elegant; clean, clear, subtle. I think it made me come across as likable. Nothing more. No one ever asked me what it was. So it remained very close to the skin. I will not repurchase it. Too much money for too little surprise. If I want an office scent, I can just go to the drugstore.

review_title: A Walking Fragrance, Like a Stroll on the Red Carpet
review_content:
It starts, as expected, citrusy, but quickly the citrus boredom transforms into a cozy "Ohh." A note emerges that is incredibly noble, yet for me, unidentifiable.
As I leave the shopping mall, the scent changes in an interesting way, becoming almost resinous.
But this note quickly disappears, and it becomes sweet and soft, smelling like a lightly vanilla orange candy.
This fragrance lingers for a while until distinct woods join in, making it slightly powdery.
And after three-quarters of an hour, I can actually smell leather!
Oranges, woods, leather, and a sweetness remain, making this fragrance very intriguing.

If a walk on the red carpet, like at a premiere, were to be represented by this fragrance, it has succeeded very well in my mind.
First, she gets ready at home, a citrusy shower, then a short, resinous ride in the limousine to the event, followed by the walk on the carpet, where she showcases her orange candy side until she reaches the attractive man in brown leather boots and links arms with him.
Gucci, I like you.

Aside from an unpleasant sting in the nose, this fragrance left me completely indifferent. I can't even say what it actually smells like; it simply has no warmth for me and seems more suited to keeping people at a distance. It was a gift from someone who clearly doesn't know me well enough, as this perfume doesn't suit me at all. My association with this scent: A woman around sixty with blue hair, horn-rimmed glasses, a tweed suit, and an exceptionally bad mood, who is just rejecting a job applicant because he hasn't shaved properly...

review_title: Not everything that glitters is gold
review_content:
It's difficult; this scent does not evoke any particular emotions in me. And yet, the sense of smell is the one that most strongly influences feelings and the subconscious. It neither brings me joy, well-being, enjoyment, nor even the opposite, such as aversion.
I only know that the fragrance seems quite trivial and interchangeable. Essentially, it is a perfect perfume for a colleague who always applies just a bit too much of a good thing. This way, you have a rather exclusive room fragrance as a side effect.
A brief start with the top notes, which spray orange blossoms and bergamot, quickly followed by musk, white flowers, and as a background panorama, the woods in a leather coat.
While I occasionally sniff at myself, the scent becomes too much for me, and I no longer want to smell it.
And as mentioned in many of the previous comments, the fragrance tends to develop more into a perfume for the more mature generation.
However, there is nothing to criticize about the bottle. I find it beautifully designed in its golden dress, with its noble angular shapes, and as a highlight, the trademark of Gucci, the broken bridle.

Nobile opens with an aromatic blend of bergamot citrus and lavender with a lime-like tarragon and rosemary herbal undertone. As Nobile enters the heart phase of its development, the early bergamot citrus recedes but the aromatic herb-laced lavender remains, coupling with a tremendous oakmoss note rising from the base joining balsam fir as co-stars with an additional rose and carnation floral supporting duo joining the lavender. In the late heart, the aromatic lavender slowly dissipates but the oakmoss and fir still remain through the dry-down now in support, as a relatively dry amber and non-smoky vetiver duo takes the fore to finish off the scent's development. Projection and longevity are both excellent, with the scent lasting 10-12 hours on skin.

Nobile is one of those rare aromatic fougere scents from the past that just can't be released today due to oakmoss restrictions. The very green herb-laced oakmoss and fir combo with floral support is absolutely captivating and dominates for most of Nobile's key development before turning to resinous amber late during the dry-down. The official note list is very long and quite frankly I am sure I missed a whole bunch of them, but Nobile just smells great, plain and simple. It unfortunately commands a price just as high as how good it smells nowadays due to its discontinuance long ago and the scarcity of remaining bottles on the after-market. That said, those looking for a reference aromatic fougere should look no further than this 4 to 4.5 star out of 5 classic by Gucci.

If you are a fan of vintage Polo Green, you will really dig Nobile by Gucci. The dry mossy / patchouli accord is very smooth, masculine and mature. Overall, the scent is fairly "quiet" compared to other aromatic fougere's from the 80's as the blend is exceptional.

A 30ml bottle can be found for around $100-$150 and is entirely worth every penny for this vintage discontinued gem of a fragrance.

4 stars

I remember the commercials when this came out. I liked the bottle so much when I saw it, I bought it without even testing it out. In a years time or so, it was gone and I forgot about it. Flash forward to 2001, I find a huge lot of Gucci Nobile products at an estate sale. I snatched it all up. Body wash and sprays, soap on a rope, deodorants, shaving cream and splash too. I absolutely adore this scent, it is the quintessential man’s cologne. A suddenly sharp but clean barbershop medicinal smell, it soon turns sweet and much gentler. Afterwards there’s this incredibly deep woods smell, sort of wet and smooth. There’s still nothing else quite like it. It’s amazing. 20+ years later and I have half of a 120ml bottle left and a 30ml bottle. If Gucci brought this back today, it’d probably sell very well. I just don’t think they’d get it quite right again.

I haven’t have this one since the nineties, but I know I’d recognize it instantly if I’d be around someone wearing it. It’s just unforgettable. I even dare to think that this is the best juice I’ve ever had. One still can get it nowadays online supposedly from vintage collectors but at exorbitant prices.
If I were forced to throw away all my collection and be required to decide to keep one I’ll certainly struggle between Nobile and Chanel allure home sport eau extreme.

Sometimes I find fougères nauseating, when the aldehyde component overpowers all else … But with Nobile, the fougère smell is toned down, smoother, and well-balanced. It’s complimentary to the spicy and sophisticated heart notes, giving them a clean pop without being overwhelming. Because at its heart, this is mostly a spicy and sophisticated green scent. Nothing smells quite like it. It's also a versatile scent - I can see it working in any season, day or night, even as a signature scent. Projection and longevity was moderate, about what you'd expect from an eau de toilette.

If you like fougéres, you'll probably love this. And if you hate fougéres, you might like this despite yourself. For comparison, my ratings of fougéres goes like this:

Gucci Nobile - 9.5
Drakkar Noir - 7.5
Azzaro pour homme - 5.5
Paco Rabanne pour homme - 4.0

It's a discontinued fragrance. And only place you can seem to find it now is eBay, where prices are expensive by any measure. Initially I thought I would just wear my sample until gone and then say goodbye, due to the cost. But it grew on me and grew on me - I’ved raised my ranking of it on here four times! Now I just love it and it’s my favorite overall fragrance. By the time I bought my full bottle, I didn’t mind paying at all.

Nobile is the prototype of the classic men's fragrance, and for those who want a realistic impression without spending a lot of money, the green Palmolive shaving stick can serve as a reference. The reviews below say it all. Nobile is a dry-citrus masterpiece with herbs, dark-powdery amber, a strong musky connection to shaving products and soap, which fades into menthol-dry...

Another gem from the 80s.

"Nobile" has a wonderfully old-fashioned style and is qualitatively incomparable to anything from the current Gucci offerings.

A freshly crafted, already green-spiced opening. Lemon alongside a hint of tarragon, a bit more rosemary, grounding lavender.

The heart is thoroughly green, framed by a touch of jasmine and subtle fir.
The overall style remains fresh with a spicy undertone, somewhat reminiscent of "Armani Eau pour homme".

Softly ambered, yet in the dry down a bit woodier, mossier, lightly musky-spicy.
A truly well-made Italian classic from the now vast category of "Strong fragrances that ignorant manufacturers have completely senselessly discontinued".

Is it the fact that it was taken off the market years ago? That it is now traded at astronomical prices? That it has since attained legendary status? Surely all of this plays a role - let's be honest: an average bottle of wine by candlelight in a fine restaurant tastes better than elsewhere... But even if you set all the psychology aside: Nobile EAU DE TOILETTE...

With reverence for this scent, I dare to make a comment. A lucky coincidence brought me to a non-damaged 5ml mini at the flea market. At a bargain price, considering that 1.5ml is sold for 10 euros and 5ml can go up to 20 euros on auction platforms. The fragrance is a true Italian through and through, with nobility and refinement, male charm, and the elegance of the 80s....

If you look at Gucci's recent fragrances, you quickly realize that the company has thrown itself into the mainstream in this regard. Flankers galore, thick cheeks with nothing but hot air inside (Made to Measure, please) and those that really had something to offer were ruthlessly stamped out. I still mourn Envy to this day.

I had never heard of Nobile until recently. That might also be because the bottles of the first Gucci fragrances were simply atrocious, and back then, I was all about aesthetics. Shame on me! But honestly, the new ones aren't winning any awards either.

Nobile is a true Italian. Not an immature ragazzino. An elegant, educated guy. Macho? Hmm, I honestly struggle with that comparison. He simply has too much style. I don't know why, but I kept thinking of Guido Brunetti from the Donna Leon novels. Unfortunately, also Vice-Questore Giuseppe Patta. Nobile manages to combine herbal notes with a wonderful freshness. What smells harsh and ethereal in Jil Sander Man III has been skillfully rounded and made elite here, fresh and radiant. Absolutely suitable for everyday wear. Which is hard to believe given the intense ingredients.

Something remarkable happened to me with this fragrance. I was lost in thought when suddenly a wave of a wonderful scent hit my nose. Wow, I thought, who smells so great here? Until I realized, it's ME!

But what good is all this? He has disappeared from the scene. However, you can still secure him as a mini for little money as a tip. I didn't even pay € 3.00 for my two untouched 5ml bottles. For the big guys, of course, prices are being asked that make you shake your head.

Yes, back then Gucci could still do it. And yes, neither before nor after has this house come even close to the quality of this fragrance...

Masculine, without being macho. Multi-layered and complex, without being exhausting. You truly can't expect much more. The quintessence of perfumery art from the 80s.

What good does it do to mourn this gem? It will NEVER be reissued. One should acquire the remaining minis on the market at reasonable prices (the few remaining full bottles are, of course, absurdly expensive, as is usual with such fragrances) and enjoy them. I still own two minis that won't last much longer, and therefore I will go hunting with the relevant suppliers once more before the rest of this treasure is finally gone...

review_title: Noble Goes the World to Ruin
review_content: … so we gladly join in :-) Nobile (Italian: noble, elegant) by Gucci was actually the fragrance that accompanied me during my training in the late 80s, alongside a few others. I liked its very fresh, spicy character, which promised me every time I applied it: This will be a good day! (even if it unfortunately wasn't always the case) From my memory, I still recall that...

My second miniature bottle and absolutely not a flop, I am firmly convinced of that, even though I didn’t know the scent beforehand. Anyone who has the large version at home should guard it like their own eye. Because this is a true gold treasure from a long-gone, golden Gucci era.

The name fits like a glove, and for me, it plays in a classic league alongside Pour Monsieur or Eau Sauvage from Chanel. Only with Chanel do they take care of their treasures (aside from forced reformulations!) and they are still available everywhere. This one has been allowed to die, even though it could have been THE classic of the Gucci house. Because Gucci doesn’t really have a true classic from the 70s or 80s. At least none that is still available for purchase. Another blemish on the brand, which weighs even heavier for me than the botching of all new releases for years! I’m curious about Made to Measure; it’s supposed to be horrendously bad and dull again!

As for the scent: A perfume for the old-school gentleman in a tuxedo. Mixed with a powerhouse 80s fragrance that is almost bursting with distinctive energy, chest hair, and thousands of ingredients.

It starts classically, with a spicy bergamot. Then the scent becomes greener and rougher, with enormous power and a tailored presence. Fir, rose. Everything is truly green and foresty-mossy. However, it’s just mild enough that it never causes a wrinkled nose. A mild gentleman-macho with a cane and chest hair peeking out from the wreck. Sounds funny, but it’s a seriously good scent! A fragrance that I could well imagine wearing as a signature scent in 10-15 years. But unfortunately, that’s not going to happen! The scent concludes with a gentle, even slightly sweet moss-wood-vetiver base, just to my taste!

The bottle is noble, simple, and classic - as the name suggests. The scent lasted a nice 7-8 hours on my wrist, and the sillage was boss-level, as our youth would probably say.

Oldie but Goldie! Rarely has this been more true!

...in the world of fragrance. I discovered this scent almost simultaneously with Cool Water. They both hit the market in the same year. At that time, my signature scent was Macasar by Rochar, which was already becoming harder to find. And then came "Nobile," a fragrance like no other that radiated a masculine spiciness I had never smelled before. Even though it wasn't...

The openings of the Gucci's have not impressed me. The are rather soft and I would suppose I have acquired a taste for a stronger, more robust perfume that can take me away, one that will grab me by the shoulders and shake me. Granted, there is no horrible alcohol whizz at first hint, just a soft hint of something to come. Maybe peach. Maybe vanilla. So we have generic fruity-gourmand blended into a soft cream sitting low, so low that I must put my nose into it and therein lies the problem. The patchouli is so weak I don't know it's there. Another common scent packaged oh-so-prettily, rather vampy to catch the eye of unsuspecting wallets, a designer name for those that care enough about labels, pretty packaging and the money shall be spent on commonality.

I think I was expecting something a little darker and more mysterious than this, based on the name and the sleek bottle. It's not a particularly inviting scent. It's predominantly fruity - but the raspberry feels a little more sour than sweet. I can faintly detect the pink pepper, but the remaining notes are lost on me. It's not bad, but it doesn't make the 'raw and compelling' statement it claims to.

review_title: Maybe I’m right - maybe I’m wrong…
review_content:
I usually appreciate and adore the Gucci scents. But not all. Guilty black is one I do not like or admire. I get the feeling that this is made for young people who want a heavy and loud perfume. I may be wrong… about young people… about Gucci… about flanker scents named black.
But then I might be right…
337/365

Obviously, this is a flanker of the original 'Gucci - Guilty'.
Gucci as a clothing brand is currently being celebrated by the youth, and fortunately, the fragrances are less 'mainstream' than one might think; I hardly catch a whiff of anyone wearing a Gucci scent in the streets and alleys. Perhaps it’s just my city.
I definitely find the bottle successful; it looks very mysterious and promising. I love the combination of black and red; it makes a statement, while the smaller 30 ml version looks even more compact.
Now, onto the actual scent:
It smells similar to the original, I think. A bit fresher, possibly due to the fruits. The opening smells slightly synthetic, but fortunately, it almost completely disappears for me. The sillage is also close to the original. By no means a bad scent.
For those who prefer something unobtrusive yet a bit different, I recommend buying it. It fits in pretty much any situation, from job interviews, evening galas, swimming pool visits, to everyday work life. It also has a 'cool' aspect; it's not just a pure summer/spring scent, very pleasant.

The bottle is SO BEAUTIFUL! My partner next to me just said it reminds him of Batman :-)
But unfortunately, the scent is so interchangeable. I tested it with great anticipation and was then disappointed. Immediately, I had two thoughts in my head:
1. Smells not very different from the "normal" Guilty
2. Reminds me of Ode l Amour by Yves Rocher, which I used very often in my youth.

Now, it must be said that Ode l Amour by Yves Rocher is not at all "Black." Just like Guilty Black is a bit too shallow for me.
It fades quickly, has a poor sillage, and simply lacks that certain something. I smell fabric softener, rose, and maybe a few woody notes. However, I understand "Black" to mean something different.

My Gucci Guilty Black. It is something special, both because of its scent and the unique bottle. Despite the black plastic exterior, it is visually well-designed and a real eye-catcher in my collection. However, I cannot share the associations from the advertising at all. Gucci Guilty Black is, for me, the ideal partner at work. Not for Monday, not for Tuesday, at the earliest...

review_title: Can do more than initially thought
review_content: A new day, a new scent. I hadn't known any from the Guilty line until now, but I came across this half-full bottle of Guilty Black. This line simply hadn't intrigued me so far, why?... I don't know. Probably because I just hadn't had an eye for it in the jungle of fragrances. The top note promises pepper & red fruits, oh yes. You can definitely perceive a distinct pepper...

When the fragrance was new and I had not yet discovered - sank Parfumo - niche and vintage scents for myself, I tested Gucci Black and was immediately love-struck. What held me back from purchasing was the price of around €70 and the fact that I was still looking for a job at that time. It took quite a while until Guilty Black was allowed to move in. I would say that at...

Well, normally I try to create many connections to the scents in the titles, sometimes informative, sometimes funny. But with Gucci Guilty Black, I simply can't come up with a title that relates to the scent itself - it's just too trivial. Therefore, the next paragraph, which usually focuses solely on the fragrance, will be all the more difficult to write. Only the bottle really reminds one of Batman & Robin.

The scent is sweet, fruity, and quite bright. The addition of Black is once again completely out of place. Red berries meet a bright hint of pepper. Then there's a not really identifiable floral note, and in the background, a synthetic amber that lingers the longest. Acceptable for younger girls without fragrance experience, but even here, the €50 would be much better spent elsewhere. You just need to browse a bit on Parfumo and develop some taste.

Bottle: kitschy, cheap, but eye-catching.
Sillage: despite the flashy scent, surprisingly calm.
Longevity: 7 hours.

A bit better than the men's counterpart, but still far behind any expectations one might have. This is neither Black nor Gucci for me. At most, guilty, and that for lack of creativity and yawning boredom.

That's really all you need to know about this scent. It is expensive, it smells expensive, and it makes a noble impression.

Without smelling it for long, you can already notice the fruits at play. The scent is very sweet, overly sweet, so it's better to wear it in winter.

This is a fragrance of modern times. It reminds me of nothing from the past, but the image comes to mind:
The woman wants to storm into a hotel with her lover so they can have a bit of peace and relaxation. Both have money and their hands full of bags... Louis Vuitton, Prada, Gucci...
and afterward in the room, the two had beautiful sex.

For such occasions, the scent is perfect, as it is very sexy and expensive. In any case, in summer, this scent would be too much.

The fragrance is nothing special, but it smells good and expensive. If you don't want to stand out too much but still want to make a corresponding impression, this is the best perfume.

~ Inspiration ~
I already like "Guilty" very much. While browsing, I also came across "Guilty Black" and hoped for a stronger evening version of my beloved daytime fragrance.

~ Bottle ~
In keeping with the name, the bottle is designed in black instead of gold. The glass in the middle with the intertwined G's is red. (I immediately thought of Batman) Admittedly, I always thought this was the men's version...

~ Scent ~
You can immediately tell that it's a "Guilty"!
It starts off with juicy, red fruits and a hint of pink pepper, before blooming lilac and violet reveal its well-known floral heart (raspberries and peach continue to provide a sparkling, fruity vibe in the background). Patchouli and amber give it a warm side in the base.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 6 hours (a bit longer on clothing and hair). 2-3 sprays are enough, as it is not overpowering but still quite intense.

~ Occasion ~
A bit heavier than "Gucci Guilty," it fits well into the mild evenings of spring and autumn. As a going-out fragrance, it feels too "proper" for me and too floral for winter.

~ Conclusion ~
A little darker, but otherwise no big difference from "Guilty."

Today, for Mother's Day, I got my dear mom her beloved Baby Doll by YSL from the fragrance dealer - and couldn't help but spray a "little" for myself. My husband, bored by my busy activities, loses himself in the view of the landscape - when he suddenly taps me on the shoulder with interest, asking: What was that? Delicious. I still have the Guilty Black bottle in my hand and...

Since I really like Gucci Guilty, I was quite excited about the Black version and I was not disappointed; it smells simply enchanting! However, I must admit that it doesn't smell very different from the original, which is not surprising since the notes are quite similar.
It starts sweet, soft, and floral, smelling of raspberry and peach. Then comes a very interesting note that I can't identify; it smells almost like a mix of chocolate and incense. Quite extraordinary and wonderful.
I find the black design inappropriate, as the scent reminds me more of a fragrant, pleasant summer day than anything dark.
However, the fragrance could be a bit stronger; unfortunately, it is almost disappearing on the skin.

I tried it out today in a store and it's nothing great. I even think that it's just a copy of various other black scents. They all smell similar or have amber and patchouli as a base, just enhanced with a few other ingredients.
They could have certainly done more with it.

I received Gardenia by Gucci (unfortunately) as a gift from my brother, as he worked on the new Garden campaign for Gucci.

At first, I was of course very, very excited. The packaging, the design, and ultimately the bottle are truly beautiful. So pretty that the scent would visually fit very nicely in my bathroom shelf.
Unfortunately, it is just too sweet for me. Personally, I prefer fresh, light fragrances.
Gardenia is not that. Maybe at the very beginning, just for a brief moment (pear, berries)... then it is very, very sweet for a long time, and many hours later, and this is the only thing I personally like about the scent, it becomes powdery on the skin. However, before it reaches this state, it gives me headaches.
In itself, Gardenia is certainly a nice, rounded fragrance if you like sweet scents. It fits well for spring and summer, but perhaps also on cooler days for snuggling under a cozy blanket.
Somehow, I perceive it as a typical, sugary sweet girl’s fragrance... unfortunately not for me.
It somewhat reminds me of Pure by Jil Sander. (which is also too sweet for me personally)

Now I have to champion this wonderfully beautiful fragrance! Since I first tested it, it hasn't let me go; I love it from the first spray to the last soft whisper.
When I first smelled it on my arm, I immediately thought - this is it, exactly what I have been searching for so long, even though I had imagined it quite differently.
At first, it is sweet-fruity, which I find totally delicious when sprayed on, but I wouldn't actually want to smell like this all day. Yet in that first moment, it smells so wonderfully of summer holidays, cycling home from a day at the pool or to the park, hair still damp and tied up, just a shirt over the bikini and long free weeks ahead.
Then the fragrance becomes softer, less sweet and floral, and the notes blend beautifully. It is the twilight of this lovely summer day. But it is just beginning, and the air is still warm, but not oppressive.
Then it slowly and quietly fades away, yet sometimes my nose still catches a hint of that summer evening.
I could smell it forever, and no other fragrance has transported me to another time like this. Thank you, Gardenia!

"Flora Gorgeous Gardenia" is a sugary little flower of the finer sort. More like frosted Frangipani than Gardenia, but still great. Fruity, sweet, feminine, youthful, spontaneous, naive, summery... these are adjectives that come to mind with this pink Gucci.

Easy to wear for young women who know how to playfully seduce. Although tailored to mass taste, it is never intrusive or sticky, never pushy or loud. Wasps and other critters are definitely attracted to it, especially this hot summer. Of course, it's different, but I can somehow handle it here. A creeping playmate, a monotonous spring awakening. The lady of the world from Rio to Berlin can hardly go wrong with this from 16 to 24. Because it surely attracts not only stinging flying insects...

Bottle: beautiful color, nice design. With a bow.
Sillage: fortunately not too heavy... that would have been deadly this summer. Not just for those with wasp allergies...
Longevity: 6 hours is longer than expected

Conclusion: sweet, tender, summery - a fine flower that lacks a bit of uniqueness. Nevertheless: worth a try!

review_title: Sugared Frangipani instead of Magnificent Gardenias
review_content:
~ Inspiration ~
So far, I have tested the regular "Flora" and "Glamorous Magnolia" from the Gucci "Flora Garden" line and was now curious about "Gorgeous Gardenia".

~ Bottle ~
The hexagonal shape indicates that this is a version of "Gucci Flora". It also features a thin black ribbon around the neck. The liquid in a delicate rose tone promises a subtle, floral scent. The name "Gorgeous Gardenia" means "Magnificent Gardenias".

~ Fragrance ~
It starts fruity-fresh with crisp green pears and tart red berries. The powerful floral heart of white gardenias and frangipani gives it a sweet yet slightly sultry aura, rounded off with brown sugar and patchouli in the base.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 7 hours (on clothing and hair even longer). 2-3 sprays are sufficient, as it is quite intense and otherwise comes off too synthetic and overloaded. The sillage is unobtrusive but noticeable.

~ Occasion ~
A lush floral scent for the warmer days and evenings in spring, summer, and autumn.

~ Conclusion ~
You can recognize the typical "Flora" character of the perfume. It has a bit of "Oh Lola!" by Marc Jacobs.

Since I enjoy wearing Flora di Gucci and Gorgeous Magnolia, I was looking forward to Gorgeous Gardenia - especially since the lovingly painted bottle appeals to me.

I expect a lovely wildflower meadow that one carefully walks through barefoot to avoid bending the stems.

However, the quite
floral scent is accompanied by a harsh soapy note that doesn't quite match my expectations.
Alongside fruity and floral elements, the clean soap keeps peeking through.
Is the gardenia responsible for this cleanliness factor?
Thus, the lovely wildflower meadow loses its romance.
I can't perceive any sweetness - the scent remains floral but harsh for me.
Somehow unbalanced.

I would rather stick with Flora di Gucci and Gorgeous Magnolia.

"Wis I didn't know it was a fragrance from Gucci, I would have thought it was a cheap drugstore scent," was my mother's indifferent verdict when we were recently in the perfume store and I sprayed this perfume on my wrist. I wouldn't have expressed it so drastically, but at that moment, the "gorgeous gardenia" really didn't smell particularly high-quality. Yet, torn back and...

Wow! This fragrance is actually really good! Definitely not what I was expecting but I'm happy about that. Very modern and not your average designer spring/summer fragrance. Where most are all citrus and aquatic, This cologne is floral and woodsy. This one really reminds me of Dior Homme, but not in smell rather in genre. The more floral, soapy and woodsy with be a nice change and make you standout from all the other heavy citrus and aquatics this summer. Like Dior Homme this one opens with a pungent almost medical citrus smell, I'm assuming from the bergamot but that dissipates in seconds and the florals takeover. The Heliotrope is centerstage in the fragrance and again like Dior Homme gives a really nice soapy/powdery scent with a little little spice from the rosemary I'm guessing. From there the scent remains this soft clean floral with a warm base and the scent stays this way for most of the duration until maybe around the 4 hour mark and then the woods and patchouli completely takes over and finish off the night. And honestly the woods is really what made me a fan of this fragrance. The warm cypress with the patchouli gives this a animalic, balsamic aroma that almost comes off as a cleaner more musky Oud. This fragrance is label a cologne but the opening is pretty wide and comes off more like a edt but once it dries down it becomes very soft which I'm sure others will confuse the performance with being weak but I think this is a A+ fragrance from the house of Gucci and another one of those fragrances pushing the boundaries and starting conversation of what men fragrance can be just like Gucci Guilty Absolute, this one belongs in my collection.

review_title: it'll grow on you if you give it the chance
review_content:
I get why this fragrance is polarizing, it's certainly not a crowd pleaser and in fact I felt a little disappointed after the first wear. I did enjoy the opening when I tested it at the store, I didn't love but I liked it and it was on sale so I went for it. First actual wear started fine, very nice opening but the dry down not so much but the damage was done and I wouldn't just leave in the back of the closet, at least I'd wear it when I stay home but after 2nd wear I paid closer attention and by the 3rd it became almost a love.

Yes, Guilty Cologne is challenging to some extend, it does have a gorgeous opening and then it turns into a baby wipe kinda smell that can be off putting at first but it's different from your average freshies and blues. The baby wipe vibe is not an actual bad thing, it does smell clean and fresh and longevity is actually real good (7hrs plus).

Overall it's a nice fragrance that falls a little bit short to become a 'love' but it is a strong 'like'

Gucci was never really my brand. Neither the overpriced clothes nor the fragrance creations. I haven't tested many from this brand, but the pyramids and concepts don't appeal to me much, and the ones I tested I found rather mediocre. I couldn't test the very popular discontinued fragrances anymore.
I tested this one about a year ago during a shopping spree. Why this one? This beautiful green smiled at me so nicely, and the word Cologne is something you always need. Just like all the L'eau, Fresh, Sport, and whatever else they are called.

During my first test, I wasn't exactly blown away, but it was a pleasant scent for everyday wear that I roughly noted down. Especially when I saw the prices for this shop online, it made its way onto my wish list. I think the prices are so low because it hasn't received much attention and the sales figures are pretty much in the basement. Especially with a discount code, you can get this for free. 50ml costs under 30 euros in many shops, and 150ml is already available for just over 50 euros. More than fair compared to other fresh scents.
Anyone expecting a typical Cologne-style fragrance will be disappointed. It is also not a typical Morillas scent, where most have a similar touch. With Guilty Absolute, he was already very creative, and here with the Cologne as well.
As I said: Anyone expecting a refreshing Cologne will be disappointed. You get a scent that resembles Nivea cream. Not exactly the same smell, but it definitely goes in that direction. Those who like moisturizing creams like Nivea might find this appealing. You are accompanied by very soft, well-groomed, and also very pleasantly creamy notes. The cypress note is rather gentle compared to other cypress scents. Overall, one shouldn't pay too much attention to the pyramid, as this creation has its very own touch.
Performance is fantastic for an EdT in the supposed Cologne concept. Projection is very, very good over long distances, and the longevity should be close to double digits. Well done.

Overall, a great bargain that can be worn very well in everyday life.

I already like the original. So I like this one too. Drawing on the Guilty DNA (gummy candy), this Cologne (in EdT concentration) surprises with its own, unusual freshness character. Very modern, very appealing, but away from all the potent Ambrox and aroma-chemical wood paths.

For me, it’s a mix of green Ahoi-Brause (without the fizz), Fanta Lime, green gummy candy, shower gel, and sweet mint drink. A penetrating, herb-fresh coolness with a subtle watery quality on a sweet gummy candy base. In green. Everything perfectly balanced. It has a light, well-groomed soapy note and develops a very gentle woodiness that keeps it from becoming too “funky-funky.”

Compared to the original, it comes without lavender, which gives the predecessor that hinted classic touch. Its “depth” is also not reached, although there is enough volume present without deploying “heavy” notes. The designation ‘Cologne’ somewhat misleads, as it is actually an Eau de Toilette. This is reflected in the sillage (especially in the first hour) and remarkable longevity (10 hrs.+ with good perceivability on my skin).

I find the scent to be a very fitting complement to the original for warm days. While the original leans towards the seductive direction, this one remains refreshing and sporty-sexy. Personally, it is a tad too modern for regular wear and a bit too sweet for a fresh scent, as it lacks the “established” traces of the original, yet it seems to me a touch more refined. It does not have the initially slightly scratchy synthetic quality (directly on the skin, not in the projection) and blends into a round, compact mass. It is also linear, but interesting and - another parallel - understated enough not to be intrusive or become tiresome.

I really enjoy it. It radiates an incredible amount of optimism, simplicity, and zest for life, and is thus characteristic, as well as in other areas (independence, understatement, blending), of a typical Morillas Freshie, in my view. Here in good mainstream quality. By the way, the aforementioned Fanta feeling was even more prominently continued in the CK Everyone released a year later, there in the classic orange variant. Open up and enjoy!

This flanker has nothing to do with its brothers. Nowadays, flankers can be completely new scents. This should be clear to everyone by now. But how does it smell, the new Gucci for men for the warmer days? Does the path continue in the right direction after the bold "Guilty Absolute"? In my opinion: oh yes! But with many asterisks...

Many people will not like "Guilty Cologne" at all. And some will like it even more. I think I belong to the latter group... It is a scent with guts. Especially when you write the word Cologne in capital letters. A bitter-floral men's fragrance in light. Very woody, very special, totally different and new. Admirable! It has something of one of the lighter versions of Givenchy's "Pi" crossed with "Fleur du Male" and some completely innovative approaches. You have to get used to it. Blind buy recommendations look different. But it stands out so much from the crowd, dares to be different, and thinks outside the box that I find it pretty awesome. Sometimes cacophony, sometimes a stroke of genius. But I definitely lean toward the latter. Violet polarizer. So if you want to explore new paths this summer and don’t want to smell like your ten sidekicks, you have to at least test it. My prediction: cult hit!

Bottle: beautiful, a visual highlight, no wonder it's highly anticipated.
Sillage: due to its uniqueness, it stands out. Sometimes positively. But not always... it’s not really loud, though.
Longevity: only 4 hours, which I find pleasant.

Conclusion: bold, different, ballsy. Gucci is making a statement. I like it. It polarizes and is a very special cologne. Between yuck and wow. But as I said: better than the same old nonsense. Marzipan meets juniper berry. Ice kisses bitterness. Lightning brushes coolness. Those who don’t dare...

I am a fan of Cologne scents, especially in Mediterranean temperatures .. so I tried it today in more Nordic climate conditions. I personally find it has a very harmonious Mediterranean note. Fresh-synthetic is mentioned here, yes it is, but I find it very harmonious. My surroundings and even in Edeka, I was positively approached about the fresh scent. Actually, I usually get...

review_title: "Young one, apply your cream well, the sun is shining!"
review_content:
Here it is again, the rare case where I simply cannot understand why there is so much negative criticism directed at a fragrance. Did I get a good batch? Or do I smell some things differently due to a genetic defect compared to most others? Joking aside, at the end of the day, everyone has their own taste, and mine tells me: Guilty Cologne I like you!

The fragrance comes in a bottle that I find quite successful; I also really liked the one from Guilty Absolute. I just find it elegant and high-quality, even if the cap comes off a bit plastic-like. The juice shines in a light mint green, which, as it turns out, fits well with the fragrance itself.

It starts off aromatic and slightly creamy, totally reminding me of creams like Nivea and Penaten. I can understand that this association may not resonate well with everyone, but to me, it feels somehow calming and clean. For me, light white floral notes are also prominent in the opening, which steer the fragrance in a classic Italian barbershop direction, but not so much that it feels outdated. After the opening, slightly more aromatic and herbaceous nuances join the fragrance; I particularly find the juniper-cypress-rosemary combo really successful, which gives the perfume a slight herbiness. However, the Nivea cream accord remains at the center, which, for me, defines the DNA of the fragrance. I find it surprising that despite the Cologne designation, the fragrance practically avoids the classic Cologne citrus in my nose and fully focuses on its aromatic-fresh creaminess.

In my opinion, Morillas has created a really good fragrance here, which stands out from my image of a classic Cologne due to its Nivea cream DNA while still being suitable for similar occasions. I simply associate the fragrance with sunshine and Dolce Vita tranquility, making it perfect for spring and summer. The longevity and sillage are not outstanding, but in my view, they fit the discussed seasons. Let’s just hope that Gucci dares to experiment a bit more in the spirit of Guilty Cologne and Guilty Absolute, both of which polarize but, aside from the fact that I think they are both great, at least break the mainstream designer fragrance cliché a little and try new paths.

Thanks for reading and see you soon :-)

Guilty Cologne is a wonderful EdT. Designed for summer, it showcases its strengths during this season. It is citrusy, fruity, creamy, fresh, and minimally herbal.

The fruity freshness comes from the bergamot, juniper berry, and rosemary. The creamy note is created by the high-quality smelling (white) musk. Cypress, patchouli, and cedar round off the fragrance and give it a very slight woodiness. The scent reminds me a lot of the Narciso Rodriguez Bleu for Him fragrances. They also have a beautifully balanced freshness, fruitiness, woodiness, and above all, creaminess. I really enjoy this interplay.

Guilty Cologne is not an EdC but an EdT, and it has solid performance: unlike the original Guilty, it lasts 5 to 6 hours with good projection in the first 3 hours. Especially on warm skin or in warm temperatures, it performs great! In general, you can wear this fragrance for any occasion without annoying anyone, and you simply smell clean and as if freshly moisturized. I can really recommend giving it a try.

I acquired this fragrance because I was drawn to the color and the bottle. Due to the many negative reviews, I had no high expectations. And yes, upon the first spray, I initially thought "hmm, something completely different." But not necessarily in a positive way. I find it has a slight lipstick touch like Dior Homme. However, since my wife liked it very much, I continued to wear it and now I wouldn't want to be without it. I think it's great that Gucci remains bold after the daring Gucci Guilty Absolut.

... Gucci that I was very disappointed with. I wore this fragrance and found it wonderfully fresh and citrusy on my skin, and since I have always had good experiences with Gucci, I thought, okay, I'll take it. When I then applied the fragrance properly for the first time, I had to realize that this perfume develops a strong synthetic, artificial unpleasant note after a rather...

This is the second time I've tried this scent, and to put it nicely, I really dislike Envy Me.

In my opinion, it doesn't smell like something I'd imagine Gucci producing. It smells quite cheap and sour. It is in no way original and it's something I'd expect to find in a cheap drugstore, not listed under a famous brandname with an expensive price tag.

The strong opening of pineapple, peony, mango and pink pepper put me right off. These notes never seem to blend well, and in general I'm not usually a fan of pineapple in perfumes to start with.

I was hoping that the heart would be much more pleasant and interesting, but unfortunately the pomegranate and green tea took over and faded out a lot of the softer more delicate notes like the jasmine, rose and musk.

During the drydown I began to smell some improvement, however by that stage I'd already decided that Envy Me wasn't my cup of tea.

For people that honestly enjoy fruity scents, this could be for you. If I had to pick fragrances that I found similar to Envy Me I'd say, Paris Hilton and Baby Doll by YSL.

Nondescript overly sweet tropical fruits strained through some limp aquatic flowers that are straining to reach the sun through a densely-musky, woody-wetland area. The musk is musty and overwhelms everything. The fruit is going stale. The wood is a bit moldy. The flowers are starting to wilt. I've smelled much worse. I've smelled much, much better.

"Mediocrities of the world, I absolve you." ~ Antonio Salieri

The opening starts off with a note of
tangy pineapple drying off with juicy peach and mango with an top drying edges
of Pink Pepper and shy Peony. the drydown is made luscious with Deep Ruby Red Pomegrante and sweet Litchi supported by a powdery rose note the Green tea makes it fresh. there is a note of amber missing i do smell also an faint scent of musk but barely notices it. I love the Flacon design
it's like pink lace from a ladies Lingerie very cute and sexy or conjours
up a Pink bedroom covered with pink rose petals with the intoxicating aroma of pink roses caressing your senses
this perfume represents First Love Innocence and purity if you want a perfume to fit these qualities this is the one.

review_title: Fruit that's been out in the sun a little too long
review_content:
You're a teenager again, stealing a spritz of your older sister’s perfume to feel more mature. As it develops on your skin, you recognise the usual sweet facets you enjoy - but also some notes that stick out and make you scrunch your nose a little.

A juicy and fruity opening, accompanied by refreshing tea and tangy pineapple notes. A little greener than the usual fruity floral fragrance, making it more unique, but all in all a tad too sour for my liking.

I used Envy me from when I was 16 to when I was 19. I really liked it, it's light, floral and sweet and it remember me my past!
It's not so strong so I didn't have any problem with headache.

I wore this fragrance about 10 years ago. I even bought it twice. It was MY scent after my "relationship" with Laura from Laura Biagiotti was over ;))) When I recently smelled it again, it was like a time machine: I was young and carefree again, the future and adulthood were far, far away. It was summer, graduation trip, campfire, tequila, and three guys who wanted something...

Yesterday I went on a sniffing tour and tried this and that. I had no specific idea in mind, so I tested a wide range. "Range" is the keyword, as I paused in surprise at Envy me, because it welcomed me with an attractively familiar scent. The note that spoke to me was the enchanting pipe vine - also known as false jasmine - which I have in my garden. The fragrance is very...

How I love this scent! At first glance, it seems quite simple. But is it really? Peony. Berries. Pomegranate. Musk. But damn, it’s done really well! This scent is pure youth for me! Studying, dorm friendships, borrowing clothes for a date. Quickly stealing some perfume from the roommate. Late-night giggles about boys, God, and the world. Dancing through the nights,...

~ Inspiration ~
I was actually drawn to "Envy Me" by Gucci solely because of its pink design. During a swap, I received a sample to test.

~ Bottle ~
The elongated glass bottle is adorned with a pink mesh pattern of Gucci emblems, which looks like a net to me. The name "Envy Me" translates to "Envy Me".

~ Scent ~
Upon application, it unfortunately has a somewhat synthetic, piercing quality, but it is also very floral and fresh right away. Pineapple, lychee, and pomegranate provide a tart fruitiness. Its intensely floral character comes from lush peonies, water jasmine, and pipe vine. The base notes consist of musk, white tea, sandalwood, and teak wood.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 5-6 hours (a bit longer on clothing and hair). 1-2 sprays are enough for me (even though it’s only an EDT), otherwise it becomes too cloying and scratchy.

~ Occasion ~
A fresh, floral-soapy scent for the mild and warmer days and evenings in spring and summer (when applied subtly, it’s also suitable for the office).

~ Conclusion ~
Due to the pink packaging, I expected a sweeter scent. Overall, it feels too "green" for me. Those who enjoy so-called flower meadow scents should definitely give this one a try :)

Envy Me could never be a signature scent for me, unless you are Surfer Barbie in the flesh. For me, it’s a mood booster. Especially in spring, our relationship noticeably comes to life. With the first spray, lychee and pineapple emerge on a harmonizing floral background, awakening summer longings. The sun rises. Not just any sun, but a Californian one that almost scares you...

"Envy Me" initially smells heavily floral to me, with almost a hint of old flowers (and old flower water) (Somehow I feel like I've been encountering this scent note more often lately...).
Then a very delicate citrus scent emerges, which to me smells like oranges and a touch of vanilla. But when I look at the fragrance notes, it seems to be more about pomegranate and sandalwood.

I find the scent somewhat disappointing; over time it becomes increasingly citrusy and thus too ordinary.
After a little while, it shifts slightly towards a soapy scent, which in this case makes the perfume better.
It is still not something to be envied.

I simply bought the scent after I sprayed it on a fragrance strip. It smelled quite acceptable then. I thought to myself, with Gucci you can't go wrong, the bottle is so pretty... Yes, that's how you deceive yourself - sprayed it on at the next opportunity: well... at first I thought it was the wrong scent I had bought... that wasn't so great after all. Neither fresh nor sweet, it was just a "something" scent that smelled synthetic and artificial...

After I was also approached in the tram by a man: "I THINK YOU'RE USING THE WRONG FRAGRANCE!!!!" it was disposed of... and the day was also ruined.... ;)

Well, you learn from mistakes... now I only test before I buy and do it thoroughly...

...it greets me after the sample appears. Quite aromatic. This scent also lingers for a while. After a few minutes, the top notes settle and the fragrance becomes flatter, more one-dimensional, slightly floral, and also weaker. In this phase, I find it pleasant, but also a bit boring. Not captivating like La Nuit Trésor, not elegant like Chanel No. 19, not warm-spicy and...

I am currently testing Bright Crystal/ Versace and Envy Me/ Gucci side by side and I find it quite boring.
The two sleeping pills could be identical twins, Gucci maybe has a little more of the pomegranate sweetness in the background, but the pineapple is thankfully quickly forgotten. Both fragrances are rather sweet, fruity than floral, completely mainstream and elicit one yawn after another from me.
If I had to choose one, it would be Gucci... but I don't have to.

Conclusion, Gucci, pretty bottle, nice name;
Versace, keep your accords best frosted.

(*Double comment, copied from Antoine)
I loved this scent from the very first moment. Its lightness and freshness transport the senses straight to a warm spring meadow. I really enjoy wearing it.

review_title: 2005, Spring, Summer and then you came …
review_content:
The Envy My called out to me from the display window … well, in 2005 I was a bit younger … well … the elongated bottle, pink Gucci emblem, spring, summer and then you came …
Sometimes it’s funny that when searching for a fragrance or a pair of pants, you end up coming home with something completely different .. well, what can I say. 2005, the scent on my skin and in the shopping bag on my wrist, you practically walked into me… my summer love 2005 …
Just as I must have smelled in that moment, you and the whole world smelled too, namely:
Floral, zesty, sweet, slightly peppery… just like our days began and evenings ended …

I will never forget this spring/summer love with you and Gucci Envy Me

In that moment in 2005, many must have envied me, and not just for this wonderful fragrance …

unfortunately, it doesn't come across as fresh and zesty as I would have expected from the ingredients.
the end result is rather dull.
I can easily imagine it on older women, but personally, I felt too young for it, and it's also not a scent that stands out. With envy me, it's certainly rare for someone to say, "oh, you smell great, what is that?"

This seems to be a very popular fragrance, and while I understand its appeal, I guess I expected something more.

Gucci eau de Parfum II appears to be the perfect Summer choice for the young and extremely feminine. This is your typical pink fruity floral, inoffensive and pleasant.

The opening of Gucci eau de Parfum II is actually quite strong, with the berries and citrus coming to the fore early in the composition. The florals, although present, hardly feature in this fragrance. The fruit certainly dominates.

The heart softens a little into a shampoo-like concoction that is both clean and delicate. Once again it is that 'straight out of the shower' type smell that is replicated here.

The drydown is by far my favourite part, with a musky and subtle berry scent creating a direct comparison to berry flavoured yoghurt. I thoroughly enjoyed this sudden creaminess and I found it to round off the scent nicely.

Although fruity fragrances aren't really my thing, I rather like its 'cuteness', I have to say that this is quite delicious. I'll also add that I found no problem with the lasting power, it lasts considerably well on me.

When I saw the rose-colored box at Karstadt, I immediately headed towards it, as I expected a rich rose scent.

However, I can't detect a rose in this friendly fragrance.

But that doesn't matter, as it exudes elegance paired with joy of life even without this proud flower.

The pink liquid rather points to the delicious blackberry, which is framed by bright jasmine.
A delicate bitterness is added by violet leaf and cedar wood - yet the scent remains cheerful.
The mandarin provides a transparent impression - and sandalwood is soft and creamy.

Gucci II has a certain "everyday chic" - and here subtle elegance and lightness go hand in hand.

Perhaps even combined with a dose of "carefreeness" that one sometimes needs in life.

Pleasant everyday all-rounder.
Intoxicatingly floral and invigorating.
Crispy creamy chic.
Delicately distinguished and decorative.
Uniquely elegant and noble.
Fruity cheerful and fresh.
Grandly graceful and pleasing.
Durable cheerful and woody.
Ideal Italian individuality.
Clear cheeky and delicious.
Tasty fun and airy.
Modern magical and lively.
Naughty-nice and cheeky.
Cleverly sparkling and cute.
Vibrant and lively quality.
Refined romantic and rosy.
Summery sunny and sensual.
Zesty bubbly and full of life.
Turbulent wonderfully dewy fresh.
Alluring vibrating and seductive.
Wonderful spicy and feminine.
Delicate tender and enchanting.

review_title: nice, subtle, unremarkable and yet a bit sassy
review_content:
I wore this fragrance 3 years ago when I was doing various not-so-great side jobs (hostess, extra for TV trash) towards the end of my studies - so I wouldn't wear it again anyway - because it reminds me of that time.
But aside from that: the first impression is a (almost too) sweet, endearing fruitiness. The only conceivable color for this scent is indeed pink.
The top note transitions seamlessly into the heart note. The base is a soft, warm whisper.

The longevity is more like an Eau de Toilette, and the sillage is very modest.

That's it, wave, wave, Gucci II...

review_title: Ange ou Démon Le Secret II?
review_content:
A twin sister of my beloved Givenchy fragrance could be Gucci Eau De Parfum II (or vice versa?). I can't detect any significant differences, only similarities. Both are beautifully delicate fruity-floral, warm and fresh. Both like a gentle scent breeze, sensual and elegant…

The only downside… How does such a light, airy fairy fragrance end up in such a heavy, bulky, and absolutely impractical bottle???... So, no…

This is how I envision Asian elegance. When I spray a bit of the perfume on my skin and take a sniff, I first notice something fruity. The mandarin and orange are the most prominent scents. After a few minutes, the fragrance changes on my skin. It is no longer as clear and fruity, but has transformed into something floral. Violet, jasmine, and blackberries emerge here....

Gucci! Gucci... this name always sounds so "big" and "powerful" in my ears. The bottle IS definitely big and powerful, and I find it very, very beautiful! Unfortunately, only the bottle; the content is not so "powerful," rather fleeting ;-)

After spraying, I am enveloped by a really strong, fruity note. Definitely red berries and massive orange. Contrary to the pyramid, I still smell penetrating, fresh raspberry. These notes remain constant; I do not detect jasmine! The top note does not differ at all from the heart note.
The red berries are a bit too strong for my nose; fortunately, the longevity of this scent leaves much to be desired! The base is hardly recognizable after about an hour... What a pity!

The bottle can stay, at least something!

I acquired this perfume after a long search because Kathleenlights said on YouTube that it was her favorite scent. It was really not easy to find, but the search was worth it.
The fragrance smells really beautifully fruity and fresh. I mostly smell the blackberries and black currants. It is truly different from the other perfumes I own.
When I wear this perfume, I am often asked what it is, and unfortunately, I have to disappoint everyone. I can no longer find the perfume online, so it seems to have been discontinued.

This is truly a perfume that makes you feel good!! At first, you are greeted by blackcurrant, citrus fruits, lemon, and orange. Then, after a few moments, these fruits blend with fruity blackberry and floral-powdery notes of violet, sweet heliotrope, and finally, cedarwood. This perfume is ideal for summer, even when it's hot!! It is not overpowering, but rather light...

....this is how this "berry scent" smells. Who still remembers those beautifully embroidered cushions for the sofa or the once-modern wicker chairs from decades ago?
Floral motifs in rich colors... here we have violets, blue heliotrope, and jasmine. Fruits were also popular for such embroidery. Dark blue blackberries, a bunch of black currants, along with sunny oranges. This creates a beautiful picture and tasteful impressions.
When the cushion fabric is light wood-colored - like cedar and sandalwood - the motifs stand out even more wonderfully. And it is particularly the slightly dominant sweet-bitter fruits that make this parade cushion something special. I really like this "parade cushion scent," as it is somewhat "old-fashioned" yet somehow timeless.
To my nose, it's a bit sweet - but still pleasant to sniff :-))

I long ignored the inconspicuous little bottle. I'm more into flashy things. ;)
Out of boredom, I finally tested it, something without rose, lily of the valley, vanilla, or musk. Great. :)
So, I like it more and more. I find it refreshingly light and delicately floral, just slightly sweet like a delicate ice cream. An ideal summer fragrance! Unobtrusive but charmingly beautiful! Well done, Gucci! :)

P.S.: The color matches the scent, subtle and lightly pink!!

Gucci II is an extraordinary fragrance that conveys understatement. Subtle and fresh; the top note: very fruity (orange, mandarin, currant), top and base note: woody-spicy (cedar wood!) - it is extremely wearable in all situations.
With this scent, a woman simply smells good.

I have the Eau de Parfum II here in the 50ml size for a short time, and I must say, what struck me negatively right away was the, in my opinion, huge bottle.
It really doesn't sit well in the hand and is quite bulky due to its square shape.

But that shouldn't bother me too much, because what is inside the heavy bottle convinced me more.

Right after spraying, I think of fruits, a basket full of forest berries. A citrus note is also clearly recognizable, and even now, you can distinctly sense the spiciness in the base note.
After a while, the flowers become more prominent, but not as strongly as the spice of the base note.

I like the scent itself; it's not a fragrance that immediately reminds me of 50 twins, and yet it is unobtrusive, making it versatile for everyday use.
However, for special occasions or going out in the evening, it would be too 'nice' and pleasing for me.

Listen... I... I'm honestly finding reviews that are over one and a half year old!
I've been buying new samples, doing collections, trying to create a harmonious feed and some fragrances are left behind. Left in the dust!

Bloom Nettare di Fiori has long been sold, I don't have it anymore, so bear that in mind reading the review.
To my surprise, I was yet again lucky and was #gifted two new fragrances. I was allowed to choose freely and even though I should be grateful, I found myself in a difficult situation. The scents I could choose from were almost all florals. You know how I feel about those. I sniffed and sniffed until I got a piercing headache, but ended up choosing Sí eau de parfume and Nettare di Fiori.

Nettare di Fiori is a pure floral fragrance, so you might wonder how I ended up choosing it, but my explanation is quite simple. Nettare di Fiori didn't have any notes that bothered me. It is a lighthearted floral fragrance of white florals, a delicate sweetness and a unassuming elegance. I cannot imagine anyone disliking it with a passion. After dry down on paper, the florals become more nuanced.

On skin, the fragrance is quite nice, not my usual type, but it isn't as bad as I have found designer fragrances to be. Floral, a little nauseating, not too sweet though. After dry down, the scent becomes musky and a little deeper. Powdery from the osmanthus and a little dirty from the patchouli. It has a funny balance of being elegantly mature, but at the same time sweetly juvenile.

I was hopeful, but true to my taste and nature, this floral isn't for me either.

Oh, still uncommented?

My father brought me a sample of this fragrance, and of course, it was immediately tried on my skin. I am not familiar with the other Blooms, so I cannot make a comparison.

I can immediately describe the top note as bright and radiant, likely thanks to the ginger and rose. The combination is quite refreshing, and I feel invigorated. A lovely first impression!

After the radiant start, a soft, rounded tuberose approaches me, wrapping itself around my arm and will not let go for half a day (on clothing, it probably lasts even better!). I am truly not a fan of tuberose, but here it is in harmony with the other two notes (which I can hardly detect) neither too piercing nor too gum-like, but so pleasant and softly floral that I let it be and even have to sniff my arm more often: Yes - I am thrilled, really beautiful! For me, it is the perfect balance between transparent, bright clarity (thanks to the ginger?) and the soft creaminess of this versatile flower. Occasionally, I catch a whiff of my own scent trail and am pleasantly surprised each time by how pleasant, fresh, and well-groomed it smells. A bit vintage, yet somehow in a modern, fresh way.

After about four hours, the tuberose is slowly enveloped in musk, which gives it more softness and depth. Unfortunately, an unpleasant spiciness comes into play for me - I suspect osmanthus here (maybe patchouli is its accomplice?). Because from the radiant, soft flower, it turns into a spicy-creamy-floral mishmash that collapses in on itself and no longer pleases... What a pity, it all started so beautifully?!

Great start, beautiful middle, but unfortunately no happy-end drydown for me. If it weren't for that, this Bloom with its bright, radiant, elegant aura and its modern vintage vibe would be a great office and year-round fragrance.

Today I sniffed my way through the Gucci Blooms, and this one surprised me among the others with its comparatively fine restraint. I had to spray again, get closer with my nose, but what a heavenly scent! Plant-based green but not as cool as Acqua di Fiori. Floral, yet layered (the Ambrosia, on the other hand, smells exclusively of tuberose absolute to me). Lush, slightly sultry, with a light nourishing sweetness (like nectar, or plants you can eat). Still, you are not overwhelmed, nor is anyone around you.
An uplifting, invigorating feel-good fragrance, sensual, without being "perfumey".
Exactly my thing, this little work of art.

Today I just wanted to sniff around at Karstadt in the perfume section, and my husband accompanied me.
A nice gesture from him, as he is a good advisor when it comes to fragrances.
I wanted to let Gucci Blooms pass through my nose and my mind - but not buy it.
But then he kindly offered me Bloom Nettare Fiori, as his eagle eyes had not missed the reduced label.
He has a good selective perception in this regard.
Unfortunately, there was no tester available.

But I always create my own images for the titles - and in my image, I saw a colorful, shimmering hummingbird sticking its beak into an exotic flower to sip the nectar.
That was enough of a buying argument for me.

And at home, with the first spray, the light colorful little bird actually fluttered around me.
Enchanting tuberose rises to my nose, accompanied by soft rose and slightly sharp ginger.
A gentle honey note softens the ginger.
Bright jasmine joins in - and noble osmanthus.
Nettare has an elegant tendency that remains ethereal - and speaks of romance.

A multifaceted, shimmering fragrance - fitting for my hummingbird fantasy.

For lovers of floral scents, Gucci Bloom Nettare di Fiori is just the right choice. Characterized by rose in the top note, followed by fresh jasmine bud in the heart note and accompanied by patchouli in the base note, this fragrance is truly wonderful!
For me, it is an evolution of the classic Gucci Bloom. It is the perfect companion for warm summer days, whether during the day for the office or in the afternoon for a stroll in the city. Anyone who likes roses should definitely try this fragrance.

Currently, I am testing quite a few fragrances, and today it was this one.

In the top note, I mainly smell the rose; I can barely detect the ginger at all. Right after that comes the tuberose, and puuuuh, it is quite strong. In combination with the musk, it gives the fragrance a rather heavy character.

But something is bothering me in the background… a glance at the pyramid made everything clear to me - patchouli. It haunts me. My nose seems to react quite sensitively to it. In every perfume I have tested so far, the patchouli stands out as an unwelcome musty disturbance.

The fragrance is still not bad - but in my opinion, it is also not particularly good. It reminds me more of a scent that older ladies like to wear. The patchouli is for me the final knockout criterion.

What a smell!!!! Considering the price, my opinion gets even worse. It starts with a bit of all three notes listed in the pyramid, none stands out above the others, all are hinted at and do not stand out due to naturalness or other. Subsequently, in the central part an amber accord (sweet enough to be unisex) is increasingly prominent, which already peeked out behind the opening notes from the beginning. It reminded me of certain versions of Playboy. There's a hint of wood coming through in the finish, but it's still the ambroxan that dominates. For the record, orange blossom, nutmeg, Spanish cistus and patchouly are absolutely not noticeable

review_title: A top shelf scent with dollar store longevity
review_content:
Purchased from : N/A
Price Paid : N/A
Do not own
Method : 3x spray on arm or wrist, two different times

This is a pissed off review. This perfume is like a girl that makes you fall for her and even impresses you over the course of 2 or 3 dates, gets your hopes up, and then drops the bomb that she's married.
