I fell in love with this scent (NOT the EDP, NOT the EDT, NOT the Elixir, NOT the Essence...THIS one) at first spray. Guns in both arms, blazing away. CHOOM CHOOM. Double barrel, baby. Then I saw the price. A little disheartened, I searched online. I was ready to pull the trigger on a 6.7oz whopper but I figured I should go back and test it on my skin first.

Scent on my skin was, as on the tester, fantastic. It blew me away. Smells like newly shampooed floor mats in a car along with fresh leather. It smells like you're buying a new car and makes you feel that way too. Or, you had your favorite car completely detailed. Very svelte, very smooth, very bougee.

It stays that way and projects 2" off the skin for the first lap. Zero complaints. Then it fades to an intimate smell around 50 minutes, nearly having to touch the nub of your nose to your hand to get the same strength. I'd be fine with this if it stayed at that strength for another 4 hours, but no, at exactly 2 hours, it fades like a forgotten memory. Sure, even up to hour #3 I can put my nostrils right up and honk my skin to get a scent but even then it's a desperate grab.

I went back today and experienced the same sad longevity.

This might be a worthy purchase in the big bottle if you can get it on sale, and be willing to re-spray every 2 hours. The scent is THAT good. But it is horribly lacking in performance. I am convinced that at retail, this is one of the worst values on the market.

Before you fall in love, test its longevity first - this is an exciting fling, not a marriage.

There I was sat on some hard unforgiving grass. Sat in little to no shade in some random girl parent’s garden, while she struggled to get Lenny Kravitz ‘Let Love Rule’ to play out of some small speakers from her Walkman all the while trying to be cool and nonchalant. At the same time flirting, laughing at all the witty and sardonic quips. Happy hair tossing, all doe eyes and searching questions.

I’m sat bored, awkward, annoyed and ignored. None of this performance was for me. I’m just an accessory.

I’m just sat there waiting for my brother to notice this 90s middle class ingénue and throw the poor girl the attention she’s struggling to get.

I don’t really know if this moment actually happened. I don’t know if it’s part of a lost summer or part of a dream. A shit dream. I don’t really know if I can trust my recollection as there’s factors that deceive and elements that appear as fact.

That is the long winded way of saying that though this iteration of the Guilty fragrance line is pleasant; I can’t trust any part of my experience of it as though parts of it are fine and nice they’re at the same time tediously familiar and banal.

I think this is a good fragrance but it’s not got anything about it that makes me think that there’s a story behind it. It’s creativity via marketing and margins. Ultimately it’s just a thing that is there without any fanfare or deeper presence - I bet when it was launched there was little relief or anxiety about its potential or performance. Just a sniff, and on to the next one.

Also this brings up the image of a white late 80s-early 90s convertible Mercedes E-class. No reason why…maybe that girl’s mum owned one.

Serious, fresh, masculine, pleasant. That's how I would describe this fragrance.
My absolute go-to scent when I want to smell fresh at an event, not intrusive but still present and high-quality/interesting.

Among the initially somewhat (!) citrusy, green-woody scent, a very light sweetness gradually mixes in.
Subtly masculine and, in contrast to other "fresh" perfumes, a bit heavier and not unpleasantly lemony like so many others.

Longevity is good; it is still noticeable in the evening. I would rate the projection as OK.

I can only agree with a statement here: I've never smelled anything comparable - a clear recommendation for anyone who needs a serious scent in their collection that doesn't come off like every other citrus/shower gel fragrance.

review_title: Pleasant Scent in Incredibly Beautiful Bottle
review_content:
The Gucci Guilty pour Homme is a fragrance that is fundamentally solid and nothing more.
I first smelled it in a perfume shop around the corner from me. It was a time when I was looking for a solid designer fragrance that isn't worn by everyone at the Sauvage EAU DE PARFUM level and is well-known. When I came across Gucci Guilty, I first had to get an overview of which version appealed to me the most. When I encountered the bottle of Guilty for the first time, I was blown away by its beauty. I don't know what it is, but I love this bottle. The fragrance I want to discuss in more detail has a typical designer characteristic.
Right! It is pleasing. Since I started wearing Gucci Guilty, I've been receiving compliments. Not because the scent is extremely good or has a mega sillage, no no. You simply smell pleasantly good and well-groomed with it, without being intrusive. The fragrance notes blend well together. Personally, I perceive the Italian lemon the strongest, but not in a sour form. Paired with the dry woods in the base, it feels much earthier and slightly sweet, like sweetened lemon tea.
Feel free to let me know if I could help you with this review. Have a nice day.

After the EDT captivated me, I was looking forward to the perfume released in 2022. However, I also wanted to test the Eau de Parfum (2020) to have a comparison. So I sprayed the perfume on my right hand, and disappointment followed immediately. I couldn't perceive a single one of the listed fragrance notes. The first impression leaned more towards aquatic, synthetic. Even as...

So much in advance: It was my first and only one from the Guilty line, so there are no comparisons to the EdT and EdP. Since there isn't much to say, I thought it was time for my first more detailed text. As a direct comparison, Versace pour Homme Dylan Blue EAU DE TOILETTE had to suffice to better categorize it. Let's get started, the bottle: Simply designed,...

review_title: Nice Frangrance – especially for autumn and winter
review_content: I was looking for a nice new fragrance dedicated for autumn and winter and came across to test the new Gucci Guilty pour Homme intense – result: I am excited about this scent. I cannot understand some of the previous comments, but I have to admit, that I cannot compare to previous Gucci fragrances. I am quite fond of the orange scent in combination with a strong sweetness and some enigmatic dry impressions. On my skin, this results in a nice and harmonious combination. It lasts medium if not long. My impression is that this fragrance is decent enough to wear it in the office, but nasty enough in order to make it interesting in comparison to some other "classical" men´s fragrances. Can of course also be used in other seasons...

review_title: An Improvement on the Original Gucci Guilty
review_content:
I honestly did not enjoy the original Gucci Guilty pour Homme. I found it a little too sour and strong, at which point I warned my boyfriend to never buy a bottle of it for so long as we were together.

I approached this Intense flanker with an air of trepidation. My fingers were crossed behind my back, and my painkillers close by just in case. Thankfully this is a far better fragrance than the original. It's strong, but nowhere near as overwhelming as Gucci Guilty pour Homme.

It's a slightly more improved composition. The lemon and orange blossom accords are less sharp, and the lavender appears to be much smoother. Amber has also been added to this flanker, along with a masculine and spicy coriander note.

I hope this fragrance isn't a limited edition. I'll most likely scream if they discontinue this and keep the sharp, messy Guilty pour Homme on the shelves.

Don't let the 'intense' fool you, as it is not as bold or overpowering as you might expect it to be. The sillage is strong, however it won't knock you out. It's still a pleasant and wearable fragrance. It has my tick of approval.

Original review written: November 2012.

This is Guilty pour Homme EAU DE TOILETTE with an ambery and chocolatey patchouli base.
I wouldn't call it totally generic, but it's been done before, it's sort of in the style of the original formulation of Black XS EAU DE TOILETTE - it's a pretty good twist on the Guilty DNA overall.

All year-round and every occasion (maybe not the dressiest, because it can come across as playful), has great longevity (I could clearly smell it after 7-8 hours) and the projection is moderate to heavy for about 2 hours.

Just like most discontinued fragrances, it's not worth the inflated price, but if you can find it for the original retail price or under, it might be worth a shot.

review_title: Reformulate 3 more times and maybe it will be in a good range
review_content:
After last week’s test where Gucci Guilty performed very poorly, yesterday it was Guilty Intense’s turn, which I had heard much better things about than the original... and it is better, but still far from good, still Gucci and unworthy of the price.

It is a mediocre autumn/winter scent, very gourmand and much sweeter and thicker than the original, which is the right direction. It reminds me somewhat of Joop’s Splash, which also combines freshness with strong sweetness/gourmand... but even here, I don’t like it well enough to buy or recommend it. Lemon & orange are nice, but mixed with the freshness somehow robbed of their essence. Fresh food is delicious, and food by the sea can be great, but food already half in the sea? No, not really^^

In this price range, there are far better alternatives and scents for the cold days, even if the bottle, sillage, and longevity are decent to very decent. It’s a shame that Gucci Pour Homme 1 is hardly available in Germany anymore; then I could compare quality with mediocrity well... I hope Gucci gets back on the right track!

That the brand Gucci, which once really brought appealing fragrances to the market, is sinking deeper into the abyss is nothing new. Perhaps the sales figures and the design of the bottles are right, but the content gets worse with each scent.

So it is with a bad premonition regarding the Guilty pour Homme offshoot Intense. I have no idea what is supposed to be intense here; apparently, they have mixed in intense amounts of powdered sugar, because this nasty powdery sweetness is unfortunately no longer a minor offense.

There is no trace of a citrusy opening, as the top and heart notes might suggest. After a few minutes, the base note arrives with a botched patchouli-wood-amber-vanilla mishmash that quickly evaporates uninspired until the end.

They could just as well have poured the content into a pink bottle. Perhaps the same is even in the female version - I wouldn’t be surprised.
For a drugstore scent under 10 €, I wouldn’t say anything, but for a Gucci product, I find it quite cheeky.

In any case, I am suing Gucci Guilty pour Homme Intense for the following criminal acts:

Label fraud
Fraudulence
Consumer deception
Olfactory bodily harm
Defamation of a global brand

Other witnesses are kindly invited to come forward …

No, I don't want to say anything against American shopping malls. Nor do I mind that they have increasingly taken over in Germany. When I smell "Guilty pour Homme Intense," I imagine an expensive, idyllic example full of well-groomed boredom: golden railings, marble paneling, a splashing fountain, tinkling easy-listening piano music ... life is beautiful! The scent is...

As some users have already mentioned before me, I wouldn't call this fragrance INTENSE!

It is not necessarily more intense than its predecessor, but rather goes in a completely different direction!

Right from the start, you can clearly perceive coriander, closely followed by orange scents...

However, a distinct sweetness is also present, without coming across as too heavy!
In my opinion, the greatest characteristic of this fragrance lies in its versatility... While some other Intense fragrances can be very heavy and are mainly intended for cold days, this one is welcome in almost any season!

Gucci Ambrosia di Fiori is a perfume made by Morillas and his mastery in creating light perfumes made it possible for him to create an airy tuberose coupled with rose and a new note: Rangoon Creeper. This elegant airy tuberose is accompanied by the refinement of powder by the rose and the rangoon creeper. If you are interested into hearing more details about this perfume, please watch my review on Youtube, together with other perfumes I find appropriate for weddings.

review_title: Tuberose in its most beautiful form
review_content:
"Opulent" is one of those terms that rarely appears in my vocabulary - perhaps because I have always understood it to have a slightly negative connotation: too rich, too exuberant, lavish abundance... Despite these associations, "opulent" describes the fragrance very accurately, and certainly in a positive sense!

The scent is linear and very "dense" - like a walk through a lush flower garden in summer. Framed by trellises adorned with plump, white blooms, a narrow path winds through the sea of flowers. The sun shines warmly from the sky, the air is humid, and one feels as if they are drowning in the sweet floral scent. Yet in the center of the garden stands an iron fountain, providing a bit of the refreshing relief one hopes for and inviting you to linger.

Performance and intensity are very good. The fact that the fragrance does not develop significantly on my skin does not detract from it; it remains rich and floral until the end. Tuberose and jasmine dominate and create a beautiful, opulent unity. A hint of green freshness prevents the scent from becoming too heavy. More of a fragrance for warm months, but I have already worn it even now in December.

The scent is exuberant, full, opulent - but that is precisely what gives it its charm. My favorite from the Bloom line.

review_title: The Floral Scent When You're (No Longer) in the Mood for Flowers
review_content:
With floral scents, you really can't lure me out from behind the stove anymore. Once my favorite fragrance direction, I now find many floral scents simply boring. A bit overdone.

That's why my expectations were low here. I got a sample and thought to myself, I'll spray it on, write a statement, and then shower late in the morning, so it doesn't matter if the scent gets washed away.

But then the green fairy appeared :D No, I didn't open a bottle of absinthe; I sprayed on the Gucci. A sea of floral scent at its finest. I once had a floral scent that smelled like a flower shop. But not in a good way. In some flower shops, it smells so organically pungent. That's not the case here. Here, it's just beautifully floral.

After a while, maybe a quarter of an hour, the jasmine comes through. Then you have a really lovely jasmine tea-like scent that is neither too sweet nor too bitter, but just right.

It makes you want flowers again :)

Smells like a wonderful jasmine tea. However, the bitterness is softened by the sweetness of the rose notes. A very intense, room-filling but pleasant fragrance. Longevity and sillage are truly above average. I love it, I think it will be my new "signature" scent. The thought that others will remember this fragrance when they think of me would definitely be nice.

I perceive the jasmine scent very strongly... actually all the time.

After 2 hours, nothing changes... I still smell jasmine, sometimes lighter, sometimes more intense....
Unfortunately, I notice no transition from top to base note... monotonous jasmine, which becomes very exhausting and unpleasant over time.

With a lot of imagination, it tells me this "baby-rose-hint of scent: 'Hello, I’m somewhere there....'

The price is great, intensity very good, lasts a long time and activates more or less (that’s my perception).

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_title: A sporty cologne that deserves a place on the shelf
review_content:
Many find this fragrance bland, boring and unoriginal, a scent that didn't live up to the expectations set by the original Gucci by Gucci pour Homme. I don't agree. I find Gucci by Gucci Sport a deliciously refreshing scent, perfect for hot Summer days and sporty activities.

This fragrance opens with a watery burst of fizzy grapefruit, mint and greenery. It reminds me slightly of cooling cucumber, however it may be the cypress that makes me feel this way.

The sillage is moderate, so it doesn't overpower. It just lingers softly on the skin, catching whiffs of it here and there.

I like the sporty concept, although for some I know, they find it too predictable and overdone. Let's just say that I live with a man that frequents the gym quite regularly, and when he wears heavy deoderants or colognes it makes him smell absolutely repulsive. However lighter scents, like Cool Water by Davidoff, Hei by Alfred Sung and fragrances like this one, last the duration of the workout and don't clash with a male's natural perspiration.

The cardamon, ambrette seeds and patchouli gives this fragrance a wonderfully grounded earthiness. However for those that detest patchouli, I guarantee that in this fragrance it does not dominate. The scent remains fresh and light throughout the composition.

Gucci by Gucci Sport keeps growing on me. Its clean, menthol-like scent, makes me long for the hot weather and hot men. Cheeky I know, it's the fragrance doing the talking, not me I swear.

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
Gucci by Gucci Sport is possibly the worst Gucci scent I’ve ever tried so far. It’s unbelievable how cheap and sad this brand has become, at least for the perfumes (thanks, Frida!). Well, anyway, if you’re nonetheless curious about how it smells and the term “utter crap” is not clear enough... basically as the name suggests, this is a shallow, cheap, metallic and conventional “sport” scent, so imagine plastic citrus notes, synthetic woody-norlimbanol base notes, a sort of aromatic-herbal accord between the two, random ozonic whiffs. Nothing more, nothing less than a deodorant. As much fresh as tacky. Pathetic.

3/10

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
Im sorry but i can't stand this fragrance. Extremely synthetic with a harsh fig note that's too loud.

Lasting power is weak. Good sillage in the first minutes, then fades out.

Updated January 2014

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
Utterly gorgeous , Fresh , Natural , Green and Light. If you like fresh bitter green perfume with fig note, you will like this one. It smells so good and very pleasant. This is my first perfume by Gucci in my collection and I'm so glad that I have it in my collection. It opens up with like fresh bitter citrusy, green , slightly spicy and fig notes in the background then dry down is green musky. The Cypress and The fig notes are dominant in this fragrance. It is suitable for the spring and summer. I really enjoy it and I like Gucci by Gucci Sport EDT for Men. Longevity is average.
Thumbs Up.
Rating : 7.5 / 10

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_title: Gucci by Gucci Sport Pour Homme
review_content:
I only came across a Gucci perfume by chance, as I found it in a sale. I then smelled the perfume in the store and was blown away by the very citrusy scent. At first, I couldn't quite decide because in the store, when I sprayed it, it couldn't fully develop due to the store being a bit overheated (in my opinion). Anyway, I then wandered around the city a bit more and found it very good after it had unfolded.

The perfume is suitable for any occasion and is especially pleasant to smell in spring/summer. It also does not come across as overpowering. The components or the transitions from top, heart, and base notes are quite fleeting, which I find a bit unfortunate. I also would have wished for the perfume to last a bit longer or to be a bit more concentrated. However, the sport designation on the bottle is well-deserved in my opinion. Overall, I find the bottle very beautifully designed and would also be happy if Gucci would continue to keep the perfume, which is probably not the case :(

So go to the store and at least give it a try. But I would strongly suspect that anyone who does not like the CHANEL ALLURE HOMME SPORT perfume would not like this one either.

So give it a try, as long as it is still available online or in your stores :)

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_title: Very weak! Completely gone within 2 hours...
review_content: Normally, I am not a fan of citrus fruits at all. You really can't assign a more boring note to a fragrance. With this beautiful, heavy, and also noble bottle containing the chic green liquid, I ended up being deceived by the appearance. By now, the scent has taken on the character of a so-called "... must be used up quickly" EDT for me. The reason is the incredibly weak...

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
"Gucci by gucci sport pour homme" starts pleasantly fresh with a subtle, well-measured lemon or grapefruit note. Even the slight acidity inherent in the citrus fruits has made its way into the stylish bottle this time, giving this EdT an authentic and noble entrance in its first minutes.
Unfortunately, that’s where the good times end. A cheap cypress aroma sets in. The scent becomes dull, and after 10 minutes, the lemon smells like toilet cleaner. Now it smells like an average 0815 scent from d&m. Not bad, not headache-inducing. Nevertheless, it certainly does not live up to the luxury image of the Gucci brand or its exorbitantly high price.

Re-launched as a new replay or banana scent for 20 euros, it would be a fair offer and surely a bestseller.

As expensive as it is now, it’s just a quick money grab with a trendy logo. And nothing more.

After 20 minutes, I sniffed again: still smells like lemon dish soap. I guess nothing will change from here on out.

Conclusion: Don’t let yourself be led by the nose!

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
I really have to emphasize this:
A long time ago, the lemons
(I just don’t remember exactly when
this was) were as sweet as rock candy.

Until one day they said: "We lemons,
we want to be as big as melons!
Also, we find the yellow disgusting,
we want to be red or bluish!"

God heard the complaints from above
and said: "Nothing can come of this!
You must stay as you are! I regret!"
Then the lemons turned sour . . .

Heinz Erhardt

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
When will perfumers and labels ever realize that a "sport fragrance" can work without grapefruit and lemon, and possibly ONLY without these ingredients, in the sense that it remains memorable and is not arbitrary and interchangeable.

Money-making. An upscale label like Gucci puts "Sport" in the name and probably sells the stuff like crazy. It's jumping on a bandwagon. Well, perfume is also a business, and I suppose they are entitled to that. For a manufacturer that has created timeless classics with "Gucci pour Homme" and (especially) "Gucci Nobile," this pandering attempt is, for me, embarrassing. Anyone who wants to smell good at the gym can find something equally good for significantly less money.

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
Enough has been mourned for the old Guccis, and rightly so, I have also torn apart Gucci by Gucci and the new Made to Measure. Both disappointed me so much that I left the Sport version aside for a long time. At some point, I thought that it must be as forgettable and similarly terrible as its brothers, that I must have forgotten my own test. Until today, when I found nothing unfamiliar in the store and checked again whether I had really had it under my nose. And there it was, I had not. But better late than never, here is my test.

GbG Sport definitely takes advantage of my extremely low expectations and presents itself much better than the other new Guccis. If I liked figs, this somewhat more upscale, noble athlete would even deserve a good rating. But again, I do not like this extremely green note, fortunately, it is just one of many notes.

GbG Sport starts with a juicy-green, slightly sour grapefruit. It also has a very slight woody undertone of cypress. Then the fragrance becomes more serious and even more suitable for everyday wear, with the fig coming in, beautifully complemented by berries and cardamom. It’s not a power fragrance and there’s no Aha effect, but it is definitely the best Gucci men’s fragrance of the last few years. The scent ends in a slightly powdery musk-vetiver clearing, which emphasizes the green-spontaneous character of the fragrance once again.

The bottle remains top-notch and is so beautiful and heavy that one wishes the scents would come close to it. Sillage is hardly present, longevity is about 6 hours.

But the fragrance is worth testing and is a successful all-rounder, which only suffers a bit from fig-minus points for me. On the other hand, Gucci was not quite as banal and cowardly here as with Guilty and Co.

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
Hm. Perhaps it can be said that the strongest sports wave of summer 2013 is over, although there are still some latecomers arriving, such as Freedom Sport. And so this comment might be a bit behind as well. But for summer 2013, I’ve let quite a few scents pass through my nose, including GbGpHS. (oops, long abbreviation, but what can you do :D)

All in all, this Gucci is indeed elegant and fresh. It might have something special. You could say it’s lemon dish soap, but a special lemon dish soap that shimmers in its own colors.

At the beginning, the scent is truly refreshing. Fresh and fruity is the opening. Cypress and grapefruit, however, seem almost a bit sticky, I would say. The freshness comes through quite well, but it leans towards being a bit cloying. The opening might actually be the best part of the fragrance, as it is quite multifaceted. The fruits seem to bubble over and glow in synthetic neon pastel colors.

Unfortunately, the further development of the scent is not really lovingly crafted. It becomes more robust and masculine, a bit sturdier, okay. But in the end, it just falls apart. Patchouli is really different. And wanting to incorporate patchouli into such a summer-fresh scent, well, I don’t know, it just doesn’t quite fit in my nose.

Overall, you can’t really go wrong with this scent. It doesn’t clash anywhere. The sillage also contributes its part. There’s no significant projection, maybe the first half hour to hour, but I’m not paying this price for that. It’s really a bit excessive.
The longevity doesn’t fare well either. 4 hours, and then it’s already over, and the scent might just pass as a nice laundry detergent for the clothes you’re currently wearing.

The bottle, on the other hand, is, I assume, the engine of the sales figures. It’s really delicate, elegant, and tasteful.

In principle, I don’t want to completely condemn the scent. There’s an effort for elegance. But it’s only an effort. The scent has potential but gets lost halfway and doesn’t reach its destination. However, the versatility is truly worth highlighting. Versatility: AAA

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
When I was in London in 2017, I sniffed through a few perfumes again. It was one of the warmest summers I have experienced, so I stepped away from my gourmand preferences and looked for something fresh.

I am a fan of the classic Acqua di Gio and find Gucci Sport quite similar, just a bit more citrusy than Armani's classic. I can't necessarily pick out the juniper berry or the other notes. I can smell grapefruit, cypress, and patchouli. Of course, you don't have much time for the fragrance to develop, more on that shortly.

The bottle looks interesting and especially the heavy cap is really very solid and made of metal. The spray head is also well-made; after several years of use, nothing has worn out. Great!

What is unfortunately not so great is the performance. This fragrance unfortunately does not project strongly even right after application, and even on my skin, I can't smell it after 1-3 hours, let alone in the air. If Gucci could improve this, it would really have a great, citrusy fragrance in an interesting bottle for summer!

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content: After testing "Made to Measure," it was time for Gucci Sport, and I have to say, this one is leagues better than the former! Here, the cardamom is perfectly highlighted by citrus fruits and, in this case, also by cypress. Over time, the scent develops a somewhat masculine character, but the freshness of the cardamom remains ever-present, which is great for me because I love...

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
I was fooled in the store by a fleeting test. It smelled zesty lemony. Also somehow like Yuzu. That matched the green color.
I then wrote it on my Christmas wish list and received it as a gift.
However, I was ultimately disappointed. Because the lemony scent was just an illusion. It seems to be temporarily triggered by other things, the lemony impression. With the fig, I don't know whether to like it or not. I feel this way about the whole perfume.
It would benefit from an additional, not too sour, not too sweet lemon, as that would reduce the rather peculiar character of the fig.
What really bothers me is the peppermint smell. It smells like older peppermint tea in a Tupperware cup with a lid that has been there for a while.... I often experienced that in school ;)
Without this mint, I would like it much more.
The perfume made me think of certain things right away in the first hours: elitist and arrogant.
Somehow it has an aloof quality. Which is neither meant positively nor negatively.
Longevity and sillage are once again outrageous. You need about 10 sprays to smell it for 45 minutes.
The bottle is super beautiful but somehow has a wannabe elite vibe. That has been quite well achieved ;)
It's almost like a parody. This bottle and then the content. Also, the much too light, shallow content does not match the heavy appearance.
Conclusion: one probably needs to test much more intensively before buying or wishing for something.

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content: Anyone who has read my reviews in the past knows how much I love sport fragrances and everything that comes with the new citrus trend. Sport fragrances are as classy as an air freshener in often not-so-quiet places or a scent tree for the car. And now Gucci comes up with such an idea. But who cares, if everyone jumps on the fashion train, then Gucci has to join in...

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_title: At least the green-red stripes look sporty
review_content:
... on the beautiful rubberized white travel spray bottle and the packaging.

Everything else regarding the scent has nothing to do with sports.

It starts with bitter grapefruit and (green) mandarin with cypress. Everything still feels a bit immature and green behind the ears.

The base scent, on the other hand, consists of a green-woody-herbaceous-bitter fig/peppermint tea mixture, with synthetic lemon as an accompaniment. The tea has been sitting for a few days, and not everyone will like the fig. A certain synthetic quality resonates throughout the fragrance, of course.

The opening is citrusy-bitter-sweet, which lasts only a short time but is still the best part of the scent.

But that likely deceived many at first glance, myself included.

No, the fragrance is unfortunately truly not a masterpiece.
It is also not really citrusy fresh.
That is simply incorrect.

Longevity and sillage are not great and can be described as poor.

After a short time, it can only be perceived up close.

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
Gucci is my favorite brand when it comes to fragrances. I may not have tried them all, but I find all their scents excellent. Well, I don't know the ones before Rush (1999). However, the rest completely convinces me, the regular Gucci by Gucci is my favorite scent at the moment.
I could hardly wait to test the sporty successor. Finally, it was released, and I rushed to the store and sprayed it on.
Well, I am disappointed. The Sport version does not smell bad in the sense of being repulsive, but the scent is quite modest, simple, and artificial. I detect a weak citrus top note and then a fruity fig accord. Nothing more comes after that. It is a light and fruity fragrance, carefree and good for summer, but a drugstore scent like Puma can surely do that too. Rush, Gucci PH 1 and 2, as well as Envy were truly special fragrances that stood out from the crowd with their concept and also smelled great. These scents were/are made for men, while GbG Sport smells like a teenager. GbG Sport is at best mediocre and simply boring. It's a shame, because Gucci usually brings much stronger offerings to the market and not such weak fruity waters.
If you're looking for a sporty scent, you’d be better off checking out Dior Homme Sport or Chanel Allure Homme Sport, which are made much better, last longer, and in my opinion, are also more mature.
Better luck next time, Gucci!

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_title: It has something ... even if I don't know what.
review_content: Gucci Sport pour Homme recently wafted towards me fresh and full of energy, yet it initially gave me a "What on earth is this?" impression. The almost forced and contrived freshness of the fragrance made me pause for a moment. However, the scent develops quite well, becoming really pleasant after a while, slightly fruity, and distinctly masculine. It feels energetic and...

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
Testing this fragrance was a challenge for me, somehow every sports scent has disappointed me so far.
So I only have one question: Can Gucci save the honor of sports, or will it fade into the insignificance like so many other sports fragrances??
The top note of this fragrance makes a nice start; I detect a light grapefruit-lime scent, which is not listed but I can clearly pick it out. The aroma is citrusy, but it excites me much more than what I usually smell in sports fragrances.
After about half an hour, the juniper and fig come out and cover the top note, which I find a bit disappointing because I liked it. But hey, that's how the fragrance develops; overall, I would describe the heart note as fruity and slightly sweet, but only very lightly.
This note fades after about 2 hours, and the scent settles into a slightly earthy vetiver blend, where I can faintly perceive the lime that I have been missing for the past 2 hours.

All in all, one can say that Gucci has managed to save the honor of sports, even though the fragrance has the usual Gucci trait of being very close to the body, the longevity of 3-5 hours is not impressive, and the heart note ruins the entire fragrance.
I would recommend the fragrance for students and office workers, for daily use; you can't really go wrong with it, almost everyone will like it. It doesn't overpower a room but stays close to the body, and it shows style that you don't wear a generic scent.

The bottle is one of the most beautiful I have ever seen; neither glass nor metal has been spared here, it is a real gem for any bathroom or vanity.

All in all, I give it 80%, as it does a lot right, but for my taste, it stays a bit too close to the body, the heart note doesn't quite fit into the fragrance development (but it doesn't disturb), and it has managed to convince me despite the name sports.
I thought again about my rating and decided that it is a bit too high; the fragrance is still a great thing, but I find 80% a bit too high when compared to other fragrances that receive 80% from me. It is still a great scent and remains one of my recommendations for purchase.

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
I received a sample of Gucci Sport pour Homme while shopping at my perfume store.

First impression: Fresh, has something!
The fruity grapefruit/tangerine freshness comes through immediately. From start to finish, there is a lightly spicy background present, although the fruity note always dominates.
I can't smell the patchouli from the base note, but I could be mistaken.

Second impression: Boring!
Somehow, the scent doesn't really develop and smells quite unremarkable. The 08/15 fragrance for everyone. Please don't get me wrong: it never smells bad or anything, but it clearly has too little character for me.

Recommendation to buy? No! Gifted, but certainly wearable, as it is never unpleasant.
For me, it lacks punk rock!

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_title: The bottle definitely looks very, very elegant!
review_content:
My father has been using this fragrance for some time now and I have to say that I find it quite brilliant as well. It is not particularly special, but it serves its purpose as an everyday scent, as well as an evening fragrance. I actually find the fresh top note with which the scent starts to be the most successful, it's a pity that it settles so early on my skin. The drydown is very pleasant and I don't find it at all overpowering. As for the longevity, it is really sufficient. On me, the scent lasts a good 6 hours, which isn't too long when compared to other brands and fragrances.
In my eyes, it is not a pure summer scent, as it is too spicy for that, but I also have a different idea of what a classic summer fragrance should be like. However, I must say that it works absolutely well in autumn and winter ;)

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content:
... am walking with my dogs. It is still warm and we pass by some pear trees that are exuding their wonderful aroma. A branch with pears is hanging over the garden fence, and I am cheeky enough to grab one. Just then, an older lady comes from the other side of the fence and says, "Please take as many as you like; I can't eat them all by myself." Caught, I turn red and apologize, and she says, "I was serious; I have way too many." So, I take a few more and thank her.

When I apply this fragrance, the first thing I notice is pears, even though they are not listed in the fragrance pyramid. There are also citrus and green notes. A bit of spiciness comes through as well. The patchouli adds a fresh touch, and the vetiver gives it a slightly dry quality.

The longevity and sillage are average.

This is a fragrance that can be worn by any age group. On warmer days, it is a lovely scent for the office, school, or even for sports. I can also imagine a sporty woman wearing this fragrance.

If you enjoy a fresh, citrusy, dry scent, this would be a good choice, even if this fragrance from Gucci has been discontinued.

product_name: Gucci by Gucci Sport pour Homme
review_content: If Gucci thinks that a piece of fabric soaked with 0.071 ml is enough for a sample, of which at least 50-75% will evaporate anyway, then I also think I can write something about this sample here :-) So what is my impression? Quite pleasant, strong, almost heavy for a sport fragrance. A powdery, tangy citrus note. I suspect that I can smell the grapefruit and vetiver the most....

Gucci Rush for Men is so good that it's one of the few discontinued fragrances that truly deserves a comeback.

Gucci nowadays has almost nothing interesting in their fragrance line for men. Guilty Absolute, that offers a woody-leather experience and the underrated Guilty Cologne are probably the only ones that i can recommend. But back in the late 90's and early 00's, Tom Ford was in charge and put some ideas on the table.

One of the best examples was this fragrance. A woody fragrance composed by Antoine Maisondieu and Daniela Andrier. Two great perfumers who created some great fragrances throughout the years. They joined again later for Bottega Veneta pour homme, another great woody-leather fragrance with pine needles upfront.

This one was launched in the beginning of the new millennium and followed a new genre of woody masculines. The milky nuance is, I believe, popularized by Feu D'Issey in '98 but doomed because it was a feminine release. This time, the milky sandalwood was joined by Cedar and Cypress with a musky finale.

Seems and feels simple, and it really is, but in a beautiful and comforting way. A second skin experience. There's definitely Iso E Super here, supporting the woods and along with the musk, helping the increase of longevity. Very dry and fresh woody fragrance with milky nuances.

The opening has light green cypress leafs and echos of Encre Noire. Both have cypress and iso E super so the comparison is logical, but this is more milky, creamy and more musky. Also more rounded and second skin-like. They just have a similar woody-new wave style.

After the opening, it mellows a bit, tuning down the cypress and cedar note and increasing the musk one. It turns into a beautiful sensual milky musk with a masculine (and new at the time) woody trail. It doesn't last long (3-5h usually) and doesn't project great, but it acts like a sexy skin scent and i like that.

It's something that i can see in the niche world easily, cause it's very conceptual and avant-garde at the time. One fragrance that has some similarities is Azzaro Visit but that one is more sweet and it lacks the beautiful musk note. And it doesn't have the green cypress. It's more a alternative on a budget.

And speaking about the price, this is ultra expensive nowadays due to its discontinuation. So I can't recommend you for those prices. But if you find this under 90€/100ml I would pick it up. It's good, unique, sexy, avant-garde and it comes in a beautiful retro plastic and metallic bottle that seems like it came from the 80's.

Overall, a beautiful woody scent that i will miss when I finish my bottle. Luckily, I still have +90ml of juice to enjoy!

4/5

If they asked me that the smell could have the future, this fragrance would come to mind. It seems an essence that has come to us with the capsule of time, it seems to have come out of the Scream video by Michael and Janet Jackson, starting from the bottle, a parallelepiped made of plastic and white metal, which recalls so much the purity, and the modern minimalism of the perfume, a bottle that looks like it looks like the packaging of the first iPods, born a few years later. After the 2000s, Gucci churned out three important masterpieces, Gucci pour homme, Gucci Envy and Gucci Rush for Man, the latter notch above his siblings.
It opens with very aromatic and sophisticated woods, almost soft and creamy, however creamy a wood could be, Mysore sandalwood, Bois d'Okoumé and juniper blend with an incense base, white musks, patchouli and lavender that makes the fragrance slightly powdery, clean, modern and slightly lactaginous. A woody-spicy, all the ingredients are clear, limpid, bleached, the perfume plays on the white color, on soft geometries, on neutrality, with a futuristic concept, very linear, aseptic but at the same time relaxing, comforting, beautiful, young, suitable for any occasion, hyper-versatile, in any context, I can't find a time of year where to place it, but I would avoid the hot months.
In the perfume there is also the touch of Tom Ford and you can see (and hear) and coincidentally many indelible scents of past years have his signature. For just this reason, every perfume collector should have this piece of history, or rather, this fragment of the future.

9.5 rating

The year 2000 seems to me, in retrospect, not to have been a particularly exciting time in terms of perfume. In the men's sections of perfumeries, aquatic scents were all the rage alongside the classics; CK One and Be were still selling quite well, while the rest got lost in the Fougère dead end. However, I spent a total of about twelve minutes per year in perfumeries back then, so my depiction of a historical review may not hold up entirely. Had I stumbled upon Rush at that time, I would surely have picked it up, but I don't recall seeing it back then. Today, the last bottles of Rush are being offered for a lot of money on eBay; I was lucky enough to acquire it for a relatively moderate sum.

I wouldn't pay the prices being asked on eBay, but I can understand why it has a loyal following, as even today there are very few fragrances that have a similar vibe. Rush is a woodsy scent with a lot of incense, but unlike the retro scents Envy and Gucci Pour Homme that also emerged from Tom Ford's Gucci era, it feels very contemporary and modern. Typical of its time yet not retro in feel, perhaps because the era was anti-retro, looking forward with anticipation.

Rush is first and foremost a rush of speed. The hyper-dynamic opening is among the best I have ever experienced; like a blindingly bright tornado, this scent engulfs me in the first hour. Ice-cold incense, musk, and a blueberry note that I don't see mentioned anywhere else are at the center, soon joined by the coniferous wood accord that I will describe in more detail shortly. Rush does not come across as synthetic in my nose; nevertheless, it is not a forest scent. If the opening of Rush had a sound, it would be that of a lightsaber being activated. I mean this quite positively, as this scent is not aggressive; it conveys a pleasant inner tension, a go-for-it! mentality that I find pretty cool.

When I think of wood and incense, I immediately think of Comme des Garçons, who often explore both themes, and without a doubt, Rush could be a scent from CdG. There is even a CdG fragrance that Rush is often compared to: Wonderwood. Anyone familiar with both scents will hardly be able to overlook the similarities, even though they are quite different. What unites them is the distinctive wood accord, particularly based on cedar, cypress, and sandalwood; both fragrances also contain incense and patchouli. Perhaps some may know this: when you pile up mulch, leave it overnight, and then poke it the next morning, a resinous, ethereal steam escapes, very woody but not dry, rather incredibly fresh and a bit oily. The YouTube reviewer Kristo once described this in relation to Wonderwood as "stardust soaked in motor oil." Both fragrances perfectly capture this scent for me. However, Wonderwood is darker, not as transparent as Rush, and also more monothematic; Rush, on the other hand, has a clearly defined development with distinct phases.

The ethereal-woody heart dominates most of the scent's progression. The scent cloud's reach is rather limited but persistent; it won't fill halls, but within its aura, this fragrance is quite dominant. Gradually becoming a bit darker, it still feels effervescent, fresh, and absolutely optimistic; it also conveys a vibe that is not necessarily sensual but certainly hedonistic. Woody scents are often dry, dark, and sometimes even gnarly, but this fragrance is never so, despite its pronounced woodiness. When I wear Rush, I do so because I feel decisive, spontaneous, and confident.

The longevity is quite okay, typical for an EdT at around seven hours, sometimes less. The base is characterized by very soft sandalwood, contrasted by musk and patchouli, both absurdly clean, which keeps this fragrance uplifting until the end. I really enjoy the varied progression of Rush; it follows a clear red thread without becoming boring. And hey: it simply smells really good; high-end designers rarely achieve better. Despite the CdG resemblance, this fragrance is also an incredibly good all-rounder. It probably wouldn't withstand a winter storm and doesn't quite fit a funeral, but otherwise, it's suitable for almost any occasion. Rush is not a unisex fragrance in the classical sense; however, I now consider the categorization as a unisex scent in many cases to be just as limiting as the division into femme and homme fragrances; Rush is a masculine scent that can also be worn by a woman. It also resembles Wonderwood in this regard.

About €2 per ml for this discontinued treasure (50ml - €102)... a real risk and by far the most expensive scent (in relation) in my collection! I took the plunge despite my concerns, as you can never be sure if the bottles are too old or have gone off. But I was not disappointed.

Gucci Rush is positioned almost exactly between the 2 Pour Hommes and is extremely pleasant and unique. It oscillates between futuristic and woody, is ultra-synthetic, and reminds one of a cyberspace world. But I have rarely smelled such a good fragrance that, precisely because of this synthetic and plastic nature, is truly one of a kind! Rush is anything but rushed. It is likable, calm, relaxed, perfectly styled, and fitting to the bottle as if it just came out of Kubrick's sci-fi masterpiece 2001. I smell lavender, cypress, many soft woods, especially the finest sandalwood I know. And there is plenty of that, even in cheap perfumes. And here you can see how it is done right. On top of that, a light touch of musk completes the perfect, elegant everyday and office scent that is probably 100 years ahead of its time. It reminds me of an illusion of a clearing in the woods and an ultra-sterile, painted forest image that one wants to fall into. But it is all artificially created. Whether everyone will like that is another question. For me, occasionally, definitely, and perfect for the office. Just a shame to wear it daily/often, and I will be careful not to press the spray head too often. Although I would love to press it more often :)

The bottle is grand and typical of the turn of the millennium, when it was unclear where the journey was headed. But definitely spaced out and ultra-chic. Unfortunately just plastic, but very well made and reminiscent of the now huge apple brand. Longevity is unfortunately a bit lacking, the magical spell from the art forest lasts only 6-8 hours. Creamy, bright, delicious, elegant, gentle. Gucci makes me swoon once again! The sillage is also rather weak, more of a casual aura than a cloud of fragrance.

Another real treat from Gucci, as good as PHI and extremely rare now. But at the eBay prices and immediately after the first sniff, you can tell that the fans are right and that you hold something extraordinary in your hands, which does not flaunt but simply offers solid uniqueness from a time when Gucci still dominated the mainstream market!

review_title: Gucci "Rush for Men": A Fragrance Addiction Career
review_content:
During earlier times of peace and until then unprecedented freedom, I found myself on a winter flight towards the tropical islands under the wind aboard a South American vulture machine, where I purchased a bottle of a fragrance that was so completely different from anything I had sniffed up to that point. My first, intoxicating impression was shaped by the perception of new, artificially but very pleasantly perceived scent substances, like those emanating from a freshly opened bucket of latex dispersion paint, which surely must have been similar to the components of the fragrance in the cellar of a mushroom farm. Leaving the cellar of the mushroom cultivation station via the scent bridge of the mushrooms, one enters a damp, moss-covered coniferous mixed forest, with an extremely woody-resinous atmosphere. The base for me was the smell of a handful of moist humus from the forest floor.

I was consistently blown away by this slightly artificial, green-earthy-spicy-resinous scent and surely evaporated more than 3 liters over my skin surface into the surroundings in the following years. Since the H/S was not overly pronounced, not much was left from a morning application, but certain reactions from people in the morning public transport suggested that not everyone shared my enthusiasm for this fragrance. Now and then, it actually happened that individuals suddenly fled from me, coughing and crying like a baby.

I may be mistaken, but as far as I remember, one of the main components was a form of oak moss, which over time was proven to have a highly allergenic effect and therefore could no longer be used. To my knowledge, this led to the discontinuation of the production of Gucci Rush for Men, and thus to the end of my specific fragrance addiction career.

In the meantime, apparently new oak moss aromas have been developed/found that no longer (so strongly) act allergenically, along with many new natural but also artificial aromas. These inspire the creation of new fragrances and enrich the "scent space." When I recently discovered the Parfumo site, the first action was to search for Gucci Rush for Men in the database... and to find the "duplications" that come very close to the original scent from back then.

I would like to take this opportunity to sincerely thank the initiators and organizers of this database for creating a freely accessible opportunity to explore the world of fragrances.

Unfortunately, this fragrance has been discontinued, but you can still find remnants online. It is clearly a lavender scent, with the lavender fully integrated, just like the other components. This makes it difficult to describe this fragrance, as nothing stands out distinctly. It is a modern scent, slightly synthetic, dry, urban. Instead of reminding one of green meadows,...

review_title: A lot of good wood in a white plastic shell
review_content: I say yes to you: Yes to your strong cypress opening. Yes to your milky-creamy incense wood heart. Yes to your bright musk-sandalwood base. You are a wood scent as it should be. Fresh, unobtrusive sandalwood with musk, instantly loveable. Subtly spicy, not exaggerated. Your incense is not strong, that's what Gucci pour Homme (2003) is for. You were ahead of your...

I scored a 10ml bottle of Gucci Rush cheaply on eBay. Since Gucci fragrances usually match my taste, I took a chance with a blind buy - and I don't regret it. The bottle is probably very old and may have been poorly stored. I guess the scent is no longer present with all its notes, and the longevity has likely suffered greatly. The lavender top note can only be sensed, and the incense has unfortunately also disappeared. Rush starts off for me with a strong cedar note, ending in a creamy sandalwood base. Very simple, but very well done. Just like FrieMo, I initially found the scent a bit synthetic, but that has changed now; I find it very authentic and natural. Those who like pure wood scents (like I do) should enjoy Rush. However, the absurdly high prices you have to pay on eBay wouldn't be worth it for me. As much as I like Rush, I have to say that it doesn't work well on my skin: Like so many cedar scents, Rush turns slightly sour on my skin.

I did some research and found a few fragrances that are said to come quite close to this discontinued Gucci creation. Mourning Rush fans should test these:
Diptyque - Tam Dao (very very similar)
Carolina Herrera - 212 (from the heart note)
Creation Lamis - Si Sure Stormy Men (available for about 10 bucks)
Pal Zileri - Sartoriale (is supposedly almost identical)
Christian Lacroix - Tumulte pour homme

You don't get to smell a fragrance like this every day. Because it no longer exists.
The opening is very hmm artificial.
The initial scent smells like plastic, but that's not a problem. On the contrary, it's something different and somehow good.
Then the lavender comes in and brightens up the plastic a bit. But soon the fragrance becomes woodier, warmer, rounder, and comes to an end.

A beautiful synthetic scent. (Emphasis on beautiful AND synthetic)

I was lucky enough to snag this fragrance (100ml) for a mere 2.- Euros at a flea market. Even more profitable, I was able to sell it on eBay - because this scent is truly a "must have" among fans. Just look at the bids on this sales platform...

The bottle design is simple and clean. The plastic gives it a futuristic and spacey feel.
However, altogether it gives off a rather cheap impression.

The scent itself is unobtrusive and clean.

The opening is spicy fresh...the further development is sweet woody.
It had recognizability and, looking back, it was one of the best Gucci fragrances.

Gucci Rush For Men is an all-round fragrance - suitable for every season and every occasion.

Therefore, it's incomprehensible why it was discontinued...

In hindsight, I am plagued by the thought of whether it was a mistake to let the fragrance go...well, I had only worn it twice...so there’s that ;)

Hmm....
I still have a little bit of it left. I don't know if I should really be sad about the discontinuation of this fragrance.
It smells a bit too much like cedar/cypress and all that woodiness; lavender is only present for me in a very light form.
Overall, I have to agree that it's relatively synthetic.
I never bought it; I received it as a full tester when it was discontinued. I probably wouldn't have bought it.

review_title: Because I would love to have it back!
review_content: I discovered this scent at my brother's and was immediately fascinated. I bought it multiple times, and now unfortunately it's only available at a high price on eBay. For me, it was not synthetic at all, but on the contrary fresh and natural; it made me discover my preference for incense scents. It also spontaneously reminded me of a walk in a spruce forest (I come from the...

review_title: Wood Rounded with a Composition of Wood
review_content: I can't really provide a completely new description here. I'm glad I have the scent, as it is definitely very special and interesting. What I really appreciate is that what the fragrance pyramid promises is also delivered. Variations of wood, lavender that fits in but doesn't stand out, and in the end, there's a spicy incense scent that isn't so extreme that it makes you...

The Voice of the Snake is one of those that isn’t necessarily innovative or ultra-unique but has instead taken an existing genre/DNA to its pinnacle. I see it as a combination of the rose/oud/ambrocenide of Ombre Nomade/Nouveau Monde , the woody earthy notes of Guilty Absolute pour Homme, and the dark filthy leather of Le Gemme - Falkar.

A reviewer said in a review of Dark Lord - Ex Tenebris Lux that Alberto Morillas used Guilty Absolute pour Homme as experimentation then perfected that experiment in Dark Lord. I can kind of see that, but I think the perfection was truly achieved one year later in Voice of the Snake. Funnily enough, both Dark Lord and Voice of the Snake have reviewers comparing them to Voldemort. Is it just the names that are inspiring this connection or is there some aromachemical common among these fragrances that is summoning He Who Must Not Be Named?

Because there is absolutely something sinister about Voice of the Snake. Biting leather, deep earth, venomous animalic oud. And no sweetness as the antidote to counteract it. Just all in on these ultra-dark yet sharp notes. Don’t let the “saffron” note fool you. There’s no medicinal spiciness here, it might as well be “leather” in the note pyramid. The oud is not too overwhelming, but it is a similar style to Ombre Nomade, so if you don’t like the oud there, you will probably not like it here. It dries down to a dark, deep, woody, mulchy patchouli. And it is potent! 12 hours on skin for me, and at least 6 of those it is projecting heavily.

I think even retail price is fair here, since this compares favorably with Bvlgari’s private line as well as the midrange of LV’s line in Ombre Nomade, but Voice of the Snake is currently available for $230 on Jomashop which is frankly a steal as far as I’m concerned.

You will find all sorts of fine analysis on the notes of this perfume. Since I have nothing else to add to those, I'll save you the technical stuff. But I will say that one thing that strikes me about this perfume is that unlike other fragrances that put an effort in balancing notes off and creating a harmony with highs and lows and sharps and smooths, etc. this fragrance is bold and rich. The creators have sort of unapologetically stated it's dominant features, without feeling the need to sugarcoat it with unnecessary hints and notes. That aside, it's one of the most long living perfumes I have ever tried. The more interesting fact is that no matter how long after use, if you can still smell it, you will smell all of it's base, subnotes and features. It's as if all of them attenuate together, which indicates they have been well balanced in the first place.

What a special perfume and it really is the perfume that Tom Riddle would use, elegant dark and very cold.

It cannot be used indoors with more than 2 sprays.

It is a beast in projection and duration.

It is very worth it and despite being a dark perfume it is not too difficult and its trail is delicious

Voice-of-the-Snake wearers possess very special sensory organs to ensure their survival.

Snakes, for example, can have varying degrees of visual acuity. Visually interesting in this case is especially the nice presentation of the delivered overall package. In the midst of the finely patterned - protective of the valuable content - packaging lies the heavy porcelain bottle: deep black, artistically ornamented.

Snake wearers absorb scent and taste particles through flicking and their tongue. The sense of smell is particularly well developed in snakes; otherwise, they wouldn't have any of their own bouquet! Through the bifurcation of the tongue, the Gucci snake can spatially orient itself with the information it has gathered. The two tongue tips act like fine measuring devices that can distinguish even the smallest differences in scent molecules: deep shadowy patchouli, serious saffron, and finely cultivated dark woody oud. A pleasing, attractive oud. Equipped this way, they can perceive their surroundings even when their sense of sight is limited. Preferably at night. This is especially important for locating prey animals, but also for escaping potential enemies or even finding partners for reproduction. The scent aura slithers between mystique, the mysterious, and - due to the fine, pure composition blade - enhancing libido. Discreet delicacy throughout the softly smoldering scent progression.

While some senses in snakes are excellently developed, the sense of hearing is quite the opposite: snakes are nearly deaf. They can perceive ground vibrations through their lower jaw. In some species, such as the Voice-of-the-Snake wearers, this means they are not only warned of approaching enemies but can also locate and catch prey at night. The only sound present is the stretched hissing of the snake bottle when spraying the venom - a distinctive spray head, a soft whisper.

Snakes can also detect the smallest temperature fluctuations. Through thermal perception, our snakes can particularly well track warm-blooded fellow humans. This means they can hunt even in complete darkness. However, even during the day, the scent remains discreet and the snake present.

Voice-of-the-Snake wearers are clever, have a keen mind, dislike haste, are interested in the deeper meanings, and remain enigmatic and mysterious (sillage) while being extremely loyal beings (longevity) with an infallible sense for their fellow humans (scent).

The Voice of the Snake is a truly enchanting and simultaneously unconditionally unencumbered, subtly dark, and conspiratorial fragrance. I hereby warn you of its wearers!

No! Not at all! No Rose-Saffron-Oud!

After a guided tour through the most beautiful bottles in a small perfumery across the pond, which I had initiated without any ulterior motive by mentioning my preference not only for Penhaligon's scents but also for their containers to the friendly saleswoman, several unsolicited fragrance samples found their way into the little bag, including this relatively new Gucci.
Although I had commented quite favorably on the Gucci bottles of the new series during said tour, my expectations for the scent itself were limited. These low expectations were somewhat confirmed after my test of the rose fragrance from the series yesterday.
This allowed the fragrance to surprise me all the more - positively.
The oud takes center stage and comes without any sweet floral notes, rather harshly, and is supported by quite bitter saffron and deep, dry patchouli as supporting characters. One might think that this combination could be somewhat one-dimensional without a counterpart, but in this case, the interesting part is taken on by the volume. It doesn't storm into the bar, clumsily with baggage, loudly demanding a drink and rudely insulting everyone present, no, it is the stranger with the grim, proud gaze and a threatening aura, who has been sitting alone in the dark corner all evening, silencing the newly arrived intruder with a silent look. This guy knows what he has, and everyone else knows it too, without him having to shout it out loud.
Creaky-dry, bitterly wicked, and yet completely still.
I like it very much!

“If you’re wondering what smells so strange, Mother: a mudblood just walked in.” He wrinkled his nose. - “Tzzzz. My boy, don’t you know that even my lord, greater and mightier than you can ever imagine in your growing dreams, is not of pure blood? Tzzzz.” Despite the snake emblem on his left breast, he clearly wanted to pay her no attention. What an unpleasant,...

review_title: There isn't a more unique perfume..
review_content: As the title suggests, I believe there is no perfume as "special" as Gucci The Voice of the Snake. I received this perfume as a gift from my father while we were shopping together in the Gucci store in Frankfurt. He spent a whopping €345 on the perfume. When I smelled it for the first time, I felt as if I were in a church and a large cloud of incense was coming towards me....

A dry gust let individual grains of sand trickle over the glossy black scale segments of the slowly winding snake. The leathery segments glided almost smoothly over the dry, rugged ground, over brittle woods and through sporadically growing saffron and patchouli flowers.

Gucci's The Voice of the Snake comes as a thoroughly dry oud fragrance. In the first moments of spraying, a very intense medicinal form of the oud accord used here unfolds.

You have to like it - I do!

Once the first veil of oud has settled, it becomes distinctly leathery. The leather note used here most likely results from the saffron and lies more in the light and airy spectrum, rather than in that of heavy and dark leather. This gives the fragrance, despite its intensity, a certain lightness and delicacy. The whole is accompanied by a subtle sweetness of saffron and a warm, nutty, almost cocoa-like hint of patchouli.

And that’s it. Gucci's Voice of the Snake is neither greatly complex nor does the fragrance exhibit a noticeable progression. However, that is not what bothers me here. I had to think long before I figured it out - it’s the coumarin. In my opinion, a little too much has been used here, which results in me being reminded of Viktor & Rolf's Spicebomb Extreme from time to time.

In conclusion, it can be said that it is quite a nice release, but for me, it lacks enough unique features to make it a staple in my collection.

review_title: Into the Desert...it Takes Your Breath Away
review_content:
Recently tested Gucci The Voice of the Snake and what can I say. 2 sprays on the test strip and then I smelled it...I was momentarily breathless.

It is brutally strong. Even days later, it barely faded. The full power of the ouds, little patchouli, and even less saffron (in my opinion) I can barely sense in the background. Only 3 ingredients are listed, but they pack a punch. Alberto Morillas has delivered a masterpiece here.

From the very first second, hard leather, quite smoky. You have to like that. And if you are a fan of it, this is a top recommendation.

That's how I imagine it. In the desert, having not drunk anything for a long time. Slowly, the dizziness sets in and you lie on the ground in the sand. A rattlesnake looks me straight in the eyes, hisses with its tongue, and rattles its tail...ready to strike.

Longevity and sillage...very, very strong. Less is more. 1-2 sprays maximum!!!

It opens with what I call the “sweet spot” for Iris: balanced perfectly between an earthy, rooty iris and a powdery one. Never truly tipping too far one way or the other. The iris at the open is similar in shape to Iris de Nuit by HEELEY (not quite as carroty as this one however) but settles to a steely, cool, iris very similar to Harmonist Royal Earth.

Once dried down, this is a shier iris, sitting close to the skin. It’s no powerhouse.

I had been sampling this off and on for about a year before I made my decision to purchase. So despite what others point to as performance issues (and they are correct) it’s such a beautiful soft fragrance that I wanted to add.

To me, this is a white eyelet dress: soft, delicate.

For a long time, I was a devoted fan of iris, as I found the often delicate buttery note enchanting, and over time I had several iris fragrances in my collection. Until - yes, until I grew weary of iris. Instead of being softly creamy, I found it rather powdery and, after prolonged use, even dusty and oppressive. From L' Erbolario to Le Galion, Prada to Guerlain, I was constantly searching for the iris that used to bring a smile to my face, but in vain. I almost resigned myself, but then Gucci announced the Tears of Iris, the first revisions were promising, and the beautiful video in the advertisement did the rest. I participated in a sharing. Should I come close to my iris dream again?

I was about to rejoice. There it was, the finely powdery, lovely, romantic pastel note that makes you forget everyday life, a hint of nostalgia, a bit of shabby chic, and due to the opulence, I already planned to dose the sample from the sharing as discreetly as possible, so I wouldn't fall into the temptation of "more is more" and thus destroy the fragrance's aura.

The disappointment came so unexpectedly that it felt almost like a shock, because after hardly an hour, the Tears of Iris had dried up, and I could only faintly sense the excitement that had moved me just moments before, close to the skin. Gone - simply gone! I don't know what went wrong in the development of the fragrance, as other iris perfumes have always had a normal progression. So it can't be the iris itself. Anyway, I felt like many other fragrance enthusiasts - the longevity is not worth mentioning, and thus the fragrance was stripped of its soul. For the delicate nuance of the scent that lingers after hours, I don't need to get too close to my piggy bank.

I will use up the sample and put the topic of iris on hold for now. Perhaps I will also return to my roots and treat myself to "Hiris" by Hermes again.

review_title: You're the closest to heaven that I'll ever be
review_content:
Every time I wear this fragrance and perceive its scent, I have the song "Iris" by the Goo Goo Dolls in my head. This is not only due to the name similarity but also to the lyrics and the mood that the song conveys.

Lines like "And I'd give up forever to touch you" or "You're the closest to heaven that I'll ever be" wonderfully reflect the unattainable elegance that the fragrance radiates, as well as a feeling of security: "When everything's made to be broken, I just want you to know who I am." A place of refuge on one's own skin.

The fragrance always remains in balance. It is mature, yet not outdated, but rather experienced. It is dry, yet lively enough not to be boring. It is floral and powdery, while also being woody. Suitable for all genders equally.

"And all I can taste is this moment, And all I can breathe is your life" translates excellently to the longevity and sillage of "Tears of Iris." Unfortunately, the place of refuge does not linger long on the skin and can only be perceived in close proximity. Time with the fragrance flies by as if it were just a moment, yet in this moment, there is so much, as if "Tears of Iris" has breathed its whole life into it.

Gucci encourages layering the fragrance with perfumed oils and Acque Profumate from The Alchemist's Garden series to make the place of refuge your home. However, I do not want that; I would like to spend more time solely with "Tears of Iris": "And I don't want to go home right now."

After just discovering the wonderful iris fragrance "Ida Violet," I did not expect such a quickly following divine top note to come flying at me when I sprayed "Tears of Iris," like a colorful bird with the colors of the rainbow, simply beautiful. The driest iris clouds my senses; I am truly overwhelmed. Stay a while, you are sooo beautiful, I think, and I am in absolute fragrance heaven.
However, I fall abruptly from scent cloud 7 after about 5 minutes when I suddenly can perceive nothing, but really nothing at all. Highly irritated, my nose wanders back to my wrist repeatedly over the next quarter of an hour; I did spray it on, or was it all just a dream...?
And then, slowly, as if from nowhere, the scent rises like the phoenix from the ashes. It returns, but now it is transformed.
Slightly spicy angelica root makes the scent stronger now. I experience it as if the fragrance is divided in two. At first, you get the full iris charge, but after a short creative pause, the other notes unfold. I would then describe it in this further phase as woody-spicy. The iris plays more of a background role, with musk harmoniously accompanying it.
By the way, the process is slowed down when sprayed on fabric; the fine top note lasts longer, and it becomes less woody-spicy, but as Serduszko already described, rather a bit lipstick-like, which I prefer.
In the statements, a similarity to "Misia" was mentioned, and the question of a true Morillas was raised.
To investigate this, I sprayed all three fragrances in parallel.
Well, the common denominator with "Misia" is probably the spicy note. In direct comparison, "Misia" (I used the edP) is clearer; there is no woody musk note here like in "Tears of Iris."
As a true Morillas, it can confidently be labeled, as the fragrance in the second phase features finely intertwined notes. Compared to "Nylaia," which came to mind, there are no scent similarities. Even though "Tears of Iris" returns after a short dip, "Nylaia" has more radiance; positively put, "Tears of Iris" remains much softer and closer to the skin.
Do you know the Harry Potter episode "The Order of the Phoenix"? The beautiful phoenix can heal with its tears until it turns to ash again, only to rise once more.
Overall, I quite like the fragrance, but I shed a small tear for the beautiful iris at the beginning; thus, the name "Tears of Iris" resonates with me personally very well ;-)
P.S.: After many, many hours (yes, I can still smell it ;-) the iris mixes in more clearly again. There remains a light sweetness reminiscent of grape sugar-fruit, as I already know from "Magnum Iris" or "Silver Iris."

Well, those who know me know that I hardly ever like lavender, actually I prefer it in the garden and not as a fragrance.
But this is so completely different.
The opening is like running your hands through a huge lavender bush.
Very, very authentic.
Even I, as a non-lavender fan, have to give it respect.
It's also quite powerful.
Fortunately for me, unfortunately for lavender lovers, it quickly pulls back.
I don't specifically smell sage.
And then this change comes along.
Everything is already quiet and still, calming, just as lavender is said to be.
A beautiful, subtly vanillic tonka bean joins in very gently, with a breeze of musk
and I would say, there's also a tiny pinch of amber.
The herbs are still present, albeit very subdued,
and give the whole thing a wonderful spiciness.
One could almost think there's a hint of the pepperiness of delicate feather carnations in there.
But I must emphasize, everything is happening very, very close to the skin.
I am practically hanging my nose on my wrist,
to smell more and more of this wonderful scent.
It's a fragrance that you don't really perceive as a perfume, but rather just as a
"This person smells good".
It's a scent that I would confidently wear for a visit to a hospital,
without disturbing anyone.
It's a fragrance that would gently lull the person opposite during a job interview, without him/her noticing.
Actually, it's meant to be layered with the other scents in this series,
but I would consider it too precious for that.
It's far too quiet to assert itself against something else
and I simply wouldn't want to mess it up.
You can't just spray this scent quickly in a perfumery for testing,
you need a lot of calm and leisure,
to explore it.
And you might need a bit more of it.
Then it becomes a very, very interesting journey.
It has pleasantly surprised me.
A Morillas, indeed.
Aaaaand, those who like it powerful will be disappointed. And also, those looking for a lavender scent will be disappointed after 10 minutes.
I am thrilled.

I'm wearing today this incredible perfume and had to write about it. I really think it is one of the most perfect autumn perfumes I've come across. When I smell it, it makes me long for countryside walks, in woolen jumpers and coats, and leather boots of course. Tweed and leather, those good old things.

Green chypre, full of oakmoss, narcissus, leather, rubbery tuberose and a hint of dense red rose. Aldehydes give a sparkling effect to it, but they are under control. So the result is creamy, green, animalic, autumnal but still shiny.

Very chic and uncommon to today’s commonplace for scents. Strong and long lasting too. Worths every cent of the edt, I own too a perfume extrait which is even better, to cry for actually. Why next generations have to be punished not to ever smell it, I will never understand.

Pure magic.

For days I pondered which fragrance to dedicate my 400th review to. I didn't want to write a critique for this occasion. But thanks to a dear perfume enthusiast, I have a sample of Gucci 3 (Extrait). Now, where better to sing praises than with a lovely Chypre? However, I must note that not all Chypres automatically win me over. There are Chypres I wouldn't even want to be embalmed with when I'm dead.
Ah yes, Gucci 3 is from the past, and it smells like it too. But I don't belong to those who claim that everything was better back then. Many things were different, some better, some also crap... Fragrances from the past were better than other fragrances from the past and sometimes even better than some from today.
Gucci 3 is a scent for big girls, those whose eggshells behind their ears have already come off, or for a lively grandma who rides motorcycles with her grandson, treats herself to stylish clothes, or travels the world. I don't mean the lady over 60 who, as I often hear from my clients of that age, says: "Oh, Mrs. ... that's all very nice, but I don't need anything anymore, I already have everything." Just the other day, I would have liked to ask the permanently permed lady (at most 65 years young) if she has already paid for her burial plot. Well, they don't wear perfume anyway.
Gucci 3 is a dark, floral-spicy Chypre that starts with a concentrated dose of aldehydes, but NOT in a soapy form. It immediately gives way to a dense spice note that can't solely come from coriander. The floral flood in the heart is so complex, opulent, and not sweet that I can't identify a single note. For all those who fear fragrances from the 1980s, I can say: Opulent: Yes! An 80s bomb? No!
The base is (for all Chypre fans) worship-worthy. A fine leather note, dark and warm, ambered, elegantly woody. I will keep an eye on Gucci 3; I have a lot, but not everything that brings me joy.
