Guccio Gucci, who, like Thierry Hermès, originally sold fine saddles and leather goods, stood for me as the epitome of style and quality, just like his label founded in the 1950s. Gucci as a corporation has had its ups and downs, like almost every other fashion house, and after a major crisis, it managed to get back on its feet with the help of Tom Ford, even becoming more profitable than before.
But - at what price? Gucci, the label, may play a significant role internationally again - but if Guccio, the father of the label, could smell what is marketed today under his name, he would be turning in his grave.
Not so with Gucci No.3! This fragrance deserves the recognition that I also have for early Gucci items: It meets a high standard, is an absolute noble chypre, a signature candidate, and - timeless.
Unfortunately, it is hardly available nowadays, as it was discontinued years ago during the restructuring within the corporation.
The best always go first.
After a green-aldehydic opening, the fragrance quickly becomes warmer, silkier, slightly fruity, and even has a minimal resemblance to Mitsouko in the heart note, although without the peach and without a distinct presence of a single floral note. The base is skillfully balanced, a leathery note amidst a bouquet of oak moss, fine woods, and amber, radiant and vibrant. A fragrance like a silk scarf, like a buttery soft leather bag, like handcrafted shoes. Luxury that one loves for a lifetime.

review_title: If you tip over, that would be silly
review_content:
Such an old Chypre treasure,
you are worth more than a simple chat!

Your beginning may have tipped for sure,
but in the end, you really pulled it off once more.

You’ve proven to me once again,
Gucci back then spared neither forest nor meadows,
rightly belonged to the olfactory giants,
offering no fragrances like today, at best good enough to lease!

You couldn’t smell more like the 80s,
even John Rambo would crawl before you.

Full of moss, forest, flowers, meadows & brush,
you belong in the executive suite, driving every boss mad.

Whether aldehydes, iris, bergamot, or amber,
you adorned even the brightest stars with dark Ramba Zamba.

Is it the patch, the moss, or just the leather?
You’re something like Jil Sanders Man Pure - not everyone liked you.

Slowly you then departed from us,
only then did the mourners sing slowly.

Are you the boss, and that as a woman,
wear this little water - and you often hear Wow!

review_title: Verona, Romeo and Juliet and a Duck as a Supporting Actor
review_content:
Few of my fragrances felt just right to accompany me to Italy for a few weeks like "Gucci N° 3".
First of all, the former saddlery managed to create a great masterpiece with this scent; secondly, at that time I still didn't own the "Voyage" version of Cartier's "Panthère", which was my constant companion back then.
Even with my always very extensive luggage, it would have been audacious to lug the heavy crystal bottle in the red leather case.
So "Gucci N° 3" accompanied me to Northern Italy.

This fragrance is also a child of its time: a rich chypre of noble craftsmanship.
In the opening with aldehydes, bergamot, and other green components, it resembles many of its fragrant contemporaries. -At that moment, a good acquaintance greets me.
The floral heart note is of particular olfactory richness. Alone, jasmine, lily of the valley, and rose cast their spell. Together with daffodil, rich tuberose, and the iris root, which I always find a bit unusual, all senses are already fully engaged.
A heavy, sensual base (initially dominated by musk and leather) is completed by amber, oakmoss, and other spices. These round off this fragrance creation to perfection.
"Gucci N° 3" floats full, harmonious, and mysterious, surrounding one for a long time with its unique charm.
Only after many hours does a still light trace remain.

Thus, "Gucci N° 3" was a lovely companion during my stay in Abano Terme. And of course, it couldn't be missing in Verona.
Instead of using the bus rides to the opera performances in the arena, I had pre-ordered tickets directly from the organizer and also reserved a hotel room in the city.
I didn't just want to experience the arena on the picturesque Piazza Brà; I wanted to indulge myself with a bit more time in this city.
The evening performance of "Tosca" was very successful. The security measures at this major event didn't bother me as a West Berliner: that was familiar to me. One of the heavily armed police officers even carried the two rented cushions behind me.
What a sight that must have been! First the usher, then me, all dressed up for the evening, and behind me the heavily armed man with the two green cushions!
These things later kept the poor gentleman sitting behind me busy: he had to keep picking up the cushion, originally meant for the back. He did it patiently and kindly!
(As my mother often used to say: Can you manage without all the fuss?)
The night was clear and correspondingly cool. But precisely because of that, the stars shone particularly bright during "E lucevan le Stelle"!

The next day was dedicated to a more extensive exploration of the city until my taxi driver arrived in the afternoon.
My first stop, of course, was the house of Romeo and the Casa di Giulietta in Via Capella.
I too stood in the courtyard and looked up at Juliet's balcony; touched by the tragedy of young love.
But of course, I asked myself: who were these two young people?
Created solely by William Shakespeare (or was it Christopher Marlowe)?
Or do they live in each of us? Doesn't every Juliet in us seek her very own Romeo?

However, I also wondered: how could Juliet's nurse keep complaining about her aching feet? The distance between the houses isn't that far.
In the end, I concluded that it wasn't the distance and frequency of the trips that caused the pain. No, it was surely the very bad road paving back then!
Because every woman who went to the arena in her summer shoes had to take those shoes to the cobbler the next day.
During the season in Verona, the cobblers in Abano Terme had their high season.

Those who have made it this far will rightly ask: what about the duck?
Yes, this duck appeared on stage in August 1994.
The summer was very hot; the open-air stage at Spandau Citadel had "Romeo & Juliet", performed by the "Spandauer Vagantenbühne", on the program. So: off we go!
Even that evening, despite the heat, I wore "Gucci N° 3": it was simply part of "Romeo and Juliet".
This rustic location is situated on a peninsula, surrounded on three sides by the Havel, lined with reeds. Therefore, the performances there also include various waterfowl as constantly changing extras.
The evening was still very warm, it was quite crowded, and a slightly shortened, somewhat parodied version of "Romeo and Juliet" delighted the audience; it would surely have pleased "Master Shakespeare" as well.
But apparently not all viewers: after the intermission, it was much emptier - not a disaster in the heat.
From the reeds, the waterfowl could be heard: the bright whistling of the coots, the ducks telling each other their goodnight stories. They formed a completely natural sound backdrop.
On the forest-fringed stage stood a scaffolding with a platform and a suggested balcony: Juliet's house.
The older lady behind me asked reluctantly: "What is that bundle of rags up there?"
The family flinched, part of the audience chuckled audibly: this bundle of rags held Romeo and Juliet!
The heart-wrenching scene began: Romeo put on his shirt and Juliet desperately asked:
"Are you already leaving? The day is still far off! It was the nightingale and not the lark!"

She didn't get to the lark. A duck had finished its own evening ritual and loudly announced itself: "Quack-quack-quack-quack!!" echoed across the open-air stage!
First, there was stunned silence - then very loud laughter!
Romeo and Juliet stood helplessly on their scaffolding. The beauty of the scene was destroyed: by a duck! The audience was rolling with laughter - those two up there had lost the thread!
It took several minutes before Romeo, somewhat dejected, finally left his Juliet and the tragedy took its course.
The final applause was loud and grateful, still interspersed with soft giggles.
It was an entirely successful evening!
(If that had been foreseeable, the RTL cameraman would surely have stayed!)

Since then, for me, "Romeo and Juliet", whether in image or sound, (and of course also "Shakespeare in Love") is accompanied by the fragrant memory of "Gucci N° 3" - and of course also a duck!
Feel free to call me an art philistine - no one can take this vivid memory away from me!

review_title: Heroic Courage in the Shift Knob!
review_content:
What have I cursed about numerous "modern" Gucci fragrances. Much of it is mass-produced, mainstream, "crowd-pleasing," all sorts of little-known "waters" that come and go.
But the "older models" more than make up for these disappointments! The older "Guilty," a poem for herb-rough floral scents, the older "Pour Homme," a skillfully distinctive fougère.
And this one here, unfortunately long discontinued, which is a highly masterful example of a "full chypre."
As mentioned by some of my "predecessors," the Italian Gucci company's journey began similarly to that of "Hermès." With leather goods and saddles and other equestrian supplies. Then came travel accessories, watches, jewelry, and FRAGRANCES.
The fragrances were probably a small business risk at the time, because besides Gucci and Hermes, a whole range of fashion, jewelry, watch, car, design companies, jewelers, and other "fragrance-foreign" businesses also ventured into fragrances.
And "Gucci" certainly showed some "heroic courage in the shift knob" in this regard!
And one of these masterpieces is "Gucci N°3," created by "Firmenich's" perfumers. In this true "full chypre," you can still smell the quality of the ingredients and their refined combination even after a long time. Without compromising the top, heart, or base notes. But wonderfully "aged" in honor, which makes it so magnificent.
With the first "spray," a wonderfully green-spicy citrus fruit-laden, slightly aldehyde-enhanced strong top note emerges, hinting at all the "delights" that may follow.
A floral, slightly herb-sweet "tumult" of aromas finds its place, all contributing to a cheerful "commotion." With fine edges and corners. A long projection is a matter of honor. However, it never becomes overly pompous or intrusive. Because none of the aromas is "too much."
A slow transition to the "base" still allows "head and heart" to be clearly recognized, nothing is overshadowed or displaced. It is always just another addition to what is already there when bitter, woody, grassy-earthy, and true oak moss facets join in. This now "complete" scent endures for hours, lively, almost tactile, and transformable in a magnificent manner! Beautiful!!!!

review_title: Gucci No. 3 - it's been a while
review_content:
"Gucci No. 3" was my second fragrance that I owned, or rather the first perfume that I bought for myself. Before that, I always used mini bottles of "Charlie" by Revlon, which I received as gifts from time to time.
Just a side note.
This fragrance is a solid Chypre, as it is no longer produced or created today. The floral notes are rather green and herbaceous, with a woody base. The aldehydes provide a certain lightness, making it feel less heavy than other Chypre fragrances.
A scent that you don't get tired of quickly.
Unfortunately, it is probably no longer in production :-(

Now I have another vintage miniature to test. Gucci № 3 is quite nice so far, but it doesn't blow me away. The longevity is quite good at around 8 to 9 hours, while the sillage is a bit weaker.

The top note starts aldehydic, green, herbal, and fruity thanks to bergamot and coriander. The heart note offers a sea of flowers consisting of lily of the valley, daffodils, jasmine blossoms, rose water, iris, violets, and tuberose. The base feels quite overloaded and smells earthy, rooty, leathery, animalic, woody, balsamic, and forest-like. I detect oak moss, musk, vetiver, and patchouli.

This is an old-school chypre that, in the end, didn't "catch" me. Therefore, my miniature will move on.

Flora by Gucci Gracious Tuberose is a lovely surprise!! I bought it unsniffed from inflight duty free a few nights ago and can't stop wearing it!

This Tuberose is definitely gracious (as it's name implies) ... a note that has the reputation for misbehaviour in most fragrances containing it has been tamed beautifully here. Fresh up top, the Rose and Orange Blossom combination with the Tuberose in the heart is utterly inspired. A 'buttery' green effect is immediately evident ... which is all at once surprising, but very interesting too. I also get a substantial resiny Cedar as this fragance dries down.
Gracious Tuberose has good sillage and slightly more than average longevity, lingering for at least 6 hours on my skin, even in the tropical weather I currently find myself in. I've had more than one compliment over the last few days ... always a good indication that something is doing the job it's supposed to!

I seldom wear anything that smells 'fresh' ... Gracious Tuberose delivers springtime in a bottle without feeling like a slap of eau de cologne ... simply lovely!!

The Flora Garden collection is not as magnificent as Mugler's Garden of Stars, but Tuberose is my favorite out of the line-up. Unfortunately, Violet and Mandarin are the sisters that were separated from the others at birth (when launched) due to exclusivity. So, I can't say how I feel about them yet. Tuberose is not anything like Michael Kors or Fracas. Its a white floral with shared attention on green notes. Very light, airy and sheer. When I smell this, I think of Miss Dior Cherie L'eau. Another fresh, white to green floral, composed of bigarade orange, white musk, caramel and patchouli. Quite classy.

Transparent, fresh and almost green flower bouquet water. Diluted and inoffensive tuberose and orange flowers, turned green through the addition of watery violet leaves and dewy white roses. Cedar is noticeable in the drydown. The peach is very subtle, fresh and not dominating at all. The freshest tuberose perfume in my collection around my favourite flower, it is very clean and refreshing, pretty easy to wear, with an almost minimal style that matches a white simple white dress and a polished ponytail for a warm summer morning. Not avant garde, uncomplicatedly contemporary. Moderate sillage and 4 to 5 hours longevity.

Sometimes I think with great enthusiasm about the strangest things - some of them for many years. I come from a family where card games are quite popular - so 'real' card games, not something like Uno or Mau-Mau - and even as a boy, I sometimes wondered how the boys, queens, and kings might look outside the well-known cutout. (I was also preoccupied with news anchors in a similar way, but that faded away eventually.)

My all-time favorite among the face cards is the Queen of Spades. In the game of Doppelkopf, a Queen of Spades is not a bad playing card either, but I always found her 'other' appearance particularly interesting. She is the only queen in the so-called 'French' deck that is shown in profile - and unlike the Queen of Clubs, Hearts, and Diamonds, she is the only one who does not smile. When the French deck is used for oracle purposes, the Queen of Spades is considered 'the foreign woman' - one who is opaque and mysterious.

She also wears less jewelry than the others - pearls and a simple bracelet - and appears overall a bit 'less polished'. She wears a dress (or just a top - who knows?) in the colors of Italy - her green cloak is trimmed with fur. The flower in her hand - to which she is inclined, but seems not to really smell - is usually a red tulip, sometimes a rose in older card games. Everything about her seems a little harsher than the other queens - a bit more serious and less sweet.

The tuberose is one of the polarizing floral accords - and one that I, who quite enjoys ignoring the often arbitrary distinction between women's and men's fragrances, perceive as rather feminine. There is something fleshy about it and something sensual and mature, with little youthful quality. And despite the playful opening of peach and bright flowers, Gucci's 'gracious tuberose' carries the same seriousness and maturity that pleasantly distinguishes the Queen of Spades from the others.

Conclusion: a mature almost soliflore of at most medium strength. And whatever one might not love about tuberose, Gucci's Gracious Tuberose has surprisingly little of that. And while I will probably never find out how the Queen of Spades looks 'down below' - I am quite sure she wears this scent.

Even early in the morning, the air in the bedroom was still, and the radio host announced a hot day.

So, I wanted to choose a fragrance that is as transparent as possible, without heaviness - but with a certain expression.

I don't want to smell citrusy, but still bright and fresh.
Gracious Tuberose seems to be the perfect choice!

Gracious - according to Leo: gracious, kind, elegant.
I find the adjective "elegant" to be the most fitting.

The intro is soft and delicately tart with peach and violet - but gains summery brightness through the orange blossom and the prominent tuberose.
The impression is radiant white.
Slightly softened, the snow white is complemented by mild woody notes.

The fragrance remains feather-light - fortunately, it is not overly fleeting, but stays perceptible for a long time.

Although not necessarily a summer scent, the gracious tuberose is also well wearable in heat.
Of course, it fits into other seasons as well.

A pleasant fragrance, with subtle elegance, that skillfully adapts to the wearer and the temperatures.

product_name: Guilty Absolu de Parfum pour Homme
review_content: From open to close this is a work of art, orange blossom and almond hit you hard off the rip giving a sweet and just a touch of bitter feel to it, its creamy and seductive, sophisticated and mature. The projection is great and sillage is wonderful, as it dries down you get more of the leather and wood and settles into a glorious mellow man smell. nnIt checks all the boxes for me, this is my first 10/10 fragrance the only downside is price of designer fragrances hitting over 200 for 2 oz, they keep going up. But it’s such a well made fragrance get a decant and try out for winter and fall it’s sexy!!

product_name: Guilty Absolu de Parfum pour Homme
review_content:
This is like the Elixir if it wasn't muddled with sweetness and actually had some thought put into it.

The opening is very similar to the Elixir, if it had a softer vanilla and was less in your face. Sadly the rum note isn't as boozy or prominent as I hoped it would be, but that is completely okay as the tonka bean makes up for it in the dry down.

They really microdosed the labdanum, chili, and leather notes, definitely supporting notes that do make the fragrance darker and do a really good job at it. I will include, that if you're here for the chili note, Guilty EDP is the best one for that. It is a lot softer and less nuanced here. Now for the tonka bean, the almond amplifies the tonka bean and I could even detect some cherry facets.

The base really completes it with the multifaceted tonka bean and benzoin, they pair really well, in the air its a very delicious and rich smell.

This is 100% a modern and safe release, however what I'm impressed by is the complexity of the tonka bean, which is almost never seen in designer releases. As a Gucci Guilty fan, this is by far the best one in the line. Is it as unique and bold as the original Gucci Guilty Absolute? No, but it performs better and can be worn a lot more. This a great take on modern sweet DNAs with a dark spicy twist, and I respect it for being that way.

product_name: Guilty Absolu de Parfum pour Homme
review_title: An elixir de parfum that didn't need a successor!
review_content:
Even though I'm not particularly into the game when it comes to older designer fragrances like Dior or Chanel, I have managed to try quite a few over time and found my favorite designer scent in Gucci Guilty Elixir, the "predecessor fragrance" to this one.

Since I work at the airport, I was able to try the new Gucci Guilty Absolu de Parfum at the Duty Free today, hopeful that I might find a new designer fragrance for myself.

At first sniff, the scent struck me as quite spicy; some unlisted pepperiness didn't appeal to me much. After a few minutes, the classic EDP DNA comes through, albeit riper, more mature, and niche-like, with more edges and not as "youthful" as the predecessor, but unfortunately, I liked nearly every aspect of that one. After a short while, I feel like I can better distinguish individual notes. I get an interesting sharpness from the chili and also a slight boozy rum note. Overall, as mentioned, the scent is more mature, edgier, niche-like, and in my perception, a bit spicier than the EDP, which unfortunately makes me like it less.

In my opinion, the EDP from Gucci didn't need any change, or at least not in this direction. I had hoped that I would like the ADP better, but unfortunately, that is not the case; nonetheless, the new interpretation is interesting.

I can't comment on longevity and sillage, as I only tried the scent once for a while on my wrist, where it held up and also seemed quite strong, so I assume that, similar to the EDP, it has some power! The bottle is nicely made; the price-performance ratio remains to be seen, as the EDP has also become cheaper over time, and the MSRP is quite a number! If you like the EDP, you might want to test this one and form your own opinion!

Apart from smelling amazing this scent is from the same year as my son was born. I did not meet it before 2003, though, when I went on a vacation to Florence. One of the cities on my ‘to visit’-list at that time. Now on my ‘to visit again’-list.
This city is full of historic places, and having just a weekend I had to be pickish with my choices. My first priority was to go to the Uffizi Gallery, but when I arrived, there was a sign stating that the waiting time was two hours for visitors who had ordered tickets in advance. For others - four hours. I decided not to spend so much precious time of my short vacation on standing in line. Instead I went for a stroll down the narrow, curvy alleys, heading for the Dome, Cattedrale de Santa Maria del Fiore.
While walking there and knowing that the oldest perfume shop in Europe is located in Florence, I thought that maybe this would be something to do instead of looking at art. Going on a perfume shop hunt. I had an example of ‘The trip goes to Florence’ in my hand - this was before the smartphones - and started my journey looking at the map of the inner city.
It was a wonderful walk. And in one of these small streets without cars I found a small ‘Profumo & Pharmaceutica’. I went in and was greeted by the most friendly and service minded person ever. She did not speak more than two words of English and my Italian was limited to ‘Mille Grazie’ but it did not matter. I told her I was looking for a new scent - ‘nova prufomo’, I think I said, and we ended up spending two hours trying scents and having a blast. She kept saying ‘good?’ and I kept saying no or yes. Finally I ended up buying Accenti. When I left the shop, I had forgotten all about the Lady of the Flower’s beautiful church. I went there the next day.
Accenti has a special place in my memory, my nose and my heart. It has made it to my top 20. For some years it was my signature scent. It is a marvelous perfume, powerful and unique. I love the way it keeps changing, sometimes it is the rose, sometimes the peach, sometimes the jasmine in front. It reminds me of this particular trip to Florence, this pocket of time in which I walked around the beautiful city and felt the breeze of history. Accenti has an Italian feeling to it. Thank you, Dominique Ropion, for making this.
93/365

It's chic sexy and demands your attention
the typical 90's glamor transitional era
when Calvin Klein introduced us with the
first unisex fragrance CK One and still
we were going though wanning years of the
big orientals of the 80's i.e like Obsession Poison
Red Door & Giorgio of Beverly hills Red
accenti reflects that swan song of the big florienals before the tread for lighter watery florals.

It opens with a sweet and a bit tart of
raspberry in a few minutes dries to an note of tangerine and peach the drying down turns to a powdery vanilla with nuance of tonka bean and a big heap of Sandalwood. the florals like the Rose
Jasmine and Lily of the Valley are very hard to detect sadly overshadowed from their louder siblings the sandalwood
raspberry vanilla and peach;

It's intoxicating richness that is an
jewel in perfumery that is sadly going to be missed.

review_title: Smells like cold marble hall within a fruit garden
review_content: It is indeed sweet and fruity, and has a light oriental vibe, but still not fully oriental to my nose. Very interesting composition. Might be cloying if sprayed on the skin with wrong chemitry. But i have found an ultimate twin to this one: "Bogner woman III" (discontinued and hard to get). Bogner smells even more intense and more fruity, it lacks that tonka-raspberry combination, that might be unpleasant to someone. Back to Accenti: still great Gucci from 90´s with great sillage and lasting power.

review_title: The Great Dominique Ropion Strikes Again...
review_content:
Accenti opens with a splash of clean, slightly aldehydic mandarin orange with hints of peach before moving to its heart. As the composition enters its early heart, the moderately sweet peach takes the fore, joined by a co-starring floral trio of almost plum-like honeyed jasmine, soft, airy rose and clean lily-of-the-valley, with the fading mandarin staying just detectable in support, pairing with slightly powdery vanilla and moderately sweet sandalwood rising from the base. During the late dry-down, the slightly sweet sandalwood and gentle dusty vanilla take the fore, with remnants of the peach remaining in support through the finish as the florals vacate. Projection is average and longevity above average at around 10 hours on skin.

Let's cut to the chase... Ropion has created a masterwork with Accenti. I am not a peach fan in compositions at all, but it is impossible not to be intoxicated with its masterful use in Accenti; coupled perfectly with the complex honeyed Dior Poison-like jasmine, airy rose and relatively clean, slightly indolic lily-of-the-valley floral trio. The sandalwood and vanilla are also used deftly, adding moderately sweet grounding to the peach-laced florals, then providing a well-integrated soft landing through the finish as they gradually take the fore. The composition from top-to-bottom smells absolutely incredible, with no note or accord seeming out of place, all melding together perfectly. The bottom line is the sadly discontinued $200+ per 100ml bottle on the aftermarket Accenti is some of Dominique Ropion's finest work and well worth seeking out even at its current lofty aftermarket price point earning an "outstanding" 4.5 stars out of 5 and a super-strong recommendation.

What a great old school, fruity, non apologetic fragrance that was created in the 90's but could have very well been manufactured in the 80's do to it's loud opening as many 80's fragrances were designed. This starts off with peach, raspberries & floral notes of rose & I also get some white floral as well.

There is vanilla, sandalwood & tonka in the base to add depth to the fragrance. It is a well balanced fragrance especially for a mass marketed designer brand. This opens up loud, heady & projects very well for the first 1-2 hours. And it last at least 8 hours on me as I am referring to the EDT. This is nothing short of a feminine fragrance. I for one hate to classify fragrances to the men/women category as I wear whatever works for my skin regardless whom it is marketed towards, tho I cannot help shake the feeling this is more suited towards the dames.

It is a shame that Gucci discontinued this beauty as this was when Gucci as a perfume house WAS one of the best in the mass market designer game. Since the fall of Gucci Envy for men, this house has taken a downward spiral into the gates of hell with it's current creations which are uninspiring & non pleasing to my nose. The great Tom Ford helped this house ALOT when he worked for them, but once he left, it was curtains & mini blinds for Gucci!

review_title: An intense fruity, floral fragrance in a style no longer considered fashionable.
review_content: Accenti EDT is an old perfume from Gucci, created in 1995 by Dominique Ropion and now discontinued. You can still find sample dabbers on eBay and other sellers. This review is based on a sealed 50 ml splash bottle I bought on eBay many years ago. It is difficult to trace the formulation and provenance as this brand has changed hands many times. Accenti looks back at the...

A few weeks ago, my favorite cousin and best friend passed away. For 60 years, we shared and extensively discussed every event in our lives. Both of our lives had their share of heavy fates, but also joyful and carefree times. Like most people's. Now she is forever unreachable. Today, I received a visit from her daughter, who was my godchild. In passing, she told me that...

When the young woman crosses my path, I feel as if someone has turned off the light in her eyes. The glow, the life, the unbearable lightness of being. Her gaze not only reminds me of a zombie but also of a person with a bowel obstruction.

But what happened that brought everything to this point?

As I stand in front of my fragrance shelf in the evening, I am almost overcome by a moral scent hangover when I encounter Gucci Accenti, one of my former loyal fragrance companions, again.

What was it like back when I was still a little scent punk? I sprayed myself with all sorts of things. Only those vintage fragrances were so strong back then that one could feel as if being gassed by this atomic bomb sillage.

But with the spraying of this fragrance, all sorts of other memories awaken in me.

All I can say is tonka bean. But I had forgotten for years what tonka bean even smelled like... It is somehow powdery, fruity, and then comes this vintage touch. But how does one explain vintage as a scent?

Like a bad omen, I also recall the funeral blues by W.H. Auden from my bookshelf:

Stop all the clocks,
Cut off the telephone.
Prevent the dog from barking
With a silent key.
Silence the pianos
And with muffled drum
Bring out the coffin.

Let aeroplanes circle moaning overhead
Scribbling on the sky
He is gone.

He was my North, my South,
My East and West.
My Sunday rest
And my week’s stress.
My talk, my song,
My day, my night.
I thought love would last forever:
Wrong, I was wrong.

You stars are not wanted now;
Put out every one.
Pack up the moon
And dismantle the sun.
Pour away the ocean
And sweep

Our neighbor (who has since passed away) was a friendly, helpful, and nice woman. Among other things, she was my confirmation sponsor and also a very generous person. I always received many Christmas and birthday gifts. - At first, they were mostly books, later on, cosmetics, as she was a very well-groomed lady herself. The sample of the fragrance that the dear Iris, in...

Misled by the name Accenti, I expected a sharp, rather austere scent. I was surprised by a warm, soft fruity melting note that emerged immediately after spraying. It is subtle yet still quite noticeable, with a hint of luxury without coming across as cool or distant. The sweet fruity orange, the golden peach, the rose - all of this creates a wonderful blend that makes you feel...

I tested Gucci Accenti today and once again found a perfume that I really like, and I have to ask myself: "why aren't you around anymore"? Unfortunately, it is mostly only available at a high price now :( A sweet scent! I can only confirm the fragrance pyramid as stated above, yet I also smell some Neroli, Tonka bean, vanilla/pod, and a bit of more robust musk in the base...

I can only agree with my predecessors. It is truly incomprehensible that this fragrance is no longer being produced, as it is really something very special and in no way a generic scent.
Unfortunately, I only own a sample, which is already half empty.

On my skin, I primarily detect spicy and floral notes, which is why I perceive the scent as slightly diva-like; that is to say, I think it suits confident women who like to stand out, but still prefer to be subtle rather than obvious. It gives one a beautiful feminine, sensual aura without being intrusive. In my opinion, Accenti is a fragrance for women between 25 and 50 who want to emphasize their self-confidence and zest for life.

For me, it is one of the best fragrances I have ever tested.

When I blind bought my JPG Flower Edition back then, I was really worried.
Because I’ve never owned a floral based perfume before, so I was nervously anticipating to try it.
The day came when it arrived and oh boy!
It was love at first spray! And I knew I would be hunting for more floral based scents.

Now for the Guilty Love Edition.
This starts off very fresh on me.
Not out of the shower fresh but more clean like a very expensive floral soap.
Then the full strenght of the floral and sweetness quickly add on top of the clean/fresh scent. The scent becomes unisex at this paticular point for me.
The dry down is just heavenly and exhilarating! Clean, (a faint minty) creamy, floral, a bit powdery and soft sweetness.
It gives an elegant, beautiful and a really good happy vibe.
I also think the orange blossom provides quite a character.

This perfume smells very unique and high quality to me.
I’m definitely going to buy another bottle for backup.

I had this on today. 3 sprays for testing. One on the collarbone, one on the back of my neck and one on my wrist. It was 15 degrees celcius but cloudy and rather windy. I was occasionally getting a whiff of the scent, whenever the wind shifted.
When I was indoors, the scent stayed constantly and I would say that the sillage was an arms lenght and leaves a good scent trail.

The longevity was 9+ hours on my skin.
Worth mentioning is that I have a very dry skin.
I use NUXE Huile Prodigieuse Multi Purpose Dry Oil Face Body Hair Spray on my upper body daily before I go out.
So the longevity on my perfumes get a tad bit longer on me.
I think women can easily wear this too.
I definitely would not mind it on my wife.
I would be constantly sniffing her, but that’s another story…lol

Spectacular release. It is like an eau fraiche of the elixir, with good performance. Easily the better of the two in warmer situations, and this thing generates positive reactions from people like nothing I've ever seen. If you like white florals, this is one of the more modern masculine-leaning interpretations. I would put this squarely in the MYSLF ballpark, but that is more feminine-leaning. This one is the grand slam, and MYSLF (both iterations) are the runner picked off at first base. I believe this is a limited edition, as well. Either way, it is a LOVE for me.

I'll say it right away and without preamble: The color of the bottle does not lie. The scent is truly nothing less.

You can clearly recognize the Guilty line. But this one is fresher, more synthetic, creamier, fruitier, and a bit less floral than Guilty pour Homme EAU DE PARFUM or Guilty Parfum pour Homme. It is quite loud, but of course not as potent as Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Homme. The orange blossoms also shine wonderfully here.

Who likes it?

I see a young man in spring. In great spirits, sun-kissed, fashionably dressed, and with a mischievous glint in his eye.

Who doesn't like it?

More mature gentlemen, who find their happiness in fougère or cardamom, might feel a bit out of place here.

How good that I have been 20 for over 30 years…

I've read several times that many buy the brand just because they want to be someone they are not.

"Maybe there's something to that," I thought to myself this morning.
Then I applied it and adjusted my sunglasses.

"I am young."
"I live in Florence."
"What does the world cost?"
"I am Gucci!"

review_title: Valentine's Day for Him and Her
review_content:
I better take another look at the packaging. Yes, indeed. "pour Homme" is written there. However, Guilty Love Edition pour Homme EAU DE PARFUM is so unisex, it almost leans towards the feminine, that one can hardly believe their eyes, or rather their nose.

Upon spraying, the fragrance starts with a synthetic, indefinable freshness (could that be juniper? Please...), but quickly becomes sweet and, above all, incredibly floral-creamy. The orange blossom is absolutely at the center here, supported in the first hour by a slightly sharp fresh note (and at this point still somewhat related to the Guilty pour Homme EAU DE TOILETTE DNA), but over time it becomes tamer and more affectionate. A super cuddly, friendly scent.
However, so much amiability is also relatively unsexy. So it's not a fragrance for a first date, but one for a solid partnership and certainly ideal for a cozy evening for two in spring or summer. But it also suits gatherings with friends and (innocent) parties.
Well-made floral fragrances that can also be worn by men have always captivated me. I love Sunshine Man and "Fleur du Mâle | Jean Paul Gaultier," and Guilty Love Edition pour Homme EAU DE PARFUM reminds me a bit of the latter, although even softer, less masculine, and even less bitter.

The floral scent projects well for 2 hours and then fades, but lasts almost 9 hours. Quite decent. And long enough to fill a Valentine's afternoon. Oh, what a pity that Valentine's Day is already over this year. Such a perfectly fitting fragrance for it.

Yes, it is my giveaway scent and it has won as well.
I had to wait a few days and, a bit hesitantly, I sprayed the glamorous magnolia. I don't usually like it too floral, but I was very pleasantly surprised.
The green notes leave a smile on my face.
FGM starts very dry, slightly bitter, with a paired sweetness of the freesia, which is subtle enough for me.
I confess that I don't really know the scent of magnolia. I do have one in my front yard, but since it is very young, it doesn't emit such a powerful magnolia scent in spring yet. According to some minor research, the scent of magnolia is simulated through artificial means. Essences of rose, jasmine, neroli, ylang-ylang, and synthetic aroma substances are used for imitation.

I find the further scent development fruity, and green still plays a good supporting role. I experience a tingling in my nose; something is happening here. Spring fizz?
FGM is marketed as a spring fragrance, which is understandable, as the magnolia takes the lead here. However, this is not so relevant for me.
Today would be a day, for example, when I could very well imagine the scent on my skin. Although it is winter, the thermometer showed about 10 degrees today.

The base note develops woody, still bitter green. The sweetness has become even more subtle.
I can sense a hint of chocolate, but probably only because it appears in the pyramid. So, gourmand lovers, you will be disappointed here.

I like the scent and am still happy that I was able to win it thanks to parfumo.

Addendum from the internet: “Magnolia scent inspires the imagination and stimulates creative creation.”

Well then, I’ll spray some........

Speaking of spraying; the longevity is average to good. I only sprayed subtly. That was a good three hours ago, and I can still perceive the scent well. The sillage is rather subtle.

Actually, I wasn't in the mood to start a new fragrance flirt. I was just going on vacation and didn't really have much money.

To my dismay, I had forgotten my then-signature scent J’adore at home. Well, okay - 20 euros - that was the maximum I could spend on a fragrance flirt from the duty-free shop at the airport...

I asked for Davidoff Cool Water Woman, as I wanted to connect those aquatic notes with the scent of the sea. Well, tough luck. The salesperson wasn't going to let me have that. With that question, I became “Davi-doof” to him.

“Are you crazy!! - Do you want to smell like millions of others! - Come on, Gucci has released a Glamorous line - you should try that and then we’ll talk....”

So I tried... Gardenia was great, but it turned too sweet on my skin.

With Flora Magnolia, I initially sensed a citrus scent, and I love citrus fragrances. Then I detected floral notes.

But I left the store without buying anything... Until...

Suddenly, a fine, extraterrestrial-galactic noble chocolate scent unfolded, paired with angelic peony and sandalwood, which I can't describe.

I was enveloped in the finest fragrance I had ever smelled.

Since vanilla turns too sweet on my skin, this was the perfect counterpart that developed well on my skin.

Unfortunately, the sillage isn't as strong as I would wish. However, I find the longevity of 5 hours to be really good.

What can I say, this fragrance flirt cost me quite a bit. With a budget of 20 euros, I ended up spending 80 euros on a fragrance, but I haven't regretted it to this day.

From this flirt, over the years, a great love for fragrance has developed. I'm soon buying my 5th bottle.

And I thank the salesperson for helping me find this love for fragrance and uniqueness. Because each of us is unique - we just have to dare to be so.

First of all - I also love wearing Flora - especially because of its enchanting lightness and romantic floral notes.

Could Glamorous Magnolia keep up with that?
Definitely!

This fragrance shines in glow and glory with bright freesias, green notes, and a tangy fresh citrus peel - right from the start.
Then, the pale pink magnolia blooms in a truly glamorous way, adding a gentle sweetness to the fresh-green entrance.

Another highlight is the fine chocolate, which skillfully merges with the sweetness of the magnolia.

A special fragrance blend that certainly has a glamour factor, yet still presents itself romantically.

My friend gifted me this beautiful fragrance today, which is also fitting for the season - and we admire the elegant magnolias in the garden together.

My precious birthday perfume voucher led me to the perfumery. After a long search, it had to be the very best... Then the discovery: Like a precious treasure, I carried it home. It became a very close confidante, yes, a beloved: the Glamorous Magnolia.

She is a lovely and delicate one, who absolutely lifts the mood with her pleasant character. Her first breath is fresh, a little green, and slightly citrusy. Her indescribable beauty truly shines when she reveals her heart: wonderfully dense magnolia and peony blossoms that radiate in all their glory. A warm, slightly powdery sweetness beautifully rounds off her presence, her completion, allowing her to emanate enjoyment and joy for her admirers for many hours.

My unique friend is neither intrusive, nor kitschy, nor overly sweet. How else can I describe her? ...simply one of a kind and incomparable...
I just can't get enough of her: my Glamorous Magnolia.

To get straight to the point: I always found the original version Flora by Gucci to be really, really terrible. It may sound strange to say this, but my untrained nose detected something very sour, almost rotten, at the end of every breath of this perfume. I’m so sorry for everyone who loves this fragrance. But I just can’t stand it. Now for the good news:
I gave Glamorous Magnolia a chance (especially because its color promised freshness). I love, love, love this scent. And I think I know why by now. Personally, I just don’t like floral fragrances that are simply sweet. However, here the magnolias are combined with wonderful citrus notes, which I personally really enjoy. Moreover, the sweetness of the magnolias is not a sharp sweetness, but rather a delicate, caressing sweetness. This results in a soft, green, fresh, yet warm fragrance that I find very pleasant.

review_title: Of Flowers and Dark Chocolate: More a Whiff than a Scent
review_content: As the basis for my brief description, I draw on 2 encounters with Glamorous Magnolia: once (a) a scent pad in a newspaper, and then (b) 3 sprays from the Turquoise. Surprisingly, two quite different impressions! a) The first encounter was pleasantly floral, warm, and developed with floral freshness into a musky warmth. I was thrilled, as nothing sweet bothered me. I am...

~ Inspiration ~
Last year I tested Gucci's "Flora" and also received a sample of "Glamorous Magnolia."

~ Bottle ~
The hexagonal shape corresponds to that of the original version, from which the new "Garden Collection" with fragrances like Magnolia, Tuberose, and Gardenia has developed.

~ Fragrance ~
It is not just made of Magnolia, but this forms the centerpiece of the scent.
With fresh citrus peels, green notes, and freesias, it starts fresh and slightly herbaceous. Blooming magnolias and peonies give it a sweet-floral and slightly powdery character. Musk, sandalwood, and dark chocolate round it off with a woody warmth.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 6 hours (on clothing and hair a bit longer). 1-2 sprays are sufficient, as it is quite intense and synthetic.

~ Occasion ~
A nice everyday fragrance for spring, summer, and autumn. In winter, it is too floral for me.

~ Conclusion ~
It bears a slight resemblance to "Oh Lola" by Marc Jacobs.

Man oh man, this is straight white spring blossoms bottled into a scent. Spring has sprung with such vigor these last few weeks where I am, that you can't go anywhere without powdery and soft florals dominating the air - and Gucci Bloom can give you the same sensation wherever you are.

It's mostly ylang-ylang and for the duration of the scent. A very linear but powerful fragrance. You can spray this on your clothes and I kid you not, will be there the next morning still just as powerful. I'd definitely say it's feminine, but I think a warm floral on a man is just as suitable too. I mean I've been wearing it for a year.

Gorgeous, heady and sophisticated white florals. Jasmine and tuberose are clearly the stars here. Exuberant white fragrance: carnal, powdery, and fresh with a beautiful creaminess. I do detect a hint of green, like smelling a freshly picked flower and inhaling all of the flower's parts: petals, heart, stem and leaves. Ylang-ylang also offers its presence, giving the scent a lovely creaminess, but also a hint of tropical sweetness that further complexifies the scent and adds a beautiful layer to it. Drydown is warm, creamy, musky and powdery.

It's a very complex scent that honors the white flowers in here. Not my thing since I'm not a fan of powderiness and I'm not that into white flowers, so it won't be making it into my collection, but I do recognize it's a very strong fragrance that has lasting power. For people who love powderiness and white florals, this might be a great choice!

The opening really goes strong with the white floral notes. Jasmine and the Rangoon Creeper found in the others. However, the ‘sun-drenched wood’ accord here does really bring a bright and sunny feeling to Profumo di Fiori.

Creeper starts off the strongest to me. Then, the jasmine really kicks into overdrive for a long while.

Solar notes have become more common in fragrances over the past few years. With the blend of floral notes, this perfume does have a warm and somewhat buttery quality to it. In the early stages, at least.

Ylang-ylang comes in to further this trend. A nice yellow floral touch to the jasmine dominant mix.

The sandalwood stands out as the non-floral part of this early. Well, aside from that generic wood note, that is sun-drenched. Later, this gets muskier, not to a huge extent. Just, more noticeable than the woods.

As it dries down, the tuberose and the jasmine sort of split duties as the leading notes. Ultimately, more of the tuberose. The ylang-ylang sticks around somewhat, but whatever is left of the Rangoon Creeper has gone into oblivion it seems.

In the end, this is a sunny and upbeat white floral with bits of ylang-ylang, musk, and wood.

This is quite a strong white floral scent that some people will not appreciate. I love it because it's not as light and airy as other floral perfumes but stronger and headier, almost spicier. My sister told me I smell like a barn the first time I was wearing this. It's still very approachable, but better and more nuanced than the original Bloom. It's the "ugly", unglamourized side of the countryside.

review_title: Do you sweat? Are you sweaty?
review_content: I only ask this because I am sweating right now. Like, just in general, constantly damp pits on this woman. But boy oh boy can you not tell. This beautiful floral really works well with human body chemistry. The sharp initial floral dries down into something aquatic and lush. As an avid SSRI enthusiast, this perfume has saved my life more than once when it came to my own personal underarm swamp situation. How can you tell I've sweat through my shirt when I smell like Gucci Bloom Profumo Di Fiori? That's right, you can't! I'm wet and unstoppable!

An adorable powder puff of a thing that takes the cleanest, most golden resins and grinds them down into a fine talc that begs to be laid down thickly on a bosom. It smells babyish and coquettish in the best way possible. Last Sunday, I put this on in Fiumicino airport and it clung to the sleeves of my cashmere cardigan all the way back to Nairobi, cocooning me against far less pleasant smells in a blissfully white, pearlescent cloud. I smelled like a freshly cleaned and lotioned baby. Almost a week later, it still lingers on the fabric.

I was annoyed. Really annoyed. You know that feeling, right? That latent annoyance. You read and read, for days on end. Pyramids. Up and down. Every Egyptologist would turn pale with envy. So many beautiful pyramids. And then you pick one. Eureka. The pyramid of your unfulfilled fragrance dreams. That one that contains everything you’ve ever dreamed of in a pyramid. You absolutely need it in your small, exquisite pyramid collection. And I mean SUBITO!
And then the postman arrives and drops a completely innocent padded envelope in your mailbox. Salivating and with flapping lips, you rush outside, immediately tear apart the carefully sealed packaging, and spray the first drops of the long-awaited dream pyramid onto your wrist in a trance-like state right in the hallway. Instinctively, you raise your hand and ... ZONK! Well. While your lips, succumbing to gravity and disappointment, seek their way downwards, you already wonder how a fragrance that is perceived extremely positively by so many people can be so painfully mediocre. And why did this damn pyramid lie so brazenly? And you know what? If it had only been this one time ...
But no. The more you test, the less you like it. You’ve probably become more discerning, no longer allowing just any old Ambrocashmeralonemaltolfusel to be slipped under your nose. And that’s where the misery begins.
Do you smell that too? That base? Yes, exactly! I mean that Baaah-sis of space musk that makes us all smell a bit like Hans-Jürgen's old sweatshirt after the fabric softener bath. I’ll just put on my hate cap right away. We’ve picked ourselves a nice hobby - you and I. And then this nonsense also costs real money! One is allowed to lose their temper over that. After all, not everyone is born with a high tolerance for frustration.
But I don’t want to just complain here; that’s not good for mental balance in the long run. And it causes wrinkles - except for me, of course. Because sometimes, things turn out quite differently. Then the corners of your mouth can actually point towards the ceiling. You’ve probably experienced that now and then too. It happened to me just recently when a small, inconspicuous spray bottle rolled out from one of those hastily torn envelope remnants.
Gucci was written on it. Well, that can go horribly wrong. They can create beautiful fragrances. Undoubtedly. But unfortunately, they often also shamelessly achieve the complete opposite. The Eyes of the Tiger. Mon Dieu. We’re fishing in quite lyrical-botanical waters here. If the name is too over-the-top, I’m always ready for confrontation. It’s like with children. If eight-year-old Quentin-Cassian fumbles while tying his shoes, I also find it hard to applaud.
But no, Gucci has a concept, of course. I just say: Amber. In faraway China, amber symbolizes the soul of the tiger. And what is considered a mirror of the soul? Yes indeed. You see, that’s how the circle closes, and we’ve clarified why this (I’m just going to shout it out into the world) stunningly beautiful, softly vanillic, and cuddly resinous amber scent is named as it is. And do you know what the best part is? Nothing annoys me here at all. And that means something. Normally, I jump out of my skin at the slightest thing that isn’t exactly where I want it to be. These tiger eyes are the purest sedative for my sanguine nature; they comfort, they envelop, they provide warmth and security. Not a tiny bit of synthetics, nothing! A perfectly rounded, deeply harmonious fragrance, whose extraordinarily natural quality justifies its (well, exorbitantly high) price. Or let’s put it this way: Compared to other outrageously overpriced fragrances, "The Eyes of the Tiger" smells significantly more high-quality.
When I set out this morning to comment on this fragrance, I spritzed myself with four hearty sprays from the little test atomizer and made my way to the stable. Drizzle, just above freezing. A gently resinous sweetness envelops me on the way across the fields. The weather is secondary. The fragrance warms me. Rain? So what? It protects me. And it does so without the specific amber heaviness that clings to so many heavily ambered perfumes, which I absolutely detest. Let’s be honest - that viscous amber feeling that often carries a hint of animalic ... it’s no good. Yuck! That annoys me right back. It feels like some clever clogs has gelled the air when you breathe. But no need to worry. The tiger eyes are free from gelatin and puma cages. The scent progression is overall quite linear and unremarkable. Here too, the fragrance remains true to its calm, grounded aura. The feather-light resinousness of the top note gradually transitions into the most beautiful vanilla base I know. I perceive a very slight powderiness, which never becomes dusty or cloying, but merely prevents the fragrance from drifting into the sticky-heavy side of vanilla. I find the sweetness perfectly balanced and never piercing or shrill.
Oh, and if you’re expecting a punch with a club-like sillage because you absolutely want the entire northern hemisphere to partake in your good taste in perfume, I’m afraid I have to disappoint you. You’ll have to go to Louis - he has something for that.
You see, I really like it. It’s balm for my annoyed soul. A fragrance for arriving, for being with oneself, not a scent for escaping, but a destination scent. A therapeutic fragrance. Perfectly suited for treating acute pyramid traumas. Did you notice? It doesn’t have any.

I have been quietly reading along for ages, and usually, there is a collection of comments for each fragrance that describe what I think in a more refined way or at least provide enough information to make my own comment unnecessary. There are rarely fragrances that I truly chase after and need to experience for myself to form an opinion - this is one of those. Why? I’m not quite sure. Maybe it was the name that reminded me of the universally beloved movie hero :)

Basically, the "title" describes almost everything. Almost everything? Well, not quite. Fans of the film series will have seen all parts including Rocky 6 aka "Rocky Balboa," for all those who haven’t (Rocky is one of the most underrated film series for me and is far from getting the depth of its character recognized in the mainstream) - Rocky 1-5 is practically the life story of a nobody who fights his way up from the streets of Philadelphia, loses fights, wins fights, gains wealth, loses wealth, turns friends into enemies and enemies into friends, but fundamentally always fights with himself - an outwardly rude, stubborn, whiny, eruptive, and cynical person, but inside an empathetic, sensitive, and sad soul in a constant battle with himself. In the sixth part, the series culminates, and Rocky has reached the end of his career, his dearly beloved wife has died, his wealth has faded, his relationship with his son is strained, and his other social interactions are marked by (self)-pity. He indulges in memories of past days and sinks into a permanently melancholic state of mind because the measures of his self-worth, first professional success and then familial success, have crumbled, and he sees a broken man in the mirror who has no goal in sight and has lost his zest for life. He imparts a lesson on life attitude to his son, which has since become part of the standard repertoire of every YouTube motivational video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mk82j1jQw_8), but which probably applies just as much to him as it does to his son. Nevertheless, a never-ending, small fire burns in his heart, and the motivation that brought him to this point still sparkles in his eyes - this indomitable will to show everyone and not give up, despite the adverse circumstances, which also leads to a reconciliatory ending of the series and gives Rocky the chance to finally make peace with himself and his soul.

So much for the digression - now to the perfume. How does all of this fit together? For me, the title "Eye of the Tiger" actually doesn’t fit the perfume at all, nor does the music. The symbiosis of an animalistic, untamed tiger to a cuddly little tiger happens for me more in the heart, and that is exactly where the perfume belongs. The spicy-smoky start with amber gives way after a while to the powdery, balsamic vanilla with a hint of rose. I can relate to the "dustiness," but it doesn’t bother me at all. There is nothing to criticize about the sillage and longevity, absolutely high quality. For me, it’s a fragrance for a cold, sunny autumn day when the wind blows a bit harsher than usual and you see the slowly browning leaves reflected in the puddles. Summer is now over, autumn has long taken hold of us, and the longing for warmer days alleviates the nostalgia of the colder and darker days a bit. If there were a Rocky score that accompanies this perfume a bit better in my opinion, it would be this one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cdcAwpXK1a4

Conclusion: The perfume is far more complex than I expected, and if I had to describe how Rocky's heart smells - this perfume would describe it perfectly. At first, it’s a bold, almost intrusive companion that becomes gentler over time and offers a sense of security without suffocating. In any case, I am smitten, and if it weren’t so expensive, I would have taken it home right away. Unfortunately, it remains only on my list of perfumes from which I will acquire a decant when the opportunity arises and use it on special occasions.

Pam... PamPamPam... PamPamPam... PamPamPaaaaaaaaammmmmm...
So, who recognized the intro??
Honestly, is it because I'm a child of the '80s or do you also hear the resonant name "The Eyes of the Tiger" and immediately think of the first few notes of Survivor's "The Eye of the Tiger" from the movie of the same name (the third part of the Rocky series with Sylvester Stallone and Mr. T.)?
Ridiculous, because it creates a complete misassociation!
Gucci's "Tiger Eyes" have nothing to do with the struggle for survival on the streets, the challenge of wanting to assert oneself against an opponent, or the thrill of a fight. It's not an exciting perfume in that sense, but rather a pure cuddly scent!
Here, Alberto Morillas once again shows that he really excels at creating scents with a cuddly factor and skillfully showcases the balance of amber and vanilla. Have you smelled it all before? Not quite..., at least not with Gucci. Because in my opinion, this fragrance does stand out a bit from the brand's usual style. These "Tiger Eyes" don't pierce you with their gaze, but rather brush against you softly and tenderly. The cistus and the hint of an unlisted touch of musk (my nose agrees with that of Yatagan) give it a special sparkle, reflecting a trace of subtle eroticism and perhaps just a tiny bit of hunting instinct. More like a tigress with particularly flirtatious eyes who might be a little in heat?
The scent is certainly persistently cuddly and enchants with its sweet-ambery smoky soft aura.
If Rocky had worn this for his fight with Mr. T., the two surely wouldn't have gotten out of the clinch, and if they did, it would probably have ended in an invitation to a candlelight dinner...

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Femme
review_content:
six months ago, I would have definitely associated this scent with the cooler season...
now it’s summer and I just couldn’t resist trying it from my cabinet. I remembered the scent as sweet, floral, and very long-lasting... nothing very extraordinary, but also not unpleasant.

Now, sprayed on in summer, it reminds me of a certain sunscreen or was it the oil from Hawaiian Tropic? I definitely feel like I’m in vacation mode now... for a hot summer evening at the beach bar, it’s certainly not the worst choice...

use with caution! Very long-lasting.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Femme
review_content:
even though I won't be adding it to my collection, as it is a bit too close to "Hubba Bubba".
It starts off very sweet, which I like, right away with a spicy unusual note. I guess it's osmanthus. Fortunately, there are no citrus notes. Then it gets even sweeter (wisteria) and just a tiny bit fruity. That's the moment when the scent starts to remind me very strongly of the pink chewing gum.
After 40 minutes, "Hubba Bubba" is gone and tonka bean is very present, a bit of fruitiness remains and vanilla brings the next, warm soft sweetness.
It is a joy to sniff, but I wouldn't want to smell like this myself.

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Femme
review_content:
Dramatic sounds fade into the biting night, filled with piercing cold. Sounds, emerging from a dark brown violin, whose heaviness recently tells of a sorrowful sadness. First timid, quiet notes that suddenly pick up speed, as if their only goal is to escape the frosty sub-zero temperatures. Vivaldi's Winter. An all-encompassing sadness, whose beginning is based on a tragic guilt and thus continuously takes its course. Overwhelming, like the weight of a gigantic stone on innocent blooming daisies. All-consuming. No light shines nearby, only individual flames burn in the blazing beyond, far removed from any real existence. The hellish tunnel continues to expand, dark and invincible.

What would she give for a spark of hope in her utterly discouraged being! What would she give for a few meager gestures of love and forgiveness in this suffocating emptiness of loneliness! What would she give for a bright spark of light in this all-consuming, darkness-occupied world!

Time takes its course and changes fundamentally as if by magic. There it is. The patch of earth, illuminated by individual bright rays, far away yet so close. Velvety expanses, violet tones that produce joyful sounds. Vivaldi's Spring, those gentle tones of the Allegro that can even awaken bears from their hibernation. The burden disappears as quickly as it once crept in. From here to now. The elixir of life is here and waits to be tasted, to become healing and whole. The elixir that symbolizes forgiveness.

To the fragrance. Even if individual opinions differ vastly from mine, I still stand by my own. This scent embodies the elixir of life par excellence. It is joyful, graceful, dense. Once, guilt (Guilty) may have been at work, to rediscover itself anew - not entirely harmoniously. With this fragrance, those times of guilt are over and are replaced by the elixir of life and proverbial forgiveness. Once sprayed on the wrist, it enchanted me immediately. The top notes consisting of citrus and flowers come across to me as creamy marzipan. I love it. The base lingers on me for quite a long time, releasing pleasantly warm essences that feel earthy, woody, and simultaneously gourmand. An absolute dream. Since "Rush | Gucci," I have found my way back to the House of Gucci after 24 years.

The elixir of life has its price. Well, in a few weeks, I will turn 50. Perhaps I will treat myself to this expensive bottle for the occasion. Merry Christmas, dear ones.

"Forgiveness is the greatest task of love - and its greatest risk."

product_name: Guilty Elixir de Parfum pour Femme
review_title: The Downfall of the House of Gucci
review_content:
Clearly referencing the current Netflix series in the title.
But I don't even find the series exciting, let alone the fragrance.
I actually like the book much better (The Fall of the House of Usher
short story by Edgar Allan Poe) and, as so often, things are not presented as originally as they should be.

I honestly have no idea what Gucci has produced here, as it is as uninspired as so many newcomers from designer houses. Yes, I have been constantly complaining lately, except maybe about the new scent from D&G. That one was quite alright. But this here is an outrage. Especially for so much money. Some regular brands can do better and for significantly less money. It's a shame really, because Gucci had fragrances in the past that were enjoyable and that people liked to wear. Guilty was my guilty pleasure scent back then; I emptied several bottles. Even today I find it lovely, but I have become more discerning. I think you know what I mean.

This scent here smells like the many €10 Bipa fragrances - artificial, overly sweet, with flowers thrown in. A pronounced, piercing opening that carries so much violet, which is already overwhelming. Rose that spreads everywhere, but is as artificial as a rose from AliExpress. Creamy undertone, with an indefinable cosmetic note. Vanilla sugar dusted, sinking into warm, damp earth. There’s not much longevity; it oozes oily, spreads insignificantly on the skin, before it gets a truckload of artificial flowers dumped on top.

The scent itself has no progression, no depth. It just oozes along. It sneaks around like a newborn kitten that isn’t yet steady on its feet.
The longevity is pretty poor for an elixir, and the sillage is the same. I can’t find joy in the bottle either. It would certainly look good on the vanity of a 14-year-old. Sorry to the fans, but that was my first association with the bottle.

Well, what else can I write? Everything has actually been said. Once again, a flop for me. Inside, I would have been excited because it is a Guilty and evokes many memories, but this one is simply quite unsuccessful.

As I brought the bottle to my nose, I smelled florality and a hint of vanilla. Hyacinth, ylang ylang and lemon open up at the beginning. An unusual feeling of freshness, like in a forest. Then the aroma began to smell floral, everything smells: jasmine, lilac, lily of the valley, iris and rose. Although there are a lot of flowers, it seems that you have come out of the forest into a clearing strewn with flowers. At the end it starts to smell like cedar, moss and vetiver. Although the aroma tries to show sweetness at the end, the aroma still smells like wood, a very beautiful tree.

I do not remember how I got my hands on the gorgeous fragrance, and it came without the top - but I do feel lucky. This is on level with Gucci Eau de Parfum, which I am very fond of. Actually, I have come to think that Eau de Gucci is a beautiful mix between Envy EdT and GEdP. The top is definitely Envy, fruity and fresh, almost sparkling and when the top fades, the Iris and the other flowers push on and softens the scent. I do sometimes make a comparison to Cacharel’s Anaïs Anaïs (the original from 1978). But EdG performs way better and has this very delicious citric aspect, that AA lacks.
EdG is long lasting and wraps me in a haze of uplifting notes for a whole day. I wear this when the temperature is below 10 degrees.
Do not hesitate to buy, if you get the chance.
Year 2, 155/365

Eau de Gucci was the second women’s fragrance launched by Gucci after Gucci No. 1 and exudes Italian-urban flair: A spritz and Villa Borghese, Trevi Fountain, Colosseum, Spanish Steps, Via Condotti, or Piazza Navona flash by. If I had to describe Eau de Gucci in one word, it would be “sophisticated.” Despite the “Eau” in the name, which suggests a light refreshing water, it is a demanding class fragrance full of life that radiates effortless elegance and stands on equal footing with Gucci's masterpiece Gucci No. 3.
By definition, Eau de Gucci is a pure Chypre with bergamot and lemon in the top notes, and oakmoss, vetiver, and musk in the base. However, this fragrance is nothing like a typical Chypre, as it is soft, cuddly, and full - the woodiness, often bitterness of a Chypre is completely absent here. The notes of Eau de Gucci are so complex and skillfully woven into a dense fragrance veil that I cannot filter out individual components. The overall impression is that of a white floral, slightly spicy scent with green undertones and a hint of sweetness, where the floral bouquet is rather abstract in nature, meaning it conveys the idea of a white floral fragrance rather than the scent of white flowers themselves.
In the 80s and 90s, Eau de Gucci was sold as a fresh summer fragrance (inexpensively) and the perfume books from that time also list it under floral-fresh fragrances. A look at the fragrance pyramid mentioned above shows how much the definition of “fresh” has changed over time. With heavyweights like ylang-ylang in the top notes, tuberose and lily in the heart notes, and amber, musk, and vanilla in the base, Eau de Gucci today would almost be considered a Floriental. Additionally, Eau de Gucci Concentree (in the blue packaging) also had a hint of an animalic note (civet?). Corresponding to its time of origin, Eau de Gucci also scores with long-lasting wear and quite a strong sillage.

I am not a fan of Chypre! Most of the perfumes I got to sniff as a child in the 70s seemed to belong to this fragrance family. Of course, I didn't know that back then. But some perfumes that I received as samples (I was curious about everything fragrant!) or that were used by my mother's friends gave me headaches.

Even today, I can rarely identify a single note in the typical perfumes of the 70s, aside from the distinctive oakmoss. Now I know that oakmoss is not necessarily my favorite note - too often it comes across as bitter, harsh, or even sour on me at first. However, some floral Chypres do belong to my repertoire; I find most of them to be elegant, slightly aloof scents that are well-suited for more serious or festive (mostly evening) occasions, such as theater, opera, concert, or even Christmas parties (no, not the extravagant kind!). But I still cannot quite warm up to herbal-green Chypres.

"Eau de Gucci" is presumably a floral Chypre according to the pyramid, but in my perception, it has more of an autumnal-woody quality. Again, I cannot identify any individual notes. For years, I have been using a mini that I regularly bring out in September because I find it fitting for the early autumn mood. Now I have also acquired a vintage bottle. Why do I like this one and others Chypres less? Kugeldistel has already mentioned it - the bitter oakmoss is very subdued here. This makes the scent more pleasant, even though it remains distinctive and unmistakable.

And the vintage has a very decent sillage! I also really like that about this perfume.

review_title: Floral Chypre with a Strong Character
review_content:
At the outset, Eau de Gucci is very fresh and citrusy. The bergamot and lemon combine with a noticeable spiciness, probably from the balsamic galbanum, which snuggles beautifully between the citrus fruits. You can immediately tell that this is a very rich fragrance with a strong character.

As a tuberose lover, I must, however, search in vain for it here, just like for the lilac. Iris and rose push themselves to the forefront, while the lily of the valley tries to keep up, but it’s simply too small and fails to do so.

In the base, it doesn’t change too much. I can detect a hint of amber, but I don’t recognize any vanilla at all.

All in all, a very beautiful fragrance and a floral chypre as it should be.

review_title: Once again, a top fragrance that is being taken away from us.
review_content: A great all-rounder, I am really sad that it is no longer available!

L'Arte, huh?... Well, what can I say? It matches its name perfectly. Art... The art of indifference and nerve! Because even negative aspects demand a certain artistry. And here, this snob Italian lands a blow! She takes no prisoners! Insolence and sass galore! Rose as a note in perfumery, is not something I am truly fond of. (When it comes to male fragrances especially, I find it almost impossible for rose to be harmoniously blended in the composition. Untill now, only Loris Azzaro's Acteur and Alain Delon's Iquitos have found a not just decent but stunning way to do the trick.) But here rose shines! And not in a usual and, more or less, expected romantic way. No! A dirty and marginally vulgar rose it is that drags you by the nose... It is the scent of a woman who, under her expensive suit ( a Gucci one doubtless), hides leather underwear and a stiletto. A stiletto that she shall not hesitate to use, if all else fails (most unlikely). She had the misfortune of being born in a fin de siecle. In an era when the loud and hyperbolic (nonetheless dazzling) enfants terribles of the '80s started walking the path to oblivion and the watery and optimistic voices of the '90s started to gather attention further still. But she didn't care about it. To tell the truth she NEVER cared about anything! And today, even after so many years have passed since her departure for the heaven of lost scents, she still remains a serious contestant for the title of the most "Fuck you!" and "In your face!" attitude of the last decades...

Like many writers on this blog, I own many, many chypres: dry green, herbal, fruity, rosy -- you name it, I've owned it. For me, perfume pretty much requires oakmoss. There are two green chypres I consider pretty nearly perfect, and both were made by Gucci: L'arte and Gucci 3. (I prefer the latter slightly.) Both are wonderfully juicy, lush and well-blended, not elegant and austere as some French chypres are. If you like the genre, you must try them.

I utterly concur in your conclusions, but disagree with your imagination, GothicHeart. A woman wearing this isn't hiding leather or a stiletto under her clothes. She's got nothing on at all under there. Onlookers -- or I should say ongawkers -- see this plainly under her expensive silk dress. Everyone's polite, of course. Her jewelry's real and she's wearing the 80's version of Jimmy Choos. The guy she's with is a rakish, rich, worldly scoundrel who wants other men to ogle his conquest. They're dining late at the Mansion on Turtle Creek in Dallas, having just come from the theater. When they get home, he's going in the back way so they can strip naked and get in the pool under the moonlight. Inside they'll drink champagne. She says she'll never forget this night.

Or so I imagine.

L'Arte di Gucci moans passion and elegance. It's a woman who makes lyric love all night and the next day writes poetry. True, if anything interferes she gets a stiletto. Minor detail, though.

Hubby hunted an unopened vintage original down for me, I fell so in love with this rosy Chypre/Oriental. It's in line to be in my oriental shiff-fest underway, but a whiff of it this morning demanded instant review. If I could only have one fragrance, this treasure is one of the few I could live with forever.

This one is a true Art of perfumery for me! I really treasure my every bottle of this discontinued beauty. For me this is an epitome of one-of the kind perfume that is not made anymore! I wish i could have twice as more as i have of it now so it would last me a lifetime. Prepare to be noticed when you wear it, not everyone likes it and understands it nowdays (it IS a heavy scent and really bold), but you going to feel yourself like a million-dollar lady! Pure sophistication and class! But this is strictly a cold time fragrance for me, i would kill anyone near me wearing this one at summertime.
A LOT of roses and big jar of honey with some spices (coriander anyone?) and you will get an absolute ÜBERsexy, animalistic fragrance that is full of passion. It takes some nerve to wear it, but if you can handle it you won´t regret. EDP is a lasting monster, lasts for over 24h on my skin and even longer on clothes.
Use it with caution, do not over spray it or you might end up having a headache. 3-4 sprays are more than enough.
But in general this is a true masterpiece and one of my most favorite and outstanding fragrances! All later Gucci edition don´t even come close to this one! Truly THE BEST Gucci ever made for my personal taste. (Gucci nr 3 is amazing as well and is on the same level of quality)

“L'Arte di Gucci” belongs to no decade, no color, and hardly to any company or DNA. It is simply a Grand Dame, for whom neither time, hype, nor money matters.

Aldehydes. Everywhere I smell aldehydes. Clear, bright, fine aldehydes. Underlaid with a blue-blooded, fruity-fluttering rose that also breaks boundaries. “The Art of Gucci” - if only the brand would reveal itself like this more often nowadays… Herbal, chypre, a bit green, a bit prickly. Beyond any doubt. A scent that massively blows me away. Definitely ready for the close-up. Rarely wearable in my mind - but that’s it for critiques. Otherwise, a queen in the Colosseum. A perfume for Anita Ekbergs in the Trevi Fountain. Incredibly noble and magnificent. Intimidating.

Bottle: a piece of jewelry!
Sillage: elbow elegance
Longevity: 8-12 hours - wide range.

Conclusion: feels more Chanel than Gucci. And that is a compliment of the highest order. This olfactory masterpiece is an extinct dino, of which every bone should be preserved, praised, cherished, and cared for. Timelessly beautiful. Died as an idol.

review_title: Palladio and the Blue Cleaning Cloth
review_content: In my comment on "Noble Potion," I already mentioned that I have a pronounced preference for Venetian villas. I am particularly taken with the buildings of Andrea Palladio. So, I used a spa stay in the Veneto in the early nineties to visit the variety of villas around Vicenza. One side thought was also to see the locations of my beloved film adaptation of the opera "Don...

From the series "holy grails". This time: L'Arte di Gucci. When: early 90s to late 90s. How many bottles: only three pieces, but always the large bottles, and it was quite expensive back then, and one of them was even the Eau de Parfum, which was extremely intense and long-lasting. A long and deep love. When it was no longer available in German retail, I searched for it during every trip abroad. It is completely incomprehensible to me that L'Arte di Gucci disappeared relatively quickly back then. A shame.

After I had already discovered some favorites (Magie Noire, Coco), L'Arte di Gucci hit me like a bomb. I confess: I bought it after my best friend (with permission).
