She, in turn, received it as a gift from her then-boyfriend. He simply went into the rather professionally run small city perfumery, got advice, and hit the nail on the head. She loved the scent immediately and for many long years. And I couldn't resist either; I was immediately captivated by it. So, the scent, not my friend's boyfriend.

L'Arte di Gucci was a super elegant, radiant, loud yet finely composed Chypre blockbuster with stunning Italian Grandezza. The grand entrance, the crowd around you parts as if by itself, the enchanting aura surrounds and radiates. No old-fashioned aldehydes disturb, everything here is 90s-modern, chic, noble, luxurious. A rather dry scent, radiantly bright yet sensually dark, sour, but by no means flat, rather very deep, with a classic oakmoss base. Very full-bodied, yet very sharp-edged, pointed. The others are soft and cuddly; L'Arte had edges and corners, yet it was so self-assured and feminine that it was still very captivating.

Dress code: the little black dress, the grand gown, or - very sexy - the black fitted business suit with the bright white blouse with the pointed, open collar. Although I wore it more to lectures or parties back then; business was not yet on the agenda.

review_title: How much is a work of art worth?
review_content:
Presumably as much as the wealthiest lover is willing to pay...

No, I will not pay the astronomical prices for which a normally-sized bottle of “L'Arte di Gucci” is offered online! Even for the miniatures, some proud sums are demanded. No, I will instead content myself for now with my two miniatures, which, despite their considerable age, are still intact.

Although I am known not to be a fan of chypres, I do make exceptions for certain floral chypres and grant them my sympathy. “L'Arte” is an opulent blend of floral notes, where the aldehydes and oakmoss prevent the scent from appearing sweet or playful. Instead, they give the fragrance a slightly austere elegance, which I particularly appreciate at festive evening events during the pre-Christmas season or even on Christmas Eve itself. And I detect a dark base here that would do honor to many current perfumes that boast of containing oud. No, oud is certainly not in here - but this dark base truly makes “L'Arte” a small work of art for me.

I find the bottle extremely fitting for the fragrance!

Perhaps one day a bargain for the normally-sized bottle will come along...

Addendum (02/18): I have since managed to snag a large bottle!

review_title: Here it really packs a punch!
review_content:
A few weeks ago, I was asked to take a look at Gucci No. 1. I did just that and quickly found what I was looking for. However, during this search, I also stumbled upon other Gucci fragrances that are no longer available today. My enthusiasm for Gucci No. 1, along with Fran's wonderful comment and my curiosity, led me to seize an irresistible offer from L'Arte di Gucci.

I must admit that this scent is not for me. There are very, very few Chypres that I like, as they must meet very specific requirements for me. L'Arte di Gucci does not meet those, although I have to concede that it is a truly wonderful Chypre, and every Chypre lover and Chypre enthusiast should know it.

The opening is sharp, angular, almost piercing, and it overwhelms me a bit.

But the heart note reconciles; dry, fine, bright, absolutely unsweetened, yet in full bloom, it envelops me in a rather impressive scent cloud. In other words: the sillage is quite remarkable. I feel as if the fragrance is moving in this stage. It gets louder, then quieter, softer, and then sharper again - nothing is calm and relaxed. L'Arte di Gucci is the fragrance for a very self-confident, strong woman, because wherever she appears with this scent - she inevitably stands in the spotlight.

Towards the base, it becomes really dry and dark green. I suspect moss, but something resinous also comes through, as even the base is not calm and relaxed, but continues to follow the tenor of the entire fragrance.

L'Arte di Gucci is one of the most beautiful and pleasant Chypres I have tested, and even though it is not for me, any Chypre fan should fall in love with it. I can only agree with Fran when she says it is a shame when such fragrances are discontinued!

I really like perfumes with white flowers. Jasmine and tuberose are my favorite. Still, the Bloom line never once convinced me to buy one. It lacked conviction. I therefore had few expectations of the new Bloom 'Intense'. Mainly because of the patchouli and spices added to the notes.
But I couldn't have been more wrong.
The white flowers, especially tuberose and jasmine, open the fragrance in a soft and sweet way. They smell so realistic. I think the sweetness comes from the coconut. Soon the patchouli joins the fragrance. Where I normally hate patchouli it is now beautiful. It makes the tuberose woodier and that in combination with the coconut is great. Somewhere the ginger buzzes around the flowers. The smell doesn't change anymore. It gets softer and softer, after which it slowly goes out like a candle.
Kudos to Gucci for this flanker. Gucci Bloom 2.0
A golden move to add coconut and make the patchouli more dominant.

I stumbled upon Bloom Intense by chance in the perfume shop... The shelves at Gucci are currently very colorful and filled with flowers due to the new flankers... in contrast, the black bottle - which looks almost minimalist in this line - caught my eye.

When sprayed, it starts with a beautiful and soft orange blossom - nice, but nothing special, I thought. Then I somehow forgot about it while shopping.

At home, then hmmm... what is this?! And why does it seem familiar? It must be something older... Vintage vibes? A very, very noble floral scent wafted into my nose. Warm woods joined in... it felt so familiar. It seems so much more interesting than the bottle suggests, lush and opulent... but not overwhelming.

A few days later, I was struck by a bolt of realization... I know where the association comes from. It is owed to the Queen of the Night, which we already know from the old version of Dior Addict (2012) EAU DE PARFUM. It is not a 1 to 1 copy, nor an alternative... but the similarity is definitely there. This is where the vintage touch became clear to me.

A very, very noble and beautiful scent that still feels modern. It was still easily recognizable on the jacket from the day before. This bottle had to be mine... I really can't help it...

How about vintage vibes?
How about expensive cream?
Really floral, like a dream from Provence?

Actually, there should be a comment here about the regular Bloom, which embodies true beauty through the rangy, the neroli, and the tuberose, but unfortunately also represents intense stuffiness.

However, when I test the Intense, I have to admit that I am holding a genuine candidate for purchase in my hands.

The beauty lies in the high quality of the natural ingredients. There is no synthetic scent detectable.

And the floral aspect is so beautiful that I almost sink into it like a cloud.

It is lush without being suffocating.
It is refined without ever appearing banal for even a second.
It is interesting, even without the keyboard of individually perceivable components.

Okay, the sillage isn't super strong, but enough to have a pick-me-up for cold gray days by your side every day!

Vintage-creamy!
Vintage-floral!
Vintage-beautiful!

Absolute recommendation for testing!

This classic indeed is distinctively from a different/much better time. This fragrance doesn't shout, doesn't pout, and doesn't even last that long. What it DOES do is wanna pull you in for a closer whiff. When that happens you can easily smell all of those classic Masculine notes not seen or smelled so much nowadays. Notes like Carnation, Cedar, Oakmoss, and leather just to name a select few. I love Everything about this Classic Chypre, from the ingredients to the distinctive bottle. I was 5 yrs old when it was launched in 1976 and if I was of age back then this beauty EASILY would've been my go to scent of the night. I say that because, to me, this was/is a definite nightlife fragrance. Man things are so different now it's almost depressing. I mean, do people even go out and dance anymore?? This, along with Halston Z-14 was likely all over Studio 54 and other haunts as well. I love the earthy leathery and quite subtle scent this exudes without chopping your head off. The only drawback is the price as it's severely expensive so you have to dig deep to acquire this gem. I received a great deal though on this one and I'm looking forward to buying another from this long gone masculine era. So this is in my top 10 and it'll stay that way for a long time to come.

I arrived a little late to this party, yet after watching House of Gucci, I had to find a bottle of the original inspiration for men. This lost masterwork speaks a different language in today's market for men. In fact, it is totally foreign to anything sold or bottled after 1990.

The composition is fairly classic for its time. It seems so subtle with its streamline notes. Citrus, vetiver, carnation on leather and cedar sound dull in today's market. It doesn't shout or project very far. It seductively draws others in to get a better wiff. Its anything but dull. In fact, it's exciting as an inch of fresh cut bills in your wallet. Most modern "blue trends" are no comparison for today's crowd. This was when tattoos were vulgar.

The 1970s was "so free to do what or who you wanted" and this was what men who had carloads for money would wear for a night on the town. This smells like wealth, prestige and status. If you had the cash, then you had a pair of those gold lined shoes to go with it. Otherwise, you might be a "wanna-be" in the crowd. I imagine those wealthy men at Studio 54 who would mingle with the "commoners". If you were single, people might swarm you. Remember the disco classic He's the Greatest Dancer? " The best designers, heaven knows-Halston, Gucci, Fiorucci..." I get it now!

review_title: The Attack Of The Composition Killer Anise...
review_content:
Gucci pour Homme (original formula) goes on with a short lived blast of natural lemon with powerful oakmoss from the base immediately detectable underneath coupling with aromatic lavender and carnation. As the composition moves to its early heart the lemon vacates as the oakmoss gains strength, now joining a potent anise and musk-laced leathery labdanum with the carnation remaining in support. During the late dry-down the anise driven development abruptly transitions to powdery vanilla and amber over slightly sweet sandalwood as traces of the supporting musk remain through the finish. Projection is average to slightly above average and longevity very good at 10-12 hours on skin.

This composition is a real puzzler. When one reads the amazing list of notes it is hard not to sniff Gucci pour Homme without a positive disposition to love it; after all, the composition has a lot to recommend it... The natural lemon at the open is amazing though all too brief (most likely made even more brief and minimized by the age of the vintage bottle I acquired). The co-starring green oakmoss and leathery labdanum (rock rose) smell great together, leading to a quite remarkable abrupt transition to the powdery vanilla and sandalwood driven late dry-down. That said, while I do *like* the composition the love has surprisingly eluded me. I suspect the culprit that is holding me back from completely embracing it is what can best be described as a musky anise heart accord that just overpowers everything in its path at times and feels a hair out of place in this chypre. I would almost expect this kind of accord in a classic fougere, truth be told. So while the composition smells impressive on the whole, the anise plays spoiler, relegating it to "good" but not "great" status... The bottom line is the $100 per 30 ml bottle on the aftermarket discontinued original Gucci pour Homme smells very nice on the whole and features some high quality materials but the musky anise heart accord holds the composition back from its full potential, reducing it to a "good" to "very good" 3 to 3.5 stars out of 5 and a recommendation with minor reservation.

Another gem from my legendary visit to the "Ferrari" perfumery in Bolzano in September.

Yes, Gucci could still do it back then. With this, its first men's fragrance, Gucci set the bar so high that they could only surpass it once ("Nobile") or reach it again ("Envy").

I wore "Gucci pour Homme (1976)" back in the 80s, when I was olfactorily interested, but by no means as passionate about perfume as I am now. A very good fragrance. The kinship noted by Zaphod with "Trussardi Uomo" does not reveal itself to me; the Trussardi is far too dark, gloomy, and ill-tempered, while this fragrance here appears quite friendly in contrast. The look at the fragrance pyramid does not mislead; just as classic as it is structured, the scent unfolds. Wonderful transitions between the fresh-citrusy opening and the spicy heart/base notes. For me, it's a classic suit fragrance, not heavy enough for the opera, but clear and unobtrusive, perhaps for a business lunch.

I have the vintage OF as an EdC in the splash bottle, as was common back then. Therefore, one must naturally make compromises regarding longevity and sillage. I believe that the EdT in the 80s had real punch, but I can't say for sure anymore.

The colleague is very hard to come by. A mini or two is still available, but OFs can almost be called phantoms, as rarely as they have crossed my path so far. Well, I own nearly 100 ml, and that should last me a while...

I eagerly unboxed it today because I have been looking forward to this scent for a long time. Letting it sit directly on the back of my hand... sniff... sniff... delicious... classic... herbal... but somehow so familiar....

I pondered with my eyes closed about which scent Gucci pour homme reminds me of... mossy green... patchouli is detectable... pepper... citrus... then sprayed Horizon by Guy Laroche on the other arm and lo and behold: to my nose, hardly any difference. It may be that better-trained noses can discern the nuances, but I cannot. Gucci is perhaps a tad "softer," "soapier."

For those who only care about the scent and not the collector's value, they should really consider the much cheaper Horizon in comparison. I would be interested to know if other noses smell it the same way I do.

Unfortunately, I can't contribute more as a first comment on this classic because I've already said everything else in the review of "Horizon." :-)

sweet and soft to begin with. yes, it has „intense“ in its name but it’s not too overpowering. perfect for a warm spring or fall night. it smells like a fruity cocktail. i find myself smelling it from time to time cause it’s just so lovely. people will definitely give you compliments and the scent lingers for hours! if you love sweet, dreamy scents, this will be for you.

review_title: A sweeter fruity version of gorgeous gardenia
review_content: I really like it. It somewhat resembles a sweet, fruity candy while still retaining the floral creaminess of the gardenia. It’s a more intense bolder , sweeter version of its gorgeous gardenia predecessor. It lasted all day and even could smell traces the next morning though I would not say it was noticeable to others at that point.

It smells exactly like the original, though I have to admit this new version delivers far better longevity and projection (though, given how weak the original was, that’s hardly surprising…).

As for the scent itself, to me it’s mostly brown sugar and red fruits. Not unpleasant, but far from remarkable – too sweet, too ordinary, and the gardenia? Completely missing, as far as I can tell.

What I do love, however, is the bottle. Its vintage silhouette, paired with a vibrant, modern color, gives it a delightfully playful edge.

Gradually, the "Guilty Pour Homme" line from Gucci has indeed turned into a somewhat successful series, which (certainly not just) I personally did not believe after the first few flopped releases. "Love" is the new, green version, roughly a summer flanker. What can this limited edition, which spreads itself nicely on the shelf, offer?

Let's put it this way: it is a nice, refreshing scent. But it is not the next hit for the line. "Guilty Love Pour Homme" is a bubbly, sparkling vetiver sunny boy somewhere between generic and very pleasant, invigorating, sexy. A good hint of chemistry (swimming pool, sunscreen, mowed artificial grass) resonates, but at the latest, the bright, erotically clean vetiver backbone more than compensates for that. Fruity, citrusy, tingling from the belly button to the little toe. A decent, short-lived summer companion. It doesn't hurt anyone, and no one will miss it when it is gone and forgotten in a few years. Especially not those who have bolder, character-stronger colognes in their collections.

Bottle: great green, nicely frosty
Sillage: discreet and not overpowering
Longevity: this green fellow never exceeds a meager 4 hours

Conclusion: Pause for thought. A bubbly, tingling summer pleasure between mowing the lawn and the chlorine pool. There are prettier scents. There are worse scents.

review_title: Flowers growing between the railway tracks
review_content:
The start, while it is too sweet for me personally, is very yummy. Jammy apricots on fresh spiced bread. Gentle musky vanilla below. Mellow white florals. It's lovely. The apricot note in particular is adorable, I can almost feel the slight fuzz of its skin when I sniff it.

Moderate sillage – maybe an arm's length, but barely. Once you're in the cloud though – it's quite potent, if not overwhelming.

I've tried two different Blooms, this one and Bloom EAU DE PARFUM, and both of them handle their white flowers in an identical manner. Heavy, but very creamy and clean. Honeyed. On the verge of being gourmand. Delicious. A smell of a warm summer evening.

Unfortunately, both of these perfumes share another similarity – an unpleasant drydown. I suppose it's balsam's fault in this particular case?

About ~2 hours in apricots and most of the flowers wither away. What's left becomes bitter, and not in a fun way. Reminds me of the unlucky flowers that grow between the train tracks and sometimes get drenched in black tar and machine oil. Unfortunate.

In another hour it all fades away. Leaves a faint bitter aftertaste. Fuzzy vanilla. Not the nice kind of fuzz like there was at the start, more like touching a fluffy synthetic sweater. But to me Gucci's drydowns often smell like that. Ah well.

When I first saw the bottle and list of notes I knew this fragrance was made for me and I wasn't wrong. It is complex and unique - one of those rare moments when designer just gets it right. Jasmine and tuberose is a beautiful combination present in all Blooms, but in this flanker it really lets the other notes shine. The cardamom and black balsam give it a smooth and velvety sweetness that doesn't overwhelm you, making it a perfect evening fragrance for summer. I can't wait to have this in my collection.

GORGEOUS chai latte, cardamom, milk, cinnamon, dry wood. might be my favorite release this year. a tinyyyyyyy hint of something fruity in the dry down. passion fruit? i think it might be the tuberose that I'm interpreting weirdly. it only makes it better though. great for warm-spice fragrance lovers!!

review_title: An Unfortunate Association for a Spicy Jasmine
review_content:
I tested Bloom Parfum by Gucci, and at first, it unfolded as a delicate jasmine - soft, floral, and unmistakably elegant. But quite quickly, it took on a spicier character. The cardamom here immediately reminded me of the seasonings in… the French boudin blanc (!) I could have sworn there was nutmeg in there too. This unexpected association made me see the fragrance through a very personal, slightly whimsical lens.

Unfortunately, because of this rather unfortunate connection, I didn’t enjoy the perfume. I simply cannot imagine walking around leaving a sillage of… boudin blanc!

I like this Parfum a lot, it was an impulse buy because I thought it smelt nice and the bottle was elegant. I chose the small option because it was a bit expensive for me at the moment and didn't want to regret it, but to my surprise it wears really well! It has a slight musk tone but keeps the sweetness throughout the wear time. I am a big fan of Jasmine and White Floral so Bloom is right up my alley. It lasts about 6-8 hours depending on the activity. I would recommend this parfum!

review_title: Bloom Noire - The Bloom Wears Black
review_content: A black bottle, adorned in gold, enchants me without a care. So luxurious and elegant. Love ignited at first glance. Night jasmine awakens, mature, yet in full splendor. Tuberose whispers softly, not ending the journey. Cardamom dances gently, apricot ignites the fire spice and sweetness, strangely familiar. Not intimate yet not too loud. Floral heart reveals femininity, an...

As I was strolling through the perfumery I trust the other day, my gaze fell upon a beautiful, apparently new bottle. With its square shape and the delicate, golden floral vines on a black background, it radiated an elegance and mystique that immediately piqued my curiosity. Although I can hardly appreciate floral scents and the brand Gucci, I cautiously sprayed a little...

I am a bloom fan, many are not. I definitely sense that. But I can't imagine how anyone could not like this one.

The regular one smells like the premises of the local flower shop, this one has those notes too, but it comes across warmer. The cardamom makes it mildly spicy, it radiates beautifully.

Upon the first spray, it seemed almost light, but after 30 seconds, the depth of this wonderful fragrance unfolded. The vanilla and musk smell completely natural, for me, it’s one of the most beautiful women's fragrances, even though I usually prefer lighter scents.

I would buy it for my wife anytime again, I would wear it myself too. Simply amazing.

The only downside: the bottle is really beautiful. But why on earth is the label crooked? Well. It doesn’t detract from the fragrance at all.

I love everything about it.

review_title: Subtle bottle that reveals its presence when you unscrew it
review_content: It is the apricot that brings a magic of sweetness and depth at the beginning, almost something dark. Standing under the Christmas tree, aware of itself while everyone else is still focused elsewhere. Ready to enchant and soothe you with Christmas magic and weight. Funny, although such tropical fruits... it really reminds me of Christmas scents.

review_title: If only the violet weren't so short-lived
review_content:
First of all, how beautiful is this packaging? The box alone is very high-quality, has the look of textured leather, then the pouch, and then the beautiful bottle. Inspired by the first perfume vessels that once stood on wooden shelves in pharmacies, the fragrance is available in an elegant, white lacquered glass bottle with a porcelain-like appearance, adorned with golden accents.
The swan as a symbol of the purity and grace of the scent.
Released in 2019, the nose behind it is Alberto Morillas.
The first haute perfumery line from Gucci, "The Alchemist's Garden." The collection, consisting of Eau de Parfum, fragrance oils, and Acque Profumate ("fragrance waters"), was inspired by the art of alchemy and perfume creation. Each fragrance is based on a special component that represents one of the house's distinctive codes and can be enhanced, muted, or blended into a completely new, unique scent with other fragrances from the collection.
Violet combines with musk and iris flowers to create a soft, powdery scent. Timeless and calming.
For me, it is definitely a winter fragrance.
A beautiful violet scent, delicate and nostalgic; unfortunately, the longevity is very short.
Elegance and comfort. Well-behaved and properly made. Not a scent for a hot night. Also not a fragrance to wear while out and about, but perfect for moments when you want to appear mature, relaxed, and elegant.
Sillage is good, and unfortunately, longevity is not. But when has violet ever been long-lasting?

Since I have been working in a "Kneipp" kindergarten for some time, I occasionally try out some recipes with plants and herbs at home.
I love the scent of violets, and since a few grow in my garden, I wanted to make violet sugar.
So I set out to pick violet flowers, and since there weren't enough (I wanted to leave some standing), my son had to go look for more (he found some at the cemetery).
The violets went into a mortar.
You probably know the movie "Perfume," that's how I felt while squeezing the essence out of the lovely, delicate little flowers.
What remained was a mushy mixture that gets mixed with sugar.
Now everything is poured onto a piece of paper to let it dry well.
When I smelled the violet sugar after an hour,
I was shocked - it was no longer my beloved violet scent! I had to retreat from the concentrated essence; it was piercing, yes, biting.
And that's exactly how Virgin Violet smells.
Okay, the base becomes more subdued and powdery/creamy, bearable.
In this case, Gucci has done a good job; the scent itself is very authentic and natural,
but for me, it's just not it.
However, my son found the smell very tasty and occasionally sprinkles the violet sugar over his food.

review_title: A comet full of powder and violets meets the skin
review_content:
Now, how does one describe a scent that is better explained visually than with pure words? Just imagine a mouse strolling over the mirror shelf of a makeup vanity, stumbling upon something beautiful and falling into a large pot of powder. On the way to its destination, it takes a detour through the cupboard with baking ingredients, leaving its prints in the vanilla sugar.

To find a comparison with other fragrances, I would say it lies somewhere between Tom Ford's Fucking Fabulous and - what I consider - the unisex Valentino Uomo Intense. It is slightly less sweet and creamy than Fucking Fabulous and a bit less spicy-leathery than Uomo Intense. The quality of the fragrance is clearly evident in that it never veers unpleasantly in any direction. Instead, it always remains pleasant on the skin, feels luxurious, and showcases its lasting and unobtrusive sillage at the best moments.

One can forgive the fragrance for not developing further after the top notes. The heart and base notes remain consistently high quality, characterized by a delicate powderiness and a hint of vanilla and musk.

I must now treat the start and the consistently constant note in this fragrance separately. Here we have the intense and radiant strength of violets or violet flowers. This note is present with such intensity that one might think they are bathing in a sea of violets. However, it is never over the top, allowing me, as an opponent of floral scents, to actually love this fragrance. At the beginning, I had to ponder whether I could find pleasure in it, but ultimately the scent won me over.
The mentioned longevity and sillage are exceedingly present, but never in a way that is bothersome. I once sprayed the fragrance on my forearm and could smell it through the ends of my sleeve throughout the day. Here, we easily have 10 hours on the clock.

In conclusion, it should be said that fans of TF Fucking Fabulous and Valentino Uomo Intense should take a look at this one, as the quality and performance are spot on. The design of the bottle is, of course, worth mentioning.

Gucci Guilty Pour Femme eau de parfum intense by Gucci is a flanker of the well known line Gucci Guilty. This flanker delivers great longevity and a statement scent profile that definitely can be unisex. If you are interested into hearing more details about this perfume, please watch my review on Youtube.

review_title: fashion show-esque scent , top model vibes
review_content: this makes me feel like i’m walking the 2009 victoria’s secret fashion show in new york (i was wearing this while watching it)…it’s so glamorous and over the top for me , which i love. it’s strong and feminine with a tiny bit of masculine leaning , making you feel confident and powerful. pretty sure my mom likes this too so it reminds me of her. strong patchouli and violet scent with a dash of vanilla and tuberose. so sexy and seductive i want a full bottle now.

I always wonder which marketing expert came up with the title "Guilty," because all my guilties are pleasing and balanced.
Neither trying nor provocative.
They are friendly companions that delight the nose.
And so does Intense - just with an elegant attitude.
With this scent, you can go to a concert or theater, as the fragrance exudes elegance - without disturbing the surroundings.
Moreover, it is not a chypre, and thankfully, it lacks that scratchy note.
The violet lightly dusts the fragrance, and plum and vanilla provide softness.
The lychee is gently sweet, accompanied by enchanting ylang.
But all the ingredients are well-balanced, so Intense does not stand out awkwardly.
A successful fragrance - that has nothing to be ashamed of.

review_title: Goodbye my Love... Luckily, I got backups.
review_content:
The old Guilty Intense cannot hold a candle to this misguided improvement. ...I have had a deep emotional connection to the mentioned perfume for 8 years.

A few weeks ago, now available in our stores, I soon found a sample of this new variant in my Douglas bag.

The following happened after the initial spray:

No glamour, no elevated elegance, no underlying eroticism under the guise of feminine fragility...
Instead, a sweet arrow of fruity/floral origin pierced the air.
It dragged a fat banner behind it that read
"Oh yes, look at me everyone! Notice me! Here I am! Now comes GRANDMA!!!!"

At first, I thought the floral note was gardenia, but then I was laughed at by the tuberose, flanked by lychee and plum...
Later, tuberose along with the fruits mutated into floral chewing gum...
The fruitiness here overshadows the floral aspect. This makes it feel very playful on one hand, but also too much on the other. The once lovely lilac is nowhere to be found. All in all, I perceive it as a cheap, uneven dupe.
The whole thing is well thought out and designed to imitate the old version in a cheap way...

The best part of the perfume is the dry down... which seems to consist SOLELY of patchouli... overshadowed by fruity-fermented remnants.
From start to finish, I had the impression of having aged years with each spray... As if Gucci (the brand) tried to appeal to that generation of perfume users who aged alongside the old Guilty Intense over the years,
I also had to think of my grandma and that I should maybe call her again. She used to wear a similar perfume.
Longevity and sillage are merely the same. However, this version feels too cheap for me to ever spray it again.

The old version is only available at astronomical prices now.

I apologize in advance to everyone who celebrates and loves the new scent.

My boyfriend gave me this fragrance a month ago and I must say I am thrilled!
The perfume impresses me with its floral-rosy scent.
The smell fades after a few hours, which I don't find problematic since I generally don't spray much. Three sprays are good to be noticed - one to two sprays to smell nice.
Personally, I find the scent not too overpowering. Other people notice it, but they don't feel "overwhelmed."
I believe that the scent can be worn in everyday life. However, due to its elegance, I will personally use the perfume for special occasions.

The fragrance starts with a strikingly beautiful fruit accord that I have rarely smelled in such a way before. Soon after, the heavier flowers blend in. The base is slightly earthy and only minimally sweet, which I find very pleasant. I also perceive a very faint smoky, subtly leathery note. There is nothing soapy or powdery that comes to my nose. A great scent for going out....

I sprayed this scent on my skin this morning at the drugstore and I loved its floral-fruity acchord, very fresh, feminin and particularly pleasant in a hot day like this. But I realized after a few hours that the sillage was weak and the longevity not good in comparison to the quite high price of this perfume. Anyway, the bouquet is well balanced and i like it, just as i like the elegant bottle . I recommend this scent only in summer.

A tangerine, full of juice. Delicious, natural, almost at Guerlain level. Tasty, fruity, slightly sweet, yet not boring and even at the end not generic, but interesting & high-quality... all of this is NOT Glorious Mandarin from Gucci's Flora series!

The scent doesn't start off too badly, but then fades unusually quickly, until it completely loses its strength after just a few hours. The fragrance is quite sweet, with very little tangerine for the name. I can imagine that the body lotion works better, as the sweetness combined with creaminess would probably create a better symbiosis with the wearer's skin than the boring perfume. Musk, jasmine, and a bit of tangerine - finito! That's too little for me, but at least you can't spread any mistakes other than boredom. I would have loved it if they had really incorporated a stronger (or any) Pina Colada accord. Maybe then it could have become something like a creamy-feminine version of the great 2014 Summer CK Ones. As it stands, there are dozens of more skillful tangerine fragrances on the market - foremost among them Mandarin Basilic and Mandarine Ambree.

...however, it turned out to be a positive ending for both of us :)

I was really looking forward to Glorious Mandarin, but since I already had Mandarin Basil from Guerlain, I expected something fresher and more mandarin-like.
The first time I tested it was therefore very sobering; I was disappointed.
It was too sweet for me, simply not mandarin enough (if that word exists), and it left a somewhat sad impression.

A few days later, I received the body lotion as a luxury sample thrown into my shopping bag. I tried it that same evening and was completely thrilled by the wonderful scent on my body!

It's a lovely fruitiness, slightly sweet, still not enough mandarin, but the scent smells great on me!
I don't find it too artificial now; the fragrance is pleasant, has something elegant about it, and I especially enjoy wearing it in the evenings.
Since I often get asked what I'm wearing, it has become one of my favorites!

I think many expected something different, which is why it may not always receive good reviews. I no longer want to miss it in my collection! :)

I have this fragrance in a small sample here. How good that I was able to try it, otherwise I might have fallen victim to a blind buy frenzy given the delicious pyramid. Praise be to you, Souk. Since I became a member here, I have sniffed a lot, and I have rarely been truly disappointed. Perfumes are often not my thing, too sweet, too green, too who-knows-what. But still, I can appreciate the quality of the creations, even if I would never buy them. Glorious Mandarin disappoints me because - yes, why? All I can smell is sweet-synthetic-artificial-cheap-lemon-mandarin.
I don't want to offend the four of you who own this fragrance, but I would be interested in the opinions of the owners.
I feel no development; it remains static with its plastic mandarin scent. Do you know the plastic lemons that you can buy with synthetic lemon juice in the supermarket? Just imagine that in mandarin. The longevity is quite good, though. I often wonder why I can sniff out the perfumes I don't like so persistently, while my favorites often evaporate much too quickly. Maybe it's because the "stinkers" just annoy me so much, while the "good ones" belong to me so much that I no longer perceive them as foreign scents?
Do you feel the same way? If you're interested in this sample, I'd be happy to send it to you. Maybe the fragrance will then receive a more positive review.

Gucci Bamboo is called my ‘accidental love’ in my collection. It was a leaving present gift from a colleague 8 years ago. She made me open and spray it in front of her and was hit with a very sharp and detergent like opening that my nose disliked and I had to hide it with a smile and a ‘mmm lovely!’. It sat unloved in a drawer for 4 years and then my colleague joined my new team and the guilt kicked in. I thought I’ll wear it on her first day and maybe use it up at work until it’s done so I don’t have guilt. And surprised myself that when the bottle was done I just had to get myself another bottle. Most of my perfumes are unlike the others. So this one is a keeper for me, it’s lovely on my skin. There’s the obvious fresh, citrus opening from the bergamot, mandarin and orange blossom with a slight juicy floral round sweetness of pear, lily and jasmine. A powdery, very slightly spicy, musky dry down with the sandalwood and a very slightly spicy tease of ambergris with a layer of comfort from the vanilla in the base. I love this on my skin, I get delight from an almost sweet, milky, creaminess that must come from the ylang ylang that gives this lovely, subtle hint of honey every now and then when I move. I see this perfume described as a simple, uninteresting scent, and I know I’ve obviously developed a strong emotional memory to it, but to me it’s a classy, fresh with hidden complex gems that I just love and will always enjoy wearing this.

Fresh, fresh, again fresh and short longevity - that's Gucci Bamboo Edt. I would always reach for the Edp, due to the cheeky drugstore longevity of this one.
You do get a full dose of citrus served up, but it simply doesn't last, which is a dealbreaker for me personally.
Nevertheless, the scent is something for those looking for something even more subtle than a... deodorant. Hm.

Gucci by Gucci (Eau de Toilette) was a bargain at the Weber market festival in the neighboring Kerken. My husband couldn't resist the price and soon the large bottle was purchased.

The EdT is fresh, slightly fruity, and floral, which is evident throughout its duration. Unfortunately, I can't write much more about the scent, as I can barely perceive it, yet I still find it pleasant.

Gucci by Gucci (Eau de Toilette) can be worn daily in spring, summer, and possibly also in autumn (generously) in everyday life, at work... and I find the bottle quite stylish, just like the EdP.

I used it up so quickly, it was just gone all of a sudden.
Can be used very generously and every day. Fresh, lightly fruity, but not salad-like, with a very slight earthy base note that still doesn't overwhelm, but allows the freshness to linger.
A great spring-summer scent for "messing around." Maybe a tad too expensive for what you get. But the bottle is well-designed. I like it angular!

The EdP is in my closet. I bought it - as always - blind; I like doing that. And I find it very herbal, although the base is really delicate and beautiful.

With the EdT, they loosened the knot a bit, which I really like. The typical Gucci by Gucci note remains, but this version is nowhere near as herbal as the EdP. It doesn't feel any less mature, but it is much more pleasant and feminine, right from the first sniff. The previously mentioned "fruity" aspect also comes through much better. (BUT one should not expect a delicious fruity scent).

One thing is for sure, I've never smelled anything similar to Gucci by Gucci before. You just have to experience it.
Just like the perfume variant, I also like this version of Gucci by Gucci. A quite delicious, fruity scent. I like it!

I'm sorry for everyone who likes the scent...but to me, it smells bitter in the opening, rancid as if Insolence EAU DE PARFUM had been spilled and someone mixed in violets and ink. Leather ???? Yes, the kind that got wet and wasn't treated and is now crumbling away. Sometimes you have fragrances that start off horrifically and then develop beautifully. I often experience that, but this one was already in other hands due to my impatience. Well, it doesn't get any better here...I also perceive a Maggi note and Indonesian patchouli. To be honest, even a plastic note. The last time I smelled that was when I rushed past a 24/7 shop on vacation that offered china at unreasonably low prices.

Sometimes there are happy coincidences in life, like today. I was actually looking for a nice spring fragrance. I should have been called by Engelsrufer, but unfortunately or fortunately, I didn't hear them. And since I never get anything for Valentine's Day, I wanted to treat myself. So off to the perfume store!

I don't know how many scents I sniffed. The new one from Escada, the new Poison Girl, the new one from Lancome, the new Velvet from Dior, the new Daisy from Marc Jacobs, the new one from Chloe in Love, etc., basically everything that's currently trending. But what can I say... it bores me, it bores me. One is almost like the last, so actually all just new softened or modernized versions of old classics or non-classics, depending on how you look at it.

Now this fragrance from Gucci's floral line isn't really new either, but for my nose, it was an experience today. Just by chance, in a small discount shelf on my way out, I saw the 100 ml bottle, which was half off. I had already sniffed too many fragrances, just one more and then I would leave. And this one knocked me off my feet, convinced me immediately, and I took it with me.

The longevity of this EDT is incredibly good! It's actually a classic. There are many fragrances with violet, but many can also come off a bit old-fashioned or smell, as I always say, a bit like hairspray. This one is for me the most beautiful violet scent that has ever come under my nose. It's fine-powdery, velvety like a cat, and at the same time as dangerous as a big cat. And the subtle wild leather note makes it irresistibly sexy! Forget the little violet being demure and pure, nooo... this fragrance is not that. So it's not just for the romantic ladies among us.

I find this fragrance more beautiful by the minute, and I feel so lovely with it, like the most beautiful rose in town. These are moments of happiness for me!

Inspired by the beautiful comment, I set out on a quest. And it was not without its challenges - testing it seems impossible. No perfume store had it. I should have taken the note in the "Did you know?" section seriously: "This fragrance is only available in Gucci boutiques."

I know the Gucci store, they have bouncers and I always feel like a criminal because I really can't afford to dress there. Besides, Hermès, Chanel, Longchamp, etc. are right next door, and I always end up wandering around for ages, leaving my account empty because I always find something I like.
But I love the smell of leather, and violets make my heart skip a beat. So I searched the internet and ordered a small bottle online. I was almost bursting with excitement. I thought of my brown suede jacket, the matching fringe bag, and the scent of violets in spring. So I unpacked the bottle right away and sprayed it generously. I start sniffing - But what was that? No sweet violets, no rugged leather. I am met with a floral-powdery blend that feels very familiar. It smells like Gucci Première, albeit a bit more robust and intense and without the orange blossom, but still very similar. I am disappointed. However, it clings to my skin forever; in my shirt, which had hidden from the washing machine, I could still smell it very intensely three days later. And it survives a shower too.

review_title: The Violet from the Big City
review_content:
Be like the violet in the woods, modest, virtuous, and pure,
not like the proud rose, that always wants to be admired!

Many of you surely remember this saying from the time when grandmas, aunts, and friends wrote pretty sayings in your poetry albums and adorned them with all sorts of cute pictures.
I managed to save my poetry album over several decades and still smile today at the many meaningful sayings and well-intentioned advice.

But what is it about a generous, lavish, magnanimous, selfless, open-hearted, and bountiful violet (so the translation at leo.org)?

First, I must go back to last weekend and the following days that I spent with my beloved in Berlin.
Clarissa, in a generous mood, wanted to invest again.....!
No, not in real estate or even in gold, a new fragrance was the object of desire, and I was in the right place in Berlin.
At first, it was a scent from the Chanel Exclusives that I wanted to invest in, then my heart briefly fluttered for a Micallef fragrance.

Held back by my beloved, who couldn't quite get excited about the selected fragrances, I gave in to reason and postponed my investment plans once more.

While strolling along Kurfürstendamm, I wandered through the perfume department of a Karstadt store and discovered the generous violet from the Gucci Garden Collection, which I had not found anywhere else until then.
So I sprayed it on my arms and hands, as I was already out for a while and had tested quite a few, and on a paper strip.
What I then smelled exceeded my expectations of this fragrance - what a creamy, powdery, beautiful violet caressed my nose......!
So I went outside with my scent strip to my beloved, who preferred to stay outside with his cigar, and held the strip under his nose.
His comment was: "This is the best scent of all that you've tested so far!"

I was astonished by his enthusiasm, as comments like "too soapy" (very popular) or "You don't need that!" often come up.

So what does this violet have that it charmed two hearts at once....?

First of all, I didn't buy the fragrance right away, but put the scent strip in my bag, which I then took out again when I got home and placed on my desk.
Again, this lovely scent wafted towards me, which had remarkably held up well on the strip.

So I held it under my better half's nose once more, and again his comment was that this was the best scent we encountered in Berlin.
Now it was clear, I had to have it, and lo and behold, it was even on sale at an online shop I like to use.
Two days of anxious waiting followed, and now it is finally here, and I am indulging in violet scent!

At first, the fragrance is wonderfully powdery, but quickly the creaminess follows, which I attribute to the iris butter and which I find very well-groomed and clean.
The suede from the base note is fortunately only subtly perceptible, as I do not like prominent leather notes.
This is not a modest violet, no, it is a very cheerful little flower that happily reveals its joyful heart to anyone who bends down to it.
For me, it is an absolute feel-good fragrance, wearable in all situations, and my clear favorite of the Garden series, as well as one of the most beautiful violet scents I have tested so far!

And when I now go into my garden and see the beautiful bunch of violets that has bloomed there this year as if from nowhere, I imagine that it also emanates such a lovely scent.......!

Since my mother consistently wore this fragrance for weeks - indeed months - it is very familiar and pleasant to me.
It suited her sporty-elegant appearance wonderfully, which also reflected her relaxed, generous nature.

She liked to be well-groomed and tidy - unlike me - but generously allowed me to be myself.

We lived together under one roof.

And the scent, although elegant and somewhat luxurious, is by no means strict or dogmatic.
It has a stylish laissez-faire quality that suited my mom well.

When I cuddled her dogs, who naturally slept in her bed, their fur exuded this fresh-noble scent of orange blossom and champagne - as if they had rested on silk pillows at the Four Seasons.

They deserved so much class!

The Bulgarian rose warms the heart, and the leather reminds one of sturdy hiking boots worn for dog walking.

The creaminess of the woods corresponds to the cuddle hours when she snuggled with her loved ones on the sofa.

Premiere is pleasant for both indoors and outdoors.
It allows for flexibility - even room for interpretation.
Not a rigid scent - but a compromise-ready one.

My mom always said, while putting on her rugged boots:
Thoughts and dogs - must be taken for a walk outside!

For me, a fragrance for remarkable personalities.

A light, creamy feel-good scent that had me pondering for two days.
Namely, what it reminded me of. Every two minutes, I had my nose on my wrist, smelling something very familiar.
Rose, floral, creamy woods, not at all patchouli.
The longevity is unfortunately not that great, but that’s okay, I’ll just spray it again, I never run out anyway!

So now the solution:
Suddenly it came to me, the scent reminds me a lot of Eau de Lacoste, which I wore last year on vacation. Now I also know why vacation memories came to mind while sniffing!

review_title: Okay, but nothing to write home about...
review_content:
Sampled this. Reading the notes, I would have expected something more neroli- or orangeblossom-ish, but the neroli and organgeblossom are modest in this fragrance, which is good I think (nothing really cloying). Smelling the sample before spraying, the tuberose made me think: 'Oh no, not another Amarige-like scent, please!', but on my skin it is much more gentle. Wearable in spring and summer I'd say. I'm picking up quite some sillage when moving around; longevity I can't judge yet, but I expect that to be decent. I don't mind it, but it doesn't thrill me either.
A bit 'mainstream' and - loving the more vintage smelling perfumes - too modern for my likes, I guess.
Migraine prone persons should be aware that this can be a bit headache inducing.

Where many white floral perfumes are big and dramatic in presentation, Bloom EDT stays decent and evokes a pretty but harmless picture of a flower field in springtime. Honey bees dancing amongst rays of sunshine in the fragrant air. A bohemian vibe rather than burlesque.

I can not fully compare with the original Bloom EAU DE PARFUM as I have only tried that one on a blotter, but it seems the scent profile is pretty similar. A bouquet of white florals with little to no other notes. I reckon the EDT is a lovely spring or summer scent with its mild intensity. Definitely worth a try.

review_title: A White Poodle on a Flower Meadow
review_content:
Currently, one perfume commercial after another is airing on TV - of course, it's the pre-Christmas season, and they want to entice customers with the scents.
I enjoy watching the clips, as they are usually imaginative and creative.
Moreover, they spark my interest in the respective fragrances being advertised.
Gucci has captured me with the snow-white poodle on a colorful flower meadow.
Does the scent live up to what this beautiful image promises?
I say a definite yes, as the lush jasmine is radiant white and vibrant - accompanied by enchanting tuberose.
The mandarin keeps the scent aquatic and transparent, so it doesn't become too much of a good thing.
The neroli adds a pleasant coolness that emphasizes the brightness of Bloom.
Light woods frame the scent profile.
Now in winter, it paints white ice flowers on the windowpane - in spring, it will reflect the sun's rays.
I am not at all fooled by the advertising, as the scent conveys exactly what the clip promises.

So, after about 15/20 minutes oud top note, comes good old Gucci by Gucci EDP. Maby not same, but very very similar to GbyG. I mean it is nice perfume, but unnecessary. In this moment, oud is trendy, and Gucci follow this trend. However, notwithstanding, must say, I am a potential buyer .

Focusing on the profitable trend of oriental perfumes centered on the agarwood accord, Gucci launched this year what is a flanker to its Gucci by Gucci 2007 creation. I think they chose this one maybe due the unisex aura of the 2007 one, although the result is only related to the it by the bottle and the secondary notes of musk, patchouli and pear. What is central and most noticeable is the now classic combination of saffron, rose and agarwood, which few brands have fled when they launch their ouds interpretations. Throughout the composition gucci oud seems to favor on me a little bit more the saffron and oud accord seems to go in and out of focus at times during the composition. At the opening, it has something quickly Animalic and smoky, blending with the pear and raspberry aromas. It's not as easy to recognize these fruits, it seems as if they had been dipped in a vat of rose-saffron-oud accord to give a slightly fruity and sweet tonality. After the fruity notes evolve, rose and saffron share space in the heart, with the rose being a little bit sweet and without any bitter nuances and with the saffron giving it leathery, powdery and spicy aroma. Finally, Gucci Oud ends in a more woody oud without medicinal nuances, and i also get some discreet patchouly earth at this phase. At that time, it fantly brings a Tom Ford Noir Noir resemblance in the skin, as a milder version of this. Honestly, this does not add anything new to the interpretation of this type of fragrance, but is concerned about offering something that not only stay on the oud and that seems to have plenty of development and harmony on skin.

There is a time window - and this window is not that small, I think it’s at least two years - during which one can still somewhat unnoticed jump on a fragrance trend, there are still combinations and variations to interpret it differently, to add something new to it, or if necessary, to quote it ironically. There are paths that have not yet been trodden or at least not widely worn.

Oud and especially the combination of Oud with rose are as well-trodden as the A3 between Cologne and Frankfurt.

There is something unworthy about a house like Gucci (even though pleasant scents were never their core business - they were saddlers, and they should remain saddlers!) to bother the world now with an Oud fragrance. I found Davidoff's Leather Blend too transparent and sales-driven, and unworthy of an upright perfumer to release an Oud fragrance in 2014. Montale might be allowed to. No one else.

Oud, don’t get me wrong - Oud is wonderful! I am always fascinated by what an inconspicuous fungus can do with a piece of wood. And there are many Oud fragrances from the years before 2010 that are wonderful - one like the other! The scent character of Oud is unmatched: radiant and metallic-glossy, at the same time hot and cold. Hard as a dagger made of Damascus steel and at the same time soft and sweet like ambrosia. A piece of Oud, called 'Jinko', from the 8th century is part of the Japanese crown jewels!

Gucci Oud is not a poorly crafted fragrance, not even that. And yet it lacks a lot - pioneering spirit and passion above all, but also depth and character and - if you sniff closely - a bit of quality as well. That it still doesn’t smell bad hardly reconciles here, because 'doesn’t smell bad' can no longer suffice for a rose-Oud fragrance.

Conclusion: Releasing this fragrance in 2014 is like saying: 'Look: Prosecco with elderflower syrup - something completely new!'

review_title: a) not reinventing the wheel; b) rather disappointing
review_content:
These were my first two bullet points that came to mind regarding G O. I had mischievously looked forward to this fragrance and could finally get my hands on it at my home base Munich at Oberpollinger and press the spray button.

Okay, some knowledgeable, competent noses had already expressed skepticism, and I must say: Gucci Oud is not that great. In principle, it doesn’t start off too badly, with a nice, interesting, stable top note that promises a lot, appearing dignified and well-ordered with a bit of pep, but then it lets you down, leaving nothing to follow that the nose would expect. While the top note was still interestingly compact with a spicy-fruity opening that suggests a truly noble and high-priced fragrance, the heart note is lackluster and even worse than the base.

The top note still has Montale quality. Some customers might pack the fragrance away after spraying it, as they are so pleased with the wonderful opening, but the further development falls flat because there is none.

The heart note with the promised orange blossom and rose reminds me of Dark Saphir by Agonist. (Please don’t take the comparison too literally, I can already see the noses jumping up) DS is also a fruity, floral Oud interpretation, but O here does not come close to DS at all. Here, the pyramid collapses like a house of cards, leaving only the cards scattered on the bottle floor, uh, on the table. The fruity-rosy-oud quality is understandable, but by no means satisfying.

The base is even less. And still for just under 140 euros. In the base, there’s a bit of wood with a little something else. A little something else that reminds of the spicy component from before, but is even thinner. So wood + to ensure it’s not just completely boring wood. However, by this point, the longevity has already become really weak. The sillage is not strong throughout. Only at the beginning is it quite okay. But for a rather high-priced Oud representative, it’s somehow not usable.

I hope I have been able to show with my lackluster writing style (stopped at 24 minutes during my first comment from my phone) that G O did not deliver what I had hoped for. I will not buy it, and my 60% applies to the top note. Unisex.

I'll say it right away... I have nothing from Gucci. Well, almost nothing. Now I have Gucci OUD. And I love it! A friendly saleswoman at Alsterhaus introduced me to it. At first, she wanted to pair me with some terrible scent from ESCADA (bahhhhh). I immediately told her not to come any closer with that stuff; I’m already allergic to the bottle. She asked me what I like, and I described... - she had just the right thing for me. Just the right thing? I don't know. She handed me the scented card sprayed with Gucci Oud. I felt dizzy! It smelled strong, initially way too strong and heavy. Then I caught fire. The rose and patchouli are clearly dominant... but what I like best is that the scent develops very dark yet warm on me. The woods are coated with saltwater. It smells like driftwood heated by the sun. Desirable. A little rose lingers and makes it a bit softer and rounder for me.

In short, after about 5 times at Alsterhaus for the "Can I quickly test my favorite scent again" meeting, I wavered from infatuation to love and bought it. It is expensive, but love, as we know, has no price.

Not sure what went wrong with the ratings here (6.9 at the time of writing this review), but this is a decent smoky woody vanilla scent on par with Sultan in my opinion. On Fragrantica it’s a 4/5 which seems more reasonable, and I think the Parfumo rating will catch up. In the air it’s mostly just sweet vanilla, but on skin some smoky depth can be felt. Not quite enough to be a myrrh accord, but there is some resinous material apparent as well. Pretty linear, though some reviews are stating they can perceive a cardamom note in the opening which I didn’t. Sillage is quite soft but it lasts a while.

review_title: Nuance on top of major mature smokey calm that Vanilla Firenze.
review_content: Amazing Black Pepper and heavy Cardamom in the abundant opening, bitter, woody, starts off smokey. Recognize the The Alchemist's Garden in this, very mature, important, builds a nostalgic sweet segment, slight bonbon Cola like, think Enigma Roja. Classic, way way modern and novel. Balanced resins kept in check at elegance level, clearly all high quality ingredients. Get the Vanillas blend more in the mid on, dry, definitaly an acquired taste, personally can't get enough of it, amongts the complete black label part of the collection, get mature nostalgic with the perfect neatness to it. Very much pleased with the nonsafe blind buy, accurate Fragrantica pyramid but recommend checking out Gucci for detailed

review_title: Amazing and completely new to me
review_content: As usual from the black line of the Gucci Alchemist Garden Collection, a proud bottle price of 345 euros. However, I must say that this fragrance is completely new and entirely unique to me. The scent was released in January 2025 and has been almost continuously sold out since then. The vanilla is strong and not artificial. Alongside it, there is a wonderful smoky note that makes the fragrance accessible to both men and women. I would describe it as neither feminine nor masculine. A perfect blend in my eyes.

review_title: I believe there was more potential here
review_content:
Vanilla Firenze is essentially a solid fragrance.
However, I think it could have been even better.
There was more potential here.
The basic idea of combining a rather harsh and dry, yet somehow sweet vanilla with a pleasant smoky myrrh character is indeed good. Unfortunately, it somehow feels a bit uneven to me in parts.

The fragrance starts with this rather dry, but still slightly sweet vanilla. This slight smokiness is already hinted at in the background. There is also this very subtle floral character. I had actually guessed it was some kind of iris. But then I saw the notes and it was the iris.

After not too long, the myrrh accord becomes a bit more intense. I also feel like I can smell a bit of saffron. I think I can also recognize gentle woods in the background. The vanilla is still there, but now noticeably less sweet and just a notch drier.
It continues like this for my nose until the end.

The fragrance is super unisex wearable and has, in my opinion, quite appealing performance. The longevity on my skin is about eight hours, and I am very satisfied with that. It should be noted, however, that the sillage is somewhat milder. At first, the fragrance projects quite well, but then it noticeably becomes closer to the skin piece by piece.

A Chant for the Nymph is very pretty. To my nose however this is more tiare and ylang ylang than it is plumeria. It hovers around the wearer in soft, pleasant, sunny cloud. The prevailing character is smooth, billowy, and floral. There is a light nuance of makeup powder and pollen. ACFTN is all warm fluffy tropical florals throughout the wear time with not much of a discernable base beyond a smidge of vanilla and lactonic musk. All this smells really good, but not particularly distinctive or structured and that's okay.

This strikes me as the perfect scent for a bride to wear for a warm weather wedding, particularly a destination wedding in a tropical locale. If you're looking for something easy to wear that is joyful and optimistic, that radiates sunshine even, A Chant for the Nymph is a great choice.

A beautiful creature dances gracefully in a clearing to a chant only she can hear.

This is beautiful floral on a bed of creamy musky vanilla.

You can smell that is made with high quality ingridients.

It's warm, not to sweet. Sunny, happy and warm

For sure it's signature scent worthy.
Unfortunately a little bit heavy on the wallet

The strength of this fragrance is, for some, its weakness: Its absolute suitability for wearing in the South Seas, more specifically on the islands of Hawaii. There, it is as deeply rooted as the frangipani flowers in Hawaii. It fits there so perfectly, it’s unbelievable. It fits there even better than the local fragrance oils. Next to "Oud Jaune Intense (Parfum) | Fragrance Du Bois," this was by far the fragrance for which I received compliments in Hawaii - especially from locals.
This fragrance managed to knock Oud Jaune Intense PARFUM off my wish list and moved into my collection during my -actual perfume break- while I was on vacation in Hawaii!
I found visiting a Gucci store in Hawaii somehow inappropriate; should my bottle run out, that will probably be unavoidable;-) (maybe then in Hawaii?!? ;-) )

It is really incredibly well made!
A truly wonderful frangipani scent, with plenty of sweetness and flowers. The fragrance is full and heavy, but: In Hawaii, I could dose it much more generously due to the climate than at home.
There, it doesn’t really fit into everyday life and is now used when I want to remind myself of Hawaii at home. And it will certainly also be used in the summer.
I wore it a lot on our outings, meaning outdoors. I can therefore imagine that it would be too much in office spaces, cars without fresh air, and indoor restaurant areas.
I don’t see it there either.

Of course, the question arises for what occasion it was created... perhaps the memory of the South Seas contributed to this?;-)

I personally am incredibly glad to have tested the fragrance as a sample. At home, during the first test, I immediately decided, "This sample is coming on the trip." And there it worked... I inevitably and in the best way associate it with Hawaii. And, as luck would have it, I found a bottle in the souk, which I discovered on Kauai, the morning before a helicopter flight. What a stroke of luck!
Back home, I enjoy the wonderfully beautiful bottle in the even more beautiful packaging. I like such things, even if you certainly don’t need them. And the fragrance... a dream!

Oud Jaune Intense PARFUM also received many compliments; I was firmly convinced that this fragrance would join my collection after the vacation. Ultimately, it seemed - to me - somehow too "intentional," too pleasing, not "specific" enough to fit exclusively and immediately in Hawaii. (The sample came back almost completely full, used less than 5 times in 5 weeks.)

And that’s exactly what I wanted: A perfume that says 100% Hawaii, as I experienced it. No mental detours to the Maldives, to South Sea resorts... No!
For me: Hawaii. And nowhere else!

This may make it "less attractive" for many, but for me, it’s the main prize!
And that this dreamy fragrance is also in the most beautiful bottle ever... Life is beautiful! Aloha

It is summer. The air smells of flowers and blossoms, and at temperatures over 30 degrees, 4ajbukoshka meets her friends in a floor-length yet summery backless dress.
Freedom is within reach; you can not only hear and see it around you but also feel it and - in the form of ice cream - almost taste it.
The girls are carefree in a kind of hipster beer garden, ringing in the weekend with lemonade and boisterous laughter. It could be like this every day!
4ajbukoshka has now been wearing her new perfume for the second day in a row. Has anyone noticed? Njain.
The girls accept it without comment, while the similarly perceived green malachite has repeatedly caused (and will likely continue to cause) Jozha (affectionately called “Igelin”) to hold her sweet little nose in the air and ask what smells so sweetly of coconut, and then she literally sticks to 4ajbukoshka.
However, the May beetles seem to have a preference for nymphs, because although three young ladies are sitting at the table, they only fly into 4ajbukoshka’s hair (and get tangled there), on her back, into her dress, and everywhere else.
Does it look ridiculous how 4ajbukoshka, after jumping up from the table in a panic, hops through the beer garden whimpering, hoping to shake off her new fans? Very likely. She doesn’t know what’s chasing her until a waitress can calm her down, and she was afraid of being stung.

Conclusion: Was it worth it? No.
“A Chant for the Nymph” is really beautiful, no question.
It is un-sticky-sweet, floral-elegant, and quiet, with a barely noticeable projection (unless you hold your nose really close to the spray point, then you might feel overwhelmed, and it almost smells of white flowers).
In my hair, it amusingly smells woodier and a bit more bitter.
There’s nothing to complain about regarding longevity; it’s in the upper range (>= 7h).
However, it occasionally reminds me of “Vert Malachite” and... loses this battle decisively, as it lacks projection, a bit more development (or even more vanilla) would be interesting, and... it is not inspiring. Neither to sing nor to write a witty review. At most, to perform an anti-May beetle chase dance.
If it weren’t for the price, this would be a scent for the office, for weekdays, for non-special occasions like shopping, taking a Sunday stroll. Or something like that.

I loved it from the first sniff, and I bought it immediately. What a beautiful scent! I'm more into niche fragrances, but this one caught my attention! I wish the longevity was better but I don't mind respraying this all day. I'm planning to get another bottle cause I know I'll finish this quick. It's one of those perfumes that you reach for without thinking about it because it's so easy on the nose. I love the lilac in this.

I host some Guilty perfumes and always have to chuckle at the "dangerous" naming - because these scents are all "innocent" and friendly.
Just the way I like it.

The marketing department seems intent on "demonizing" them, which is completely unnecessary.

This endeavor reminds me of the charming bull terrier of our neighbor, who responded to the dangerous name "Danger."
The poor animal was cursed with the name, as "Danger" was the embodiment of kindness.
However, the appearance of a bull terrier with its strong crocodile-like jaws is not appealing to everyone.
And then there's such a combative name.
My friends certainly made a fearful detour around the dear creature - exclaiming: Danger in Uniform! Danger in a suit!
Despite this witty wordplay, the good dog deserved more pets.

And so Guilty Love Edition is a fine pink cloud that one wants to snuggle into.
Just as I like to cuddle into my pink silk pillows.

Love - yes - but more like infatuation or a little crush that lifts the mood - but remains casual.

Yet Love Edition is not arbitrary - just pleasantly friendly and light-footed.

The sweet fruits harmonize with the flowers - with the narcissus being soft and not piercing.
The violet adds a delicate bitter note, which remains transparent - thanks to the aquatic notes.
Jasmine provides bright elegance framed by equally bright patchouli.

Another beautifully rounded Guilty - and my verdict is: Not guilty!

Just once more I want to see you again ...
before we sink into a sea of black flowers.

Just once more I want to understand you as a Femme Fatale
and look into those perfectly made-up eyes ...

Just once more I want to grasp your strengths,
which become rigid with sweet, gourmand words ...

Just once more I want to walk away from you
and realize that it is often the strong women who stand up and continue on with perfectly applied powder.

Just once more ...

Epilogue
“Remembering who you are,
is how you get your power back”.
Author unknown

review_title: Green Bergamot and an Ocean Breeze
review_content:
Aquatics aren't usually my style, however I must admit that Flora by Gucci Eau Fraiche is by far my favourite from the Flora range.

I wasn't a huge fan of the original Flora. Something in it just didn't sit right with me. I also found it unoriginal and plain. This Summer inspired flanker is much nicer. It's crisp, delicate and fresh. It also feels very feminine and clean on the skin.

Flora by Gucci Eau Fraiche opens with green, citrusy bergamot and a refreshing ocean breeze accord. There are a fair few fruit notes in this composition, and while they are definitely present, they smell subdued on the skin. Osmanthus and peony predominantly feature in the heart of this fragrance, adding a fresh floral touch.

Due to the watery aspect, Flora by Gucci Eau Fraiche seems like the perfect fragrance to wear to the beach or to the public pool. It is a very Summer appropriate scent. I doubt that I would crave such a fragrance during Winter.

Since its release in 2011, Flora by Gucci Eau Fraiche has had quite a few good reviews and many fans. I can now see why it is so widely liked. I too wouldn't mind a bottle of this in my collection for the warmer months.

The projection may be fairly light on, however the longevity was impressive. Flora by Gucci Eau Fraiche lasts even longer on fabric. I highly recommend this flanker.

Original review written: February 2013.

review_title: Little Flowers and Fruits Fished from the Pond
review_content:
Wow, how many Floras are there from Gucci?! Anyway. I think I've clicked on the right one here, the one I'm wearing today... "Flora Eau Fraiche" - a... floral freshie?!

Forgive me, this scent doesn't exactly inspire me creatively. An uninspired Gucci concoction. Never bad, but despite the promising kumquat on paper, nothing stands out here. Soapy floral notes. Delicate fruit flesh. Subtle greenery. Pond and meadow. Cocktail and alcohol-free. Boredom and fluffiness. Politically correct. A lost rose for most of the time. No spark comes through, it feels fake... Don't get me wrong - it's never bad. But for me, it's also never good.

Bottle: square and sweet
Sillage: weak or tender?
Longevity: 3-4 hours, if at all

Conclusion: a watery-creamy Gucci bouquet without horror or applause.

I'm surprised that no one has shared their opinion on this yet - I've known the scent for 2 months now and so far, Gucci's fragrances have always flown off the shelves on launch day, what about this one?

I really like the top note; you are practically bombarded with bittersweet fruity kumquats. Unfortunately, they are just passing through, these wobbly little things. Once they're gone, the scent becomes floral-citrusy and still retains a bit of bittersweetness, resembling the heart note of Cafe Vert by Il Profumo. Great for summer. The base is spicy-fresh and woody, with patchouli taking a back seat.

Not bad!!

Gucci jumps on the designer-exclusive-fragrance train, and they have really put in the effort!

The concept isn't really new. There are a number of perfumes, a handful of perfume oils, and three scented waters. This is supposed to allow you to combine your very own scent. The corresponding bottles differ in size, but also in design. And I find the design, reminiscent of antique apothecary bottles with changing animal motifs, somewhat kitschy, but still very charming; I can't help it!

I admit, the appearance has contributed significantly to my interest :D But certainly independent of that, I liked the scent from the whole range the best. "Tears of Iris" takes a solid second place.

But what does a squirrel have to do with mimosa?
According to the saleswoman, the scent is supposed to reflect the softness of a squirrel's tail. (Sounds a bit far-fetched at first).
On the Gucci website, it just says that the squirrel embodies the "energy of the scent" and that the scent is bright and cheerful.

And how does the cheerful squirrel smell? Quite clearly like mimosa, but nice!
I'm not a particular expert on mimosas, but I know "Mimosa pour Moi," "9.1 Komorebi," and "Almond Cucumber" well. And they all have in common that I find them not quite balanced and a bit too sweet.

This scent is different. Not extremely different; the difference is rather subtle at first glance, but in terms of consistency and especially in the development, I like it infinitely better. It really feels cheerful to me, somewhat airy-floral-bouncing. Like a squirrel jumping from treetop to treetop, if you want to stretch the motif on the bottle even further.
And above all - no joke - I find it smells somehow fluffy! Like a soft white rabbit on a spring meadow-fluffy.
A lively, energy-infused softness, not just a simple cuddly sofa.

I find neither winter nor pepper in this scent. I smell a very fine spring-like mimosa scent, initially with a slight almond undertone, beautifully unsticky in the development, and I believe there must be some green note in the scent that supports this fine balance.

Beautiful!

review_title: If you've smelled black shoe polish you've smelled this
review_content:
Take a pair of black leather shoes with some cypres shoe trees in them, open up a tin of polish and take a lighter and light the polish so that it softens up.

That's 100% identical to this smell. It's shoe polish, with some burning (incense) and then Cyprus.

I just can't imagine any scenario where you would want to smell like this, to the point that it's projecting more than an arms length off of you, and the silage trail is massive. In no way is this a safe blind buy.

It's uncanny how identical this smells to black shoe polish.

I will say, this is one of the best perfume bottle designs I've ever seen, I just wish it smelled as good as it looked.

review_title: Smooth incense with woody tones, very nicely done
review_content:
A Midnight Stroll is my of Gucci’s collection The Alchemist’s Garden and is a lovely dark blend of incense, cypress, and cedar, so it fittingly is incense-dominant but leans wood as well. It’s dark and smooth, reminiscent in execution of By Kilian Incense Oud but fittingly with more incense and less oud. It’s not quite as ashy as Profumum Roma Olibanum—which I usually regard as one of the best incense-dominant fragrances in the market—so it’s an even smoother, slightly more mainstream/designer-esque incense-heavy mix that is nonetheless very wearable and fairly enjoyable, without much bite in the opening.

It performs pretty well overall, and in the US, is sold via the Gucci website and the department stores Saks Fifth Avenue and Nordstrom, and its retailing pricing is $330 for 100ml. Also, I usually don’t gawk over bottle design the look of The Alchemist’ Garden’s bottles, most even more colorful than the black of A Midnight Stroll, are lovely.

Overall, A Midnight Stroll is great, and would certainly be made better by a lower price point, so I’d be curious to see if it’s available anywhere on the secondary market, and I’ll have to seek out some others in The Alchemist’s Garden.

8 out of 10

Context: You are Erik Alfredson, leader of a Viking village, which will fight against a hostile village today.
You wake up to a tremendous thunder. It is dark, but the sun is already dawning through the window. You pull off the furs that kept you warm on this cool autumn night and get up. You give your wife, who lies next to you and is sleeping, a kiss on the forehead, knowing that you may not return from the journey you will embark on today. Upon arriving in the kitchen, you grab the bag of food that your wife has prepared for you. A loaf of bread and 2 wild boar legs. You put on your helmet, leave your wooden hut, and make your way through the forest to the village square. It is raining, and you walk briskly through puddles, the mud splattering up on you. Upon reaching the village square, you can already hear your men from afar, who will embark on the journey with you. They too know that not everyone will return. One of them is smoking a pipe, the scent of tobacco enveloping the village square. Now everything comes together. The scent of oud rising from the wooden huts around you. The leather of the furs you covered yourself with at night. The earthy smell that emanates from the rain-soaked ground. The tobacco from your men's pipes. The fear of what lies ahead. You set off towards your boat to embark on this journey together.

This describes this scent for me.

... I exhale the last big puff of my Parliament cigarette.

The cold, damp air mixes with the scent of fresh smoke.

For a few more meters, I carry the almost burnt-out butt with me and reflect.

On my life, my experiences, the things one survives, and what life still has in store for me. It is so peaceful... Just the stars, a gentle wind sweeping through the old town, and me.

This beautiful scent of a cold night slowly but surely drives away that of burnt tobacco, and I stroll further out of the city, heading towards the church. The damp earth and the typical church smell always fill this place with a very calm, albeit mysterious aura.
