But now it is time to go home. Carelessly, I toss the butt onto the damp ground and stamp it out as I walk by... The first rays of sunlight of the day gently accompany me on my way home.

--------------------------------------------------------------

The fragrance truly smells like a nighttime walk in the rain. The first few minutes are almost aggressive and sharply smoky, but this quickly settles into a pleasant incense note. The cypress and cade wood together evoke for me that typical scent of a rainy evening in early summer.

It’s great for layering... But definitely as a base, so that the aggressive cigarette note can first fade away.

Very mysterious, especially at the beginning, still very masculine...

tested thanks to a sample I had heard that it resembled harmonist fire hypnotizing, very present on social networks.

for me it's a disappointment, the scent is out of the ordinary it's undeniable, but it's a mixture of smoky smell with spices or even oud. At times like an apple cinnamon infusion mixed with nuit de feu lv.

a warm and ideal perfume for winter with a decent trail and longevity but which will not join my collection

review_title: Epic home bringer that Gloaming Night, should've started the Alchemist's Garden with this.
review_content: Perfect craft, not sure how excitement and nostalgia can coexist so well like that, with the charm and style to it. It's a movie. Get the mature snug, not too much going on as far as multidirectional, got the rare standout, dense and solid. Opens up dark brown earthy, actually bit fresh fruity too, two days in don't get the Cinnamon yet, immediately Patchouli starts unfolding upon the bitter opening with sheer omnitemporal class, this was elegant in ancient times as well as having futuristicals to it in the present. All purpose, shut pretty much any scenario down with this because it will as well appeal to mass. Stunned by and very pleased with the blind purchase.

review_title: Gucci, Gucci what have you done?
review_content:
Unfortunately, another fragrance from the house of Gucci that comes across as so boring and insignificant that it is personally not worth 50€, let alone the over 300€ that are demanded on the Gucci website.

The scent itself starts quite subtly with patchouli, but this quickly comes across as extremely shallow. A puddle, scattered with insignificant, randomly chosen flowers lies under the moonlight, lazily casting shadows. A bit of pepper sprinkled in, some indifferent nutmeg, and also a touch of bay leaf. In the base, cinnamon creams with rose, but this does not come across as rich, rather distinctly pale, and there you have the whole structure of this magnificent specimen.

Longevity and sillage are just average, which is quite disappointing, especially since this is not a 20€ Bipa fragrance that can dissolve into nothing after a few hours. But here? Only the bottle looks appealing and has a touch of nostalgia. The content, however, is quite a flop.

This is not only noticeable with Gucci; other houses are also constantly declining when it comes to new releases. See my review of Prada's "Paradoxe | Prada" for reference.

Back in my youth, I much preferred Gucci Guilty, although it is not a milestone either, but certainly more interesting and rewarding than A Gloaming Night.

One can only ask: "Gucci, Gucci what have you done?"
In this case, nothing at all, except for significantly raising the prices.
For a hint of boredom, well hidden, in a quite beautiful vessel...

Normally, I don't want to always give bad reviews, but unfortunately, A Gloaming Night has managed to receive a poor rating from me again. With Gucci perfumes, it's like with the brand's clothing: it looks great and is beautifully made on the outside, but that's about it. This comparison can also be applied to the perfume A Gloaming Night. The only truly great thing here is the bottle.

I didn't have high expectations for this Gucci after the last flop, Gucci 1921; the level could hardly sink any lower. Fortunately, the level hasn't dropped further, but it has only slightly increased. It's actually a shame that I have to be glad that the scent is just a flop and not a disaster.

The scent itself is simply boring without any character. I mainly smell cinnamon and soft patchouli, and although it's not listed as a note, a hint of rose. Unfortunately, cinnamon is the only note that can really assert itself, and I certainly didn't want a cinnamon scent here. I can only agree with ParfumAholic and say that I was hoping for something mystical and mysterious. A fragrance with only one note that is really recognizable seems very, very weak to me at almost €295, especially given the description of A Gloaming Night on Gucci's homepage. The scent also has no real development. A Gloaming Night just drifts along. The biggest problem for me is that it’s a scent that doesn't stick in your mind at all.

The longevity is also rather disappointing; after 6 hours, it was already over. The sillage is only above arm's length for an hour, and after just over 3 hours, it's already very close to the skin.

In conclusion, I can only say: Not like this, Gucci!

€295 for this joke is absolutely unacceptable!!!

review_title: Humble Love That Blooms in Attention
review_content: The fragrance keeps every promise, but not everyone is capable of understanding its nature. Probably only a few. It cannot be defined, that’s true. Nor does it need to be. Its purpose is different. The scent begins with a magical opening, an attempt to describe it; the delicate-sweet and completely elegant trail of a charming woman, who humbly rains down on a red carpet. The continuation shows that her nature is reserved, yet this makes her stand out. Her uniqueness draws attention to itself.

For a crazy niche price, Gucci presents us with a good EdP that can be worn well by both men and women. To my nose, it is primarily floral (with patchouli en masse) and secondarily slightly herbaceous (the work of vetiver). There is no scent progression. I imagine this fragrance as an enchanted garden at sunset, a hedge maze. A young lover, lost within it, her husband having...

I call it clean, I call it fresh and uplifting.
Summer will be an excellent roll out opportunity for it, will give it more wear as I only just received it & its a like and keeper.. I won't say its anything revolutionary & surely there's something out there its similar to.
Find it at a cracking price & then its worth the purchase, at RRP i'd certainly not have bought it.

I don't know what some people always expect! A new fragrance cannot always be the super new, never-before-seen composition.
There have been many brilliant perfumers who have created true masterpieces.
So, it's hard to create something completely new, especially when the fragrance pyramid is limited to just a few individual notes.
So. so what!
In my opinion, to put it simply, this is a fresh, crisp summer scent, as has been created many times before.
These days, people don't like to commit. The fragrance is marketed as "unisex." Strategically smart, as this allows for a broader audience appeal.
In my view, and this is my personal opinion, Gucci 1921 is a very classic men's fragrance.
I, as a woman, have tested it...and yes, I like it very much.
I also have no problem wearing it myself, especially now in the
summer.
And yet...I would find it better on a man, sexy and more interesting.
Whether one wants to spend a lot of money on such an average fragrance is up to each individual.
It's not bad, but the wheel has not been reinvented here.

I received my bottle of Gucci 1921 this morning. I was really looking forward to this fragrance from Gucci, especially given the high price for a fresh scent. Of course, I had to spray it on immediately.

Right after spraying, my expectation of a great and unique summer fragrance bursts. I start to think, what is this???

Unfortunately, I could answer that question just seconds later, and so could my girlfriend. Acqua di Giò pour Homme is my name, today disguised as Gucci 1921, with a little freshness and aquatic notes from Light Blue pour Homme Eau Intense added for improvement. I really don’t need to write anything about the notes or the development, because I could just buy the two previously mentioned fragrances or read the reviews about them. The result is the same.

I am really very disappointed with what Gucci and Alberto Morillas have produced. I really find it quite a disgrace, because we are truly talking about a fragrance twin here. I have rarely experienced such disappointment while testing.

The longevity is, what a surprise, the same as the two previously mentioned perfumes. After 5-6 hours, the whole drama is thankfully over. You can surely sense my disappointment and also my anger over this really poor release.

There is simply no reason for me to purchase Gucci 1921, unless I am looking for a new decoration in the form of a bottle for my apartment.

MasterLi's review inspired me to hunt down a miniature and, yes, Gucci 1 is one to be experienced. I love that swiftly after the accomplished top note. a little stank comes through from ambergris and musk rising into the indolic floral heart. This is awfully light on me, though. A watered miniature? Who knows? I'm just glad I got to smell this remarkable scent. With its bergamot-jasmine-musk-vanilla accord, it's almost a classic oriental, missing only amber. I've noticed that many of the perfumes I really adore have in excess of 20 notes -- this one lists 26. There was a time when great perfumers knew what to do with the olfactory version of "everything but the kitchen sink." Guy Robert certainly did. Fortunately, I have Amouage Gold that he also designed, reportedly using 120 of the best ingredients money could buy. Roberts said Gold Woman was his greatest creation to date. Wait, let me compare them ... Gold Woman is initially sweeter and in the drydown more powdery. It's clearly more complex, but to me it has a less subtle allure than his earlier stunner, Gucci 1. However, both are utter treasures. Now I'm wishing I had a full strength version of Gucci 1.

They don't make them like this ANY more! This is what Gucci really is for people who remember the name and the brand. Very woody and slightly (sickly) floral. But at the same time warm and gives off a floral, almost herbal type vibe. This stuff is brilliant. Truly... They do NOT make them like this any more! (Which is a shame... A real shame). If you find this or have a bottle. Please, SAVOUR it. Make it last while you can. This is how real ladies used to smell like. Not like today's designer fragrance disasters.

...that was my encounter with Gucci No.1. About 3 years ago, I got a sample of it and at the first sniff, it was "Yuck", at the second "Hmm..." and by the third, I was in love. At 15, I was actually much too young for this scent, which is quite feminine, but I already knew back then that I liked heavy fragrances. This one is definitely among them.
To be honest, I am a bit overwhelmed by the huge fragrance pyramid of this scent; I can't really say what exactly I smelled - except for the sandalwood, which I always detect. The combination of patchouli and sandalwood with many flowers is actually a pretty good description of the fragrance. Heavy, sweet, but floral/herbaceous at the same time. At some point, a bottle of this EdP will find its way to me...

review_title: I fear parfumo is my ruin...
review_content:
Many years ago, I briefly got acquainted with Gucci regarding "Envy". It wasn't that impressive, so this acquaintance wasn't pursued further. Last year, I came across a sample of two new Gucci fragrances, "Guilty" and "Flora". Neither of these led to a rekindling of the acquaintance.

Then, I was introduced to Gucci's no. 1 by a very nice expert, and a very dear parfumista (a thousand thanks at this point, dear Silverrain) gave me a drop of her precious extrait.

Even in the packaging, it smelled wonderful and somehow familiar. Then I applied it - being an extrait - very carefully, just a tiny drop, on my wrist.

What happened next is comparable to the reaction that cats show when you give them a valerian sachet to play with (cat owners know what I'm talking about *gg*). I was completely taken away and utterly unresponsive. It was indeed an olfactory orgasm that I experienced here.

Gucci no. 1 bears a great resemblance to the wonderful Fidji (Vintage!!!), but is distinctly more feminine and softer. The harsh beauty of Fidji is missing here.

I truly cannot pick out a single component here explicitly. It is such a fantastically composed whole, as I have hardly experienced before. The direction is soft, fine, bright, and femininely floral, the accords float like fine veils and alternate. Despite this wonderful perfection, the scent never becomes boring or monotonous.

Gucci no. 1 is a very sensual, very mature feminine fragrance that captivates me from the very first second. With a good sillage, it achieves an equally good projection, and the longevity is simply top-notch at a minimum of 24 hours!

I have done everything to track down this fragrance, as it is "discontinued", and I am very happy that I can use it extensively.
*
Addendum:

In the meantime, two bottles (one for spraying and one pouring bottle) of the no. 1 EdP have joined my collection.

The EdP offers a completely different facet of the fragrance. In the top note, a very fine, soft scent of night jasmine lingers here for about half an hour, as I know it from Spanish gardens. Very authentic, like those small, white flowers that release a warm, delicate floral aroma at night.

Only then does the well-known "Fidji note" slowly develop, which the extrait has already shown me.

Why would anyone let such a wonderful fragrance fade away without a sound?????

review_title: A Song for a Rose, hidden rose behind lemon balm
review_content: I just received my decant of this one. I was intrigued by the scent but frankly. It's not a rose perfume at all. The main accord I am getting is lemon balm, not even lemon grass. No woodiness. The rose stands in the back and you have to search for it because the lemon balm is so dominant. I do not dislike lemon balm since we always had it and I enjoyed squeezing the leaves to have my hands smelling lemon balm. I can imagine that I will actually enjoy this fragrance in hot weather because of this lemon balm and the freshness it brings. Just not what I had expected by the name and the listed notes. Would I buy a full bottle? most likely not, will I still enjoy my decant? hopefully in summer this year!

What’s inside is what it says on the label: roses.
Climbing roses, to be precise.
The clouds in the sky pass quickly, creating a wild play of shadows. Just when the rose bush is in the shade, damp and slightly sour, its blossoms immediately shine again in the sunlight, juicy and almost fruity.
The scent has a soapy undertone, not of the classic kind, but much more like modern liquid soap. This soapy note cannot quite find its place, sounding dissonant.
What’s special about this climbing rose is that there are no walls, no gates, no wires - the blossoms cling nowhere, they float. Like a painting without a canvas.
There is only the choir of roses with the soap, which misses the right note, and the musical accompaniment is absent. There is no background. No other little flowers, no green, no wood. Nevertheless, the scent radiates powerfully, lasting a long time.
This fragrance leaves me somewhat confused with its seemingly intentional superficiality, with its missing structure.
For me, it is exactly that: a stiff mask, a facade.

review_title: With the Guitar in the Rose Field
review_content:
And there I sat...

I sat in a field full of strong red roses... And while my eyes perceive a strong purple of lavender on the horizon, I strum Wicked Game by Chris Isaak to myself... By the way, this song has been my favorite since I was a child.

The most beautiful things in life don't have to be complicated. Sometimes all it takes is a guitar made of good wood, a few roses, and something clean and soapy on the horizon to make our happiness perfect.

It lasts for 7 hours, but the sillage becomes rather subtle after a maximum of 3 hours. Although it was never overwhelmingly dominant. At most, it starts off with a 2-meter radius. After that, it’s about half a meter where you can really perceive the scent.

Moreover, the bottle is a true masterpiece.

I never thought that the rose/ oud genre had still so much room for uniqueness. I tried dozens of oud scents and a lot of them are very close or even redundant. As a collector of discontinued scents I had it on my radar for a long time, however 90€ bucks seemed pretty steep for a almost certain redundant (so I thought) blind buy. The rising prices along with the somewhat unique sounding blackberry note convinced me to click the buy button. And boy was I surprised...
The opening has a blast of realistic and juicy/tart blackberry. Not dusty like in Jubilation XXV or metallic like in SMW, just realistic and authentic. After the first few minutes in merges with the slightly jammy rose and creates an aura of its own. The combination ts just so clever, it balances the sweet floral character of the rose perfectly. The oud is dark and woody but far away from any fecal directions.
It defeinetly shares similarities to its predecessor Intense Oud, which also used a similar dry and woody oud. In some way you could see it as a fruitier and more playful version of the intense Oud.
Longevity is decent but not a beast like the real Middle Eastern oud scents.
During the last years the Guilty line or even Gucci as a whole was one of the most uninspired brands out there, but gems like this save the reputation - well done, I sincerely applaud for such a release!

review_title: My Gucci Guilty Oud Review On YouTube
review_content: I was really curious about this one as Gucci just launched Gucci Guilty Absolut Pour Femme, just a few months ago and now we have this new one Gucci Guilty Oud. Gucci is cranking out the scents now? Well, I loved Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Homme from early 2017 and I love Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Femme from just a few months ago. And of course, I absolutely adore Gucci Intense Oud from late 2015. But is this new Gucci Guilty Oud any good? From my research on this new Gucci release, I learned that Gucci Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Homme and Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Femme and made the new Oud from notes within the two previous releases. But to me, this seems more like a flanker of Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Femme and not Gucci Guilty Absolute Pour Homme. Please watch my review on YouTube to find out all about this latest Gucci Guilty Oud. Thank you.

For those of you who are fond of the good ol' Italian cologne profile of citrus/bergamot, florals/orange in the middle, and a little bit of incense-ish stuff in the basenotes, this is a nice, clean one of those. The drydown is less woody or incense-heavy than you'd think out of a patchouli base. There's some powder in here.

I loved my old Prada Infusion d'Homme, which has a lot of the same elements in a very different presentation - that scent really punched you in the face with neroli. Guilty Eau is way more mellowed out - for better or worse. Don't expect ridiculous sillage out of it, but the remaining scent throughout the day is pleasant and personal.

review_title: I thought our story was over...
review_content:
Gucci Guilty PH - a pretty disastrous line, even if you disregard the excellent, discontinued predecessors in the Gucci universe. I really thought the line would be discontinued soon & slowly phased out... bam, in my face, says Gucci! There really is a new flanker "Eau" in the store - I never expected that! I thought Gucci was going new ways... apparently, they conjured up the lighter version of their failed confession completely behind my back last year. Or at least on board the ferry, where I took a 2-hour ride from Tallinn to Helsinki today. Curiosity wins, it had to go on my skin, maybe the "relationship break" with Guilty did us good...?

Partially yes, because I like "Eau". It combines the classic, quite boring Guilty PH DNA with a citrusy iris, almost a bit piercing, synthetic, metallic & high-pitched. A yawn meets cool detachment. The longer I test it & wear the sample as a refreshment after showering, the more the impression of the best Guilty (for my personal taste) is solidified. Its iced out attitude, the creamy iris-orange blossom powder somewhere between "Dior Homme Sport/Cologne/Eau", "Kenzo Power (Cologne)" & the original, appeals to me. The sparkling, very youthful & hyper-modern orientation is sexy & will surely do well in summer. However, at 10 degrees in Helsinki (today's testing conditions), it struggles. In "GG PH Eau" (this name can only be abbreviated!), everything is bright, white, lemony, on ice & casually relaxed - even the patchouli, which at least gives the fragrance some foundation. A wonderful scent, far above its superfluous brothers. It deserves more attention & should be tested by you - I would be very interested in your opinion & whether it can also reduce your Guilty prejudices a bit.

Bottle: very cool in this lighter, matte silver. Fits.
Sillage & longevity: never real strengths of the male Guiltys - here even more subtle & only 3 hours, as is fitting for an Eau.

Conclusion: no wonder it flies under all radars - an extremely defensive powder-citrus. Somewhere between the original GGPH & Dior Homme Sport. I like it, but overall it seems to be another unfortunate point in the misunderstood Guilty history. I've never warmed up to them, with this undercover Eau being the closest... Synthetic done right!

I had almost given up on finding a Gucci fragrance that suited me, until I stumbled upon this little gem. In my opinion, this is by far the best Gucci fragrance, but knowing my luck it is a limited edition and has since been discontinued.

I disliked the original Gucci Envy Me, however Envy Me 2 is much more subdued and fresher. The orange in the top notes is delightful when blended with the violet. I very rarely enjoy fresh, summery scents, however Envy Me 2 had me with the first spritz.

The scent is very unique and soft. It is green in a way, but not in a sharp or bitter sense.

The drydown is very pretty with the patchouli and vanilla being only very subtle, making for a pleasant casual feel. Envy Me 2 is clean without being too soapy or shampoo-like. It has an almost powdery quality and a slight hint of sweetness that gives this fragrance character. I find Envy Me 2 to be very uplifting, and certainly long-lasting on the skin.

For now this fragrance is still available online and in some select stores, so I urge those who wish to try it or buy it, to hurry.

I know it, I know - I carry a big name.
One that most people associate with luxury, glitz and glamour, striking extravagance, and obvious wealth.
Sometimes, this makes me a bit uncomfortable, because actually, you know, I prefer it quieter, more unobtrusive; I like to stay in the background.
That’s not something my family appreciates; they passionately stand in the spotlight, at the center, enjoying attention and publicity - in that sense, I am certainly something like the black sheep, even though great-grandfather Guccio, the founder of our dynasty, said years ago that a little more modesty would do his descendants good, and I would most resemble him.
My aunts and cousins didn’t like hearing that at all; I haven’t been invited to some family celebrations since then.
But that’s fine, then I don’t have to dress up.
I feel most comfortable in jeans and white shirts or T-shirts, and in summer, I like to wear light dresses - that doesn’t quite go with the haute couture that my lovely relatives love to wrap themselves in.
I also prefer to go out into the countryside to my weekend house and wander through forests and meadows, lie in the grass and count the clouds, let my bare feet dangle in the stream, and watch the sheep grazing, instead of spending my nights at noisy parties.
In the company, you’ll find me more in the office than in the studio or behind the catwalk - it’s quieter there, and they say I have a knack for our suppliers and a head for numbers, which is quite accurate.
It’s a simple life compared to that of my siblings, but it’s what I like, what I’ve always wanted.
No great heights from which one can fall deeply, and no deep valleys; our father has already taken care of that.
Am I happy?
Absolutely, I wouldn’t want it any other way - and so, when I think about it, maybe I am just a little bit enviable after all...

Yes, how should I begin?
Maybe with a question for you: Do you expect something special from a brand like Gucci? Something that stands out from other fragrances?

In my opinion, yes. But as I have come to know Gucci, I will be regularly disappointed anyway. So maybe I should finally stop waiting for a miracle.

"Envy me 2". Yes. The bottle is really pretty.
As for the scent:
Imagine a cool autumn day, with everything that comes with it. Golden rays of sunshine, some flowers in the front gardens of the houses, in one or another garden there is a pond where the goldfish swim around. Leaves are falling to the ground...

Golden rays of sunshine:
Undoubtedly, the scent feels pleasantly soft and cozy due to the rose in the heart note, a little warm. Just like the golden rays of sunshine on an autumn afternoon.

The flowers in the front gardens:
Yes, the floral notes cannot be denied even if one wanted to. - I don’t want to. And unfortunately, the scent feels as familiar as the neighborhood I see when I look out the window.

The garden ponds:
In contrast to the warmth from the floral notes, something very special comes through. Something that makes the scent feel pleasantly fresh again. However, I suspect that I am just imagining this. Who knows...

Colorful leaves:
That’s what autumn is all about. Leaves, colored in various hues, from different trees, diverse and beautiful.
... Well, I must disappoint you. Versatility? Recognition test? Not a chance.

Yes, it is a nice scent that really smells floral and "good." The intensity and longevity are also on point. One drop and everything smells like it.
BUT if this scent is missing from a collection, then there is really no need to be ashamed of it.

The scent somehow reminds me a lot of chewing gum or the scented stickers from Barbie that I had as a child.
It awakens childhood memories in me. I only wear it in very specific moments.

Hmm, is it even worth writing a review for a fragrance that hasn't been produced for a while and is becoming increasingly hard to find?

Yes. It is still available, and I once loved it and still like it today.

Yes, it is a rather ordinary, almost inconspicuous, and surely quite interchangeable fragrance for many. But for me, it was my first choice in my late twenties when going out, partying, flirting, or having "a nice evening." I, back then a sporty and agile type with a penchant for not necessarily stylish but free, bold, somewhat quirky, and always comfortable outfits, which were characterized by two things: large handbags and short leather jackets. And it fit perfectly.

This fragrance is light, fresh, floral, exuding a charm that is not primarily stylish but still beautifully present. I smell pastel, lemon yellow (no, no lemon in the fragrance development), and a kind of lime green. It is cheerful and girlish. A bit flighty, but likable and totally uncomplicated.

Envy me 2 starts off with a violet note, artificial. Not bad, but artificial. A little rose, the almost white one with the pink, slightly frayed leaf edge, soon emerges, or rather many small bush roses perhaps. The floral note remains from beginning to end, the minimal sandalwood trace and a bit more patchouli towards the end give the fragrance increasing grounding; depth would be too much to ask for, rather a light warmth. It stays predominantly floral on me, slightly sweet, fresh, delicate green, and airy.

I still have a bit left that I occasionally like to wear. As a reminder of another decade, I find it not necessarily fitting for me today, but I still like it. And I keep it in loving memory.

Would I buy it if it were still available? Yes, I would, for my daughter.

The low rating for this one is crazy. The Heart of Leo is a fantastic woody-spicy-fruity scent where the notes don't really capture the complexity. It reminds me of Armani Privé - Bleu Lazuli or Gajah Mada where it's this smooth unspecific sweet/sour fruity note atop a unisex/masculine leaning woody base. There are a bit of oriental notes, but it doesn't really take the resinous route as the notes suggest. I'd say it's more of a cedarwood/sandalwood and patchouli along with a smooth amber to bridge the gap between the fruity notes and the dry woods. There is also a bit of leather, I think it's a similar accord to The Voice of the Snake but way in the background.

Not really getting the complaints about the performance either. The sillage is subtle, sure, but that might be by design. Not every fragrance has to enter before you into a room. Pricing is expensive at retail, sure, but it's available at Jomashop currently for $185 which I think is a very decent price for a fragrance of this caliber.

review_title: Leo ist wahrscheinlich doch kein leo
review_content:
Ich habe eine kontroverse Meinung zu diesem Parfum:
Einerseits hat der Parfum mit dem ersten Sprühstoß mein Herz erobert anderseits verstehe ich, dass für so eine schwache Leistung ist dieser Duft keine 350€ wert.
Die erste Noten sind von Johannisbeere und Leder, die ich echt einzigartig fand, das hat besonders, mit Charakter gerochen, aber dafür wiederum feminin. Die Komposition passt perfekt für die Dates und für einen Abend in einer Bar.
Ich habe mich erstmal in den Duft tatsächlich verliebt.
Aber S/H haben leider zutiefst enttäuscht. Der Duft blieb ohne Nachzusprüchen nicht länger als 3 Studen und wird am Ende ganz schwach. Alles andere, als eine Komposition die dem Image von „Leo“ unterstützen sollte.
Ich hätte gesagt, Parfüm ist maximal 150-180€ wert, für 350 kann man deutlich qualitativere Sachen holen. In dem Preissegment halten sich viele Parfüms bis 8-12 Stunden, wo man die am Ende noch ganz stark wahrnimmt.

In the end, The Heart of Leo actually surprised me positively, as it has not been rated very well on Parfumo. I find the scent quite pleasant, though not spectacular. The longevity on my skin is around 10 hours with a rather mediocre sillage.

Since the complexity of the fragrance is limited, it makes little sense to talk about top, heart, or base notes. The scent is predominantly fruity, sweet, and very powdery with blackcurrants. Additionally, I detect a certain woodiness with a spicy-herbaceous aroma of woodruff. I cannot identify any incense or myrrh here.

For me, The Heart of Leo is quite good, feminine but still too expensive for what is offered here. I thank Kamyar for the decant.

review_title: Disillusioned - A name alone won't save it
review_content:
Update:

I had the opportunity to test the fragrance twice at the airport, and I must unfortunately say that my first sample was contaminated and diluted. The user who sold me the sample is no longer around... Nevertheless, the price for what you get is too high. It also doesn't come across as masculine.

The sharp smell at the beginning is absent. It starts with berries and then becomes very powdery. Unfortunately, up close. The incense is hard for me to grasp. Still, the first review was too harsh.

I've adjusted the review! The statement below still holds true :). Just without the hairspray smell.

------

Man, oh man… it could have been great, but it isn’t…
When the fragrance was announced, I was really hyped. This trio of notes appealed to me!!! At €345 for 100ml, I expected niche quality, which I think is justified at that price.

Unfortunately, in my eyes, a lower quality is delivered here than some drugstore scents. At least olfactorily, it’s a real disappointment for me! I will now try to describe what I perceive with goodwill.

Fragrance applied to a clean wrist with 2 good sprays. First, a sting in the nose. Then the blackcurrant comes out like a candy or a wild fruit tea… Then, relatively quickly, I only perceive the chemical smell of super glue and hairspray. With a lot of goodwill and imagination, I still smell something slightly leathery, but that’s just my imagination. Unfortunately, I don’t perceive incense and myrrh.

Now for the closing statement:

Could have been better - more quality, more amore… it didn’t smell like a lion, more like a chemistry set, eh!
A name doesn’t save the scent either. After a short time, Gucci is done, str...

For me, a flop; luckily, I only got a sample. Recommendation! Spend your money on another fragrance :)

I'll keep this short and sweet, as there is not that much to say about this scent.
Like the name suggests, this is a light and soft version of Guilty. To me, this smells mainly like lilac and warm white musk, unfortunately I don't get the fruity notes of strawberry and litchi. It's a little aquatic in the opening and dries down powdery with a hit of a dusty pollen vibe.

It's a nice scent for spring time, but quite weak and a little boring to me. Maybe it could work if you're looking for a really light, inoffensive, work-appropriate lilac. But honestly, the other Guilty flankers aren't that dark and heavy either, so I would rather get one of those.
This one is just okay to me, bordering on a weak like, but nothing to write home about.

On Thursday, the anniversary of the day my husband and I met will be celebrated for - I don’t know how many times.

I still need to find out the exact number, otherwise he gets offended.
He knows it perfectly well, of course.

I always have to check our marriage duration painstakingly in the wedding ring when asked, which he responds to with an annoyed eye roll.
I save myself by saying: It feels like just yesterday!

He knows that I am disorganized.
Nevertheless, I can expect a gift.
I sense morning air or rather morning scent.

I envision the pleasantly light yet expressive Guilty Eau as my gift wish.
I know he generally likes the Guilty fragrances, and only what doesn’t bother him is given as a gift.

It is delicately aquatic - but not thin, rather beautifully transparent.
A soft lychee wafts towards me, accompanied by anise.
We both like lilac, and it is pleasantly non-soapy.
The wild strawberries come straight from the forest.
I am so wild for your strawberry mouth - comes to my mind.
Musk gives a golden morning shimmer.

A bright, joyful scent - weightless like the butterflies that swirled around us - ahem - "some" years ago.
This tingling feeling can certainly be revived by Eau.

product_name: Guilty Love Edition MMXXI pour Homme
review_content:
A very well-crafted perfume in the Guilty line. I was intrigued by it because it is also called Love Edition. Upon application, I immediately notice - it is 1 to 1 Guilty as you know it from men's perfumes, it has that citrusy, bitter lavender note, and on top of that, this one is even a bit sweeter. Nice woody citrus, that’s all it needs.
The scent surprisingly lasts quite a while; you can smell it very lightly afterwards, but it is always nice to spray it on again.
This fragrance is available for men and women (pour Femme), but I would argue that Pour Homme actually leans more towards a unisex scent, as it appears elegantly fresh and is not very masculine.
As already mentioned, it definitely has something from the classic Guilty perfumes, and anyone who enjoys wearing those would not go wrong with this one.

product_name: Guilty Absolu de Parfum pour Femme
review_content:
The Gucci family has welcomed a new member, just in time for autumn/winter, when hopefully it will be cool again on the shelves. First of all, it should be said that this is an absolutely intense and overwhelming scent.

The opening with bitter almond is reminiscent of marzipan and slightly fruity. But then it gets serious. Spicy and herbaceous with patchouli and slightly floral with the roses, which smell a bit musty and autumnal. As if you were smelling a bouquet of roses that was placed on the cemetery for All Souls' Day in December. Morbid charm for those who like it that way. To me, the scent now smells a bit off.

But then it continues intensely. Coffee dominates heavily, but not freshly brewed; rather, it’s the scent that wafts into your car on the A1 in Bremen. When the wind comes from a well-known coffee roastery. This typical scent of the area now mixes with the morbid, slightly sour opening. A powerful blend that will surely find its admirers, especially since it also includes the currently trendy vanilla. But not the stuff from the baking aisle, rather a strong, room-filling vanilla supported by tonka.

For those who love intense oriental fragrances and want to make a statement with the motto "Stand out at any cost," this scent is a good fit. For me, it’s a bit too much of everything and too disharmonious. I prefer subtler orientals in winter.

Now for the longevity. Today is Wednesday, and I wore the scent on Sunday. The scent is still present on my skin and surrounds me. And it was just a tiny drop. Fortunately, the musty notes are gone, and only patchouli with vanilla remains. But still, it feels too clingy for me.

product_name: Guilty Absolu de Parfum pour Femme
review_content: Boozy plums, like port wine, but it also has a coffee note, more bitter through patchouli and rose than Black Opium le Parfum. When this port wine/amaretto note fades, the fragrance becomes creamier with tonka and then unfortunately also a bit uninteresting. It's a pity that the top note doesn't last longer. Definitely worth a test for fans of Black Opium le Parfum, Ghinza Datura, and Amore Cafe.

Think byKilian Imperial Tea, with the on and on incredible Alchemist's Garden cozy and warm smoke settle. Get bit green creamy milk, like that moment in Memoir Man in the opening, fourth day amply sprayed on arm, gets earthier, more and more woody like one wouldn't believe. More on the bitter side, balmy green, close tie with the Tea note, but Jasmine predominant, with the gentle musk to it all. Get the serene joyful, uplifter, an everyday pick, all purpose casual aand doesn't get loud if oversprayed. Personally don't get the spa sameness almost at all? Got it the first two times/days, in the imediate opening, lasted for 30 min tops, then next days barely got it anymore towards and in the drydown, so yeah, again: an Aura Tea scent, must try it out on own skin. Very pleased and surprised by the blind purchase, luving the line more and more

review_title: The big brother of Gucci Guilty Absolute
review_content:
This perfume smells like a Gucci Guilty Absolute but without cypres and with something herbal instead.

Morillas sometimes doesn't declare the leather within the notes (Black Tie example) but if there isn't leather, there is some alchemy because to a earthy accord of vetiver and papyrus doesn't smell.

Linear, but pleasant, one more point of quality than Guilty Absolute, you may think that they are very similar until you have them hand by hand, the price is excessive, but it is still a full-bodied leather perfume worth trying.

Strange smell.

It comes out with the fresh smell of ginger and herbs and spices but quickly turns into something deeply earthy, like a vetiver or a very earthy patchouli. If the name wanted to convey the smell of a medicinal garden, it is quite well achieved, it would be a waterlogged garden (papyrus) with very damp soil. The sum of notes also leads me to think of a slightly camphoric or medicinal smoke.

Abstinence would be fine too. So, short and sweet:
Based on the fragrance notes, I couldn't resist. I like ginger - I consume it daily. I like wood and vetiver because they are light green and fresh. I like cedarwood because it also has a fresh and spicy scent.
All in all, I was looking forward to Hortus-Sanitatis.
But what a disappointment for my expectations *sigh*
Ginger is so inconspicuous, as if it has slipped under some fruits in the fruit bowl and is just rotting there. Vetiver is very dominant. I like it and it conveys the feeling of a recovery garden, wellness oasis, and health. Cedarwood... wtf?! Where did they dig that up? Sharp, captivating, pitch black, and cold. I almost thought of incense, but the bad kind. The only thing that could save this scent would be papyrus wood. Fresh, sparkling, and a touch sour. But there is too little of that to tone down the cedar.
Earthy yes, green, mossy like after a rain shower, but unfortunately again "cold".
Definitely too sharp and above all cold for me. It reminds me a bit of medicine. The price? Almost outrageous.

review_title: The Herbal Book of 1491 - Masterfully Realized
review_content:
The Hortus Sanitatis is a book of herbal medicine that was printed in Mainz in 1491 (!). And this is astonishingly well captured in this fragrance. On one hand, the herbal notes do remind one of medicine. At the same time, there is a mustiness described below; I would rather say the smell of old walls, old linen. It is likely inspired by ancient papyrus, which absorbed these scents when the Hortus Sanitatis was in its time. This is how a book smells that has been stored and breathed for a long time, perhaps in a monastery where such herbs were cultivated and processed into tinctures in the 15th century.
The scent reminds me of a visit to the dungeon in Hamburg, where visitors walk through scenes of the dark history of the Hanseatic city. To be precise, the station that reminds me is dedicated to the theme of the plague. A monk in a linen robe in a laboratory with numerous tinctures describes to the visitor how much the Hanseatic city of Hamburg suffered from the plague. That sounds worse than it is. The scent does not stink like the plague!
One can only observe a very extreme exaggeration of this scent there.
I could swear that I could smell an animalic note. Both in the dungeon, where the scent of bodily fluids was mixed with the herbal tinctures. But also, the perfume Hortus Sanitatis contains something animalic for me in its later development. A certain smokiness also emerges. The scent transforms a lot; time and again, a different herbal note seems to come through. Although not listed in the fragrance pyramid, various herbs are present. I suspect sage, which in nature also possesses a certain animalic quality, can sometimes smell like stale urine, chamomile, thyme, rosemary, tarragon, and especially bay leaf. A monastery garden with herb beds, a laboratory where tinctures simmer and smoke over an open flame, and in the midst of it, a book of recipes and effects, the Hortus Sanitatis, which absorbs these scents.
I believe Morillas has masterfully realized the theme and created a wearable perfume from this challenge (because who wants to smell like an old musty book or a medieval plague station).
I do not want to deny that this perfume is demanding. But there is so much to smell, and it does not scream for compliments. It envelops the wearer with a mysterious aura.

review_title: The Lorsch Medicine Book to spray on?
review_content: I must say right away that I am actually not a fan of Alberto Morillas' creations; most of the time, they are too linear or boring for me. Hortus Sanitatis is an exception, this fragrance is truly unique and special. However, I am still surprised that something like this comes from Gucci, as the brand has mostly been represented in Douglas or Müller until now. Hortus Sanitatis is definitely not a perfume that will receive many compliments; rather, it may even provoke negative reactions, as it is 100% not a scent for the club or anything like that. Hortus Sanitatis really reminds me of traditional herbal medicine from the Middle Ages; I imagine being in a monastery in the year 800. The healing arts have just been invented, and the whole monastery smells of the monks' homemade medicine. I must honestly say, though, I cannot answer whether I will acquire a bottle of Hortus Sanitatis, as there is almost no opportunity to wear this scent.

I am the very lucky owner of this wonderful scent. When I spray it I think ‘quality’ at once. It never tops amazing me, because even though it is quite linear it still shifts between the notes. The fragrances balances between sour and green and woody/floral. The mix is simply great. When I wear this I feel clean and fresh all through the day - and I mean all day because Envy edp is long lasting. More than eight hours on my skin. Sillage is sociable.
The bottle is a monolith - dark glass. So beautiful!
357/365

My first comment in the Parfumo community begins with nostalgia, longing... As far as my memory serves me, the fragrance started cool and gradually became warmer. To me, it was a very appealing green, warm "cozy" scent without being intrusive. I have tested fragrances (Tom Ford vert Bohème, Hermes monsieur Li) that are said to be similar to you, but none could compare - envy I miss you ...

review_title: The big beautiful sister with a quirky character
review_content:
In search of a bright floral, softly green scent, I stumbled upon the Gucci Envy line years ago, equipped with a friend's recommendation to definitely try Envy Me by Gucci.

So I started with the small playful sisters of Envy Eau de Parfum, which I found nice, but they were a bit too "silly" in a positive sense for me. Can a floral scent not also be elegant and seductive, mature? It can! Especially when the "musk ox takes it by the horns" and it is called Envy Eau de Parfum.

As a vanilla addict, I quickly tend to distance myself from a fragrance if at least a hint of vanilla is not used. But now I had found Envy EDP by Gucci, and the vanilla hadn't even been a misstep during its creation. The bottle - pitch black, very elegant - caught my eye immediately.

Consistently, only flowers were used in the heart. There they merge and acquire a slightly lemony note. The iris, jasmine, and powdery magnolia show the hyacinth where its place is, beneath them. By the way, I have the feeling that the woods were indeed used in the top note - rather unusual.

With the warming musk note in the base, the floral slightly lemony core remains seductively on the skin, truly for an eternity. The longevity is superb, without being intrusive. This extravagant quirky scent is wearable for any occasion. My preferred seasons are more spring/summer. In winter, however, please do bring on the beloved vanilla bomb!

I love this scent. I received it as a gift 5 years ago and it is still in my collection today. I am so sad that this fragrance is no longer available for purchase
That's why I don't dare to use too much of it, which is silly because it is very weak and you actually have to overspray
I am still looking for an alternative that is preferably a bit cheaper
To me, it smells like pear, watermelon, and lotus
As if you were sitting in a garden filled with many lotus flowers and eating a plate of juicy pears and watermelon
You can smell the lotus flowers, the watermelon, the pears, and the grass around you
Overall, a beautiful summer scent, I just wish it had better longevity for the price

I love the color green - not without reason did I marry a green-skirted person.

And so my eyes were also drawn to the beautiful green bottle - which doesn’t promise too much, because "green" is the theme in this Gucci collection.

But it’s not our home garden green; instead, long vines dangle before my eyes, with cute little monkeys swinging on them - accompanied by exotic animal sounds.
A toucan flutters by and the colorful parrots tell me something in a foreign language.

No question - I have landed in the tropics.

But there is no steamy heat there - rather a pure cool air.
This is likely due to the flowing aquatic fruits - like pear and watermelon - topped with fresh lemon.
No dark green, sweat-inducing jungle feeling - instead, a gentle breeze blows here.
The exotic flowers appear enchanting - but soft.
Sandalwood embraces you and the cedar has a slightly smoky effect.

A peaceful atmosphere where one likes to linger.

In the jungle, the quiet jungle - the lion sleeps tonight ...

Gucci Flora Emerald Gardenia

Gardenia has captured my heart

It is a very warm, dreamy, and feminine scent!

Imagine you land in a magical garden with many fruit trees and you are eating a sweet pear or watermelon... you are sitting in the soft grass and the sun warms your face... the birds are chirping softly somewhere in the background...
The sweet juice of the ripe fruits explodes in your mouth... it is so ripe and so fruity... all your senses are indulging...
Mmmm... such a sweet and fruity explosion
simply MAGICAL!!

The scent is green-floral - fruity

Applying this fragrance to your hand, you can hear the sweet aroma of ylang-ylang and in the distance a mandarin candy. A very cool combination, somewhere playful and cute. Jasmine, lily of the valley and lilac open in the middle. A very pleasant floral scent, very reminiscent of a summer day when all the flowers begin to smell. As a result, it smells of both moss and wood. It feels like you walked into an old wooden abandoned house covered in moss.

review_title: One doesn't always have to be reasonable
review_content:
It is, of course, a stroke of luck to find a fragrance from 1982 for 45,-- online. It is, of course, unreasonable to order it, as the likelihood that it has not aged gracefully is quite high. Well, sometimes I am unreasonable, and sometimes I just get lucky.

There is nothing to criticize about my splash bottle, and the previous owners probably did not know what a fine fragrance they had. The packaging was still original, but the cellophane was already brittle, yellowed, and shattered like glass. The perfume itself is perfectly fine. Not even the top note shows a hint of fatigue. Since I do not plan to open a fragrance museum and wait until Eau de Gucci Concentree is completely gone, I have decanted the fragrance into a spray bottle, as otherwise, I would simply wear it too infrequently. But now I do so with growing enthusiasm.

On the day of the order, I had not yet looked into the pyramid and actually expected to receive a pure fresh chypre, as I had never encountered it in my professional environment before. The "Eau de.." fragrances from that time are usually unisex, suitable for everyday wear, and occasionally interchangeable. Therefore, I was all the more surprised and delighted that the perfume turned out to be light and summer-appropriate, yet expressive and a floral scent without sweetness and with a rather even rugged progression. Even though no oak moss is listed here, I am not sure if a tiny bit of it was not used after all.

Lilac, jasmine, and violet sound cutely romantic, but I cannot really pin down any of the notes, and the bitter citrus opening leaves no doubt that Eau de Gucci Concentree can be worn unisex, provided the potential wearer is not fixated on oriental, oud, amber, and similar rather heavy fragrance notes. Vetiver and sandalwood keep each other in check in the base, so the fragrance cannot be sorted into one corner or another.

I refrain from falling back into the lament about perfume culture, which is no longer what it used to be. Nevertheless, I enjoy conjuring up the aura of past times with a few spritzes of Eau de Gucci Concentree.

Some may find it pointless or unreasonable to write a comment about a perfume that is hardly available anymore, but - see title - a comment does not necessarily have to drive the sales figures of current perfumes, but simply expand our fragrance horizon. I still enjoy unearthing buried treasures.

Definitely not unisex, this fragrance screams feminine in all its glory!

A rose is a rose, and boys, this is a Queen rose - not a King.
Pure, enchanting sophistication, the hint of dusty Patchouli perfectly balanced on soft, juicy, pinky petals. No pepper, but a veil of musk to envelope in such suave, angelic embrace. It murmurs of that nonchalant sassiness typical of women confident about their place in the world, and consequently, unafraid of their sexual appeal, a charm aquired with each experience.
I don't see a man pulling this off, or a girl. This is a shapely, mature, happy woman in my mind. Smiling to herself, she slowly walks downtown, content and carefree, unaware of others' attention. For she's an indomitable spirit, and time can't change that.
It's a rose, a Queen among Ladies, and she doesn't care.

Such a pity that sillage is not as intense, and longevity only a dream. This would have been my perfect rose.

review_title: Heavenly... This is how I believe angels smell...
review_content:
If I had to choose a single fragrance as the absolute number 1 of the most beautiful scents ever, it would be Gucci Flora 1966... It simply doesn't get more feminine and sensual than this.. A cozy, creamy scent that stays relatively close to the skin..

An indescribable fragrance.. I love bergamot scents but here the bergamot is simply out of this world.. Soft, creamy and a bit powdery.. The other notes, like bourbon pepper, peony, musk, and a hint of patchouli dance subtly in the background and make this scent incredibly beautiful for me...

Unfortunately, the sillage is quite weak on my skin.. Longevity is average... The bottle is deep black, incredibly elegant and beautiful...

Anyone expecting a darkly nuanced scent here will be disappointed. Once you press the sprayer, you are enveloped in a huge load of radiant flowers. At first, you smell a light citrus freshness paired with a hint of vanilla spiciness. The roses mentioned in the fragrance pyramid are immediately present - and they don’t leave. Dominating the scent from start to finish is the peony. In my opinion, the rose garden is accompanied by other floral undertones, but they are very much in the background and hardly noticeable. I'm not entirely sure what it is. Under torture, I would probably guess lily of the valley, but hopefully, that won't happen to me.
The scent development unfolds very slowly - gradually you notice that the fragrance has reached the base: The floral notes still remain, but they no longer radiate as they did at first; instead, they become duller, softer; the scent is at this point only very close to the skin. What I find very pleasant is that the base, despite a woody undertone, comes across as quite fresh. Personally, I don’t like, well, let’s be honest, I HATE it when a floral-fresh scent is suddenly overwhelmed by a tree with a click. Here, everything goes hand in hand, it feels very harmonious.

Overall, this Flora variant is rather understated. Unlike the original Flora, which I find very sweet and striking, it exudes a graceful charm characterized by understatement. Subtle notes that mostly stay close to the skin envelop the wearer in a "just showered" cloud, sometimes appearing a bit cool, but never distant.

At every stage of the scent development, I like the fragrance. An absolute Mari candidate. I really enjoy rose scents - Chloé is one of the fragrances I wear the most. Rosy, fresh, slightly spicy, soft, like just showered - ah! Based on the fragrance pyramid displayed here, I would have guessed this direction as well. However, Gracy Flora reminds me more of the Stella line from Ms. McCartney. I had several Stellas and would buy them again anytime. Nevertheless, I didn’t feel comfortable with FloraGrace. Despite its subtle and elegant character, it annoyed me over time so much that I got headaches from it.
I gifted it to my mom. I really like it on her. (But keep the skin chemistry discussions away from me!) I enjoy it when she wears it and relish from afar the wafting cloud she emits as she glides past me.

Despite the happy ending, it should be mentioned that I don't think the scent is as good as the price suggests. I can't see any difference in quality compared to other Gucci fragrances. Whether Gucci wanted to launch a more exclusive scent similar to Chanel's "Les Exclusifs" line or Armani's Armani Privè fragrances, I don't know. If so: missed the mark. It could be better. For a fragrance in this price category, I expected something more; perhaps my expectations were too high. Maybe the reference to Grace, the beautiful and dearly lost Monegasque, is enough to justify the price. If you can't go to Monaco to wrap yourself in the wealth and beauty of the South of France, you can wrap yourself in this scent. It's still cheaper...

I have once again been reminded that a well-sounding and promising fragrance pyramid resembling other perfumes that one enjoys wearing does not automatically mean that this applies to every scent. One more reason not to make blind purchases anymore.
Whether this fragrance is something for you or not, you will have to find out for yourself. Apparently, it is still available, despite being a limited edition. And well, the Flora-patterned little bag is quite cute...

This is ‘an old woman’s perfume’… if you ask my partner. He does not like aldehydes. And yes, I understand the comparison with Montana’s Parfum de Peau. L’Arte di Gucci EdT and Parfum de Peau have so much in common, when it comes to being late eighties/early nineties fragrances with all the power and ado there is to it. They share jasmine, rose and amber but they also share the leathery/spicy/floral accords. Rich and soapy, long lasting and loud - that is my kind of fragrance (when I am alone).
My nose is simply not skilled enough to make out the many nuances in this wonder, but I can appreciate it, and I can admire the gorgeous bottle. Actually, here is the Arte in L’Arte: the bottle.
I have the one with black top decorated with delicate golden details. I adore the asymmetrical bottle with the most deliciously looking golden juice. I assume that extremely interesting pictures can be and have been taken of this masterpiece. Just look at the photos taken by Parfumo members - this bootle is eye candy, just waiting to be gazed upon. I look forward to the day when I get my hands on the EdP. Then I shall start taking pictures of the two together. They are a handsome couple. And I am looking forward to see how much stronger the EdP can be, because the EdT is, well, really strong.
L’Arte di Gucci EdT offers a journey back in time to my late teens and early twenties. A powerful potion in a marvelous vessel.
Year 2, 120/365

review_title: A Chypre for Non-Chypre Fans / Gucci's Discontinued Masterpiece
review_content:
Once again, this is a fragrance where the name could not have been chosen more aptly.

L'Arte di Gucci, a shy, delicate Chypre mythical creature of modern perfumery from Gucci, that hides away. Not many know it or get to see it.

Its prices are astronomical, and this is not only due to its rarity but also its quality.

A Chypre that breaks conventions and follows its own, modern path.

It impresses with a sparkling, bright aldehydic lightness for a Chypre.
Additionally, it is underscored with floral fruity elements.
Subtle green leathery nuances can also be perceived as it develops.

Somewhat lighter than the EdP, but still expressive.
An elegant fragrance that is also very well suited for more festive occasions or evening events.

The Rembrandt or Picasso among Gucci's fragrances.

I searched for this fragrance for a very long time and had it on my wish list.

Yesterday, it finally happened.
Found the treasure as a 50ml splash.
The joy was immense.

At some point, I also need to get the EdP in the large bottle (even rarer), of which I am lucky to already own 3 minis.

Inquiries among parfumo users have always been denied; no one gives up the black EdP bottle once they have it.

Thus, the search continues for new treasures and masterpieces in the fragrance universe.

review_title: The mistake of Sauvage edt generic
review_content:
tested following a purchase through a sample. This fragrance is really perfect for fall and preparing the transition from summer to winter.

what struck me in this perfume was the presence of an anise smell, it reminds me a little of PDM's Pegasus while being very different. It also reminds me of this slightly aniseed smell of Sauvage Dior in edt but the generic version which in my opinion was a complete failure compared to the original perfume.

nevertheless the discovery of this scent was a pleasant novelty for me. It’s really a perfume that I recommend for all ages, I find it more masculine.

the sillage is honest without being incredible, for longevity count between 5 and 7 hours so it lasts for a day's work.

the price is high, not very accessible but with it you will really have the impression of feeling differently from others.

Whoever names Gucci's fragrances may be a true poet, but the copywriters trample him underfoot. Like an overanalyzed poem in sixth-grade German class, the author has been silenced, and you can't convince me otherwise.

I Loved You At Your Darkest is not only a magnificent album by the Polish death metal band Behemoth, but also a phrase that stems from the Bible. Now, despite numerous quotes on embroidered pillows, the phrase does not actually appear in the holy scripture, but it summarizes Romans 5:8. A dark passage about the death of Jesus Christ, who did not die for humanity because it is worthy, but because it sins. Thus, humanity was at its lowest point and was nevertheless showered with love. The incarnate absolution, if one believes in such a thing. The sacrifice for the unworthy.

It would be a wonderful sacred analogy for the fragrance. The ceremonial incense, the blasphemous pepper, and the wooden cross. My German teacher would be proud of how much meaning I could extract from my nose. Whether the cross was made of cedar is another question. But what does Gucci write on their website? Love seems to shine through the darkness, like a falcon cutting through the sky? Someone really tried hard to invent something profound for the name of the perfume, and I am not a fan. Thank God the scent is better than the missed opportunity for impressive storytelling.

After receiving my sample, I sprayed heretical amounts on my left forearm. Seeing a whole milliliter missing hurt like nails through hands and feet. When I pressed my oversized Silesian nose against my skin, the pepper first revealed itself. Unfortunately, it is by no means as authentic as I know it from "Armani Privé - Bois d'Encens | Giorgio Armani." The pepper is very shy and mild, showing rather the minty facets it can have when freshly ground and is blunt. The incense quickly joins with its ethereal smoke, as if it followed a shining star to the manger. So light and cool that it fits every season and strongly reminds me of "Series 3: Incense - Kyoto | Comme des Garçons." The pepper gives everything a certain depth but remains in the background.
A fleeting sweet side appears briefly, presenting a fleeting floral accord before it suddenly turns into soap, fabric softener, and freshly washed laundry, which I never expected. The perfume seemingly does not know what it wants to be, constantly changing its shape, yet keeps my nose intrigued on the skin. An exciting olfactory cinema, and that was just the first hour!
The actual expectation of the fragrance pyramid only reveals itself with the passage of time. The pepper becomes noticeably sharper, the cedarwood finally shows itself, and out of nowhere comes burnt butter, but probably only because I associate pepper so much with food. Every time I inhale this scent, I smell something new, but it remains consistently smoky-spicy.

If I had to describe it visually, it would be a small stone chapel in the Italian mountains with wooden benches. The door is open, the cold memory of incense lingers in the air. The pastor has hung laundry outside and is grinding black pepper in a mortar because he is making Cacio e Pepe for himself and a few villagers later. Sorry, that's all I can write at the moment.

The fragrance can ideally be worn to confession because it is very close to the skin and, with a bit of luck and God's blessing, would only fill the claustrophobia-inducing confessional. After 5 hours, it is no longer really perceptible, but that should cover a fruitful year of sins until the priest sends us home with forgiveness. Thus, the price of the beautiful bottle is a slap in the face, but I turn the other cheek. Love at Your Darkest is a stunning composition, but will be deemed unworthy for the general public due to its longevity and sillage. I love it nonetheless, because I am so kind.

Gocce di Fiori isn’t too complicated of a fragrance. Actually, it’s pretty darn similar to the original Gucci Bloom, while being a fresh and sheer version of the formulation.

The main difference in terms of the composition, is that the jasmine feels more prevalent here, and there is a honeysuckle note lightly floating around in the mix.

It’s like a stripped down version of Bloom, but one that will serve its purposes as a lighter wear for the spring and summer months.

Upon the first spray of Gocce di Fiori, I pick up a good deal of the jasmine, but blended with the honeysuckle and Rangoon creeper.

However, as it dries down this one becomes more of a jasmine and tuberose fragrance. I still pick up the other two notes, but they are just slight impressions of how they were during the opening act.

It's quite annoying not to be able to get a sample of the scent worldwide; if I were cheeky, I would dismiss it as somewhat arrogant.

According to international reviews, I can expect a masculine vetiver scent during testing, not a Sycomore launch like Chanel, but I’ll let myself be surprised.

In the opening, there are traditional citrus notes, nothing piercing, rather soft and reserved - already here, the impression of being ultra-classic begins. A bit soapy and old-fashioned, we approach the next note, which is dominated by lavender. In my perception, I see scenarios of a Mediterranean landscape before me.
Morning mood, the lavender doesn't want to scent yet because there's too little sun, roses also refuse their flood of senses. So let's wait and see if this restrained morning mood wants to finally give way in the scent.
That restraint... this olfactory restrained morning mood runs through the scent, unfortunately! No note really wants to come forward, everything is so reserved that one is tempted to apply three times to get that hoped-for kick.

I bury myself in my left hand... where is the leather and where is my beloved iris? I can't find them. Already after 15 minutes, vetiver appears, very distinguished and noble. I can only imagine my iris and my leather... let me get my sketch pad :-(

Throughout, vetiver truly dominates, well done no question. Unfortunately, I know only better vetiver scents, and this one does not impress at all.

I find the concept of Gucci Museo a bit too boring. It’s probably just me; I expected a bit more design, Italian joie de vivre - Dolce Vita, but that’s not the case, and I’ll just take note of that.

The addition of Museo should have warned me... there are modern and classic ones, here we encounter an ultra-classic museum. The works are booked for 10 years, no deviation from the exhibition planned, fact!!

Longevity is very good; despite its reserved aura, the scent lasts over 7 hours. The sillage is not really strong and surely won’t negatively stand out to anyone.

Overall impression, short and sweet: too classically composed and completely lacking in statement and ambition. Tradition or not, more could have been made from the notes. This scent would have benefited from a few edges.
For an Italian classic scent, it lacks a variety of fougère notes, this overlay of herbs and fine hesperidic notes, this Cologne style.
So unfortunately, it’s a cool, morning walk in the garden that doesn’t go beyond the restraint.
If I want to wander nostalgically in the garden, then certainly with the best scent ever... Sous le Vent :-)

This fruity fresh floral smells exactly like the bright red artificially flavored fruit punch 'Hawaiian Punch', somewhat similar to Red Fruit Punch Kool-Aid. It is not bad, in its ability to transport me back to the summer of 1977, the backyard, kids and lots of high fructose corn-syrup drinks in the sunshine. It is saved from being totally unwearable by the fact that it is quite sheer and not overly cloying. I couldn't detect the woodiness or level of muskiness that gave the original Rush its naughty reputation as a 'party girl scent'. This is a warm weather frozen white rum punch with juicy non-descript red berries projecting a fruity-tooty youthful splash, strictly for poolside parties and be prepared to be attacked by ants and bees, for sure. While I enjoyed the sniffing experience, I knew almost immediately that I, personally, didn't want to smell like a kid's beverage drink. I also suspect that there is something identical to this available for a fraction of the price in the Demeter Fragrance Library's Tropical Drink Scent section.

Morning forest air. Fresh resinousness. Somewhere in the distance, a few wild roses are blooming. Before you, the last remnants of the campfire from the night before glow. You take a dip in the nearby forest lake. On the shore, you squeeze yourself some orange juice and garnish it with rosemary. You let your thoughts wander and watch the clouds drift by.

This might be my favorite Sorcinelli because it places the classic incense quality in a completely new context: There is nothing sacred or historically heavy anymore-a forest-fresh lightness surrounds everything and you simply feel good. For me, there is not a single disruptive note here. The musk even gives it a subtle creamy powderiness.

Fluffy, light, soft, soothing, yet still alluring-a Sorcinelli for every day. I am completely thrilled.

review_title: The swiftest chop. Anyone else would have missed it
review_content:
Yes, I like all notes of them.
Conclusion: They disappear quickly, so you can't love or hate them.
I'll explain it. It's like sucking delicious lemonade through a 10m straw. The limit of the straw is 10m, and you can definitely smell it, but after about 10 seconds, it smells like an hour has passed since the last scent disappeared. No matter how you look at it, I think this scent is too gentle. The scent is a nice white flower scent, but the scent fades quickly. It feels like sprinkling alcohol on concrete in the hot sun and it evaporates in an instant. I don't recommend it. Perfumes with natural fragrances are difficult. There is a jasmine scent similar to LUST from LUSH, but it may be the same scent because it is a natural fragrance.

review_title: Affordable sweet orange blossom twist of Mugler Alien
review_content:
The opening of Néroli & Petit Grain Printanier is all about sweet mandarine and orange blossom, and the deep, intense, bitter green petitgrain, which together make an intriguing pairing of indolic bittersweet. Surprisingly, about 20 minutes in, the fragrance starts to show a strong jasmine, which makes the whole smells distinctively similar to Mugler Alien layered over the caramelised mandarine undertone of orange blossom.

This Alien impression eventually fades after about 1 hour, and Neroli & Petit Grain Printanier returns to a fluffy orange blossom skin scent until the end. The sillage is moderate to soft, and the longevity is around 5 hours on my skin.

While neroli and petitgrain might lead one to expect a cologne type of fresh, transparent fragrances, Néroli & Petit Grain Printanier actually retains quite some of the natural indolic and sweet aspects of the orange blossom, but is still very approachable and nowhere near as being syrupy or cotton candy-like. I would recommend it as budget-friendly sweet orange blossom or an orange flower twist of Mugler Alien.

The orangey part comes across rather tame. This is not a summer fresh scent; rather, a creamy, white-flower, plant-green, tender aura soon emerges as the true focus, framed by a candy-like, zesty citrus note. As the name addition of the fragrance aptly suggests, it is less summery and more spring-like. The bushiness of the petit grains shows only in hints, yet still represents a charming touch.

I find this overall feminine, in a young-fresh-flirty and very charming way. The pungent aspect of jasmine is sufficient to distinguish the scent from actual skin cream and to emphasize a perfumed quality, but it is not overpowering.

The vanilla remains very subdued. Even by noon, the floral cream is finely tart, and up until the eighth hour, there is always a reliable hint of green present.

Conclusion: A cream scent in the best sense. Unobtrusive and providing a good natural fragrance feeling, yet not flimsy or arbitrary. Perhaps even suitable for girls of that age who are gradually taking their mothers' cosmetic choices seriously. The present candidate offers the possibility of gifting a chemical-free, subtle, and not least beautiful scent that still allows the young ones to feel a certain hint of grown-up-ness.

Everyone else will simply feel comfortable with it.

I thank Bellemorte for the sample.

Neroli & Petit Grain Printanier is a fragrance that starts off very fresh with a light green undertone.

Neroli quickly becomes very prominent and is supported by a woody note. It truly smells like freshly crushed stems.

A few minutes later, the scent turns fruity, with the fruitiness being very concentrated and intense. The neroli scent has nearly disappeared.

After about an hour, Neroli & Petit Grain Printanier reaches the conclusion of its development with a citrus note.

Neroli & Petit Grain Printanier is a lovely spring fragrance that fortunately has nothing to do with 4711 Echt Kölnisch Wasser. It feels very natural. The sillage is good at first but quickly draws back to body closeness. The longevity is very good for a natural fragrance, lasting seven hours.
